  • Negative rapid flu test doesn't rule out influenza: RIDT sensitivity only 50-70%. If high clinical suspicion, send PCR and treat empirically
  • Primary viral pneumonia can cause ARDS rapidly: Young, healthy patients can deteriorate quickly (24-72hr). Early ICU transfer and aggressive respiratory support
  • Procalcitonin helps guide antibiotics: Low PCT (<0.25) = viral. High PCT (>0.5) = bacterial co-infection. Can help avoid unnecessary antibiotics
  • Influenza myocarditis is underrecognized: Check troponin in severe cases, especially with chest pain or arrhythmias. Can cause acute heart failure
  • Zanamivir is inhaled - avoid in lung disease: Can cause bronchospasm in asthma/COPD patients. Use oseltamivir instead
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Hypoxemic respiratory failure (Oâ‚‚ sat <90% despite supplemental Oâ‚‚)
  • Need for HFNC, NIPPV, or mechanical ventilation
  • Septic shock (hypotension requiring vasopressors)
  • ARDS (P/F ratio <300)
  • Altered mental status, encephalopathy
  • Lactic acidosis (lactate >4mmol/L)
  • Rapid clinical deterioration despite therapy
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Afebrile â‰¥24hr without antipyretics
  • Oâ‚‚ sat â‰¥90% on room air (or back to baseline if chronic lung disease)
  • Respiratory rate <24/min at rest
  • Tolerating PO intake and medications
  • Completed 5-day course of oseltamivir (or at least 48hr and improving)
  • No evidence of bacterial superinfection (or completed appropriate antibiotic course)
  • Able to perform ADLs or return to baseline function
  • Follow-up arranged (PCP within 1 week)
COMPLICATIONS TO MONITOR

Acute: Primary viral pneumonia â†’ ARDS (P/F <200, high mortality), secondary bacterial pneumonia (S. aureus, S. pneumoniae - most common), septic shock, myocarditis (troponin elevation, arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock), rhabdomyolysis (CK >10,000, AKI), encephalitis/encephalopathy (altered mental status, seizures, especially children), exacerbation of underlying conditions (asthma, COPD, heart failure)

Chronic: Post-viral chronic cough (weeks-months), persistent fatigue, prolonged recovery in elderly/frail patients, cardiovascular events (MI, stroke in first 2 weeks post-infection - 3-5x increased risk)

Prevention: Annual influenza vaccine (inactivated or live attenuated). Highest priority: healthcare workers, elderly, chronic disease, pregnant women, young children. Vaccine reduces risk of hospitalization by 40-60%. Post-exposure prophylaxis with oseltamivir 75mg daily Ã— 10 days for high-risk unvaccinated contacts

â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

57. COVID-19 SEVERE DISEASE

SARS-CoV-2 â€¢ Viral Pneumonia â†’ ARDS â€¢ Dexamethasone + Supportive Care
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Disease Severity Classification (NIH):

  • Mild: Any symptoms (fever, cough, fatigue) without dyspnea or abnormal imaging
  • Moderate: Evidence of lower respiratory disease (clinical or imaging) + Oâ‚‚ sat â‰¥94% on room air
  • SEVERE: Oâ‚‚ sat <94% on room air, P/F ratio <300, RR >30/min, or lung infiltrates >50%
  • CRITICAL: Respiratory failure (requiring mechanical ventilation, HFNC, NIPPV), septic shock, multiorgan dysfunction

Severe/Critical COVID-19 Presentation:

  • Respiratory: Progressive dyspnea (typically 5-10 days after symptom onset), tachypnea (RR >30/min), hypoxemia (Oâ‚‚ sat <94%), increased work of breathing, bilateral pneumonia
  • Systemic: Persistent fever, fatigue, myalgias, anorexia
  • GI: Diarrhea (20-30%), nausea, abdominal pain
  • Neurologic: Confusion, delirium, headache, anosmia/ageusia (loss of smell/taste)
  • Thromboembolic: DVT, PE, stroke, MI (hypercoagulable state)

High-Risk Groups (for Severe Disease):

  • Age: â‰¥65 years (risk increases exponentially with age)
  • Chronic conditions: Obesity (BMI â‰¥30), diabetes, hypertension, cardiovascular disease, chronic lung disease (COPD, asthma), chronic kidney disease, liver disease
  • Immunocompromised: Solid organ transplant, hematologic malignancy, chemotherapy, HIV (CD4 <200), chronic high-dose steroids (â‰¥20mg prednisone daily), immunosuppressive medications
  • Pregnancy: Increased risk of severe disease, preterm birth, ICU admission
  • Other: Smoking, sickle cell disease, Down syndrome, neurologic conditions, tuberculosis

Typical Timeline: Symptom onset (day 0) â†’ fever/cough/fatigue (days 1-4) â†’ hypoxemia/dyspnea (days 5-8) â†’ ARDS/critical illness (days 8-12) â†’ recovery or multiorgan failure (weeks 2-4+)

Key Features Distinguishing COVID-19 ARDS: "Silent hypoxemia" (profound hypoxemia with minimal dyspnea), preserved lung compliance early, hypercoagulability (elevated D-dimer), inflammatory cytokine storm (elevated CRP, ferritin, IL-6)

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

SARS-CoV-2 Testing:

  • Nucleic acid amplification (NAAT/PCR): GOLD STANDARD. Nasopharyngeal swab. Sensitivity 80-90%. Detects active infection
  • Rapid antigen test: Results in 15-30min. Sensitivity 60-80% (lower than PCR). Best within first 5-7 days of symptoms. False negatives common
  • Timing: Test all hospitalized patients with respiratory symptoms. PCR preferred. Antigen OK for screening, but confirm negatives with PCR if high suspicion
  • Repeat testing: If initial negative but high suspicion, repeat in 24-48hr or send lower respiratory sample (sputum, BAL)

Labs (for Severity Assessment & Prognostication):

  • CBC: Lymphopenia (common, correlates with severity), thrombocytopenia (severe disease)
  • CMP: BUN/Cr (AKI in 20-40% of hospitalized), transaminitis (ALT/AST elevation), hypoalbuminemia (poor prognosis)
  • Inflammatory markers: CRP, ferritin, LDH (elevated in severe disease, correlate with mortality), IL-6 (if available - very high in cytokine storm)
  • D-dimer: Elevated in >70% of severe cases. Markedly elevated (>5,000ng/mL) = poor prognosis, high VTE risk
  • Procalcitonin: Usually low-normal in viral infection. Elevation suggests bacterial superinfection
  • Troponin: Elevated in 20-30% of hospitalized patients (myocardial injury, myocarditis). Associated with increased mortality
  • BNP: If heart failure suspected (COVID-19 can precipitate HF)

Imaging:

  • CXR: Bilateral patchy infiltrates, consolidation, ground-glass opacities. Peripheral distribution. Normal CXR does NOT exclude COVID-19 pneumonia
  • CT chest: More sensitive. Bilateral ground-glass opacities (GGO) with peripheral distribution, "crazy-paving" pattern, consolidation. Useful if CXR nondiagnostic. CT not needed for diagnosis/management in typical cases

ABG: Assess P/F ratio if hypoxemic. <300 = ARDS. A-a gradient typically elevated

Other Testing (as indicated):

  • ECG: If chest pain, troponin elevation (check for STEMI, arrhythmias, myocarditis)
  • Blood cultures: If bacterial superinfection suspected
  • Respiratory viral panel: Rule out co-infections (influenza, RSV) if early in illness
  • VTE workup: CT-PE if high suspicion (tachycardia, hypoxemia out of proportion to lung findings, elevated D-dimer >5,000)

Poor Prognostic Indicators: Age >65, oxygen requirement, elevated inflammatory markers (CRP >100mg/L, D-dimer >5,000ng/mL, ferritin >1,000ng/mL, LDH >400U/L), lymphopenia (<800/ÂµL), thrombocytopenia, AKI, troponin elevation, obesity (BMI â‰¥35)

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Corticosteroids (PROVEN MORTALITY BENEFIT - MAINSTAY):

  • Dexamethasone 6mg IV/PO daily Ã— 10 days (or until discharge): RECOVERY trial showed 30% reduction in mortality at 28 days in patients requiring oxygen. Number needed to treat = 8 (for supplemental Oâ‚‚), 4 (for mechanical ventilation)
  • Alternatives (if dexamethasone unavailable): Prednisone 40mg daily, methylprednisolone 32mg daily, hydrocortisone 160mg daily (divided doses)
  • Who to treat: ALL patients requiring supplemental oxygen or mechanical ventilation
  • Who NOT to treat: Mild COVID-19 not requiring oxygen (may cause harm)
  • Duration: 10 days or until discharge (whichever comes first). Can stop earlier if no longer requiring oxygen

Antiviral Therapy:

  • Remdesivir (Veklury): 200mg IV loading dose, then 100mg IV daily Ã— 4 days (total 5 days). Modest benefit - reduces time to recovery by 5 days in hospitalized patients requiring oxygen (not ventilated). Consider in severe COVID-19 within 10 days of symptom onset. Less effective in mechanically ventilated patients. NOT a mortality benefit drug
  • Timing: Start within 10 days of symptom onset for maximum benefit
  • Contraindications: eGFR <30mL/min, ALT >10Ã— ULN. Use cautiously if eGFR 30-60
  • Note: Other antivirals (nirmatrelvir-ritonavir/Paxlovid, molnupiravir) are for OUTPATIENTS only (within 5 days of symptoms). NOT for hospitalized patients with severe disease

IL-6 Receptor Antagonists (Anti-Cytokine Therapy):

  • Tocilizumab (Actemra) 8mg/kg IV once (max 800mg): Consider in patients with rapidly increasing oxygen requirements, CRP >75mg/L, within 24hr of ICU admission. Reduces mortality in severe/critical COVID-19 when combined with dexamethasone
  • Baricitinib (Olumiant) 4mg PO daily Ã— 14 days: JAK inhibitor. Alternative to tocilizumab. Reduces mortality when combined with dexamethasone. Easier administration (oral). Contraindicated if ALC <200/ÂµL, ANC <500/ÂµL
  • Use ONE (not both): Tocilizumab OR baricitinib, in combination with dexamethasone
  • Screen for infections: Before use, rule out active bacterial/fungal infections

Respiratory Support:

  • Supplemental oxygen: Target Oâ‚‚ sat 92-96% (or 88-92% if COPD). Start with nasal cannula
  • High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC): 40-60L/min, FiOâ‚‚ 0.4-1.0. Effective in preventing intubation in many patients. ROX index (SpOâ‚‚/FiOâ‚‚ Ã— RR) <3.85 after 12hr = high risk of HFNC failure
  • Prone positioning (AWAKE PRONING): Patient prone for 2-4hr several times daily while on HFNC. Improves oxygenation, may prevent intubation
  • NIPPV (BiPAP/CPAP): Use cautiously (risk of aerosolization, delayed intubation). Consider in select patients who decline intubation or as bridge
  • Mechanical ventilation: Intubate if worsening hypoxemia (P/F <150), work of breathing, or altered mental status. LUNG-PROTECTIVE VENTILATION: TV 6mL/kg IBW, plateau pressure <30cmHâ‚‚O, PEEP 10-15cmHâ‚‚O (higher PEEP in COVID-19), driving pressure <15cmHâ‚‚O
  • Prone positioning (INTUBATED): For P/F <150 (moderate-severe ARDS). 16hr prone daily. Improves mortality
  • ECMO: Consider for refractory hypoxemia despite maximal support. Transfer to ECMO center

Anticoagulation (CRITICAL - Hypercoagulable State):

  • Prophylactic anticoagulation: ALL hospitalized patients unless contraindicated. Enoxaparin 40mg SQ daily (preferred) or heparin 5000 units SQ TID. Consider higher prophylactic dose (enoxaparin 0.5mg/kg BID) if BMI >40 or D-dimer >5,000
  • Therapeutic anticoagulation: If confirmed VTE (PE, DVT). NOT routinely for all severe COVID-19 patients (trials showed no benefit, increased bleeding in non-ICU patients)
  • Monitor D-dimer: Trending D-dimer useful. Persistently elevated or rising = higher VTE risk
  • Low threshold for CT-PE: If worsening hypoxemia, tachycardia, elevated D-dimer

Antibiotics (for Bacterial Superinfection ONLY):

  • When to add: Clinical worsening after 7-10 days, new fever, leukocytosis, procalcitonin >0.5, positive bacterial cultures, lobar consolidation (new or worsening)
  • Initial therapy: Ceftriaxone 1-2g IV daily + azithromycin 500mg IV daily (community-acquired pneumonia coverage). Consider vancomycin if MRSA risk (ICU, prior MRSA, necrotizing pneumonia)
  • De-escalate: Stop antibiotics if procalcitonin <0.25 and no bacterial source identified. COVID-19 itself does NOT require antibiotics
  • Bacterial co-infection uncommon: Only 8-15% of hospitalized COVID-19 patients have bacterial co-infection. Secondary bacterial pneumonia more common after 7-10 days (S. aureus, Pseudomonas, Enterobacterales)

Supportive Care:

  • Fluids: Conservative fluid strategy (avoid fluid overload - worsens ARDS). Target euvolemia. Use vasopressors early if shock
  • Vasopressors: Norepinephrine first-line for shock. Target MAP â‰¥65mmHg
  • Sedation/analgesia: Light sedation if mechanically ventilated (target RASS -1 to 0). Daily sedation interruption
  • Neuromuscular blockade: Consider in severe ARDS (P/F <150) with ventilator dyssynchrony. Time-limited (â‰¤48hr). Increased risk of ICU weakness
  • Nutrition: Early enteral nutrition (within 48hr). NG/NJ tube if unable to tolerate PO
  • Stress ulcer prophylaxis: PPI for mechanically ventilated patients
  • Glycemic control: Target glucose 140-180mg/dL (avoid hypoglycemia). Hyperglycemia common with dexamethasone

Therapies NO LONGER RECOMMENDED (Ineffective or Harmful):

  • Hydroxychloroquine: NO benefit. DO NOT USE
  • Ivermectin: NO benefit. DO NOT USE
  • Convalescent plasma: NO mortality benefit. Not recommended
  • Vitamin C, vitamin D, zinc: No proven benefit in treatment (prevention data mixed)
  • Azithromycin alone: NO antiviral effect. Only use if bacterial superinfection

Infection Control:

  • Airborne + contact precautions: N95 respirator, gown, gloves, eye protection for all healthcare workers
  • Negative pressure room: Preferred for hospitalized patients, especially if aerosol-generating procedures
  • Duration of isolation: â‰¥10 days from symptom onset AND â‰¥24hr afebrile without antipyretics AND improvement in symptoms. Immunocompromised: â‰¥20 days (or negative PCR). Consult infection control
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Dexamethasone saves lives in severe COVID-19: 30% mortality reduction if requiring oxygen. Give to ALL patients on Oâ‚‚. Don't give to mild cases not requiring Oâ‚‚
  • "Silent hypoxemia" is real: Patients can have Oâ‚‚ sat 70-80% with minimal dyspnea. Check pulse ox on ALL suspected COVID-19 patients
  • Timing matters for progression: Most patients who worsen do so around days 7-10. Close monitoring during this window
  • COVID-19 is a hypercoagulable state: Elevated D-dimer in 70%. High VTE risk (10-30%). Low threshold for CT-PE. Prophylactic anticoagulation for all hospitalized patients
  • Bacterial co-infection is uncommon: Only 8-15% at admission. Don't reflexively start antibiotics. Check procalcitonin. Stop if <0.25 and no bacterial source
  • Awake proning works: Have patients on HFNC lie prone 2-4hr multiple times daily. Improves oxygenation and may prevent intubation
  • Most antivirals don't work in severe disease: Remdesivir has modest benefit. Paxlovid is for OUTPATIENTS only (within 5 days). Dexamethasone is the most important drug
  • Avoid fluid overload: COVID-19 ARDS - keep patients dry. Aggressive fluids worsen respiratory status. Use vasopressors early if needed
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Oâ‚‚ sat <90% despite supplemental Oâ‚‚ >6L/min
  • Need for HFNC, NIPPV, or mechanical ventilation
  • Rapidly increasing oxygen requirements (>2L/hr escalation)
  • RR >30/min with accessory muscle use
  • Altered mental status, confusion, obtundation
  • Septic shock (hypotension requiring vasopressors)
  • P/F ratio <200
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Oâ‚‚ sat â‰¥92% on room air at rest and with ambulation (or baseline if chronic lung disease)
  • Afebrile â‰¥24hr without antipyretics
  • Respiratory rate <24/min at rest
  • Clinical improvement (resolving symptoms)
  • Completed minimum 5 days of treatment (dexamethasone)
  • Able to perform ADLs independently
  • Adequate home support, especially if elderly/high-risk
  • Follow-up arranged (telehealth or in-person within 3-7 days)
  • Pulse oximeter for home monitoring if marginal Oâ‚‚ sats
COMPLICATIONS TO MONITOR

Acute (During Hospitalization): ARDS (20-40% of hospitalized patients, high mortality), secondary bacterial/fungal infections (aspergillosis, candidemia after prolonged steroids/ICU stay), thromboembolic disease (PE, DVT, stroke, MI - 10-30% incidence), acute kidney injury (20-40%, poor prognosis), myocardial injury (troponin elevation, myocarditis, stress cardiomyopathy), arrhythmias, shock (septic, cardiogenic), multiorgan failure

Subacute/Chronic (Post-Discharge): Post-COVID syndrome/"Long COVID" (30% of hospitalized patients - fatigue, dyspnea, cognitive impairment, lasting months), pulmonary fibrosis (after severe ARDS), chronic thromboembolic disease, persistent cardiac dysfunction (reduced EF, myocarditis sequelae), post-ICU syndrome (weakness, PTSD, depression), organizing pneumonia (can occur weeks post-infection)

Follow-up: All hospitalized patients should have follow-up within 1-2 weeks post-discharge. Assess for persistent symptoms, oxygen needs, functional status. Chest imaging (CXR or CT) at 4-12 weeks if severe disease or persistent symptoms. Pulmonary function testing if dyspnea persists. Consider post-COVID clinic referral for prolonged symptoms

â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

58. SKIN/SOFT TISSUE INFECTIONS (CELLULITIS, NECROTIZING FASCIITIS)

Bacterial Skin Infection â€¢ Cellulitis vs Necrotizing â€¢ Early Surgery Saves Lives
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Cellulitis (Non-Necrotizing SSTI): Acute bacterial infection of dermis and subcutaneous tissue. Characterized by erythema, warmth, swelling, tenderness. Usually unilateral lower extremity

Cellulitis Presentation:

  • Erythema: Red, poorly demarcated area. Spreads centrifugally from entry site
  • Warmth: Affected area warm to touch compared to surrounding skin
  • Swelling: Edema of affected limb. May have peau d'orange appearance
  • Tenderness: Pain with palpation. Pain usually proportionate to appearance
  • Systemic symptoms (50%): Fever, chills, malaise. More common in severe cases
  • Regional lymphadenopathy: Inguinal nodes (lower extremity cellulitis), axillary nodes (upper extremity)
  • Lymphangitis (30%): Red linear streaking from site toward regional lymph nodes

Common Sites: Lower extremities (60-70%), upper extremities (20%), face (5-10%), trunk (rare). Look for portal of entry (trauma, insect bite, tinea pedis, chronic venous insufficiency, lymphedema)

Risk Factors for Cellulitis: Tinea pedis (athlete's foot - toe web spaces), venous insufficiency, lymphedema (prior surgery, radiation), obesity, diabetes, peripheral vascular disease, chronic kidney disease, immunosuppression, IV drug use, prior cellulitis (recurrence rate 20-30%)

NECROTIZING SOFT TISSUE INFECTIONS (SURGICAL EMERGENCY):

  • Necrotizing Fasciitis (NF): Rapidly progressive infection of fascia and subcutaneous tissue with necrosis. High mortality (20-30%). REQUIRES URGENT SURGICAL DEBRIDEMENT
  • Type I NF (Polymicrobial, 70-80%): Mixed aerobic + anaerobic bacteria (Streptococcus, E. coli, Bacteroides, Clostridium). Risk factors: diabetes, peripheral vascular disease, obesity, immunocompromised. Often post-surgical, perineal (Fournier's gangrene)
  • Type II NF (Monomicrobial, 20-30%): Group A Streptococcus (Strep pyogenes) OR Staphylococcus aureus (including CA-MRSA). Younger, healthier patients. Post-trauma, varicella, NSAIDs use

RED FLAGS for Necrotizing Fasciitis (Think NF!):

  • Severe pain OUT OF PROPORTION to physical findings: CLASSIC. Severe pain but skin may look relatively benign initially
  • Rapidly progressive erythema/swelling: Spreads within hours, not days
  • Systemic toxicity: High fever, tachycardia (HR >120), hypotension, altered mental status, septic shock
  • Skin changes (LATE findings): Dusky/purple discoloration, hemorrhagic bullae (blood-filled blisters), crepitus (gas in soft tissue), skin necrosis, anesthesia (nerve involvement)
  • Wooden hard induration: Firm, boardlike feel to subcutaneous tissue
  • Gas on imaging: Crepitus on exam or gas in soft tissue on X-ray/CT
  • Lab abnormalities: WBC >15,000, lactate >4, Cr elevated, CK elevated (myonecrosis), severe metabolic acidosis, thrombocytopenia

LRINEC Score (Laboratory Risk Indicator for Necrotizing Fasciitis): CRP â‰¥150mg/L (4 pts), WBC <15 or >25K (1-2 pts), Hgb <11g/dL (2 pts), Na <135mEq/L (2 pts), Cr >1.6mg/dL (2 pts), glucose >180mg/dL (1 pt). Score â‰¥6 = intermediate risk (50% PPV), â‰¥8 = high risk (75% PPV) for NF. HOWEVER: Clinical suspicion trumps score. Don't delay surgery for scoring

Other Necrotizing Infections:

  • Fournier's Gangrene: Necrotizing fasciitis of perineum/genitalia. Diabetics, elderly men. Polymicrobial. Extremely high mortality (20-40%)
  • Clostridial Myonecrosis (Gas Gangrene): Clostridium perfringens. Post-trauma (crush injury), post-surgical, spontaneous (malignancy, immunocompromised). Crepitus, serosanguinous discharge, rapid progression. Very high mortality
  • Streptococcal Toxic Shock Syndrome (STSS): Group A Strep with necrotizing fasciitis + shock + multiorgan failure. Mortality >30%

Common Pathogens by Infection Type:

  • Non-purulent cellulitis: Î²-hemolytic Streptococcus (Group A, C, G most common), S. aureus (less common)
  • Purulent cellulitis (abscess): S. aureus (including MRSA)
  • Water exposure: Vibrio vulnificus (seawater), Aeromonas (freshwater)
  • Animal bites: Pasteurella (cats/dogs), Capnocytophaga (dogs), Eikenella (human bites)
  • Immunocompromised: Pseudomonas, fungal (Mucor, Rhizopus)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical Diagnosis (Cellulitis): Diagnosis is clinical based on characteristic findings (erythema, warmth, swelling, tenderness). Imaging and lab tests NOT routinely needed for uncomplicated cellulitis

Labs (for Severe or Complicated Infections):

  • CBC: Leukocytosis (WBC >15,000 suggests severe infection or necrotizing process). Bandemia (left shift). Thrombocytopenia (in sepsis, necrotizing infection)
  • CMP: BUN/Cr (assess renal function, AKI in sepsis), glucose (hyperglycemia in stress/infection, especially diabetes)
  • CRP: Elevated in bacterial infection. CRP >150mg/L increases suspicion for necrotizing infection (LRINEC score component)
  • CK: Markedly elevated (>1,000) suggests myonecrosis (muscle involvement). Concerning for clostridial myonecrosis or necrotizing infection
  • Lactate: >2mmol/L suggests hypoperfusion. >4mmol/L = severe sepsis. Associated with necrotizing infection
  • Blood cultures: Obtain in: fever + systemic toxicity, immunocompromised, diabetic with severe infection, suspected necrotizing infection, hemodynamic instability. Positive in only 5-10% of cellulitis cases

Microbiology (Limited Role in Cellulitis):

  • Blood cultures: Low yield (5-10%) in uncomplicated cellulitis. Obtain if septic, immunocompromised, or severe infection
  • Wound culture: Only if purulent drainage present (abscess). Swab of intact skin NOT useful (contaminated). Aspirate of abscess preferred
  • Tissue biopsy/culture: Reserved for: (1) Failed empiric therapy, (2) Immunocompromised (atypical organisms), (3) Surgical debridement (send tissue for culture)

Imaging:

  • Plain X-ray: Limited utility. Can detect gas in soft tissue (crepitus), foreign body, osteomyelitis (if concern for bone involvement). ALWAYS obtain if crepitus present
  • Ultrasound: Can differentiate cellulitis from abscess (hypoechoic fluid collection). Useful at bedside. "Cobblestoning" pattern suggests abscess. Can guide drainage
  • CT with IV contrast: GOLD STANDARD for necrotizing infections. Obtain urgently if high suspicion for NF. Findings: gas in fascial planes, fascial thickening, fluid tracking along fascial planes, lack of enhancement (necrosis), muscle involvement
  • MRI: Most sensitive for soft tissue infections. Can differentiate cellulitis, abscess, necrotizing fasciitis, myositis. Useful for deep infections, spinal/pelvic infections. NOT needed for routine cellulitis. Too slow if suspecting NF (do CT, then OR)

When to Image:

  • URGENT CT (within 1-2hr): Suspected necrotizing fasciitis (pain out of proportion, crepitus, skin necrosis, septic shock, LRINEC â‰¥6)
  • Ultrasound: Suspected abscess (fluctuance, purulent drainage). Guide I&D
  • X-ray: Crepitus on exam, foreign body, suspected osteomyelitis (bone tenderness, chronic wound)
  • NO imaging needed: Uncomplicated cellulitis with clear diagnosis, no red flags

Surgical Exploration (Diagnostic & Therapeutic): If high suspicion for NF but CT equivocal, proceed to OR for direct visualization. "Finger test" - blunt dissection along fascial planes. In NF, fascia separates easily ("dishwater" fluid, necrotic tissue, lack of bleeding). Don't delay surgery waiting for imaging

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

CELLULITIS (Non-Necrotizing) Management:

Non-Purulent Cellulitis (No Abscess):

  • Mild (outpatient): Cephalexin 500mg PO QID Ã— 5-7 days OR Dicloxacillin 500mg PO QID OR Cefadroxil 1g PO BID
  • Moderate-Severe (hospitalized, no MRSA risk):
    • Cefazolin 1-2g IV q8hr: First-line. Excellent Strep/MSSA coverage
    • Alternatives: Nafcillin 1-2g IV q4-6hr, Oxacillin 1-2g IV q4-6hr
    • Penicillin allergy (non-anaphylactic): Ceftriaxone 1-2g IV daily (low cross-reactivity)
    • Penicillin anaphylaxis: Clindamycin 600-900mg IV q8hr OR Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12hr

MRSA Risk Factors: Prior MRSA infection, injection drug use, incarceration, close contact with MRSA-infected person, purulent drainage, abscess

Purulent Cellulitis/Abscess OR MRSA Risk:

  • Abscess management: Incision & drainage (I&D) is PRIMARY treatment. Antibiotics are ADJUNCT if surrounding cellulitis or systemic symptoms
  • Empiric MRSA coverage (if systemic symptoms or extensive cellulitis):
    • Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12hr (target trough 15-20): First-line IV MRSA coverage
    • Alternatives: Linezolid 600mg IV/PO q12hr, Daptomycin 4-6mg/kg IV daily (NOT for pneumonia), Ceftaroline 600mg IV q12hr
  • Outpatient MRSA coverage (mild purulent cellulitis post-I&D): TMP-SMX 1-2 DS PO BID + Cephalexin 500mg QID (for Strep coverage) OR Doxycycline 100mg PO BID OR Clindamycin 300-450mg PO TID

NECROTIZING FASCIITIS Management (SURGICAL EMERGENCY):

Step 1: URGENT SURGICAL CONSULTATION (STAT): Surgery is LIFE-SAVING. Time to OR directly correlates with mortality. Goal: debridement within 6 hours of diagnosis. "Time is tissue, tissue is life"

Step 2: Aggressive Resuscitation & Support:

  • IV fluids: 30mL/kg crystalloid bolus (NS or LR) within first hour. Continue aggressive fluid resuscitation. May need 4-10L in first 24hr
  • Vasopressors: Norepinephrine if hypotensive despite fluids. Target MAP â‰¥65mmHg
  • ICU admission: ALL suspected/confirmed NF patients
  • Blood cultures: 2 sets before antibiotics
  • Lactate: Follow serial lactates q2-4hr. Goal: lactate clearance (normalize within 6hr)

Step 3: BROAD-SPECTRUM Antibiotics (Start IMMEDIATELY, before OR):

  • Empiric Regimen for Necrotizing Fasciitis:
    • Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12hr (for MRSA, Strep)
    • PLUS Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6hr (broad Gram-neg, anaerobic coverage)
    • PLUS Clindamycin 600-900mg IV q8hr (CRITICAL - stops toxin production in Group A Strep, covers anaerobes, penetrates necrotic tissue)
  • Alternative regimens:
    • Vancomycin + Meropenem 1g IV q8hr + Clindamycin (if severe sepsis, immunocompromised)
    • Vancomycin + Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily + Metronidazole 500mg IV q8hr + Clindamycin
  • If Clostridial myonecrosis suspected (gas gangrene):
    • Penicillin G 4 million units IV q4hr + Clindamycin 900mg IV q8hr
    • Consider hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) if available (controversial, delays surgery)

Step 4: Surgical Debridement (URGENT):

  • Aggressive wide debridement: Remove ALL necrotic tissue, fascia, muscle. May require multiple trips to OR (second-look within 24-48hr). Debride until healthy bleeding tissue
  • Amputation: May be necessary for limb salvage if extensive involvement or refractory sepsis
  • Fournier's gangrene: Debride perineum, scrotum. Diverting colostomy if rectal involvement
  • Negative pressure wound therapy (VAC): After debridement. Promotes healing, facilitates subsequent closures

Step 5: Adjunctive Therapies (for Streptococcal Toxic Shock):

  • IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin) 1-2g/kg IV once: Consider in Group A Strep NF with toxic shock syndrome. Neutralizes streptococcal superantigens. May reduce mortality (controversial, limited data)
  • Clindamycin is ESSENTIAL: Inhibits toxin production (unlike Î²-lactams which increase toxin release as bacteria lyse)

Duration of Antibiotics:

  • Uncomplicated cellulitis: 5-7 days (or until clinical improvement + afebrile 48hr)
  • Severe cellulitis: 7-10 days
  • Necrotizing fasciitis: 10-14 days (or longer until all necrotic tissue debrided and clinically improving)

Supportive Care for Cellulitis:

  • Elevation: Elevate affected limb above heart level. Reduces edema, improves lymphatic drainage
  • Mark borders: Outline erythema with marker to track progression/improvement
  • Analgesia: NSAIDs (ibuprofen 400-600mg PO q6-8hr) or acetaminophen 650-1000mg q6hr. Avoid NSAIDs in Group A Strep (theoretical increased risk of NF progression - controversial)
  • Treat predisposing conditions: Tinea pedis (antifungal cream), venous stasis (compression), edema (diuretics if CHF), optimize diabetes control
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Pain out of proportion = necrotizing fasciitis until proven otherwise: Don't be fooled by benign-appearing skin. Severe pain with minimal skin findings is CLASSIC for NF. Call surgery immediately
  • Crepitus = gas in tissue = EMERGENCY: Crepitus (crackling feel) on palpation indicates gas-forming organisms (Clostridium, Streptococcus, polymicrobial NF). Get imaging (X-ray or CT) and call surgery STAT
  • Time to OR = survival in NF: Mortality increases 7-9% for every hour delay to surgery. Don't wait for CT if high clinical suspicion. "Stabilize in the OR, not the ICU"
  • Clindamycin is critical in Group A Strep NF: Stops toxin production (Î²-lactams don't). Add clindamycin to all suspected NF empiric regimens
  • Most cellulitis is streptococcal, not MRSA: Non-purulent cellulitis without risk factors â†’ don't need MRSA coverage. Cefazolin is appropriate. Reserve vancomycin for purulent infections or MRSA risk factors
  • Blood cultures are low-yield in cellulitis: Only 5-10% positive. Reserve for severe cases, sepsis, immunocompromised
  • Abscess = I&D, not just antibiotics: Antibiotics don't penetrate abscesses well. I&D is primary treatment. Antibiotics only needed if surrounding cellulitis or systemic symptoms
  • LRINEC score helps but don't rely on it: Score â‰¥6 raises suspicion for NF. But NF can occur with low scores. Clinical gestalt and imaging trump the score
  • Treat the source: Tinea pedis (athlete's foot) is the most common portal of entry for lower extremity cellulitis. Treat with topical antifungals to prevent recurrence
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • ANY suspicion for necrotizing fasciitis
  • Septic shock (hypotension requiring vasopressors)
  • Severe pain out of proportion to exam findings
  • Skin necrosis, hemorrhagic bullae, crepitus
  • Lactate >4mmol/L
  • Altered mental status, confusion
  • WBC >25,000 or <4,000
  • Rapidly progressive erythema (spreading over hours)
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Afebrile â‰¥24hr without antipyretics
  • Erythema improving (use marked borders to track)
  • Decreased swelling and tenderness
  • Able to ambulate (if lower extremity)
  • Tolerating PO antibiotics
  • Appropriate outpatient antibiotic regimen selected
  • Source control achieved (abscess drained, if applicable)
  • Follow-up arranged (PCP or ID within 3-5 days)
  • Patient educated on warning signs (worsening erythema, fever, systemic symptoms)
  • Predisposing factors addressed (tinea pedis treatment, wound care)
COMPLICATIONS TO MONITOR

Cellulitis Complications: Abscess formation (requires I&D), bacteremia/sepsis (5-10%), lymphangitis (ascending infection toward lymph nodes), recurrent cellulitis (20-30% within 3 years - higher if lymphedema, chronic venous insufficiency, or tinea pedis not treated), chronic lymphedema (from repeated episodes damaging lymphatics), post-cellulitis venous thrombosis (thrombophlebitis)

Necrotizing Fasciitis Complications: Septic shock (30-50%, high mortality), multiorgan failure (renal, respiratory, cardiac), limb loss (amputation needed in 20-30%), extensive scarring/disfigurement, chronic pain (neuropathic from nerve damage), functional impairment (prolonged rehabilitation), mortality (overall 20-30%, up to 50% if shock, 70-80% if clostridial myonecrosis)

Prevention of Recurrent Cellulitis: Treat tinea pedis aggressively (topical or oral antifungals - terbinafine 250mg daily Ã— 2-4 weeks), compression stockings for venous insufficiency/lymphedema, elevate legs regularly, emollients for dry/cracked skin, prompt treatment of skin injuries/wounds, consider antibiotic prophylaxis if â‰¥3 episodes per year (penicillin VK 250-500mg daily OR erythromycin 250mg daily)

ðŸ“– Drug Reference: ðŸ’Š Vancomycin, ðŸ’Š Cefazolin, ðŸ’Š Doxycycline
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

59. TUBERCULOSIS (ACTIVE DISEASE)

Mycobacterium tuberculosis â€¢ Pulmonary + Extrapulmonary â€¢ Multi-Drug Regimen â€¢ Airborne Isolation
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Tuberculosis (TB) Overview: Infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Transmitted via airborne droplets. Can affect lungs (pulmonary TB, 80-85%) or other organs (extrapulmonary TB, 15-20%). Highly contagious. Public health emergency requiring isolation and reporting

Latent TB vs Active TB:

  • Latent TB Infection (LTBI): Infected with M. tuberculosis but no symptoms, not contagious. Positive TST/IGRA, normal CXR. 5-10% lifetime risk of reactivation (higher if immunocompromised)
  • Active TB Disease: Symptomatic, contagious (if pulmonary/laryngeal), abnormal CXR, positive AFB smear/culture. Requires multi-drug treatment

PULMONARY TB (Most Common, 80-85%):

Classic Presentation (Subacute/Chronic):

  • Chronic cough: â‰¥3 weeks duration. Initially dry, becomes productive. Hallmark symptom
  • Hemoptysis: Blood-tinged sputum (25-50%). Can be massive in cavitary disease
  • Constitutional symptoms ("B symptoms"): Fever (low-grade, evening), night sweats (drenching, change clothes), weight loss (>10% body weight), anorexia, malaise, fatigue
  • Chest pain: Pleuritic (if pleural involvement), dull ache
  • Dyspnea: If extensive disease, pleural effusion, or miliary TB

Physical Exam (Often Unremarkable): May have rales/crackles over involved lung fields, dullness to percussion (consolidation, effusion), amphoric breath sounds (cavity), cachexia (advanced disease). Exam may be entirely normal despite extensive radiographic disease

EXTRAPULMONARY TB (15-20%, Higher in HIV/Immunocompromised):

  • Tuberculous Lymphadenitis (Most Common EPTB): Painless, firm, matted cervical or supraclavicular lymph nodes. May suppurate (cold abscess). Slow progression over weeks-months
  • Pleural TB: Exudative pleural effusion. Pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea. Effusion often lymphocyte-predominant. Pleural fluid ADA (adenosine deaminase) >40 U/L highly suggestive
  • Tuberculous Meningitis (TB Meningitis): Subacute headache, fever, altered mental status, cranial nerve palsies (especially CN VI), seizures. CSF: lymphocytic pleocytosis, low glucose, high protein. HIGH MORTALITY (20-50%) even with treatment
  • Miliary TB (Disseminated): Hematogenous spread to multiple organs. High fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly. CXR: bilateral diffuse miliary (millet seed) nodules (1-3mm). Often in HIV, elderly, immunocompromised
  • Skeletal TB (Pott's Disease): Vertebral osteomyelitis (thoracic/lumbar spine most common). Back pain, paravertebral abscess, cord compression, gibbus deformity. MRI shows vertebral destruction, abscess
  • Genitourinary TB: Dysuria, hematuria, flank pain, sterile pyuria. Can cause ureteral strictures, hydronephrosis, chronic kidney disease
  • Pericardial TB: Pericardial effusion, tamponade, constrictive pericarditis (chronic). High mortality
  • Abdominal TB: Peritonitis (ascites, abdominal pain), intestinal involvement (chronic diarrhea, obstruction, perforation). Ascites: high protein, lymphocyte-predominant, ADA >39 U/L

High-Risk Populations:

  • HIV/AIDS (CD4 <200): 10-20x increased risk. More likely disseminated/extrapulmonary TB. TB accelerates HIV progression
  • Immunosuppression: TNF-Î± inhibitors (infliximab, adalimumab - screen before starting), transplant recipients, chronic steroids (â‰¥15mg prednisone daily), chemotherapy
  • Close contact: Household contact with active TB case (20-30% infection rate)
  • Endemic areas: India, China, Southeast Asia, Sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America, Eastern Europe
  • Congregate settings: Homeless shelters, prisons, nursing homes
  • Healthcare workers: Exposure to undiagnosed TB patients
  • Other: Diabetes, chronic kidney disease, silicosis, malignancy, malnutrition, alcoholism, IV drug use

Drug-Resistant TB:

  • Multidrug-Resistant TB (MDR-TB): Resistant to isoniazid (INH) + rifampin (RIF). 5% of new cases globally. Higher in HIV, prior TB treatment. Requires â‰¥18-24 months treatment. Lower cure rates (50-70%)
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant TB (XDR-TB): MDR-TB + resistance to fluoroquinolones + second-line injectable (amikacin, kanamycin, capreomycin). Very poor prognosis. Mortality 30-50%
  • Risk factors for resistance: Prior TB treatment, non-adherence, endemic areas (Russia, South Africa, India), HIV co-infection, close contact with known drug-resistant case
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Tuberculin Skin Test (TST) & Interferon-Gamma Release Assay (IGRA):

  • Use: Screen for LATENT TB infection. NOT for diagnosis of active TB disease
  • TST (Mantoux test): Intradermal injection. Read at 48-72hr. Induration â‰¥5mm (HIV, immunocompromised, close contact), â‰¥10mm (immigrants, healthcare workers, high-risk), â‰¥15mm (low-risk) considered positive
  • IGRA (QuantiFERON-TB Gold, T-SPOT): Blood test. Measures T-cell response to TB antigens. Not affected by BCG vaccination (unlike TST). Preferred in BCG-vaccinated individuals
  • Both can be negative in active TB: Anergy from severe illness, immunosuppression. Don't rule out active TB based on negative TST/IGRA alone

Chest X-Ray (CXR) - Essential:

  • Primary TB (children, recent infection): Hilar/mediastinal lymphadenopathy, middle/lower lobe infiltrates, Ghon complex (calcified granuloma + lymph node)
  • Reactivation TB (adults): Upper lobe infiltrates (apical/posterior segments), cavitary lesions (thin-walled cavities with air-fluid levels), fibronodular opacities, volume loss. Right upper lobe most common
  • Miliary TB: Bilateral diffuse miliary (millet seed) nodules, 1-3mm
  • Pleural effusion: Unilateral, moderate-large. May be only finding
  • Advanced disease: Fibrosis, traction bronchiectasis, destroyed lung

Note: CXR can be normal in early disease or extrapulmonary TB. HIV patients may have atypical or normal CXR despite active pulmonary TB

Sputum Testing (GOLD STANDARD for Pulmonary TB):

  • Collection: 3 separate sputum samples on 3 different days (ideally early morning, deep cough). If unable to produce sputum: induced sputum (nebulized hypertonic saline), bronchoscopy with BAL, gastric aspirate (children)
  • AFB Smear (Acid-Fast Bacilli): Ziehl-Neelsen or Auramine-rhodamine stain. Results in 24hr. Positive = patient is infectious. Sensitivity 50-60% (needs 5,000-10,000 organisms/mL). Negative smear does NOT rule out TB. Semi-quantitative: 1+ to 4+ (higher = more infectious)
  • Mycobacterial Culture (GOLD STANDARD): Solid media (Lowenstein-Jensen) takes 3-8 weeks. Liquid media (MGIT) faster (1-3 weeks). Definitive diagnosis. Allows drug susceptibility testing (DST). ESSENTIAL
  • Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT):
    • Xpert MTB/RIF (GeneXpert): Rapid PCR test (results in 2 hours). Detects M. tuberculosis + rifampin resistance. Sensitivity 80-90% (higher if smear-positive). WHO-recommended. Use on first sputum sample
    • Cepheid Xpert MTB/RIF Ultra: Improved sensitivity (90-95%). Detects lower bacterial loads
  • Histopathology (if tissue available): Caseating granulomas with Langhans giant cells. Supportive but not specific (fungi, sarcoid can mimic)

Extrapulmonary TB Diagnosis:

  • Pleural fluid: Lymphocyte-predominant exudate, ADA >40 U/L (90% sensitivity), low glucose, high protein. Pleural biopsy (caseating granulomas, culture) more sensitive than pleural fluid culture
  • CSF (TB meningitis): Lymphocytic pleocytosis (50-500 cells/ÂµL), low glucose (<45mg/dL or <50% serum), high protein (>100mg/dL). AFB smear low sensitivity (10-20%). Culture takes weeks. Large volume (6-10mL) increases yield. Xpert MTB/RIF on CSF (sensitivity 50-60%)
  • Lymph node: Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) for AFB smear/culture, or excisional biopsy (caseating granulomas, culture)
  • Urine: 3 early morning urine samples for AFB culture. Xpert MTB/RIF on urine (moderate sensitivity)
  • Biopsy: Any suspected site (bone, peritoneum, pericardium) - send for AFB smear, culture, histopathology

Labs:

  • CBC: Anemia of chronic disease, lymphopenia (miliary TB), monocytosis
  • CMP: Hyponatremia (SIADH in TB meningitis, miliary TB), elevated alkaline phosphatase (hepatic TB, drug toxicity)
  • ESR/CRP: Elevated (nonspecific inflammatory markers)
  • HIV test: Obtain in ALL TB patients. HIV/TB co-infection common
  • Baseline LFTs: Before starting treatment (INH, RIF, PZA are hepatotoxic)

Drug Susceptibility Testing (DST): CRITICAL. Perform on all initial isolates. Guides therapy. Tests susceptibility to INH, RIF, PZA, ethambutol, fluoroquinolones, second-line drugs. Takes 2-4 weeks. Don't wait for results to start treatment. Adjust regimen when results available

Additional Testing:

  • CT chest: If CXR abnormal or high suspicion with normal CXR. Better delineates cavities, lymphadenopathy, complications
  • Bronchoscopy with BAL: If unable to produce sputum, high suspicion with negative sputum, suspected endobronchial TB
  • MRI spine: If Pott's disease suspected (back pain, neurologic deficits)
  • Ophthalmology exam: Check for choroidal tubercles (miliary TB), before starting ethambutol (monitor for optic neuritis)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

ISOLATION (CRITICAL - Airborne Precautions):

  • Airborne isolation room: Negative pressure, â‰¥6 air changes/hour, HEPA filtration. Private room. Door closed
  • N95 respirators: For all healthcare workers entering room. Fit-tested. Surgical mask for patient when leaving room
  • Duration: Until 3 consecutive negative AFB smears (usually 2-4 weeks of treatment) OR clinically improving + receiving appropriate therapy Ã— 2 weeks. TB meningitis/extrapulmonary TB (non-pulmonary) generally NOT infectious - standard precautions
  • Reporting: TB is REPORTABLE to public health department. Contact investigation for close contacts

STANDARD TREATMENT REGIMEN (Drug-Susceptible TB):

Intensive Phase (First 2 Months) - RIPE:

  • Rifampin (R): 600mg PO daily (or 10mg/kg/day, max 600mg)
  • Isoniazid (I/INH): 300mg PO daily (or 5mg/kg/day, max 300mg) + Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) 25-50mg daily (prevent peripheral neuropathy)
  • Pyrazinamide (P/PZA): 1000-2000mg PO daily (weight-based: 40-55kg = 1000mg, 56-75kg = 1500mg, 76-90kg = 2000mg, >90kg = 2000mg)
  • Ethambutol (E): 800-1600mg PO daily (weight-based: 40-55kg = 800mg, 56-75kg = 1200mg, 76-90kg = 1600mg, >90kg = 1600mg)
  • Duration: 2 months (8 weeks) OR until AFB smear-negative and clinical improvement

Continuation Phase (Next 4-7 Months) - Rifampin + Isoniazid:

  • Rifampin 600mg PO daily + Isoniazid 300mg PO daily (+ pyridoxine 25-50mg daily)
  • Duration:
    • Uncomplicated pulmonary TB (cavitary disease, smear-negative at 2 months): 4 months continuation (total 6 months therapy)
    • Cavitary disease + positive smear at 2 months: 7 months continuation (total 9 months)
    • TB meningitis, miliary TB, bone/joint TB: 10-12 months continuation (total 12 months therapy)

Total Treatment Duration:

  • Drug-susceptible pulmonary TB: 6 months (2 months RIPE, then 4 months RI)
  • Extrapulmonary TB (lymph nodes, pleura): 6 months (same as pulmonary)
  • TB meningitis, miliary TB, bone/spine TB: 9-12 months
  • MDR-TB: 18-24 months (complex regimen, consult ID/TB specialist)

Directly Observed Therapy (DOT): STRONGLY RECOMMENDED for all TB patients. Healthcare worker observes patient taking medications (3-5 times/week or daily). Ensures adherence, prevents resistance, improves cure rates. Public health department coordinates DOT

Alternative Dosing (Intermittent Therapy): 3 times weekly dosing (after initial 2 weeks daily therapy) acceptable if DOT ensured. Used in resource-limited settings. Doses higher than daily dosing (consult ID/TB expert for dosing)

Drug-Resistant TB:

  • Rifampin-Resistant (RR-TB): Detected by Xpert MTB/RIF. Treat as MDR-TB until full DST results
  • MDR-TB (INH + RIF resistant): Requires 4-5 drugs including fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin) + second-line injectable (amikacin, capreomycin) + pyrazinamide + ethambutol + others (linezolid, bedaquiline, delamanid). CONSULT ID/TB SPECIALIST. Treatment 18-24 months
  • XDR-TB: MDR + resistant to fluoroquinolones + injectable. Very limited options. Newer drugs: bedaquiline, delamanid, pretomanid. MUST consult TB expert

HIV Co-Infection (TB-HIV):

  • Start TB treatment immediately: Don't delay for ART initiation
  • When to start ART:
    • CD4 <50: Start ART within 2 weeks of starting TB treatment (balance immune reconstitution vs TB treatment)
    • CD4 >50: Start ART within 8 weeks of TB treatment
    • TB meningitis: DELAY ART until 8 weeks (risk of IRIS with neurologic worsening)
  • Drug interactions: Rifampin induces CYP450 (decreases ART levels). Integrase inhibitors (dolutegravir, raltegravir) or efavirenz preferred. Avoid protease inhibitors with rifampin. Consider rifabutin (less CYP induction) instead of rifampin if needed

TB Meningitis (Special Considerations):

  • Adjunctive corticosteroids: Dexamethasone 0.3-0.4mg/kg/day IV Ã— 4 weeks, then taper over 4 weeks. Reduces mortality and disability. START WITH FIRST DOSE OF TB DRUGS
  • Duration: 9-12 months total treatment
  • Monitor: Repeat lumbar punctures if worsening symptoms (hydrocephalus, increased ICP). Shunt if needed

Monitoring During Treatment:

  • Clinical: Weekly initially, then monthly. Assess adherence, symptoms, side effects
  • Sputum smears: Monthly until 2 consecutive negatives, then at end of treatment
  • LFTs: Baseline, then monthly (or sooner if symptoms of hepatitis). Hold drugs if ALT >3Ã— ULN with symptoms or >5Ã— ULN asymptomatic
  • CMP: Monitor creatinine (ethambutol cleared renally), uric acid (pyrazinamide causes hyperuricemia)
  • Visual acuity & color vision: Monthly (ethambutol optic neuritis). Baseline ophthalmology exam
  • CXR: At 2 months, end of treatment, then as needed. Improvement may lag clinical improvement

Treatment Failure: Persistent positive sputum cultures after 4 months of treatment. Suggests drug resistance, non-adherence, malabsorption. Repeat DST. Consult ID/TB specialist. Do NOT add single drug to failing regimen (creates resistance)

Supportive Care:

  • Nutrition: High-calorie, high-protein diet. Many patients malnourished
  • Diabetes control: Rifampin decreases efficacy of oral hypoglycemics. May need insulin
  • Symptom management: Cough suppressants, antipyretics, analgesics PRN
  • Contact investigation: Public health screens close contacts (TST/IGRA, CXR). Treat LTBI if indicated
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • TB is "the great mimicker": Can present as pneumonia, lymphoma, cancer, chronic meningitis, osteomyelitis. High index of suspicion in endemic areas, immunocompromised, chronic symptoms
  • Don't wait for culture to treat: Cultures take weeks. Start treatment based on clinical/radiographic suspicion and positive AFB smear or Xpert. Adjust when DST results available
  • Never add a single drug to a failing regimen: Creates resistance. If treatment failing, add â‰¥2 new drugs and consult TB specialist
  • Rifampin turns body fluids orange: Warn patients (urine, tears, sweat). Contact lenses permanently stained. Not harmful
  • INH peripheral neuropathy is preventable: Give pyridoxine (vitamin B6) 25-50mg daily with INH to ALL patients. Essential in diabetics, HIV, pregnant women, alcoholics, malnourished
  • Ethambutol optic neuritis is dose-dependent: Monitor visual acuity and color vision monthly. Mostly reversible if caught early. Higher risk if renal insufficiency (dose-adjust) or >2 months use
  • TB-HIV co-infection is deadly but treatable: Start TB treatment first, then ART (within 2-8 weeks depending on CD4). Watch for IRIS (immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome) - paradoxical worsening when starting ART
  • TB meningitis needs steroids: Dexamethasone reduces mortality and disability. Start with first dose of TB drugs. Delay ART until 8 weeks (risk of IRIS neurologic worsening)
  • Sputum cultures must be done: Only way to confirm diagnosis and perform drug susceptibility testing. Negative smears don't rule out TB (sensitivity only 50-60%). Culture is gold standard
  • Adherence is everything: Non-adherence â†’ treatment failure â†’ drug resistance â†’ MDR-TB/XDR-TB. DOT (directly observed therapy) is highly effective and recommended for ALL patients
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation (extensive TB pneumonia, ARDS)
  • TB meningitis with decreased consciousness (GCS <13), increased ICP, neurologic deterioration
  • Hemodynamically unstable (septic shock rare but possible)
  • Massive hemoptysis (>200mL in 24hr)
  • Drug-induced hepatotoxicity (ALT >10Ã— ULN, coagulopathy, encephalopathy)
  • Severe IRIS (immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome) in HIV patients starting ART
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Clinically stable and improving (no fever, improved symptoms)
  • Tolerating PO medications
  • 3 consecutive negative AFB smears (pulmonary TB) OR clinically improving on treatment Ã— 2 weeks
  • Appropriate outpatient TB regimen prescribed (DOT arranged)
  • Public health notified (contact investigation underway)
  • Close follow-up arranged (ID clinic, public health DOT program)
  • Patient counseled on adherence, side effects, infectivity
  • Isolation precautions no longer needed (3 negative smears or appropriate duration on therapy)
  • Directly Observed Therapy (DOT) arranged through public health
COMPLICATIONS TO MONITOR

Acute (During Active Disease): Respiratory failure (extensive pneumonia, ARDS), massive hemoptysis (eroded pulmonary artery - requires bronchial artery embolization or surgery), pneumothorax (cavitary disease rupture), empyema (pleural space infection), pericardial tamponade (pericardial TB), spinal cord compression (Pott's disease with epidural abscess), obstructive hydrocephalus (TB meningitis - may need shunt), ARDS (miliary TB, severe pneumonia)

Treatment-Related Complications:

  • Hepatotoxicity (INH, RIF, PZA): Transaminitis (10-20%), symptomatic hepatitis (1-3%). Monitor LFTs monthly. Hold drugs if ALT >5Ã— ULN or >3Ã— ULN with symptoms. Rechallenge drugs sequentially when LFTs normalize. INH most hepatotoxic
  • Peripheral neuropathy (INH): Prevented by pyridoxine (vitamin B6). Higher risk in diabetes, HIV, alcohol, malnutrition
  • Optic neuritis (Ethambutol): Decreased visual acuity, red-green color blindness. Monitor monthly. Usually reversible if caught early. Dose-adjust in renal insufficiency
  • Hyperuricemia/gout (Pyrazinamide): Elevated uric acid. Treat with NSAIDs, colchicine. Allopurinol if recurrent gout (but wait until after PZA phase)
  • Thrombocytopenia (Rifampin): Immune-mediated. Stop rifampin. Can use rifabutin instead
  • Orange discoloration (Rifampin): Body fluids (urine, tears, sweat) turn orange-red. Harmless. Warn patients (contact lenses stained)
  • Drug interactions (Rifampin): CYP450 inducer. Decreases levels of: oral contraceptives (use barrier method), warfarin, anticonvulsants, antiretrovirals, immunosuppressants
  • IRIS (Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome): Paradoxical worsening when starting ART in HIV patients on TB treatment. Inflammatory reaction to dead/dying TB. Can be severe (lymph node enlargement, worsening infiltrates, fever). Manage with NSAIDs or steroids. Don't stop ART or TB drugs

Chronic (Post-Treatment): Chronic pulmonary sequelae (fibrosis, bronchiectasis, destroyed lung, aspergilloma in old cavities - hemoptysis risk), chronic pericarditis (constrictive - may need pericardiectomy), chronic meningitis sequelae (hydrocephalus, seizures, cranial nerve palsies, cognitive impairment), skeletal deformities (gibbus deformity from vertebral collapse), chronic kidney disease (GU TB), relapse (5% after adequate treatment - usually within 1 year, higher if HIV, drug-resistant TB, non-adherence)

Prevention: Treat LTBI (latent TB infection) in high-risk individuals: INH 300mg daily Ã— 9 months OR rifampin 600mg daily Ã— 4 months OR INH-rifapentine weekly Ã— 3 months (3HP). BCG vaccine (limited efficacy in adults, not used in US). Infection control (airborne precautions, N95 respirators). Contact investigation and treatment of close contacts

â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

60. HIV/AIDS COMPLICATIONS

Advanced HIV Disease â€¢ CD4 <200 â€¢ Opportunistic Infections â€¢ Antiretroviral Therapy
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

HIV/AIDS Overview: Advanced HIV disease occurs when CD4 count <200 cells/Î¼L (AIDS-defining) or presence of opportunistic infections. Patients vulnerable to infections, malignancies, and complications related to severe immunosuppression

Common AIDS-Defining Illnesses by CD4 Count:

  • CD4 <500: Herpes zoster (shingles), tuberculosis reactivation, recurrent bacterial pneumonia, oral/vaginal candidiasis
  • CD4 <200: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP), candidal esophagitis, CNS toxoplasmosis, disseminated histoplasmosis/coccidioidomycosis, chronic cryptosporidiosis
  • CD4 <50: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis/colitis, Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) disseminated infection, primary CNS lymphoma, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML)

PNEUMOCYSTIS JIROVECII PNEUMONIA (PCP) - Most Common AIDS-Defining Illness:

  • Presentation: Subacute onset (weeks) of dyspnea, dry cough, fever. Progressive hypoxemia. Typically CD4 <200
  • Physical exam: Tachypnea, hypoxemia (Oâ‚‚ sat low, often 80s-90s on room air), clear lung sounds or fine crackles. NO consolidation
  • CXR: Diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates ("ground glass"). Can be normal in 10-20%. Pneumothorax can occur
  • Diagnosis: Induced sputum (methenamine silver stain, DFA), bronchoscopy with BAL (gold standard, sensitivity >95%)
  • LDH: Markedly elevated (>500, often >1000). Nonspecific but sensitive

CANDIDAL ESOPHAGITIS:

  • Presentation: Odynophagia (painful swallowing), dysphagia, retrosternal chest pain. Usually oral thrush present (white plaques on tongue/buccal mucosa). CD4 typically <200
  • Diagnosis: Clinical (presence of oral thrush + odynophagia highly specific). Endoscopy if atypical or no response to treatment (shows white plaques in esophagus)

CNS TOXOPLASMOSIS (Toxoplasma encephalitis):

  • Presentation: Altered mental status, focal neurologic deficits (hemiparesis, aphasia, ataxia), seizures, headache, fever. CD4 typically <100
  • MRI brain: Multiple ring-enhancing lesions (80%), typically at gray-white junction, basal ganglia. Mass effect, edema
  • Toxoplasma IgG: Positive in 90% (past exposure). Negative IgG makes toxoplasmosis less likely
  • Diagnosis: Presumptive based on imaging + CD4 <100 + positive Toxoplasma IgG. Empiric treatment trial (if improvement in 7-14 days â†’ confirms diagnosis). Brain biopsy if no response or IgG negative

CMV RETINITIS:

  • Presentation: Painless vision loss, floaters, visual field defects. CD4 <50
  • Fundoscopy: "Pizza pie" or "cottage cheese and ketchup" appearance. Hemorrhagic necrosis along retinal vessels
  • Risk: Retinal detachment, permanent blindness if untreated. OPHTHALMOLOGY EMERGENCY

CMV COLITIS:

  • Presentation: Chronic diarrhea (watery or bloody), abdominal pain, fever, weight loss. CD4 <50
  • Diagnosis: Colonoscopy with biopsy (CMV inclusion bodies, immunostaining)

MYCOBACTERIUM AVIUM COMPLEX (MAC):

  • Presentation: Disseminated disease. High fever, night sweats, weight loss, anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy. Chronic diarrhea (GI involvement). CD4 <50
  • Labs: Pancytopenia, elevated alkaline phosphatase
  • Diagnosis: Blood cultures (mycobacterial blood cultures - takes 2-4 weeks). Positive in 90%

CRYPTOCOCCAL MENINGITIS:

  • Presentation: Subacute headache (weeks), fever, altered mental status, nausea/vomiting. Minimal meningeal signs. CD4 <100
  • CSF: Elevated opening pressure (>25cmHâ‚‚O in 75%), lymphocytic pleocytosis, low glucose, high protein. India ink (encapsulated yeast), cryptococcal antigen (CrAg) nearly 100% sensitive
  • Serum CrAg: Also highly sensitive. Positive in disseminated disease
  • Imaging: MRI may be normal or show hydrocephalus, cryptococcomas

IMMUNE RECONSTITUTION INFLAMMATORY SYNDROME (IRIS):

  • Definition: Paradoxical worsening of opportunistic infection after starting ART (antiretroviral therapy). Occurs as CD4 count rises and immune system "awakens"
  • Timing: Typically 2-12 weeks after starting ART
  • Presentation: Fever, worsening symptoms/imaging of prior infection (e.g., TB lymphadenitis enlarges, PCP infiltrates worsen). Can be severe (respiratory failure, neurologic deterioration)
  • Management: Continue ART + continue OI treatment. Corticosteroids if severe (prednisone 0.5-1mg/kg/day)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Essential Labs:

  • CD4 count: Determines risk of opportunistic infections. <200 = AIDS. <50 = highest risk
  • HIV viral load: Assesses disease control, treatment response. Goal <20-50 copies/mL (undetectable)
  • CBC: Anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia common in advanced disease. Pancytopenia (think MAC, disseminated infection)
  • CMP: Renal function (before nephrotoxic drugs), electrolytes, liver enzymes
  • LDH: Elevated in PCP, lymphoma, hemolysis
  • Blood cultures: Bacterial (if fever/sepsis), mycobacterial (if CD4 <50 with fever/night sweats - rule out MAC, TB)

Imaging Based on Presentation:

  • CXR: If respiratory symptoms (PCP, TB, bacterial pneumonia, Kaposi sarcoma)
  • CT chest: If CXR nondiagnostic but high suspicion for PCP or other pulmonary process
  • MRI brain (with contrast): If altered mental status, focal deficits, seizures (toxoplasmosis, lymphoma, PML, cryptococcoma)
  • CT abdomen/pelvis: If abdominal pain, diarrhea, hepatosplenomegaly (CMV colitis, MAC, lymphoma, Kaposi sarcoma)

Specific OI Diagnostics:

  • PCP: ABG (A-a gradient), induced sputum or BAL (methenamine silver stain, DFA, PCR). Î²-D-glucan elevated
  • Toxoplasmosis: MRI brain, Toxoplasma IgG serology
  • Cryptococcus: Serum CrAg (screening if CD4 <100), lumbar puncture (opening pressure, CSF CrAg, India ink, fungal culture)
  • CMV: Ophthalmology exam (retinitis), colonoscopy with biopsy (colitis), CMV PCR (viremia)
  • MAC: Mycobacterial blood cultures (hold 4-6 weeks)
  • TB: Sputum AFB smear/culture/PCR (Xpert MTB/RIF), mycobacterial blood cultures if disseminated

Lumbar Puncture Indications: Headache, altered mental status, seizures, fever with neurologic symptoms. Check opening pressure, cell count, protein, glucose, Gram stain/culture, CrAg, VDRL (syphilis), consider Toxoplasma PCR, JC virus PCR (PML)

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

ANTIRETROVIRAL THERAPY (ART) - Foundation:

  • Start ART in ALL patients: Regardless of CD4 count. Reduces mortality, prevents disease progression, reduces transmission
  • Timing: Start within 2 weeks of OI diagnosis (balance immune recovery vs IRIS risk). EXCEPTION: TB meningitis (delay ART 8 weeks to reduce IRIS-related neurologic complications), cryptococcal meningitis (delay 4-6 weeks after starting antifungals)
  • Regimen: Integrase inhibitor-based (dolutegravir, bictegravir) + 2 NRTIs (tenofovir/emtricitabine). Consult HIV specialist for regimen selection
  • Drug interactions: Many ART drugs interact with rifampin (TB treatment), azoles (fungal treatment). Adjust doses or choose alternative agents

PCP TREATMENT:

  • First-line: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Bactrim) 15-20mg/kg/day (based on TMP component) IV or PO divided TID-QID Ã— 21 days. Example: 2 DS tablets PO TID
  • Alternative (if sulfa allergy): Pentamidine 4mg/kg IV daily Ã— 21 days (nephrotoxic, pancreatitis, hypoglycemia), OR clindamycin 600mg IV q6h + primaquine 15-30mg PO daily Ã— 21 days (check G6PD first)
  • Adjunctive corticosteroids: Prednisone 40mg PO BID Ã— 5 days, then 40mg daily Ã— 5 days, then 20mg daily Ã— 11 days (total 21 days). INDICATION: PaOâ‚‚ <70mmHg on room air OR A-a gradient >35mmHg. START WITHIN 72 HOURS of antibiotics. Reduces mortality and respiratory failure
  • Secondary prophylaxis: After completion, continue TMP-SMX 1 DS tablet PO daily until CD4 >200 Ã— 3 months

CANDIDAL ESOPHAGITIS TREATMENT:

  • First-line: Fluconazole 200-400mg PO/IV daily Ã— 14-21 days
  • Alternative (fluconazole-refractory): Itraconazole 200mg PO daily, posaconazole 400mg PO BID, voriconazole 200mg PO BID, OR micafungin 150mg IV daily, caspofungin 70mg IV load then 50mg daily
  • Response: Symptoms improve in 3-5 days. If no improvement by 7 days â†’ endoscopy (confirm diagnosis, rule out CMV/HSV co-infection)

CNS TOXOPLASMOSIS TREATMENT:

  • First-line (acute therapy Ã— 6 weeks): Pyrimethamine 200mg PO load, then 50-75mg PO daily (weight-based) + sulfadiazine 1-1.5g PO QID + leucovorin (folinic acid) 10-25mg PO daily (prevents bone marrow toxicity)
  • Alternative: Pyrimethamine + leucovorin + clindamycin 600mg IV/PO q6h (if sulfa allergy)
  • Second-line: TMP-SMX 5mg/kg (TMP component) IV q12h
  • Anticonvulsants: If seizures occur. Levetiracetam preferred (fewer drug interactions than phenytoin)
  • Corticosteroids: Dexamethasone if significant mass effect/edema. Use cautiously (can mask treatment failure)
  • Clinical response: 80-90% improve by 7-14 days. Repeat MRI at 2 weeks. If worsening â†’ consider brain biopsy (lymphoma vs other diagnosis)
  • Secondary prophylaxis: After acute treatment, continue pyrimethamine 25-50mg daily + sulfadiazine 2-4g daily (divided) + leucovorin 10-25mg daily until CD4 >200 Ã— 6 months

CRYPTOCOCCAL MENINGITIS TREATMENT:

  • Induction (2 weeks): Amphotericin B lipid complex 3-4mg/kg IV daily + flucytosine 25mg/kg PO QID. Goal: sterilize CSF
  • Consolidation (8 weeks): Fluconazole 400mg PO daily
  • Maintenance (â‰¥1 year): Fluconazole 200mg PO daily until CD4 >200 Ã— 6 months AND undetectable viral load
  • Elevated ICP management (CRITICAL): Daily therapeutic lumbar punctures (remove 20-30mL CSF) to maintain opening pressure <20cmHâ‚‚O. Persistent elevated ICP â†’ lumbar drain. Untreated elevated ICP causes blindness, death
  • Monitor: Creatinine (amphotericin nephrotoxic), potassium/magnesium (wasting), CBC (flucytosine bone marrow suppression)

CMV RETINITIS TREATMENT:

  • Induction (2-3 weeks): Ganciclovir 5mg/kg IV q12h OR foscarnet 90mg/kg IV q12h OR valganciclovir 900mg PO BID (if can tolerate PO)
  • Maintenance: Valganciclovir 900mg PO daily OR ganciclovir 5mg/kg IV 5-7Ã—/week until immune recovery (CD4 >100 Ã— 6 months)
  • Ophthalmology: Urgent consultation. Consider intravitreal injections if sight-threatening

CMV COLITIS TREATMENT:

  • Induction: Ganciclovir 5mg/kg IV q12h Ã— 3-6 weeks (until symptoms resolve)
  • Maintenance: Valganciclovir 900mg PO daily until CD4 >100 Ã— 6 months

MAC TREATMENT:

  • Therapy: Clarithromycin 500mg PO BID + ethambutol 15mg/kg PO daily + rifabutin 300mg PO daily (if ART allows). Continue until CD4 >100 Ã— 12 months AND â‰¥12 months treatment AND asymptomatic
  • Alternative: Azithromycin 500-600mg daily (instead of clarithromycin)

IRIS MANAGEMENT:

  • Continue ART: Do not stop (benefit of immune recovery outweighs IRIS risk in most cases)
  • Continue OI treatment: Ensure adequately treating underlying infection
  • Corticosteroids if severe: Prednisone 0.5-1mg/kg/day Ã— 2 weeks, then taper. Consider if respiratory failure, neurologic deterioration, or life-threatening symptoms
TEACHING PEARLS

ðŸ’¡ Start ART early: Within 2 weeks of OI diagnosis in most cases (except TB meningitis, cryptococcal meningitis). Early ART reduces mortality

ðŸ’¡ PCP prophylaxis indications: CD4 <200, prior PCP, or CD4 <14%. TMP-SMX 1 DS tablet daily or 3Ã—/week. Prevents #1 AIDS-defining illness

ðŸ’¡ Toxoplasmosis prophylaxis: CD4 <100 + positive Toxoplasma IgG. TMP-SMX 1 DS daily (also covers PCP)

ðŸ’¡ MAC prophylaxis: CD4 <50. Azithromycin 1200mg weekly or clarithromycin 500mg BID

ðŸ’¡ Ring-enhancing brain lesions in HIV: #1 = Toxoplasmosis (multiple lesions, CD4 <100). #2 = Primary CNS lymphoma (solitary, CD4 <50, EBV-associated). Empiric toxo treatment trial for 2 weeks; if no response â†’ biopsy

ðŸ’¡ Cryptococcal meningitis ICP crisis: Elevated opening pressure (>25cmHâ‚‚O) is the rule, not exception. Daily LPs to drain CSF are MANDATORY. Failure to control ICP â†’ blindness, death despite antifungals

ðŸ’¡ PCP in pregnancy: TMP-SMX contraindicated in 1st trimester (folate antagonist). Use pentamidine. After 1st trimester, TMP-SMX is safe

ðŸ’¡ CMV viremia vs disease: Positive CMV PCR alone is not disease. Need end-organ involvement (retinitis, colitis, esophagitis, pneumonitis). Don't treat viremia alone

ðŸ’¡ Rifampin drug interactions: Rifampin is potent CYP450 inducer. Decreases levels of protease inhibitors, NNRTIs, many other drugs. Use rifabutin (less induction) or integrase inhibitors (less affected) with HIV treatment

ðŸ’¡ Diarrhea in AIDS: Broad differential. Infectious (CMV, MAC, Cryptosporidium, Microsporidium, Isospora, C. diff), medication-related (protease inhibitors), HIV enteropathy. Workup: stool cultures, ova & parasites, CMV PCR, colonoscopy if refractory

ðŸ’¡ PML (progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy): JC virus reactivation. CD4 <50. Progressive focal neurologic deficits, no fever, no enhancement on MRI. White matter lesions. CSF JC virus PCR diagnostic. NO specific treatment. Only ART (immune restoration)

ðŸ’¡ Kaposi sarcoma: HHV-8 associated. Violaceous skin lesions, oral lesions, GI/pulmonary involvement. Can occur at any CD4 but more common <200. Treatment: ART (causes regression in most)

ICU ESCALATION CRITERIA
  • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation (severe PCP, ARDS)
  • Septic shock (bacterial sepsis, disseminated infection)
  • Altered mental status with airway compromise (meningitis, encephalitis)
  • Seizures refractory to treatment (toxoplasmosis, CNS infection)
  • Hemodynamic instability (MAC with bacteremia, overwhelming sepsis)
  • Severe electrolyte abnormalities from treatment (amphotericin-induced hypokalemia/hypomagnesemia)
DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Clinical improvement of OI on appropriate therapy
  • Tolerating oral medications (or has outpatient IV access for continued treatment)
  • No longer requiring IV medications that cannot be given outpatient
  • ART started (if treatment-naive) or regimen optimized
  • Prophylaxis medications prescribed for OI prevention
  • Follow-up arranged with HIV specialist
  • Social support/housing stable (critical for medication adherence)
  • Patient educated on warning signs, medication adherence, side effects
COMPLICATIONS TO MONITOR

IRIS (Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome): Paradoxical worsening of OI after starting ART (2-12 weeks). Can be life-threatening. Continue ART, continue OI treatment, add corticosteroids if severe

Medication Toxicities: Amphotericin (nephrotoxicity, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, infusion reactions), ganciclovir/valganciclovir (bone marrow suppression), TMP-SMX (rash, hyperkalemia, renal dysfunction), pentamidine (hypoglycemia, pancreatitis, nephrotoxicity)

ART Side Effects: GI intolerance, hepatotoxicity, nephrotoxicity (tenofovir), neuropsychiatric effects (efavirenz), rash (nevirapine, abacavir - check HLA-B*5701), lipodystrophy, metabolic syndrome

Drug Interactions: ART interacts with many medications (azoles, rifamycins, anticonvulsants, PPIs, statins). Consult pharmacist/HIV specialist for regimen selection

Non-adherence: Complex regimens, side effects, social issues â†’ resistance development. Directly observed therapy, social work support, simplify regimens

â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

61. OPPORTUNISTIC INFECTIONS IN IMMUNOCOMPROMISED HOST

Non-HIV Immunosuppression â€¢ Transplant â€¢ Chemotherapy â€¢ Biological Agents
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Immunocompromised Host Overview: Patients with impaired immune function due to underlying disease (hematologic malignancy, solid organ/stem cell transplant), medications (chemotherapy, high-dose steroids, biologics), or inherited immunodeficiency. Susceptible to infections by organisms that rarely cause disease in immunocompetent hosts

Types of Immunosuppression:

  • Neutropenia: ANC <500 cells/Î¼L (severe <100). Risk of bacterial/fungal infections. Duration and depth critical
  • Cell-mediated immunity defects: Solid organ transplant, chronic steroids (>20mg prednisone daily Ã— >2 weeks), TNF-Î± inhibitors, lymphoma. Risk: intracellular pathogens (Listeria, Nocardia, mycobacteria), fungi (Cryptococcus, Pneumocystis), viruses (CMV, VZV)
  • Humoral immunity defects: Multiple myeloma, CLL, splenectomy, complement deficiencies. Risk: encapsulated bacteria (Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis)
  • Combined defects: Stem cell transplant, intensive chemotherapy regimens, HIV/AIDS

INVASIVE FUNGAL INFECTIONS (Most Feared Complications):

Invasive Aspergillosis:

  • Risk factors: Prolonged neutropenia, hematologic malignancy (AML, allogeneic stem cell transplant), high-dose steroids, lung transplant
  • Pulmonary aspergillosis (most common): Fever, cough, pleuritic chest pain, hemoptysis. CT chest: nodules with surrounding ground-glass opacity ("halo sign" early, "air-crescent sign" late), cavitation
  • Invasive sinusitis: Facial pain, nasal congestion, black necrotic eschars in nasal cavity, cranial nerve palsies (cavernous sinus extension)
  • CNS aspergillosis: Altered mental status, focal deficits, seizures. MRI: ring-enhancing lesions, hemorrhage
  • Diagnosis: Galactomannan (serum/BAL - sensitivity 70-80% in high-risk), Î²-D-glucan (nonspecific but sensitive), CT-guided biopsy (gold standard - septate hyphae with acute-angle branching)

Invasive Candidiasis:

  • Risk factors: Central lines, TPN, broad-spectrum antibiotics, GI surgery/perforation, neutropenia
  • Candidemia: Fever unresponsive to antibiotics, hemodynamic instability. Blood cultures positive (but can be negative in tissue-invasive disease)
  • Hepatosplenic candidiasis (chronic disseminated): Persistent fever during neutropenia recovery. RUQ pain, elevated alkaline phosphatase. Imaging: "bulls-eye" or target lesions in liver/spleen
  • Candida endophthalmitis: Chorioretinal lesions (white fluffy infiltrates) on fundoscopy. Screen all candidemia patients

Mucormycosis (Zygomycosis):

  • Risk factors: Diabetic ketoacidosis, neutropenia, hematologic malignancy, deferoxamine use, iron overload
  • Rhinocerebral mucormycosis: AGGRESSIVE. Facial/periorbital swelling, facial pain, black necrotic eschars (palate, nasal turbinates), proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, vision loss. Can invade brain (cavernous sinus thrombosis, stroke). HIGH MORTALITY (>50%)
  • Pulmonary mucormycosis: Fever, cough, hemoptysis, pleuritic chest pain. CT: nodules, consolidation, cavitation. Angioinvasive â†’ infarction
  • Diagnosis: Tissue biopsy (broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching). Cultures often negative

Pneumocystis jirovecii Pneumonia (PCP):

  • Risk factors: Prolonged high-dose steroids (>20mg prednisone Ã— >1 month), hematologic malignancy, solid organ transplant, chemotherapy (especially fludarabine, alemtuzumab), TNF-Î± inhibitors. NOT just HIV
  • Presentation: Subacute dyspnea, dry cough, fever. Progressive hypoxemia. CXR: bilateral interstitial infiltrates. LDH markedly elevated
  • Diagnosis: Induced sputum, BAL (methenamine silver stain, DFA, PCR). Î²-D-glucan elevated (80-90% sensitive)

VIRAL INFECTIONS:

CMV (Cytomegalovirus) Disease:

  • Risk factors: Solid organ transplant (especially lung, heart), stem cell transplant, high-dose steroids
  • CMV viremia vs disease: Viremia = PCR positive without symptoms. Disease = end-organ involvement (pneumonitis, colitis, retinitis, hepatitis, encephalitis)
  • CMV pneumonitis: Dyspnea, fever, hypoxemia. CXR/CT: bilateral interstitial infiltrates. BAL: CMV by culture/PCR + cytopathic inclusions. HIGH MORTALITY in stem cell transplant
  • CMV colitis: Diarrhea (bloody), abdominal pain, fever. Colonoscopy: ulcers, biopsy shows inclusions
  • Monitoring: Weekly CMV PCR in high-risk transplant patients (preemptive therapy if viral load rising)

Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) - Disseminated/Severe:

  • Risk: Can disseminate in immunocompromised (visceral involvement: pneumonitis, hepatitis, encephalitis)
  • Presentation: Dermatomal zoster BUT lesions outside dermatome (disseminated), hemorrhagic vesicles, visceral symptoms
  • Treatment: Acyclovir 10mg/kg IV q8h (vs PO for immunocompetent shingles)

BK Virus (Polyomavirus):

  • Risk: Kidney transplant recipients. Can cause BK nephropathy â†’ graft loss
  • Presentation: Rising creatinine, proteinuria, hematuria (mimics rejection)
  • Diagnosis: Urine/plasma BK PCR (high viral load), kidney biopsy (viral inclusions, tubular injury)

BACTERIAL INFECTIONS:

Nocardia:

  • Risk: Solid organ transplant (especially lung), chronic steroids, pulmonary alveolar proteinosis
  • Presentation: Pulmonary (most common): cough, fever, nodules/cavitation on imaging. Can disseminate to CNS (brain abscess), skin (subcutaneous abscesses)
  • Diagnosis: Sputum/tissue culture (slow-growing, modified AFB stain positive, Gram-positive branching filaments)

Listeria monocytogenes:

  • Risk: Cell-mediated immunity defects (transplant, steroids, TNF-Î± inhibitors, elderly)
  • Presentation: Meningitis (headache, fever, altered mental status), bacteremia. CSF: lymphocytic or neutrophilic pleocytosis. Blood cultures often positive

Mycobacteria (TB, NTM):

  • Risk: TNF-Î± inhibitors (screen with IGRA/TST before starting), solid organ transplant, high-dose steroids
  • Nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM): M. avium complex, M. abscessus. Pulmonary disease (nodules, cavitation), disseminated disease (in severe immunosuppression)

PARASITIC INFECTIONS:

Toxoplasma gondii:

  • Risk: Stem cell transplant (especially if donor seropositive/recipient seronegative), heart transplant (reactivation in donor heart)
  • Presentation: Similar to HIV-related toxoplasmosis (CNS lesions, fever, altered mental status)

Strongyloides stercoralis Hyperinfection:

  • Risk: Endemic exposure (tropical/subtropical regions) + immunosuppression (steroids). Parasite can persist for decades in immunocompetent, then hyperinfect
  • Presentation: Abdominal pain, diarrhea, ileus, pulmonary symptoms. Can cause Gram-negative bacteremia (larvae carry gut bacteria). HIGH MORTALITY
  • Diagnosis: Stool ova & parasites (multiple samples), serology. Larvae in sputum/BAL if pulmonary involvement
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

History - CRITICAL for Risk Stratification:

  • Type/duration of immunosuppression: Chemotherapy regimen, transplant type/date, biologic agents (infliximab, rituximab, etc.), steroid dose/duration
  • Neutropenia: ANC, duration (>7 days = high risk)
  • Prophylaxis medications: PCP prophylaxis (TMP-SMX), antifungal (fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole), antiviral (acyclovir, valganciclovir)
  • Exposures: Travel (endemic fungi - Histoplasma, Coccidioides, Blastomyces), pets, construction sites (Aspergillus), undercooked meat (Toxoplasma), gardening/soil (Nocardia)
  • Prior infections: Latent TB, endemic fungi, VZV, CMV serostatus

Laboratory Studies:

  • CBC with differential: ANC (neutropenic fever defined as ANC <500 + fever â‰¥38.3Â°C once or â‰¥38Â°C Ã— 1hr), anemia, thrombocytopenia
  • CMP: Renal function (before antifungals, antivirals), liver enzymes (hepatic involvement)
  • Blood cultures Ã— 2 sets: Bacterial, fungal (if prolonged fever/neutropenia)
  • Fungal biomarkers: Galactomannan (Aspergillus), Î²-D-glucan (Candida, Aspergillus, PCP - NOT Mucor), Cryptococcal antigen
  • Viral studies: CMV PCR (quantitative), EBV PCR, BK virus PCR (transplant patients), respiratory viral panel
  • Sputum: Gram stain/culture, AFB smear/culture, fungal culture, PCP stain (if indicated)

Imaging:

  • CT chest (high-resolution): Preferred over CXR. Aspergillus (halo sign, air crescent, nodules), PCP (ground-glass), Mucor (nodules, infarction), Nocardia (cavitary nodules)
  • CT sinus: If facial pain/congestion (Aspergillus, Mucor sinusitis)
  • MRI brain (with contrast): If altered mental status, focal deficits (Toxoplasma, Aspergillus, Nocardia, Listeria, Cryptococcus)
  • CT abdomen/pelvis: If abdominal pain (hepatosplenic candidiasis, CMV colitis, typhlitis)

Invasive Diagnostics (Often Necessary):

  • Bronchoscopy with BAL: PCP, Aspergillus, viral pneumonitis (CMV). Send for bacterial/fungal/viral cultures, PCP stain, Galactomannan, cytology
  • CT-guided biopsy: Lung nodules (Aspergillus, Mucor, Nocardia - definitive diagnosis). Liver/spleen lesions (hepatosplenic candidiasis)
  • Lumbar puncture: Altered mental status. Cell count, protein, glucose, Gram stain/culture, cryptococcal antigen, Toxoplasma PCR, VZV/HSV PCR. Opening pressure (Cryptococcus)
  • Endoscopy/colonoscopy: GI symptoms (CMV colitis, esophagitis). Biopsy for CMV inclusions, cultures
  • Skin biopsy: Rash (disseminated fungal infection, Nocardia, cutaneous viruses)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

EMPIRIC THERAPY FOR NEUTROPENIC FEVER (ANC <500 + Fever):

  • Start within 1 hour: Delays increase mortality
  • Regimen: Cefepime 2g IV q8h OR piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h OR meropenem 1g IV q8h (if prior ESBL, Pseudomonas, or critically ill)
  • Add vancomycin 15-20mg/kg q8-12h IF: Hemodynamic instability, concern for catheter-related infection, skin/soft tissue infection, MRSA colonization, mucositis
  • Duration: Continue until ANC >500 AND afebrile Ã— 48hr (minimum 7 days even if culture-negative)
  • If persistent fever at 4-7 days: ADD empiric antifungal (voriconazole, caspofungin, or liposomal amphotericin B). Repeat imaging, fungal workup

INVASIVE ASPERGILLOSIS:

  • First-line: Voriconazole 6mg/kg IV q12h Ã— 2 doses (loading), then 4mg/kg IV q12h (maintenance). Switch to PO when stable (200-300mg PO BID)
  • Alternative: Isavuconazole 372mg IV q8h Ã— 6 doses (loading), then 372mg IV daily, OR liposomal amphotericin B 3-5mg/kg IV daily
  • Salvage/combination: Voriconazole + anidulafungin (echinocandin) for severe/refractory disease
  • Duration: Minimum 6-12 weeks. Continue until lesions resolve AND immune reconstitution (ANC recovery, reduced immunosuppression if possible)
  • Monitor: Voriconazole levels (trough 1-5.5 mcg/mL - wide inter-patient variability, hepatotoxicity, visual changes)

MUCORMYCOSIS:

  • Medical: Liposomal amphotericin B 5-10mg/kg IV daily. High-dose required. Alternative: posaconazole 300mg PO BID (loading Ã— 1 day, then 300mg daily) or isavuconazole
  • Surgical debridement: MANDATORY for rhinocerebral, sino-orbital disease. Extensive debridement of necrotic tissue (repeat surgeries often needed). Medical therapy alone = FAILURE
  • Reverse immunosuppression: Reduce steroids, optimize diabetes control, discontinue deferoxamine if applicable
  • Duration: Several months (12+ weeks). Continue until clinical/radiographic resolution
  • Mortality: 40-80% despite aggressive treatment

INVASIVE CANDIDIASIS:

  • Candidemia/invasive candidiasis: Echinocandin (first-line): Micafungin 100mg IV daily, caspofungin 70mg IV load then 50mg daily, OR anidulafungin 200mg IV load then 100mg daily
  • Alternative (if stable, Candida albicans): Fluconazole 800mg IV load, then 400mg IV/PO daily
