  • Remove central line: Candidemia requires line removal within 24-48hr (unless no alternative access)
  • Ophthalmology exam: Within 1 week to rule out endophthalmitis (5-10% of candidemia)
  • Duration: 14 days after first negative blood culture AND resolution of symptoms. Longer if endocarditis, osteomyelitis, or abscess (4-6 weeks minimum)

PCP (Non-HIV):

  • Treatment: TMP-SMX 15-20mg/kg/day (TMP component) IV or PO divided TID-QID Ã— 21 days
  • Alternative: Pentamidine 4mg/kg IV daily Ã— 21 days (if sulfa allergy)
  • Adjunctive steroids: Prednisone 40mg BID Ã— 5 days â†’ 40mg daily Ã— 5 days â†’ 20mg daily Ã— 11 days. INDICATION: PaOâ‚‚ <70mmHg OR A-a gradient >35mmHg. START within 72 hours of antibiotics
  • Note: PCP in non-HIV often MORE severe presentation, higher mortality than HIV-related PCP

CMV DISEASE:

  • Treatment: Ganciclovir 5mg/kg IV q12h (induction Ã— 2-3 weeks) â†’ valganciclovir 900mg PO daily (maintenance until viremia clears + immune recovery)
  • CMV pneumonitis in stem cell transplant: Ganciclovir + IV immunoglobulin (IVIG 0.5g/kg every other day Ã— 10 doses). HIGH MORTALITY despite treatment
  • Alternative (if renal dysfunction, ganciclovir resistance): Foscarnet 90mg/kg IV q12h
  • Monitoring: Weekly CMV PCR to assess treatment response. Monitor CBC (ganciclovir causes neutropenia)

NOCARDIA:

  • Treatment: TMP-SMX 5-10mg/kg/day (TMP component) IV or PO divided BID-TID. High-dose required
  • Duration: Prolonged. Pulmonary: 6-12 months. CNS: 12 months minimum. Often combined with other agents (imipenem, amikacin, linezolid) for severe/CNS disease
  • Susceptibilities: Check antibiotic sensitivities (resistance patterns vary by species)

LISTERIA MENINGITIS:

  • Treatment: Ampicillin 2g IV q4h + gentamicin 5-7mg/kg IV daily (synergistic) Ã— 21 days minimum
  • Alternative (if penicillin allergy): TMP-SMX 5mg/kg (TMP component) IV q6h
  • Note: Ceftriaxone does NOT cover Listeria. Ampicillin is mandatory

STRONGYLOIDES HYPERINFECTION:

  • Treatment: Ivermectin 200 mcg/kg PO daily Ã— 2 days. Repeat in 2 weeks. For hyperinfection: continue daily until stool/sputum negative Ã— 2 weeks
  • Add albendazole 400mg PO BID (if severe): Not proven but often used in combination
  • Reduce immunosuppression: If possible (critical for cure)
  • Treat Gram-negative bacteremia: Broad-spectrum antibiotics (often concurrent)

REDUCING IMMUNOSUPPRESSION:

  • Balance: Need immune function to clear infection BUT must prevent organ rejection (transplant) or manage underlying disease
  • Steroids: Taper if possible (cannot stop abruptly if chronic use - adrenal insufficiency). Life-threatening infections may require reduction
  • Transplant immunosuppression: Reduce calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus, cyclosporine), hold antimetabolites (mycophenolate) temporarily. Maintain some immunosuppression to prevent rejection. Consult transplant team
  • Biologic agents: Hold TNF-Î± inhibitors, rituximab during active infection
TEACHING PEARLS

ðŸ’¡ Neutropenic fever = emergency: Start empiric antibiotics within 1 hour. Cefepime or piperacillin-tazobactam. Add vancomycin if unstable or catheter-related infection suspected

ðŸ’¡ Think Aspergillus if: Prolonged neutropenia + pulmonary nodules with halo sign on CT. Start voriconazole immediately while awaiting biopsy. Don't wait for culture (often negative)

ðŸ’¡ Mucor = aggressive surgical debridement + amphotericin: Medical therapy alone fails. Rhinocerebral mucor requires extensive ENT surgery, often multiple procedures

ðŸ’¡ Black necrotic eschar in immunocompromised: Mucormycosis until proven otherwise. Biopsy urgently. Broad, non-septate hyphae

ðŸ’¡ CMV viremia vs disease: Positive PCR alone is NOT disease. Need end-organ involvement (pneumonitis, colitis, retinitis). Preemptive therapy if rising viral load in transplant patients

ðŸ’¡ Listeria not covered by ceftriaxone: Ampicillin is mandatory for Listeria meningitis. Think Listeria in transplant/steroid patient with meningitis

ðŸ’¡ Nocardia mimics TB: Pulmonary nodules, cavitation. Weakly acid-fast positive. Long treatment course (6-12 months). Can disseminate to CNS (brain abscess)

ðŸ’¡ Screen for Strongyloides before immunosuppression: Serology in patients from endemic areas (tropics). Hyperinfection can occur decades after initial exposure when steroids started. Give ivermectin preemptively if positive

ðŸ’¡ Î²-D-glucan elevated in: Candida, Aspergillus, PCP. NOT Mucor or Cryptococcus. Use to monitor treatment response

ðŸ’¡ PCP in non-HIV: More severe presentation, worse outcomes than HIV-related PCP. Still use TMP-SMX + steroids if hypoxemic

ðŸ’¡ VZV in immunocompromised: Always treat with IV acyclovir 10mg/kg q8h. Can disseminate (visceral organs). Don't use oral therapy

ðŸ’¡ Duration of antifungal therapy: Aspergillosis requires months (minimum 6-12 weeks). Continue until immune recovery AND radiographic improvement. Early discontinuation = relapse

ICU ESCALATION CRITERIA
  • Septic shock requiring vasopressors
  • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation (severe PCP, Aspergillus pneumonia)
  • Neutropenic fever with hemodynamic instability
  • CNS infection with altered mental status/airway compromise
  • Mucormycosis requiring urgent surgical debridement + aggressive medical management
  • Refractory hypoxemia despite maximal support
DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Clinical improvement on appropriate antimicrobial therapy
  • ANC recovering if neutropenic (>500 cells/Î¼L)
  • Hemodynamically stable, afebrile Ã— 48-72hr
  • Tolerating oral medications (or has outpatient IV access arranged)
  • Appropriate prophylaxis prescribed (if indicated)
  • Follow-up arranged with oncology/transplant/infectious disease
  • Immunosuppression regimen adjusted (if modifications needed)
  • Patient/family educated on warning signs, when to return
COMPLICATIONS TO MONITOR

Persistent/Recurrent Infections: Inadequate immune recovery (prolonged neutropenia, ongoing immunosuppression), resistance (fungi, bacteria), inadequate source control (abscess, catheter), wrong diagnosis (biopsy needed)

Medication Toxicities: Amphotericin (nephrotoxicity, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, infusion reactions - rigors, fever), voriconazole (hepatotoxicity, visual changes, drug interactions), ganciclovir (bone marrow suppression), TMP-SMX (hyperkalemia, nephrotoxicity, rash)

Organ Rejection (Transplant Patients): Reducing immunosuppression to treat infection can precipitate rejection. Monitor allograft function closely

Secondary Infections: Broad-spectrum antibiotics â†’ C. difficile. Prolonged antifungals â†’ resistant organisms. Prophylaxis helps but doesn't eliminate risk

Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS): Paradoxical worsening when ANC recovers or immunosuppression reduced. Especially with fungal infections (Aspergillus, Cryptococcus). May require steroids

â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

62. SIADH (SYNDROME OF INAPPROPRIATE ADH)

Euvolemic Hyponatremia â€¢ Dilutional Hyponatremia
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Asymptomatic hyponatremia discovered on routine labs OR neurologic symptoms (confusion, headache, nausea) in euvolemic patient with concentrated urine

Symptoms (Correlate with Na Level and Rate of Drop):

  • Mild (Na 130-135): Often asymptomatic, subtle cognitive changes
  • Moderate (Na 125-129): Headache, nausea, confusion, lethargy
  • Severe (Na <125): Vomiting, altered mental status, seizures, coma
  • Critical (<120 or ACUTE drop): Cerebral edema â†’ seizures, respiratory arrest, brainstem herniation, death

Physical Exam: EUVOLEMIC - no edema, normal skin turgor, moist mucous membranes, normal JVP, no orthostatic vitals

Common Causes:

  • Malignancy (most common): SCLC (most classic), pancreatic/duodenal CA, lymphoma, head/neck cancers
  • Pulmonary: Pneumonia, TB, COPD exacerbation, aspergillosis, positive pressure ventilation
  • CNS: Meningitis, encephalitis, SAH, subdural hematoma, brain tumors, trauma, stroke
  • Medications: SSRIs, carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, vincristine, cyclophosphamide, NSAIDs, PPIs, MDMA/ecstasy
  • Post-operative: Physiologic response to surgery (transient)
  • Endocrine: Severe hypothyroidism, adrenal insufficiency (must exclude first!)
  • Idiopathic: 10-15% of cases
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

SIADH Diagnostic Criteria (Must meet ALL):

  • Hyponatremia: Na <135 mEq/L (usually <130)
  • Plasma hypo-osmolality: Serum osm <275 mOsm/kg
  • Inappropriately concentrated urine: Urine osm >100 mOsm/kg (typically >300-400)
  • Elevated urine sodium: Urine Na >40 mEq/L (on normal salt diet)
  • Clinical euvolemia: No edema, no volume depletion
  • Normal thyroid, adrenal, renal function: TSH, cortisol, Cr normal
  • No diuretic use

Essential Labs:

  • Serum: BMP (Na, K, Cr), serum osmolality, glucose, TSH, cortisol (AM or random)
  • Urine: Urine sodium, urine osmolality, specific gravity
  • Calculate serum osmolality: 2(Na) + Glucose/18 + BUN/2.8

Workup for Underlying Cause:

  • Medication review: Stop offending agents if possible
  • CT chest: Screen for SCLC, pneumonia
  • Head CT/MRI: If neurologic symptoms or CNS cause suspected
  • Consider: Lumbar puncture if meningitis/encephalitis suspected, CXR, additional malignancy workup

Key Lab Pattern:

  • â†“ Serum Na + â†“ Serum Osm + â†‘ Urine Osm + â†‘ Urine Na + Euvolemia = SIADH
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Treatment Depends on Severity and Acuity:

âš¡ SEVERE/SYMPTOMATIC (Na <120 OR seizures/coma/respiratory arrest):

  • 3% Hypertonic Saline: 100 mL IV bolus over 10 minutes, can repeat Ã— 2-3 as needed
  • Alternative: 2 mL/kg bolus over 10-20 minutes
  • Goal: Raise Na by 4-6 mEq/L acutely to abort seizures, then STOP acute correction
  • Check Na q2-4h during active correction
  • âš ï¸ DO NOT exceed 8-10 mEq/L rise in first 24 hours! Risk of osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS)

MODERATE (Na 125-129, mild symptoms):

  • Fluid restriction: 800-1000 mL/day (primary therapy)
  • Goal: Negative fluid balance of 500-1000 mL/day
  • Consider salt tablets 1-2g TID to increase osmolar load
  • Monitor Na daily initially

CHRONIC/MILD (Na 130-135, asymptomatic):

  • Treat underlying cause first
  • Fluid restriction 1000-1500 mL/day
  • High-salt, high-protein diet
  • Monitor outpatient

Adjunct Pharmacotherapy:

  • Urea: 15-30g PO BID (osmotic diuretic, increases free water excretion) - rarely used in US
  • Demeclocycline: 300-600 mg PO BID (induces nephrogenic DI) - slow onset (3-5 days), risk of photosensitivity, nephrotoxicity
  • Vaptans (V2 receptor antagonists):
    • Tolvaptan (Samsca): 15 mg PO daily (can increase to 30-60 mg). ONLY for euvolemic/hypervolemic hyponatremia
    • Reserved for severe, refractory SIADH
    • Very expensive, requires close monitoring (risk of overly rapid correction)
    • âš ï¸ Risk of osmotic demyelination if used incorrectly
    • Contraindicated: Hypovolemic hyponatremia, anuric renal failure, hepatic impairment

âš ï¸ CRITICAL CORRECTION LIMITS (Prevent Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome):

  • Maximum correction: 8-10 mEq/L in first 24 hours
  • Maximum correction: 18 mEq/L in first 48 hours
  • High-risk groups for ODS: Chronic hyponatremia (>48 hours), alcoholism, malnutrition, liver disease, hypokalemia
  • If overcorrect â†’ consider giving D5W to re-lower Na

Treat Underlying Cause:

  • Stop offending medications (SSRIs, carbamazepine)
  • Treat pneumonia, CNS infection
  • Oncology consult for malignancy-related SIADH
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Euvolemia is KEY: If patient has edema (CHF, cirrhosis) or volume depletion â†’ NOT SIADH. Must be euvolemic
  • Osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS): Caused by overly rapid Na correction. Presents 2-6 days later with dysarthria, dysphagia, paraplegia, "locked-in" syndrome. Irreversible and devastating
  • "8 in 24" rule: Never raise Na >8-10 mEq/L in 24 hours, especially in chronic hyponatremia
  • SCLC = classic: Ectopic ADH production. SIADH may be first presentation of lung cancer
  • SSRIs underrecognized cause: Especially in elderly patients. Can occur weeks-months after starting
  • Exercise-induced hyponatremia: Endurance athletes (marathons) drinking excessive hypotonic fluids. Treat with fluid restriction, NOT IV saline
  • Don't give NS for SIADH: Makes it WORSE! Kidneys excrete the sodium, keep the water â†’ Na drops further. Exception: severe symptomatic needing 3% hypertonic
  • Fluid restriction is hard: Most patients fail 800mL/day restriction. Compliance is poor
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Severe symptomatic hyponatremia (seizures, coma, respiratory arrest)
  • Na <120 mEq/L with symptoms
  • Need for 3% hypertonic saline
  • Rapidly dropping Na despite treatment
  • Altered mental status
  • Requiring q2h Na monitoring
  • Suspected or confirmed osmotic demyelination
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Na >125-130 mEq/L and stable/trending up
  • Asymptomatic or mild symptoms only
  • Underlying cause identified and addressed
  • Patient/family educated on fluid restriction
  • Offending medications discontinued
  • Close follow-up arranged (PCP or endocrine)
  • Discharge instructions include fluid restriction goal
  • Na recheck in 2-3 days
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

63. BOWEL OBSTRUCTION (SMALL/LARGE)

Mechanical Intestinal Blockage â€¢ Surgical Emergency
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Tetrad: Abdominal pain, distension, nausea/vomiting, obstipation (inability to pass stool or flatus)

Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO) - 80% of obstructions:

  • Pain: Crampy, colicky, periumbilical, intermittent (initially)
  • Vomiting: Early and prominent, bilious initially â†’ feculent if prolonged
  • Distension: Variable (minimal if proximal obstruction)
  • Bowel sounds: High-pitched, hyperactive "rushes" early â†’ absent if ischemia/perforation
  • Most common causes: Adhesions (60%, especially post-surgical), hernias (20%), malignancy, Crohn's disease, radiation enteritis

Large Bowel Obstruction (LBO) - 20% of obstructions:

  • Pain: Lower abdominal, constant, progressive
  • Distension: MARKED, progressive
  • Vomiting: Late finding (if competent ileocecal valve) or absent
  • Bowel sounds: Decreased to absent
  • Most common causes: Colorectal cancer (60%), diverticular disease (20%), volvulus (5%), fecal impaction

âš ï¸ RED FLAGS for Complicated/Strangulated Bowel:

  • Fever: Suggests ischemia, perforation, or necrosis
  • Tachycardia, hypotension: Sepsis, hypovolemia from third-spacing
  • Peritoneal signs: Guarding, rigidity, rebound tenderness â†’ perforation/necrosis
  • Severe, constant pain: Rather than colicky â†’ ischemia
  • Bloody stool: Suggests mucosal ischemia
  • Leukocytosis, metabolic acidosis: Ischemia, bacterial translocation
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Labs:

  • CBC: Leukocytosis suggests ischemia/perforation (WBC >15k concerning)
  • CMP: Hypokalemia, hypochloremia (from vomiting), elevated BUN/Cr (dehydration), metabolic acidosis (ischemia)
  • Lactate: Elevated in bowel ischemia/necrosis (>2.5-4 concerning)
  • Lipase: To exclude pancreatitis
  • Type & screen: If operative intervention likely

Imaging:

  • Abdominal X-ray (initial screening):
    • SBO: Dilated small bowel (>3cm), air-fluid levels, paucity of colonic gas
    • LBO: Dilated colon (>6cm cecum, >9cm sigmoid), air-fluid levels
    • Free air under diaphragm â†’ perforation (upright or left lateral decubitus)
    • Sensitivity only 50-60% - negative X-ray does NOT exclude obstruction
  • CT Abdomen/Pelvis with IV contrast (GOLD STANDARD):
    • Sensitivity/specificity >95% for obstruction
    • Identifies transition point, cause, and complications
    • Signs of ischemia: Bowel wall thickening, pneumatosis, mesenteric stranding, portal venous gas
    • Can distinguish partial vs complete obstruction
    • Key finding: "Transition point" where dilated bowel suddenly changes to collapsed bowel
  • Consider: CT enterography if Crohn's suspected, colonoscopy if LBO from malignancy suspected
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Initial Management (All Patients):

  • NPO: Nothing by mouth
  • IV Fluids: Aggressive resuscitation with NS or LR (1-2L bolus, then 150-250 mL/hr). Third-spacing can cause massive fluid losses
  • NG Tube: Decompress stomach, prevent aspiration, relieve symptoms
    • Consider long tube (Dobhoff, NG-J) for SBO if available
    • May prevent need for surgery in partial SBO
  • Correct electrolytes: Replace K, Cl aggressively (vomiting causes hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis)
  • Pain control: Opioids acceptable (old teaching that they mask diagnosis is FALSE)
  • Antiemetics: Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV q8h

ðŸš¨ URGENT SURGICAL CONSULTATION for:

  • Complete SBO with no prior abdominal surgery (likely hernia or mass)
  • Signs of strangulation/ischemia (fever, tachycardia, peritonitis, acidosis, elevated lactate)
  • Perforation (free air, peritonitis)
  • Large bowel obstruction (most require surgery)
  • Closed-loop obstruction (high risk of strangulation)
  • Cecal diameter >12 cm (risk of perforation)
  • Failure of conservative management after 48-72 hours

Conservative Management (Partial SBO from Adhesions):

  • Indications: Partial SBO, no signs of strangulation, history of prior abdominal surgery (adhesions)
  • NPO + NG tube + IV fluids
  • Serial abdominal exams q4-6h
  • Water-soluble contrast study (Gastrografin) can be both diagnostic and therapeutic:
    • If contrast reaches colon in 24 hours â†’ ~90% resolve without surgery
    • Osmotic effect may help resolve partial obstruction
  • Resolution typically within 24-72 hours
  • If no improvement in 3-5 days â†’ surgery

Antibiotics:

  • Not routinely needed for simple uncomplicated obstruction
  • Give if: Signs of ischemia, perforation, peritonitis, or preoperative prophylaxis
  • Regimen: Cefoxitin 2g IV q6h OR cefazolin 2g + metronidazole 500mg q8h OR pip-tazo 3.375g q6h

Special Considerations:

  • Sigmoid volvulus: Flexible sigmoidoscopy for decompression (success rate 70-80%), then elective surgery
  • Cecal volvulus: Usually requires surgery
  • Malignant LBO: Consider stent as bridge to surgery or palliative if metastatic
  • Adhesive SBO in virgin abdomen: High suspicion for incarcerated hernia - early surgery
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Adhesions = #1 cause SBO: 60% of cases. Usually in patients with prior abdominal surgery. Partial SBO from adhesions can often be managed conservatively
  • Never-operated abdomen: SBO without prior surgery suggests hernia (check all hernial orifices!), malignancy, or Crohn's â†’ usually needs surgery
  • Vomiting pattern: Early vomiting = proximal obstruction, late/absent vomiting = distal or large bowel obstruction
  • Gastrografin challenge: Water-soluble contrast given via NG tube. Reaches colon in 24h = likely resolves without surgery. Also therapeutic
  • "Rule of 3-6-9": Normal small bowel <3cm, normal large bowel <6cm, cecum <9cm. Cecum >12cm = impending perforation
  • Closed-loop obstruction: Both ends of bowel segment obstructed â†’ rapid progression to ischemia. Classic example: sigmoid volvulus, internal hernia
  • Strangulated bowel: Vascular compromise â†’ ischemia â†’ necrosis â†’ perforation. High mortality if delayed. Look for fever, peritonitis, acidosis
  • Virgin abdomen LBO: Think cancer until proven otherwise. Needs colonoscopy/surgery for diagnosis and treatment
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Septic shock from perforation/ischemia
  • Peritonitis with hemodynamic instability
  • Severe metabolic acidosis (lactate >4)
  • Post-operative complications
  • Multi-organ dysfunction
  • Requiring vasopressors
  • Respiratory failure (aspiration, abdominal compartment syndrome)
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Conservative management successful:
  • Resolution of symptoms (pain, nausea, vomiting)
  • Passing flatus and/or stool
  • Tolerating regular diet without N/V
  • Non-distended, soft abdomen with normal bowel sounds
  • No peritoneal signs
  • Post-operative (if surgery):
  • Return of bowel function
  • Tolerating diet, ambulating
  • Adequate pain control on PO meds
  • Surgical follow-up arranged
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

64. INFLAMMATORY BOWEL DISEASE (IBD) FLARE

Ulcerative Colitis â€¢ Crohn's Disease â€¢ Acute Exacerbation
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

General: Acute worsening of chronic inflammatory bowel disease with increased bowel frequency, abdominal pain, and systemic symptoms

ULCERATIVE COLITIS (UC) FLARE:

  • Classic symptoms: Bloody diarrhea (hallmark), mucus in stool, tenesmus, urgency, lower abdominal cramping
  • Frequency: 10-20+ bloody stools per day in severe flare
  • Distribution: Continuous inflammation starting in rectum, extends proximally (rectum always involved)
  • Systemic features: Fever, tachycardia, weight loss, fatigue, anemia
  • Extraintestinal manifestations: Erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum, uveitis, arthritis, primary sclerosing cholangitis

CROHN'S DISEASE FLARE:

  • Classic symptoms: Abdominal pain (RLQ common if terminal ileum involved), non-bloody diarrhea (unless colonic disease), weight loss
  • Distribution: Skip lesions (patchy inflammation), can affect anywhere from mouth to anus. Terminal ileum most common (70%)
  • Complications: Strictures (obstruction), fistulas (entero-enteric, entero-cutaneous, perianal), abscesses
  • Perianal disease: Fissures, fistulas, abscesses (highly suggestive of Crohn's)
  • Extraintestinal: Similar to UC plus oral aphthous ulcers

SEVERE/FULMINANT COLITIS (UC or Crohn's Colitis) - Medical Emergency:

  • Truelove-Witts Criteria for Severe UC:
    • â‰¥6 bloody stools per day
    • PLUS â‰¥1 of: Fever >37.8Â°C, HR >90, Hgb <10.5 g/dL, ESR >30 mm/hr
  • Signs of toxicity: Severe abdominal pain, distension, peritoneal signs, hypotension, altered mental status
  • Toxic megacolon: Colon dilation >6cm on X-ray + systemic toxicity (fever, tachycardia, leukocytosis). Risk of perforation (25% mortality)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Labs:

  • CBC: Anemia (chronic disease Â± GI bleeding), leukocytosis (flare or steroids), thrombocytosis (inflammation)
  • CMP: Hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia (diarrhea), elevated Cr (dehydration), hypoalbuminemia (malnutrition)
  • Inflammatory markers: CRP, ESR elevated (correlate with disease activity)
  • Stool studies:
    • C. diff PCR: MANDATORY - exclude infectious trigger (common in IBD flares)
    • Stool culture: Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, E. coli O157:H7
    • Ova & parasites: If travel history
    • Fecal calprotectin: Marker of intestinal inflammation (>200-250 mcg/g suggests active disease)
  • Consider: CMV PCR (blood/stool) if steroid-refractory (CMV colitis common in severe UC), blood cultures if febrile

Imaging:

  • Abdominal X-ray (first-line if severe):
    • Assess for toxic megacolon (colon >6 cm), free air (perforation), obstruction
    • Bowel wall thickening, "thumbprinting" (mucosal edema)
  • CT Abdomen/Pelvis with IV contrast:
    • UC: Bowel wall thickening, "target sign," continuous involvement starting rectum
    • Crohn's: Bowel wall thickening, "comb sign" (engorged mesenteric vessels), skip lesions, complications (abscess, fistula, stricture)
    • Evaluate for complications: perforation, abscess, obstruction
  • MR enterography: Better for small bowel Crohn's disease (preferred over CT for young patients)

Endoscopy:

  • Flexible sigmoidoscopy (preferred over colonoscopy in acute severe colitis):
    • Safer than full colonoscopy (lower perforation risk)
    • Assess severity, obtain biopsies to exclude CMV
    • Appearance: UC = continuous erythema, friability, ulceration. Crohn's = skip lesions, cobblestoning
  • Colonoscopy: AVOID in severe acute colitis (high perforation risk). Defer until stabilized
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Initial Management (All Patients):

  • IV Fluids: Aggressive repletion (often 3-6L deficit from diarrhea)
  • Electrolyte replacement: K, Mg aggressively
  • Blood transfusion: If Hgb <7 g/dL or symptomatic anemia
  • Bowel rest (NPO): If severe colitis, obstruction, or pre-operative
  • VTE prophylaxis: IBD is hypercoagulable state - enoxaparin 40 mg SC daily (unless active bleeding)
  • âš ï¸ AVOID:
    • NSAIDs: Can worsen flares
    • Antidiarrheals (loperamide): Risk of toxic megacolon
    • Opioids: Risk of toxic megacolon, ileus

Medical Therapy by Severity:

MILD-MODERATE FLARE (Outpatient Management Usually):

  • 5-ASA (Mesalamine):
    • UC: Mainstay for mild-moderate disease. PO: 2.4-4.8 g/day divided. Rectal: Suppositories (proctitis) or enemas (left-sided)
    • Crohn's: Less effective, not routinely used
  • Prednisone: 40-60 mg PO daily Ã— 1-2 weeks, then taper over 8-12 weeks
  • Budesonide (Crohn's ileal/right colon disease): 9 mg PO daily (lower systemic effects than prednisone)

MODERATE-SEVERE FLARE (Hospitalization Required):

  • IV Corticosteroids (First-Line):
    • Methylprednisolone: 40-60 mg IV daily OR Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV q6-8h
    • Response expected in 3-5 days
    • If no improvement by day 3 â†’ assess for steroid-refractory disease
  • Consider CMV testing: CMV colitis causes steroid-refractory UC. Treat with ganciclovir if positive

SEVERE/STEROID-REFRACTORY DISEASE (Rescue Therapy):

  • Infliximab (Remicade):
    • Anti-TNF biologic, highly effective for steroid-refractory disease
    • Induction: 5 mg/kg IV at weeks 0, 2, 6, then q8 weeks maintenance
    • Response rate 60-70% in acute severe UC
    • Screen for TB, hepatitis B before starting
  • Cyclosporine:
    • Alternative to infliximab (especially if anti-TNF failure)
    • 2 mg/kg/day IV continuous infusion
    • Bridge to maintenance therapy (thiopurines)
    • Requires monitoring: levels, Mg, renal function (nephrotoxic)
  • Consider earlier surgery if not responding to medical rescue therapy

Antibiotics:

  • Crohn's with perianal disease/abscess: Ciprofloxacin 500 mg PO BID + Metronidazole 500 mg PO TID
  • UC: Not routinely indicated unless toxic megacolon, perforation, or sepsis concern
  • If toxic megacolon: Broad-spectrum (pip-tazo 3.375g IV q6h or cefepime 2g q8h + metronidazole 500mg q8h)

ðŸš¨ SURGICAL CONSULTATION for:

  • Toxic megacolon (high perforation risk)
  • Perforation or peritonitis
  • Massive hemorrhage
  • Steroid-refractory disease failing rescue therapy
  • Crohn's complications: Abscess (for drainage), obstruction, fistulas
  • UC surgery = Total colectomy with ileostomy (curative)
  • Crohn's surgery = Resection of diseased segment (NOT curative, high recurrence)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • C. diff is common trigger: Always test! IBD patients have higher rates of C. diff, which can mimic or trigger flare
  • UC = bloody diarrhea, Crohn's = pain/obstruction: Classic distinction but lots of overlap. Crohn's colitis can also have bloody diarrhea
  • Toxic megacolon = surgical emergency: Colon >6cm + systemic toxicity. 25% mortality if perforation. Needs urgent surgery if medical therapy fails
  • IBD is hypercoagulable: 3Ã— risk of VTE. Always give prophylactic anticoagulation unless active major bleeding
  • CMV colitis in steroid-refractory UC: Up to 30% of steroid-refractory UC has CMV. Test for it! Treat with ganciclovir
  • Avoid colonoscopy in acute severe colitis: High perforation risk. Use flexible sigmoidoscopy instead (just to rectosigmoid)
  • UC surgery is curative: Total colectomy removes all disease. Crohn's surgery is NOT curative (can recur anywhere in GI tract)
  • Smoking paradox: Smoking worsens Crohn's but protective for UC. Don't recommend smoking to UC patients though!
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Toxic megacolon
  • Hemodynamic instability/shock
  • Massive GI bleeding requiring transfusion
  • Severe sepsis
  • Peritonitis/perforation (surgical emergency)
  • Multi-organ dysfunction
  • Requiring vasopressors
  • Post-operative monitoring after colectomy
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Decreased stool frequency (<3-4/day)
  • Minimal/no blood in stool
  • Afebrile, hemodynamically stable
  • Tolerating oral diet
  • Pain controlled with oral medications
  • Hgb stable, no transfusion requirement
  • Transitioned to oral steroids (if needed)
  • C. diff negative (if tested)
  • GI follow-up arranged (within 1-2 weeks)
  • Patient educated on maintenance therapy
  • VTE prophylaxis plan if prolonged flare
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

65. TUMOR LYSIS SYNDROME

Oncologic Emergency â€¢ Metabolic Crisis from Tumor Cell Death
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Acute kidney injury, cardiac arrhythmias, seizures, or sudden death in patient with high-burden malignancy within hours-days of starting chemotherapy

Pathophysiology: Massive tumor cell lysis â†’ release of intracellular contents â†’ hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia â†’ AKI, arrhythmias, seizures

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Renal: AKI (most common), oliguria/anuria, fluid overload, uremia. Uric acid and phosphate precipitate in tubules causing obstructive nephropathy
  • Cardiac: Arrhythmias (peaked T-waves, widened QRS from hyperkalemia), cardiac arrest, QT prolongation (from hypocalcemia), heart failure
  • Neurologic: Seizures (hypocalcemia), altered mental status, tetany, muscle cramps, paresthesias
  • GI: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia
  • Neuromuscular: Weakness, tetany, Chvostek/Trousseau signs (hypocalcemia)

High-Risk Malignancies:

  • Highest risk: Burkitt lymphoma, lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma (ALL, T-cell ALL), DLBCL with high tumor burden
  • Moderate-high risk: AML with WBC >25k (especially M4/M5), CLL, bulky solid tumors responsive to chemo (SCLC, germ cell)
  • Key feature: Rapidly dividing tumors with high proliferation rate and chemo-sensitivity

Timing: Usually 12-72 hours after chemotherapy initiation (can be up to 7 days), but can occur spontaneously in high-burden disease

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Cairo-Bishop Classification (Laboratory TLS): â‰¥2 of following metabolic abnormalities within 3 days before or 7 days after chemotherapy:

  • Hyperuricemia: Uric acid >8 mg/dL or 25% increase from baseline
  • Hyperkalemia: K >6 mEq/L or 25% increase
  • Hyperphosphatemia: Phosphate >4.5 mg/dL (adults) or >6.5 mg/dL (children), or 25% increase
  • Hypocalcemia: Corrected calcium <7 mg/dL or 25% decrease

Clinical TLS: Laboratory TLS PLUS one or more of:

  • Increased creatinine (â‰¥1.5Ã— ULN or â‰¥1.5Ã— baseline)
  • Cardiac arrhythmia or sudden death
  • Seizure

Essential Labs (q4-6h initially):

  • CMP: BUN, creatinine, potassium, calcium, phosphate
  • Uric acid: Most sensitive early marker
  • LDH: Marker of cell turnover (very high in TLS)
  • Magnesium: Often low
  • CBC: Track tumor burden (WBC if leukemia)
  • ABG/VBG: Monitor acid-base status

ECG: For hyperkalemia monitoring (peaked T-waves, QRS widening) and hypocalcemia (QT prolongation)

Urinalysis: Uric acid crystals, phosphate crystals, pH

Imaging: Renal ultrasound if concern for obstruction

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

PREVENTION (Best Strategy for High-Risk Patients):

  • Aggressive IV hydration: NS at 200-300 mL/hr (3L/mÂ²/day) starting 24-48 hours BEFORE chemotherapy
  • Goal urine output 80-100 mL/hr (2-3 mL/kg/hr)
  • Continue for 48-72 hours after chemotherapy
  • Avoid: Alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate (historical practice, no longer recommended - increases calcium phosphate precipitation)

Uric Acid Management (Choose ONE):

  • Rasburicase (Elitek) - PREFERRED for high-risk TLS:
    • Dose: 0.1-0.2 mg/kg IV Ã— 1 dose (can repeat daily if needed)
    • Recombinant urate oxidase - converts uric acid to allantoin (10Ã— more soluble)
    • Rapidly lowers uric acid within 4 hours
    • Contraindications: G6PD deficiency (causes severe hemolysis), pregnancy
    • More expensive but much more effective than allopurinol
  • Allopurinol - For LOW-RISK or prophylaxis:
    • Dose: 300 mg PO daily (or 100 mg/mÂ²/dose PO TID, max 800 mg/day)
    • Xanthine oxidase inhibitor - prevents NEW uric acid formation
    • Does NOT treat existing hyperuricemia (takes days to work)
    • Start 1-2 days before chemotherapy

Electrolyte Management:

  • Hyperkalemia:
    • Calcium gluconate 1-2g IV if ECG changes
    • Insulin 10 units + D50 50mL IV
    • Kayexalate 30g PO/PR (slower onset)
    • Albuterol nebs (10-20 mg)
    • Dialysis if refractory or K >6.5 with ECG changes
  • Hyperphosphatemia:
    • Phosphate binders: Sevelamer 800-1600 mg PO TID with meals
    • Avoid calcium-based binders (risk calcium-phosphate precipitation)
    • Dialysis if Phos >10 mg/dL or symptomatic
  • Hypocalcemia:
    • DO NOT give calcium unless symptomatic (seizures, tetany, severe QTc prolongation >500ms)
    • Giving calcium with high phosphate â†’ calcium-phosphate precipitation in tissues/kidneys
    • If must give: Calcium gluconate 1-2g IV slowly

Renal Replacement Therapy:

  • Indications: Refractory hyperkalemia (K >6.5), severe hyperphosphatemia (>10), volume overload, uremia, oliguria/anuria, acidosis
  • CRRT preferred over HD: Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) or hemodialysis (CVVHD) for better hemodynamic stability
  • Intermittent HD acceptable if CRRT unavailable
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Prevention >>> Treatment: Identify high-risk patients BEFORE chemo and start aggressive hydration + rasburicase prophylactically
  • Rasburicase black box: Must screen for G6PD deficiency before giving. Causes catastrophic hemolysis in G6PD patients
  • Don't treat asymptomatic hypocalcemia: Giving calcium with high phosphate causes soft tissue calcification and worsens renal injury
  • LDH as surrogate: Very high LDH (>2-3Ã— ULN) suggests massive tumor burden and high TLS risk
  • Uric acid sampling artifact: If using rasburicase, must place specimen on ice immediately - sample continues to degrade uric acid ex vivo at room temp (falsely low)
  • Alkalinization outdated: No longer recommended - historical practice. Increases calcium-phosphate precipitation
  • TLS can occur spontaneously: Very high-burden tumors (Burkitt, ALL) can cause TLS even before chemotherapy starts
  • Rasburicase Ã— 1 often sufficient: Single dose usually adequate due to long half-life (~16-20 hours)
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Severe hyperkalemia (K >6.5) with ECG changes
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Seizures or altered mental status
  • Oliguric/anuric AKI requiring dialysis
  • Fluid overload with respiratory compromise
  • Need for CRRT/emergent HD
  • Rapidly worsening labs despite treatment
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Labs normalizing or stable (K <5.5, Phos <5, Uric acid <8, Ca >7.5)
  • Creatinine downtrending or at new baseline
  • Adequate urine output maintained
  • No cardiac arrhythmias
  • Tolerating PO (for oral phosphate binders)
  • Close oncology and nephrology follow-up arranged
  • Patient/family education on TLS monitoring
  • Consider if ongoing chemotherapy cycles planned
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

66. THROMBOCYTOPENIA (ITP, HIT, TTP/HUS)

Low Platelets â€¢ Bleeding Risk vs Thrombotic Risk
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Clinical Context is KEY to Diagnosis: Platelets <150k/ÂµL, presentation varies by etiology

IMMUNE THROMBOCYTOPENIA (ITP) - Primary Platelet Destruction:

  • Classic patient: Otherwise healthy young adult (20-40s) or child presenting with isolated thrombocytopenia
  • Presentation: Petechiae, purpura, mucosal bleeding (epistaxis, gingival bleeding), menorrhagia. Major bleeding rare unless platelets <10-20k
  • Key features: NO other cytopenias, NO splenomegaly, patient feels well otherwise
  • Diagnosis of exclusion: Must rule out other causes (HIV, HCV, H. pylori, SLE, drugs, bone marrow disorders)

HEPARIN-INDUCED THROMBOCYTOPENIA (HIT) - Prothrombotic Emergency:

  • Timing: Platelets drop 5-10 days after heparin exposure (any dose, any route including flushes!) OR <24 hours if recent heparin exposure (<100 days ago)
  • Classic drop: Platelets fall >50% from baseline OR absolute count <150k
  • ðŸš¨ PARADOX: Despite low platelets, HIGH risk of THROMBOSIS (30-50%), NOT bleeding!
  • Thrombotic complications:
    • DVT/PE (most common)
    • Arterial thrombosis: Stroke, MI, limb ischemia, mesenteric ischemia
    • Skin necrosis at injection sites
    • Adrenal hemorrhage/infarction
  • 4 T's Score: Thrombocytopenia, Timing, Thrombosis, oTher causes (use to assess pre-test probability)

THROMBOTIC THROMBOCYTOPENIC PURPURA (TTP) - Hematologic Emergency:

  • Classic pentad (only 40% have all 5):
    • Thrombocytopenia (100%)
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia with schistocytes (100%)
    • Neurologic symptoms (60%): Confusion, headache, seizures, stroke, fluctuating mental status
    • Renal dysfunction (40%): Elevated Cr, hematuria, proteinuria
    • Fever (20%)
  • Key features: MAHA (schistocytes on smear) + thrombocytopenia + neuro symptoms = TTP until proven otherwise
  • Demographics: Black females > others, age 30-40s

HEMOLYTIC UREMIC SYNDROME (HUS) - TTP's Renal Cousin:

  • Triad: MAHA + thrombocytopenia + AKI (dominant feature)
  • Classic (Shiga toxin-producing E. coli, STEC-HUS): Follows bloody diarrhea (E. coli O157:H7), predominantly affects children
  • Atypical (aHUS): Complement-mediated, can occur at any age, more severe, worse prognosis
  • Less prominent neurologic symptoms than TTP
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Essential Labs for ALL:

  • CBC with diff and peripheral smear: Look for schistocytes (TTP/HUS), large platelets (ITP), other cytopenias
  • Reticulocyte count: Elevated in hemolysis
  • LDH: Markedly elevated in TTP/HUS (>1000), mildly elevated in ITP
  • Haptoglobin: Low/undetectable in hemolysis
  • Indirect bilirubin: Elevated in hemolysis
  • Direct Coombs (DAT): Negative in TTP/HUS (confirms MAHA), positive in AIHA
  • PT/PTT, fibrinogen: Normal in ITP/HIT/TTP (helps exclude DIC)
  • BMP, Cr: Renal function

ITP-Specific Workup:

  • HIV, HCV, H. pylori testing
  • ANA, direct Coombs (exclude SLE, Evans syndrome)
  • TSH (associated autoimmune thyroid disease)
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Consider if age >60, atypical features, failed to respond to steroids

HIT-Specific Workup:

  • PF4 antibody (HIT antibody): High sensitivity (~95%) but poor specificity. Positive = confirms exposure, not necessarily disease
  • Serotonin release assay (SRA): Gold standard, high specificity but not widely available
  • Timing and clinical context often diagnostic - don't wait for antibody to act
  • Doppler ultrasound: Screen for DVT even if asymptomatic

TTP/HUS-Specific Workup:

  • ADAMTS13 activity: <10% diagnostic of TTP (send before plasmapheresis but don't wait for results)
  • Stool culture/Shiga toxin PCR: For STEC-HUS
  • Complement levels: For atypical HUS (low C3, C4, factor H)
  • Urinalysis: Hematuria, proteinuria, RBC casts
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

IMMUNE THROMBOCYTOPENIA (ITP):

  • Treat if: Platelets <30k OR any bleeding OR high-risk patient (elderly, on anticoagulation)
  • First-line:
    • Corticosteroids: Prednisone 1 mg/kg/day (40-60 mg) Ã— 2-4 weeks, then taper OR Dexamethasone 40 mg PO daily Ã— 4 days
    • Â± IVIG: 1 g/kg IV Ã— 1-2 days (faster response, use if severe bleeding or high-risk)
  • Second-line (steroid-refractory): Rituximab, thrombopoietin receptor agonists (eltrombopag, romiplostim), splenectomy
  • Platelet transfusions: Avoid unless life-threatening bleeding (will be consumed rapidly but may provide temporary hemostasis)
  • If H. pylori positive: Eradication improves platelets in 50% of cases

HEPARIN-INDUCED THROMBOCYTOPENIA (HIT):

  • ðŸš¨ IMMEDIATE ACTIONS:
    • STOP ALL HEPARIN: IV, SC, flushes, heparin-coated catheters
    • DO NOT give platelet transfusions (increases thrombosis risk)
    • START alternative anticoagulation IMMEDIATELY (even without confirmed thrombosis - 30-50% will develop clots)
  • Alternative Anticoagulants (Choose ONE):
    • Argatroban (preferred if hepatic/renal impairment): Direct thrombin inhibitor, start 2 mcg/kg/min, adjust to aPTT 1.5-3Ã— baseline
    • Bivalirudin: Direct thrombin inhibitor, 0.15-0.2 mg/kg/hr
    • Fondaparinux: 5-10 mg SC daily (based on weight), indirect Xa inhibitor
    • DOACs (apixaban, rivaroxaban): Increasing evidence for use, easier to dose
  • Duration: Anticoagulate for â‰¥3 months (longer if thrombosis occurred)
  • Warfarin: DO NOT start until platelets >150k and overlap with argatroban/bivalirudin for 5 days (risk of warfarin-induced limb gangrene)
  • Future surgeries: Can use bivalirudin for cardiac surgery, AVOID all heparin products forever

THROMBOTIC THROMBOCYTOPENIC PURPURA (TTP):

  • ðŸš¨ THIS IS A MEDICAL EMERGENCY - >90% mortality if untreated!
  • URGENT PLASMAPHERESIS (Plasma Exchange):
    • Start immediately, within hours of diagnosis (don't wait for ADAMTS13)
    • Daily treatments (1-1.5 plasma volumes) until platelets normalize and LDH normalizes
    • Average duration: 5-7 days
    • Replaces missing ADAMTS13 enzyme
  • Caplacizumab: Anti-vWF antibody, 10 mg IV bolus before first PLEX, then 10 mg SC daily. Reduces time to platelet recovery
  • Corticosteroids: Prednisone 1 mg/kg daily or methylprednisolone 1g IV daily Ã— 3 days
  • Rituximab: For acquired TTP or refractory cases, 375 mg/mÂ² weekly Ã— 4
  • Platelet transfusions CONTRAINDICATED: Can worsen thrombosis (except life-threatening bleeding)
  • Red cell transfusions: OK if symptomatic anemia

HEMOLYTIC UREMIC SYNDROME (HUS):

  • STEC-HUS (E. coli): Supportive care (hydration, dialysis if needed). Usually self-limited in children. NO antibiotics (may worsen by increasing toxin release)
  • Atypical HUS: Eculizumab (complement C5 inhibitor), 900 mg weekly Ã— 4, then 1200 mg q2 weeks. Must vaccinate for meningococcus first (if time permits)
  • Plasma exchange: Less effective than for TTP but consider in severe atypical HUS
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • MAHA + thrombocytopenia = TTP until proven otherwise: Start plasmapheresis emergently. >90% mortality if untreated
  • HIT is prothrombotic, not bleeding: Paradoxically, low platelets cause clots, not bleeding. STOP heparin and START alternative anticoagulation immediately
  • ITP is diagnosis of exclusion: Must rule out HIV, HCV, SLE, drugs, marrow disorders. Otherwise healthy patient with isolated low platelets
  • Schistocytes = MAHA hallmark: Present in TTP, HUS, DIC, HELLP. Indicates RBC fragmentation from microvascular thrombi
  • Never give platelets in TTP/HIT: Worsens thrombosis ("fuel for the fire")
  • ADAMTS13 <10% = TTP: But don't wait for results - treat empirically if clinical suspicion. Takes days to result
  • HIT 4 T's score: High score (â‰¥6) = ~50% probability of HIT. Low score (<4) = <5% probability. Helps guide testing
  • ITP platelet goal: Treat to prevent bleeding, NOT to normalize counts. Goal >30k, not >150k
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • TTP: All patients until stable
  • Major bleeding (ICH, GI bleed)
  • Neurologic deterioration (TTP)
  • Severe AKI requiring dialysis (HUS)
  • HIT with arterial thrombosis (stroke, limb ischemia, MI)
  • ITP with platelets <10k and bleeding
  • Requiring plasmapheresis
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • ITP: Platelets >30k (or >50k if high bleeding risk), no active bleeding, tolerating oral steroids, heme f/u arranged
  • HIT: Platelets >150k, on therapeutic alternative anticoagulation, no thrombosis, transitioned to warfarin/DOAC if appropriate
  • TTP: Platelets normalized, LDH normalized, no neuro symptoms, completed PLEX course, heme f/u
  • HUS: Cr improving/stable, no dialysis need, hemolysis resolving
  • Patient educated on avoiding triggers
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

67. DISSEMINATED INTRAVASCULAR COAGULATION (DIC)

Consumptive Coagulopathy â€¢ Thrombosis + Bleeding
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Bleeding (oozing from IV sites, venipuncture, mucosal bleeding, petechiae, ecchymoses) AND thrombosis (digital ischemia, renal failure, ARDS, stroke) in critically ill patient

Spectrum:

  • Acute DIC (decompensated): Severe bleeding Â± thrombosis, rapid onset, life-threatening
  • Chronic DIC (compensated): Mild symptoms, often thrombotic >bleeding, seen in malignancy

Clinical Features:

  • Bleeding (dominant in acute DIC): Diffuse petechiae, purpura, oozing from wounds/IV sites/mucosa, GI bleed, intracranial hemorrhage
  • Thrombosis (microvascular): Digital/acral ischemia, renal failure, ARDS, hepatic dysfunction, altered mental status
  • Multi-organ dysfunction: Due to microvascular thrombosis

Common Underlying Causes (ALWAYS present):

  • Sepsis (most common): Gram-negative>gram-positive, especially meningococcemia
  • Trauma: Massive tissue injury, burns, head trauma, crush injury
  • Obstetric: Placental abruption, amniotic fluid embolism, retained dead fetus, HELLP syndrome
  • Malignancy: Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), adenocarcinomas (pancreas, prostate, lung), mucin-producing tumors
  • Vascular: Giant hemangioma (Kasabach-Merritt), aortic aneurysm, large vessel malformations
  • Toxic: Snake venom, drug reactions, transfusion reactions
  • Immunologic: Severe allergic reactions, ABO-incompatible transfusion
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

DIC Score (ISTH Criteria) - Score â‰¥5 = overt DIC:

  • Platelets: >100k (0 pts), 50-100k (1 pt), <50k (2 pts)
  • D-dimer: No increase (0), moderate increase (2), strong increase (3)
  • PT prolongation: <3 sec (0), 3-6 sec (1), >6 sec (2)
  • Fibrinogen: >100 mg/dL (0), <100 mg/dL (1)

Laboratory Findings (Typical Pattern):

  • Thrombocytopenia: Progressive decline, often <100k (hallmark finding)
  • PT/PTT prolonged: Due to consumption of clotting factors
  • Fibrinogen LOW: Usually <100 mg/dL (but can be normal initially as it's an acute phase reactant)
  • D-dimer VERY elevated: Markedly increased (>10Ã— normal), indicates fibrinolysis
  • Peripheral smear: Schistocytes (fragmented RBCs) present in 50% - suggests microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Factor levels LOW: Factors II, V, VIII, X consumed (rarely checked)

Essential Labs: CBC with diff, PT/INR, PTT, fibrinogen, D-dimer, peripheral smear, LDH, haptoglobin (hemolysis), DIC panel

Identify Underlying Cause: Blood cultures, imaging for trauma/malignancy, pregnancy test, evaluate for sepsis source

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

ðŸŽ¯ TREAT THE UNDERLYING CAUSE - This is PRIMARY therapy:

  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics for sepsis
  • Delivery of fetus/placenta in obstetric emergencies
  • Chemotherapy for APL (all-trans retinoic acid)
  • Source control for trauma/surgery

Supportive Care:

  • Aggressive hemodynamic support
  • Maintain tissue perfusion and oxygenation
  • Avoid unnecessary procedures/lines if possible

Blood Product Replacement (Threshold-Based):

  • Platelets:
    • Transfuse if <10-20k (spontaneous bleeding risk)
    • OR <50k with active bleeding or planned procedure
    • Goal: Keep >50k if active bleeding
    • Give 1 apheresis unit or 4-6 units pooled platelets
  • FFP (Fresh Frozen Plasma):
    • If PT/PTT >1.5Ã— normal AND active bleeding or planned procedure
    • Dose: 15-20 mL/kg (typically 4 units for adults)
    • Replaces all clotting factors
  • Cryoprecipitate:
    • If fibrinogen <100 mg/dL AND active bleeding
    • Dose: 10 units (1 unit raises fibrinogen ~5-10 mg/dL)
    • Goal fibrinogen >100-150 mg/dL
  • PRBCs: Transfuse for symptomatic anemia or Hgb <7 g/dL

Anticoagulation (Controversial, Limited Indications):

  • NOT routinely recommended in most DIC
  • Consider heparin ONLY IF:
    • Chronic/compensated DIC with thrombosis (e.g., cancer-associated)
    • Acral ischemia with threatened limb loss
    • Purpura fulminans
  • Dose: Unfractionated heparin 300-500 units/hr (no bolus) OR prophylactic LMWH
  • Contraindications: Active major bleeding, intracranial hemorrhage, severe thrombocytopenia (<20k)

Antifibrinolytics (Generally AVOID):

  • Tranexamic acid/aminocaproic acid usually contraindicated
  • May worsen thrombosis
  • Exception: APL with severe hyperfibrinolysis (rare)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • DIC is NEVER a primary diagnosis: Always find and treat the underlying cause. DIC won't resolve until the trigger is addressed
  • Lab pattern: â†“Plts + â†“Fibrinogen + â†‘D-dimer + â†‘PT/PTT = classic DIC tetrad
  • Fibrinogen paradox: Can be normal/elevated early (acute phase reactant) - serial monitoring shows TREND down
  • Schistocytes â‰  mandatory: Only 50% have schistocytes. Absence doesn't exclude DIC
  • Don't chase numbers blindly: Transfuse based on clinical bleeding + thresholds, not just to normalize labs
  • APL = special case: High risk of DIC at diagnosis. Start ATRA immediately, supportive with aggressive platelet/cryoprecipitate transfusions
  • Heparin paradox: Despite being a clotting disorder, anticoagulation rarely helps and often harms
  • Mortality high: 30-50% depending on cause. Septic DIC has worst prognosis
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Active major bleeding (GI, ICH, pulmonary)
  • Severe thrombocytopenia (<20k)
  • Multi-organ dysfunction (ARDS, AKI, altered mental status)
  • Refractory hypotension/shock
  • Requiring massive transfusion
  • Septic shock with DIC
  • Rapidly progressive coagulopathy
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Unlikely for acute DIC - usually requires ICU-level care
  • For chronic/compensated DIC:
  • Underlying cause identified and treated
  • No active bleeding
  • Stable platelet count (>50k trending up)
  • Coagulation parameters improving
  • Hematology follow-up arranged
  • If malignancy-related: oncology follow-up
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

68. ACUTE GOUT/PSEUDOGOUT (CRYSTAL ARTHROPATHY)

Acute Monoarticular Arthritis â€¢ Crystal-Induced Synovitis
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Acute-onset severe monoarticular joint pain, erythema, warmth, and swelling (develops over 6-12 hours) with exquisite tenderness and limited range of motion

GOUT (Monosodium Urate Crystals):

  • Most affected joints: 1st MTP joint (podagra - 50% of first attacks), midfoot, ankle, knee
  • Presentation: "Worst pain of my life," cannot tolerate even bedsheet touching joint, pain peaks at 24 hours
  • Timing: Often overnight/early morning, awakens patient from sleep
  • Appearance: Red, hot, swollen, shiny skin over joint
  • Chronic findings: Tophi (firm subcutaneous nodules) on ears, elbows, fingers, Achilles tendon
  • Risk factors: Hyperuricemia (>7 mg/dL), obesity, HTN, CKD, diuretics, alcohol (beer), high purine diet (red meat, seafood)
  • Precipitants: Surgery, acute illness, dehydration, alcohol binge, starting allopurinol/febuxostat

PSEUDOGOUT (Calcium Pyrophosphate Deposition - CPPD):

  • Most affected joints: Knee (50%), wrist, shoulder, ankle
  • Presentation: Similar to gout but often less severe, longer duration (days-weeks vs hours-days)
  • Demographics: Elderly patients (>65 years), more common in women
  • Associated conditions: Hyperparathyroidism, hemochromatosis, hypomagnesemia, hypothyroidism
  • Chronic: Chondrocalcinosis on X-ray (calcium deposition in cartilage)

Important: Can mimic septic arthritis! Must differentiate. Consider septic arthritis if fever >39Â°C, systemic toxicity, immunocompromised, prosthetic joint

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

ðŸŽ¯ GOLD STANDARD: Arthrocentesis with Synovial Fluid Analysis

  • ALWAYS PERFORM if: First attack, uncertain diagnosis, concern for septic arthritis, fever, immunocompromised
  • Safe to tap even on anticoagulation: Benefit >> risk

Synovial Fluid Analysis:

  • Crystal analysis (polarized microscopy - DIAGNOSTIC):
    • Gout: Needle-shaped, negatively birefringent (yellow under parallel light), intracellular and extracellular
    • Pseudogout: Rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent (blue under parallel light), often weakly birefringent
  • Cell count: WBC typically 20,000-100,000/ÂµL (inflammatory), predominantly PMNs (>80%)
  • Gram stain and culture: MUST send to rule out septic arthritis (can coexist with gout ~5%!)
  • Appearance: Cloudy to purulent

Labs:

  • Serum uric acid: Often elevated (>7 mg/dL) BUT can be normal during acute attack in 30-40%! Do NOT use to rule in/out
  • CBC: May have mild leukocytosis (10-15k)
  • CRP/ESR: Elevated (non-specific inflammatory markers)
  • BMP: Check renal function before NSAIDs/colchicine
  • For pseudogout: Calcium, phosphate, magnesium, PTH, TSH, iron studies (if <50 years old)

Imaging:

  • X-ray of affected joint:
    • Gout (chronic): Punched-out erosions with overhanging edges, soft tissue tophi
    • Pseudogout: Chondrocalcinosis (linear calcium in cartilage, "meniscus sign" in knee)
    • May be normal in acute flare
  • Ultrasound: Can show "double contour sign" (urate deposition on cartilage) - sensitive for gout
  • Consider MRI: If concern for septic arthritis, osteomyelitis
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Acute Attack Treatment (Choose ONE anti-inflammatory):

Option 1: NSAIDs (First-line if no contraindications):

  • Indomethacin: 50 mg PO TID Ã— 2-3 days, then 25 mg TID until resolved (traditional choice)
  • Naproxen: 500 mg PO BID
  • Ibuprofen: 800 mg PO TID
  • Use for 5-7 days or until 1-2 days after complete resolution
  • Contraindications: CKD (Cr >1.5), active PUD, heart failure, on anticoagulation
  • Add PPI for gastric protection

Option 2: Colchicine (Effective if started within 36 hours of attack):

  • Loading dose: 1.2 mg PO, then 0.6 mg 1 hour later (total 1.8 mg day 1)
  • Maintenance: 0.6 mg PO BID or daily until resolved
  • Side effects: Diarrhea (dose-limiting), nausea - very common. GI symptoms often as bad as gout!
  • Dose reduction needed: CKD (0.3-0.6 mg daily), hepatic impairment
  • Interactions: Avoid with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (clarithromycin, cyclosporine - risk of toxicity)

Option 3: Corticosteroids (If NSAIDs/colchicine contraindicated):

  • Intra-articular injection (preferred for monoarticular):
    • Triamcinolone 40 mg for large joints (knee, shoulder)
    • 20 mg for medium joints, 10 mg for small joints
    • Dramatic improvement within 24-48 hours
    • Must rule out septic arthritis first!
  • Systemic steroids:
    • Prednisone 30-40 mg PO daily Ã— 5-7 days (can taper over 10-14 days)
    • OR Methylprednisolone 100-150 mg IM Ã— 1
    • Good for polyarticular gout or when IA injection not feasible

Adjunct Therapy:

  • Ice packs: 15-20 minutes several times daily
  • Rest and elevation: Avoid weight-bearing on affected joint
  • Adequate hydration: Helps uric acid excretion

âš ï¸ DO NOT Start Uric Acid-Lowering Therapy (Allopurinol/Febuxostat) During Acute Attack:

  • Will prolong or worsen acute flare
  • Wait 2-4 weeks after flare resolves
  • If already on ULT: Continue it (don't stop)
  • When starting ULT: Always give prophylactic colchicine 0.6 mg daily Ã— 3-6 months to prevent flares

Long-Term Management (Outpatient):

  • Indications for ULT: â‰¥2 attacks/year, tophi, chronic kidney disease, uric acid >9 mg/dL, urolithiasis
  • Allopurinol: Start 100 mg daily, titrate up by 100 mg q2-4 weeks to goal uric acid <6 mg/dL (max 800 mg/day)
  • Febuxostat: 40-80 mg daily (more expensive, alternative if allopurinol intolerant)
  • Lifestyle: Weight loss, limit alcohol (especially beer), reduce red meat/seafood, stay hydrated
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Normal uric acid â‰  excludes gout: 30-40% have normal levels during acute attack due to uricosuria. Diagnosis is by crystals, not serum uric acid
  • Tap before you treat: If first attack or uncertain diagnosis, arthrocentesis is essential. Septic arthritis can coexist with gout
  • Never start allopurinol during flare: Will worsen/prolong attack. Wait until 2-4 weeks after resolution. But if already on it, continue
  • Colchicine dosing changed: Old regimen (1.2 mg then 0.6 mg q1h) caused terrible diarrhea. New low-dose regimen (1.8 mg total day 1) equally effective with fewer GI side effects
  • Intra-articular steroids are magic: Work fast (24-48h), avoid systemic effects, excellent for monoarticular flares. But must rule out infection first!
  • Uric acid >9 = always treat: These patients will have recurrent attacks. Need chronic ULT
  • Diuretics = gout trigger: Especially thiazides and loops. Cause uric acid retention. Consider stopping if recurrent gout
  • Pseudogout in elderly: Think CPPD if knee arthritis in 70+ year old, especially women. X-ray shows chondrocalcinosis
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Septic arthritis cannot be ruled out with high clinical suspicion
  • Polyarticular flare with systemic toxicity
  • Severe pain refractory to multiple therapies
  • Most gout patients do NOT need ICU
  • Consider admission to floor for IV steroids if:
  • - Unable to take PO medications
  • - Failed outpatient management
  • - Severe polyarticular disease
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Pain controlled with oral medications
  • Septic arthritis excluded (if tapped)
  • Able to ambulate (or baseline mobility)
  • Discharge prescriptions:
  • - NSAID OR colchicine OR prednisone Ã— 5-7 days
  • - PPI if on NSAID
  • - Pain control (avoid opioids if possible)
  • Rheumatology or PCP follow-up in 2-4 weeks
  • Discussed avoiding ULT initiation until flare resolves
  • Lifestyle modifications reviewed
ðŸ“– Drug Reference: ðŸ’Š Colchicine, ðŸ’Š Gout Medications, ðŸ’Š Prednisone
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

69. ANAPHYLAXIS

Systemic Type I Hypersensitivity â€¢ Life-Threatening Allergic Reaction
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Triad: Acute-onset (<2 hours) involving â‰¥2 organ systems: skin/mucosa + respiratory/cardiovascular/GI

Diagnostic Criteria (any ONE):

  • Criterion 1: Acute onset (minutes-hours) with skin/mucosa involvement PLUS â‰¥1 of: respiratory compromise OR hypotension/end-organ dysfunction
  • Criterion 2: â‰¥2 of following after likely allergen exposure: skin/mucosa, respiratory compromise, hypotension, GI symptoms
  • Criterion 3: Hypotension after exposure to KNOWN allergen

Organ System Manifestations:

  • Skin (80-90%): Urticaria, pruritus, flushing, angioedema (lips, tongue, uvula). Note: 10-20% have NO skin findings!
  • Respiratory (70%): Dyspnea, wheeze, stridor, throat tightness, hoarseness, cough. Upper airway edema can be LETHAL
  • Cardiovascular (30-35%): Hypotension, tachycardia, dizziness, syncope, chest pain, cardiac arrest
  • GI (25-30%): Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, cramping abdominal pain
  • Neurologic: Altered mental status, confusion, "sense of impending doom"

Common Triggers: Foods (peanuts, tree nuts, shellfish, fish), medications (Î²-lactams, NSAIDs, chemotherapy), venoms (Hymenoptera), radiocontrast, latex

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical Diagnosis: Do NOT delay treatment for diagnostic testing! Anaphylaxis is a CLINICAL diagnosis

Serum Tryptase:

  • Draw within 15 min - 3 hours of symptom onset (peak 1-2 hours)
  • Elevated >11.4 ng/mL suggests mast cell degranulation
  • Also draw baseline tryptase 24+ hours later for comparison
  • Sensitivity only 60-70%, so NORMAL level does NOT exclude anaphylaxis

Initial Labs: CBC, CMP, ABG/VBG if respiratory distress, troponin if chest pain/older patient

Consider: Chest X-ray if wheezing (to exclude other causes), ECG if cardiovascular symptoms

Allergy Testing: Outpatient referral for skin testing and allergen-specific IgE 4-6 weeks after event

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

âš¡ EPINEPHRINE IS FIRST-LINE - Give IMMEDIATELY:

  • Epinephrine 1:1000 (1 mg/mL) IM: 0.3-0.5 mg (0.3-0.5 mL) into anterolateral thigh, repeat q5-15min PRN
  • Pediatric: 0.01 mg/kg IM (max 0.3 mg), repeat q5-15min
  • IM route preferred over SC (faster absorption)
  • NO absolute contraindications - benefits outweigh risks even with CV disease
  • If refractory after 2-3 doses â†’ consider IV epinephrine infusion

Aggressive IV Fluid Resuscitation:

  • 1-2 liters NS rapid bolus (adults), then continue at 200-300 mL/hr
  • Massive capillary leak can cause 35% plasma volume loss in 10 minutes!
  • May need 4-6 liters in first hour

Airway Management:

  • Monitor closely for upper airway obstruction (stridor, voice changes, drooling)
  • Early intubation if signs of airway edema - can rapidly progress to complete obstruction
  • Have difficult airway equipment ready - angioedema makes intubation challenging
  • Consider cricothyrotomy if cannot intubate

Adjunct Medications (NOT substitutes for epinephrine):

  • H1 antihistamine: Diphenhydramine 25-50 mg IV/IM/PO (peds: 1 mg/kg max 50mg)
  • H2 antihistamine: Famotidine 20 mg IV or ranitidine 50 mg IV
  • Corticosteroids: Methylprednisolone 125 mg IV or hydrocortisone 200 mg IV (may prevent biphasic reaction, but NOT acute therapy)
  • Bronchodilators: Albuterol nebulizer for persistent bronchospasm
  • Glucagon (if on Î²-blocker): 1-5 mg IV bolus over 5 min, then 5-15 mcg/min infusion (bypasses Î²-receptors)

Refractory Hypotension:

  • Epinephrine infusion: 0.1-1 mcg/kg/min (start low, titrate up)
  • Consider vasopressin 0.01-0.04 units/min if epinephrine-resistant

Patient on Î²-Blocker: May be refractory to epinephrine. Give glucagon AND higher/repeated doses of epinephrine

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Epinephrine has NO absolute contraindications: Even in elderly/cardiac patients, benefits far outweigh risks. Delay = death
  • Biphasic reactions occur in 5-20%: Second wave 4-12 hours later. Observe ALL patients â‰¥4-6 hours (longer if severe)
  • IM thigh > SC arm: Anterolateral thigh gives faster, more reliable absorption than subcutaneous deltoid
  • Antihistamines/steroids are NOT first-line: They do not reverse anaphylaxis. Epinephrine is the ONLY life-saving drug
  • Î²-blockers complicate treatment: Blunt response to epinephrine and may cause paradoxical bradycardia. Give glucagon
  • ACE-I patients: More severe/prolonged reactions due to impaired bradykinin degradation
  • Idiopathic anaphylaxis: 30-50% of cases - no identifiable trigger despite workup
  • Tryptase timing: Peak 1-2 hours, returns to baseline by 12-24 hours. Too early or too late = false negative
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Requiring repeat IM epinephrine (â‰¥2 doses)
  • Need for continuous IV epinephrine
  • Respiratory distress/airway edema
  • Persistent hypotension despite fluids
  • Dysrhythmias or cardiac arrest
  • Severe presentation or delayed response to treatment
  • Patient on Î²-blocker with poor response
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Complete resolution of symptoms Ã— 4-6 hours minimum (longer if severe)
  • Hemodynamically stable without pressors
  • Normal respiratory status, no wheezing
  • Received steroids and antihistamines
  • MUST PRESCRIBE: EpiPen Ã— 2 (0.3 mg for adults, 0.15 mg if <30 kg) with training on use
  • Anaphylaxis action plan provided
  • Allergy/immunology referral scheduled
  • Discussed trigger avoidance and medical alert bracelet
ðŸ“– Drug Reference: ðŸ’Š Epinephrine
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

70. DRUG OVERDOSE/TOXIDROMES

Acetaminophen â€¢ Salicylates â€¢ Tricyclic Antidepressants â€¢ Common Toxidromes
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

General Approach: Identify toxidrome by vital signs and physical exam, then narrow differential and treat

COMMON TOXIDROMES:

  • Anticholinergic ("Hot as a hare, Blind as a bat, Dry as a bone, Red as a beet, Mad as a hatter"):
    • Causes: TCAs, antihistamines (diphenhydramine), atropine, scopolamine, jimson weed
    • Signs: Hyperthermia, mydriasis, dry skin/mucosa, flushed, urinary retention, decreased bowel sounds, altered mental status/delirium
  • Cholinergic ("SLUDGE" + "DUMBELS"):
    • Causes: Organophosphates, carbamates, nerve agents
    • SLUDGE: Salivation, Lacrimation, Urination, Defecation, GI distress, Emesis
    • DUMBELS: Defecation, Urination, Miosis, Bradycardia/Bronchospasm, Emesis, Lacrimation, Salivation
    • Also: Fasciculations, muscle weakness, seizures
  • Sympathomimetic:
    • Causes: Cocaine, amphetamines, methamphetamine, synthetic cathinones ("bath salts"), MDMA
    • Signs: HTN, tachycardia, hyperthermia, mydriasis, diaphoresis, agitation, seizures
  • Sedative-Hypnotic:
    • Causes: Benzodiazepines, barbiturates, GHB, ethanol
    • Signs: CNS depression, respiratory depression, hypotension, hypothermia, normal pupils

ACETAMINOPHEN OVERDOSE - Silent Killer:

  • Stages:
    • Stage 1 (0-24h): Asymptomatic or N/V, malaise
    • Stage 2 (24-72h): RUQ pain, elevated LFTs/INR
    • Stage 3 (72-96h): Fulminant hepatic failure, encephalopathy, coagulopathy, death
    • Stage 4 (>5 days): Recovery OR need for transplant
  • Toxic dose: >7.5-10g in adults (>150 mg/kg in children) or >4g/day chronically

SALICYLATE OVERDOSE (Aspirin):

  • Classic triad: Altered mental status, tachypnea (respiratory alkalosis), metabolic acidosis
  • Symptoms: Tinnitus, vertigo, nausea, vomiting, diaphoresis, hyperpnea, confusion, seizures, pulmonary edema
  • Lab findings: Mixed respiratory alkalosis + metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), hypokalemia, hypoglycemia (or hyperglycemia)

TRICYCLIC ANTIDEPRESSANT (TCA) OVERDOSE:

  • Triad of death: Seizures, cardiac arrhythmias (wide-complex), hypotension
  • Anticholinergic signs PLUS cardiac toxicity
  • ECG findings: QRS widening >100ms (predicts seizures/arrhythmias), terminal R wave in aVR, QTc prolongation
  • Agents: Amitriptyline, nortriptyline, imipramine, doxepin
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

ALL Overdose Patients:

  • Vitals + repeat q15-30min: BP, HR, RR, temp, O2 sat, glucose
  • ECG: QRS width, QTc, arrhythmias
  • Labs: CBC, CMP, VBG (check pH, lactate), acetaminophen level, salicylate level, ethanol level
  • Urine drug screen: Limited utility (many false +/-, doesn't detect levels). Don't let it guide treatment
  • Specific levels when indicated: Digoxin, lithium, theophylline, iron, valproic acid, carbamazepine

Acetaminophen Specific:

  • 4-hour acetaminophen level: Plot on Rumack-Matthew nomogram to determine need for NAC
  • Level >150 mcg/mL at 4 hours = treat
  • LFTs, PT/INR: Baseline and serial (q12-24h)
  • If unknown timing or chronic ingestion â†’ treat empirically if level >10 mcg/mL

Salicylate Specific:

  • Salicylate level: >30 mg/dL = moderate, >70 mg/dL = severe. Repeat q2-4h until trending down (bezoar concern)
  • ABG/VBG: Look for mixed acid-base (respiratory alkalosis + metabolic acidosis)
  • Urine pH (if available)

TCA Specific:

  • Serial ECGs: QRS >100ms bad prognostic sign
  • TCA levels NOT helpful for acute management
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

GENERAL SUPPORTIVE CARE (All Patients):

  • ABCs: Airway protection, ventilatory support, IV access
  • Dextrose: Check glucose, give D50 50mL IV if hypoglycemic or altered
  • Naloxone: 0.4-2 mg IV/IM/IN if concern for opioid (see separate opioid section)
  • Thiamine: 100 mg IV before dextrose (if concern for alcohol use/malnutrition)
  • Benzodiazepines: For agitation, seizures (lorazepam 2-4 mg IV q5-10min PRN)

GI DECONTAMINATION:

  • Activated charcoal: 1 g/kg (50-100g) PO/NGT if <1-2 hours since ingestion AND protected airway
    • Contraindications: Unprotected airway, ileus, GI perforation/obstruction, caustic ingestion
    • NOT effective for: Alcohols, lithium, iron, heavy metals
  • Gastric lavage: Rarely indicated (only massive life-threatening ingestion <1 hour)
  • Whole bowel irrigation: Polyethylene glycol (GoLYTELY) for sustained-release pills, iron, lithium, body packers

ACETAMINOPHEN OVERDOSE - N-Acetylcysteine (NAC):

  • Indications: 4-hour level above treatment line on nomogram OR >10 mcg/mL with unknown time OR any evidence of hepatotoxicity
  • IV Protocol (preferred):
    • Loading: 150 mg/kg in 200mL D5W over 60 minutes
    • Second: 50 mg/kg in 500mL D5W over 4 hours
    • Third: 100 mg/kg in 1000mL D5W over 16 hours
    • Total 21-hour protocol
  • PO Protocol: 140 mg/kg load, then 70 mg/kg q4h Ã— 17 doses (72 hours total)
  • Anaphylactoid reactions common with IV NAC (15-20%) - slow/stop infusion, give antihistamines, restart slower
  • Monitor: LFTs, PT/INR q12-24h. Can stop NAC once acetaminophen undetectable AND LFTs improving/normal

SALICYLATE OVERDOSE:

  • IV Fluids: Aggressive hydration with D5 Â½ NS (dextrose to prevent CNS hypoglycemia despite normal serum glucose)
  • Urinary Alkalinization (Key Treatment):
    • Goal urine pH 7.5-8.0 (traps ionized salicylate in urine â†’ increases excretion)
    • Add 150 mEq (3 amps) NaHCOâ‚ƒ to 1L D5W, run at 200-250 mL/hr
    • May need additional IV bicarbonate boluses
    • Replete potassium aggressively (hypokalemia prevents alkalinization)
  • Hemodialysis indications:
    • Salicylate level >100 mg/dL (acute) or >70 mg/dL (chronic)
    • Severe acidosis (pH <7.2)
    • AKI/ESRD
    • Pulmonary edema
    • Severe CNS symptoms (seizures, coma)
    • Failure of urinary alkalinization
  • Avoid: Aspirin-containing products, acidifying agents

TRICYCLIC ANTIDEPRESSANT (TCA) OVERDOSE:

  • Sodium Bicarbonate (Antidote for QRS Widening):
    • Indications: QRS >100ms, ventricular arrhythmias, hypotension
    • 1-2 mEq/kg (1-2 amps = 50-100 mEq) IV bolus, repeat q3-5min until QRS narrows
    • Then continuous infusion: 150 mEq (3 amps) in 1L D5W
    • Goal: Serum pH 7.50-7.55 (alkalemia counteracts sodium channel blockade)
    • Monitor serial ECGs
  • Seizures: Benzodiazepines (lorazepam 2-4 mg IV), avoid phenytoin (may worsen cardiac toxicity)
  • Hypotension: IV fluids + norepinephrine (vasopressor of choice)
  • Arrhythmias:
    • Sodium bicarbonate (first-line)
    • Lidocaine for refractory VT
    • AVOID: Class IA (procainamide, quinidine) and IC (flecainide) antiarrhythmics
  • Intralipid emulsion: 20% lipid emulsion 1.5 mL/kg bolus for refractory cardiac arrest

Poison Control: Call 1-800-222-1222 for all serious overdoses

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Acetaminophen = #1 overdose in US: Often intentional, but also accidental from multiple sources (Tylenol + Percocet + cold meds). Low threshold to check level
  • NAC is NOT toxic: Give liberally. If ANY doubt about toxicity â†’ treat. Can give even days later if hepatotoxicity present
  • Salicylate paradox: Serum glucose normal/high but CNS hypoglycemia â†’ always give dextrose in fluids
  • Urinary alkalinization KEY for salicylates: More important than dialysis for most cases. But can't alkalinize if hypokalemic â†’ repleteK aggressively
  • TCA "3 C's of treatment": Charcoal (if early), Cardiac monitoring, biCarbonate (for wide QRS)
  • QRS width predicts TCA toxicity: QRS >100ms = seizures and arrhythmias imminent. Push bicarb immediately
  • Don't trust urine drug screens: Many false positives/negatives. Treat the patient, not the test
  • Acetaminophen nomogram only works for single acute ingestion: If chronic ingestion or unknown time â†’ treat if level >10 mcg/mL
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Altered mental status or coma
  • Seizures
  • Hemodynamic instability/shock
  • Respiratory failure or need for intubation
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • TCA overdose with QRS widening
  • Severe salicylate toxicity needing dialysis
  • Acetaminophen with hepatotoxicity (elevated LFTs/INR)
  • Need for continuous cardiac monitoring
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Acetaminophen: Completed NAC protocol, LFTs normal/improving, PT/INR normal, asymptomatic
  • Salicylate: Level <30 mg/dL and trending down, normal acid-base, asymptomatic
  • TCA: Asymptomatic Ã— 6 hours, normal ECG, no QRS widening
  • General: Normal vital signs, mental status at baseline, no suicidal ideation
  • Psych evaluation: Completed if intentional ingestion
  • Close follow-up arranged
  • Poison Control contacted (for intentional)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

71. OPIOID OVERDOSE/WITHDRAWAL

Opioid Toxicity â€¢ Opioid Withdrawal Syndrome
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

OPIOID OVERDOSE - "Classic Triad":

  • CNS depression: Altered mental status, drowsiness, coma (GCS <15)
  • Respiratory depression: Bradypnea (RR <12), shallow breathing, hypoxia, apnea
  • Miosis: Pinpoint pupils (2-3mm) - highly specific but not 100% sensitive

Additional Features:

  • Cardiovascular: Bradycardia, hypotension (usually mild)
  • Decreased bowel sounds
  • Hypothermia
  • Pulmonary edema: Can occur, especially with heroin ("heroin lung")
  • Track marks: May be present in IV drug users

Common Agents:

  • Prescription: Oxycodone, hydrocodone, morphine, hydromorphone (Dilaudid), fentanyl, methadone, tramadol
  • Illicit: Heroin, illicit fentanyl (50-100Ã— more potent than morphine), carfentanil
  • Special concern: Fentanyl-laced pills ("pressed pills" sold as oxycodone/Xanax) â†’ epidemic of overdose deaths

Exceptions to Miosis:

  • Meperidine (Demerol): Can cause mydriasis
  • Tramadol: Serotonergic properties, may have normal/dilated pupils
  • Severe hypoxia/anoxia: Pupils dilate due to brain injury
  • Co-ingestion with anticholinergics: Dilated pupils

OPIOID WITHDRAWAL - Miserable but NOT Life-Threatening:

  • Timing: Onset 6-12 hours after last short-acting opioid (heroin), 24-48 hours for long-acting (methadone)
  • Peak: 36-72 hours, duration 5-10 days
  • Symptoms ("flu-like"):
    • Early: Anxiety, restlessness, yawning, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, diaphoresis, mydriasis
    • Late: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal cramping, myalgias, piloerection ("goose flesh"), tachycardia, HTN, fever
  • Key: Uncomfortable but NOT dangerous (unlike alcohol/benzo withdrawal which CAN be fatal)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

OVERDOSE - Clinical Diagnosis:

  • Don't wait for confirmatory testing - TREAT clinically!
  • Essential: Vitals (RR most important), pulse ox, glucose, ECG
  • ABG/VBG: If severe respiratory depression (assess pCOâ‚‚, hypercapnia)
  • Labs: CBC, CMP, lactate, acetaminophen level (co-ingestion common with prescription opioids), salicylate, ethanol
  • Urine drug screen:
    • Often positive but NOT required for treatment
    • Caveats: Fentanyl/methadone often NOT detected on standard screens. Screens typically only detect morphine, codeine, hydromorphone
    • Synthetic opioids require special testing
  • CXR: If hypoxia persists after naloxone (pulmonary edema, aspiration)
  • Head CT: If no response to naloxone, concern for trauma/intracranial pathology

WITHDRAWAL - Clinical Diagnosis + Assessment:

  • COWS (Clinical Opiate Withdrawal Scale): Objective scoring tool
    • Score 5-12 = mild, 13-24 = moderate, 25-36 = moderately severe, >36 = severe
    • Assesses: VS, GI upset, tremor, restlessness, pupil size, anxiety, gooseflesh, etc.
  • Labs usually not needed unless concern for complications
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

OPIOID OVERDOSE:

Immediate Resuscitation:

  • Airway/Breathing:
    • Bag-valve-mask ventilation if apneic/severe respiratory depression
    • Supplemental Oâ‚‚ to maintain SpOâ‚‚ >90%
    • Consider intubation if no response to naloxone or prolonged
  • IV access, monitor

ðŸŽ¯ NALOXONE (Narcan) - Opioid Antagonist:

  • Indications: Respiratory depression (RR <12) OR coma/unresponsive from suspected opioid
  • IV/IM/SC dosing:
    • Start: 0.04-0.4 mg IV, titrate up by 0.4 mg q2-3min until respiratory drive restored
    • Goal: Adequate respiration (RR >12), NOT full reversal/consciousness
    • Maximum: 10 mg (if no response after 10 mg, reconsider diagnosis)
  • Intranasal: 4 mg (1 spray) in each nostril, repeat q2-3min PRN (easier for EMS/lay public)
  • IM/SC: 0.4-2 mg, repeat q2-3min PRN (if no IV access)
  • Duration: 30-90 minutes (shorter than most opioids!) â†’ re-sedation common
    • Especially with long-acting opioids (methadone, sustained-release formulations, fentanyl)
    • May need continuous naloxone infusion (2/3 of effective bolus dose per hour)
  • Caution: Naloxone precipitates acute withdrawal in opioid-dependent patients (uncomfortable but not dangerous). Use lowest effective dose

Observation Period:

  • Short-acting opioids (heroin, oxycodone): Observe 4-6 hours after last naloxone dose
  • Long-acting opioids (methadone, fentanyl, sustained-release): Admit for 24 hours monitoring
  • Watch for re-sedation, respiratory depression

Post-Overdose Care:

  • Take-home naloxone kit: ALWAYS prescribe intranasal naloxone at discharge + educate patient/family
  • Harm reduction counseling: Never use alone, avoid mixing with benzodiazepines/alcohol, fentanyl test strips
  • Addiction treatment referral: Offer medication-assisted treatment (MAT) - buprenorphine, methadone, naltrexone
  • Social work consult

OPIOID WITHDRAWAL TREATMENT:

Symptom Management (Supportive):

  • Clonidine: 0.1-0.2 mg PO q6h PRN (max 0.8 mg/day)
    • Î±â‚‚-agonist, reduces sympathetic hyperactivity
    • Helps: Anxiety, agitation, tachycardia, HTN, diaphoresis
    • Monitor BP (can cause hypotension)
  • Ondansetron: 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN for N/V
  • Loperamide: 4 mg PO initially, then 2 mg after each loose stool (max 16 mg/day) for diarrhea
  • NSAIDs: Ibuprofen 600-800 mg PO q8h for myalgias
  • Hydroxyzine or promethazine: 25-50 mg q6h PRN for anxiety/insomnia
  • Avoid benzodiazepines (high abuse potential, unless severe anxiety/insomnia)

Medication-Assisted Treatment (MAT) - PREFERRED Long-Term:

  • Buprenorphine (Suboxone):
    • Partial Î¼-opioid agonist - treats withdrawal, reduces cravings, low overdose risk
    • Can initiate in ED once patient in moderate withdrawal (COWS â‰¥8-12)
    • Start: 2-4 mg SL, repeat 2-4 mg q2-4h PRN (max 8-12 mg day 1)
    • Maintenance: 12-16 mg SL daily
    • Requires X-waiver to prescribe outpatient (or prescribe 3-day bridge to clinic)
  • Methadone:
    • Full Î¼-opioid agonist - highly effective but requires special clinic
    • Start 10-30 mg PO daily, titrate slowly
    • Cannot prescribe for outpatient addiction treatment (only federally-licensed clinics)
  • Naltrexone (Vivitrol):
    • Opioid antagonist - blocks effects if relapse occurs
    • 50 mg PO daily OR 380 mg IM monthly
    • Must be opioid-free â‰¥7-10 days before starting (will precipitate withdrawal)

Key Principle: MAT (buprenorphine, methadone) is MORE effective than detox alone. Reduces mortality by 50-70%

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Naloxone goal = restore respiration, NOT consciousness: Overtitrating causes severe withdrawal and patient will leave AMA. Just enough to breathe (RR >12)
  • Fentanyl epidemic: Illicit fentanyl now in everything (fake pills, heroin, cocaine). Much more potent â†’ may need higher/repeated naloxone doses
  • Re-sedation is common: Naloxone wears off faster than most opioids. Long-acting opioids (methadone, fentanyl patch) require prolonged monitoring
  • Withdrawal uncomfortable but NOT deadly: Unlike alcohol/benzo withdrawal. Can't die from opioid withdrawal (though it feels like you might!)
  • Give naloxone kit at discharge: ~50% of OD patients will overdose again within 1 year. Take-home naloxone saves lives
  • Start buprenorphine in the ED: Best time to engage patients in treatment. Can bridge to outpatient clinic with 3-day supply
  • Urine drug screen limitations: Standard screens miss fentanyl, methadone, synthetic opioids. Clinical diagnosis >> lab test
  • Stigma kills: Opioid use disorder is a medical disease, not a moral failure. Use non-judgmental language, offer treatment
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Overdose:
  • Persistent respiratory depression despite naloxone
  • Need for intubation
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Severe co-ingestion (benzos, alcohol)
  • Need for continuous naloxone infusion
  • Withdrawal:
  • Usually does NOT require ICU
  • Exception: Severe co-morbidities, elderly with cardiac disease
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Overdose:
  • Normal mental status and respiratory rate
  • Observed 4-6 hours (short-acting) or 24 hours (long-acting) after last naloxone
  • No re-sedation
  • MUST provide: Take-home naloxone kit + training
  • Harm reduction counseling completed
  • Addiction treatment referral offered/accepted
  • Started on buprenorphine (if appropriate)
  • Withdrawal:
  • Symptoms controlled with outpatient meds
  • Tolerating PO, hydrated
  • Discharge Rx: Clonidine, ondansetron, loperamide
  • MAT arranged (buprenorphine or methadone clinic)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

72. ACUTE APPENDICITIS

RLQ Pain â€¢ Periumbilical â†’ RLQ Migration â€¢ Surgical Emergency
CLINICAL PRESENTATION
