Classic History: Periumbilical pain migrating to RLQ over 12-24 hours, anorexia, nausea/vomiting (typically after pain onset)

Physical Exam:

  • McBurney's point tenderness: 1/3 distance from ASIS to umbilicus
  • Rovsing sign: RLQ pain with LLQ palpation
  • Psoas sign: Pain with right hip extension (retrocecal appendix)
  • Obturator sign: Pain with internal rotation of flexed right hip (pelvic appendix)
  • Rebound/guarding: Suggests peritonitis (perforation)

Atypical Presentations:

  • Elderly: Blunted symptoms, often present with perforation
  • Pregnant: Pain may be RUQ/flank (displaced appendix)
  • Retrocecal: Flank pain, less peritoneal signs
  • Pelvic: Suprapubic pain, urinary symptoms
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Alvarado Score (MANTRELS):

  • Migration of pain to RLQ (1)
  • Anorexia (1)
  • Nausea/vomiting (1)
  • Tenderness in RLQ (2)
  • Rebound pain (1)
  • Elevated temperature >37.3Â°C (1)
  • Leukocytosis >10,000 (2)
  • Shift to left >75% neutrophils (1)
  • Interpretation: 0-4 low risk, 5-6 intermediate, 7-10 high risk

Labs: CBC (leukocytosis with left shift), CMP, lipase, UA (rule out UTI, mild pyuria can occur from inflamed appendix), pregnancy test (all women of childbearing age)

Imaging:

  • CT abdomen/pelvis with IV contrast: Gold standard (sensitivity 94%, specificity 95%)
  • Findings: Dilated appendix >6mm, periappendiceal fat stranding, appendicolith, abscess
  • Ultrasound: First-line in pediatrics, pregnancy. Noncompressible tubular structure >6mm
  • MRI: Alternative in pregnancy if US inconclusive
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Surgical Consultation: URGENT - appendectomy is definitive treatment

Pre-operative:

  • NPO
  • IV fluids: Resuscitate if dehydrated
  • Antibiotics: Start pre-operatively for surgical prophylaxis
  • Uncomplicated: Single dose cefazolin + metronidazole or cefoxitin
  • Perforated/complicated: Broader coverage (pip-tazo, ceftriaxone + metronidazole)
  • Pain control: IV opioids (doesn't mask exam findings)

Operative Approach:

  • Laparoscopic appendectomy: Preferred approach
  • Timing: Should occur within 24 hours of diagnosis
  • Perforated with abscess: May require drainage + interval appendectomy

Non-operative Management: In select cases, antibiotics alone may be considered (recent evidence), but recurrence rate 25-40%

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Anorexia is nearly universal: If patient is hungry, reconsider diagnosis
  • Vomiting follows pain: If vomiting precedes pain, consider gastroenteritis
  • Don't delay imaging for fear of perforation: CT doesn't cause perforation, delayed diagnosis does
  • Pain medication doesn't mask diagnosis: Administer analgesia while awaiting imaging
  • Consider in all RLQ pain: Including women with ovarian pathology as differential
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

73. ACUTE CHOLANGITIS

Biliary Infection â€¢ Charcot's Triad â€¢ Biliary Drainage Emergency
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Charcot's Triad (50-70% sensitivity):

  • 1. Fever/chills
  • 2. RUQ pain
  • 3. Jaundice

Reynolds' Pentad (severe/suppurative cholangitis):

  • Charcot's triad PLUS:
  • 4. Altered mental status
  • 5. Hypotension

Risk Factors: Choledocholithiasis (most common), biliary strictures, malignancy, prior ERCP/biliary stents, parasites (endemic areas)

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Tokyo Guidelines 2018 (TG18) Diagnostic Criteria:

  • A. Systemic inflammation: Fever >38Â°C and/or shaking chills, OR lab (WBC, CRP elevated)
  • B. Cholestasis: Jaundice, OR abnormal LFTs (ALP, GGT, AST, ALT >1.5Ã— ULN)
  • C. Imaging: Biliary dilation, OR evidence of etiology (stone, stent, stricture)
  • Definite: A + B + C | Suspected: A + B or A + C

Labs:

  • CBC (leukocytosis), CMP, LFTs (cholestatic pattern: elevated ALP, GGT, direct bili)
  • Blood cultures: Positive in 20-70% (E. coli, Klebsiella, Enterococcus most common)
  • Lipase (rule out pancreatitis)

Imaging:

  • RUQ ultrasound: First-line. CBD dilation (>6mm, or >8mm post-cholecystectomy), stones
  • MRCP: If US inconclusive, better stone detection
  • CT: Good for complications, but less sensitive for CBD stones

Severity Grading (TG18):

  • Grade I (Mild): Does not meet Grade II/III criteria
  • Grade II (Moderate): WBC >12K or <4K, fever â‰¥39Â°C, age â‰¥75, bili â‰¥5, albumin <0.7Ã— LLN
  • Grade III (Severe): Organ dysfunction (cardiovascular, neuro, respiratory, renal, hepatic, hematologic)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Resuscitation:

  • IV fluids, vasopressors if septic shock
  • Correct coagulopathy if present (vitamin K, FFP)

Antibiotics (start immediately):

  • Mild/Moderate: Ceftriaxone + metronidazole, OR pip-tazo, OR ertapenem
  • Severe/septic shock: Pip-tazo, OR meropenem, OR cefepime + metronidazole
  • Add vancomycin if risk for resistant gram-positives (prior biliary intervention)
  • Duration: 4-7 days after source control

Biliary Drainage (CRITICAL):

  • ERCP: First-line for decompression + stone extraction
  • Timing by severity:
  • Grade III: URGENT <12-24 hours (after initial resuscitation)
  • Grade II: EARLY 24-48 hours
  • Grade I: ELECTIVE 24-72 hours
  • If ERCP not feasible: Percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage (PTBD) or EUS-guided drainage

Cholecystectomy: If gallstone etiology, perform during same admission or within 2 weeks once infection controlled

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Cholangitis is a biliary sepsis: Source control (drainage) is as important as antibiotics
  • Charcot's triad has low sensitivity: Don't wait for all 3 to act
  • Ascending infection: Bacteria ascend from duodenum when bile flow obstructed
  • CBD stones cause cholangitis, GB stones cause cholecystitis: Different pathophysiology
  • Biliary drainage saves lives: Mortality in severe cholangitis without drainage is very high
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

74. ACUTE CHOLECYSTITIS

Gallbladder Inflammation â€¢ RUQ Pain â€¢ Murphy's Sign
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Presentation:

  • RUQ/epigastric pain lasting >6 hours (differentiates from biliary colic)
  • Fever, nausea, vomiting
  • Often precipitated by fatty meal
  • May radiate to right shoulder/scapula (referred pain)

Physical Exam:

  • Murphy's sign: Inspiratory arrest with RUQ palpation (deep breath while palpating GB area causes patient to stop breathing due to pain)
  • RUQ tenderness, possible palpable GB
  • Guarding (suggests perforation/gangrene)

Calculous vs Acalculous:

  • Calculous (90%): Gallstone impacted in cystic duct
  • Acalculous (10%): ICU patients, burns, TPN, sepsis, vasculitis. Higher mortality (10-50%)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Tokyo Guidelines 2018 Diagnostic Criteria:

  • A. Local signs: Murphy's sign, RUQ mass/pain/tenderness
  • B. Systemic signs: Fever, elevated CRP, elevated WBC
  • C. Imaging: Characteristic findings on US/CT/MRI/HIDA
  • Suspected: A + B | Definite: A + B + C

Labs:

  • CBC (leukocytosis), CMP, LFTs (usually mild elevation; if sig elevated, consider CBD stone)
  • Lipase (rule out pancreatitis)
  • Mildly elevated bilirubin common (inflammation, not obstruction)

Imaging:

  • RUQ Ultrasound: First-line (sensitivity 88%, specificity 80%)
  • Findings: Gallstones, GB wall thickening (>3mm), pericholecystic fluid, sonographic Murphy's sign
  • HIDA scan: If US inconclusive. Non-filling of GB = cystic duct obstruction (sensitivity 97%)
  • CT: For complications (perforation, abscess, gangrene)

Severity Grading:

  • Grade I (Mild): No organ dysfunction, mild GB inflammation
  • Grade II (Moderate): WBC >18K, palpable mass, symptoms >72hr, marked local inflammation (gangrenous, emphysematous, pericholecystic abscess)
  • Grade III (Severe): Organ dysfunction (cardiovascular, neuro, respiratory, renal, hepatic, hematologic)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Initial Management:

  • NPO
  • IV fluids
  • Pain control: NSAIDs (ketorolac) + opioids PRN
  • Antiemetics

Antibiotics:

  • Mild (Grade I): Single-dose surgical prophylaxis may be sufficient if early cholecystectomy
  • Moderate-Severe: Ceftriaxone + metronidazole, OR pip-tazo
  • Continue until cholecystectomy if delayed, or 24h post-op if uncomplicated

Cholecystectomy:

  • Early cholecystectomy preferred: Within 72 hours of symptom onset (or admission)
  • Grade I/II: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy during index admission
  • Grade III: Stabilize first, then cholecystectomy or cholecystostomy tube if too sick
  • Delayed cholecystectomy: Higher complication rates, more difficult surgery

High-Risk/Poor Surgical Candidates:

  • Percutaneous cholecystostomy tube: Drainage procedure as bridge or definitive
  • Can perform interval cholecystectomy once patient optimized
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Biliary colic vs cholecystitis: Colic resolves in <6hr; cholecystitis pain is persistent
  • Sonographic Murphy's: More specific than clinical Murphy's sign
  • Acalculous cholecystitis: Think in ICU patients. High mortality, low threshold to treat
  • Early surgery is safe: Within 72hr, easier dissection planes, shorter hospital stay
  • Emphysematous cholecystitis: Gas in GB wall on CT. Clostridium, diabetics. Surgical emergency
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

75. ENCEPHALITIS

Brain Parenchymal Inflammation â€¢ AMS + Fever â€¢ HSV Most Common
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Triad:

  • 1. Fever
  • 2. Altered mental status (confusion, personality change, decreased LOC)
  • 3. Focal neurologic deficits (seizures, aphasia, hemiparesis, movement disorders)

Distinguishing Features (vs Meningitis):

  • Encephalitis = brain parenchyma involvement â†’ altered mentation, seizures, focal deficits
  • Meningitis = meninges â†’ headache, stiff neck, photophobia
  • Often overlap (meningoencephalitis)

Common Etiologies:

  • HSV-1: Most common sporadic cause. Temporal lobe predilection
  • Arboviruses: West Nile, Eastern equine, St. Louis (summer/fall, mosquito exposure)
  • Enteroviruses: Summer/fall epidemics
  • VZV: Immunocompromised, may have rash
  • Autoimmune: Anti-NMDA receptor, LGI1, CASPR2 (consider if young, psychiatric symptoms)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Lumbar Puncture (ESSENTIAL):

  • CSF profile: Lymphocytic pleocytosis (usually 10-500 WBC), normal-mildly elevated protein, normal glucose
  • HSV PCR: Sensitivity 96%, specificity 99%. SEND ON ALL PATIENTS
  • Viral panel PCR: HSV, VZV, enteroviruses, West Nile, others based on exposure
  • RBC in CSF: Suggests hemorrhagic encephalitis (HSV)
  • Cytology, autoimmune panel: If no infectious cause identified

Imaging:

  • MRI Brain with contrast: Study of choice
  • HSV findings: T2/FLAIR hyperintensity in temporal lobes (medial > lateral), insular cortex, cingulate gyrus. Often asymmetric
  • CT: May be normal early; temporal lobe hypodensity seen later

EEG: Periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PLEDs) in temporal region suggests HSV

Additional Labs: CBC, CMP, HIV test, blood cultures, consider paraneoplastic/autoimmune panel if no infectious cause

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Empiric Therapy (START IMMEDIATELY - do not wait for LP/imaging):

  • Acyclovir 10 mg/kg IV q8h: Continue until HSV PCR negative. If HSV+, treat 14-21 days
  • Adjust for renal function
  • Ensure adequate hydration (prevent acyclovir crystalluria/AKI)

If Meningitis Also Suspected:

  • Add empiric bacterial meningitis coverage (ceftriaxone + vancomycin Â± ampicillin)
  • Dexamethasone 0.15 mg/kg q6h if bacterial meningitis suspected (give before or with first abx dose)

Seizure Management:

  • Load levetiracetam 20-30 mg/kg IV if seizures occur
  • Continuous EEG monitoring if persistent AMS

Supportive Care:

  • ICU admission for severe cases
  • Manage cerebral edema (elevate HOB, osmotic therapy if needed)
  • DVT prophylaxis (mechanical preferred if seizures)

Autoimmune Encephalitis:

  • If workup negative for infectious causes, consider autoimmune
  • Treatment: High-dose steroids, IVIG, plasmapheresis
  • Screen for underlying malignancy (ovarian teratoma in anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Treat first, diagnose second: Start acyclovir immediately if encephalitis suspected. HSV mortality untreated 70%, treated <20%
  • HSV PCR can be negative early: If high suspicion, repeat LP in 3-7 days. Continue acyclovir pending repeat
  • Temporal lobe = HSV until proven otherwise: Classic MRI finding
  • West Nile: Flaccid paralysis + encephalitis in summer should raise suspicion
  • Don't forget autoimmune: Young patients with psychiatric symptoms, movement disorders, seizures - think anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

76. INTRACEREBRAL HEMORRHAGE (ICH)

Hypertensive Hemorrhage â€¢ Acute Stroke â€¢ BP Control Critical
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Presentation:

  • Sudden onset focal neurologic deficit (similar to ischemic stroke)
  • Headache (more common than ischemic stroke)
  • Vomiting, decreased LOC (suggests elevated ICP/larger hemorrhage)
  • Seizures (5-15% at onset)

Cannot Distinguish ICH from Ischemic Stroke Clinically: MUST have imaging

Location-Based Deficits:

  • Basal ganglia/putamen (most common): Contralateral hemiparesis, hemisensory loss
  • Thalamus: Sensory > motor, eyes deviate downward ("looking at nose")
  • Cerebellum: Ataxia, vertigo, nystagmus, can deteriorate rapidly
  • Pons: Quadriparesis, pinpoint pupils, "locked-in" syndrome
  • Lobar: Deficits depend on location (frontal, parietal, occipital, temporal)

Common Causes:

  • Hypertension (60-70%): Deep structures (basal ganglia, thalamus, pons, cerebellum)
  • Cerebral amyloid angiopathy: Elderly, lobar hemorrhages, often recurrent
  • Anticoagulation/coagulopathy
  • Vascular malformations: AVM, cavernous malformation (younger patients)
  • Hemorrhagic transformation of ischemic stroke
  • Tumor, cocaine/sympathomimetics
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Imaging:

  • Non-contrast CT head: First-line. Hyperdense (bright) lesion with surrounding edema
  • CT angiography: "Spot sign" (contrast extravasation) predicts hematoma expansion
  • MRI: Better for underlying lesion (tumor, cavernoma, amyloid angiopathy)
  • Conventional angiography: If vascular malformation suspected

ICH Score (Prognosis):

  • GCS 3-4 (2 pts), GCS 5-12 (1 pt), GCS 13-15 (0 pts)
  • ICH volume â‰¥30 mL (1 pt)
  • Intraventricular extension (1 pt)
  • Infratentorial origin (1 pt)
  • Age â‰¥80 (1 pt)
  • 30-day mortality: Score 0 = 0%, Score 5 = 100%

Labs: CBC, PT/INR, aPTT, fibrinogen, blood type/screen, CMP, troponin, toxicology screen

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Blood Pressure Management (CRITICAL):

  • Target SBP <140 mmHg: Intensive BP lowering within 6 hours is safe and may improve outcomes (INTERACT2, ATACH-2)
  • Agents: Nicardipine or clevidipine infusion (titratable). Labetalol IV bolus alternative
  • Avoid: Precipitous drops (>60 mmHg in 1 hour)
  • Exception: Avoid aggressive lowering if large infarct with hemorrhagic transformation

Anticoagulation Reversal (URGENT):

  • Warfarin: 4-factor PCC (25-50 units/kg) + Vitamin K 10mg IV. Goal INR <1.4
  • Dabigatran: Idarucizumab 5g IV (if available) or 4-factor PCC
  • Factor Xa inhibitors (rivaroxaban, apixaban): Andexanet alfa if available, or 4-factor PCC 50 units/kg
  • Heparin: Protamine (1mg per 100 units heparin given in last 2-3 hours)
  • Thrombocytopenia: Platelet transfusion if <100,000

ICP Management:

  • Elevate head of bed 30Â°
  • Osmotic therapy: Mannitol 1g/kg or hypertonic saline 23.4% 30mL
  • Consider EVD if intraventricular hemorrhage with hydrocephalus
  • Avoid hyperthermia (increases ICP and poor outcomes)

Seizure Prophylaxis:

  • Not routinely recommended (AHA guidelines 2022)
  • Treat clinical seizures; consider continuous EEG if decreased LOC out of proportion to imaging

Surgical Consultation:

  • Cerebellar hemorrhage >3cm: Urgent surgical evacuation (can herniate rapidly)
  • Supratentorial: Consider for superficial lobar hemorrhages, especially if deteriorating
  • Minimally invasive surgery: Emerging option (MISTIE III trial)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • You cannot tell ICH from ischemic stroke without CT: Always image before thrombolytics
  • Hematoma expansion is the enemy: 30-40% expand in first 3-6 hours. BP control and reversal critical
  • Cerebellar hemorrhage is surgical emergency: Small posterior fossa, can herniate quickly
  • SBP <140 is safe: Don't be afraid to aggressively treat BP
  • ICH score is self-fulfilling: Don't withdraw care based solely on score
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

77. GI PERFORATION

Surgical Emergency â€¢ Free Air â€¢ Peritonitis
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Presentation:

  • Sudden onset severe abdominal pain
  • Peritoneal signs: Rigidity, rebound tenderness, guarding
  • Fever, tachycardia, hypotension (septic shock)
  • Absent bowel sounds

Location-Based Features:

  • Peptic ulcer (gastric/duodenal): Sudden epigastric pain, may radiate to shoulder (diaphragmatic irritation), NSAIDs/H. pylori history
  • Appendiceal: Initially RLQ, then diffuse
  • Colonic (diverticular, tumor, ischemic): LLQ or diffuse, feculent peritonitis (higher mortality)
  • Small bowel: Trauma, ischemia, foreign body, Crohn's disease

Special Populations:

  • Elderly: May have blunted symptoms, minimal peritoneal signs despite perforation
  • Immunocompromised/steroids: Masked inflammatory response
  • Post-procedure: Colonoscopy, ERCP, endoscopy
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Imaging:

  • CT abdomen/pelvis with IV contrast: Study of choice (sensitivity >90% for free air)
  • Findings: Pneumoperitoneum (free air), extraluminal contrast, inflammatory changes at perforation site, abscess
  • Upright CXR: Free air under diaphragm (70-80% sensitive). Quick bedside test
  • Left lateral decubitus abdominal XR: If upright not possible

Labs:

  • CBC (leukocytosis), CMP, lactate (elevated suggests ischemia/shock)
  • Type and screen (prepare for OR)
  • Lipase (rule out pancreatitis)
  • Blood cultures

Free Air DDx:

  • True perforation (most common)
  • Recent surgery/procedure
  • Barotrauma (mechanical ventilation)
  • Extension from pneumothorax/pneumomediastinum
  • Benign pneumatosis (less peritoneal signs)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Resuscitation (Parallel with Surgical Consult):

  • NPO
  • Large-bore IV access, aggressive fluid resuscitation
  • Vasopressors if refractory hypotension
  • NG tube for decompression
  • Foley catheter for UOP monitoring

Antibiotics (Start Immediately):

  • Upper GI perforation: Ceftriaxone + metronidazole (less fecal contamination)
  • Lower GI/colonic perforation: Pip-tazo OR cefepime + metronidazole OR carbapenem
  • Continue for 4-7 days depending on source control

Surgical Intervention:

  • Emergent surgery is typically required
  • Peptic ulcer: Graham patch (omental patch repair)
  • Appendix: Appendectomy
  • Colon: Resection with diversion (Hartmann procedure) vs primary anastomosis
  • Small bowel: Resection and primary anastomosis

Conservative Management (Select Cases):

  • Stable patient, contained perforation (walled off), no diffuse peritonitis
  • NPO, IV antibiotics, close monitoring
  • Percutaneous drainage of abscess if present
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Free air = surgery until proven otherwise: Even small amounts are significant
  • Elderly can have perforation without classic peritonitis: High index of suspicion
  • Feculent peritonitis (colonic) is more lethal than gastric: Bacterial load much higher
  • Lactate elevation + free air = surgical emergency: Don't delay for optimization
  • Post-colonoscopy perforation: Can be delayed 24-48 hours. Always consider in recent procedure
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

78. SUBARACHNOID HEMORRHAGE (SAH)

Thunderclap Headache â€¢ Aneurysm Rupture â€¢ Neurosurgical Emergency
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Presentation:

  • "Worst headache of my life" - sudden onset, maximal intensity at onset (thunderclap)
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Neck stiffness (meningismus)
  • Photophobia
  • Syncope at onset (25-50%)
  • Seizures

Sentinel Headache: 20-50% report minor "warning leak" headache days-weeks before major rupture

Hunt and Hess Grade:

  • Grade 1: Mild headache, no neurologic deficit
  • Grade 2: Severe headache, stiff neck, no deficit other than cranial nerve palsy
  • Grade 3: Drowsy, confused, mild focal deficit
  • Grade 4: Stupor, hemiparesis
  • Grade 5: Coma, decerebrate posturing

Causes:

  • Aneurysmal (85%): Most common locations - anterior communicating, posterior communicating, MCA bifurcation
  • Non-aneurysmal perimesencephalic (10%): Benign, venous origin
  • Other (5%): AVM, trauma, vasculitis, coagulopathy
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Imaging:

  • Non-contrast CT head: First-line. Sensitivity 95-100% within 6 hours, decreases over time
  • Look for: Hyperdensity in subarachnoid space (basilar cisterns, Sylvian fissures, interhemispheric fissure)
  • CT Angiography: If CT positive, obtain immediately to identify aneurysm (sensitivity 95-100%)

Lumbar Puncture:

  • Indicated if: CT negative but clinical suspicion high
  • Wait 6-12 hours from headache onset (allows RBC lysis â†’ xanthochromia)
  • Positive findings: Elevated RBCs (not clearing from tube 1 to tube 4), xanthochromia (yellow CSF on visual inspection or spectrophotometry)
  • Xanthochromia: Bilirubin from RBC breakdown. Most reliable indicator of true SAH vs traumatic tap

Ottawa SAH Rule (for clinical decision-making):

  • Investigate for SAH if thunderclap headache + any of: Age â‰¥40, neck pain/stiffness, witnessed LOC, onset with exertion, limited neck flexion
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Initial Stabilization:

  • ABCs: Intubate if decreased LOC (GCS â‰¤8)
  • BP control: SBP <160 mmHg before aneurysm secured (prevent rebleeding)
  • Pain control: Avoid hypertensive spikes (use short-acting opioids)
  • Seizure prophylaxis: Often given (levetiracetam), though controversial
  • Stool softeners: Avoid Valsalva

Aneurysm Treatment (Within 24-72 hours):

  • Endovascular coiling: Preferred for many aneurysms (less invasive)
  • Surgical clipping: For certain locations/morphologies
  • Goal: Secure aneurysm before rebleeding (highest risk day 0-1)

Prevention of Complications:

  • Vasospasm (peak days 4-14):
    • Nimodipine 60mg PO/NG q4h for 21 days (only proven agent to improve outcomes)
    • Monitor with TCDs or CTA
    • Treat symptomatic vasospasm: Induced hypertension, endovascular intervention
  • Hydrocephalus: External ventricular drain (EVD) if needed
  • Hyponatremia: Common (SIADH or cerebral salt wasting). Monitor sodium closely
  • DVT prophylaxis: Mechanical first, then chemical after aneurysm secured
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • "Worst headache of life" = SAH until proven otherwise: Always investigate
  • CT sensitivity drops over time: ~100% at 6hr, ~50% at 7 days. LP needed if CT negative and high suspicion
  • Nimodipine is neuroprotective, not BP control: Continue even if hypotensive
  • Rebleeding is catastrophic: Mortality 70%. Secure aneurysm early
  • Vasospasm kills in the second week: Monitor closely days 4-14
  • Sentinel headache: Mild headaches preceding SAH are often missed. High index of suspicion
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

79. ESOPHAGEAL SPASM

Dysphagia â€¢ Chest Pain â€¢ Normal Endoscopy â€¢ Manometry Diagnosis
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Intermittent dysphagia to both solids and liquids with non-cardiac chest pain, worse with hot/cold liquids or emotional stress. Often mimics cardiac chest pain with substernal pressure radiating to back or arms.

  • Symptoms:
    • Dysphagia: Intermittent, paradoxically worse with liquids than solids
    • Chest pain: Substernal, squeezing, can radiate to back/jaw/arms
    • Triggered by: Hot/cold liquids, rapid eating, emotional stress
    • Duration: Seconds to minutes, can last hours
    • Relief: May improve with warm liquids, calcium channel blockers, nitroglycerin
  • Types:
    • Distal Esophageal Spasm (DES): Multiple simultaneous contractions in distal esophagus
    • Jackhammer Esophagus: Hypercontractile peristalsis (>8000 mmHgÂ·sÂ·cm)
    • Nutcracker Esophagus: High-amplitude peristaltic contractions (>180 mmHg)
  • Associated Conditions: GERD (50%), anxiety disorders, diabetes, alcohol use
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Initial Evaluation:

  • Rule Out Cardiac: ECG, troponin if acute chest pain (cardiac workup first)
  • Upper Endoscopy: Normal or mild inflammation; excludes structural lesions, strictures, eosinophilic esophagitis
  • Barium Esophagram: "Corkscrew" or "rosary bead" appearance (simultaneous contractions), tertiary contractions

Definitive Testing:

  • High-Resolution Esophageal Manometry (Gold Standard):
    • Distal Esophageal Spasm: â‰¥20% premature contractions (DCI >450 mmHgÂ·sÂ·cm)
    • Jackhammer: â‰¥20% swallows with DCI >8000 mmHgÂ·sÂ·cm
    • Normal LES relaxation (distinguishes from achalasia)
    • Chicago Classification v4.0 criteria
  • pH Monitoring: If GERD suspected as trigger (24-hour pH-impedance)
  • Labs: Usually normal; TSH if thyroid dysfunction suspected
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

First-Line Medical Therapy:

  • Calcium Channel Blockers:
    • Diltiazem 30-60 mg PO TID-QID (before meals)
    • Nifedipine 10-30 mg PO TID-QID
    • Response rate: 50-70%
  • Nitrates:
    • Isosorbide dinitrate 5-10 mg SL PRN before meals
    • Long-acting: Isosorbide mononitrate 30-60 mg PO daily
    • Side effects: Headache, hypotension
  • PPI Therapy: If GERD component (omeprazole 20-40 mg PO daily)

Second-Line Therapy:

  • Tricyclic Antidepressants:
    • Imipramine 25-50 mg PO qHS (pain modulation)
    • Trazodone 100-150 mg PO qHS
  • Phosphodiesterase-5 Inhibitors: Sildenafil 50 mg PO prior to meals (emerging data)
  • Peppermint Oil: 0.2 mL enteric-coated capsules TID (natural smooth muscle relaxant)

Interventional Therapy (Refractory Cases):

  • Botulinum Toxin Injection: 100-200 units into esophageal body (temporary relief, 3-6 months)
  • Peroral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM):
    • Success rate: 80-90% for spastic disorders
    • Lower esophageal myotomy length 6-10 cm
  • Surgical Myotomy: Rarely needed; reserved for failed POEM

Lifestyle Modifications:

  • Avoid triggers: Very hot/cold foods, carbonated beverages, rapid eating
  • Small, frequent meals
  • Stress reduction techniques
  • Avoid late-night eating
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Cardiac Mimicry: Up to 30% of patients with chest pain and normal coronary angiography have esophageal spasm. Always consider after cardiac workup is negative, especially if pain relieved by nitroglycerin (which relaxes esophageal smooth muscle).
  • The Nutcracker Paradox: Jackhammer/nutcracker esophagus may be asymptomatic. Symptom correlation on manometry is crucial - many patients have high-amplitude contractions without symptoms.
  • GERD Connection: 50% of spasm patients have GERD. Acid reflux can trigger spasm, so always treat reflux first before escalating to other therapies.
  • Manometry Timing: Perform manometry AFTER upper endoscopy and off PPI therapy (if possible) for accurate diagnosis. Requires specialized motility center.
  • Natural History: Only 3-5% of DES progresses to achalasia. Most patients have stable or improving symptoms over time, especially with treatment.
  • Drug-Induced Spasm: Bisphosphonates, NSAIDs, and potassium supplements can cause spasm. Review medication list before extensive workup.
  • Corkscrew Sign: Classic barium finding but only seen during symptomatic episodes (20-30% sensitivity). Normal barium swallow doesn't exclude diagnosis.
  • POEM vs. Heller: POEM has replaced Heller myotomy as first-line surgical therapy for refractory spastic disorders - less invasive, better outcomes, fewer complications.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Severe chest pain unresponsive to medical management
  • Unable to exclude acute coronary syndrome despite negative workup
  • Significant dehydration or inability to tolerate oral intake
  • Hemodynamic instability
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Pain controlled on oral medications
  • Able to tolerate oral intake without dysphagia
  • Cardiac causes excluded (negative troponin, normal ECG)
  • Follow-up arranged with GI/primary care
  • Prescription for calcium channel blockers or nitrates
  • Patient educated on trigger avoidance and medication use
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

80. GASTRITIS / GASTRIC EROSIONS

Epigastric Pain â€¢ NSAID Use â€¢ H. pylori â€¢ Endoscopic Diagnosis
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Dyspepsia with epigastric pain, nausea, and early satiety. May be asymptomatic or present with upper GI bleeding (hematemesis, melena) if erosive/hemorrhagic.

  • Symptoms:
    • Epigastric pain/burning: Postprandial or fasting
    • Nausea/vomiting: May have coffee-ground emesis
    • Early satiety and bloating
    • Anorexia and weight loss (chronic cases)
    • GI bleeding: Melena, hematemesis (if erosive)
  • Types of Gastritis:
    • Erosive (Acute): NSAIDs, alcohol, stress, bile reflux
    • Non-Erosive (Chronic): H. pylori, autoimmune, eosinophilic
    • Hemorrhagic: Stress-related mucosal disease (SRMD) in ICU
    • Atrophic: Chronic H. pylori or autoimmune (pernicious anemia)
  • Risk Factors:
    • NSAIDs/aspirin (most common cause of erosive gastritis)
    • H. pylori infection (most common cause of chronic gastritis)
    • Alcohol (dose-dependent mucosal injury)
    • Stress: Critical illness, burns, trauma, post-surgical
    • Bile reflux (post-gastrectomy)
    • Autoimmune (pernicious anemia, type 1 DM, thyroiditis)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Initial Labs:

  • CBC: Anemia (acute blood loss or chronic B12 deficiency in atrophic gastritis)
  • BMP: Assess for dehydration, renal function
  • If Bleeding: Type & screen, coagulation studies

H. pylori Testing (All patients with gastritis):

  • Non-Invasive (First-Line if no alarm symptoms):
    • Urea Breath Test: Sensitivity/specificity >95% (gold standard non-invasive)
    • Stool Antigen: Sensitivity 91-98%, specificity 94-99%
    • Serology: IgG antibody (can't distinguish active from past infection, not for test-of-cure)
  • Invasive (At time of endoscopy):
    • Rapid Urease Test (CLO test): Sensitivity 90-95%
    • Histology: Gold standard, allows assessment of atrophy/metaplasia
    • Culture: For antibiotic resistance testing if multiple treatment failures
  • Testing Notes: Hold PPI Ã—2 weeks, antibiotics/bismuth Ã—4 weeks before testing to avoid false negatives

Endoscopy (EGD) - Indications:

  • Urgent: Active GI bleeding, hemodynamic instability
  • Prompt: Alarm symptoms (age >60, weight loss, dysphagia, anemia, family history gastric cancer)
  • Routine: Persistent symptoms despite PPI, confirm diagnosis, assess for complications

Endoscopic Findings:

  • Erosive Gastritis: Multiple shallow erosions, erythema, friability, may have active bleeding
  • Non-Erosive: Erythema, nodularity (H. pylori), pallor (atrophic)
  • Hemorrhagic: Petechiae, submucosal hemorrhage, overlying clot
  • Biopsy: Antrum and body for H. pylori, inflammation grade, atrophy, intestinal metaplasia

Additional Testing (Atrophic Gastritis):

  • Vitamin B12: <200 pg/mL indicates deficiency
  • Gastrin Level: Elevated (>500 pg/mL) in atrophic gastritis with achlorhydria
  • Antiparietal Cell Antibodies: Present in 90% of autoimmune gastritis
  • Anti-Intrinsic Factor Antibodies: Specific (98%) but less sensitive (50%) for pernicious anemia
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Acute Management:

  • Discontinue Offending Agents: NSAIDs, alcohol, smoking
  • Acid Suppression:
    • PPI (First-Line): Omeprazole 40 mg PO BID or pantoprazole 40 mg IV BID (if NPO/bleeding)
    • Continue for 4-8 weeks for erosive gastritis
    • Can transition to once-daily after acute phase
  • If Active Bleeding:
    • Resuscitation: 2 large-bore IVs, crystalloid, pRBC as needed
    • Urgent EGD: Within 24 hours for hemodynamically significant bleeding
    • Endoscopic therapy: Epinephrine injection, thermal coagulation, hemostatic powder

H. pylori Eradication (If Positive):

  • First-Line: Clarithromycin-Based Triple Therapy (14 days):
    • PPI (omeprazole 20 mg or equivalent) PO BID
    • Clarithromycin 500 mg PO BID
    • Amoxicillin 1000 mg PO BID
    • Use only if local clarithromycin resistance <15% and no prior macrolide exposure
  • Alternative: Bismuth Quadruple Therapy (14 days, preferred if resistance >15%):
    • PPI (omeprazole 20 mg) PO BID
    • Bismuth subsalicylate 525 mg (2 tabs) PO QID
    • Metronidazole 250 mg (or 500 mg TID) PO QID
    • Tetracycline 500 mg PO QID
  • Concomitant Therapy (14 days, high efficacy):
    • PPI BID + Clarithromycin 500 mg BID + Amoxicillin 1000 mg BID + Metronidazole 500 mg BID
  • Test of Cure: Urea breath test or stool antigen â‰¥4 weeks after completion of therapy

Stress Ulcer Prophylaxis (ICU/Critically Ill):

  • Indications: Mechanical ventilation >48h, coagulopathy (PLT <50K, INR >1.5), history of GI bleeding
  • Agent: Pantoprazole 40 mg IV daily or famotidine 20 mg IV BID
  • Duration: While critically ill with risk factors; discontinue when ICU risk resolved

Autoimmune Atrophic Gastritis:

  • B12 Supplementation: 1000 mcg IM monthly (lifelong) for pernicious anemia
  • Surveillance: EGD every 3-5 years (increased gastric cancer risk)
  • PPI: Generally not needed (achlorhydria already present)

Supportive Care:

  • Antiemetics: Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV/PO Q8H PRN
  • Sucralfate 1g PO QID: Mucosal protectant (if not on PPI)
  • Dietary: Small frequent meals, avoid irritants (spicy, acidic foods, caffeine)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • NSAID Gastritis is Dose-Dependent: Even low-dose aspirin (81 mg) increases gastric erosion risk. COX-2 selective agents (celecoxib) reduce but don't eliminate risk. Always consider PPI co-therapy for high-risk patients (age >60, history of PUD, anticoagulation).
  • H. pylori Testing Strategy: Test-and-treat is appropriate for young patients (<60) with dyspepsia. Endoscopy first for alarm symptoms. Never use serology for test-of-cure (stays positive for years after eradication).
  • PPI Before Testing: PPIs decrease sensitivity of all H. pylori tests except serology. Hold Ã—2 weeks before urea breath test or stool antigen. Can cause false-negative endoscopic biopsies.
  • Clarithromycin Resistance Rising: Now >15% in many regions including US. Bismuth quadruple or concomitant therapy preferred first-line in high-resistance areas. Check local antibiograms.
  • Gastric Cancer Screening: Chronic H. pylori infection is the strongest risk factor for gastric adenocarcinoma. Eradication reduces risk by 50%. Atrophic gastritis and intestinal metaplasia warrant surveillance endoscopy.
  • Autoimmune Gastritis Triad: Pernicious anemia (B12 deficiency), achlorhydria (high gastrin), and increased risk of gastric carcinoid tumors (due to hypergastrinemia causing ECL cell hyperplasia).
  • Stress Gastropathy: Common in ICU patients but actual clinically significant bleeding is rare (3-5%). Target prophylaxis to high-risk patients only (ventilated, coagulopathic) to reduce C. diff and pneumonia risks from PPIs.
  • Erosions vs. Ulcers: Erosions are superficial (mucosa/submucosa), heal quickly, rarely bleed significantly. Ulcers penetrate muscularis, take longer to heal, have higher bleeding/perforation risk. Treatment differs.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Active GI bleeding with hemodynamic instability (SBP <90, HR >120)
  • Massive hematemesis or large-volume melena
  • Hemoglobin drop >3 g/dL despite transfusion
  • Need for >4 units PRBC transfusion
  • Signs of perforation (peritoneal signs, free air on imaging)
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable for >24 hours
  • Hemoglobin stable without transfusion requirement
  • No evidence of active bleeding (no melena, stable Hgb)
  • Tolerating oral intake
  • On PPI therapy (omeprazole 40 mg daily or equivalent)
  • H. pylori treatment initiated if positive
  • Follow-up EGD arranged if indicated (within 4-8 weeks)
  • Patient educated on NSA ID avoidance, PPI compliance
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

81. HEMORRHOIDS

Bright Red Blood Per Rectum â€¢ Anal Pain â€¢ Prolapse â€¢ Straining
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Painless bright red blood per rectum on toilet paper or coating stool, often with straining or constipation. External hemorrhoids may cause anal pain, especially if thrombosed.

  • Internal Hemorrhoids (Above Dentate Line):
    • Painless bleeding: Bright red, on paper or dripping into toilet
    • Prolapse: May reduce spontaneously or require manual reduction
    • Mucus discharge and pruritus
    • No pain (unless thrombosed or strangulated)
    • Covered by mucosa (insensate above dentate line)
  • External Hemorrhoids (Below Dentate Line):
    • Painful swelling: Especially if thrombosed
    • Skin tags: Residual from previous thrombosis
    • Itching and irritation
    • Acute thrombosis: Severe pain, purple/blue nodule
    • Covered by anoderm (sensate below dentate line)
  • Grades of Internal Hemorrhoids:
    • Grade I: Bleeding only, no prolapse (confined to anal canal)
    • Grade II: Prolapse with straining, spontaneously reduces
    • Grade III: Prolapse with straining, requires manual reduction
    • Grade IV: Irreducible prolapse, risk of strangulation
  • Risk Factors: Chronic constipation/straining, prolonged sitting, pregnancy, obesity, low-fiber diet, aging, portal hypertension (but rarely sole cause), chronic diarrhea
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical Diagnosis (History and Examination):

  • History:
    • Bleeding pattern: Bright red, on paper vs. mixed with stool
    • Pain: Suggests external or thrombosed hemorrhoid
    • Prolapse: Timing (with defecation, constant), reducibility
    • Duration and severity of symptoms
    • Associated symptoms: Weight loss, change in bowel habits (red flags for malignancy)
  • Physical Examination:
    • Inspection: Look for external hemorrhoids, skin tags, thrombosis, prolapse, fissures
    • Digital rectal exam: Assess for masses, tenderness, tone
    • Anoscopy: Visualize internal hemorrhoids, classify grade
    • Note: Internal hemorrhoids typically not palpable on DRE

Additional Evaluation:

  • Labs:
    • CBC: If significant bleeding or symptoms of anemia
    • Iron studies: If chronic bleeding suspected
  • Colonoscopy - Indications:
    • Age â‰¥45 (per colon cancer screening guidelines)
    • Red flag symptoms: Weight loss, change in bowel habits, anemia, family history
    • Occult blood positive (not just hemorrhoid bleeding)
    • Persistent bleeding despite treatment
    • Not routinely needed for young patients with typical hemorrhoid symptoms

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Anal fissure (painful, sentinel tag, visible tear)
  • Colorectal cancer or polyp (older age, constitutional symptoms)
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (diarrhea, abdominal pain)
  • Rectal prolapse (circumferential, concentric rings)
  • Abscess/fistula (fever, purulent drainage)
  • Proctitis (tenesmus, mucus, urgency)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Conservative Medical Management (First-Line for Grades I-II):

  • Dietary Modifications:
    • High-fiber diet: 25-35 g daily (fruits, vegetables, whole grains)
    • Fiber supplementation: Psyllium 1 tablespoon BID or methylcellulose
    • Hydration: 8-10 glasses water daily
    • Improvement in 50-90% with fiber alone
  • Stool Softeners: Docusate 100-200 mg PO BID
  • Topical Therapy:
    • Hydrocortisone 1% cream: BID Ã—1 week (short-term only to avoid atrophy)
    • Witch hazel pads (Tucks): Cooling, anti-inflammatory
    • Lidocaine 5% ointment: For pain relief
    • Combination products: Preparation H, Anusol (limited evidence)
  • Sitz Baths: Warm water 15-20 minutes TID and after bowel movements
  • Bowel Habit Modification:
    • Avoid straining and prolonged sitting on toilet
    • Respond promptly to defecation urge
    • Limit bathroom time to <3-5 minutes

Thrombosed External Hemorrhoid:

  • If Presenting <48-72 Hours:
    • Excision under local anesthesia (preferred, definitive)
    • Elliptical incision over thrombosis, remove clot and hemorrhoidal tissue
    • Faster pain relief than conservative management
  • If Presenting >72 Hours or Mild:
    • Conservative management: Pain control, sitz baths, stool softeners
    • Pain typically resolves in 7-14 days
    • May leave residual skin tag
  • Pain Control:
    • NSAIDs: Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q8H or naproxen 500 mg PO BID
    • Acetaminophen: 650-1000 mg PO Q6H
    • Short course narcotics if severe (oxycodone 5 mg PO Q6H PRN Ã—3-5 days)

Office-Based Procedures (Grades I-III):

  • Rubber Band Ligation:
    • Indications: Grades II-III with bleeding or prolapse
    • Technique: Place band at base of hemorrhoid column
    • Success rate: 70-80%, can repeat
    • Complications: Pain, bleeding, thrombosis (rare: pelvic sepsis)
    • Multiple hemorrhoids staged 2-4 weeks apart
  • Infrared Coagulation/Sclerotherapy:
    • Best for Grade I with bleeding
    • Lower efficacy than rubber band ligation
    • Fewer complications, less pain

Surgical Management (Grades III-IV or Failed Conservative):

  • Hemorrhoidectomy (Excisional):
    • Indications: Grade IV, large external component, failed office procedures
    • Success rate: >95%
    • Recovery: 2-4 weeks, significant post-op pain
    • Complications: Pain, bleeding, infection, stenosis, incontinence (rare)
  • Stapled Hemorrhoidopexy (PPH):
    • Circular stapler repositions prolapsed tissue
    • Less pain than excision, faster recovery
    • Higher recurrence rate than hemorrhoidectomy

Discharge Instructions:

  • Continue high-fiber diet indefinitely
  • Return if: Severe pain, fever, urinary retention, excessive bleeding
  • Follow-up in 2-4 weeks to assess response
  • Colonoscopy if indicated per age/symptoms
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Not All BRBPR is Hemorrhoids: Always consider colorectal cancer, especially age >45, family history, or associated symptoms (weight loss, change in bowel habits, anemia). Don't attribute all bleeding to hemorrhoids without appropriate screening.
  • Portal Hypertension Misconception: Hemorrhoids are NOT anorectal varices and don't decompress portal pressures. Patients with cirrhosis get hemorrhoids at the same rate as general population from straining, not portal hypertension.
  • Thrombosed External Timing: Excision is most beneficial within 48-72 hours of symptom onset. After 72 hours, thrombus is organizing and pain is improving - conservative management is equally effective with less procedure risk.
  • Rubber Band Ligation Risk: Rare but catastrophic complication is pelvic sepsis (incidence 1 in 55,000). Warn patients to return for fever, urinary retention, or severe pain. Occurs 2-9 days post-procedure.
  • Fiber is First-Line: Fiber supplementation alone improves symptoms in 50-90% of Grade I-II hemorrhoids. Start with 7-10g daily, increase gradually to 25-35g to minimize gas/bloating. Takes 4-6 weeks for full effect.
  • Steroid Cream Duration: Never use topical steroids >7 days - causes tissue atrophy, skin thinning, and can worsen symptoms long-term. Short burst for acute symptoms only.
  • Internal Hemorrhoids Don't Hurt: If patient has significant pain, think external hemorrhoid, thrombosis, fissure, or abscess. Internal hemorrhoids above dentate line lack somatic innervation (unless strangulated/necrotic).
  • Pregnancy Hemorrhoids: Common in 3rd trimester from pelvic pressure and constipation. Almost always resolve postpartum. Conservative management only during pregnancy - defer procedures until 3-6 months postpartum.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Massive hemorrhoidal bleeding causing hemodynamic instability (rare)
  • Thrombosed hemorrhoid with signs of systemic infection/sepsis
  • Post-operative hemorrhoidectomy complications requiring ICU monitoring
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Pain controlled on oral analgesics
  • No active bleeding or bleeding controlled
  • Able to tolerate oral intake and pass stool
  • Thrombosed hemorrhoid managed (either conservative or excised)
  • Patient educated on stool softeners, high-fiber diet, sitz baths
  • Follow-up with primary care or colorectal surgery if needed
  • Return precautions given (severe pain, fever, inability to urinate)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

82. INTRA-ABDOMINAL ABSCESS

Fever â€¢ Abdominal Pain â€¢ Post-Operative â€¢ CT Diagnosis â€¢ Source Control
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Persistent fever with abdominal pain in patient with recent surgery, perforated viscus, or intra-abdominal infection. May present insidiously with non-specific symptoms.

  • Clinical Features:
    • Fever: Often persistent despite antibiotics
    • Abdominal pain: Localized or diffuse, depending on location
    • Ileus: Nausea, vomiting, decreased bowel sounds, distension
    • Systemic signs: Tachycardia, leukocytosis, sepsis
    • Subacute presentation: Anorexia, weight loss, failure to thrive
  • Common Locations:
    • Subphrenic: Right/left upper quadrant, under diaphragm
    • Perihepatlic: Morrison's pouch, perihepatic space
    • Lesser Sac: Behind stomach, anterior to pancreas
    • Pelvis: Pouch of Douglas (rectouterine/rectovesical)
    • Paracolic Gutters: Right or left lateral
    • Inter-loop: Between bowel loops
    • Retroperitoneal: Perirenal, psoas, paraspinal
  • Etiologies:
    • Post-operative: Anastomotic leak, contamination (most common after colorectal surgery)
    • Perforated viscus: Appendicitis, diverticulitis, PUD, bowel perforation
    • Infected pancreatitis: Pancreatic necrosis (typically >2-3 weeks after onset)
    • Primary peritonitis: Cirrhosis with ascites (SBP)
    • Intra-abdominal sepsis: Cholecystitis, cholangitis
    • Trauma: Penetrating or blunt with hollow viscus injury
    • Crohn's disease: Penetrating disease with abscess formation
  • Risk Factors: Recent abdominal surgery, immunosuppression, diabetes, malignancy, prior abscess, IBD, complicated appendicitis/diverticulitis
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Initial Labs:

  • CBC: Leukocytosis (may be normal in immunosuppressed), left shift, bandemia
  • CMP: Assess for electrolyte abnormalities, renal function, hepatic dysfunction
  • Liver Enzymes: Elevated if hepatobiliary or subphrenic abscess
  • Lactate: Elevated in sepsis, bowel ischemia
  • Blood Cultures: Send before antibiotics (positive in 20-30% of intra-abdominal infections)
  • Inflammatory Markers: ESR and CRP elevated (not specific but trend useful)

Imaging (CT Abdomen/Pelvis with IV Contrast - Gold Standard):

  • Findings Consistent with Abscess:
    • Fluid collection with enhancing wall ("rim enhancement")
    • Gas bubbles within collection (pathognomonic)
    • Mass effect on adjacent structures
    • Surrounding inflammation/fat stranding
  • Sensitivity/Specificity: >95% for abscess detection
  • Planning Drainage: CT guides percutaneous vs. surgical approach

Alternative Imaging:

  • Ultrasound:
    • Useful for hepatic, pelvic abscesses
    • Limited by bowel gas, obesity
    • Advantages: Bedside, no radiation, can guide drainage
  • MRI:
    • If contrast-allergy or pregnancy
    • Excellent for liver, pelvis, retroperitoneum
    • Time-consuming, limited availability

Microbiologic Diagnosis:

  • Abscess Fluid Analysis:
    • Gram stain and culture (aerobic and anaerobic)
    • Cell count and differential
    • Consider fungal cultures if immunosuppressed or persistent fever
  • Common Organisms:
    • Polymicrobial (80%): Enteric gram-negatives (E. coli, Klebsiella) + anaerobes (Bacteroides fragilis)
    • Enterococcus (20-30%, controversial pathogenicity)
    • Fungi: Candida (immunosuppressed, prolonged antibiotics, post-op)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Source Control (Most Important):

  • Percutaneous Drainage (Preferred if feasible):
    • CT or ultrasound-guided catheter placement
    • Success rate: 70-90% for simple abscesses
    • Advantages: Less invasive, lower morbidity, can be repeated
    • Criteria: Safe access route, unilocular or few loculations, >3-4 cm size
    • Catheter management: Daily outputs, flush if needed, remove when <10-20 mL/day
  • Surgical Drainage (Indications):
    • No safe percutaneous access
    • Multiloculated or complex collections
    • Failed percutaneous drainage (persistent fever/leukocytosis >72h)
    • Associated with bowel perforation, fistula, or necrotic tissue
    • Phlegmon or organized infection requiring debridement
  • Timing: Urgent drainage for sepsis/septic shock; otherwise within 24 hours of diagnosis

Empiric Antibiotic Therapy:

  • Community-Acquired, Mild-Moderate Severity:
    • Piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375 g IV Q6H or 4.5g IV Q8H
    • Alternative: Ceftriaxone 2g IV Q24H + metronidazole 500 mg IV Q8H
    • Alternative: Ciprofloxacin 400 mg IV Q12H + metronidazole 500 mg IV Q8H
  • High Severity or Healthcare-Associated:
    • Meropenem 1g IV Q8H
    • Imipenem 500 mg IV Q6H or doripenem 500 mg IV Q8H
    • Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV Q6H (extended infusion)
    • Consider: Vancomycin 15-20 mg/kg IV Q8-12H if MRSA risk (penetrating trauma, prior MRSA)
  • Add Antifungal Coverage (if indicated):
    • Indications: Recent broad-spectrum antibiotics, immunosuppressed, recurrent abscess, Candida in cultures/operative findings
    • Fluconazole 800 mg IV Ã—1, then 400 mg IV Q24H
    • If azole-resistant: Echinocandin (micafungin 100 mg IV Q24H or caspofungin 70 mg IV Ã—1, then 50 mg Q24H)
  • Duration:
    • 4-7 days if adequate source control achieved
    • Extend to 10-14 days if slow clinical response or incomplete drainage
    • Can transition to PO when afebrile Ã—24h, improving WBC, tolerating PO
  • De-escalation: Narrow based on culture results and clinical improvement

Supportive Care:

  • Resuscitation: IV fluids, vasopressors for septic shock (norepinephrine first-line)
  • NPO/Bowel Rest: If ileus or concern for bowel involvement
  • NG Tube: For decompression if significant ileus or vomiting
  • Nutrition: Enteral if tolerated; TPN if prolonged NPO expected
  • DVT Prophylaxis: Heparin 5000 units SC TID or enoxaparin 40 mg SC daily
  • Monitor: Serial exams, vital signs, WBC, drain outputs

Follow-Up Imaging:

  • Repeat CT if persistent fever/leukocytosis >72h despite drainage and antibiotics
  • Confirm resolution if patient slow to improve or had complex abscess
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Source Control is Everything: Antibiotics alone fail in 90% of intra-abdominal abscesses. The KEY to successful treatment is adequate drainage - "pus somewhere, must go somewhere." Persistent fever on antibiotics = inadequate source control until proven otherwise.
  • The 72-Hour Rule: If no clinical improvement (defervescence, decreasing WBC) within 72 hours of drainage + antibiotics, assume inadequate drainage. Get repeat imaging and consider re-intervention or surgical drainage.
  • Post-Op Fever Timing: Intra-abdominal abscesses typically present 5-10 days post-operatively. Earlier fever (days 1-3) is more likely atelectasis, UTI, or wound infection. Later fever (>14 days) consider retained foreign body or anastomotic leak.
  • Pancreatic Abscess Exception: Infected pancreatic necrosis shouldn't be drained in first 2-3 weeks (worsens outcomes). Initial management is antibiotics alone. Delay intervention until necrosis is organized/walled-off (â‰¥4 weeks).
  • Enterococcus Dilemma: Enterococcus in intra-abdominal infections is often a colonizer, not a pathogen. IDSA guidelines don't recommend routine coverage unless immunosuppressed, valvular heart disease, or enterococcus bacteremia. Drain the abscess first.
  • Candida Coverage Controversies: Routine antifungal coverage not recommended for community-acquired infections. Reserve for high-risk patients: upper GI perforation, recurrent infection, immunosuppression, or Candida in perioperative cultures.
  • Drain Not Draining: If percutaneous drain outputs suddenly decrease with persistent fever, assume drain malfunction (kinked, clotted, malpositioned). Flush catheter and obtain repeat imaging. Don't pull drain until abscess resolved and output minimal.
  • Interloop Abscess Challenge: Small abscesses between bowel loops are difficult to drain percutaneously (bowel in the way). Often require surgical approach or prolonged antibiotic therapy with serial imaging to ensure resolution.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Septic shock requiring vasopressor support
  • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
  • Acute renal failure requiring dialysis
  • Multi-organ dysfunction
  • Large abscess with impending perforation or rupture
  • Post-operative complications (anastomotic leak, bleeding)
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable without vasopressors for >24 hours
  • Afebrile for >24 hours (or downtrending fever)
  • Improving leukocytosis and inflammatory markers
  • Abscess adequately drained (percutaneous or surgical)
  • Tolerating oral intake
  • Completed initial antibiotics course (typically 4-7 days IV, then transition to PO)
  • Drain output decreasing (if percutaneous drain placed)
  • Imaging shows resolution or improvement of abscess
  • Follow-up arranged with surgery and infectious disease
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

83. MALLORY-WEISS TEAR

Hematemesis After Retching â€¢ Non-Variceal Bleeding â€¢ Usually Self-Limited
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Hematemesis following forceful or prolonged vomiting/retching episodes. Typically in patients with alcohol use, hyperemesis, or eating disorders.

  • Typical Presentation:
    • Initial non-bloody vomiting: Forceful retching from alcohol, gastroenteritis, hyperemesis
    • Hematemesis: Bright red blood after multiple vomiting episodes
    • Volume: Usually small to moderate (rarely massive)
    • Self-limited: 80-90% stop bleeding spontaneously
    • Epigastric/chest discomfort: From retching, not the tear itself
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Alcohol use (most common): Binge drinking with vomiting
    • Hyperemesis: Gravidarum, chemotherapy, gastroenteritis
    • Eating disorders: Bulimia with self-induced vomiting
    • Hiatal hernia (50% of patients)
    • Medications: Cough, NSAIDs (predispose to bleeding)
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Mucosal tear in gastroesophageal junction or distal esophagus
    • Caused by sudden increase in intra-abdominal pressure + negative intrathoracic pressure
    • Linear tear 5-40 mm long, usually single (can be multiple)
    • Location: 80% gastric side of GE junction, 20% esophageal side
  • Mallory-Weiss vs. Boerhaave:
    • Mallory-Weiss: Mucosal tear only, bleeding, no perforation
    • Boerhaave: Full-thickness perforation, pneumomediastinum, sepsis, surgical emergency
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Initial Assessment:

  • History:
    • Recent forceful vomiting/retching (key historical feature)
    • Alcohol consumption
    • NSAID/anticoagulant use
    • Prior GI bleeding, liver disease, coagulopathy
  • Physical Exam:
    • Vital signs: Usually stable (hematemesis typically limited)
    • Volume status: Orthostatics, skin turgor, mucous membranes
    • Abdominal exam: Epigastric tenderness common
    • Look for stigmata of chronic liver disease

Labs:

  • CBC: Baseline hemoglobin/hematocrit, platelets
  • CMP: BUN:Cr ratio >30 suggests upper GI source (blood urea from protein digestion)
  • Coagulation Studies: PT/INR if anticoagulated or liver disease suspected
  • Type & Screen: Prepare for possible transfusion
  • Lactate: If concerned for shock/hypoperfusion

Risk Stratification (Glasgow-Blatchford Score):

  • Score 0-1: Low risk, possible outpatient management with close follow-up
  • Score â‰¥2: Hospitalization recommended
  • Components: Hemoglobin, BUN, systolic BP, pulse, melena, syncope, hepatic/cardiac disease

Upper Endoscopy (EGD):

  • Timing:
    • Urgent (<12h): Active bleeding, hemodynamic instability
    • Early (12-24h): High-risk features (large volume hematemesis, coagulopathy, cirrhosis)
    • Routine: Stable patients without high-risk features
  • Endoscopic Findings:
    • Linear mucosal tear at GE junction (usually gastric side)
    • Active bleeding (rare, <10% at time of endoscopy)
    • Forrest Classification:
      • Forrest Ia: Spurting arterial bleeding
      • Forrest Ib: Oozing bleeding
      • Forrest IIa: Visible vessel (non-bleeding)
      • Forrest IIb: Adherent clot
      • Forrest III: Clean-based tear (lowest rebleed risk)
    • Often difficult to visualize if bleeding has stopped
  • Endoscopic Therapy (if indicated):
    • Epinephrine injection (1:10,000 dilution)
    • Thermal coagulation (bipolar or heater probe)
    • Hemoclipping
    • Hemospray (topical powder)
    • Combination therapy preferred for high-risk lesions

Imaging (If Boerhaave Suspected):

  • CXR: Look for pneumomediastinum, pleural effusion, subcutaneous emphysema
  • CT Chest with Oral Contrast: Gold standard if perforation suspected (severe chest pain, fever, sepsis)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Initial Resuscitation:

  • IV Access: 2 large-bore IVs (18g or larger)
  • Fluid Resuscitation: NS or LR bolus, target MAP >65 mmHg
  • Blood Products (if indicated):
    • pRBC transfusion: Goal Hgb >7 g/dL (>8 g/dL if cardiovascular disease)
    • Platelets: If <50,000 and active bleeding
    • FFP: If INR >1.5 and active bleeding (goal INR <1.5)
    • Prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC): For rapid INR reversal if on warfarin
  • Reverse Anticoagulation (if applicable):
    • Warfarin: Vitamin K 10 mg IV + PCC (or FFP)
    • Dabigatran: Idarucizumab 5g IV
    • Factor Xa inhibitors: Andexanet alfa or PCC

Medical Management:

  • Proton Pump Inhibitor:
    • Pantoprazole 80 mg IV bolus, then 8 mg/h continuous infusion Ã—72h
    • Alternative: Omeprazole 40-80 mg IV BID
    • Transition to PO: Omeprazole 40 mg PO BID after EGD, then 20-40 mg daily Ã—4-8 weeks
  • Antiemetics:
    • Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV/PO Q8H PRN
    • Prevent further vomiting to allow healing
  • Prokinetic (if gastroparesis contributing):
    • Metoclopramide 10 mg IV/PO TID (30 min before meals)
  • Avoid: NSAIDs, alcohol (counsel patient)

Endoscopic Intervention (Minority of Cases):

  • Indications for Therapy:
    • Active bleeding at endoscopy (Forrest Ia or Ib)
    • Visible vessel (Forrest IIa)
    • Adherent clot (Forrest IIb) - controversial, consider clot removal
  • No Therapy Needed: Clean-based tear (Forrest III) - most common finding

Supportive Care:

  • NPO Initially: Advance to clear liquids after stabilization, then regular diet as tolerated
  • Monitor: Serial Hgb/Hct, vital signs, stool color (melena)
  • NG Tube: Not routinely recommended (may worsen tear); consider if massive bleeding or airway protection needed

Disposition:

  • ICU: Active bleeding, hemodynamic instability, significant comorbidities
  • Telemetry Floor: Most patients (stable, completed EGD)
  • Discharge: After 24h if stable, Hgb stable, tolerating PO, Glasgow-Blatchford score 0-1

Follow-Up:

  • GI follow-up in 2-4 weeks
  • Continue PPI for 4-8 weeks to allow healing
  • Alcohol cessation counseling
  • Address underlying cause (hyperemesis, bulimia, etc.)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Self-Limited Course: 80-90% of Mallory-Weiss tears stop bleeding spontaneously without intervention. Rebleeding rate is only 0-10%. This is one of the most benign causes of hematemesis - don't overtreat.
  • Classic History is Key: The diagnosis is strongly suggested by history of forceful vomiting followed by hematemesis. If history is atypical (no vomiting, chronic bleeding), consider alternative diagnoses (PUD, erosive gastritis, Cameron lesions).
  • High-Risk Features for Intervention: Rebleeding risk increased with: Coagulopathy (INR >2.5), thrombocytopenia (<50K), active bleeding at endoscopy, cirrhosis, large tears >2 cm. These patients warrant more aggressive management.
  • PPI Rationale: Unlike peptic ulcers, acid suppression doesn't directly heal Mallory-Weiss tears (they're mechanical). PPIs are given to (1) prevent further mucosal injury, (2) stabilize clot by raising gastric pH, and (3) treat coexistent gastritis/esophagitis.
  • Don't Confuse with Boerhaave: Boerhaave syndrome is full-thickness esophageal rupture (Mackler's triad: vomiting, chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema). It's a surgical emergency with 20-40% mortality. Mallory-Weiss is mucosal only.
  • Hiatal Hernia Association: 50% of Mallory-Weiss patients have hiatal hernia. The anatomic distortion at GE junction makes mucosa more vulnerable to shear forces during retching.
  • BUN:Cr Ratio Clue: Ratio >30 suggests upper GI bleed (blood is digested protein, producing urea). Lower ratio or normal ratio suggests lower GI source or non-GI cause of anemia.
  • Therapeutic Endoscopy Rare: Only 10-15% of Mallory-Weiss patients have active bleeding or high-risk stigmata requiring endoscopic therapy. Most endoscopies are diagnostic only (clean-based tear or already healed).
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Active bleeding with hemodynamic instability despite resuscitation
  • Hemoglobin <7 g/dL with ongoing transfusion requirements
  • Need for >4 units PRBC
  • Failed endoscopic hemostasis requiring repeat intervention or surgery
  • Esophageal perforation (rare complication)
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable for >24 hours
  • Hemoglobin stable without transfusion requirement
  • No evidence of rebleeding
  • Tolerating oral intake
  • On PPI therapy (omeprazole 40 mg daily for 4-8 weeks)
  • Alcohol cessation counseling if applicable
  • Follow-up with GI and primary care arranged
  • Return precautions for recurrent hematemesis, melena, dizziness
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

84. NEUROGENIC SHOCK

Spinal Cord Injury â€¢ Bradycardia + Hypotension â€¢ Warm Extremities â€¢ Loss of Sympathetic Tone
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Hypotension with paradoxical bradycardia and warm, dry skin following acute spinal cord injury above T6. Results from loss of sympathetic tone with unopposed parasympathetic activity.

  • Clinical Triad (Distinguishes from other shock states):
    • Hypotension: SBP <90 mmHg (variable severity)
    • Bradycardia: HR 50-60 bpm (pathognomonic when combined with hypotension)
    • Warm, Dry Skin: Peripheral vasodilation (unlike hypovolemic/cardiogenic shock)
  • Mechanism - Loss of Sympathetic Outflow:
    • Spinal sympathetic pathway disrupted (T1-L2 sympathetic chain)
    • Loss of vasomotor tone â†’ Peripheral vasodilation â†’ Decreased SVR
    • Loss of cardiac sympathetic innervation (T1-T4) â†’ Bradycardia
    • Unopposed vagal tone â†’ Further bradycardia
    • Venous pooling â†’ Decreased preload
  • Spinal Cord Injury Level:
    • Above T6: Classic neurogenic shock (significant sympathetic disruption)
    • Cervical (C3-C5): Most severe, includes diaphragm (respiratory failure)
    • Below T6: Less likely to cause shock (preserved upper sympathetics)
  • Causes of Spinal Cord Injury:
    • Trauma: MVA, falls, sports injuries, penetrating injury
    • Non-traumatic: Epidural abscess, hematoma, tumor, cord infarction
    • Iatrogenic: Epidural anesthesia (rare high block), spinal surgery complication
  • Spinal Shock vs. Neurogenic Shock:
    • Spinal Shock: Neurologic - flaccid paralysis, areflexia (lasts days-weeks)
    • Neurogenic Shock: Hemodynamic - hypotension/bradycardia from sympathetic loss
    • These often coexist but are distinct entities
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical Diagnosis (Key Features):

  • History: Recent trauma or acute neurologic event
  • Vital Signs: Hypotension + Bradycardia (or inappropriately normal HR for degree of hypotension)
  • Neurologic Exam:
    • Flaccid paralysis below level of injury
    • Loss of reflexes (spinal shock)
    • Sensory level
    • Priapism (pathognomonic in males)
    • Poikilothermia (inability to thermoregulate)
  • Skin: Warm, flushed, dry (vasodilated) above injury level; may be cool below injury

Rule Out Other Shock States (Critical):

  • Hypovolemic Shock:
    • Tachycardia, cold/clammy skin, narrow pulse pressure
    • Rule out: Hemorrhage (intra-abdominal, chest, pelvic/long bone fractures)
    • Neurogenic shock does NOT cause tachycardia or cold extremities
  • Cardiogenic Shock: Elevated JVP, pulmonary edema, cold extremities
  • Septic Shock: Fever, tachycardia (usually), warm extremities (early), altered mental status
  • Mixed Shock: Spinal injury patients may have concurrent hemorrhagic shock (polytrauma)

Labs:

  • CBC: Baseline hemoglobin (rule out hemorrhage)
  • CMP: Electrolytes, renal function
  • Lactate: May be elevated but less than hypovolemic/septic shock (if isolated neurogenic)
  • ABG: If respiratory compromise (high cervical injury)
  • Troponin: If concern for concurrent cardiac injury/MI
  • Blood Cultures: If sepsis cannot be excluded

Imaging:

  • CT Spine (Cervical/Thoracic):
    • Identify level and extent of spinal injury
    • Fractures, subluxation, epidural hematoma
    • STAT in trauma patients
  • MRI Spine (If stable):
    • Assess cord edema, contusion, compression
    • Evaluate for ligamentous injury, disc herniation
    • Gold standard for cord pathology
  • Trauma Imaging (Rule out concurrent injuries):
    • FAST exam or CT chest/abdomen/pelvis for hemorrhage
    • Chest X-ray
    • Pelvic X-ray if mechanism warrants

Hemodynamic Monitoring:

  • Arterial Line: Continuous BP monitoring
  • Central Venous Catheter: CVP monitoring, vasopressor infusion
  • Foley Catheter: Urine output monitoring (neurogenic bladder common)
  • Consider PA Catheter or ECHO: If hemodynamics unclear or mixed shock
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

ABCs and Initial Resuscitation:

  • Airway:
    • C-spine precautions: In-line stabilization, avoid hyperextension
    • Intubate if: C5 or above injury (diaphragm paralysis), respiratory distress, GCS â‰¤8
    • Video laryngoscopy preferred (less neck manipulation)
  • Breathing:
    • High-flow O2 to maintain SpO2 >95%
    • Monitor for respiratory failure (cervical injuries)
    • Mechanical ventilation with lung-protective strategies if intubated
  • Circulation:
    • Large-bore IV access (2 peripheral IVs)
    • Spinal precautions during all procedures

Hemodynamic Goals:

  • MAP Target: 85-90 mmHg (for 7 days post-injury)
    • Maintains spinal cord perfusion pressure
    • Higher MAP associated with improved neurologic outcomes
    • AANS/CNS guidelines recommend MAP 85-90 mmHg Ã—7 days
  • Heart Rate: 60-100 bpm (treat symptomatic bradycardia)

Fluid Resuscitation:

  • Initial Fluid Bolus:
    • NS or LR 500-1000 mL IV bolus
    • Reassess BP and perfusion
    • Caution: Excessive fluids worsen cord edema and pulmonary edema
  • Goal: Euvolemia (avoid both hypo- and hypervolemia)
  • Monitoring: CVP, urine output, clinical exam

Vasopressors (First-Line After Fluids):

  • Norepinephrine (Preferred):
    • Start: 0.01-0.05 mcg/kg/min (central line preferred)
    • Titrate to MAP 85-90 mmHg
    • Alpha-1 agonist (vasoconstriction) + beta-1 (inotropy/chronotropy)
  • Dopamine (Alternative):
    • Start: 5-10 mcg/kg/min
    • Increases HR and contractility (may help bradycardia)
    • Higher arrhythmia risk than norepinephrine
  • Phenylephrine (Pure Alpha Agonist):
    • If excessive tachycardia with norepinephrine/dopamine
    • May worsen bradycardia (reflex response)
  • Avoid: Excessive fluids as sole therapy (worsens cord edema)

Bradycardia Management:

  • Atropine:
    • 0.5-1 mg IV bolus (can repeat Q3-5min, max 3 mg)
    • For symptomatic bradycardia (HR <50 with hypotension/altered mental status)
    • May have limited effect (denervated heart)
  • Transcutaneous Pacing:
    • If atropine fails or severe/persistent bradycardia
    • Temporary transvenous pacing for refractory cases
  • Dopamine or Epinephrine Infusion: For persistent symptomatic bradycardia

Spinal Cord Injury Specific Management:

  • Spinal Immobilization: C-spine collar until cleared by imaging
  • Neurosurgical Consultation: STAT for surgical evaluation/decompression
  • High-Dose Steroids (Controversial, Generally NOT Recommended):
    • Methylprednisolone was previously used (NASCIS protocols)
    • No longer recommended per AANS/CNS guidelines (no proven benefit, increased complications)
    • May be considered on case-by-case basis by neurosurgery
  • Early Surgical Decompression (If Indicated):
    • Within 24 hours improves outcomes
    • Indications: Compression, unstable fracture, progressive deficit

Supportive Care:

  • DVT Prophylaxis:
    • SCDs initially (within 24h)
    • Enoxaparin 30 mg SC BID (once hemorrhage ruled out, typically after 72h)
    • Spinal cord injury = VERY high DVT risk
  • Stress Ulcer Prophylaxis: PPI (pantoprazole 40 mg IV daily)
  • Foley Catheter: Neurogenic bladder common (monitor urine output, avoid over-distension)
  • Temperature Management: External warming/cooling (poikilothermia common)
  • Early Mobilization/Rehab: Once hemodynamically stable and spine cleared/stabilized

Disposition:

  • ICU Admission: All patients with neurogenic shock
  • Monitoring: Continuous cardiac, arterial line, central access, neuro checks Q1H
  • Duration: Shock typically resolves over days to weeks as sympathetic tone recovers (or doesn't)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Hypotension + Bradycardia = Neurogenic Until Proven Otherwise: This paradoxical combination is pathognomonic for neurogenic shock. All other shock states cause tachycardia (compensatory). If you see "HR 58, BP 85/50" after trauma, think spinal cord injury.
  • Don't Overcorrect the Bradycardia: HR 50-60 bpm is expected in neurogenic shock and does NOT need treatment unless symptomatic (hypotension, altered mental status, chest pain). Treat the MAP, not the number. Excessive atropine can cause tachycardia and worsen myocardial O2 demand.
  • Fluid Caution: Unlike hypovolemic shock, aggressive crystalloid resuscitation WORSENS outcomes in neurogenic shock by causing pulmonary/spinal cord edema. Give modest fluid bolus (1-2L), then start vasopressors early to achieve MAP goals.
  • MAP 85-90 mmHg for 7 Days: Specific guideline for acute SCI to maintain spinal cord perfusion. Higher than usual MAP goal. This is time-limited (7 days), then transition to standard goals (MAP 65+).
  • Rule Out Hemorrhage: Polytrauma patients can have BOTH neurogenic and hemorrhagic shock. Neurogenic shock alone doesn't cause narrow pulse pressure, cold extremities, or profound tachycardia (if present, assume hemorrhage). Get FAST/CT to rule out bleeding.
  • Priapism is Pathognomonic: Sustained erection in male patient with spinal injury is virtually diagnostic of cord injury and neurogenic shock. Results from loss of sympathetic tone with unopposed parasympathetic activity.
  • Methylprednisolone Controversy: Despite NASCIS trials, high-dose steroids are NO LONGER recommended per AANS/CNS guidelines (2013). Increased infection/complications, no proven benefit. Don't give unless neurosurgery specifically requests.
  • Sympathetic Recovery is Variable: Some patients regain sympathetic function over weeks-months. Others have permanent dysfunction (chronic orthostasis, thermoregulation issues, autonomic dysreflexia). Early rehab and education essential.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • ALL patients with neurogenic shock require ICU admission
  • Vasopressor requirement (norepinephrine, phenylephrine)
  • Spinal cord injury (any level)
  • Hemodynamic instability (SBP <90, bradycardia <60 with hypotension)
  • Need for mechanical ventilation (high cervical injury)
  • Ongoing fluid resuscitation requirements
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable without vasopressor support for >48-72 hours
  • MAP consistently >65 mmHg
  • Heart rate normalized or stable (typically 60-80 with injury)
  • Spinal shock resolved (return of reflexes below lesion)
  • No further progression of neurologic deficits
  • Appropriate disposition arranged (acute rehab for spinal cord injury)
  • Urinary catheter management plan in place
  • DVT prophylaxis established (LMWH once spinal hematoma risk assessed)
  • Follow-up with neurosurgery and physical medicine/rehab arranged
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

85. RUPTURED ABDOMINAL AORTIC ANEURYSM

Abdominal/Back Pain â€¢ Hypotension â€¢ Pulsatile Mass â€¢ Surgical Emergency
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Triad (Only 50% Present): Abdominal/back pain + Hypotension + Pulsatile abdominal mass. Ruptured AAA is a surgical emergency with mortality 50-80% overall, 90% if reaches ED alive.

  • Symptoms:
    • Pain: Abdominal, back, or flank pain (sudden or gradually worsening)
    • Radiation: Back, groin, flank, or hip
    • Character: Tearing, ripping, or constant dull ache
    • May be painless in 30% (especially if contained/elderly)
  • Hemodynamic Status:
    • Frank Rupture (Free Intraperitoneal): Profound hypotension/shock, rapid exsanguination
    • Contained Rupture (Retroperitoneal): Relative hemodynamic stability initially, may compensate temporarily
    • Syncope or near-syncope (25%)
  • Physical Exam:
    • Pulsatile Abdominal Mass: Palpable in 50-75% (sensitivity decreases with obesity, hypotension)
    • Abdominal distension and peritoneal signs
    • Hypotension or shock
    • Femoral pulses may be diminished or absent
    • Grey Turner sign: Flank ecchymosis (late, rare)
    • Cullen sign: Periumbilical ecchymosis (late, rare)
  • Atypical Presentations:
    • GI bleeding (aortoenteric fistula)
    • Lower extremity ischemia (distal embolization)
    • Isolated back pain mimicking renal colic/MSK pain
    • Syncope without obvious cause
  • Risk Factors for AAA:
    • Age >65 years (especially men)
    • Smoking (strongest modifiable risk factor)
    • Male sex (M:F = 4:1)
    • Family history (20% have first-degree relative with AAA)
    • Hypertension, hyperlipidemia, CAD, PAD
    • Known AAA (rupture risk increases with size: 1%/year if 5-5.9 cm, 10%/year if 6-6.9 cm, >20%/year if â‰¥7 cm)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical Diagnosis in Unstable Patients:

  • High Clinical Suspicion + Hemodynamic Instability:
    • Do NOT delay for imaging if patient unstable
    • Bedside ultrasound if immediately available (see below)
    • Activate vascular surgery and go directly to OR

Bedside Ultrasound (FAST Extended for AAA):

  • Indication: Unstable patient, rapid screening
  • Findings:
    • Aortic diameter >3 cm (normal â‰¤3 cm)
    • AAA defined as aortic diameter â‰¥3 cm
    • Intraperitoneal free fluid (ruptured)
    • Sensitivity: 95-100% for AAA presence, less sensitive for rupture
  • Limitation: Can't definitively diagnose rupture or assess proximal/distal extent

CT Angiography (CTA) Abdomen/Pelvis - Gold Standard:

  • Indication: Hemodynamically stable or stabilized patient
  • Findings:
    • AAA size and extent (infrarenal vs. suprarenal)
    • Active extravasation or contained rupture
    • Retroperitoneal hematoma
    • Vessel anatomy for surgical/endovascular planning
  • Sensitivity/Specificity: >95% for rupture
  • Contraindication: DO NOT send unstable patient to CT scanner

Labs (Don't Delay Surgery):

  • Type & Cross: 6-10 units pRBC (massive transfusion anticipated)
  • CBC: Baseline hemoglobin (may be normal acutely due to hemoconcentration)
  • CMP: Renal function (contrast), electrolytes
  • Coagulation Studies: PT/INR, PTT (baseline, anticipate coagulopathy)
  • Lactate: Assess perfusion/shock
  • Troponin: If concern for MI (may delay surgery)

ECG and CXR:

  • Rule out MI/arrhythmia (if time permits and patient stable)
  • Don't delay surgery for these tests if diagnosis clear

Differential Diagnosis (The Great Mimicker):

  • Renal colic (unilateral, colicky, hematuria)
  • Diverticulitis (LLQ pain, fever, CT shows colonic inflammation)
  • Acute MI (chest pain radiating, ECG changes)
  • Perforated viscus (peritonitis, free air)
  • Pancreatitis (epigastric pain, elevated lipase)
  • Mesenteric ischemia (pain out of proportion, lactate)
  • Musculoskeletal back pain (no vascular symptoms)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Pre-Hospital and ED Resuscitation:

  • IV Access: 2 large-bore peripheral IVs (16g or larger) or intraosseous if unable
  • Permissive Hypotension (Key Concept):
    • Goal SBP: 70-90 mmHg (or MAP 50-70 mmHg)
    • Maintain perfusion to vital organs WITHOUT increasing bleeding
    • Overly aggressive resuscitation disrupts clot and worsens hemorrhage
    • "Pop the clot" phenomenon
  • Limited Fluid Resuscitation:
    • Give minimal crystalloid (250-500 mL boluses PRN for MAP 50-70)
    • Avoid large-volume resuscitation before surgical control
    • Immediate surgical intervention is priority, not normalization of BP
  • Blood Products (Once Activated):
    • Massive Transfusion Protocol: 1:1:1 ratio pRBC:FFP:Platelets
    • Consider O-negative blood immediately if unstable
    • Tranexamic acid (TXA): 1g IV over 10 min, then 1g over 8h (if given <3h from injury)
  • Avoid:
    • NO chest compressions if cardiac arrest (futile and worsens bleeding)
    • NO palpation of abdomen if ruptured AAA suspected (may disrupt clot)

Immediate Consultation:

  • Vascular Surgery: STAT consultation (as soon as diagnosis suspected)
  • Anesthesia: Activate OR, prepare for emergency surgery
  • Blood Bank: Massive transfusion protocol

Definitive Management - Surgical Repair:

  • Open Surgical Repair (OSR):
    • Traditional approach: Midline laparotomy, aortic cross-clamp, graft replacement
    • Advantages: Definitive repair, no anatomic limitations
    • Disadvantages: High physiologic stress, longer recovery
    • Perioperative mortality: 40-50% for ruptured AAA
  • Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR):
    • Minimally invasive: Femoral access, stent-graft deployment
    • Advantages: Lower physiologic stress, may reduce mortality (30-40%)
    • Disadvantages: Requires suitable anatomy, risk of endoleak, not always available emergently
    • Increasingly preferred if anatomically feasible and available
  • Decision Factors:
    • Hemodynamic stability (EVAR requires more time/setup)
    • Anatomic suitability (proximal/distal landing zones)
    • Institutional resources/expertise

Intraoperative Management:

  • Rapid Sequence Intubation: Consider awake intubation if unstable
  • Permissive Hypotension Until Aortic Control: Avoid BP augmentation until cross-clamp applied
  • Massive Transfusion: 1:1:1 ratio, consider whole blood if available
  • Correct Coagulopathy:
    • Maintain temperature >36Â°C (warming devices)
    • Calcium replacement (citrate from transfusions)
    • Fibrinogen replacement if <150 mg/dL (cryoprecipitate or fibrinogen concentrate)

Post-Operative Management (ICU):

  • Complications to Monitor:
    • Abdominal Compartment Syndrome: Bladder pressure >20 mmHg, may require decompressive laparotomy
    • Acute Kidney Injury: Contrast, ischemia, rhabdomyolysis (common, may need CRRT)
    • Colonic Ischemia: Inferior mesenteric artery occlusion (bloody diarrhea, acidosis)
    • Spinal Cord Ischemia: Paraplegia (1-3% risk, from spinal artery compromise)
    • Lower Extremity Ischemia: Distal embolization or graft thrombosis
    • ARDS/Multi-Organ Failure: From massive transfusion, shock
  • Supportive Care:
    • Mechanical ventilation (often prolonged)
    • Vasopressor support
    • Renal replacement therapy if needed
    • Nutrition (early enteral if tolerated)

Prognosis:

  • Overall mortality: 50-80% (includes pre-hospital deaths)
  • If reaches ED alive: 40-50% mortality
  • Better outcomes: Younger age, contained rupture, EVAR, expedient surgery
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Think AAA in "The Big Three": Any elderly patient with: (1) Abdominal/back pain, (2) Hypotension/syncope, or (3) Known AAA. Have extremely low threshold to image - ruptured AAA kills 50-80%, early diagnosis saves lives.
  • Permissive Hypotension is Counterintuitive but Lifesaving: Target SBP 70-90 mmHg UNTIL surgical control. Aggressively resuscitating to "normal" BP before aortic cross-clamp increases bleeding ("pops the clot") and worsens mortality. This goes against your instincts but is evidence-based.
