  • Don't Send Unstable Patient to CT: If patient has hypotension + abdominal/back pain + pulsatile mass (or high suspicion), go directly to OR. Bedside ultrasound showing AAA is sufficient. Patient can die in scanner waiting for CT.
  • Ruptured AAA Mimics Renal Colic: Elderly patient with "renal colic" and hematuria may actually have ruptured AAA causing ureteral compression. Always consider AAA in older patients with flank/back pain, especially if hypotensive or no prior stone history.
  • Normal Hemoglobin Doesn't Exclude: Hgb may be normal initially after rupture due to hemoconcentration (blood loss not yet equilibrated). Don't be falsely reassured by "normal labs" in acute setting.
  • EVAR Improving Outcomes: Meta-analyses show 30-day mortality advantage for EVAR vs. OSR (30-35% vs. 45-50%). If center has EVAR capability and patient has suitable anatomy, this is increasingly preferred approach.
  • Don't Forget Screening Guidelines: Men age 65-75 with smoking history should get one-time ultrasound screening for AAA (USPSTF Grade B). Detection and elective repair of AAA before rupture has <5% mortality vs. 50-80% for ruptured.
  • Cardiac Arrest from Ruptured AAA is Futile: If patient arrests from exsanguination, CPR is ineffective (pushes blood out faster) and OR is only chance. Resuscitative thoracotomy with aortic cross-clamping is a Hail Mary but has been done with rare survival.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • ALL patients with ruptured AAA require ICU (surgical ICU preferred)
  • Post-operative management after EVAR or open repair
  • Ongoing transfusion requirements or coagulopathy
  • Vasopressor support
  • Mechanical ventilation
  • Acute kidney injury or dialysis requirement
  • Abdominal compartment syndrome
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable without vasopressors for >72 hours
  • No evidence of ongoing bleeding or rebleeding
  • Stable hemoglobin without transfusion requirement
  • Extubated and breathing comfortably on room air or low-flow O2
  • Adequate renal function (or stable on dialysis with outpatient plan)
  • Tolerating oral intake, bowel function returned
  • Wound healing appropriately without signs of infection
  • Pain controlled on oral medications
  • Follow-up with vascular surgery arranged (typically 2-4 weeks)
  • CT angiography scheduled per surgery (usually 1 month post-op)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

86. B12 / FOLATE DEFICIENCY ANEMIA

Macrocytic Anemia â€¢ Neurologic Symptoms (B12) â€¢ Hypersegmented Neutrophils
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Macrocytic anemia with fatigue, glossitis, and neurologic symptoms (B12 only). Often insidious onset over months to years.

  • General Anemia Symptoms:
    • Fatigue, weakness, dyspnea on exertion
    • Pallor
    • Tachycardia, heart failure (if severe)
    • Symptoms often develop slowly (compensated)
  • Specific to B12/Folate Deficiency:
    • Glossitis: Beefy red, smooth tongue (atrophic papillae)
    • Angular cheilitis: Cracks at corners of mouth
    • Hyperpigmentation: Especially hands, knuckles (melanin deposition)
    • Jaundice: Mild, from ineffective erythropoiesis (hemolysis of megaloblasts in marrow)
  • Neurologic Manifestations (B12 ONLY, NOT Folate):
    • Subacute Combined Degeneration: Demyelination of dorsal/lateral columns
      • Posterior column: Loss of position/vibration sense, sensory ataxia
      • Lateral corticospinal: Weakness, spasticity, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign
      • Classic: Gait ataxia + paresthesias + weakness
    • Peripheral neuropathy: Stocking-glove distribution, paresthesias
    • Cognitive/Psychiatric: Memory loss, dementia, depression, psychosis
    • Optic neuropathy: Visual changes (rare)
    • CRITICAL: Neuro damage may be irreversible if prolonged deficiency
  • Folate-Specific: Neural tube defects in pregnancy (if deficient periconceptionally)
ETIOLOGIES

Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin) Deficiency:

  • Pernicious Anemia (Most Common in Developed Countries):
    • Autoimmune destruction of gastric parietal cells
    • Loss of intrinsic factor â†’ Impaired B12 absorption
    • Associated: Autoimmune disorders (thyroiditis, vitiligo, type 1 DM)
    • Antiparietal cell antibodies (85-90%), anti-intrinsic factor antibodies (50-70%, more specific)
    • Atrophic gastritis on endoscopy
  • Dietary Deficiency:
    • Strict vegans (B12 only in animal products)
    • Rare in developed countries (liver stores last 3-5 years)
  • Malabsorption:
    • Gastrectomy or gastric bypass (loss of intrinsic factor production)
    • Terminal ileum disease: Crohn's, resection, bacterial overgrowth
    • Pancreatic insufficiency (need pancreatic proteases to cleave R-protein)
    • Celiac disease
    • Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm)
  • Medications:
    • Metformin (decreases B12 absorption, 10-30% of users)
    • PPIs/H2 blockers (chronic use, impaired cleavage from food)
    • Nitrous oxide (inactivates B12, seen in anesthesia/recreational use)

Folate (Folic Acid) Deficiency:

  • Dietary Deficiency (Most Common Cause):
    • Poor intake: Elderly, alcoholics, poverty
    • Folate depletes rapidly (body stores only 2-3 months)
  • Increased Demand:
    • Pregnancy and lactation
    • Hemolytic anemias (increased RBC turnover: sickle cell, thalassemia)
    • Malignancy, inflammatory states
    • Dialysis (folate removed)
  • Malabsorption:
    • Celiac disease, tropical sprue
    • Small bowel resection
  • Medications:
    • Methotrexate (dihydrofolate reductase inhibitor)
    • Trimethoprim, sulfasalazine, phenytoin
    • Alcohol (impairs absorption and utilization)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Complete Blood Count:

  • Anemia: Hemoglobin variable (may be severe, <7 g/dL)
  • Macrocytosis: MCV >100 fL (often 110-140 fL in severe deficiency)
  • Pancytopenia: May have leukopenia and thrombocytopenia (megaloblastic changes affect all cell lines)

Peripheral Blood Smear (Diagnostic):

  • Macro-ovalocytes: Large, oval RBCs
  • Hypersegmented Neutrophils (Pathognomonic): â‰¥5 lobes in neutrophil (normal â‰¤4)
  • Anisocytosis and poikilocytosis: Variable RBC size/shape
  • Howell-Jolly bodies: Nuclear remnants in RBCs

Vitamin Levels:

  • Serum B12:
    • <150 pg/mL: Deficient
    • 150-400 pg/mL: Borderline/low (consider methylmalonic acid if symptomatic)
    • >400 pg/mL: Normal
    • Note: Can be falsely normal in myeloproliferative disorders, liver disease
  • Serum Folate:
    • <3 ng/mL: Deficient
    • Less reliable (reflects recent intake, not tissue stores)
  • RBC Folate:
    • Better reflects tissue stores than serum folate
    • <150 ng/mL: Deficient

Confirmatory Tests (If B12 Borderline or Normal with High Suspicion):

  • Methylmalonic Acid (MMA):
    • Elevated (>0.4 Âµmol/L) in B12 deficiency (NOT elevated in folate deficiency)
    • Most sensitive test for B12 deficiency
    • Also elevated in renal failure (confounding factor)
  • Homocysteine:
    • Elevated in BOTH B12 and folate deficiency (less specific)
    • Normal: <15 Âµmol/L
    • Also elevated in renal failure, hypothyroidism

Etiology Workup (Once Deficiency Confirmed):

  • For B12 Deficiency:
    • Anti-Intrinsic Factor Antibodies: Specific for pernicious anemia (50-70% sensitive)
    • Anti-Parietal Cell Antibodies: Less specific (85-90% sensitive, but also in 10% of normal elderly)
    • Gastrin Level: Elevated in pernicious anemia (achlorhydria)
    • EGD: Consider if atrophic gastritis suspected (increased gastric cancer risk)
  • For Folate Deficiency:
    • Dietary history
    • Alcohol use screening
    • Consider celiac antibodies (TTG-IgA) if malabsorption suspected

Additional Labs:

  • Reticulocyte Count: Inappropriately low for degree of anemia (ineffective erythropoiesis)
  • LDH: Elevated (intramedullary hemolysis)
  • Indirect Bilirubin: Mildly elevated (hemolysis)
  • Haptoglobin: Low (hemolysis)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

CRITICAL RULE: Always Treat B12 First (or Simultaneously) Before Folate:

  • Rationale: Giving folate alone to a B12-deficient patient can correct the anemia BUT precipitate/worsen neurologic damage (subacute combined degeneration)
  • Safe Approach: Treat both if unsure, or confirm B12 status before folate monotherapy

Vitamin B12 Replacement:

  • Acute/Severe Deficiency or Neurologic Symptoms:
    • Cyanocobalamin (B12) 1000 mcg IM daily Ã—1 week
    • Then: 1000 mcg IM weekly Ã—4 weeks
    • Then: 1000 mcg IM monthly (lifelong if pernicious anemia or malabsorption)
  • Maintenance or Mild Deficiency:
    • Oral Cyanocobalamin 1000-2000 mcg PO daily
    • Effective even in pernicious anemia (1-2% absorbed by mass action, bypasses intrinsic factor)
    • Requires patient adherence
  • Alternative Routes:
    • Sublingual cyanocobalamin 1000 mcg daily
    • Intranasal cyanocobalamin 500 mcg weekly (expensive, lower adherence)
  • Hydroxocobalamin: Alternative to cyanocobalamin (longer-acting, less commonly used in US)

Folate Replacement:

  • Treatment Dose:
    • Folic Acid 1-5 mg PO daily
    • Duration: Until deficiency corrected and underlying cause addressed (usually 1-4 months)
  • Prophylaxis (High-Risk Groups):
    • Pregnancy: 400-800 mcg daily (prenatal vitamins)
    • Chronic hemolysis: 1 mg daily
    • Dialysis: 1 mg daily
    • Methotrexate: Leucovorin (folinic acid) rescue or folic acid 1 mg daily

Monitoring Response:

  • Reticulocytosis: Peaks at 5-7 days (indicates bone marrow response)
  • Hemoglobin: Begins to rise by 1 week, normalizes in 6-8 weeks
  • MCV: Gradually decreases to normal over 2-3 months
  • Neurologic Symptoms: May take weeks to months to improve (may be irreversible if longstanding)
  • Recheck B12/Folate: 4-8 weeks after starting treatment

Supportive Care:

  • Transfusion:
    • If symptomatic (chest pain, dyspnea, CHF exacerbation) or Hgb <7 g/dL
    • Transfuse SLOWLY (1 unit over 3-4 hours) to avoid volume overload
    • Goal: Hgb 7-9 g/dL (NOT full correction acutely)
  • Potassium Supplementation:
    • Monitor K+ closely in first week of treatment
    • Rapid cell production depletes K+ ("refeeding hypokalemia")
    • Supplement if K+ <3.5 mEq/L

Address Underlying Cause:

  • Pernicious anemia: Lifelong B12 replacement
  • Dietary: Nutrition counseling, supplementation
  • Medications: Adjust/discontinue if possible, supplement as needed
  • Malabsorption: Treat underlying condition (celiac, Crohn's), may need parenteral supplementation

Long-Term Follow-Up:

  • Pernicious Anemia: Lifelong replacement, surveillance EGD (increased gastric cancer risk - consider every 3-5 years)
  • Check B12/Folate Levels: Annually if on maintenance therapy
  • Screen for Autoimmune Disorders: If pernicious anemia (thyroid, diabetes, etc.)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Never Give Folate Without B12: Treating folate deficiency alone in a B12-deficient patient can WORSEN or PRECIPITATE irreversible neurologic damage (subacute combined degeneration). Always check B12 or treat both empirically if uncertain.
  • Hypersegmented Neutrophils are Pathognomonic: â‰¥5% of neutrophils with â‰¥5 lobes (or any with â‰¥6 lobes) is diagnostic for megaloblastic anemia. This finding persists even if patient already started replacement, making it useful diagnostically.
  • MMA is the Best Confirmatory Test: Methylmalonic acid is elevated in B12 deficiency but NOT folate deficiency, making it the most specific test. Use it when B12 level is borderline (150-400) but clinical suspicion is high.
  • Metformin and B12: 10-30% of long-term metformin users develop B12 deficiency. Check B12 annually in diabetics on metformin, especially if peripheral neuropathy develops (often attributed to diabetes but may be B12).
  • Oral B12 Works Even in Pernicious Anemia: High-dose oral B12 (1000-2000 mcg daily) is effective even without intrinsic factor because 1-2% is absorbed by passive diffusion. Cost-effective alternative to IM if patient adherent.
  • Nitrous Oxide = Instant B12 Deficiency: Nâ‚‚O inactivates B12 (oxidizes cobalt atom) within hours. Recreational "whippet" use or prolonged anesthesia exposure can cause acute subacute combined degeneration in previously borderline patients.
  • Neuro Damage May Be Irreversible: If subacute combined degeneration is present >6-12 months before treatment, neurologic recovery is often incomplete. Early recognition and treatment is critical. Anemia may be minimal but neuro symptoms prominent.
  • Pernicious Anemia = Gastric Cancer Risk: Atrophic gastritis and achlorhydria in pernicious anemia increase gastric adenocarcinoma risk 3-6 fold. Consider surveillance EGD every 3-5 years per ACG guidelines.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Severe neurologic compromise requiring ICU-level monitoring
  • Hemodynamic instability from severe anemia (Hgb <4-5 g/dL)
  • Heart failure or myocardial ischemia from severe anemia
  • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
  • Multi-organ dysfunction from severe deficiency
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable
  • Hemoglobin improving or stable (typically >7-8 g/dL for discharge)
  • No active cardiac ischemia or heart failure
  • B12/folate replacement initiated (B12 1000 mcg IM or folate 1 mg PO daily)
  • No evidence of alternative causes requiring hospital-level care
  • Outpatient hematology follow-up arranged if needed
  • Patient educated on lifelong B12 replacement if pernicious anemia
  • Return precautions for worsening neurologic symptoms, severe fatigue
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

87. BONE MARROW FAILURE / MDS / APLASTIC ANEMIA

Pancytopenia â€¢ Bone Marrow Hypoplasia â€¢ Transfusion-Dependent â€¢ Infection Risk
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Progressive pancytopenia with anemia symptoms, infections (neutropenia), and bleeding/bruising (thrombocytopenia). May present insidiously or acutely.

  • Symptoms by Cell Line Affected:
    • Anemia (Low RBC): Fatigue, dyspnea, pallor, tachycardia
    • Neutropenia (Low WBC): Recurrent infections, fever, oral ulcers
    • Thrombocytopenia (Low Platelets): Petechiae, purpura, bleeding (gums, nose, GI, CNS)
  • Physical Exam:
    • Pallor, petechiae, ecchymoses
    • NO hepatosplenomegaly (distinguishes from leukemia/lymphoma)
    • NO lymphadenopathy (distinguishes from hematologic malignancies)
    • Fever if infection present
APLASTIC ANEMIA

Definition: Bone marrow failure with pancytopenia and hypocellular marrow (<25% cellularity). Immune-mediated destruction of hematopoietic stem cells.

  • Severity Classification (Camitta Criteria):
    • Severe (SAA): Marrow cellularity <25% AND â‰¥2 of:
      • ANC <500/ÂµL
      • Platelets <20,000/ÂµL
      • Reticulocytes <60,000/ÂµL (corrected <1%)
    • Very Severe (vSAA): SAA criteria + ANC <200/ÂµL
    • Non-Severe (NSAA): Pancytopenia but doesn't meet SAA criteria
  • Etiologies:
    • Idiopathic (70%): Presumed autoimmune, no identifiable cause
    • Medications: Chloramphenicol, sulfonamides, gold, carbamazepine, NSAIDs, chemotherapy
    • Toxins: Benzene, pesticides, organic solvents
    • Viral: Hepatitis (seronegative hepatitis most common), EBV, CMV, parvovirus B19, HIV
    • Radiation: Ionizing radiation exposure
    • Inherited: Fanconi anemia, dyskeratosis congenita (usually present in childhood)
    • Pregnancy: Rare, may resolve postpartum
MYELODYSPLASTIC SYNDROMES (MDS)

Definition: Clonal stem cell disorders with ineffective hematopoiesis, dysplastic changes, and risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

  • Clinical Features:
    • Cytopenias (anemia most common, 80-85%)
    • Macrocytosis common (MCV >100 fL)
    • Progression to AML in 30% over time
    • Median age: 70+ years
  • WHO Classification (Selected Types):
    • MDS with Single Lineage Dysplasia: One cell line affected
    • MDS with Multilineage Dysplasia: â‰¥2 cell lines affected
    • MDS with Excess Blasts (MDS-EB): 5-19% blasts in marrow (higher AML risk)
    • MDS with del(5q): Isolated del(5q) cytogenetics, better prognosis
  • Risk Factors:
    • Prior chemotherapy/radiation (therapy-related MDS, poor prognosis)
    • Occupational exposures (benzene, pesticides)
    • Smoking
    • Inherited: Down syndrome, Fanconi anemia
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Complete Blood Count:

  • Pancytopenia: Anemia + leukopenia + thrombocytopenia
  • Reticulocyte Count: Low/inappropriately normal (indicates marrow failure)
  • MCV: May be elevated (especially MDS)

Peripheral Blood Smear:

  • Aplastic Anemia: Normocytic/normochromic RBCs, no dysplasia, no blasts
  • MDS: Dysplastic changes
    • RBCs: Macrocytosis, dimorphic population, basophilic stippling
    • WBCs: Hypogranular neutrophils, pseudo-Pelger-HuÃ«t anomaly (bilobed nucleus)
    • Platelets: Large/abnormal
    • May see blasts (if MDS-EB)

Bone Marrow Biopsy and Aspirate (Definitive Diagnosis):

  • Aplastic Anemia:
    • Hypocellular marrow (<25% cellularity for age)
    • Fatty replacement
    • No dysplasia or abnormal cells
    • Cytogenetics: Normal
  • MDS:
    • Normo- to hypercellular marrow (paradoxically cellular despite cytopenias)
    • Dysplastic changes in â‰¥10% of cells in â‰¥1 lineage
    • Increased blasts (5-19% in MDS-EB)
    • Cytogenetics: Often abnormal (del(5q), trisomy 8, -7/del(7q), complex)

Additional Labs:

  • B12/Folate: Rule out nutritional deficiency
  • LDH: Elevated in MDS (ineffective erythropoiesis)
  • EPO Level: Guide treatment (if <500 mU/mL, better response to ESA)
  • Viral Serologies: Hepatitis panel, HIV, EBV, CMV, parvovirus
  • Autoimmune Workup: ANA, RF (if concern for autoimmune etiology)
  • PNH Screen: Flow cytometry for CD55/CD59 (paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, associated with aplastic anemia)
  • Fanconi Anemia Testing: Chromosome breakage test (if young patient or family history)

Prognostic Scoring:

  • IPSS-R (Revised International Prognostic Scoring System) for MDS:
    • Incorporates: Cytogenetics, marrow blast %, cytopenias
    • Predicts survival and AML transformation risk
    • Guides treatment intensity
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Supportive Care (All Patients):

  • Transfusions:
    • pRBC: Goal Hgb >7 g/dL (or >8 if cardiac disease), use leukoreduced
    • Platelets: Goal >10,000/ÂµL prophylactic, >50,000/ÂµL if bleeding or pre-procedure
    • CMV-negative blood products if transplant candidate
  • Infection Prophylaxis (if ANC <500/ÂµL):
    • Fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin 500 mg PO daily or ciprofloxacin 500 mg PO BID)
    • Antifungal: Fluconazole 400 mg PO daily or posaconazole 300 mg PO daily
    • Antiviral: Acyclovir 400 mg PO BID (HSV prophylaxis)
  • Febrile Neutropenia: Broad-spectrum antibiotics (see separate condition)
  • Growth Factors:
    • Erythropoiesis-Stimulating Agents (ESA): Epoetin alfa or darbepoetin for anemia (if EPO <500 and MDS)
    • G-CSF: Filgrastim for severe neutropenia with recurrent infections
  • Iron Chelation (if ferritin >1000 ng/mL from transfusions):
    • Deferasirox 20-30 mg/kg PO daily
    • Prevents organ damage from iron overload

APLASTIC ANEMIA - Definitive Treatment:

  • Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant (HSCT) - First-Line if Young with Matched Donor:
    • Indications: Age <40-50, severe/very severe AA, matched sibling donor
    • Success rate: 80-90% long-term survival if <20 years old
    • Refer to transplant center immediately
    • Minimize transfusions before transplant (reduces alloimmunization/GVHD risk)
  • Immunosuppressive Therapy (IST) - First-Line if No Donor or Older Age:
    • Horse Anti-Thymocyte Globulin (h-ATG) + Cyclosporine:
      • h-ATG 40 mg/kg/day IV Ã—4 days
      • Cyclosporine 5-6 mg/kg/day PO BID (adjust to trough 200-400 ng/mL)
      • Continue cyclosporine 6-12 months, taper slowly
      • Response rate: 60-70% (hematologic improvement by 3-6 months)
    • Eltrombopag: Add to h-ATG/cyclosporine (improves response rate)
    • Steroids: Methylprednisolone during ATG to prevent serum sickness
  • Eltrombopag Monotherapy (Refractory/Relapsed):
    • 150 mg PO daily (TPO receptor agonist)
    • Response rate: 40% in refractory cases

MDS - Treatment by Risk Category:

  • Lower-Risk MDS (IPSS-R Low/Intermediate):
    • Observation: If asymptomatic, minimal cytopenias
    • ESA + G-CSF: For anemia (if EPO <500 mU/mL)
    • Lenalidomide: If del(5q) cytogenetics, 10 mg PO daily Ã—21 days/cycle (67% transfusion independence)
    • Luspatercept: For transfusion-dependent anemia with ring sideroblasts
    • Immunosuppression: ATG/cyclosporine in selected cases (younger, hypocellular)
  • Higher-Risk MDS (IPSS-R Intermediate/High/Very High):
    • HSCT: Only curative option if transplant-eligible
    • Hypomethylating Agents (HMA):
      • Azacitidine 75 mg/mÂ² SC/IV days 1-7 every 28 days
      • Decitabine 20 mg/mÂ² IV daily Ã—5 days every 28 days
      • Response rate: 40-50%, median survival benefit 9-10 months
      • Continue until progression or intolerance
    • Intensive Chemotherapy: If fit and AML transformation (7+3 induction)

Monitoring:

  • CBC with differential weekly initially, then adjust based on stability
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Every 6-12 months to assess response and monitor for progression
  • Cytogenetics: Serially to detect clonal evolution
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Pancytopenia Without Organomegaly = Think Bone Marrow Failure: Aplastic anemia and MDS present with cytopenias but NO splenomegaly or lymphadenopathy (unlike leukemia/lymphoma). If pancytopenia with big spleen, think different diagnosis.
  • MDS is "Ineffective" Hematopoiesis: Paradoxically, MDS marrow is often hypercellular (lots of cells) but produces dysfunctional cells that die in marrow (intramedullary hemolysis). This is why you see cytopenias despite cellular marrow.
  • HSCT is Curative for Aplastic Anemia: If patient <40-50 years with severe AA and matched sibling donor, HSCT should be first-line (80-90% cure rate). Refer immediately and MINIMIZE transfusions beforehand to reduce alloimmunization.
  • Horse ATG > Rabbit ATG: Multiple trials show horse anti-thymocyte globulin superior to rabbit ATG for aplastic anemia (higher response rate, better survival). Always use h-ATG if available.
  • MDS with del(5q) = Lenalidomide: Isolated del(5q) cytogenetics predicts excellent response to lenalidomide (67% achieve transfusion independence). This is one of the few MDS subtypes with targeted therapy.
  • PNH Association: 30-50% of aplastic anemia patients have PNH clone detectable by flow cytometry. Screen all aplastic anemia patients for PNH (CD55/CD59 deficiency). Some will develop overt PNH later.
  • Seronegative Hepatitis â†’ Aplastic Anemia: Hepatitis-associated aplastic anemia typically occurs 2-3 months after acute hepatitis, and serologies are often NEGATIVE (non-A, non-B, non-C hepatitis). Young males most common.
  • MDS Transforms to AML: ~30% of MDS patients progress to AML over time. Higher-risk MDS (high blast count, poor cytogenetics) transforms faster. This is why close monitoring with serial bone marrow biopsies is essential.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Septic shock or severe infection with neutropenia (ANC <500)
  • Massive transfusion requirement or uncontrolled bleeding
  • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
  • Multi-organ dysfunction
  • Tumor lysis syndrome (rare but can occur with MDS treatment)
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable, afebrile >48 hours
  • ANC recovering or stable (ideally >500 if neutropenic)
  • Hemoglobin and platelets at safe baseline for patient
  • Any active infections controlled on appropriate antibiotics
  • Transfusion requirements met (target Hgb >7, platelets >10k if stable)
  • Outpatient hematology/oncology follow-up arranged (within 1-2 weeks)
  • Growth factor therapy initiated if indicated (G-CSF, EPO, TPO agonists)
  • Patient educated on fever precautions if neutropenic (return for temp >100.4Â°F)
  • Bone marrow biopsy completed or arranged
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

88. DRUG-INDUCED THROMBOCYTOPENIA

Platelet <100,000/ÂµL â€¢ Recent Medication â€¢ Bleeding Risk â€¢ Heparin/Quinine/Antibiotics
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Acute onset thrombocytopenia (platelets <100,000/ÂµL) temporally related to new medication exposure. May present with bleeding manifestations or incidentally discovered on labs.

  • Timing:
    • Acute Onset: Within 1-2 weeks of starting new medication
    • Re-exposure: Within hours to days if previously exposed (immune memory)
  • Clinical Manifestations:
    • Asymptomatic: Platelets 50,000-100,000/ÂµL, found incidentally
    • Mucocutaneous Bleeding: Platelets 10,000-50,000/ÂµL
      • Petechiae (pinpoint hemorrhages)
      • Purpura (larger bruises)
      • Gingival bleeding, epistaxis
      • Menorrhagia
    • Severe Bleeding: Platelets <10,000/ÂµL
      • GI bleeding (melena, hematemesis)
      • Hematuria
      • Intracranial hemorrhage (rare but life-threatening)
  • Physical Exam:
    • Petechiae (especially lower extremities, dependent areas)
    • Purpura, ecchymoses
    • Wet purpura (blood blisters in mouth = high bleeding risk)
    • NO splenomegaly (distinguishes from ITP, liver disease)
MECHANISMS AND COMMON CAUSATIVE DRUGS

Immune-Mediated (Drug-Dependent Antibodies):

  • Mechanism: Drug or drug-platelet complex induces antibody formation â†’ Platelet destruction/consumption
  • Most Common Culprits:
    • Quinine/Quinidine: Classic cause, found in tonic water, supplements
    • Antibiotics:
      • Beta-lactams (penicillin, cephalosporins)
      • Sulfonamides (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole)
      • Vancomycin
      • Linezolid (dose-dependent + immune)
      • Rifampin
    • Anticonvulsants: Valproic acid, carbamazepine, phenytoin
    • NSAIDs: Naproxen, ibuprofen, diclofenac
    • Antiplatelet Agents: Abciximab, eptifibatide, tirofiban (GPIIb/IIIa inhibitors)
    • H2 Blockers: Cimetidine, ranitidine
    • Diuretics: Furosemide, HCTZ
    • Antiretrovirals: Zidovudine (AZT)
    • Immunosuppressants: Sirolimus, mycophenolate

Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT) - Special Category:

  • Type I HIT (Non-immune):
    • Early (1-2 days), mild (platelets >100K), transient
    • Direct platelet aggregation
    • No clinical significance, heparin can continue
  • Type II HIT (Immune-mediated, SERIOUS):
    • Onset: 5-10 days (earlier if prior heparin exposure)
    • Mechanism: PF4-heparin antibodies â†’ Platelet activation â†’ Thrombosis
    • Platelets drop >50% from baseline (not necessarily <100K)
    • PARADOX: Thrombocytopenia PLUS thrombosis (arterial/venous)
    • Mortality 20-30% if not recognized
    • Unfractionated heparin > LMWH risk

Dose-Dependent Bone Marrow Suppression:

  • Chemotherapy: All cytotoxic agents
  • Immunosuppressants: Azathioprine, mycophenolate
  • Linezolid: Thrombocytopenia common with >2 weeks use
  • Valproic Acid: Dose-dependent, usually mild

TTP-Like (Thrombotic Microangiopathy):

  • Drugs: Quinine, ticlopidine, clopidogrel, cyclosporine, tacrolimus
  • Mechanism: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia + thrombocytopenia + organ dysfunction
  • See TTP/HUS section for full details
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

History (Most Important):

  • Medication Review: ALL medications including OTC, herbals, supplements (quinine in tonic water!)
  • Timing: When medication started, when platelets dropped
  • Prior Exposures: Has patient taken drug before? (Re-exposure â†’ rapid drop)
  • Bleeding Symptoms: Petechiae, epistaxis, GI/GU bleeding

Labs:

  • CBC with Differential:
    • Isolated thrombocytopenia (RBC/WBC normal in immune-mediated)
    • Pancytopenia suggests bone marrow suppression
  • Peripheral Blood Smear:
    • Rule out pseudothrombocytopenia (platelet clumping from EDTA)
    • Assess platelet size/morphology
    • Look for schistocytes (TTP/HUS)
    • No blasts (rule out leukemia)
  • PT/PTT: Normal (isolated platelet disorder)
  • If Bleeding: Type & screen, fibrinogen, D-dimer

HIT-Specific Testing (If Heparin Exposure):

  • 4T Score (Pre-test Probability):
    • Thrombocytopenia magnitude
    • Timing of platelet fall
    • Thrombosis or other sequelae
    • Other causes of thrombocytopenia
    • Score 0-3: Low probability (HIT unlikely)
    • Score 4-5: Intermediate
    • Score 6-8: High probability (HIT likely)
  • HIT ELISA (PF4 Antibody):
    • High sensitivity (>95%), moderate specificity
    • Positive = may have HIT, confirm with functional assay
    • Negative = HIT excluded
  • Serotonin Release Assay (SRA) - Gold Standard:
    • Functional assay, high specificity
    • Send to reference lab, takes days

Additional Testing (If Diagnosis Unclear):

  • Bone Marrow Biopsy: If pancytopenia, concern for marrow disorder, or diagnosis uncertain
  • HIV, Hepatitis C: Can cause thrombocytopenia
  • Autoimmune Workup: If considering ITP (ANA, RF)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Management:

  • DISCONTINUE OFFENDING DRUG (Most Important):
    • Stop ALL non-essential medications
    • If multiple suspects, stop all or use most likely culprit
    • Platelets typically recover within 1-2 weeks after stopping drug
  • Assess Bleeding Risk:
    • Mild (>50K): Observation, avoid trauma/procedures
    • Moderate (10-50K): Close monitoring, avoid NSAIDs/anticoagulants
    • Severe (<10K or active bleeding): Hospitalize, consider treatment

Supportive Care:

  • Platelet Transfusion:
    • Indications:
      • Active bleeding + platelets <50,000/ÂµL
      • Severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/ÂµL) with bleeding risk
      • Pre-procedure: Goal >50,000 (surgery) or >100,000 (CNS/ophthalmology)
    • Dose: 1 apheresis unit or 4-6 pooled units (should raise platelets ~30,000-50,000/ÂµL)
    • NOTE: Transfusions often have SHORT duration in immune-mediated (antibodies destroy transfused platelets)
    • AVOID in HIT: Worsens thrombosis risk
  • Avoid:
    • NSAIDs, aspirin (impair platelet function)
    • IM injections
    • Anticoagulation (unless HIT, see below)
    • Invasive procedures unless essential

Specific Treatment for Severe Cases (Platelets <10K or Bleeding):

  • IVIG (If Life-Threatening Bleeding):
    • 1 g/kg IV Ã—1-2 days
    • Rapid increase in platelets (within 24-48h)
    • Benefit temporary (days)
  • Corticosteroids:
    • Prednisone 1 mg/kg PO daily
    • Consider if platelets not recovering after stopping drug
    • Unclear benefit, often used empirically
  • Plasmapheresis: If TTP-like drug reaction (see TTP protocol)

HIT-Specific Management (Type II):

  • STOP ALL HEPARIN IMMEDIATELY:
    • All UFH and LMWH
    • Flush heparin lines
    • Remove heparin-coated catheters
  • Start NON-HEPARIN ANTICOAGULATION (Even Without Thrombosis):
    • Rationale: HIT is prothrombotic state, 50% develop thrombosis if untreated
    • First-Line Agents:
      • Argatroban: 2 mcg/kg/min IV (adjust to aPTT 1.5-3Ã— baseline), preferred if hepatic dysfunction
      • Bivalirudin: 0.15-0.2 mg/kg/h IV
      • Fondaparinux: 7.5 mg SC daily (off-label, emerging evidence)
      • DOACs: Apixaban, rivaroxaban (after platelets recover >150K)
    • Duration: 4 weeks minimum (or longer if thrombosis present)
    • AVOID: Warfarin alone initially (increases thrombosis risk until therapeutic anticoagulation achieved)
  • DO NOT Transfuse Platelets: Increases thrombosis risk
  • Screen for Thrombosis: Duplex ultrasound (DVT), CTA chest (PE)

Monitoring:

  • CBC daily initially, then every 2-3 days
  • Platelets typically recover within 1-2 weeks after drug cessation
  • If no recovery by 2-3 weeks, consider alternative diagnosis (ITP, bone marrow disorder)

Prevention/Avoidance:

  • Document Drug Allergy: In EMR, alert bracelet
  • Avoid Re-exposure: Will cause rapid recurrence (hours to days)
  • Cross-Reactivity: May occur within drug classes (e.g., beta-lactams)
  • Patient Education: Provide list of medications to avoid
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Think Drugs FIRST in New Thrombocytopenia: Drug-induced thrombocytopenia is diagnosis of exclusion but should be TOP of differential. Meticulous medication history (including OTC, herbals, supplements) is essential. Quinine in tonic water is a classic culprit.
  • HIT is Thrombosis WITH Thrombocytopenia: Unlike other drug-induced thrombocytopenias, HIT causes CLOTTING (arterial/venous thrombosis) despite low platelets. Don't be fooled - anticoagulate immediately, don't transfuse platelets. The "T" in HIT stands for thrombocytopenia but thrombosis is what kills.
  • 4T Score Guides HIT Testing: Low 4T score (0-3) has high NPV - HIT is extremely unlikely, don't stop heparin or start alternate anticoagulation based on low score. Intermediate/high scores warrant HIT testing and empiric treatment while awaiting results.
  • Stop Drug = Cure: For most drug-induced thrombocytopenias, simply stopping the offending agent leads to recovery in 1-2 weeks. If platelets aren't improving by 2-3 weeks, reconsider diagnosis (may be ITP or bone marrow disorder).
  • GPIIb/IIIa Inhibitors = Rapid Onset: Abciximab, eptifibatide, tirofiban can cause severe thrombocytopenia within HOURS (not days). Always check platelet count 2-4 hours after starting these medications in catheterization lab.
  • IVIG Works Fast but Temporarily: In life-threatening bleeding with drug-induced thrombocytopenia, IVIG can raise platelets within 24-48 hours. But effect is temporary (days) - buys time while drug clears from system.
  • Never Re-challenge: Once patient has drug-induced thrombocytopenia, re-exposure causes RAPID recurrence (hours to days) because immune memory is present. Document as allergy and avoid forever, including cross-reactive drugs.
  • Warfarin Alone Worsens HIT: Starting warfarin without adequate alternative anticoagulation in HIT causes venous limb gangrene (warfarin-induced skin necrosis). Always anticoagulate with direct thrombin inhibitor or fondaparinux FIRST, overlap with warfarin once platelets recover >150K.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Active life-threatening bleeding (ICH, massive GI bleed, pulmonary hemorrhage)
  • Platelet count <10,000/Î¼L with high bleeding risk
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia with thrombosis requiring anticoagulation
  • Multi-organ dysfunction from TTP/HUS
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable without active bleeding
  • Platelet count improving or stable (typically >30,000-50,000 for discharge depending on etiology)
  • Offending drug discontinued
  • No evidence of thrombotic complications (if HIT)
  • If HIT: transitioned to non-heparin anticoagulant (argatroban, fondaparinux)
  • If ITP: on appropriate treatment (IVIG, steroids) with outpatient hematology follow-up
  • Patient educated on avoiding offending drug in future
  • Medical alert bracelet recommended if severe reaction (especially HIT)
  • Follow-up with hematology arranged
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

89. ACUTE LEUKEMIA / LYMPHOMA (Acute Presentations)

Cytopenias â€¢ Blasts â€¢ Lymphadenopathy â€¢ B-Symptoms â€¢ Oncologic Emergency
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Acute-onset cytopenias with or without leukocytosis, constitutional symptoms, and/or lymphadenopathy. May present with oncologic emergencies (hyperleukocytosis, tumor lysis, SVC syndrome).

  • Symptoms by Cytopenias:
    • Anemia: Fatigue, dyspnea, pallor
    • Thrombocytopenia: Petechiae, bruising, bleeding (gums, epistaxis, GI, CNS)
    • Neutropenia: Recurrent infections, fever
  • B-Symptoms (Lymphoma):
    • Fever >38Â°C (without infection)
    • Drenching night sweats
    • Unintentional weight loss >10% body weight in 6 months
  • Physical Exam:
    • Leukemia: Pallor, petechiae, hepatosplenomegaly (50%), gingival hypertrophy (AML-M5), chloromas (AML), NO significant lymphadenopathy
    • Lymphoma: Lymphadenopathy (cervical, axillary, inguinal), hepatosplenomegaly, Waldeyer's ring involvement
ACUTE LEUKEMIAS

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML):

  • Definition: â‰¥20% blasts in bone marrow or peripheral blood (WHO criteria)
  • Peak Age: 65+ years (median 68)
  • Presentation:
    • Acute onset (days to weeks)
    • Cytopenias (anemia, thrombocytopenia, neutropenia)
    • Leukocytosis in 50% (may be low, normal, or high)
    • DIC (especially APL - M3 subtype)
    • Leukostasis if WBC >100,000/ÂµL
  • Subtypes of Note:
    • Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL, M3): t(15;17), DIC, tretinoin-responsive, curable
    • AML with inv(16) or t(8;21): Better prognosis
    • Therapy-related AML: Prior chemotherapy/radiation, poor prognosis

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL):

  • Definition: â‰¥20% lymphoblasts in bone marrow
  • Peak Age: Children 2-5 years (80% pediatric), second peak in older adults
  • Presentation:
    • Cytopenias, bone pain (children)
    • Mediastinal mass (T-cell ALL)
    • CNS involvement (5-10%)
  • Subtypes:
    • B-cell ALL: 75% of cases
    • T-cell ALL: 25%, more common in adolescents/young adults, mediastinal mass
    • Philadelphia chromosome-positive (Ph+): t(9;22), 25% of adult ALL, worse prognosis (but improved with TKIs)
AGGRESSIVE LYMPHOMAS (Acute Presentations)

Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL):

  • Most common aggressive NHL (30% of all lymphomas)
  • Rapidly enlarging lymphadenopathy
  • Extranodal involvement common (40%): GI, bone, CNS, testes
  • B-symptoms in 30%

Burkitt Lymphoma:

  • Highly aggressive, very high proliferation rate (Ki-67 ~100%)
  • Subtypes: Endemic (African, EBV+, jaw mass), sporadic (abdomen, GI), HIV-associated
  • Tumor lysis syndrome risk with treatment
  • Curable with intensive chemotherapy

Lymphoblastic Lymphoma:

  • T-cell or B-cell, similar to ALL
  • Mediastinal mass common (T-cell)
  • Bone marrow <25% blasts (vs. â‰¥25% = ALL)
  • Treated like ALL (intensive chemotherapy + CNS prophylaxis)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Initial Labs:

  • CBC with Differential:
    • Cytopenias (anemia, thrombocytopenia, neutropenia)
    • WBC: Variable (low, normal, or high)
    • BLAST count on differential
  • Peripheral Blood Smear:
    • Leukemia: Circulating blasts, Auer rods (AML)
    • Lymphoma: May see circulating lymphoma cells (rare)
  • Chemistry:
    • CMP, LDH (elevated, tumor burden marker)
    • Uric acid (tumor lysis risk)
    • Calcium, phosphorus (tumor lysis)
  • Coagulation:
    • PT/INR, PTT, fibrinogen, D-dimer
    • Rule out DIC (especially APL)
  • Type & Screen: Anticipate transfusion needs

Bone Marrow Biopsy and Aspirate (Definitive for Leukemia):

  • Morphology: â‰¥20% blasts for leukemia diagnosis
  • Flow Cytometry: Immunophenotyping (distinguish AML vs. ALL vs. lymphoma)
  • Cytogenetics: Prognostic information, guide therapy (e.g., APL t(15;17), Ph+ ALL t(9;22))
  • Molecular Studies: FLT3, NPM1, CEBPA (AML), BCR-ABL (Ph+ ALL)

Lymph Node Biopsy (Definitive for Lymphoma):

  • Excisional Biopsy Preferred: Whole lymph node (core needle if excisional not feasible)
  • Histology: Architecture, cell morphology
  • Immunohistochemistry: CD20, CD3, Ki-67, etc.
  • Flow Cytometry: B-cell vs. T-cell, clonality
  • Cytogenetics/FISH: t(14;18) (follicular), t(11;14) (mantle cell), MYC rearrangement (Burkitt)

Staging/Disease Assessment:

  • CT Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis: Lymphadenopathy, organomegaly, masses
  • PET/CT: For lymphoma staging (not routinely for leukemia)
  • Lumbar Puncture: CNS prophylaxis/staging for ALL, Burkitt, lymphoblastic lymphoma
  • Bone Marrow Biopsy: For lymphoma staging (especially aggressive)

Tumor Lysis Labs (If High Burden):

  • K+, PO4, Ca2+, uric acid, LDH, Cr
  • Check Q4-6H initially if high risk
ONCOLOGIC EMERGENCIES

Hyperleukocytosis / Leukostasis:

  • Definition: WBC >100,000/ÂµL with symptoms
  • Symptoms: Dyspnea, hypoxia, confusion, vision changes, priapism
  • Mechanism: Blast sludging in microcirculation â†’ tissue hypoxia
  • Treatment:
    • Urgent leukapheresis (if AML)
    • Hydroxyurea 50-100 mg/kg PO daily (cytoreduction)
    • Aggressive hydration
    • Allopurinol or rasburicase (prevent TLS)
    • AVOID transfusions initially (increases viscosity)
    • Start chemotherapy once WBC controlled

Tumor Lysis Syndrome (TLS):

  • Definition (Cairo-Bishop): â‰¥2 of: Hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia (within 3 days before or 7 days after chemotherapy)
  • High-Risk: Burkitt, lymphoblastic lymphoma, ALL, AML with WBC >100K
  • Treatment:
    • Aggressive Hydration: NS 200-300 mL/hr (goal UOP 80-100 mL/hr)
    • Rasburicase: 0.2 mg/kg IV Ã—1 (for uric acid >8 mg/dL or high risk)
    • Allopurinol: 300-600 mg PO daily (if low risk or after rasburicase)
    • Manage hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia
    • Consider dialysis if refractory

DIC (Especially APL):

  • Presentation: Bleeding, thrombosis, coagulopathy
  • Labs: Low platelets, low fibrinogen, elevated PT/PTT, elevated D-dimer
  • Treatment:
    • Urgent hematology consultation
    • Start ATRA (all-trans retinoic acid) IMMEDIATELY if APL suspected (don't wait for confirmation)
    • Transfuse: pRBC, platelets, cryoprecipitate/FFP to maintain fibrinogen >100-150 mg/dL, platelets >30-50K
    • AVOID heparin

SVC Syndrome:

  • Presentation: Facial swelling, JVD, dyspnea, upper extremity edema
  • Cause: Mediastinal mass (lymphoma, esp. T-cell lymphoblastic)
  • Treatment:
    • Elevate head of bed, supplemental O2
    • Urgent tissue diagnosis (biopsy before steroids if possible)
    • Steroids: Dexamethasone 10 mg IV (if respiratory compromise)
    • Radiation or chemotherapy once diagnosis confirmed
INITIAL MANAGEMENT

Supportive Care:

  • Transfusions:
    • pRBC: Goal Hgb >7 g/dL (>8 if cardiac disease)
    • Platelets: >10K prophylactic, >50K if bleeding or pre-procedure
    • Use leukoreduced, irradiated, CMV-negative products
  • Infection Prophylaxis (Neutropenic):
    • Fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin 500 mg daily)
    • Antifungal (fluconazole 400 mg daily or posaconazole)
    • Antiviral (acyclovir 400 mg BID)
    • PJP prophylaxis (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole DS TIW or atovaquone)
  • Febrile Neutropenia: Broad-spectrum antibiotics (piperacillin-tazobactam or cefepime)

Urgent Hematology/Oncology Consultation:

  • Arrange same-day consultation for new leukemia/aggressive lymphoma diagnosis
  • Coordinate bone marrow biopsy, lymph node biopsy
  • Discuss treatment plan (chemotherapy timing, clinical trials)

Disposition:

  • Admit: New leukemia or aggressive lymphoma diagnosis (ICU if unstable, oncologic emergency)
  • Goals: Stabilize, complete workup, initiate treatment
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • APL = Start ATRA Immediately: If you suspect APL (Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia - AML M3) based on clinical presentation and smear (Auer rods, promyelocytes), start ATRA (tretinoin) IMMEDIATELY without waiting for cytogenetics. APL causes life-threatening DIC and ATRA is life-saving. Delay kills.
  • Hyperleukocytosis Paradox: WBC >100,000/ÂµL with leukostasis causes tissue hypoxia. Transfusing pRBC/platelets BEFORE cytoreduction increases blood viscosity and worsens leukostasis. Cytoreduction (leukapheresis, hydroxyurea) FIRST, then transfuse.
  • Tumor Lysis Can Occur Before Chemo: High-burden cancers (Burkitt, lymphoblastic lymphoma, high WBC leukemia) can have spontaneous tumor lysis BEFORE treatment starts. Monitor labs closely, start hydration and rasburicase preemptively in high-risk patients.
  • Blasts on Smear = Urgent Workup: Circulating blasts on peripheral smear require immediate hematology consultation and bone marrow biopsy within 24 hours. Don't wait for outpatient follow-up - this is potentially life-threatening.
  • Lymphoma vs. Leukemia Physical Exam: Lymphoma = prominent lymphadenopathy, less hepatosplenomegaly. Leukemia = hepatosplenomegaly common, minimal lymphadenopathy. If confused, remember: lymphoma is lymph node disease, leukemia is bone marrow disease.
  • Philadelphia Chromosome Changes Everything: Ph+ ALL (t(9;22), BCR-ABL fusion) was historically dismal prognosis. Now with tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs like imatinib, dasatinib), outcomes dramatically improved. Always check for Ph+ and add TKI to chemotherapy.
  • CNS Prophylaxis in ALL and Burkitt: Both have high risk of CNS involvement (5-10% at diagnosis, much higher without prophylaxis). Always do LP for staging and administer intrathecal chemotherapy (methotrexate, cytarabine) as part of treatment protocol.
  • Excisional Biopsy for Lymphoma Diagnosis: Core needle biopsies often insufficient for lymphoma subtyping (need architecture). Excisional lymph node biopsy is gold standard. If patient has mediastinal mass and you're considering lymphoma, get tissue diagnosis BEFORE giving steroids (destroys lymphocytes, makes diagnosis impossible).
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Septic shock or severe neutropenic fever unresponsive to antibiotics
  • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
  • Tumor lysis syndrome with renal failure requiring dialysis
  • Leukostasis with end-organ damage (CNS symptoms, respiratory failure)
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation with life-threatening bleeding
  • Multi-organ dysfunction
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable, afebrile >48 hours
  • Acute complications resolved (tumor lysis syndrome, leukostasis, infection)
  • Electrolytes normalized, renal function stable
  • Transfusion-dependent but at safe baseline (Hgb >7, platelets >10-20k)
  • Chemotherapy initiated or arranged with hematology/oncology
  • Central line placed if needed for chemotherapy
  • Outpatient hematology/oncology follow-up arranged (within days)
  • Patient educated on neutropenic precautions
  • Return precautions for fever >100.4Â°F, bleeding, severe weakness
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

90. CEREBRAL SALT WASTING (CSW)

Hyponatremia â€¢ Volume Depletion â€¢ CNS Injury â€¢ High Urine Sodium
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Hyponatremia with clinical euvolemia or hypovolemia in patient with CNS pathology (SAH, TBI, meningitis, neurosurgery). Renal sodium wasting leads to volume depletion despite low serum sodium.

  • Timing: Typically occurs 2-10 days after CNS injury (peak 7-10 days)
  • Symptoms:
    • Hyponatremia: Confusion, lethargy, headache, nausea, seizures (if severe/rapid)
    • Volume Depletion: Orthostasis, tachycardia, decreased urine output, dry mucous membranes
    • May be masked by underlying CNS pathology
  • Associated CNS Conditions:
    • Subarachnoid hemorrhage (Most Common): 30-40% incidence
    • Traumatic brain injury
    • Intracerebral hemorrhage
    • Meningitis/encephalitis
    • Brain tumors
    • Post-neurosurgery
PATHOPHYSIOLOGY AND MECHANISM
  • Mechanism (Not Fully Understood):
    • CNS injury â†’ Release of natriuretic peptides (BNP, ANP, or "cerebral natriuretic peptide")
    • Natriuretic peptides â†’ Renal sodium wasting
    • Sodium loss â†’ Obligate water loss (isotonic fluid loss)
    • Net result: Hyponatremia + Hypovolemia
  • Distinction from SIADH (Critical):
    Feature Cerebral Salt Wasting SIADH
    Volume Status Hypovolemic Euvolemic
    Urine Na+ >40 mEq/L (high) >40 mEq/L (high)
    Serum Uric Acid Low or normal Low (<4 mg/dL)
    BUN Elevated (â†‘BUN/Cr) Low-normal
    Response to Saline Improves Na+ Worsens/no change
    Treatment IVF + Salt Fluid restrict
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Labs:

  • Serum Sodium: Typically 120-135 mEq/L (can be <120 if severe)
  • Serum Osmolality: Low (<280 mOsm/kg) - true hyponatremia
  • Urine Sodium: >40 mEq/L (inappropriately high for hypovolemic state)
  • Urine Osmolality: >100 mOsm/kg (concentrated urine despite hyponatremia)
  • BUN/Cr: BUN:Cr ratio >20:1 (prerenal from volume depletion)
  • Serum Uric Acid: Variable (low-normal, less reliable than in SIADH)

Volume Assessment (Key to Diagnosis):

  • Clinical Signs of Hypovolemia:
    • Orthostatic hypotension (SBP drop >20 mmHg or HR increase >20 bpm)
    • Tachycardia
    • Decreased skin turgor, dry mucous membranes
    • Flat neck veins
  • Objective Measures (if available):
    • CVP <5 mmHg (if central line present)
    • Negative fluid balance (intake < output)
    • Weight loss
  • CHALLENGE: Volume assessment difficult in ICU patients with CNS injury (sedated, on vasopressors, receiving IVF)

Response to Treatment (Diagnostic and Therapeutic):

  • Saline Challenge:
    • Give NS 500-1000 mL IV bolus
    • CSW: Sodium improves (positive response)
    • SIADH: Sodium worsens or no change (dilution)

Rule Out Other Causes of Hyponatremia:

  • Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisol, ACTH stimulation test
  • Hypothyroidism: TSH, free T4
  • Diuretic use: Medication review
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Goals of Treatment:

  • Correct hypovolemia (restore normal volume status)
  • Correct hyponatremia (prevent/treat symptoms)
  • Prevent complications (cerebral vasospasm in SAH, seizures)

Fluid and Sodium Replacement:

  • Isotonic Saline (0.9% NS):
    • First-line therapy
    • Bolus: 500-1000 mL IV initially, assess response
    • Maintenance: 100-250 mL/hr continuous infusion
    • Goal: Restore euvolemia (CVP 8-12, MAP >65, UOP >0.5 mL/kg/hr)
  • Hypertonic Saline (3% NaCl) - If Severe or Symptomatic:
    • Indications: Na+ <120 mEq/L with symptoms (confusion, seizures, coma)
    • Dose: 100 mL IV bolus over 10 min (can repeat Ã—2-3)
    • Infusion: 0.5-1 mL/kg/hr continuous (30-60 mL/hr for 70 kg patient)
    • Target: Increase Na+ by 4-6 mEq/L in first few hours (just enough to stop symptoms)
    • Maximum Correction:
      • 8 mEq/L in first 24 hours
      • 18 mEq/L in first 48 hours
      • Prevents osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS)

Oral Salt Supplementation:

  • Salt Tablets: 1-3 g PO TID (if patient able to take PO)
  • High-Salt Diet: Encourage salty foods, broths
  • Used as adjunct to IV therapy or for long-term management

Fludrocortisone (Mineralocorticoid):

  • Dose: 0.1-0.2 mg PO BID
  • Mechanism: Promotes renal sodium retention
  • Use: Adjunct therapy if persistent CSW despite aggressive salt/fluid replacement
  • Side Effects: Hypertension, hypokalemia, fluid overload

Monitoring:

  • Serum Na+: Q4-6H initially, then Q8-12H once stable
  • Volume Status: Daily weights, I/O balance, orthostatics
  • Urine Output: Goal >0.5 mL/kg/hr
  • Neurologic Exam: Frequent assessments (q1-2h in ICU)

Special Consideration in SAH:

  • Euvolemia is Critical: Hypovolemia increases risk of cerebral vasospasm and delayed cerebral ischemia
  • Aggressive Volume Repletion: Target high-normal volume status
  • Monitor for Vasospasm: Transcranial Dopplers, CT perfusion
  • CSW treatment aligns with SAH management goals (maintain perfusion)

Duration of Treatment:

  • CSW typically self-limited, resolves over 2-4 weeks
  • Continue salt supplementation until sodium stable off therapy
  • Monitor for recurrence (uncommon)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • CSW vs. SIADH: The Million-Dollar Question: Both present with hyponatremia + high urine sodium in CNS injury patients. The KEY is volume status: CSW = hypovolemic (give fluids), SIADH = euvolemic (restrict fluids). Treating SIADH as CSW is safe (extra fluids), but treating CSW as SIADH is catastrophic (fluid restriction worsens hypovolemia and cerebral perfusion, especially in SAH).
  • When in Doubt, Give Saline: In neurocritical care, especially SAH, it's safer to err toward CSW diagnosis. Volume depletion increases vasospasm risk. Give isotonic saline and observe response: CSW improves, SIADH doesn't worsen significantly. This is the "therapeutic trial" approach.
  • SAH = High CSW Risk: 30-40% of SAH patients develop CSW, usually days 3-10 post-bleed (peak day 7). Hyponatremia in SAH patient should be assumed CSW until proven otherwise, especially if any signs of volume depletion.
  • Don't Overcorrect Sodium: Even though CSW requires aggressive salt/fluid replacement, you must still respect the 8/18 rule (8 mEq/L increase in 24h, 18 mEq/L in 48h) to prevent osmotic demyelination. Monitor Na+ closely, slow down fluids if correcting too fast.
  • Urine Sodium >40 in Both: High urine sodium is NOT specific for SIADH - it's also present in CSW (renal sodium wasting). Don't use urine sodium alone to distinguish. Volume status is king.
  • BUN:Cr Ratio is Helpful: Elevated BUN with preserved Cr (ratio >20:1) suggests prerenal azotemia from hypovolemia (CSW). Normal/low BUN suggests euvolemia (SIADH). Not perfect but useful adjunct.
  • Fludrocortisone is Adjunct, Not First-Line: Some centers use fludrocortisone routinely for CSW, but it's not necessary in most cases. IV saline + oral salt are usually sufficient. Fludrocortisone can cause hypertension (bad in SAH/ICH) and hypokalemia.
  • CSW is Self-Limited: Unlike SIADH (which may persist), CSW typically resolves spontaneously over 2-4 weeks as brain injury heals. You can wean salt supplementation and monitor for recurrence, which is rare.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Severe hyponatremia (Na <120 mEq/L) with altered mental status or seizures
  • Rapid sodium correction needed with close monitoring
  • Hemodynamic instability from hypovolemia
  • Ongoing neurosurgical issues requiring ICU-level care
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Sodium corrected to safe level (typically >130 mEq/L, or stable >125 mEq/L if chronic)
  • No seizures or severe neurologic symptoms
  • Euvolemic or volume replete
  • Underlying neurosurgical condition stable
  • On appropriate salt tablets (1-2g TID) and high-salt diet
  • If on fludrocortisone: outpatient endocrinology follow-up arranged
  • Patient educated on high-salt diet, liberal fluid intake
  • Follow-up with neurosurgery and primary care arranged
  • Recheck sodium within 2-3 days of discharge
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

91. ACUTE GLOMERULONEPHRITIS

Hematuria + Proteinuria + HTN + Edema â€¢ Nephritic Syndrome â€¢ Kidney Biopsy Definitive
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Nephritic Syndrome (Classic Presentation): Hematuria + Hypertension + Edema + Proteinuria (sub-nephrotic range, usually <3.5 g/day) + AKI

Clinical Features:

  • Hematuria:
    • Gross hematuria (tea-colored, cola-colored urine) or microscopic
    • Dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts on urinalysis (pathognomonic for glomerular source)
  • Hypertension: New-onset or worsening HTN from fluid retention + decreased GFR
  • Edema:
    • Periorbital edema (morning, most specific for glomerular disease)
    • Lower extremity edema, weight gain
    • Pulmonary edema if severe (volume overload)
  • Acute Kidney Injury: Elevated creatinine, decreased GFR (from glomerular inflammation)
  • Oliguria: Urine output <400 mL/day (indicates severe disease)

DISTINGUISH NEPHRITIC FROM NEPHROTIC SYNDROME:

Feature Nephritic Syndrome Nephrotic Syndrome
Hematuria +++ (prominent, RBC casts) + (mild or absent)
Proteinuria <3.5 g/day >3.5 g/day (heavy)
Hypertension +++ (prominent) +/- (mild or absent)
Edema ++ (moderate) +++ (severe, anasarca)
AKI +++ (common) + (less common)
Hypoalbuminemia Mild Severe (<2.5 g/dL)

COMMON CAUSES OF ACUTE GLOMERULONEPHRITIS:

  • Post-Infectious GN (Most Common in Children):
    • Post-Streptococcal GN: 1-3 weeks after pharyngitis or 3-6 weeks after impetigo
    • Other infections: Staph, pneumococcus, viral (Hep B/C, HIV, endocarditis)
  • IgA Nephropathy (Most Common Worldwide, Especially in Adults):
    • Episodic gross hematuria concurrent with URI/GI infection ("synpharyngitic")
    • Mesangial IgA deposition on biopsy
  • Rapidly Progressive GN (RPGN):
    • Anti-GBM disease (Goodpasture's): Pulmonary hemorrhage + GN
    • ANCA-associated vasculitis: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), microscopic polyangiitis (MPA)
    • Immune complex-mediated: Lupus nephritis, post-infectious, cryoglobulinemia
  • Lupus Nephritis: SLE with renal involvement (WHO Class III or IV)
  • Membranoproliferative GN (MPGN): Often with Hep C, cryoglobulinemia, or complement disorders
  • Alport Syndrome: Hereditary nephritis with deafness and ocular abnormalities
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Urinalysis (Critical First Step):

  • Hematuria: RBCs (>3/hpf microscopic, or grossly visible)
  • RBC Casts: Pathognomonic for glomerulonephritis (vs. non-glomerular hematuria)
  • Dysmorphic RBCs: >5% suggests glomerular source
  • Proteinuria: Usually 1-3+ on dipstick (sub-nephrotic range)
  • WBCs/WBC casts: May be present (inflammatory)

Quantify Proteinuria:

  • Urine Protein-to-Creatinine Ratio (UPCR): Spot urine; <3.5 g/g in nephritic, >3.5 g/g in nephrotic
  • 24-Hour Urine Collection: Gold standard but cumbersome

Laboratory Studies:

  • BMP: Elevated creatinine, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis (if AKI)
  • CBC: Anemia (from CKD or hemolysis if TMA), leukocytosis (if infection)
  • Albumin: Usually normal or mildly low in nephritic (vs. <2.5 g/dL in nephrotic)
  • Complement Levels (C3, C4):
    • **Low C3 and C4:** Lupus, cryoglobulinemia, endocarditis
    • **Low C3, Normal C4:** Post-streptococcal GN, MPGN, shunt nephritis
    • **Normal C3 and C4:** IgA nephropathy, ANCA vasculitis, anti-GBM disease

Serologic Testing (Based on Clinical Suspicion):

  • Post-Streptococcal:
    • ASO titer (anti-streptolysin O): Elevated if recent pharyngitis
    • Anti-DNase B: More sensitive if recent skin infection
    • Streptozyme: Composite of streptococcal antibodies
  • Rapidly Progressive GN:
    • **ANCA:** c-ANCA (GPA), p-ANCA (MPA, EGPA)
    • **Anti-GBM Antibodies:** Goodpasture's syndrome
  • Lupus Nephritis:
    • ANA, anti-dsDNA, complement (C3, C4)
  • Hepatitis Serologies: Hep B surface antigen, Hep C antibody (for MPGN, cryoglobulinemia)
  • Cryoglobulins: If suspect mixed cryoglobulinemia (Hep C, vasculitis)
  • HIV Testing: HIVAN (HIV-associated nephropathy) can present with nephritic features

Renal Ultrasound:

  • Assess kidney size (normal or enlarged in acute GN; small in chronic)
  • Rule out obstruction
  • Assess cortical echogenicity

Kidney Biopsy (DEFINITIVE DIAGNOSIS):

  • Indications:
    • Unclear diagnosis (not classic post-infectious)
    • RPGN (creatinine doubling over days-weeks, crescents on UA)
    • Nephrotic-range proteinuria
    • Persistent hematuria/proteinuria for >4 weeks
    • Systemic disease (lupus, vasculitis)
  • Provides:
    • Light microscopy: Pattern (proliferative, crescentic, membranous)
    • Immunofluorescence: IgA, IgG, IgM, C3 deposition patterns
    • Electron microscopy: Location of deposits (subepithelial, subendothelial, mesangial)
  • Contraindications: Uncontrolled HTN, bleeding disorder, solitary kidney (relative)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

GENERAL SUPPORTIVE MANAGEMENT:

  • Fluid and Sodium Restriction:
    • Fluid restrict to 1-1.5 L/day if oliguric or edematous
    • Sodium restrict to <2 g/day
  • Diuretics (for Volume Overload):
    • Furosemide: 20-80 mg IV/PO daily (titrate to urine output and volume status)
    • Goal: Negative 0.5-1 L/day until euvolemic
    • Monitor electrolytes (hypokalemia, hyponatremia)
  • Hypertension Control:
    • Goal BP: <130/80 mmHg (lower if significant proteinuria)
    • ACE Inhibitors or ARBs: First-line (reduce proteinuria, protect kidney)
      • Lisinopril 10-40 mg PO daily, or
      • Losartan 50-100 mg PO daily
      • **Caution:** Monitor creatinine (may rise initially) and potassium (risk of hyperkalemia)
    • Calcium Channel Blockers: Add if BP not controlled (amlodipine 5-10 mg daily)
    • Avoid NSAIDs: Worsen renal function and fluid retention
  • Treat Hyperkalemia:
    • If K+ >5.5 mEq/L: Calcium gluconate, insulin + dextrose, sodium polystyrene sulfonate
    • Consider dialysis if severe hyperkalemia refractory to medical management

SPECIFIC THERAPIES (Based on Etiology):

1. Post-Streptococcal GN:

  • Antibiotics: Penicillin or amoxicillin (to eradicate strep, not to treat GN itself)
  • Supportive Care: Fluid/sodium restriction, diuretics, BP control (as above)
  • Prognosis: Excellent in children (>95% full recovery); adults may develop CKD (10-20%)
  • Duration: Complement normalizes in 6-8 weeks; hematuria/proteinuria resolves in 3-6 months

2. IgA Nephropathy:

  • ACE Inhibitor or ARB: First-line (reduce proteinuria)
    • Goal: UPCR <1 g/g
  • Corticosteroids: Consider if proteinuria >1 g/day despite ACEi/ARB for 3-6 months
    • Prednisone 0.5-1 mg/kg/day (max 60-80 mg) Ã— 2-3 months, then taper
    • **Evidence:** TESTING trial showed benefit in reducing kidney failure risk
  • Fish Oil (Omega-3): 4 g/day (modest benefit, anti-inflammatory)
  • Prognosis: Variable; 20-40% progress to ESRD over 20 years

3. Rapidly Progressive GN (RPGN):

  • URGENT NEPHROLOGY CONSULTATION - this is a renal emergency
  • High-Dose Corticosteroids:
    • Methylprednisolone 500-1000 mg IV daily Ã— 3 days (pulse therapy), then prednisone 1 mg/kg/day PO Ã— 4-6 weeks, taper
  • Immunosuppression (ANCA Vasculitis or Lupus):
    • Cyclophosphamide: 500-1000 mg/mÂ² IV monthly Ã— 6 months, or 2 mg/kg/day PO Ã— 3-6 months
    • Rituximab: 375 mg/mÂ² weekly Ã— 4 doses (alternative to cyclophosphamide, especially in ANCA vasculitis)
    • Mycophenolate Mofetil: 2-3 g/day PO (for lupus nephritis, after induction)
  • Plasmapheresis:
    • Indicated for: Anti-GBM disease (remove circulating antibodies), severe ANCA vasculitis with pulmonary hemorrhage or dialysis-dependent AKI
    • Protocol: Daily or every-other-day sessions Ã— 7-14 treatments
  • Prognosis: Without treatment, RPGN progresses to ESRD in weeks-months. Early aggressive treatment can preserve renal function.

4. Lupus Nephritis:

  • Class III/IV (Proliferative):
    • Induction: High-dose corticosteroids + cyclophosphamide (6 months) or mycophenolate (6-12 months)
    • Maintenance: Mycophenolate or azathioprine + low-dose prednisone
  • Hydroxychloroquine: All lupus patients (reduces flares)

RENAL REPLACEMENT THERAPY (Dialysis):

  • Indications:
    • Volume overload refractory to diuretics (pulmonary edema)
    • Severe hyperkalemia refractory to medical therapy
    • Severe metabolic acidosis (pH <7.1)
    • Uremic symptoms (pericarditis, encephalopathy, bleeding)
  • Modality: Hemodialysis (intermittent or CRRT if unstable)

NEPHROLOGY REFERRAL:

  • ALL patients with acute GN should be referred to nephrology
  • Urgent/Emergent: RPGN (creatinine doubling), oliguria, pulmonary hemorrhage, uncertain diagnosis requiring biopsy
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • RBC Casts = Glomerulonephritis: Finding RBC casts on urinalysis is pathognomonic for glomerular disease. No other condition causes RBC casts. If you see them, think GN, not kidney stones, UTI, or other non-glomerular causes of hematuria.
  • Nephritic vs. Nephrotic - Remember the "itic" vs. "otic": Nephritic = inflammatory (hematuria, HTN, RBC casts, sub-nephrotic proteinuria). Nephrotic = leaky (massive proteinuria >3.5 g/day, hypoalbuminemia, edema, hyperlipidemia). Both can coexist, but one usually predominates.
  • Complement Levels Point to Diagnosis: Low C3 + Low C4 = lupus or cryoglobulinemia. Low C3 + Normal C4 = post-strep GN or MPGN. Normal complements = IgA nephropathy or ANCA vasculitis. Complement patterns narrow your differential significantly.
  • Post-Strep GN Has a Latent Period: Symptoms appear 1-3 weeks after pharyngitis or 3-6 weeks after impetigo. The classic presentation is a child with tea-colored urine 2 weeks after a sore throat. ASO titers confirm recent strep infection.
  • RPGN is a Renal Emergency: Rapidly progressive GN (creatinine doubling over days-weeks, crescents on biopsy) requires URGENT diagnosis and treatment. Without aggressive immunosuppression Â± plasmapheresis, it progresses to ESRD within weeks-months. Call nephrology immediately.
  • IgA Nephropathy = Synpharyngitic Hematuria: Unlike post-strep GN (2-week delay), IgA nephropathy causes gross hematuria concurrent with or within 1-2 days of URI. "I get a cold, my urine turns red" is the classic history. It's the most common primary GN worldwide.
  • Goodpasture's = Pulmonary-Renal Syndrome: Anti-GBM disease causes both pulmonary hemorrhage (hemoptysis, dyspnea, alveolar infiltrates) and glomerulonephritis. Young male smokers are classic. Urgent plasmapheresis + immunosuppression can be life-saving. Test for anti-GBM antibodies immediately.
  • Kidney Biopsy is Definitive but Not Always Needed: Classic post-strep GN in a child (recent strep, low C3, hematuria, spontaneous improvement) doesn't need biopsy - manage supportively. But RPGN, unclear diagnosis, systemic disease, or lack of improvement ALWAYS warrants biopsy. When in doubt, consult nephrology.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Severe acute kidney injury requiring dialysis emergently
  • Pulmonary hemorrhage (diffuse alveolar hemorrhage)
  • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
  • Hypertensive emergency with end-organ damage
  • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis with concern for dialysis-dependence
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable, blood pressure controlled (<140/90)
  • Renal function stable or improving (Cr stable or downtrending)
  • No dialysis requirement (or stable on outpatient dialysis)
  • Fluid status euvolemic (no significant edema or volume overload)
  • Urine output adequate
  • On appropriate immunosuppression if indicated (steroids, cyclophosphamide)
  • Outpatient nephrology follow-up arranged (within 1-2 weeks)
  • Kidney biopsy completed or arranged
  • Patient educated on low-sodium diet, fluid restriction if needed
  • Recheck labs arranged within 3-7 days
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

92. PSYCHOGENIC POLYDIPSIA (PRIMARY POLYDIPSIA)

Compulsive Water Drinking â€¢ Hyponatremia â€¢ Psychiatric Illness â€¢ Low Urine Osmolality
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Excessive water intake (>3 L/day, often 10-20 L/day) from compulsive drinking behavior, leading to hyponatremia and dilute urine. Also called "primary polydipsia" or "dipsogenic diabetes insipidus."

Clinical Features:

  • Polydipsia:
    • Excessive water drinking (often >10 L/day in severe cases)
    • Compulsive, non-physiologic (not driven by true thirst)
    • Patients may carry water bottles constantly, drink from taps/fountains excessively
  • Polyuria:
    • High urine output (often 5-15 L/day) - dilute urine from excessive intake
    • Nocturia (frequent nighttime urination)
  • Hyponatremia (If Intake Exceeds Renal Capacity to Excrete Free Water):
    • Mild: 130-135 mEq/L (often asymptomatic)
    • Moderate: 125-130 mEq/L (nausea, confusion, headache)
    • Severe: <125 mEq/L (seizures, coma, cerebral edema)
  • Other Symptoms:
    • Dizziness, lightheadedness
    • Weakness, fatigue
    • Weight fluctuations (water weight)

Typical Patient Profile:

  • Psychiatric Illness (Most Common):
    • Schizophrenia (most common, 10-20% of patients)
    • Bipolar disorder, schizoaffective disorder
    • Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)
    • Anxiety disorders
  • Developmental Disorders: Autism spectrum, intellectual disability
  • Medications:
    • Antipsychotics (especially clozapine, olanzapine) - can worsen polydipsia
    • Anticholinergics (dry mouth â†’ â†‘ drinking)
  • Less Common: "Health fad" excessive water intake (fitness/wellness culture), factitious disorder

Pathophysiology:

  • Normal kidneys can excrete up to ~15-20 L/day of free water (maximal dilution = urine osmolality ~50 mOsm/kg)
  • If intake exceeds renal capacity â†’ positive free water balance â†’ hyponatremia
  • Chronic polydipsia can cause "wash out" of medullary concentration gradient â†’ partial nephrogenic DI (impaired concentrating ability)

DISTINGUISH FROM DIABETES INSIPIDUS:

Feature Psychogenic Polydipsia Central DI Nephrogenic DI
Mechanism Excessive water intake â†“ ADH secretion Renal resistance to ADH
Serum Na+ Low or low-normal High or high-normal High or high-normal
Serum Osm Low (<280) High (>295) High (>295)
Urine Osm Very low (<100) Low (<300) Low (<300)
Water Deprivation Test Urine concentrates normally Urine stays dilute â†’ concentrates with desmopressin Urine stays dilute, no response to desmopressin
Psychiatric History Often present Absent Absent (unless drug-induced)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Initial Laboratory Assessment:

  • Serum Sodium: Low (125-135 mEq/L typical) or low-normal
  • Serum Osmolality: Low (<280 mOsm/kg)
  • Urine Osmolality:
    • Very dilute (<100 mOsm/kg) during active water drinking
    • Key diagnostic clue: Urine osm is LOWER than serum osm (inappropriate dilution)
  • Urine Sodium: Variable (often low due to volume expansion suppressing ADH/aldosterone)
  • BMP: Check for other electrolyte abnormalities, assess renal function

Assess Volume Status:

  • Patients are typically euvolemic or mildly hypervolemic (from water overload)
  • No signs of hypovolemia (no orthostasis, tachycardia)
  • No signs of severe hypervolemia (no edema, ascites)

Water Deprivation Test (Definitive Test to Distinguish from DI):

  • Protocol:
    • Patient stops all fluid intake
    • Measure serum and urine osmolality hourly
    • Weigh patient hourly (stop if >3-5% body weight loss)
    • Monitor vital signs
    • Stop test when: Urine osm plateaus (2 consecutive values within 30 mOsm), serum osm >295-300 mOsm/kg, or clinical instability
  • Results:
    • Psychogenic Polydipsia: Urine concentrates appropriately (urine osm >600-800 mOsm/kg)
    • Central DI: Urine stays dilute (<300 mOsm/kg), then concentrates after desmopressin (DDAVP) given
    • Nephrogenic DI: Urine stays dilute even after desmopressin
  • CAUTION:
    • Chronic polydipsia can cause partial nephrogenic DI ("medullary washout") â†’ blunted response on water deprivation test
    • May need prolonged abstinence from excess water intake (days-weeks) before testing to restore medullary gradient

Serum ADH (Copeptin) - Not Routinely Done:

  • Copeptin (stable ADH surrogate) can help distinguish: Low in central DI, normal/high in nephrogenic DI and psychogenic polydipsia
  • Rarely needed in clinical practice

Exclude Other Causes of Hyponatremia:

  • Assess Volume Status: Hypovolemic, euvolemic, or hypervolemic?
  • Rule Out SIADH: Check urine osm (should be inappropriately HIGH in SIADH, LOW in psychogenic polydipsia)
  • TSH, Cortisol: Rule out hypothyroidism, adrenal insufficiency (causes of hyponatremia)
  • Medications: Review for diuretics, SSRIs, carbamazepine (cause SIADH or hyponatremia)

Psychiatric Evaluation:

  • Assess for underlying psychiatric disorders (schizophrenia, bipolar, OCD)
  • Review medications (antipsychotics, anticholinergics)
  • Assess insight into drinking behavior (many patients lack awareness of problem)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

ACUTE MANAGEMENT (If Symptomatic Hyponatremia):

  • Stop Water Intake: Immediate cessation of oral intake (NPO or restrict to <1 L/day)
  • Treat Severe Symptomatic Hyponatremia (Na+ <120 mEq/L with seizures, coma):
    • 3% Hypertonic Saline: 100 mL IV bolus over 10 minutes, may repeat Ã— 2-3 if seizures persist
    • Goal: Increase Na+ by 4-6 mEq/L acutely (enough to stop seizures)
    • **CAUTION:** Do NOT correct too rapidly - risk of osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS)
      • Limit correction to 6-8 mEq/L in 24 hours, 12-14 mEq/L in 48 hours
  • Monitor Sodium Closely: Check Na+ every 2-4 hours during acute correction

CHRONIC MANAGEMENT (Behavioral and Pharmacologic):

1. Fluid Restriction (Primary Treatment):

  • Goal: Limit fluid intake to 1-1.5 L/day (less than renal free water clearance)
  • Implementation:
    • Supervised fluid intake in inpatient or residential settings
    • Remove access to excessive water (lock bathrooms, limit fountain access)
    • Behavioral modification, habit reversal training
  • Challenge: Compliance is poor, especially in unmonitored settings. Many patients compulsively seek water.

2. Treat Underlying Psychiatric Disorder:

  • Optimize Antipsychotic Therapy:
    • Consider switching from high-risk antipsychotics (clozapine, olanzapine) to lower-risk agents
    • Ensure psychiatric symptoms are well-controlled (psychosis can worsen polydipsia)
  • Behavioral Therapy: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), habit reversal techniques
  • Address Anticholinergic Side Effects: If dry mouth contributing â†’ artificial saliva, sugar-free gum (avoid drinking)

3. Pharmacologic Interventions (Limited Evidence):

  • Demeclocycline: 600-1200 mg/day PO (induces nephrogenic DI â†’ prevents hyponatremia)
    • Mechanism: Blocks ADH action in kidney â†’ impairs water reabsorption
    • Side effects: Photosensitivity, nephrotoxicity, esophagitis
    • **Caution:** Can cause hypernatremia if patient reduces intake; monitor Na+ closely
  • Urea: 15-60 g/day PO (osmotic diuresis)
    • Increases free water excretion
    • Unpalatable, poor compliance
  • Clozapine Dose Reduction: If on clozapine and polydipsia severe, consider reducing dose (but weigh risk of worsening psychosis)

MONITORING AND FOLLOW-UP:

  • Frequent Sodium Monitoring:
    • Inpatient: Daily serum sodium
    • Outpatient: Weekly initially, then monthly once stable
  • Weight Monitoring: Daily weights (rapid fluctuations suggest excess water intake)
  • Urine Specific Gravity: Can monitor daily (specific gravity <1.005 indicates dilute urine from excess intake)
  • Close Coordination with Psychiatry: Ensure psychiatric stability, optimize medications

EDUCATION:

  • Educate patient (and caregivers) about risks of excessive water intake (hyponatremia, seizures, death)
  • Explain that "more water is not always healthier" - dispel wellness myths
  • Provide behavioral strategies to reduce drinking urges

PROGNOSIS:

  • Chronic, relapsing condition - very difficult to manage long-term
  • Compliance with fluid restriction is poor, especially in outpatient settings
  • Risk of recurrent severe hyponatremia and complications (seizures, falls, ODS from overly rapid correction)
  • Best outcomes in supervised/residential psychiatric settings with strict fluid control
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Serum Osm < Urine Osm = Not Psychogenic Polydipsia: The hallmark of psychogenic polydipsia is very dilute urine (urine osm <100 mOsm/kg) with low serum osmolality (<280). If urine is concentrated (>300 mOsm/kg), think SIADH or other causes of hyponatremia, NOT psychogenic polydipsia.
  • Psychiatric Illness is the Key Clue: The vast majority of patients with psychogenic polydipsia have schizophrenia (10-20% of patients with schizophrenia), bipolar disorder, or other serious psychiatric illness. If you see polyuria + polydipsia + hyponatremia in a psychiatric patient, psychogenic polydipsia is top of the differential.
  • Water Deprivation Test Distinguishes from DI: Psychogenic polydipsia: urine concentrates normally (>600 mOsm/kg). Central DI: urine stays dilute, then concentrates with DDAVP. Nephrogenic DI: urine stays dilute despite DDAVP. BUT chronic polydipsia can cause "medullary washout" â†’ blunted response mimicking partial nephrogenic DI.
  • Don't Correct Sodium Too Fast: Even though psychogenic polydipsia causes hyponatremia from excess water intake, the same rules for correction apply: limit to 6-8 mEq/L in 24 hours to avoid osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS). Overzealous correction can cause locked-in syndrome, quadriplegia, death.
  • Fluid Restriction is Primary Treatment: The key is limiting intake to <1.5 L/day. This is extremely difficult in unmonitored settings - patients compulsively seek water. Best managed in supervised psychiatric facilities with locked bathrooms and controlled water access. Outpatient compliance is abysmal.
  • Clozapine is a Common Culprit: Clozapine and olanzapine are strongly associated with polydipsia (mechanism unclear - may involve dry mouth, altered thirst regulation, or SIADH). Consider switching antipsychotics if polydipsia is severe and refractory.
  • Demeclocycline Induces Nephrogenic DI: Demeclocycline blocks ADH action in the kidneys â†’ prevents water reabsorption â†’ protects against hyponatremia. It's used off-label for psychogenic polydipsia and SIADH. But it can cause hypernatremia if intake decreases, and it's nephrotoxic - monitor closely.
  • This is a Chronic, Relapsing Condition: Unlike DI (which can be well-controlled with DDAVP or addressing the cause), psychogenic polydipsia is very difficult to manage long-term. Patients lack insight, compulsively drink despite education, and have frequent ER visits for symptomatic hyponatremia. It's frustrating for everyone involved.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Severe hyponatremia (Na <120 mEq/L) with seizures or coma
  • Acute water intoxication requiring close monitoring
  • Altered mental status requiring frequent neuro checks
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Sodium corrected to safe level (typically >130 mEq/L)
  • Mental status at baseline
  • No seizures during hospitalization
  • Underlying psychiatric condition addressed
  • Close monitoring of fluid intake established (behavioral plan, restricted access)
  • Psychiatry follow-up arranged (within days to week)
  • Outpatient psychiatry or case management to monitor fluid restriction
  • Patient/caregivers educated on risks of excessive water intake
  • Recheck sodium within 2-3 days of discharge
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

93. RENAL TUBULAR ACIDOSIS (RTA)

Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis â€¢ Normal GFR â€¢ Impaired Renal Acid Handling
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Overview: Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) = group of disorders characterized by impaired renal acid excretion or bicarbonate reabsorption â†’ hyperchloremic (non-anion gap) metabolic acidosis with normal or near-normal GFR.

THREE MAIN TYPES:

TYPE 1 RTA (DISTAL RTA):

  • Mechanism: Impaired H+ secretion in distal tubule â†’ inability to acidify urine
  • Key Features:
    • Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis (non-anion gap)
    • **Hypokalemia** (most common electrolyte abnormality)
    • **Urine pH >5.5** despite acidemia (pathognomonic - cannot acidify urine)
    • Nephrocalcinosis, kidney stones (calcium phosphate) - chronic complications
    • Bone disease (rickets in children, osteomalacia in adults) from chronic acidosis
  • Common Causes:
    • Autoimmune diseases: SjÃ¶gren's syndrome (most common), lupus, rheumatoid arthritis
    • Medications: Amphotericin B, lithium, ifosfamide
    • Genetic: Hereditary forms (mutations in H+-ATPase)
    • Obstructive uropathy, sickle cell disease

TYPE 2 RTA (PROXIMAL RTA):

  • Mechanism: Impaired proximal tubule HCO3- reabsorption â†’ bicarbonate wasting
  • Key Features:
    • Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
    • **Hypokalemia** (from bicarbonaturia)
    • **Urine pH <5.5** once HCO3- is below reabsorptive threshold (can acidify urine, unlike Type 1)
    • Fractional excretion of HCO3- >15% (when HCO3- repleted to normal)
    • Often part of Fanconi syndrome (global proximal tubule dysfunction: also phosphaturia, glucosuria, aminoaciduria, uricosuria)
  • Common Causes:
    • Fanconi syndrome: Multiple myeloma, light chain deposition, cystinosis, Wilson's disease
    • Medications: Tenofovir, ifosfamide, aminoglycosides, cisplatin, valproic acid, topiramate
    • Genetic: Hereditary forms (rare)
    • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: Acetazolamide (iatrogenic Type 2 RTA)

TYPE 4 RTA (HYPERKALEMIC RTA):

  • Mechanism: Aldosterone deficiency or resistance â†’ impaired K+ and H+ secretion in distal tubule
  • Key Features:
    • Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis (mild, usually HCO3- 18-22 mEq/L)
    • **HYPERKALEMIA** (distinguishes from Types 1 and 2)
    • Urine pH <5.5 (can acidify urine somewhat)
    • Often mild acidosis (vs. severe in Types 1 and 2)
  • Common Causes:
    • Hypoaldosteronism:
      • Diabetes (hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism, most common cause of Type 4 RTA)
      • CKD, NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors, ARBs, heparin
      • Adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease)
    • Aldosterone Resistance:
      • Medications: K+-sparing diuretics (spironolactone, amiloride), trimethoprim, pentamidine
      • Urinary tract obstruction, sickle cell disease

COMPARISON OF RTA TYPES:

Feature Type 1 (Distal) Type 2 (Proximal) Type 4
Urine pH >5.5 (cannot acidify) <5.5 (can acidify) <5.5
Serum K+ Low (hypokalemia) Low (hypokalemia) High (hyperkalemia)
Severity of Acidosis Severe (HCO3- <15) Moderate (HCO3- 12-18) Mild (HCO3- 18-22)
