Stones/Nephrocalcinosis Yes (common) No No
Fanconi Syndrome No Often present No
Most Common Cause SjÃ¶gren's syndrome Medications (tenofovir) Diabetic hypoaldosteronism
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Initial Laboratory Assessment:

  • ABG or VBG:
    • Metabolic acidosis (pH <7.35, HCO3- <22 mEq/L)
    • Respiratory compensation (low pCO2)
  • Anion Gap:
    • Normal anion gap (8-12 mEq/L) - hyperchloremic acidosis
    • Formula: AG = Na+ - (Cl- + HCO3-)
    • **Key:** RTA is a non-anion gap acidosis (vs. anion gap acidosis from lactic acidosis, ketoacidosis, renal failure)
  • BMP:
    • Na+: Usually normal
    • K+: Low (Types 1 and 2) or HIGH (Type 4) - critical distinguishing feature
    • Cl-: Elevated (to maintain electroneutrality as HCO3- falls)
    • Creatinine: Normal or near-normal (RTA occurs with normal GFR; if GFR <20-30, acidosis is from renal failure, not RTA)

Urine Studies (Critical for Diagnosis):

  • Urine pH:
    • **Type 1:** >5.5 despite acidemia (pathognomonic - cannot acidify urine)
    • **Type 2 and 4:** <5.5 (can acidify urine)
  • Urine Anion Gap (UAG):
    • Formula: UAG = (Urine Na+ + Urine K+) - Urine Cl-
    • **Positive UAG:** Suggests RTA (impaired NH4+ excretion)
    • **Negative UAG:** Suggests GI HCO3- loss (e.g., diarrhea) - normal renal response
  • Urine Osmolar Gap (Alternative to UAG):
    • Formula: Urine OG = Measured Osm - [2(Na+ + K+) + Urea/2.8 + Glucose/18]
    • Estimates NH4+ excretion: Low OG â†’ RTA; High OG â†’ normal renal acidification (GI losses)
  • Fractional Excretion of HCO3- (FE-HCO3-, for Type 2 Diagnosis):
    • Measure after HCO3- loading (give IV bicarbonate to raise serum HCO3- to ~24 mEq/L)
    • FE-HCO3- = (Urine HCO3- Ã— Serum Cr) / (Serum HCO3- Ã— Urine Cr) Ã— 100
    • **Type 2 RTA:** FE-HCO3- >15% (massive bicarbonaturia)
    • **Type 1 RTA:** FE-HCO3- <3% (minimal bicarbonaturia)

Additional Testing (Based on RTA Type):

  • Type 1 RTA:
    • **Renal ultrasound:** Look for nephrocalcinosis, kidney stones
    • **Autoimmune workup:** ANA, anti-SSA (SjÃ¶gren's), anti-SSB, rheumatoid factor
    • **Genetic testing:** If family history or young age
  • Type 2 RTA:
    • **Urine studies:** Glucosuria, phosphaturia, aminoaciduria, uricosuria (Fanconi syndrome)
    • **Serum/urine protein electrophoresis (SPEP/UPEP):** Rule out multiple myeloma
    • **Ceruloplasmin:** If suspect Wilson's disease
  • Type 4 RTA:
    • **Renin and Aldosterone Levels:
      • Low renin + Low aldosterone = Hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism (diabetic nephropathy, NSAIDs)
      • High renin + Low aldosterone = Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's)
      • High renin + High aldosterone with hyperkalemia = Aldosterone resistance (K+-sparing diuretics)
    • **Cosyntropin stimulation test:** If suspect adrenal insufficiency
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

TYPE 1 RTA (DISTAL) TREATMENT:

  • Alkali Therapy (Primary Treatment):
    • Sodium Bicarbonate: 1-3 mEq/kg/day PO in divided doses (typically 650-1300 mg [7.8-15.5 mEq] PO TID-QID)
      • Goal: Maintain serum HCO3- >22 mEq/L
    • Alternative: Sodium Citrate/Citric Acid (Shohl's Solution): 1-3 mEq/kg/day
      • Better tolerated than bicarbonate (less GI upset)
      • Citrate is metabolized to bicarbonate
    • Alternative: Potassium Citrate: 30-100 mEq/day (if hypokalemic)
      • Dual benefit: Repletes K+ and provides alkali
  • Potassium Supplementation:
    • Often needed (hypokalemia is common)
    • KCl 20-40 mEq PO daily-BID, or potassium citrate (as above)
  • Treat Underlying Cause:
    • Discontinue nephrotoxic medications (amphotericin B, lithium)
    • Treat autoimmune disease (SjÃ¶gren's, lupus)
  • Monitor:
    • Serum HCO3-, K+, Cl- every 1-3 months initially, then every 6-12 months
    • Renal ultrasound annually (monitor for nephrocalcinosis progression)

TYPE 2 RTA (PROXIMAL) TREATMENT:

  • Alkali Therapy (Higher Doses Needed Than Type 1):
    • Sodium Bicarbonate: 5-15 mEq/kg/day PO in divided doses
      • Much higher doses needed because HCO3- is wasted in urine (poor efficacy)
      • Goal: Maintain HCO3- >18-20 mEq/L (complete correction often not achievable)
    • Potassium Citrate: Preferred if hypokalemic (provides both K+ and alkali)
  • Thiazide Diuretics (Paradoxically Helpful):
    • Hydrochlorothiazide: 25-50 mg PO daily
      • Mechanism: Induces volume depletion â†’ â†‘ proximal HCO3- reabsorption â†’ less bicarbonaturia
      • **Caution:** Worsens hypokalemia - must supplement K+
  • Potassium Supplementation:
    • Essential (bicarbonaturia causes K+ wasting)
    • KCl or potassium citrate 40-100 mEq/day
  • Treat Underlying Cause:
    • Discontinue causative medications (tenofovir, ifosfamide, topiramate)
    • Treat Fanconi syndrome causes (myeloma, Wilson's disease)

TYPE 4 RTA TREATMENT:

  • Treat Hyperkalemia (Primary Goal):
    • Dietary K+ Restriction: <2-3 g (50-75 mEq)/day
    • Loop Diuretics: Furosemide 20-80 mg PO daily (promotes K+ excretion)
    • Potassium Binders:
      • **Patiromer (Veltassa):** 8.4-25.2 g PO daily (binds K+ in GI tract)
      • **Sodium Zirconium Cyclosilicate (Lokelma):** 10 g PO TID Ã— 48 hours, then 10 g daily
      • **Sodium Polystyrene Sulfonate (Kayexalate):** 15-60 g PO daily (less preferred - risk of colonic necrosis)
  • Fludrocortisone (If Aldosterone Deficiency):
    • Dose: 0.1-0.2 mg PO daily
    • Indication: Hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism, Addison's disease
    • **Caution:** Can worsen hypertension, heart failure, edema (monitor BP, volume status)
  • Sodium Bicarbonate (If Significant Acidosis):
    • Usually mild acidosis (HCO3- 18-22) - may not need treatment
    • If HCO3- <18 mEq/L: Give sodium bicarbonate 650-1300 mg PO TID
  • Discontinue Causative Medications:
    • K+-sparing diuretics (spironolactone, amiloride, triamterene)
    • NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors/ARBs (if safe to stop)
    • Trimethoprim, pentamidine, heparin
  • Tight Glycemic Control (If Diabetic):
    • Improves hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism over time

GENERAL MONITORING:

  • Serum electrolytes (Na+, K+, Cl-, HCO3-) every 1-3 months initially, then every 6-12 months
  • ABG/VBG if acidosis not improving
  • Bone density (DEXA) if Type 1 RTA (risk of osteomalacia)
  • Renal function (creatinine, GFR) - ensure RTA not progressing to CKD
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Hyperkalemia = Type 4, Hypokalemia = Types 1 and 2: The serum potassium immediately tells you which type of RTA. Type 4 causes hyperkalemia (aldosterone deficiency/resistance). Types 1 and 2 cause hypokalemia (renal K+ wasting). Check K+ first.
  • Urine pH >5.5 = Type 1 RTA: The pathognomonic finding of Type 1 RTA is inability to acidify urine despite systemic acidemia. If urine pH >5.5 with metabolic acidosis, it's Type 1 (distal RTA). Types 2 and 4 can acidify urine (pH <5.5).
  • Positive Urine Anion Gap = RTA, Negative = GI Loss: Hyperchloremic acidosis can be from RTA or GI HCO3- loss (diarrhea). Urine anion gap (UAG = [U-Na + U-K] - U-Cl) distinguishes: Positive UAG = RTA (impaired NH4+ excretion). Negative UAG = normal renal response to GI loss.
  • Type 1 RTA â†’ Kidney Stones: Type 1 RTA causes nephrocalcinosis and recurrent calcium phosphate kidney stones from chronic alkaline urine (pH >6), hypercalciuria, and low urinary citrate. If a patient has recurrent kidney stones + non-anion gap acidosis, check urine pH - it's probably Type 1 RTA.
  • Diabetics Get Type 4 RTA: The most common cause of Type 4 RTA is hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism in diabetic nephropathy. If a diabetic has hyperkalemia + non-anion gap acidosis (HCO3- 18-22) with normal-ish GFR, think Type 4 RTA before blaming the kidney failure.
  • SjÃ¶gren's Causes Type 1, Tenofovir Causes Type 2: SjÃ¶gren's syndrome is the most common cause of Type 1 RTA (distal tubule dysfunction from autoimmune inflammation). Tenofovir is a classic cause of Type 2 RTA (proximal tubule toxicity causing Fanconi syndrome). Know the classic associations.
  • Type 2 RTA Needs HUGE Doses of Bicarbonate: Type 2 RTA wastes bicarbonate in the urine, so you need 5-15 mEq/kg/day (vs. 1-3 mEq/kg/day for Type 1). Despite high doses, you often can't fully correct HCO3- to normal. Adding a thiazide diuretic (induces volume depletion â†’ â†‘ proximal reabsorption) helps.
  • RTA Requires Normal GFR: By definition, RTA occurs with normal or near-normal GFR. If GFR <20-30 mL/min, the non-anion gap acidosis is from renal failure (uremic acidosis), not RTA. RTA = tubular dysfunction without glomerular failure.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Severe metabolic acidosis (pH <7.1, HCO3 <10) with hemodynamic compromise
  • Severe hyperkalemia (K >6.5 mEq/L) with ECG changes or dysrhythmias
  • Respiratory distress from metabolic acidosis
  • Need for dialysis for refractory acidosis or hyperkalemia
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Acid-base status corrected or stable (pH >7.30, HCO3 >18 mEq/L)
  • Electrolytes normalized (K normal if Type 4 RTA, K corrected if hypokalemic RTA)
  • Underlying cause identified (renal biopsy if needed, medication review)
  • On appropriate treatment (bicarbonate supplementation, potassium management)
  • Outpatient nephrology follow-up arranged
  • Patient educated on medication compliance (bicarbonate, potassium as indicated)
  • Recheck labs within 1 week
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

94. BURNS / THIRD-SPACING

Capillary Leak â€¢ Hypovolemia â€¢ Fluid Resuscitation
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Patient with thermal, chemical, or electrical burn injury presenting with signs of intravascular volume depletion despite normal or increased total body water due to capillary leak and fluid sequestration into injured tissues.

  • Burn Classification by Depth:
    • Superficial (1st degree): Erythema, painful, no blisters (sunburn)
    • Superficial partial-thickness (2nd degree): Blisters, painful, blanches
    • Deep partial-thickness: White/yellow, decreased sensation
    • Full-thickness (3rd degree): Leathery, painless, does not blanch
    • Fourth degree: Extends to muscle, tendon, bone
  • Total Body Surface Area (TBSA): Calculated using Rule of Nines:
    • Head/neck: 9%
    • Each arm: 9%
    • Anterior trunk: 18%
    • Posterior trunk: 18%
    • Each leg: 18%
    • Perineum: 1%
    • Alternative: Patient's palm (including fingers) = 1% TBSA
  • Signs of Third-Spacing/Hypovolemia: Tachycardia, hypotension, decreased urine output (<0.5 mL/kg/hr), altered mental status, lactic acidosis, elevated hematocrit (hemoconcentration)
  • Inhalation Injury Red Flags: Facial burns, singed nasal hairs, carbonaceous sputum, hoarseness, stridor, enclosed space exposure, carboxyhemoglobin >10%
  • Electrical Injury Complications: Cardiac dysrhythmias, rhabdomyolysis, compartment syndrome, deeper tissue injury than apparent on surface
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Initial Assessment:

  • TBSA Calculation: Use Rule of Nines or Lund-Browder chart for accurate assessment
  • Burn Center Transfer Criteria:
    • Partial-thickness burns >10% TBSA
    • Full-thickness burns any size
    • Burns involving face, hands, feet, genitalia, perineum, major joints
    • Electrical or chemical burns
    • Inhalation injury
    • Circumferential burns
    • Burns with trauma or medical comorbidities
    • Pediatric burns (consider >5% TBSA)

Laboratory Studies:

  • CBC: Elevated hematocrit from hemoconcentration (fluid loss), leukocytosis
  • BMP: Hyperkalemia (cell lysis), hyponatremia (third-spacing), elevated BUN/Cr (prerenal from hypovolemia)
  • Arterial Blood Gas: Metabolic acidosis from hypoperfusion, carboxyhemoglobin level
  • CPK/Myoglobin: Rhabdomyolysis (especially electrical burns)
  • Lactate: Elevated in shock state
  • Coagulation Studies: May develop DIC in severe burns
  • Carboxyhemoglobin: >10% suggests inhalation injury (>25% serious toxicity)

Imaging/Additional Studies:

  • Chest X-ray: Baseline for suspected inhalation injury (initially often normal)
  • ECG: Essential for electrical burns (dysrhythmias), continuous telemetry monitoring
  • Bronchoscopy: Gold standard for diagnosing inhalation injury if suspected
  • Compartment Pressure Measurement: If concern for compartment syndrome (circumferential burns, electrical injury)

Urine Output Monitoring:

  • Goal: 0.5-1 mL/kg/hr adults, 1 mL/kg/hr children
  • Myoglobinuria: Tea-colored urine suggests rhabdomyolysis (electrical burns, extensive muscle injury)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Management (First Hour):

  • Airway Assessment:
    • Early intubation if signs of inhalation injury (edema progresses rapidly)
    • Lower threshold for intubation with facial burns, stridor, hoarseness
    • Use large ETT (7.5-8.0) due to anticipated secretions
  • Stop the Burning Process: Remove clothing, irrigate chemical burns for 20+ minutes, cool thermal burns with room temperature water (avoid hypothermia)
  • Large-Bore IV Access: Two large-bore peripheral IVs (through burned skin if necessary), central line if needed
  • Foley Catheter: Essential for monitoring urine output during resuscitation

Fluid Resuscitation (Parkland Formula):

  • Parkland Formula: 4 mL Ã— kg Ã— %TBSA (only count partial and full-thickness burns)
  • First 24 Hours Fluid Distribution:
    • Give 50% of calculated volume in first 8 hours from time of burn
    • Give remaining 50% over next 16 hours
    • Use Lactated Ringer's solution (isotonic crystalloid)
  • Example: 80 kg patient with 40% TBSA burn:
    • Total 24h fluid = 4 Ã— 80 Ã— 40 = 12,800 mL
    • First 8 hours: 6,400 mL (800 mL/hr)
    • Next 16 hours: 6,400 mL (400 mL/hr)
  • Titrate to Urine Output: Goal 0.5-1 mL/kg/hr (30-50 mL/hr for 70 kg adult)
  • If Myoglobinuria Present:
    • Increase fluids to achieve urine output 1-2 mL/kg/hr
    • Consider sodium bicarbonate to alkalinize urine (goal pH >6.5)
    • Mannitol 12.5-25g IV if urine output inadequate despite fluids

Pain Management:

  • IV Opioids: Morphine 0.1-0.2 mg/kg IV or fentanyl 1-2 mcg/kg IV (avoid IM/SC due to poor absorption in third-spacing)
  • Anxiolytics: Lorazepam 0.5-2 mg IV for severe anxiety/agitation
  • Consider Ketamine: 0.1-0.3 mg/kg IV for dressing changes/procedures (preserves airway reflexes)

Wound Management:

  • Sterile Technique: Cover burns with clean, dry dressings initially
  • Avoid Ice: Can worsen tissue injury and cause hypothermia
  • Tetanus Prophylaxis: Update if >5 years since last booster
  • Topical Antimicrobials: Silver sulfadiazine (avoid on face, pregnancy, sulfa allergy) or Silvadene alternatives
  • Escharotomy: Immediate if circumferential burns causing compartment syndrome or respiratory compromise

Specific Situations:

  • Inhalation Injury:
    • 100% oxygen (half-life of COHb: 90 min on 100% O2 vs 4 hours on room air)
    • Consider hyperbaric oxygen if COHb >25% or severe symptoms
    • Bronchodilators for bronchospasm
    • NO role for prophylactic antibiotics or steroids
  • Electrical Burns:
    • Cardiac monitoring for 24-48 hours if abnormal ECG or high-voltage exposure
    • Aggressive fluid resuscitation (tissue injury often deeper than apparent)
    • Early fasciotomy if compartment syndrome suspected
  • Chemical Burns:
    • Prolonged irrigation (20-60 minutes) with copious water/saline
    • Specific antidotes: Calcium gluconate for HF burns, irrigation with amphoteric solution for alkali burns
    • Avoid neutralizing agents (exothermic reactions can worsen injury)

Supportive Care:

  • Temperature Regulation: Warm room, warming blankets (hypothermia common due to loss of skin barrier)
  • Nutrition: Early enteral nutrition (high caloric needs: 25-30 kcal/kg + 40 kcal per %TBSA burn)
  • GI Prophylaxis: PPI or H2-blocker (stress ulcer prophylaxis - Curling's ulcer)
  • DVT Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin or LMWH once hemodynamically stable

Transfer to Burn Center:

  • Early Communication: Contact burn center early in resuscitation
  • Continue Resuscitation During Transfer: Maintain IV access, continue fluids, monitor vitals
  • Transfer Documentation: TBSA calculation, fluid given, urine output, injuries, medical history
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Parkland Formula Pitfall: The formula is a starting point, NOT a rigid prescription. Titrate fluids to urine output (0.5-1 mL/kg/hr). Over-resuscitation causes abdominal compartment syndrome and pulmonary edema; under-resuscitation causes acute kidney injury and shock.
  • "8-Hour Clock" Starts at Time of Burn: NOT time of arrival to hospital. If patient arrives 3 hours after burn, you have only 5 hours to give the first half of calculated fluids. Adjust hourly rate accordingly to catch up.
  • Only Count Partial and Full-Thickness Burns: Do NOT include superficial (first-degree) burns in TBSA calculation for Parkland formula. Only blistering (partial-thickness) and worse are counted.
  • Hematocrit Paradox: Elevated hematocrit in burns indicates hemoconcentration from plasma loss into third-space, NOT polycythemia. It's a marker of hypovolemia requiring MORE fluid resuscitation.
  • Early Intubation for Inhalation Injury: Airway edema progresses rapidly over 12-24 hours. If you're debating intubation, intubate NOW. Delayed intubation with facial/airway edema can become a surgical airway emergency.
  • Tea-Colored Urine = Myoglobinuria Emergency: Indicates massive rhabdomyolysis (common in electrical burns). Requires aggressive fluid resuscitation (urine output goal 1-2 mL/kg/hr), urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate, and mannitol if needed to prevent ATN.
  • Escharotomy vs Fasciotomy: Escharotomy releases constricting circumferential eschar (through skin only); fasciotomy releases deeper compartments (through fascia). Escharotomy is immediate bedside procedure; fasciotomy requires OR. Both are needed urgently if compartment syndrome develops.
  • No Role for Prophylactic Antibiotics: Prophylactic systemic antibiotics do NOT reduce infection rates and promote resistant organisms. Use topical antimicrobials (silver sulfadiazine) and treat infections when clinically evident with cultures.
  • Curling's Ulcer: Stress gastroduodenal ulceration is common complication of severe burns (>30% TBSA). Start PPI prophylaxis early. Named after Thomas Curling who first described it in burn patients in 1842.
  • Electrical Burns Are Icebergs: Surface injury dramatically underestimates tissue damage. Electricity follows path of least resistance (through nerves, vessels, muscles) causing deep tissue necrosis. Always assume worse injury than visible and monitor for compartment syndrome, rhabdomyolysis, dysrhythmias.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • ALL severe burns (>20% TBSA) require ICU admission
  • Inhalation injury requiring mechanical ventilation
  • Burns involving face, airway, requiring close monitoring
  • Electrical burns with cardiac dysrhythmias
  • Hemodynamic instability despite fluid resuscitation
  • Rhabdomyolysis with acute kidney injury
  • Need for escharotomy or surgical intervention
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable without IV fluid resuscitation needs
  • Pain controlled on oral medications
  • Able to tolerate oral intake
  • Wound care manageable as outpatient (or home health arranged)
  • No signs of infection (afebrile, no purulent drainage)
  • Urine output adequate without IV fluids
  • Physical/occupational therapy arranged if needed
  • Follow-up with burn clinic or plastic surgery arranged (within 3-7 days)
  • Patient/family educated on wound care, dressing changes
  • Return precautions for fever, worsening pain, signs of infection
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

95. HEMIPLEGIC MIGRAINE

Motor Aura â€¢ Stroke Mimic â€¢ Genetic Mutations
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Patient with history of migraine presenting with transient unilateral motor weakness (hemiparesis or hemiplegia) as part of migraine aura, typically followed by severe headache. Motor symptoms may persist for hours to days, mimicking acute stroke.

  • Motor Aura (Required): Fully reversible unilateral motor weakness, may range from mild hemiparesis to complete hemiplegia
  • Additional Aura Symptoms (Common):
    • Visual aura: Scintillating scotoma, fortification spectra, homonymous hemianopia (90%)
    • Sensory aura: Paresthesias, numbness in hemibody distribution (70%)
    • Speech/language disturbance: Aphasia, dysarthria (40%)
    • Brainstem symptoms: Diplopia, vertigo, ataxia, decreased consciousness (rare, suggests basilar-type)
  • Temporal Progression:
    • Aura symptoms develop gradually over 5-60 minutes (NOT sudden onset like stroke)
    • Each aura symptom lasts 5 minutes to 72 hours
    • Motor symptoms may persist longer than other aura types
    • Headache typically follows aura within 60 minutes (but may overlap or be absent)
  • Headache Characteristics: Severe, throbbing, unilateral (often contralateral to motor symptoms), associated with photophobia, phonophobia, nausea/vomiting
  • Age of Onset: Typically begins in childhood/adolescence (before age 20 in most cases), rarely presents de novo after age 40
  • Family History:
    • Familial Hemiplegic Migraine (FHM): At least one first- or second-degree relative with hemiplegic migraine
    • Sporadic Hemiplegic Migraine (SHM): No affected relatives
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

ICHD-3 Diagnostic Criteria for Hemiplegic Migraine:

  • A. At least two attacks fulfilling criteria B and C
  • B. Aura including both:
    • Fully reversible motor weakness
    • Fully reversible visual, sensory, and/or speech/language symptoms
  • C. At least three of the following:
    • At least one aura symptom spreads gradually over â‰¥5 minutes
    • Two or more aura symptoms occur in succession
    • Each aura symptom lasts 5-72 hours
    • At least one aura symptom is unilateral
    • At least one aura symptom is positive (e.g., flickering lights, tingling)
    • Headache accompanies or follows aura within 60 minutes
  • D. Not better accounted for by another diagnosis (stroke, seizure, etc.)

Initial Evaluation (First Presentation or Atypical Features):

  • Neuroimaging (MRI Brain Preferred):
    • ESSENTIAL to rule out stroke, especially on first presentation
    • DWI/ADC sequences to exclude acute ischemia
    • MRA or CTA to evaluate for arterial dissection, vasculitis
    • May show T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in watershed zones or cerebellar atrophy (chronic FHM)
  • CT Head (if MRI unavailable): To exclude hemorrhage, mass lesion (less sensitive for acute ischemia)
  • Laboratory Studies:
    • CBC, CMP: Rule out metabolic causes (hypoglycemia, hyponatremia)
    • ESR/CRP: Elevated in vasculitis
    • Hypercoagulable workup: If stroke suspected (protein C/S, antiphospholipid antibodies, factor V Leiden, prothrombin gene mutation)
    • Toxicology screen: Rule out drug-induced causes

Additional Testing (Based on Clinical Suspicion):

  • EEG: If seizure suspected (may show spreading cortical depression during aura)
  • Lumbar Puncture: If meningoencephalitis, SAH, or CNS vasculitis suspected
  • Echocardiogram + Bubble Study: If concern for PFO/ASD with paradoxical embolism
  • Genetic Testing:
    • Consider in familial cases (mutations in CACNA1A, ATP1A2, SCN1A genes)
    • CACNA1A (FHM1): P/Q-type calcium channel, most common (50%), may have cerebellar signs
    • ATP1A2 (FHM2): Na+/K+-ATPase pump (20%), may have seizures
    • SCN1A (FHM3): Sodium channel (<10%), may have seizures
    • Typically sent by neurology, not emergently necessary

Differentiating from Stroke:

  • Favors Hemiplegic Migraine:
    • Gradual onset over 5-60 minutes (vs sudden in stroke)
    • Positive symptoms (tingling, visual phenomena) before negative symptoms
    • March of symptoms across body parts
    • Prior history of similar episodes
    • Younger age (<40), especially if childhood onset
    • Family history of hemiplegic migraine
  • Favors Stroke:
    • Sudden onset (maximal deficit at onset)
    • Only negative symptoms (weakness, numbness, vision loss)
    • Older age (>50), vascular risk factors
    • Alteration in consciousness
    • Persistent symptoms beyond 72 hours
  • Key Principle: When in doubt, treat as stroke until proven otherwise. Hemiplegic migraine is diagnosis of exclusion.
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Acute Management (First Presentation or Uncertain Diagnosis):

  • Stroke Protocol:
    • Activate stroke team for first presentation with motor weakness
    • NIH Stroke Scale assessment
    • STAT neuroimaging (CT or MRI)
    • AVOID tPA in hemiplegic migraine (case reports of worsening symptoms, hemorrhage)
    • If diagnosis uncertain, withhold thrombolytics and complete imaging workup
  • Observation: Admit for telemetry and neuro checks if first episode or prolonged symptoms (>1 hour)

Acute Treatment (Confirmed Hemiplegic Migraine):

  • Triptans: CONTRAINDICATED in Hemiplegic Migraine
    • Risk of prolonged aura, vasoconstriction during vulnerable period
    • Absolute contraindication per FDA labeling
    • This includes sumatriptan, rizatriptan, all triptans
  • First-Line Abortive Therapy:
    • NSAIDs: Ibuprofen 800 mg PO or ketorolac 30 mg IV
    • Acetaminophen: 1000 mg PO
    • Antiemetics: Metoclopramide 10 mg IV (also helps headache via central dopamine antagonism) or prochlorperazine 10 mg IV
  • Second-Line Options:
    • IV Magnesium Sulfate: 2 grams IV over 15-30 minutes (may abort aura and improve headache)
    • Chlorpromazine: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 25 mg) for refractory headache
    • IV Fluids: Normal saline 1-2L (dehydration common trigger)
    • Corticosteroids: Dexamethasone 10-20 mg IV (for status migrainosus, prevents recurrence)
  • Supportive Care:
    • Dark, quiet room
    • Cold compress to head
    • Avoid sensory triggers

Prophylactic Therapy (Recurrent Episodes):

  • Indications for Prophylaxis: â‰¥2 attacks per month, attacks causing significant disability, attacks lasting >48 hours
  • First-Line Preventive Medications:
    • Verapamil: 120-480 mg daily (calcium channel blocker, preferred for FHM1 with CACNA1A mutation)
    • Topiramate: 25-100 mg BID (may worsen cognitive symptoms in some patients)
    • Valproic Acid: 500-1000 mg daily (avoid in women of childbearing potential)
  • Alternative Preventives:
    • Acetazolamide: 250-500 mg daily (especially if cerebellar signs present)
    • Lamotrigine: 100-200 mg daily (particularly effective for aura)
    • Flunarizine: 5-10 mg daily (not available in US, calcium channel blocker)
  • Newer Agents (Limited Data in Hemiplegic Migraine):
    • CGRP Antagonists: Erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab (case reports suggest safety and efficacy, but not FDA-approved for HM)
    • Avoid monoclonal antibodies targeting CGRP pathway until more data available
  • AVOID in Prophylaxis:
    • Beta-blockers (propranolol, metoprolol): May worsen aura
    • Triptans: Contraindicated

Lifestyle Modifications:

  • Trigger Avoidance: Sleep deprivation, stress, hormonal changes, certain foods (aged cheese, alcohol, MSG), bright lights
  • Regular Sleep Schedule: 7-9 hours nightly, consistent bedtime
  • Hydration: Adequate daily water intake
  • Stress Management: Cognitive behavioral therapy, biofeedback, relaxation techniques
  • Exercise: Regular aerobic exercise (but avoid triggering attacks)

Neurology Referral:

  • Indications: All patients with hemiplegic migraine should have outpatient neurology follow-up
  • Purpose: Confirmation of diagnosis, genetic counseling, prophylactic management, monitoring for complications (rare: status migrainosus, migrainous infarction, permanent sequelae)

Complications:

  • Migrainous Infarction: Aura symptoms lasting >7 days with neuroimaging showing ischemic infarction (RARE, <0.5% of hemiplegic migraine patients)
  • Persistent Aura: Aura symptoms lasting >1 week without infarction (may respond to steroids, antiepileptics)
  • Seizures: Slightly increased risk, especially in FHM2 and FHM3 (sodium/potassium channel mutations)
  • Cognitive Impairment: Rare, associated with recurrent severe attacks (cerebellar atrophy in some FHM1 patients)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Triptans Are Absolutely Contraindicated: All triptans (sumatriptan, rizatriptan, etc.) are contraindicated in hemiplegic migraine due to risk of prolonged aura and potential stroke. This is an FDA black box warning. NSAIDs, antiemetics, and magnesium are first-line instead.
  • Hemiplegic Migraine Is a Diagnosis of Exclusion: First presentation requires full stroke workup. Never diagnose hemiplegic migraine at bedside without neuroimaging excluding stroke, even with classic migraine history. Motor weakness = stroke until proven otherwise.
  • Gradual Onset Distinguishes from Stroke: Hemiplegic migraine aura develops gradually over 5-60 minutes with "march" of symptoms across body parts. Stroke is sudden (maximal at onset). This temporal profile is the key clinical differentiator.
  • Positive Symptoms Before Negative: Migraine aura typically starts with positive symptoms (tingling, visual sparkles) that evolve into negative symptoms (numbness, weakness). Stroke presents with only negative symptoms from the start.
  • Familial vs Sporadic Has Genetic Implications: Familial Hemiplegic Migraine (FHM) requires at least one first- or second-degree relative with hemiplegic migraine and has identified genetic mutations (CACNA1A, ATP1A2, SCN1A). Sporadic HM has no family history and genetic etiology is unclear. Genetic testing helpful for family planning.
  • FHM1 (CACNA1A) May Have Cerebellar Signs: Patients with CACNA1A mutations (most common FHM type) may develop progressive cerebellar atrophy with nystagmus, ataxia between attacks. Think of this if patient has "migraine plus cerebellar findings."
  • Don't Confuse with Basilar-Type Migraine: Basilar-type migraine (now called "migraine with brainstem aura") has brainstem symptoms (diplopia, dysarthria, vertigo, bilateral visual symptoms) but NO motor weakness. Motor weakness defines hemiplegic migraine.
  • Verapamil Is Prophylactic of Choice for FHM1: Calcium channel blockers (especially verapamil) are particularly effective for FHM1 (CACNA1A mutations affecting calcium channels). Start 120 mg daily, titrate to 480 mg as tolerated.
  • Prolonged Aura Can Last Days: Unlike typical migraine aura (5-60 minutes), hemiplegic migraine motor aura can persist for hours to days (up to 72 hours). This prolonged duration mimics stroke and causes diagnostic confusion. Document resolution over time to confirm diagnosis.
  • Migrainous Infarction Is a Real Entity: In rare cases (<0.5%), prolonged hemiplegic migraine aura can cause permanent ischemic stroke (migrainous infarction). Diagnosis requires aura lasting >7 days with MRI showing infarction in relevant territory. This is a medical emergency and changes management.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Inability to rule out stroke despite imaging (persistent diagnostic uncertainty with high-risk features)
  • Status migrainosus (severe headache >72 hours) unresponsive to treatment
  • Severe persistent neurologic deficits with unclear etiology
  • Complications from treatment (e.g., hypotension from aggressive medication)
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Stroke definitively ruled out (MRI with DWI showing no restricted diffusion)
  • Motor weakness resolved or clearly improving
  • Headache improved or manageable on oral medications
  • Patient able to ambulate safely (or baseline function if chronic deficits)
  • Diagnosis confirmed as hemiplegic migraine by neurology
  • Prophylactic therapy initiated (verapamil, topiramate, or alternative)
  • Outpatient neurology follow-up arranged (within 1-2 weeks)
  • Patient educated on avoiding triptans, recognizing warning signs
  • Return precautions for recurrent weakness, persistent symptoms >72 hours
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

96. TODD'S PARALYSIS

Postictal Weakness â€¢ Seizure Sequela â€¢ Transient Hemiparesis
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Patient with focal motor weakness (hemiparesis, monoparesis, or rarely quadriparesis) developing immediately after a focal or generalized tonic-clonic seizure, typically resolving within 48 hours. Most commonly presents as unilateral weakness contralateral to seizure focus.

  • Temporal Relationship to Seizure:
    • Onset: Immediately following cessation of seizure activity
    • Duration: Minutes to 48 hours (typically resolves within 24 hours)
    • Resolution: Gradual improvement over hours, complete recovery expected
    • Red flag: Weakness persisting >48 hours suggests stroke, not Todd's paralysis
  • Motor Deficits (Most Common):
    • Hemiparesis/hemiplegia (70%): Affects face, arm, leg on one side
    • Monoparesis (20%): Single limb weakness
    • Rarely: Focal weakness of specific muscle groups, quadriparesis
    • Distribution corresponds to seizure focus (contralateral to epileptogenic zone)
  • Other Postictal Neurologic Deficits:
    • Aphasia (10%): If seizure originates from dominant hemisphere language cortex
    • Visual field deficits: Homonymous hemianopia
    • Sensory deficits: Numbness, paresthesias (less common than motor)
    • Gaze deviation: Eyes deviate toward seizure focus (away from weak side)
    • Confusion, lethargy (expected postictal state)
  • Seizure Characteristics:
    • Type: Most commonly follows focal motor seizures with or without generalization (Jacksonian march)
    • Can occur after generalized tonic-clonic seizures (less common)
    • Duration: Longer seizure duration increases likelihood and severity of Todd's paralysis
    • Status epilepticus: High association with Todd's paralysis
  • Patient Population:
    • Known epilepsy: Most cases occur in patients with established seizure disorder
    • First seizure: Can be presenting sign of new-onset focal epilepsy
    • Structural lesions: Higher incidence in patients with stroke, tumor, AVM, trauma
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Critical Principle: Todd's Paralysis Is a Diagnosis of Exclusion

  • Must rule out acute stroke, particularly if first seizure or no witnessed seizure
  • Weakness could represent stroke that caused seizure (stroke-induced seizure), NOT postictal paralysis
  • Todd's paralysis should only be diagnosed with high confidence in witnessed seizure followed immediately by weakness

Initial Assessment:

  • History (Critical):
    • WITNESSED seizure immediately preceding weakness? (if no witness, consider stroke)
    • Prior history of epilepsy? Previous Todd's paralysis?
    • Timing: How long after seizure did weakness begin? (immediate suggests Todd's)
    • Progression: Is weakness improving or stable/worsening? (improving suggests Todd's, stable/worsening suggests stroke)
    • Seizure type and duration (longer seizures â†’ more likely Todd's)
  • Physical Examination:
    • Neurologic exam: Document extent and severity of weakness (NIH Stroke Scale useful)
    • Look for tongue bite, incontinence, other trauma supporting seizure
    • Assess for confusion, postictal state (supports Todd's diagnosis)

Neuroimaging (ESSENTIAL):

  • MRI Brain with DWI/ADC (Preferred):
    • Rule out acute ischemic stroke (restricted diffusion on DWI)
    • Todd's paralysis: NO restricted diffusion on DWI (key differentiator)
    • May show T2/FLAIR cortical hyperintensity or gyral swelling in seizure focus (transient, resolves)
    • Helps identify structural cause of seizure (old stroke, tumor, AVM, cortical dysplasia)
  • CT Head (if MRI unavailable/contraindicated):
    • Rules out hemorrhage, large infarct, mass
    • Less sensitive for acute ischemia and seizure-related changes
    • If CT negative but stroke still suspected, must follow with MRI
  • MRA or CTA: Consider if vascular abnormality suspected (dissection, vasculitis)

Laboratory Studies:

  • Basic Metabolic Panel: Hyponatremia, hypoglycemia can cause seizures and alter mentation
  • Antiepileptic Drug Levels: If on AEDs, check levels (subtherapeutic may explain breakthrough seizure)
  • Troponin: Seizure can cause demand ischemia, elevated troponin
  • CK: Elevated in prolonged seizures, rhabdomyolysis
  • Toxicology Screen: Rule out drug-induced seizures (cocaine, amphetamines, withdrawal states)
  • Prolactin: Elevated 10-20 minutes post-seizure (NOT specific, don't rely on this to diagnose seizure)

EEG:

  • Indications: All patients with first seizure, unexplained weakness, or concern for ongoing subclinical seizures
  • Timing: Ideally within 24 hours of seizure (yield decreases over time)
  • Findings in Todd's Paralysis:
    • Focal slowing (delta waves) in hemisphere corresponding to weakness
    • Epileptiform discharges localize seizure focus
    • May be normal (postictal changes resolve quickly)
  • Role: Confirms seizure occurred, identifies epileptogenic focus, guides long-term management

Differentiating Todd's Paralysis from Stroke:

Todd's Paralysis Acute Stroke
Onset Immediately after witnessed seizure Sudden, no seizure
Progression Gradual improvement over hours Stable or worsening
Duration Minutes to 48 hours (usually <24h) Persistent beyond 48 hours
MRI DWI NO restricted diffusion Restricted diffusion (bright on DWI)
Sensorium Postictal confusion Alert (unless large stroke)
EEG Focal slowing, epileptiform activity Focal slowing, no epileptiform
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Acute Management:

  • Observation:
    • Admit for telemetry and neurologic monitoring
    • Serial neurologic exams to document improvement (every 2-4 hours)
    • If weakness NOT improving after 12-24 hours, reconsider diagnosis (repeat imaging)
  • No Specific Treatment for Todd's Paralysis:
    • Supportive care only (spontaneous resolution expected)
    • Physical therapy/occupational therapy to prevent complications during weakness
    • DVT prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin or LMWH if prolonged weakness
  • DO NOT Give tPA:
    • Todd's paralysis is NOT an indication for thrombolysis
    • High risk of hemorrhage without benefit (no ischemia to treat)
    • If diagnosis uncertain, MUST rule out stroke with MRI before withholding tPA

Seizure Management:

  • Optimize Antiepileptic Therapy:
    • If on AEDs: Check levels, adjust doses to therapeutic range
    • If breakthrough seizure despite compliance: Increase dose or add second agent
    • If medication non-compliance: Counsel on adherence, simplify regimen
  • First Seizure Management:
    • Provoked seizure (hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, alcohol withdrawal, drug intoxication): Treat underlying cause, AED usually not needed long-term
    • Unprovoked seizure: Neurology consultation for AED initiation decision (typically start after second unprovoked seizure, or first seizure with high recurrence risk)
    • Structural lesion on imaging: Usually warrants AED initiation after first seizure
  • Common AED Options (Neurology to Guide):
    • Levetiracetam (Keppra): 500-1500 mg BID (broad-spectrum, well-tolerated, few drug interactions)
    • Phenytoin (Dilantin): Load 15-20 mg/kg IV, then 300 mg daily (narrow therapeutic index, many interactions)
    • Valproic acid: 250-500 mg BID (avoid in women of childbearing potential)
    • Lamotrigine: 25-200 mg BID (requires slow titration, Stevens-Johnson syndrome risk)

Identify and Treat Seizure Etiology:

  • Metabolic: Correct hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia
  • Toxic: Cocaine, amphetamines, bupropion, tramadol, antidepressants â†’ supportive care, benzodiazepines
  • Withdrawal: Alcohol, benzodiazepines â†’ benzodiazepine taper, thiamine, folate
  • Infectious: Meningoencephalitis â†’ LP, empiric antibiotics/antivirals pending cultures
  • Structural: Stroke, hemorrhage, tumor, AVM â†’ neurosurgical consultation as indicated

Disposition:

  • Admission Indications:
    • Todd's paralysis (for observation until resolution)
    • First seizure with unclear etiology
    • Breakthrough seizure on AEDs
    • Status epilepticus
    • Structural lesion requiring intervention
  • Discharge Criteria:
    • Complete resolution of Todd's paralysis
    • Seizure clearly provoked with correctable cause
    • Therapeutic AED levels
    • Reliable follow-up arranged
  • Discharge Instructions:
    • Neurology follow-up within 1-2 weeks
    • Outpatient EEG if not done inpatient
    • Driving restrictions (varies by state, typically 3-6 months seizure-free)
    • Avoid high-risk activities (swimming alone, heights, operating heavy machinery)
    • Medication compliance counseling
    • Return precautions: Recurrent seizures, worsening weakness, new symptoms

Long-Term Management (Neurology):

  • Epilepsy Surgery Evaluation: If refractory epilepsy (seizures despite 2+ AEDs), consider referral to epilepsy center for surgery workup
  • VNS (Vagal Nerve Stimulator): Alternative for refractory epilepsy not amenable to surgery
  • Dietary Therapy: Ketogenic diet may reduce seizures in some patients
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Named After Robert Bentley Todd (1849): British physician who first described transient postictal paralysis in patients with epilepsy. His observations were fundamental to understanding focal seizures and their aftermath.
  • Todd's Paralysis Is Diagnosis of Exclusion: Never diagnose without imaging to rule out stroke. The clinical dilemma: weakness could be (1) Todd's paralysis after seizure, (2) stroke that caused a seizure, or (3) coincidental stroke unrelated to seizure. MRI DWI is gold standard to differentiate.
  • No Restricted Diffusion on MRI DWI: This is THE key imaging finding that distinguishes Todd's paralysis from acute ischemic stroke. Stroke shows restricted diffusion (bright on DWI, dark on ADC); Todd's paralysis shows NO restricted diffusion. May see transient T2/FLAIR cortical hyperintensity from seizure activity.
  • Duration >48 Hours â†’ Not Todd's Paralysis: By definition, Todd's paralysis resolves within 48 hours (most within 24 hours). Persistent weakness beyond 48 hours strongly suggests stroke or another structural lesion, not postictal phenomenon. Re-image and reconsider diagnosis.
  • Mechanism: Neuronal Exhaustion Theory: Exact pathophysiology unknown, but leading theory is temporary neuronal dysfunction and depletion of neurotransmitters after prolonged seizure activity. It's a "metabolic paralysis" from exhausted motor cortex, not ischemia. Neurons need time to recover.
  • Weakness Localizes the Seizure Focus: Todd's paralysis is contralateral to epileptogenic zone. Right-sided weakness â†’ left hemisphere seizure focus. This helps localize lesion for surgical workup in refractory epilepsy.
  • Longer Seizure = More Likely Todd's: Risk and severity of Todd's paralysis correlate with seizure duration. Status epilepticus has highest association. Brief (<1 minute) generalized seizures rarely cause Todd's paralysis.
  • EEG Shows Focal Slowing: During and immediately after Todd's paralysis, EEG typically shows focal slowing (delta waves) in affected hemisphere. This corresponds to "exhausted" neurons. Epileptiform discharges may also be present, localizing seizure focus. EEG helps confirm diagnosis.
  • DO NOT Give tPA for Todd's Paralysis: Thrombolysis is CONTRAINDICATEDâ€”it exposes patient to hemorrhage risk without benefit (no clot to lyse). This is a common ED dilemma: stroke mimic with weakness. Key is obtaining MRI before tPA decision when Todd's is suspected.
  • Recurrent Todd's Paralysis Suggests Poor Seizure Control: Patients with frequent Todd's paralysis have inadequately controlled epilepsy. Each episode indicates breakthrough seizure activity. Optimize AEDs or refer for epilepsy surgery evaluation if refractory to medications.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Status epilepticus requiring continuous EEG monitoring
  • Inability to rule out stroke despite imaging (diagnostic uncertainty)
  • Persistent altered mental status concerning for ongoing seizure activity
  • Hemodynamic instability post-seizure
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Stroke ruled out (MRI with DWI negative for restricted diffusion)
  • Todd's paralysis resolved completely
  • Seizures controlled on antiepileptic medication
  • Patient at neurologic baseline
  • Therapeutic AED levels if on chronic seizure medication
  • Outpatient neurology follow-up arranged (within 1-2 weeks)
  • EEG completed or arranged as outpatient
  • Patient educated on seizure precautions, medication compliance
  • Driving restrictions discussed (state-specific, typically 3-6 months seizure-free)
  • Return precautions for recurrent seizures, persistent weakness
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

97. TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURY (TBI)

Concussion â€¢ Intracranial Hemorrhage â€¢ Glasgow Coma Scale
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Patient with head trauma presenting with altered consciousness (ranging from brief confusion to prolonged coma), neurologic deficits, or signs of intracranial hemorrhage. Severity ranges from mild (concussion) to severe (coma, mass effect).

  • Mild TBI (Concussion, GCS 13-15):
    • Loss of consciousness: <30 minutes (or none)
    • Post-traumatic amnesia: <24 hours
    • Confusion, disorientation, difficulty concentrating
    • Headache, dizziness, nausea/vomiting
    • Photophobia, phonophobia
    • Emotional lability, irritability, sleep disturbances
    • Normal neurologic exam (or subtle deficits)
  • Moderate TBI (GCS 9-12):
    • Loss of consciousness: 30 minutes to 24 hours
    • Post-traumatic amnesia: 1-7 days
    • Confusion, lethargy, disorientation
    • Focal neurologic deficits possible
    • May have abnormal CT findings (small hemorrhage, edema)
  • Severe TBI (GCS 3-8):
    • Loss of consciousness: >24 hours
    • Coma, unresponsive or minimally responsive
    • Post-traumatic amnesia: >7 days
    • Focal deficits, posturing (decorticate, decerebrate)
    • Abnormal CT: Large hemorrhage, mass effect, midline shift
    • Elevated ICP signs (Cushing's triad: hypertension, bradycardia, irregular respirations)

Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage:

  • Epidural Hematoma (EDH):
    • Mechanism: Skull fracture (temporal bone) â†’ middle meningeal artery rupture
    • Classic: "Lucid interval" (initial LOC, then alert period, then rapid deterioration)
    • CT: Biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdensity, does NOT cross suture lines
    • Emergency: Neurosurgical evacuation if >30 mL or midline shift >5 mm
  • Subdural Hematoma (SDH):
    • Mechanism: Bridging vein tear (especially elderly, anticoagulated patients)
    • Acute: High-density crescent on CT, crosses suture lines
    • Chronic: Low-density crescent (weeks old), can rebleed
    • Risk factors: Elderly, alcoholism, anticoagulation, falls
  • Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (Traumatic SAH):
    • Blood in sulci, cisterns from cortical vessel injury
    • Usually mild, self-limited (vs aneurysmal SAH)
    • Monitor for delayed vasospasm (rare in traumatic SAH)
  • Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage / Contusion:
    • Bruising of brain parenchyma (coup or contrecoup injury)
    • Common locations: Frontal, temporal poles
    • CT: Mixed density (blood + edema), may expand over first 48 hours
  • Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI):
    • Severe shearing injury from rapid acceleration-deceleration
    • CT: Often normal or small hemorrhages at grey-white junction
    • MRI: Microhemorrhages on GRE/SWI sequences, best for diagnosis
    • Poor prognosis: Coma, severe disability common

Red Flags (High Risk for Intracranial Injury):

  • GCS <15 at 2 hours post-injury
  • Loss of consciousness â‰¥5 minutes
  • Focal neurologic deficits
  • Persistent vomiting (â‰¥2 episodes)
  • Age â‰¥65 years
  • Skull fracture (palpable, Battle's sign, raccoon eyes, hemotympanum, CSF rhinorrhea/otorrhea)
  • Anticoagulation (warfarin, DOACs, antiplatelets)
  • Dangerous mechanism (fall >3 feet, high-speed MVC, pedestrian struck, assault)
  • Post-traumatic seizure
  • Severe persistent headache
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS):

Component Response Score
Eye Opening Spontaneous 4
To voice 3
To pain 2
None 1
Verbal Response Oriented 5
Confused conversation 4
Inappropriate words 3
Incomprehensible sounds 2
None 1
Motor Response Obeys commands 6
Localizes pain 5
Withdraws from pain 4
Flexion to pain (decorticate) 3
Extension to pain (decerebrate) 2
None 1
  • Total Score: 3-15 (3 = worst, 15 = best)
  • Severity: Mild (13-15), Moderate (9-12), Severe (3-8)

CT Head Decision Rules:

  • Canadian CT Head Rule (High Sensitivity):
    • High Risk (neurosurgical intervention needed): GCS <15 at 2h, suspected skull fracture, vomiting â‰¥2 episodes, age â‰¥65
    • Medium Risk (brain injury on CT): Amnesia >30 min, dangerous mechanism
    • If ANY risk factor present: CT indicated
  • New Orleans Criteria:
    • CT if ANY: Headache, vomiting, age >60, drug/alcohol intoxication, seizure, trauma visible above clavicles, anterograde amnesia
  • NEXUS II (Newer): Age â‰¥65, evidence of skull fracture, scalp hematoma, neurologic deficit, altered LOC, abnormal behavior, coagulopathy, persistent vomiting

CT Head (Non-Contrast):

  • Indications: Any red flag or high-risk feature, GCS <15, focal deficits, anticoagulation
  • Findings:
    • Hemorrhage: EDH, SDH, SAH, IPH, IVH
    • Skull fracture: Linear, depressed, basilar
    • Midline shift, herniation, effacement of cisterns
    • Pneumocephalus (air in cranium, suggests skull fracture/dural tear)
  • Repeat CT Indications:
    • GCS decline â‰¥2 points
    • New focal deficits
    • Persistent or worsening headache
    • Routine repeat at 6-12 hours for initial hemorrhage (assess expansion)

MRI Brain:

  • Indications: Diffuse axonal injury suspected (GCS doesn't match CT findings), subacute/chronic TBI, detailed injury characterization
  • Sequences:
    • GRE/SWI: Detects microhemorrhages (DAI)
    • DWI: Identifies cytotoxic edema, ischemia
    • FLAIR: Cortical contusions, edema
  • NOT for acute management: CT is faster, more practical in trauma setting

Laboratory Studies:

  • CBC: Baseline hemoglobin (ongoing hemorrhage), platelets (coagulopathy risk)
  • Coagulation Studies: PT/INR, PTT if anticoagulated or suspected coagulopathy
  • Type & Screen: If neurosurgery anticipated
  • Alcohol Level, Toxicology: Common confounders in altered mental status
  • Electrolytes, Glucose: Rule out metabolic causes of AMS

Cervical Spine Imaging:

  • Indications: All patients with TBI should be evaluated for c-spine injury (10% have concomitant c-spine injury)
  • Canadian C-Spine Rule: High-risk mechanism, age â‰¥65, dangerous mechanism, paresthesias â†’ CT c-spine
  • CT C-Spine: Preferred in obtunded patients or those with high-risk features
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Initial Resuscitation (Severe TBI, GCS â‰¤8):

  • Airway Management:
    • Early intubation for GCS â‰¤8 (unable to protect airway)
    • Rapid sequence intubation with inline stabilization (assume c-spine injury)
    • Avoid hypoxia (SpO2 goal >90%) and hypotension (SBP goal â‰¥100 mmHg)
    • Ventilator settings: Normocapnia (PaCO2 35-40 mmHg); avoid hyperventilation unless acute herniation
  • Circulation:
    • Maintain SBP â‰¥100 mmHg (age 50-69) or â‰¥110 mmHg (age 15-49, >70)
    • IV fluid resuscitation: Isotonic crystalloid (normal saline or LR), avoid hypotonic fluids (worsen cerebral edema)
    • Vasopressors if needed: Norepinephrine preferred
  • Treat Hypotension and Hypoxia FIRST: These are the two most harmful secondary insults in TBI (worse than elevated ICP)

ICP Management (Severe TBI with Signs of Elevated ICP):

  • ICP Monitoring Indications:
    • Severe TBI (GCS 3-8) with abnormal CT (hematoma, contusion, edema, compressed cisterns)
    • Severe TBI with normal CT but â‰¥2 of: age >40, SBP <90, posturing
    • Goal ICP: <20-22 mmHg, CPP (cerebral perfusion pressure) 60-70 mmHg
  • Head of Bed Elevation: 30 degrees (improves venous drainage, reduces ICP)
  • Hyperosmolar Therapy:
    • Hypertonic Saline (3% or 23.4%): 250 mL bolus 3% NaCl or 30 mL bolus 23.4% NaCl IV (preferred, more effective than mannitol)
    • Mannitol: 0.25-1 g/kg IV bolus (onset 15-30 min, duration 4-6h; monitor serum osmolality <320 mOsm/kg)
    • Use for acute ICP elevation or signs of herniation (blown pupil, Cushing's triad, posturing)
  • Sedation:
    • Propofol infusion: 20-75 mcg/kg/min (reduces cerebral metabolic rate, lowers ICP)
    • Fentanyl: 25-100 mcg/hr (analgesia, reduces ICP from pain/agitation)
    • Avoid oversedation (masks neuro exam)
  • Avoid Hyperthermia: Fever worsens secondary brain injury; goal normothermia (acetaminophen, cooling blankets)
  • Seizure Prophylaxis:
    • Levetiracetam 500-1000 mg IV BID or phenytoin load 20 mg/kg for first 7 days (reduces early post-traumatic seizures)
    • No benefit for long-term prophylaxis beyond 7 days unless patient has actual seizure

Hyperventilation (ONLY for Acute Herniation):

  • Mechanism: Hypocapnia â†’ cerebral vasoconstriction â†’ reduced ICP (but also reduces cerebral blood flow â†’ ischemia)
  • Target: PaCO2 30-35 mmHg (NOT <30 mmHg)
  • Duration: Temporary bridge to definitive treatment (surgery, ICP monitor placement)
  • Avoid Prophylactic Hyperventilation: Worsens outcomes by causing ischemia

Surgical Intervention (Neurosurgery Consultation):

  • Indications for Craniotomy/Craniectomy:
    • EDH >30 mL or midline shift >5 mm
    • SDH >10 mm thickness or midline shift >5 mm
    • Depressed skull fracture (>1 cm depression)
    • Large contusions with mass effect
    • Refractory elevated ICP despite medical management
  • Decompressive Craniectomy: Last resort for refractory ICP; improves survival but may leave severe disability

Reversal of Anticoagulation:

  • Warfarin:
    • Vitamin K 10 mg IV PLUS 4-factor PCC (Kcentra) 25-50 units/kg IV (preferred over FFP)
    • Alternative: FFP 10-15 mL/kg if PCC unavailable (slower, less effective)
  • Dabigatran (Pradaxa): Idarucizumab (Praxbind) 5 grams IV
  • Factor Xa Inhibitors (rivaroxaban, apixaban): Andexanet alfa (Andexxa) 400-800 mg IV or 4-factor PCC 50 units/kg
  • Heparin: Protamine 1 mg per 100 units heparin (max 50 mg)
  • Antiplatelet Agents:
    • Platelet transfusion if neurosurgery planned
    • DDAVP 0.3 mcg/kg IV if uremic platelet dysfunction

Mild TBI (Concussion) Management:

  • Observation:
    • 4-6 hours in ED if reliable home situation, normal CT (if obtained), GCS 15
    • Discharge with responsible adult for home observation
  • Return Precautions: Worsening headache, vomiting, confusion, seizures, weakness, vision changes â†’ return immediately
  • Cognitive Rest: Avoid screens, reading, work/school for 24-48 hours
  • Physical Rest: No sports, exercise, or activities with reinjury risk until cleared by physician
  • Graduated Return to Activity: Stepwise progression over days to weeks (no symptoms at each stage before advancing)
  • Follow-Up: Primary care or sports medicine in 1-2 weeks for clearance

Post-Concussion Syndrome (Symptoms >3 Months):

  • Symptoms: Persistent headaches, dizziness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, memory problems, mood changes
  • Management: Multidisciplinary (neurology, neuropsychology, physical therapy), symptom-directed treatment (headache meds, vestibular therapy, cognitive rehab)

Disposition:

  • ICU Admission: GCS â‰¤12, intracranial hemorrhage, elevated ICP, need for ICP monitoring, anticoagulation with ICH
  • Floor Admission: GCS 13-14, isolated skull fracture, need for serial neuro exams
  • Discharge: GCS 15, normal CT (or low-risk isolated finding), reliable follow-up, responsible adult at home
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Hypotension and Hypoxia Are the Deadliest Secondary Insults: Single episode of hypotension (SBP <90) or hypoxia (SpO2 <90%) doubles mortality in TBI. Airway, breathing, circulation BEFORE worrying about ICP. Maintain SBP â‰¥100-110 mmHg and SpO2 >90%.
  • "Talk and Die" Syndrome (Epidural Hematoma): Classic lucid interval: patient is initially unconscious, then wakes up and seems fine ("talks"), then rapidly deteriorates hours later ("dies" without intervention). High-pressure arterial bleeding (middle meningeal artery) â†’ rapid expansion â†’ herniation. Emergency craniotomy saves lives.
  • Lens-Shaped vs Crescent-Shaped on CT: Epidural hematoma is biconvex/lens-shaped (doesn't cross suture lines, limited by dura attachments). Subdural hematoma is crescent-shaped (crosses suture lines, follows brain contour). This distinction is high-yield for boards and clinical practice.
  • CPP = MAP - ICP (Cerebral Perfusion Pressure): Goal CPP 60-70 mmHg ensures adequate brain perfusion. If ICP rises or MAP drops, CPP falls â†’ brain ischemia. Maintain blood pressure AND reduce ICP. CPP <50 mmHg = bad news.
  • Cushing's Triad = Herniation Until Proven Otherwise: Hypertension (widened pulse pressure), bradycardia, irregular respirations = impending brainstem herniation from elevated ICP. This is a late, ominous sign. Immediate intervention required: hyperventilate, hyperosmolar therapy, neurosurgery.
  • Hypertonic Saline > Mannitol for ICP Reduction: 3% or 23.4% saline is more effective and safer than mannitol (no risk of hypovolemia, hypotension, or rebound ICP). Mannitol causes osmotic diuresis â†’ dehydration â†’ decreased CPP. Use saline first.
  • Avoid Prophylactic Hyperventilation: Hypocapnia causes cerebral vasoconstriction â†’ reduced cerebral blood flow â†’ ischemia. Only hyperventilate for acute herniation (PaCO2 30-35 mmHg) as temporary bridge to surgery. Target normocapnia (35-40 mmHg) otherwise.
  • Repeat CT at 6-12 Hours for Traumatic ICH: Hemorrhagic contusions and hematomas can expand in first 24-48 hours. Always repeat CT if clinical decline, but also routinely for any significant bleed to assess for expansion. Many bleeds enlarge even without GCS change.
  • Seizure Prophylaxis Only for First 7 Days: Levetiracetam or phenytoin reduces early post-traumatic seizures (first week) but NOT late seizures (>7 days). No benefit to prophylaxis beyond 7 days unless patient has actual seizure. If seizure occurs, continue AED long-term.
  • Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI) = "Worst GCS for the CT": Patient in coma (GCS 4-6) but CT looks normal or shows only tiny punctate hemorrhages. MRI (GRE/SWI) reveals extensive microhemorrhages at grey-white junction from shearing forces. Poor prognosisâ€”severe disability common. DAI is hallmark of severe acceleration-deceleration injury (high-speed MVCs).
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • ALL severe TBI (GCS â‰¤8) requires ICU admission
  • Intracranial hemorrhage with mass effect or midline shift
  • Need for ICP monitoring
  • Hemodynamic instability requiring vasopressor support
  • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
  • Seizures requiring ongoing treatment
  • Signs of herniation (blown pupil, Cushing's triad, posturing)
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable without vasopressors
  • Neurologically stable or improving (GCS â‰¥13-15 for mild TBI)
  • Repeat imaging stable (no expansion of hemorrhage, no new findings)
  • No seizures (or controlled on prophylactic AED for severe TBI)
  • Pain controlled on oral medications
  • Able to ambulate safely and perform ADLs (or baseline if chronic deficits)
  • Follow-up with neurosurgery arranged if indicated (within 1-4 weeks)
  • If concussion: graduated return-to-activity plan explained
  • Patient/family educated on return precautions (worsening headache, vomiting, confusion, seizures)
  • Repeat imaging arranged if indicated (typically 4-6 weeks for significant injury)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

98. MALARIA

Plasmodium Species â€¢ Fever Paroxysms â€¢ Blood Smear
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Patient with recent travel to malaria-endemic area (Sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia, Latin America) presenting with fever, chills, headache, and myalgias. Fever classically occurs in paroxysms (cyclic pattern every 48-72 hours depending on species), though early infection often has irregular fever.

  • Five Plasmodium Species:
    • P. falciparum: Most deadly (causes severe malaria), no relapse from liver (erythrocytic cycle only)
    • P. vivax: Relapsing (hypnozoites in liver), causes severe anemia
    • P. ovale: Relapsing (hypnozoites), clinically similar to P. vivax, less common
    • P. malariae: Chronic low-grade parasitemia, can persist for years, no relapse
    • P. knowlesi: Zoonotic (from monkeys), Southeast Asia, can cause severe disease
  • Transmission: Female Anopheles mosquito bite (typically dusk to dawn), rarely transfusion/needlestick/vertical transmission
  • Incubation Period: 7-30 days (P. falciparum), weeks to months (P. vivax/ovale), years (P. malariae)

Uncomplicated Malaria (Most Presentations):

  • Fever: High fever (39-41Â°C), may have classic paroxysms (chills â†’ fever â†’ sweats), but early infection often irregular
  • Classic Paroxysm Timing by Species:
    • P. falciparum: Irregular or daily fever
    • P. vivax/ovale: Tertian fever (every 48 hours)
    • P. malariae: Quartan fever (every 72 hours)
  • Associated Symptoms:
    • Headache (severe, frontal)
    • Myalgias, arthralgias
    • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea
    • Malaise, fatigue
    • Dry cough (mild)
  • Physical Exam:
    • Splenomegaly (50-75%, develops after 1-2 weeks)
    • Hepatomegaly (30-50%)
    • Jaundice (hemolytic anemia)
    • Pallor (anemia)
    • Tachycardia, tachypnea

Severe Malaria (P. falciparum, Requires Hospitalization):

  • Cerebral Malaria:
    • Altered mental status (confusion, delirium, coma)
    • Seizures (especially children)
    • GCS <11 or Blantyre Coma Score <3 (pediatric)
    • Mechanism: Sequestration of infected RBCs in cerebral microvasculature
    • High mortality (15-20% even with treatment)
  • Severe Anemia: Hemoglobin <7 g/dL or hematocrit <20%
  • Acute Respiratory Distress: Pulmonary edema, ARDS (often delayed, can occur after treatment started)
  • Renal Failure: Acute kidney injury (creatinine >3 mg/dL), "blackwater fever" (dark urine from massive hemolysis)
  • Metabolic Acidosis: Lactic acidosis (bicarbonate <15 mEq/L, lactate >5 mmol/L)
  • Hypoglycemia: Glucose <40 mg/dL (from parasite consumption + quinine-induced hyperinsulinemia)
  • Hyperparasitemia: >5% parasitemia (>250,000/Î¼L) or >2% with organ dysfunction
  • Shock: Hypotension, multiorgan failure
  • Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC): Bleeding, thrombocytopenia, elevated PT/PTT
  • Jaundice: Bilirubin >3 mg/dL with other signs of severity
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical Suspicion (Who to Test):

  • ANY fever in patient with travel to malaria-endemic area in past year (especially past 3 months)
  • Immigrants/refugees from endemic countries
  • NO FEVER does NOT rule out malaria (some patients afebrile at presentation)

Definitive Diagnosis:

  • Thick and Thin Blood Smears (Gold Standard):
    • Thick smear: Higher sensitivity (concentrates parasites), used for screening
    • Thin smear: Species identification, quantifies parasitemia
    • Repeat every 12-24 hours for 3 sets if initial negative but high suspicion
    • Timing: Can draw anytime (don't wait for fever spike)
    • Parasitemia calculation: (# parasites / # RBCs) Ã— 100
  • Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs):
    • Detect parasite antigens (HRP-2 for P. falciparum, pLDH for all species)
    • Sensitivity 95% for P. falciparum, lower for other species
    • Results in 15-20 minutes
    • Limitation: Cannot quantify parasitemia, may stay positive for weeks after treatment
    • Use: Adjunct to blood smear, NOT replacement (always confirm with smear)
  • PCR: Most sensitive (detects low-level parasitemia), species identification, but not widely available, slow turnaround

Laboratory Findings:

  • CBC:
    • Anemia: Normocytic, normochromic from hemolysis (Hgb often 7-10 g/dL)
    • Thrombocytopenia: 80-90% of cases (platelets 50,000-150,000/Î¼L), rarely causes bleeding
    • Leukopenia or normal WBC (leukocytosis suggests bacterial co-infection)
  • Comprehensive Metabolic Panel:
    • Elevated creatinine: Acute kidney injury in severe malaria
    • Hypoglycemia: Common in severe malaria and quinine treatment
    • Hyponatremia: SIADH-like picture
    • Elevated transaminases: Mild AST/ALT elevation (200-500 U/L)
    • Elevated bilirubin: Indirect (hemolysis)
  • Lactate: Elevated in severe malaria (>5 mmol/L indicates poor prognosis)
  • LDH: Elevated (hemolysis marker)
  • Haptoglobin: Low (intravascular hemolysis)
  • Arterial Blood Gas: Metabolic acidosis in severe malaria
  • Coagulation Studies: PT/PTT may be elevated in DIC

Determining Severity (Hospitalize vs Outpatient):

  • Severe Malaria (ANY of the following = HOSPITALIZE):
    • Altered mental status, seizures, coma
    • Severe anemia (Hgb <7 g/dL)
    • Renal failure (Cr >3 mg/dL)
    • Pulmonary edema, ARDS
    • Hypoglycemia (<40 mg/dL)
    • Shock, acidosis (lactate >5)
    • Hyperparasitemia (>5% or >2% with organ dysfunction)
    • DIC, bleeding
    • Jaundice (bilirubin >3 mg/dL with other severity criteria)
  • Uncomplicated Malaria (Can Consider Outpatient if Reliable):
    • No severity criteria
    • Able to tolerate oral medications
    • Parasitemia <2%
    • Reliable for follow-up
    • Access to care if worsens

Additional Testing:

  • Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) Testing: Before giving primaquine (can cause severe hemolysis in G6PD deficiency)
  • Chest X-ray: If respiratory symptoms (rule out ARDS, pulmonary edema)
  • Lumbar Puncture: If altered mental status to rule out meningitis/encephalitis (CSF usually normal in cerebral malaria)
  • Blood Cultures: If febrile and ill-appearing (rule out bacterial sepsis, co-infection common)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Treatment Selection Based on Species and Severity:

SEVERE MALARIA (P. falciparum or Unknown Species):

  • IV Artesunate (First-Line, Preferred):
    • Dose: 2.4 mg/kg IV at 0, 12, and 24 hours, then daily until oral therapy tolerated
    • Available through CDC Drug Service (770-488-7788)
    • 20-30% reduction in mortality vs quinine
    • Switch to oral ACT (artemisinin-based combination therapy) when able to tolerate PO
  • IV Quinidine (Alternative if Artesunate Unavailable):
    • Loading dose: 10 mg/kg (max 600 mg) IV over 1-2 hours, then 0.02 mg/kg/min continuous infusion
    • PLUS doxycycline 100 mg IV/PO BID OR clindamycin 10 mg/kg IV TID
    • Cardiac monitoring required (QT prolongation, torsades risk)
    • Monitor glucose closely (causes hyperinsulinemia â†’ hypoglycemia)
  • Supportive Care (Critical):
    • ICU monitoring for severe malaria
    • IV fluids: Cautious hydration (risk of pulmonary edema), monitor I/Os closely
    • Correct hypoglycemia: Dextrose 50 mL D50 IV bolus, then maintenance D5W or D10W infusion
    • Transfuse PRBCs: If Hgb <7 g/dL or severe anemia with symptoms
    • Renal replacement therapy: Hemodialysis if acute kidney injury with uremia or fluid overload
    • Anticonvulsants: Benzodiazepines for seizures (do NOT use prophylactic phenobarbitalâ€”increases mortality)
    • Mechanical ventilation: If ARDS or respiratory failure
  • Adjunctive Therapies with NO BENEFIT (Avoid):
    • Steroids: NO benefit, may increase complications
    • Exchange transfusion: NOT routinely recommended (conflicting evidence)

UNCOMPLICATED MALARIA:

  • P. falciparum or Unknown Species (Chloroquine-Resistant):
    • First-Line: Artemether-lumefantrine (Coartem): 4 tablets (20/120 mg) PO BID Ã— 3 days (with fatty food to improve absorption)
    • Alternatives:
      • Atovaquone-proguanil (Malarone): 4 tablets (250/100 mg) PO daily Ã— 3 days
      • Quinine sulfate 542 mg PO TID Ã— 3-7 days PLUS doxycycline 100 mg PO BID Ã— 7 days OR clindamycin 20 mg/kg/day divided TID Ã— 7 days
      • Mefloquine 750 mg PO once, then 500 mg 6-12 hours later (neuropsychiatric side effects common)
  • P. falciparum from Chloroquine-Sensitive Area (Rareâ€”Central America west of Panama Canal, Haiti, Dominican Republic):
    • Chloroquine phosphate: 600 mg base (1000 mg salt) PO, then 300 mg base at 6, 24, and 48 hours
  • P. vivax or P. ovale:
    • Erythrocytic Stage (Blood Infection): Chloroquine 600 mg base PO, then 300 mg base at 6, 24, 48 hours
    • PLUS Hepatic Stage (Hypnozoites, Prevents Relapse): Primaquine 30 mg base PO daily Ã— 14 days
      • MUST check G6PD level first (primaquine causes severe hemolysis in G6PD deficiency)
      • If G6PD deficient: Use primaquine 45 mg weekly Ã— 8 weeks (slower regimen) OR avoid primaquine (accept relapse risk)
      • If chloroquine-resistant P. vivax (Southeast Asia, Oceania): Use artemether-lumefantrine or atovaquone-proguanil PLUS primaquine
  • P. malariae or P. knowlesi:
    • Chloroquine (same as P. vivax) or artemether-lumefantrine
    • NO primaquine needed (no liver stage)

Monitoring During Treatment:

  • Daily blood smears: Until parasitemia cleared (should decrease by 75% at 48 hours)
  • Daily labs: CBC, CMP, glucose (especially with quinine/quinidine)
  • Clinical assessment: Vital signs, mental status, urine output
  • Treatment failure: If parasitemia unchanged or worsening at 48-72 hours, consider resistance, change regimen

Special Populations:

  • Pregnancy:
    • Severe malaria: IV artesunate (all trimesters), IV quinidine alternative
    • Uncomplicated: Quinine + clindamycin Ã— 7 days (avoid doxycycline), artemether-lumefantrine in 2nd/3rd trimester
    • Avoid primaquine (hemolysis risk to fetus if G6PD deficient)
    • Avoid atovaquone-proguanil (limited safety data)
  • Children:
    • Same drugs, dose by weight
    • Avoid doxycycline <8 years old (tooth staining)
    • Artemether-lumefantrine safe and effective

Disposition and Follow-Up:

  • Hospitalize: All severe malaria, pregnant women, young children, unable to tolerate oral medications, parasitemia >2%, unreliable for follow-up
  • Outpatient: Uncomplicated malaria in reliable patients, close follow-up (daily phone calls, recheck in 2-3 days)
  • Follow-Up Blood Smear: At day 7, 14, 28 to confirm cure and detect recrudescence/relapse

Prevention (Counseling for Future Travel):

  • Chemoprophylaxis: Atovaquone-proguanil (Malarone), doxycycline, or mefloquine starting before travel
  • Mosquito Avoidance: Insect repellent (DEET), long sleeves/pants, bed nets (permethrin-treated), avoid dusk/dawn outdoor exposure
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • P. falciparum = The Killer: Responsible for 90% of malaria deaths. Causes severe malaria (cerebral malaria, severe anemia, ARDS, renal failure, acidosis). Other species (P. vivax, ovale, malariae, knowlesi) rarely cause death. Always assume P. falciparum in sick patient until proven otherwise.
  • Classic Fever Paroxysms Are Often Absent: Textbook cyclic fevers (chills-fever-sweats every 48-72 hours) occur in minority of cases, usually only after several weeks. Early malaria typically has irregular fevers. DO NOT rule out malaria because fever isn't cyclic.
  • Thrombocytopenia + Fever + Travel = Think Malaria (and Dengue): Malaria causes thrombocytopenia in 80-90% of cases but rarely causes bleeding. If fever + low platelets + recent travel to tropics, malaria and dengue are top differentials. Blood smear distinguishes them.
  • Always Get THREE Sets of Blood Smears if Suspicion High: Parasitemia can be low or fluctuate. Single negative smear does NOT rule out malaria. Repeat every 12-24 hours for 3 sets (thick and thin) before excluding diagnosis. Sensitivity of single smear ~70%, three smears ~95%.
  • IV Artesunate Saves Lives (20-30% Mortality Reduction): For severe malaria, IV artesunate is superior to quinine/quinidine. Faster parasite clearance, fewer complications. Available through CDC Drug Service 24/7 (770-488-7788). If artesunate delayed, start quinidine as bridge but switch to artesunate when available.
  • Primaquine Is for Liver Stage (Relapse Prevention) Only: P. vivax and P. ovale form dormant hypnozoites in liver that cause relapses months to years later. Primaquine is the ONLY drug that eradicates liver-stage parasites. Must give after treating blood stage to prevent relapse. Check G6PD FIRST (primaquine causes severe hemolysis if G6PD deficient).
  • Cerebral Malaria = Altered Mental Status + Malaria, NOT Meningitis: Cerebral malaria is impaired consciousness (coma) from sequestration of infected RBCs in brain microvasculature, NOT from meningitis/encephalitis. LP is usually normal (do it to rule out co-infection, but don't expect pleocytosis). Treat the malaria, not the "meningitis."
  • Blackwater Fever = Massive Intravascular Hemolysis: Dark/black urine from hemoglobinuria due to massive RBC lysis (usually P. falciparum). Historically associated with quinine treatment, but can occur from malaria itself. Leads to acute renal failure. Aggressive hydration, transfusion, dialysis if needed.
  • Hypoglycemia Is Common and Deadly in Severe Malaria: Occurs from (1) parasite consuming glucose, (2) quinine-induced hyperinsulinemia, (3) impaired gluconeogenesis. Check glucose frequently, especially during quinine/quinidine treatment. Empiric dextrose infusion may be life-saving.
  • Malaria vs Dengue vs Typhoid = The "Tropical Fever Triad": All three present with fever, headache, myalgias after tropical travel. Key differentiators: Malaria (blood smear shows parasites, thrombocytopenia, rigors), Dengue (severe myalgias, rash, leukopenia, positive serology), Typhoid (relative bradycardia, rose spots, positive blood culture). When in doubt, test for all three.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • ALL severe malaria requires ICU admission
  • Cerebral malaria (altered mental status, seizures, coma)
  • Severe anemia (Hgb <7 g/dL)
  • Acute respiratory distress or pulmonary edema
  • Renal failure (Cr >3 mg/dL) or requiring dialysis
  • Hypoglycemia (<40 mg/dL) refractory or recurrent
  • Shock or metabolic acidosis (lactate >5 mmol/L)
  • Hyperparasitemia (>5% or >2% with organ dysfunction)
  • DIC or significant bleeding
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable, afebrile >48 hours
  • Parasitemia cleared or significantly reduced (<1%)
  • No signs of severe malaria (normal mental status, stable labs)
  • Tolerating oral antimalarial medication
  • Completed appropriate course of IV artesunate (if severe malaria) and transitioned to oral therapy
  • Hemoglobin stable (typically >7 g/dL)
  • Renal function stable or improving
  • Outpatient infectious disease follow-up arranged
  • Blood smear follow-up arranged (day 7, 14, 28 to confirm cure)
  • Patient educated on medication completion, return precautions for fever
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

99. MUSCULOSKELETAL CHEST PAIN

Costochondritis â€¢ Chest Wall Tenderness â€¢ Benign Cause
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Patient presenting with chest pain that is reproducible with palpation of the chest wall, positional, or exacerbated by movement. Pain is typically sharp, well-localized, and NOT associated with exertion, dyspnea, diaphoresis, or other cardiac symptoms. Most common cause of chest pain in young, otherwise healthy patients.

  • Characteristics of Musculoskeletal Chest Pain:
    • Sharp, stabbing, or aching quality (rarely pressure-like)
    • Well-localized (patient can point with one finger)
    • Reproduced by palpation of chest wall or specific movements
    • Worsened by deep breathing, coughing, arm movement, twisting
    • Positional (better or worse in certain positions)
    • Duration: Seconds to minutes (fleeting) or constant for days
    • NOT related to exertion (key differentiator from angina)
    • NO associated dyspnea, diaphoresis, nausea (unlike ACS)

Common Musculoskeletal Causes:

  • Costochondritis:
    • Inflammation of costal cartilage (rib-sternum junction)
    • Most commonly affects 2nd-5th ribs
    • Bilateral or unilateral chest pain
    • Exquisite tenderness to palpation over affected costochondral junctions
    • No swelling (vs Tietze syndrome which has visible swelling)
    • Etiology: Often idiopathic, sometimes post-viral illness, repetitive strain
  • Tietze Syndrome:
    • Similar to costochondritis but with visible swelling of costochondral junction
    • Typically affects single rib (2nd or 3rd most common)
    • Palpable, tender mass over costochondral junction
    • Less common than costochondritis, affects younger patients (20-40 years)
  • Intercostal Muscle Strain:
    • From overuse, vigorous coughing, trauma, heavy lifting, sudden twisting
    • Pain along rib cage, worsened by movement or deep breathing
    • Tenderness over affected intercostal muscles
    • May have bruising if traumatic
  • Rib Fracture:
    • From trauma, severe coughing (stress fracture), or osteoporosis
    • Severe, sharp pain worsened by breathing, coughing, movement
    • Point tenderness over fracture site
    • Palpable step-off or crepitus if displaced
    • Complications: Pneumothorax, hemothorax (if displaced), flail chest (if multiple adjacent ribs)
  • Sternoclavicular Joint Arthritis/Inflammation:
    • Pain at sternoclavicular junction (medial clavicle)
    • Tenderness, swelling over SC joint
    • Causes: Osteoarthritis, inflammatory arthritis (RA, psoriatic), infection (rare)
  • Precordial Catch Syndrome (Texidor's Twinge):
    • Sudden, sharp, fleeting chest pain (seconds to 3 minutes)
    • Left parasternal or apical region
    • Occurs at rest, worsened by deep breathing
    • Adolescents and young adults
    • Benign, self-limited (no treatment needed)
    • Etiology: Unknown, possibly intercostal muscle spasm
  • Xiphoidalgia (Xiphoid Process Syndrome):
    • Pain at xiphoid process (lower sternum)
    • Exquisite tenderness to palpation of xiphoid
    • Worsened by bending forward, eating large meals
    • Benign, often chronic/recurrent
  • Slipping Rib Syndrome:
    • Hypermobility of lower ribs (8-10) due to inadequate cartilage attachment
    • Sharp pain in lower chest/upper abdomen
    • "Hooking maneuver" reproduces pain (examiner hooks fingers under costal margin and pulls anteriorly)
    • Clicking or popping sensation
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Critical Principle: Must Rule Out Life-Threatening Causes FIRST

  • Musculoskeletal chest pain is a diagnosis of exclusion in the ED
  • ALWAYS consider and rule out: ACS, PE, aortic dissection, pneumothorax, pericarditis, esophageal rupture
  • Young, healthy patient with classic musculoskeletal features + normal ECG â†’ low probability of cardiac cause
  • Older patient or cardiac risk factors â†’ must rule out cardiac cause despite musculoskeletal features

History (Key Questions):

  • Reproducibility: "Can you push on your chest and make the pain worse?" (If yes, favors musculoskeletal)
  • Exertional: "Does the pain occur with walking, climbing stairs, or exertion?" (If yes, consider cardiac)
  • Radiation: Pain radiating to jaw, left arm, back (concerning for cardiac)
  • Associated Symptoms: Dyspnea, diaphoresis, nausea/vomiting (concerning for cardiac)
  • Triggers: Movement, position, breathing (favors musculoskeletal); exertion, stress (favors cardiac)
  • Recent Activity: Heavy lifting, new exercise routine, trauma, prolonged coughing

Physical Examination:

  • Vital Signs: Normal HR, BP, RR, SpO2 (tachycardia, hypotension, hypoxia suggest serious pathology)
  • Chest Wall Palpation:
    • Systematically palpate sternum, ribs, costochondral junctions, intercostal spaces
    • Reproduce patient's pain with palpation (highly specific for musculoskeletal cause)
    • Note location, swelling, deformity, crepitus
  • Range of Motion: Ask patient to twist, reach overhead, bend forward (worsens musculoskeletal pain)
  • Cardiac Exam: Normal S1/S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops
  • Lung Exam: Clear breath sounds bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, decreased breath sounds (rule out pneumonia, pneumothorax)

Electrocardiogram (ECG):

  • Indications: All patients >30 years, cardiac risk factors, atypical features, cannot definitively rule out ACS clinically
  • Expected Findings in Musculoskeletal Pain: Normal sinus rhythm, no ST-T changes, no Q waves
