  • Abnormal ECG: ST elevation/depression, T-wave inversions, new Q waves â†’ pursue cardiac workup (troponin, cardiology consult)

Laboratory Studies (Selective, Based on Suspicion):

  • Troponin: NOT routinely needed for classic musculoskeletal pain in young, low-risk patients with normal ECG
  • Indications for Troponin:
    • Age >40 with cardiac risk factors (HTN, DM, smoking, family history)
    • Exertional component to pain
    • Any concern for ACS
    • Abnormal ECG
  • D-dimer: If concern for PE (dyspnea, tachycardia, hypoxia, risk factors)
  • CBC: If fever, concern for infection

Imaging:

  • Chest X-ray:
    • Indications: Trauma, concern for rib fracture, pneumothorax, or if pulmonary symptoms (cough, dyspnea)
    • Findings in musculoskeletal pain: Typically normal
    • May show rib fracture (but X-ray misses 50% of rib fractures)
    • NOT routinely needed for classic costochondritis
  • CT Chest: If concern for PE, aortic dissection, or to better characterize rib fractures/chest wall pathology
  • Ultrasound: Can identify rib fractures (more sensitive than X-ray), assess for pneumothorax at bedside (FAST exam)

Decision Tools:

  • HEART Score (for Chest Pain Risk Stratification):
    • History, ECG, Age, Risk factors, Troponin
    • Score 0-3: Low risk (<2% MACE), consider discharge
    • Score 4-6: Moderate risk, admit for observation
    • Score â‰¥7: High risk, admit for aggressive workup
  • Reproducible Chest Pain + Normal ECG in Low-Risk Patient: Very low likelihood of ACS (<1%), can safely discharge without troponin in select cases
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Management of Musculoskeletal Chest Pain:

  • Reassurance:
    • Explain that pain is from chest wall, NOT heart or lungs
    • Emphasize benign nature (not life-threatening)
    • Discuss expected course (may last days to weeks, gradual improvement)
  • Analgesia (First-Line):
    • NSAIDs: Ibuprofen 400-600 mg PO TID or naproxen 500 mg PO BID (most effective due to anti-inflammatory properties)
    • Acetaminophen: 650-1000 mg PO q6h (if NSAIDs contraindicated)
    • Typically 7-14 days course, then as needed
  • Topical Agents:
    • Lidocaine patches or diclofenac gel (Voltaren) applied to affected area
    • Heat or ice packs (whichever provides relief)
  • Activity Modification:
    • Avoid aggravating activities (heavy lifting, strenuous exercise) temporarily
    • Gentle stretching and range of motion exercises
    • Gradual return to normal activity as pain improves

Specific Treatments by Diagnosis:

  • Costochondritis / Tietze Syndrome:
    • NSAIDs Ã— 2-4 weeks
    • Reassurance (self-limited, typically resolves in weeks to months)
    • If refractory: Local corticosteroid injection (triamcinolone 40 mg + lidocaine into costochondral junction) by outpatient provider
  • Intercostal Muscle Strain:
    • NSAIDs, ice/heat, rest
    • Physical therapy if prolonged symptoms
  • Rib Fracture:
    • Analgesia (Critical): Adequate pain control to prevent respiratory complications (atelectasis, pneumonia)
      • NSAIDs + acetaminophen scheduled (around-the-clock)
      • Opioids (oxycodone 5-10 mg q4-6h) if severe pain uncontrolled by NSAIDs
      • Consider intercostal nerve block (bupivacaine injection) for severe pain
    • Incentive Spirometry: Use every hour while awake to prevent atelectasis (pain â†’ shallow breathing â†’ atelectasis â†’ pneumonia)
    • Rib Belt: NOT recommended (restricts breathing, increases pneumonia risk)
    • Admission Indications:
      • Elderly (>65 years) or comorbidities (COPD, heart failure)
      • Multiple rib fractures (â‰¥3) or flail chest
      • Associated injuries (pneumothorax, hemothorax, pulmonary contusion)
      • Inadequate pain control or hypoxia
    • Discharge: Young, healthy patients with 1-2 simple rib fractures, adequate pain control, normal oxygen saturation
  • Precordial Catch Syndrome:
    • Reassurance only (benign, self-limited)
    • No treatment needed (pain lasts seconds to minutes)
    • Explain recurrence is common but harmless
  • Slipping Rib Syndrome:
    • Conservative: NSAIDs, activity modification
    • If refractory: Intercostal nerve block or surgical resection of hypermobile rib (rare)

Disposition:

  • Discharge (Most Musculoskeletal Chest Pain):
    • Diagnosis: Musculoskeletal chest pain (costochondritis, muscle strain, etc.)
    • Medications: NSAIDs, acetaminophen as above
    • Follow-up: Primary care in 1-2 weeks if symptoms not improving
    • Return Precautions: Worsening pain, dyspnea, fever, exertional chest pain, syncope â†’ return to ED immediately
  • Admit: Rib fractures in high-risk patients (see above), inability to rule out cardiac cause, persistent pain with concerning features

Follow-Up Management:

  • Primary Care: 1-2 weeks if symptoms persist or worsen
  • Physical Therapy: For chronic or recurrent musculoskeletal pain (posture correction, strengthening, stretching)
  • Rheumatology: If suspicion for inflammatory arthritis (RA, ankylosing spondylitis) affecting costochondral joints
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Musculoskeletal Chest Pain Is the Most Common Cause in Young Patients: In patients <40 without cardiac risk factors, musculoskeletal pain accounts for 30-50% of ED chest pain presentations. Cardiac causes are rare (<5%) in this population, but must still be ruled out.
  • Reproducible Tenderness = Very Unlikely to Be Cardiac: If you can reproduce the patient's exact chest pain by palpating the chest wall, likelihood of ACS is <1-2%. This is a powerful clinical finding. However, reproducibility does NOT rule out serious causes (PE, pneumothorax still possible), so use clinical judgment.
  • Costochondritis vs Tietze Syndrome: Both cause chest wall pain and tenderness at costochondral junctions. Key difference: Tietze has visible/palpable swelling of the junction (true inflammation), while costochondritis has tenderness without swelling. Tietze is less common, affects younger patients, and typically involves only one rib (usually 2nd).
  • NSAIDs Are More Effective Than Acetaminophen: Costochondritis and other musculoskeletal pain respond better to NSAIDs (anti-inflammatory) than acetaminophen alone. Scheduled NSAIDs (not PRN) for 7-14 days provide best relief. Reserve acetaminophen for patients with NSAID contraindications (renal disease, bleeding risk, NSAID allergy).
  • Rib Fractures Can Cause Significant Morbidity: Pain from rib fractures causes splinting (shallow breathing) â†’ atelectasis â†’ pneumonia, especially in elderly. Adequate analgesia (NSAIDs + opioids if needed) and incentive spirometry are critical to prevent respiratory complications. Don't undertreated rib fracture pain.
  • X-ray Misses 50% of Rib Fractures: Plain chest X-rays have low sensitivity for rib fractures (especially non-displaced). If high suspicion but X-ray negative, consider ultrasound (more sensitive) or treat empirically. CT is gold standard but usually not necessary for clinical management.
  • Precordial Catch Syndrome = Texidor's Twinge: Sudden, sharp, fleeting chest pain lasting seconds to 3 minutes in adolescents/young adults. Left parasternal, worse with deep breathing, occurs at rest. Benign and self-limited. Just reassureâ€”no workup or treatment needed. Named after Miller and Texidor who first described it in 1955.
  • Slipping Rib Syndrome = "Hooking Maneuver": To diagnose, hook your fingers under the patient's lower costal margin (ribs 8-10) and pull anteriorly. If this reproduces pain and/or clicking sensation, positive test for slipping rib syndrome (hypermobile ribs). Conservative management usually effective.
  • Red Flags That Should Prompt Cardiac Workup: Age >40, exertional pain, radiation to jaw/arm, diaphoresis, dyspnea, cardiac risk factors (HTN, DM, smoking, family history), abnormal vital signs, abnormal ECG. Even if musculoskeletal features present, these require troponin and further evaluation.
  • Musculoskeletal Pain Can Coexist with Serious Pathology: Just because you can reproduce pain with palpation doesn't mean the patient can't also have PE, pneumothorax, or pneumonia. Use clinical gestalt. If patient looks sick, has dyspnea, hypoxia, or other concerning features, pursue appropriate workup even with chest wall tenderness.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Musculoskeletal chest pain does NOT require ICU admission
  • If ICU admission needed, it is for non-musculoskeletal etiology (MI, PE, dissection) that was initially missed
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Cardiac causes definitively excluded (normal ECG, negative troponin if obtained)
  • Pain controlled on oral NSAIDs/acetaminophen
  • Able to tolerate oral intake
  • If rib fracture: adequate pain control, normal oxygen saturation, incentive spirometry demonstrated
  • Patient educated on analgesic use, activity modification
  • Follow-up with primary care arranged if symptoms not improving in 1-2 weeks
  • Return precautions explained (worsening pain, dyspnea, fever, exertional chest pain)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

100. DIABETES INSIPIDUS

Polyuria â€¢ Polydipsia â€¢ Hypernatremia â€¢ Dilute Urine
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Sudden onset of profound polyuria (>3 L/day, often 10-15 L/day) with intense thirst, preference for ice-cold water, and hypernatremia with inappropriately dilute urine (urine osmolality <300 mOsm/kg despite serum osmolality >300 mOsm/kg).

  • Pathophysiology: Central DI results from inadequate ADH (vasopressin) secretion from posterior pituitary due to hypothalamic/pituitary damage. Nephrogenic DI results from renal resistance to ADH at the collecting duct level (aquaporin-2 dysfunction). Both lead to inability to concentrate urine and free water loss.
  • Risk Factors: Neurosurgery (especially transsphenoidal), traumatic brain injury, pituitary/hypothalamic tumors (craniopharyngioma, germinoma), infiltrative diseases (sarcoidosis, histiocytosis X, lymphoma), hypoxic brain injury, medications (lithium, demeclocycline, amphotericin, foscarnet), hypercalcemia, hypokalemia, pregnancy (vasopressinase), genetic (X-linked nephrogenic DI, autosomal AVPR2/AQP2 mutations)
  • Symptoms: Polyuria (large volume, dilute urine), intense thirst and polydipsia, nocturia (3-6 times/night), preference for ice-cold water, irritability, fatigue, confusion (if unable to maintain adequate intake), dehydration signs if fluid intake inadequate
  • Physical Exam: May appear normal if maintaining adequate oral intake. With inadequate intake: tachycardia, orthostatic hypotension, poor skin turgor, dry mucous membranes, altered mental status. Weight loss. Check for visual field defects (pituitary mass), signs of panhypopituitarism
  • Variants/Subtypes: Central DI (ADH deficiency) vs Nephrogenic DI (ADH resistance) vs Primary Polydipsia (psychogenic, compulsive water drinking). Triphasic response post-neurosurgery: initial DI (1-2 days), SIADH phase (days 3-10), permanent DI (>10 days). Partial DI (some residual ADH function)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Studies:

  • Serum Sodium: Often elevated (>145 mEq/L, can be >160 mEq/L); may be normal if patient maintaining adequate intake
  • Serum Osmolality: Elevated (>300 mOsm/kg, normal 275-295); primary finding
  • Urine Osmolality: Inappropriately low (<300 mOsm/kg, often <100 mOsm/kg) despite elevated serum osmolality. Urine specific gravity <1.005
  • Urine Output: Typically >3 L/day (can be 10-20 L/day in severe cases); hourly output >200-300 mL/hr
  • 24-Hour Urine Volume: Confirms polyuria; simultaneous osmolality measurement
  • Plasma ADH Level: Low/undetectable in central DI, elevated in nephrogenic DI (but test often unavailable acutely)
  • Other: BUN, creatinine, glucose (rule out hyperglycemia/DKA), calcium (hypercalcemia causes nephrogenic DI), potassium (hypokalemia causes nephrogenic DI)

Diagnostic Testing:

  • Water Deprivation Test: Gold standard for diagnosis (requires close monitoring). Withhold fluids, measure hourly urine volume, osmolality, and serum osmolality. DI: urine osmolality remains <300 mOsm/kg despite rising serum osmolality >300 mOsm/kg. Then give desmopressin (DDAVP): Central DI shows >50% increase in urine osmolality; Nephrogenic DI shows <50% increase; Primary polydipsia shows already-concentrated urine before DDAVP
  • DDAVP Challenge Test: Can be done acutely in suspected DI with hypernatremia. Give desmopressin 2-4 mcg IV/SC, measure urine osmolality at 2 and 4 hours. Central DI: urine osmolality increases >600 mOsm/kg; Nephrogenic DI: minimal response
  • Copeptin Level: Emerging biomarker (stable ADH surrogate); low in central DI, elevated in nephrogenic DI

Imaging:

  • MRI Brain with Pituitary Protocol: Essential in central DI. Look for: loss of normal posterior pituitary "bright spot" on T1 (absent in central DI, present in nephrogenic DI and normal), hypothalamic/pituitary masses, infiltrative diseases, evidence of trauma/surgery, ectopic posterior pituitary. Evaluate entire pituitary stalk and hypothalamus
  • CT Head: If MRI contraindicated; less sensitive but can identify masses, hemorrhage, calcifications

Diagnostic Criteria:

  • DI Diagnosis: Polyuria (>3 L/24hr or >40-50 mL/kg/24hr) + dilute urine (osmolality <300 mOsm/kg) + serum hyperosmolality (>300 mOsm/kg) or hypernatremia (>145 mEq/L)
  • Distinguish Central vs Nephrogenic: DDAVP response (>50% increase in urine osmolality = central; <50% = nephrogenic)
  • Rule Out: Primary polydipsia (low serum osmolality), osmotic diuresis (glucose, urea, mannitol), post-obstructive diuresis
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Management:

  • Assess volume status and hemodynamics; establish IV access
  • Strict I&O monitoring (hourly urine output initially, may need Foley catheter)
  • Measure serum sodium, osmolality, urine osmolality STAT
  • Calculate free water deficit: Free water deficit (L) = 0.6 Ã— body weight (kg) Ã— [(current Na/140) - 1]
  • Allow oral free water intake if patient alert and able to drink (preferred)
  • If hypernatremic with altered mental status or unable to drink: give hypotonic fluids IV (0.45% saline or D5W)
  • CORRECT SODIUM SLOWLY: maximum 10-12 mEq/L per 24 hours to avoid cerebral edema (osmotic demyelination in reverse)

Pharmacologic Treatment (Central DI):

  • Desmopressin (DDAVP) - First Line:
    • IV/SC: 1-4 mcg IV/SC q12-24h (acute); start 1-2 mcg, titrate based on response
    • Intranasal: 10-20 mcg (0.1-0.2 mL) once or twice daily
    • PO: 0.1-0.2 mg PO BID-TID (range 0.1-1.2 mg/day divided); start low, titrate up
    • Monitor sodium closely; risk of hyponatremia with overtreatment
  • Caution: In triphasic response post-neurosurgery, hold DDAVP during SIADH phase (days 3-10) to avoid severe hyponatremia

Pharmacologic Treatment (Nephrogenic DI):

  • Thiazide Diuretics: Hydrochlorothiazide 25-50 mg PO daily. Causes mild volume depletion, increasing proximal tubule reabsorption, paradoxically reducing distal delivery and urine output by 30-50%
  • Amiloride: 5-10 mg PO BID, particularly for lithium-induced nephrogenic DI (blocks lithium entry into collecting duct cells)
  • NSAIDs: Indomethacin 50 mg PO TID, reduces GFR and increases ADH effect; use cautiously (GI/renal toxicity)
  • Low Sodium Diet: <2 g/day reduces urine output by decreasing solute excretion
  • Treat Underlying Cause: Discontinue lithium if possible, correct hypercalcemia, correct hypokalemia

Fluid Management:

  • Match urine output with free water replacement (PO preferred if possible)
  • If IV fluids needed: D5W or 0.45% saline at rate matched to urine output losses
  • Avoid rapid sodium correction (max 10-12 mEq/L per 24 hours)
  • Check serum sodium q4-6h initially, then q12h once stable
  • Daily weights to assess fluid balance

Endocrinology Consultation:

  • Consult for all cases of confirmed or suspected DI
  • Assess for panhypopituitarism (check TSH, free T4, cortisol, LH, FSH, testosterone/estradiol, IGF-1)
  • Central DI + anterior pituitary dysfunction suggests pituitary/hypothalamic disease
  • Long-term management planning and DDAVP dosing adjustment

Disposition:

  • ICU if: severe hypernatremia (>160 mEq/L), altered mental status, hemodynamic instability, post-neurosurgical patients, unable to maintain oral intake
  • Floor with telemetry: moderate hypernatremia (148-160 mEq/L), new diagnosis requiring DDAVP titration, stable patients transitioning to oral therapy
  • Discharge once: sodium normalized or stable (140-145 mEq/L), adequate oral intake maintained, DDAVP regimen established, endocrine follow-up arranged within 1-2 weeks
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Triphasic Response Post-Neurosurgery: Classic pattern after transsphenoidal surgery: (1) Initial DI (hours to 2 days) from surgical trauma/edema, (2) SIADH phase (days 3-10) from release of stored ADH from dying neurons, (3) Permanent DI (>10 days) if >80% of neurons destroyed. Must stop DDAVP during SIADH phase to avoid severe hyponatremia. About 30% develop permanent DI.
  • Loss of Posterior Pituitary Bright Spot: Normal posterior pituitary appears bright on T1 MRI (ADH-containing vesicles). In central DI, this "bright spot" is absent. In nephrogenic DI, it's present (ADH production intact). This finding is 80% sensitive for central DI. Also look for ectopic bright spot along pituitary stalk (ectopic neurohypophysis).
  • Central DI + Anterior Pituitary Dysfunction = Think Infiltrative Disease: Isolated central DI can be idiopathic or post-surgical. But if patient also has hypopituitarism (low TSH, ACTH, GH, gonadotropins), think infiltrative process: histiocytosis X (most common in children), sarcoidosis, lymphoma, metastases (especially breast, lung). Requires extensive pituitary imaging and sometimes biopsy.
  • Distinguish from Primary Polydipsia: Both cause polyuria and dilute urine, but primary polydipsia has LOW serum osmolality (<280 mOsm/kg) and LOW sodium (<138 mEq/L) from water overload. DI has HIGH serum osmolality (>300) and HIGH sodium (>145). Water deprivation test: polydipsia patients concentrate urine normally once water restricted.
  • Lithium-Induced Nephrogenic DI is Common and Often Irreversible: Occurs in 20-40% of patients on chronic lithium therapy. Lithium enters collecting duct principal cells via ENaC channels, accumulates, and downregulates aquaporin-2. Treat with amiloride (blocks ENaC, prevents lithium entry) 5-10 mg BID plus thiazide. Stopping lithium may improve but not fully resolve DI if damage is extensive (>10 years exposure).
  • Don't Overcorrect Hypernatremia Too Rapidly: Rapid sodium correction in DI can cause cerebral edema (reverse osmotic demyelination). The brain adapts to chronic hypernatremia by accumulating organic osmolytes. Rapid lowering of serum osmolality causes water shift into brain cells. Maximum correction rate: 10-12 mEq/L per 24 hours (0.5 mEq/L per hour). In chronic severe hypernatremia, consider 6-8 mEq/L per 24 hours.
  • Hypovolemic Patients May Not Show Severe Polyuria Initially: If patient is volume-depleted on presentation, reduced GFR may mask the full extent of polyuria. After IV fluid resuscitation, urine output may suddenly increase dramatically to 500-1000 mL/hour as GFR improves and the DI becomes clinically apparent. Anticipate this and have DDAVP ready.
  • Intranasal DDAVP Can Be Unreliable: Intranasal desmopressin absorption varies with nasal congestion, rhinitis, or upper respiratory infections. If patient not responding to intranasal DDAVP, switch to oral or SC route. Oral bioavailability is only 5-10% (vs 10-20% intranasal), so oral dose is 10-20 times higher than intranasal dose.
  • Risk of Hyponatremia with DDAVP Overtreatment: DDAVP has long half-life (8-12 hours for IV, 12-24 hours for oral). Giving too much or too frequently without allowing kidney to excrete free water causes dilutional hyponatremia. Monitor sodium q6-12h during dose titration. If Na drops below 135 mEq/L, hold next dose and allow natural diuresis to occur.
  • Nephrogenic DI from Hypercalcemia or Hypokalemia: Hypercalcemia (>11 mg/dL) causes nephrogenic DI by impairing collecting duct response to ADH and causing interstitial nephropathy. Hypokalemia (<3.0 mEq/L) downregulates aquaporin-2. Always check and correct calcium and potassium in patients with polyuria. Correcting the electrolyte abnormality often resolves the DI without need for specific DI treatment.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Severe hypernatremia (serum sodium >160 mEq/L)
  • Altered mental status, confusion, seizures
  • Hemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachycardia unresponsive to fluids)
  • Post-neurosurgical patient (especially within 10 days of transphenoidal surgery)
  • Urine output >500 mL/hour despite treatment
  • Unable to maintain adequate oral intake despite thirst
  • Rapid sodium changes requiring frequent monitoring and IV fluid adjustments
  • Suspected panhypopituitarism with adrenal crisis
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Serum sodium normalized (138-145 mEq/L) or stable near-normal range
  • Urine output controlled (<3 L/day) on DDAVP regimen
  • Patient able to maintain adequate oral fluid intake (matching urine losses)
  • Patient and family educated on DDAVP administration (timing, dose, route)
  • Patient educated on monitoring for signs of overtreatment (hyponatremia: headache, nausea, confusion)
  • Patient educated on monitoring for signs of undertreatment (recurrent polyuria, thirst)
  • Endocrinology follow-up arranged within 1-2 weeks for DDAVP titration
  • MRI brain completed (if central DI) or scheduled as outpatient
  • If post-neurosurgical: cleared by neurosurgery, aware of triphasic response potential
  • Written instructions including when to call doctor (urine output >4 L/day, severe thirst, confusion, headache)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

101. PHEOCHROMOCYTOMA CRISIS

Hypertensive Emergency â€¢ Catecholamine Excess â€¢ Palpitations â€¢ Diaphoresis
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Paroxysmal or sustained severe hypertension (BP often >220/120 mmHg) with episodic triad of severe headache, profuse diaphoresis, and palpitations, often triggered by anesthesia, surgery, medications (metoclopramide, opioids), or tumor manipulation.

  • Pathophysiology: Catecholamine-secreting tumor of chromaffin cells (90% adrenal medulla, 10% extra-adrenal paragangliomas). Excessive release of epinephrine, norepinephrine, and/or dopamine causes severe hypertension, tachycardia, and hypermetabolic state. Crisis can be triggered by direct tumor stimulation (palpation, surgery, biopsy), medications, or spontaneous massive catecholamine release. Can cause catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy (Takotsubo-like), cerebrovascular events, or multiorgan failure.
  • Risk Factors: Genetic syndromes: MEN 2A/2B (RET mutation), VHL syndrome (VHL gene), NF1 (neurofibromatosis type 1), familial paraganglioma syndromes (SDH gene mutations). About 40% of pheochromocytomas are hereditary. Known adrenal mass. Family history of pheochromocytoma or paraganglioma. History of refractory hypertension
  • Symptoms - Classic Triad (present in 50%): (1) Severe, pounding, occipital headache, (2) Profuse diaphoresis (soaking through clothes), (3) Palpitations or chest tightness. Other symptoms: Anxiety, sense of impending doom, pallor, tremor, nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain, chest pain (angina from coronary vasospasm), dyspnea. Episodes last minutes to hours, can occur multiple times daily or weekly
  • Physical Exam: Severe hypertension (often >220/120 mmHg, can be >300/150 mmHg in crisis), wide pulse pressure, tachycardia (HR 100-140), orthostatic hypotension (paradoxical - volume depletion from pressure natriuresis), pallor or flushing, diaphoresis, tremor, fever, retinopathy on fundoscopy (hypertensive changes), abdominal mass (if large tumor), cafÃ©-au-lait spots (NF1), thyroid nodules (MEN 2)
  • Variants/Subtypes: Pheochromocytoma (adrenal) vs Paraganglioma (extra-adrenal: bladder, organ of Zuckerkandl, thorax). Benign vs malignant (10% are malignant - metastases to bone, liver, lung, lymph nodes). Predominantly norepinephrine-secreting (sustained hypertension) vs epinephrine-secreting (paroxysmal hypertension with hypotension between episodes). Dopamine-secreting (rare, often malignant, may have normal BP)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Studies - Biochemical Testing (Definitive Diagnosis):

  • Plasma Free Metanephrines: MOST SENSITIVE TEST (96-99% sensitivity). Measure plasma-free metanephrine and normetanephrine. Normal <0.5 nmol/L; >4 times upper limit of normal (ULN) is diagnostic. Draw with patient supine for 20 minutes. Nearly 100% negative predictive value - normal level rules out pheo
  • 24-Hour Urine Fractionated Metanephrines and Catecholamines: Measure metanephrine, normetanephrine, epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine. >2 times ULN strongly suggests pheo. More specific than plasma testing but less sensitive. Interfering substances: acetaminophen, MAO inhibitors, tricyclic antidepressants
  • Plasma Catecholamines: Norepinephrine >2000 pg/mL highly suggestive. Less sensitive than metanephrines. Must be drawn during symptomatic episode for best yield
  • Chromogranin A: Elevated in most neuroendocrine tumors; non-specific but supports diagnosis. False elevation with PPI use
  • Supporting Labs: Hyperglycemia (catecholamine-induced insulin resistance), hypokalemia (increased renin), elevated hematocrit (volume contraction), leukocytosis, elevated calcium (MEN 2A with hyperparathyroidism)

Imaging - Tumor Localization:

  • CT Abdomen/Pelvis with Contrast: First-line anatomic imaging. Pheochromocytomas appear as heterogeneous, enhancing adrenal masses 3-10 cm, often with areas of necrosis/hemorrhage. Measure Hounsfield units: typically >10 HU (distinguish from adenoma). Sensitivity 90-95% for adrenal tumors. Caution: IV contrast can precipitate crisis (ensure alpha blockade first)
  • MRI Abdomen: Preferred if CT contraindicated or in pregnancy. Characteristic "lightbulb" bright appearance on T2-weighted images (sensitivity 90-100%). Better for extra-adrenal paragangliomas and metastatic disease. No contrast-induced crisis risk
  • Functional Imaging (if biochemically positive but CT/MRI negative):
    • I-123 MIBG Scan: Metaiodobenzylguanidine scintigraphy. Taken up by chromaffin cells. Sensitivity 80-90%, specificity 95-100%. Best for detecting metastatic disease and extra-adrenal paragangliomas
    • FDG-PET: High sensitivity for malignant pheo and paragangliomas (especially SDH mutations)
    • Ga-68 DOTATATE PET: Emerging modality with high sensitivity for SDH-mutated tumors

Cardiac Evaluation:

  • ECG: Sinus tachycardia, LVH, ST-T wave changes, QT prolongation, rarely MI pattern
  • Echocardiogram: Assess for catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy (Takotsubo pattern with apical ballooning), LVH, systolic/diastolic dysfunction, valvular disease. Important for preoperative risk stratification
  • Troponin: May be elevated (myocardial strain, type 2 MI from demand ischemia)

Genetic Testing:

  • Recommended for all patients with pheochromocytoma/paraganglioma (40% have germline mutations)
  • Test for: RET (MEN 2), VHL, NF1, SDHB, SDHD, TMEM127, MAX genes
  • Genetic counseling referral for positive results
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Management (Acute Crisis):

  • Transfer to ICU immediately; continuous cardiac monitoring and arterial line
  • IV access (two large-bore IVs); avoid palpating abdomen (can trigger catecholamine release)
  • ECG, cardiac enzymes, strict I&O
  • Goal BP: <160/100 mmHg acutely, then gradual reduction to <140/90 mmHg
  • NEVER give beta-blockers before alpha blockade (can cause unopposed alpha vasoconstriction and hypertensive crisis)

Pharmacologic Treatment - Acute Hypertensive Crisis:

  • Phentolamine (Alpha-Blocker) - FIRST LINE for acute crisis:
    • Give 5-10 mg IV bolus, repeat q5-15min as needed
    • Or infusion: 0.5-1 mg/min IV, titrate to BP goal
    • Non-selective alpha-1 and alpha-2 antagonist, rapid onset (1-2 min), short duration (10-15 min)
  • Nicardipine (CCB) - Alternative or Adjunct:
    • Start 5 mg/hr IV infusion, titrate by 2.5 mg/hr q5-15min (max 15 mg/hr)
    • Good for BP control without reflex tachycardia
  • Sodium Nitroprusside:
    • 0.5-10 mcg/kg/min IV infusion, titrate to BP goal
    • Effective but short-acting, requires close monitoring, cyanide toxicity risk if prolonged use
  • After Alpha Blockade, Add Beta-Blocker ONLY if tachycardia (HR >110):
    • Esmolol 50-200 mcg/kg/min IV infusion (short-acting, easily titratable)
    • Or labetalol 10-20 mg IV bolus q10min (but has alpha:beta ratio of 1:7, less ideal)
  • Volume Resuscitation: IV crystalloids 1-2 L bolus. Patients are often volume-depleted from chronic pressure natriuresis despite elevated BP

Preoperative Medical Preparation (Once Diagnosis Confirmed):

  • Phenoxybenzamine (Non-Selective Alpha Blocker) - Gold Standard:
    • Start 10 mg PO BID, increase by 10-20 mg/day every 2-3 days
    • Target dose: 1 mg/kg/day divided BID-TID (typical 40-100 mg/day)
    • Goal: BP <140/90 mmHg with orthostatic hypotension (SBP drop >20 mmHg on standing)
    • Duration: Minimum 10-14 days before surgery
    • Long-acting (24-48 hrs), irreversible alpha blockade
  • Doxazosin or Prazosin (Selective Alpha-1 Blockers) - Alternative:
    • Doxazosin: Start 2 mg PO daily, titrate up to 16-32 mg daily
    • Shorter-acting, fewer side effects, but may be less effective for crisis prevention
  • Beta-Blocker (Add AFTER adequate alpha blockade):
    • Atenolol 25-50 mg PO daily or Metoprolol 25-50 mg PO BID
    • For persistent tachycardia (HR >90) or arrhythmias
  • CCB (If additional BP control needed):
    • Amlodipine 5-10 mg PO daily or Nifedipine XL 30-90 mg daily
  • High-Salt Diet: Encourage salt intake to expand intravascular volume

Definitive Treatment - Surgical Resection:

  • Laparoscopic adrenalectomy is treatment of choice for pheochromocytoma
  • Open surgery if large tumor (>6 cm), malignant, or extra-adrenal paraganglioma
  • Timing: Delay surgery until adequate preoperative alpha/beta blockade (10-14 days minimum)
  • Perioperative management: Continue alpha-blocker until morning of surgery, have phentolamine available intraoperatively, anticipate hypotension post-tumor removal (loss of catecholamines), IV fluids 2-3 L perioperatively

Consultations:

  • Endocrinology: Immediate consult for diagnosis confirmation, biochemical testing, preoperative optimization
  • Surgery (Endocrine Surgery): For definitive resection planning
  • Anesthesiology: Early involvement for perioperative planning (high-risk surgery)
  • Cardiology: If cardiomyopathy, severe arrhythmias, or CAD
  • Genetics: For germline mutation testing and family counseling

Disposition:

  • ICU: All patients in hypertensive crisis, catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy, or perioperative period
  • Floor with telemetry: Stable patients undergoing preoperative alpha/beta blockade titration
  • Discharge: Only after successful tumor resection, postoperative recovery, stable BP off pressors, and confirmed biochemical cure (plasma metanephrines normalized 2-6 weeks post-op)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Never Beta-Block Before Alpha-Blockade ("Rule of Alpha First"): Giving beta-blocker first causes unopposed alpha-receptor stimulation (vasoconstriction), precipitating severe hypertensive crisis, potentially fatal. Always establish alpha blockade first, then add beta-blocker only if needed for tachycardia. Think: "A before B in the alphabet, alpha before beta in pheo."
  • The Classic Triad is Only 50% Sensitive: Headache + diaphoresis + palpitations occur together in only half of cases. Many patients present with isolated sustained hypertension without paroxysms. High index of suspicion needed: young patient with severe refractory hypertension, hypertension with orthostatic hypotension (paradoxical), hypertension triggered by anesthesia/surgery. The "rule of 10s": 10% extra-adrenal, 10% bilateral, 10% malignant, 10% in children, 10% familial (actually now 40%).
  • Plasma Free Metanephrines Have Near-Perfect Negative Predictive Value: Normal plasma-free metanephrines essentially rule out pheochromocytoma (NPV >99%). If high clinical suspicion but negative test, repeat testing after 6 months. Metanephrines (breakdown products of catecholamines) are continuously produced by tumor, whereas catecholamines are released episodically, making metanephrines more reliable screening test than catecholamines.
  • 40% Are Hereditary - All Patients Need Genetic Testing: Previously thought rare, but germline mutations found in 40% of pheochromocytomas/paragangliomas. Most common: RET (MEN 2A/2B: medullary thyroid cancer + pheo + hyperparathyroidism), VHL (VHL syndrome: CNS/retinal hemangioblastomas + RCC + pheo), NF1 (cafÃ©-au-lait spots + neurofibromas), SDH mutations (familial paraganglioma). Genetic testing guides surveillance for syndromic features and family screening.
  • Orthostatic Hypotension in Hypertensive Patient is a Red Flag: Paradoxical finding: severe hypertension when supine but orthostatic drop >20 mmHg when standing. Caused by chronic catecholamine-induced pressure natriuresis leading to volume depletion and downregulated baroreceptor reflexes. If you see this combination (hypertension + orthostatic hypotension), think pheo until proven otherwise.
  • Perioperative Management is High-Risk: Tumor manipulation during surgery causes massive catecholamine release, risking hypertensive crisis, arrhythmias, MI, stroke. After tumor removal, BP can crash (loss of catecholamine drive, residual alpha blockade). Requires experienced anesthesia team with arterial line, have phentolamine boluses ready for intraoperative spikes, and anticipate need for 2-3 L IV fluids and possible pressors (norepinephrine) post-resection.
  • Phenoxybenzamine Causes Orthostatic Hypotension - That's the Goal: When titrating preoperative alpha blockade with phenoxybenzamine, target is not just BP <140/90 but achieving orthostatic hypotension (SBP drop >20 mmHg on standing). This indicates adequate alpha blockade and volume expansion has occurred. Patients need to increase salt/fluid intake during this period. Orthostasis confirms readiness for surgery.
  • Labetalol is NOT Ideal for Pheo Crisis: Despite being an alpha/beta blocker, labetalol has 1:7 alpha:beta ratio (much more beta blockade). In pheo crisis, this can worsen hypertension via unopposed alpha stimulation. Prefer pure alpha-blockers (phentolamine) followed by pure beta-blockers (esmolol) if needed. Labetalol can be used once adequate alpha blockade established, but not first-line.
  • Catecholamine-Induced Cardiomyopathy Can Mimic MI: Takotsubo (stress) cardiomyopathy pattern: apical ballooning, ST elevations, troponin elevation, but normal coronary arteries on angiography. Caused by catecholamine myocardial toxicity. Can also see true type 2 MI from demand ischemia. Echo shows wall motion abnormalities that typically resolve after tumor resection. Cardiac MRI can help distinguish from acute MI.
  • Lifelong Surveillance Required After "Cure": Even after complete tumor resection and biochemical cure, 5-15% recurrence rate over 10-20 years. Annual plasma metanephrine testing required indefinitely. Malignant pheochromocytomas (10%) can recur after many years. Hereditary cases require more intensive surveillance (imaging every 1-2 years). "Cure" is never truly confirmed - it's a lifetime diagnosis requiring ongoing monitoring.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Hypertensive emergency (BP >220/120 mmHg with end-organ damage)
  • Hypertensive crisis requiring IV antihypertensive drip (phentolamine, nicardipine, nitroprusside)
  • Acute coronary syndrome (chest pain, ECG changes, troponin elevation)
  • Catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy (Takotsubo, heart failure, pulmonary edema)
  • Cerebrovascular event (stroke, hypertensive encephalopathy, seizures)
  • Tachydysrhythmias (atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia)
  • Perioperative patients (during tumor resection or immediate post-op period)
  • Suspected pheochromocytoma crisis triggered by surgery/anesthesia
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Successful tumor resection completed
  • Postoperative recovery complete (typically 3-5 days)
  • BP controlled (<140/90 mmHg) off IV medications, on oral regimen or no medications
  • No ongoing chest pain, dyspnea, or neurologic symptoms
  • Plasma metanephrines drawn 2 weeks post-op showing normalization (confirms cure)
  • Patient educated on symptoms of recurrence (5-15% recurrence risk)
  • Endocrinology follow-up scheduled for 6-12 weeks for repeat biochemical testing
  • Genetic testing results discussed or scheduled for outpatient
  • Family members referred for screening if hereditary syndrome identified
  • Annual surveillance with plasma metanephrines arranged (lifelong monitoring required)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

102. SEVERE ACUTE DIARRHEA / VOLUME DEPLETION

Frequent Watery Stools â€¢ Dehydration â€¢ Electrolyte Abnormalities â€¢ Acute Kidney Injury
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Abrupt onset of â‰¥3 loose/watery stools per day lasting <14 days, often with nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramping, and signs of volume depletion (tachycardia, orthostatic hypotension, decreased urine output, acute kidney injury).

  • Pathophysiology: Infectious (bacterial, viral, parasitic), medication-induced (antibiotics causing C. difficile), inflammatory, osmotic, or secretory mechanisms causing increased intestinal fluid secretion and decreased absorption. Volume depletion results from GI losses exceeding oral intake, with secondary renal hypoperfusion causing prerenal AKI. Electrolyte losses (Na, K, bicarbonate) can cause metabolic acidosis and dysrhythmias.
  • Risk Factors: Recent antibiotic use (C. difficile), recent travel (traveler's diarrhea), immunosuppression (HIV, chemotherapy, transplant), contaminated food/water, nursing home residence, hospitalization, inflammatory bowel disease, diabetes (autonomic neuropathy), laxative abuse, elderly age, chronic kidney disease
  • Symptoms: Frequent loose/watery stools (>3/day, can be 10-20/day in severe cases), abdominal cramping, nausea, vomiting, fever (infectious), tenesmus, fecal urgency, fecal incontinence, thirst, dizziness, weakness, decreased urine output, confusion (elderly)
  • Physical Exam: Tachycardia, orthostatic vital signs (BP drop >20 mmHg systolic or HR increase >20 bpm on standing), hypotension (if severe), dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, delayed capillary refill, cool extremities, decreased urine output, altered mental status, abdominal tenderness (diffuse or focal), hyperactive bowel sounds, occult blood on rectal exam (inflammatory/invasive diarrhea)
  • Variants/Subtypes: Watery diarrhea (most common: viral, ETEC, cholera) vs Inflammatory/Bloody diarrhea (Shigella, Campylobacter, Salmonella, EHEC, C. difficile, IBD flare). Secretory (persists with fasting: VIPoma, carcinoid) vs Osmotic (stops with fasting: lactose intolerance, sorbitol). Hospital-acquired vs Community-acquired
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Studies:

  • Basic Metabolic Panel: Assess volume status and electrolytes. Expect: elevated BUN/Cr ratio >20:1 (prerenal AKI), hyponatremia or hypernatremia, hypokalemia (<3.0 mEq/L common), non-anion gap metabolic acidosis (bicarbonate loss in stool), elevated creatinine
  • Complete Blood Count: Leukocytosis (bacterial infection), bandemia (sepsis), hemoconcentration (elevated Hgb/Hct if volume depleted), thrombocytosis (IBD), eosinophilia (parasites)
  • Lactate: Elevated if hypoperfusion, sepsis, or mesenteric ischemia. Lactate >4 mmol/L concerning for severe sepsis
  • Urinalysis: Concentrated urine (specific gravity >1.020), elevated urine sodium if volume depleted, urine osmolality >450 mOsm/kg
  • Stool Studies (if indicated):
    • C. difficile PCR (if antibiotic use within 3 months or healthcare exposure)
    • Stool culture (if fever >38.5Â°C, bloody diarrhea, severe illness, immunocompromised)
    • Stool ova & parasites (if travel history, persistent diarrhea >7 days)
    • Giardia/Cryptosporidium antigen (immunocompromised, waterborne exposure)
    • Fecal leukocytes or lactoferrin (suggests inflammatory diarrhea)
    • Fecal occult blood
  • Blood Cultures: If fever, severe illness, immunocompromised, signs of bacteremia/sepsis

Imaging:

  • CT Abdomen/Pelvis with IV Contrast: Indicated if severe abdominal pain, peritoneal signs, concern for toxic megacolon, ischemic colitis, colonic perforation, intra-abdominal abscess. Findings: colonic wall thickening (C. difficile, CMV colitis), pneumatosis, free air (perforation), "thumbprinting" (ischemic colitis)
  • Abdominal X-ray: If concern for toxic megacolon (colon diameter >6 cm), obstruction, free air

Endoscopy:

  • Colonoscopy: Consider if bloody diarrhea of unclear etiology, suspected IBD flare, persistent diarrhea despite treatment, immunocompromised. Can visualize pseudomembranes (C. difficile), ulcerations (CMV, IBD), ischemia. Caution in acute severe colitis (perforation risk)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Management:

  • Assess hemodynamic stability (orthostatic vitals, BP, HR)
  • Establish IV access (two large-bore IVs if severe dehydration or hypotensive)
  • Volume resuscitation: LR or NS 1-2 L bolus, reassess, repeat as needed
  • Goal: normalize BP, HR <100, urine output >0.5 mL/kg/hr
  • Monitor strict I&O (consider Foley catheter if critically ill)
  • Contact isolation precautions if suspected infectious diarrhea

Fluid and Electrolyte Replacement:

  • Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) - Preferred if mild-moderate dehydration and tolerating PO: WHO-ORS formula or commercial products (Pedialyte). Contains glucose and sodium for coupled absorption. Goal: 50-100 mL/kg over 2-4 hours
  • IV Fluid Resuscitation - If severe dehydration, unable to tolerate PO, or hypotensive:
    • Lactated Ringer's or 0.9% saline 1-2 L bolus initially
    • Continue IV fluids at 150-250 mL/hr, adjust based on ongoing losses
    • Match ongoing stool losses with IV fluids (may require 3-6 L/day)
  • Potassium Replacement: Most patients need K+ repletion. If K <3.0 mEq/L: give 40-80 mEq PO or 20-40 mEq IV (max rate 10 mEq/hr via peripheral line, 20 mEq/hr via central line). Check K q4-6h
  • Bicarbonate: Usually corrects with volume resuscitation. If severe acidosis (pH <7.2, HCO3 <10), consider sodium bicarbonate
  • Magnesium Replacement: Check and replace if Mg <1.5 mg/dL (2-4 g IV over 4 hours)

Antimicrobial Therapy (if indicated):

  • C. difficile Infection:
    • Fidaxomicin 200 mg PO BID x 10 days (preferred, lower recurrence)
    • Or Vancomycin 125 mg PO QID x 10 days
    • If fulminant/severe (WBC >15k, Cr â‰¥1.5x baseline, hypotension, ileus, toxic megacolon): Vancomycin 500 mg PO/NG QID + Metronidazole 500 mg IV q8h
    • Stop offending antibiotic if possible
  • Campylobacter: Azithromycin 500 mg daily x 3 days (if severe or immunocompromised)
  • Shigella: Ciprofloxacin 500 mg BID x 3 days or Azithromycin 500 mg daily x 3 days
  • Salmonella (non-typhi): Usually self-limited, antibiotics only if bacteremia, immunocompromised, or age >50 with high risk. Ciprofloxacin 500 mg BID x 7 days
  • Giardia: Metronidazole 250 mg TID x 5-7 days or Tinidazole 2 g single dose
  • Cryptosporidium: Nitazoxanide 500 mg BID x 3 days (immunocompetent); no effective treatment if HIV/immunocompromised (improve immune status)
  • Do NOT use antibiotics for EHEC/STEC (E. coli O157:H7): Increases risk of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)

Symptomatic Management:

  • Antimotility Agents - Use with EXTREME CAUTION:
    • Loperamide 4 mg initial, then 2 mg after each loose stool (max 16 mg/day)
    • CONTRAINDICATIONS: bloody diarrhea, fever >38.5Â°C, C. difficile, EHEC/STEC, severe colitis (risk of toxic megacolon)
    • Generally safe for uncomplicated watery diarrhea
  • Antiemetics: Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN
  • Probiotics: Lactobacillus or Saccharomyces boulardii may reduce duration; evidence mixed

Nutrition:

  • Continue normal diet as tolerated; avoid prolonged fasting (delays recovery)
  • BRAT diet (bananas, rice, applesauce, toast) is outdated - normal diet preferred
  • Avoid dairy temporarily if lactose intolerance suspected
  • Encourage oral fluids with electrolytes

Disposition:

  • ICU: Septic shock, severe electrolyte disturbances, toxic megacolon, fulminant C. difficile
  • Floor: Moderate-severe volume depletion requiring IV fluids, unable to tolerate adequate PO intake, elderly with comorbidities, AKI requiring monitoring
  • Discharge: Mild-moderate diarrhea, tolerating PO, hemodynamically stable, improving symptoms, able to follow-up
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • BUN/Cr Ratio >20:1 Suggests Prerenal AKI from Volume Depletion: In severe diarrhea, GI losses cause hypovolemia and renal hypoperfusion. BUN rises disproportionately to creatinine due to increased proximal tubule urea reabsorption. Ratio >20:1 (e.g., BUN 60, Cr 2.0 = ratio 30:1) indicates prerenal etiology. After adequate IV fluid resuscitation, ratio normalizes (<15:1) and creatinine improves, confirming prerenal diagnosis.
  • Don't Withhold Antimotility Agents in All Cases - Know Your Contraindications: Loperamide is safe and effective for uncomplicated watery diarrhea (viral, traveler's diarrhea from ETEC). Absolute contraindications: bloody diarrhea, high fever (>38.5Â°C), suspected C. difficile, EHEC/STEC (E. coli O157:H7), severe colitis/IBD flare. Risk is precipitating toxic megacolon or prolonging infection by slowing bacterial clearance. If watery diarrhea without red flags, antimotility is appropriate and improves quality of life.
  • Antibiotics for EHEC/STEC (E. coli O157:H7) Increase Risk of HUS: Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (O157:H7 and other Shiga toxin-producing E. coli) causes bloody diarrhea, often from undercooked beef or contaminated produce. Antibiotics trigger Shiga toxin release, increasing risk of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS): microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, AKI, can be fatal. If bloody diarrhea and suspect STEC: do NOT give antibiotics, send stool for Shiga toxin PCR, monitor CBC and renal function for HUS development (days 5-7 of illness).
  • Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) is as Effective as IV Fluids for Mild-Moderate Dehydration: WHO-ORS contains precise glucose:sodium ratio (2:1) to maximize coupled absorption via SGLT1 transporters in small intestine. Glucose-facilitated sodium absorption pulls water into bloodstream. Equally effective as IV fluids if patient can tolerate oral intake, cheaper, no IV complications. Give 50-100 mL/kg over 2-4 hours. Transition to ORS from IV fluids as soon as patient tolerating PO.
  • Fulminant C. difficile Requires Dual Therapy (PO Vancomycin + IV Metronidazole): Severe/fulminant C. diff defined by: WBC >15k, Cr â‰¥1.5x baseline, hypotension, ileus, or toxic megacolon. Oral vancomycin alone may not reach colon if ileus present. Add IV metronidazole 500 mg q8h to ensure colonic antibiotic levels. If ileus: give vancomycin via NGT (500 mg QID) or rectal enema (vancomycin 500 mg in 100 mL NS q6h). Early surgical consultation for toxic megacolon or perforation (mortality 50% without colectomy).
  • Severe Hypokalemia is Common and Dangerous: Diarrhea causes massive potassium losses (normal stool K 75-90 mEq/L; diarrhea can lose 300+ mEq/day). Hypokalemia <3.0 mEq/L causes cardiac arrhythmias (prolonged QT, torsades de pointes), muscle weakness, ileus. Aggressively replace: if K 2.5-3.0, give 40-80 mEq PO; if K <2.5, give 40 mEq IV over 4 hours (central line preferred if giving >10 mEq/hr). Check K q4-6h until >3.5 mEq/L. Most patients need 120-200 mEq total replacement.
  • Lactate Elevation Can Be from Hypoperfusion, Sepsis, or Metformin + AKI: In severe diarrhea with volume depletion, lactate >2-4 mmol/L can result from tissue hypoperfusion (prerenal state), sepsis (if bacteremia), or lactic acidosis from metformin accumulation if AKI present (metformin renally excreted). Distinguish: if hypoperfusion alone, lactate clears with IV fluids; if sepsis, remains elevated and patient appears toxic; if metformin-induced, lactate very high (>10 mmol/L), hold metformin, consider dialysis if severe.
  • Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis is Expected in Diarrhea: Stool contains bicarbonate (20-40 mEq/L). Massive diarrhea causes bicarbonate loss, resulting in hyperchloremic non-anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA). Example: pH 7.28, HCO3 14, Cl 112, anion gap 14 (normal). Distinguish from anion gap acidosis (lactic acidosis, ketoacidosis) which suggests more ominous process. NAGMA in diarrhea is expected and corrects with volume resuscitation and treating underlying cause.
  • Immunocompromised Patients Need Broader Stool Workup: HIV/AIDS (CD4 <200), chemotherapy, transplant, chronic steroids are at risk for atypical infections. Send expanded stool panel: CMV PCR/culture (most common in HIV), Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC), Cryptosporidium, Microsporidia, Cyclospora, Isospora. Consider colonoscopy with biopsies. CMV colitis: hemorrhagic colitis with ulcerations, treat with ganciclovir 5 mg/kg IV q12h. MAC: watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, treat with azithromycin + ethambutol.
  • Consider Ischemic Colitis in Elderly with Bloody Diarrhea: Acute onset bloody diarrhea with abdominal pain in elderly patient (especially with vascular disease, AF, hypotension, cocaine use). Results from decreased colonic blood flow, most often affecting "watershed" areas (splenic flexure, sigmoid). CT: colonic wall thickening, "thumbprinting". Mild cases: supportive care, bowel rest, resolve in 48-72 hours. Severe cases: gangrenous bowel, peritonitis, septic shock, require urgent surgical resection. Do NOT use antibiotics empirically for bloody diarrhea before considering ischemic colitis.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Septic shock (hypotension requiring vasopressors, lactate >4 mmol/L)
  • Severe dehydration with persistent hypotension despite 3-4 L IV fluids
  • Acute kidney injury with oliguria/anuria requiring urgent dialysis consideration
  • Life-threatening electrolyte disturbances (K <2.5 or >6.5 mEq/L, severe acidosis pH <7.2)
  • Toxic megacolon (colon diameter >6 cm with systemic toxicity)
  • Fulminant C. difficile colitis (WBC >35k, lactate >5, ileus, peritoneal signs)
  • Altered mental status, seizures from severe electrolyte abnormalities
  • GI bleeding with hemodynamic instability
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable (BP >90/60, HR <100, normal orthostatics)
  • Tolerating adequate oral fluids (>1-1.5 L/day) without vomiting
  • Diarrhea frequency decreasing or stable (<5 stools/day)
  • Electrolytes normalized or improving trend (K >3.5, Na 135-145, normal bicarb)
  • Renal function improved or stable (Cr at or near baseline)
  • Afebrile for 24 hours if infectious etiology
  • Appropriate antibiotics prescribed if indicated (C. diff, Shigella, Giardia)
  • Patient educated on hydration, signs of worsening, when to return (severe abdominal pain, bloody stools, fever, dizziness, decreased urine output)
  • Follow-up arranged with PCP within 3-7 days
  • If C. difficile: educated on recurrence risk (20-30%), hand hygiene, avoid PPIs if possible
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

103. DIVERTICULITIS (COMPLICATED)

LLQ Pain â€¢ Fever â€¢ Leukocytosis â€¢ Abscess/Perforation/Fistula
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Acute left lower quadrant (LLQ) abdominal pain with fever and leukocytosis. Complicated diverticulitis involves abscess formation, perforation with peritonitis, fistula (colovesical, colovaginal), or stricture/obstruction.

  • Pathophysiology: Diverticula are herniations of colonic mucosa through muscular wall at points of vascular penetration. Most common in sigmoid colon (90%). Microperforation or macroperforation leads to inflammation (diverticulitis). Complicated diverticulitis (20-25% of cases) includes: (1) Abscess formation (pericolic or distant), (2) Free perforation causing fecal peritonitis, (3) Fistula formation (most common colovesical: pneumaturia, fecaluria), (4) Stricture causing obstruction
  • Risk Factors: Age >40 years (prevalence 30% by age 60, 60% by age 80), Western diet (low fiber), obesity, smoking, NSAIDs/aspirin, immunosuppression, connective tissue disorders (Marfan, Ehlers-Danlos), polycystic kidney disease, chronic constipation
  • Symptoms: Acute LLQ abdominal pain (constant, may radiate to back/groin), fever >38Â°C, anorexia, nausea, change in bowel habits (diarrhea or constipation), dysuria/frequency if bladder involvement, pneumaturia/fecaluria (colovesical fistula), vaginal passage of stool/flatus (colovaginal fistula)
  • Physical Exam: LLQ tenderness (most sensitive finding), palpable tender mass (phlegmon or abscess), rebound tenderness, guarding, rigidity (if peritonitis), fever, tachycardia, hypotension (if septic), diminished bowel sounds, rectal exam: tenderness, palpable mass if low abscess
  • Variants/Subtypes: Uncomplicated diverticulitis (colonic inflammation only) vs Complicated diverticulitis: Hinchey Classification - Stage Ia (pericolic abscess <4 cm), Stage Ib (pericolic abscess >4 cm), Stage II (pelvic/distant abscess), Stage III (purulent peritonitis), Stage IV (fecal peritonitis - worst prognosis)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Studies:

  • Complete Blood Count: Leukocytosis (WBC >11k, typical 12-18k), left shift (bandemia), thrombocytosis. Severe leukocytosis (>20k) suggests abscess or perforation
  • Basic Metabolic Panel: Acute kidney injury (prerenal from sepsis/dehydration), electrolyte abnormalities
  • Liver Function Tests: Usually normal; if elevated, consider liver abscess or biliary pathology
  • Lactate: Elevated (>2 mmol/L) if sepsis, mesenteric ischemia, or perforation. Lactate >4 mmol/L indicates severe sepsis/shock
  • Lipase: To rule out pancreatitis (similar presentation)
  • Urinalysis: May show pyuria, hematuria if colovesical fistula or bladder irritation from adjacent inflammation. True UTI vs sterile pyuria (inflammation without infection)
  • Blood Cultures: If fever >38.5Â°C, septic appearance, immunocompromised. Common organisms: E. coli, Bacteroides, Enterococcus

Imaging - CT Abdomen/Pelvis with IV Contrast (Gold Standard):

  • Indications: All patients with suspected complicated diverticulitis. CT has 97% sensitivity, 100% specificity for diverticulitis
  • Classic CT Findings:
    • Colonic wall thickening (>4 mm)
    • Pericolic fat stranding (inflammation)
    • Diverticula visible
    • Abscess: loculated fluid collection with enhancing rim (Hinchey Ib/II)
    • Free air (pneumoperitoneum): perforation, requires emergent surgery
    • Extraluminal air/fecalith: microperforation contained by mesentery
    • Bowel obstruction: dilated bowel proximal to inflamed segment (stricture)
    • Colovesical fistula: air in bladder (pneumaturia) without urinary catheter
  • Contraindications: Renal insufficiency (relative; consider non-contrast CT or MRI), contrast allergy (can premedicate or use MRI)

Alternative Imaging:

  • Ultrasound: Can be used (especially in pregnant patients or young adults), shows hypoechoic bowel wall thickening. Less sensitive than CT (61-85%)
  • MRI Abdomen/Pelvis: If pregnancy, renal insufficiency, contrast allergy. Excellent for evaluating pelvic abscesses and fistulas
  • Abdominal X-ray: Low sensitivity but can detect free air (upright CXR or left lateral decubitus), bowel obstruction, ileus. Not diagnostic for diverticulitis

Colonoscopy:

  • CONTRAINDICATED in acute diverticulitis: Risk of perforation. Defer 6-8 weeks after acute episode
  • Indication for delayed colonoscopy (6-8 weeks post-resolution): To rule out colon cancer (can mimic diverticulitis), especially if first episode, age >50, alarm features (weight loss, anemia), or complicated diverticulitis with abscess/fistula. Cancer found in 2-11% of first diverticulitis episodes in patients >50
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Management:

  • IV access, hemodynamic stabilization (IV fluids if tachycardic, hypotensive)
  • NPO initially, advance diet as tolerated (clear liquids â†’ low-residue diet)
  • Pain control: IV opioids (morphine 2-4 mg IV q2-4h, hydromorphone 0.5-1 mg IV q3-4h). Avoid NSAIDs (may worsen inflammation/perforation risk)
  • Antiemetics: Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV q8h PRN
  • Strict I&O monitoring

Antibiotic Therapy:

  • Uncomplicated Diverticulitis (now controversial whether antibiotics needed): Recent data suggests select immunocompetent patients with CT-confirmed uncomplicated diverticulitis (no abscess, no perforation, WBC <15k, able to tolerate PO) can be managed without antibiotics. However, most still treat with antibiotics
  • Complicated Diverticulitis (ALWAYS require antibiotics): Abscess, perforation, fistula, immunocompromised, severe illness, sepsis
  • Empiric Antibiotic Regimens (broad-spectrum, cover GNR and anaerobes):
    • Mild-Moderate (outpatient or floor): Ciprofloxacin 500 mg PO BID + Metronidazole 500 mg PO TID x 7-10 days. Or Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875 mg PO BID x 7-10 days. Or Moxifloxacin 400 mg PO daily x 7-10 days (monotherapy)
    • Severe/Complicated (IV therapy):
      • Piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375 g IV q6h (or 4.5 g q8h for severe)
      • Or Ceftriaxone 1-2 g IV daily + Metronidazole 500 mg IV q8h
      • Or Ciprofloxacin 400 mg IV q12h + Metronidazole 500 mg IV q8h
      • Or Carbapenem (Meropenem 1 g IV q8h or Ertapenem 1 g IV daily) - if recent antibiotics, healthcare-associated, or very ill
    • Duration: 4-7 days IV (if abscess drained or free perf), up to 7-14 days total
    • Transition to PO antibiotics once improving: afebrile 24-48 hours, WBC normalizing, tolerating PO, pain improved

Abscess Management:

  • Small Pericolic Abscess (<4 cm, Hinchey Ia): Antibiotics alone, no drainage needed. Success rate 70-85%
  • Large Abscess (>4 cm, Hinchey Ib/II): Percutaneous CT-guided drainage + antibiotics
    • Indications: abscess >4 cm, accessible for percutaneous approach, patient too unstable for surgery
    • Interventional radiology consultation for drain placement (usually 10-14 Fr pigtail catheter)
    • Drain to gravity, flush with 10-20 mL saline TID, remove when output <10 mL/day and patient clinically improved (typically 7-14 days)
    • Success rate 70-85%; avoids urgent surgery in most cases
    • Failed drainage (persistent sepsis, enlarging abscess): requires surgical intervention

Surgical Management:

  • EMERGENT Surgery Indications (immediate OR):
    • Hinchey III (purulent peritonitis) or IV (fecal peritonitis)
    • Diffuse peritonitis, free air on imaging
    • Hemodynamic instability/septic shock despite resuscitation
    • Clinical deterioration despite antibiotics Â± drainage
  • Surgical Options:
    • Hartmann Procedure (most common emergent): Sigmoid resection, end colostomy, rectal stump (stapled or oversewn). Colostomy reversal in 3-6 months if patient recovers
    • Primary Resection with Anastomosis: If minimal contamination, stable patient. Higher risk of anastomotic leak in acute setting
    • Laparoscopic Peritoneal Lavage: Controversial, for Hinchey III (purulent peritonitis) without feculent peritonitis. Not standard of care
  • ELECTIVE Surgery Indications (post-resolution, 6-8 weeks later):
    • Recurrent diverticulitis (â‰¥2 episodes) - now controversial, individualize decision
    • Complicated diverticulitis (abscess, fistula, stricture, recurrent bleeding)
    • Immunocompromised (transplant, chronic steroids, chemotherapy) - even after first episode
    • Young age (<50 years) - previously standard, now individualized
    • Inability to exclude cancer

Consultations:

  • Surgery (General Surgery or Colorectal Surgery): Consult early for all complicated diverticulitis cases. Emergent consult if peritonitis, free air, septic shock
  • Interventional Radiology: For CT-guided abscess drainage (abscesses >4 cm)
  • Gastroenterology: For outpatient colonoscopy 6-8 weeks post-discharge (rule out colon cancer)

Disposition:

  • ICU: Septic shock, Hinchey III/IV requiring emergent surgery, post-operative from emergent surgery
  • Floor: Complicated diverticulitis (abscess, unable to tolerate PO, severe pain, immunocompromised), requiring IV antibiotics
  • Discharge/Outpatient: Mild-moderate diverticulitis, CT-confirmed, able to tolerate PO, hemodynamically stable, reliable for follow-up, adequate oral antibiotic coverage
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Always Get CT with IV Contrast for Suspected Complicated Diverticulitis: Clinical diagnosis alone misses abscesses, microperforation, and alternative diagnoses (colon cancer, appendicitis, ovarian pathology, ischemic colitis). CT is 97% sensitive, 100% specific. Don't rely on physical exam alone - even with classic LLQ tenderness and fever, CT changes management in 30% of cases by identifying abscess needing drainage or perforation requiring surgery.
  • Hinchey Classification Guides Surgical vs Medical Management: Hinchey Ia (pericolic abscess <4 cm): antibiotics alone. Hinchey Ib (pericolic abscess >4 cm): percutaneous drainage + antibiotics. Hinchey II (distant/pelvic abscess): percutaneous drainage + antibiotics. Hinchey III (purulent peritonitis): emergent surgery (Hartmann). Hinchey IV (fecal peritonitis): emergent surgery, worst prognosis (mortality 20-40%). Know this classification - it dictates management and need for urgent surgical consultation.
  • Colovesical Fistula: Air in Bladder Without Foley = Diverticulitis Until Proven Otherwise: Most common fistula complication (65%). Patient presents with pneumaturia (air in urine), fecaluria (stool in urine), recurrent UTIs. CT shows air in bladder without urinary catheter. Occurs when inflamed sigmoid colon (left side) erodes into dome of bladder. Diagnosis: CT cystogram may show contrast in colon. Treatment requires sigmoid resection with bladder repair - antibiotics alone never cure fistula.
  • Antibiotics May NOT Be Needed for Uncomplicated Diverticulitis: Recent high-quality RCTs (AVOD, DIABOLO trials) show select patients with CT-confirmed uncomplicated diverticulitis (no abscess, no perforation, immunocompetent, WBC <15k) can be managed with supportive care alone without antibiotics. No difference in complication rates. However, this applies ONLY to uncomplicated cases. Complicated diverticulitis (abscess, perforation, fistula, immunosuppression, severe illness) ALWAYS requires antibiotics. This is evolving practice - many institutions still use antibiotics for all cases.
  • Defer Colonoscopy 6-8 Weeks Post-Resolution to Rule Out Colon Cancer: Colon cancer can present identically to diverticulitis (LLQ pain, fever, leukocytosis, CT showing colonic wall thickening). About 2-11% of first diverticulitis episodes in patients >50 are actually cancer. Colonoscopy during acute diverticulitis risks perforation. Wait 6-8 weeks to allow inflammation to resolve, then perform colonoscopy to visualize mucosa and rule out malignancy, especially if first episode, age >50, or alarm symptoms (weight loss, anemia, positive FOBT).
  • Immunosuppressed Patients Have Worse Outcomes and Need Surgery After First Episode: Transplant recipients, chronic steroids, chemotherapy, biologics (TNF-alpha inhibitors) have 3-5x higher perforation rate, higher mortality, and more aggressive disease. Even uncomplicated diverticulitis in immunosuppressed patient may progress to perforation rapidly. Strategy: lower threshold for admission, IV antibiotics, early surgical consultation, and consider elective sigmoid resection after first episode to prevent recurrence (unlike immunocompetent where surgery typically reserved for recurrent episodes).
  • Young Age (<40-50 Years) Does NOT Automatically Mean More Aggressive Disease: Old teaching: young patients have more virulent diverticulitis, need surgery after first episode. Recent data shows this is FALSE. Young patients have similar complication rates to older patients. Current approach: individualize surgical decision based on frequency of recurrence, impact on quality of life, presence of complications - NOT age alone. Don't tell 35-year-old they "need" prophylactic sigmoid resection after first uncomplicated episode.
  • Percutaneous Abscess Drainage Avoids Urgent Surgery in 70-85% of Cases: Abscess >4 cm (Hinchey Ib/II) traditionally required urgent surgery (Hartmann procedure). Now, CT-guided percutaneous drainage + antibiotics successfully treats abscess, allows acute inflammation to resolve, then patient can undergo elective one-stage sigmoid resection 6-8 weeks later (lower morbidity, higher primary anastomosis rate, avoid colostomy). Drainage "converts" complicated diverticulitis to uncomplicated, allowing definitive surgery to be done electively under optimal conditions.
  • High-Fiber Diet AFTER Resolution - Avoid During Acute Episode: During acute diverticulitis: low-residue diet or NPO initially (reduce colonic stimulation). After resolution (2-4 weeks): transition to high-fiber diet (25-30 g/day) to prevent recurrence. Fiber increases stool bulk, reduces intraluminal pressure, decreases diverticula formation. Old myth: avoid nuts, seeds, popcorn (no evidence they cause diverticulitis - DEBUNKED). High fiber reduces recurrence risk by 30-40%.
  • Hartmann Procedure is Emergency Surgery, NOT Definitive Treatment: Hartmann = sigmoid resection + end colostomy + rectal stump oversewn/stapled. Performed in emergency setting (Hinchey III/IV, peritonitis) because primary anastomosis too high-risk (leak rate 10-20% in contaminated field). Colostomy is temporary. Plan colostomy reversal in 3-6 months once patient recovered. Reversal surgery: reconnect colon to rectal stump, restore bowel continuity. About 50-60% of patients undergo successful reversal; others never reversed due to comorbidities, age, patient preference.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Septic shock (hypotension requiring vasopressors, lactate >4 mmol/L)
  • Diffuse peritonitis with free air (Hinchey IV - fecal peritonitis)
  • Purulent peritonitis (Hinchey III) requiring emergent surgery
  • Hemodynamic instability despite aggressive fluid resuscitation
  • Post-operative from emergent Hartmann procedure or bowel resection
  • Clinical deterioration despite antibiotics and abscess drainage
  • Severe lactic acidosis (lactate >4 mmol/L), concern for bowel ischemia/necrosis
  • Respiratory failure from sepsis or abdominal compartment syndrome
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Afebrile for >24-48 hours (Temp <38Â°C without antipyretics)
  • Tolerating regular or low-residue diet without nausea/vomiting
  • Pain adequately controlled on oral analgesics
  • WBC normalized or trending down (<12k, ideally <10k)
  • Hemodynamically stable (normal vital signs without tachycardia)
  • Able to ambulate independently
  • Discharged on appropriate oral antibiotics (7-10 day course completed)
  • Follow-up arranged with PCP or GI within 1-2 weeks
  • Colonoscopy scheduled for 6-8 weeks post-discharge (to rule out colon cancer)
  • Patient educated on high-fiber diet after resolution (25-30 g fiber/day), avoiding nuts/seeds NOT necessary
  • Red flag symptoms discussed: worsening pain, fever, unable to tolerate PO, vomiting, distension (obstruction)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

104. CIRRHOSIS COMPLICATIONS (VARICEAL BLEEDING, HEPATORENAL SYNDROME)

Portal Hypertension â€¢ GI Bleeding â€¢ Renal Failure â€¢ Ascites
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Decompensated cirrhosis presenting with acute variceal hemorrhage (hematemesis, melena, hemodynamic instability) or hepatorenal syndrome (rapidly progressive renal failure with oliguria, resistant ascites, without other cause of renal dysfunction).

  • Pathophysiology: Variceal Bleeding: Portal hypertension (HVPG >12 mmHg) causes portosystemic collaterals (varices in esophagus, stomach, rectum). Rupture causes massive GI bleeding (mortality 15-20% per episode). Hepatorenal Syndrome (HRS): Functional renal failure from severe hepatic dysfunction, splanchnic vasodilation, effective hypovolemia, and renal vasoconstriction. No intrinsic kidney damage - kidneys are structurally normal but failing due to hemodynamic changes. Reversible with liver transplant but rapidly fatal without treatment.
  • Risk Factors: Decompensated cirrhosis (any etiology: EtOH, NASH, viral hepatitis, autoimmune), MELD score >15, Child-Pugh class B/C, large varices on EGD, red whale markings on varices (high rupture risk), SBP, recent binge alcohol use, NSAIDs, anticoagulation
  • Symptoms - Variceal Bleeding: Hematemesis (bright red or coffee-ground), melena, hematochezia (if brisk bleeding), dizziness, syncope, dyspnea, chest pain (if severe anemia), altered mental status (hepatic encephalopathy from blood in GI tract)
  • Symptoms - Hepatorenal Syndrome: Oliguria (<400-500 mL/day), abdominal distension (ascites), confusion (hepatic encephalopathy), nausea, weakness. Patients often initially have type 2 HRS (slower, more chronic) then progress to type 1 HRS (rapid, <2 weeks)
  • Physical Exam: Stigmata of cirrhosis: jaundice, spider angiomata, palmar erythema, gynecomastia, testicular atrophy, caput medusae. Tense ascites (fluid wave, shifting dullness). Asterixis (hepatic encephalopathy). Hypotension, tachycardia (variceal bleeding). Splenomegaly (portal hypertension)
  • Variants/Subtypes: Variceal Bleeding: Esophageal (most common 80%), gastric (15%), rectal (5%). HRS: Type 1 (rapid, <2 weeks, doubling of Cr to >2.5 mg/dL, very poor prognosis) vs Type 2 (slower, moderate renal dysfunction, associated with refractory ascites)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Studies:

  • Complete Blood Count: Anemia (acute blood loss or chronic disease), thrombocytopenia (<100k common in cirrhosis from splenic sequestration, bone marrow suppression), leukopenia
  • Comprehensive Metabolic Panel: Elevated BUN (GI bleeding), elevated Cr (HRS), hyponatremia (<130 mEq/L common in advanced cirrhosis), hypoglycemia possible, elevated bilirubin
  • Liver Function Tests: Elevated AST/ALT (usually <300 unless acute hepatitis superimposed), elevated alkaline phosphatase, hypoalbuminemia (<3.0 g/dL), hyperbilirubinemia (both direct and indirect)
  • Coagulation Studies: Prolonged PT/INR (INR often 1.5-3.0 or higher in decompensated cirrhosis from decreased synthetic function), prolonged PTT. Do NOT routinely correct INR unless active bleeding and performing procedure
  • Lactate: Elevated if hypovolemic shock, hepatic hypoperfusion, or mesenteric ischemia
  • Type & Screen / Crossmatch: Essential for variceal bleeding; anticipate transfusion needs
  • Ammonia Level: Often elevated in hepatic encephalopathy; useful to assess need for lactulose escalation
  • Blood Cultures: Draw before antibiotics if concern for SBP or bacteremia

HRS-Specific Laboratory Criteria:

  • Serum creatinine >1.5 mg/dL or doubling of baseline to >2.5 mg/dL (Type 1)
  • Urine sodium <10 mEq/L (avid sodium retention)
  • Urine osmolality > serum osmolality (kidneys concentrating urine)
  • Urinalysis: bland sediment (no casts, minimal protein, no RBCs/WBCs)
  • Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) <1% (prerenal pattern)
  • No improvement after 48-hour trial of albumin and diuretic withdrawal
  • Absence of shock, nephrotoxic drugs, parenchymal renal disease

Imaging:

  • Renal Ultrasound: To rule out obstructive uropathy, assess kidney size (normal to slightly enlarged in HRS, small kidneys suggest chronic kidney disease)
  • CT Abdomen/Pelvis: If concern for other cause of renal failure (obstruction, abscess, hepatocellular carcinoma with vascular invasion)
  • Doppler Ultrasound of Liver: Assess portal vein patency (portal vein thrombosis can worsen portal hypertension, precipitate bleeding)

Endoscopy - URGENT Upper Endoscopy (EGD):

  • Perform within 12 hours of presentation for suspected variceal bleeding
  • Diagnostic: confirms variceal source, grades varices (small vs large)
  • Therapeutic: band ligation (preferred over sclerotherapy), bleeding control
  • If not variceal: peptic ulcer, gastritis, Mallory-Weiss tear, portal hypertensive gastropathy

Paracentesis (if ascites present):

  • Rule out SBP (fluid PMN >250/ÂµL)
  • Send ascitic fluid for: cell count with differential, culture (blood culture bottles at bedside), albumin, total protein, Gram stain
  • Calculate serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG): Serum albumin minus ascitic fluid albumin. SAAG â‰¥1.1 g/dL confirms portal hypertension as cause of ascites
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

VARICEAL BLEEDING MANAGEMENT:

Immediate Resuscitation:

  • IV access: Two large-bore IVs (18-gauge or larger)
  • Hemodynamic monitoring: continuous telemetry, frequent vitals q15min initially
  • Target BP: permissive hypotension initially (SBP 90-100 mmHg) to reduce variceal pressure before endoscopy
  • Target Hemoglobin: 7-9 g/dL (restrictive transfusion strategy better outcomes). Transfuse PRBCs to Hgb 7-8 g/dL, avoid over-transfusion (increases portal pressure, rebleeding risk)
  • Do NOT over-resuscitate with fluids (worsens portal hypertension and rebleeding)

Pharmacologic Therapy for Variceal Bleeding:

  • Octreotide (Somatostatin Analog) - START IMMEDIATELY before endoscopy:
    • Bolus: 50 mcg IV push
    • Infusion: 50 mcg/hr continuous IV infusion
    • Duration: 2-5 days (until hemostasis confirmed)
    • Mechanism: splanchnic vasoconstriction, reduces portal pressure
  • Prophylactic Antibiotics (CRITICAL - reduces mortality):
    • Ceftriaxone 1 g IV daily x 7 days (preferred in advanced cirrhosis, prior quinolone use)
    • Or Ciprofloxacin 400 mg IV BID x 7 days
    • Or Norfloxacin 400 mg PO BID x 7 days (if can tolerate PO)
    • Prevents SBP and bacteremia (occurs in 20% of variceal bleeds)
  • Proton Pump Inhibitor: Pantoprazole 80 mg IV bolus, then 8 mg/hr infusion (reduces non-variceal bleeding, protects mucosa)

Endoscopic Therapy - URGENT (within 12 hours):

  • Esophageal Variceal Band Ligation (EVL) - Preferred: Place bands on varices to achieve hemostasis. Success rate 80-90%. Repeat banding sessions q2-4 weeks until varices obliterated
  • Sclerotherapy: Inject sclerosant into varices. Alternative if banding not feasible. Higher complication rate than banding
  • If Bleeding Not Controlled with Above Measures: Consider rescue therapies below

Rescue Therapies (if endoscopic therapy fails):

  • Balloon Tamponade (Minnesota or Sengstaken-Blakemore Tube):
    • Temporary measure (bridge to TIPS or surgery)
    • Inflate esophageal and gastric balloons to tamponade varices
    • High complication rate: esophageal perforation, aspiration, pressure necrosis
    • Use ONLY as last resort, max 24 hours inflation
    • Requires ICU, intubation for airway protection
  • TIPS (Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt):
    • Interventional radiology creates shunt between portal and hepatic veins, reduces portal pressure
    • Indications: refractory variceal bleeding despite endoscopic therapy, rebleeding within 5 days, high-risk patients (Child-Pugh B/C with active bleeding at endoscopy)
    • Early TIPS (within 72 hours) in high-risk patients improves survival
    • Complications: hepatic encephalopathy (30-50%), shunt stenosis/thrombosis, liver failure
    • Contraindications: severe hepatic encephalopathy, heart failure, polycystic liver disease, hepatocellular carcinoma

HEPATORENAL SYNDROME MANAGEMENT:

Diagnostic Confirmation (ensure criteria met):

  • Cirrhosis with ascites
  • Cr >1.5 mg/dL or doubling to >2.5 mg/dL
  • No improvement after 2 days of diuretic withdrawal + 1 g/kg albumin IV (max 100 g/day x 2 days)
  • No shock, no nephrotoxins (NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, contrast), no parenchymal kidney disease
  • Urine sodium <10 mEq/L, bland urinalysis

Pharmacologic Treatment (HRS-Specific):

  • Albumin + Vasoconstrictors - FIRST LINE:
    • Albumin: 1 g/kg IV on day 1 (max 100 g), then 20-40 g IV daily
    • PLUS Midodrine + Octreotide (if no ICU bed):
      • Midodrine: 7.5 mg PO TID, increase by 2.5 mg TID every 3 days (max 15 mg TID). Goal MAP >15 mmHg increase or SBP >120 mmHg
      • Octreotide: 100-200 mcg SC TID (or 50 mcg/hr IV infusion if unable to take PO)
    • PLUS Norepinephrine (if ICU setting) - MOST EFFECTIVE:
      • Norepinephrine 0.5-3 mg/hr IV infusion, titrate to MAP >10 mmHg increase
      • More effective than midodrine/octreotide, preferred if ICU available
    • Duration: Continue until Cr <1.5 mg/dL or liver transplant
    • Response rate: 40-50% with reversal of HRS
  • Terlipressin (Vasopressin Analog) - GOLD STANDARD (if available):
    • Dose: 1 mg IV bolus q4-6h, increase to 2 mg q4-6h if no response after 3 days
    • Most effective drug for HRS (reversal rate 40-50%)
    • Not FDA-approved in US but available in Europe, being considered for US approval
    • Complications: ischemic events (MI, mesenteric ischemia, limb ischemia) in 5-10%

Supportive Care for HRS:

  • Stop all diuretics (worsens renal perfusion)
  • Avoid nephrotoxins: NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, IV contrast
  • Maintain euvolemia: avoid aggressive diuresis and over-resuscitation
  • Treat precipitating factors: SBP (if present), GI bleeding, infections
  • Paracentesis: Large-volume paracentesis (>5 L) requires albumin 6-8 g per liter removed

Definitive Treatment (HRS):

  • Liver Transplantation - ONLY CURE: HRS resolves after transplant (kidneys are structurally normal). List for transplant urgently. MELD score includes creatinine, so HRS improves transplant priority
  • Renal Replacement Therapy (Dialysis): Bridge to transplant. Continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) preferred over intermittent HD in hemodynamically unstable patients. Does not improve survival unless transplant occurs

Consultations:

  • Gastroenterology/Hepatology: URGENT for variceal bleeding (endoscopy), HRS management, transplant evaluation
  • Interventional Radiology: For TIPS if refractory variceal bleeding
  • Nephrology: For HRS management, dialysis consideration
  • Transplant Surgery: For liver transplant evaluation (expedite if HRS Type 1)
  • Interventional Radiology: For TIPS placement

Disposition:

  • ICU: Active variceal bleeding, hemodynamic instability, HRS Type 1 on vasopressors, post-TIPS, balloon tamponade, hepatic encephalopathy grade 3-4
  • Floor with Telemetry: Controlled variceal bleeding post-endoscopy, HRS Type 2, moderate ascites, hepatic encephalopathy grade 1-2
  • Discharge: Stable post-variceal bleed (after observation, repeat Hgb stable, no rebleeding x 48-72 hours), on appropriate prophylaxis (beta-blocker, repeated banding sessions scheduled)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Restrictive Transfusion Strategy (Target Hgb 7-9 g/dL) Reduces Rebleeding and Mortality: Over-transfusion increases portal venous pressure, precipitating rebleeding. Landmark study showed targeting Hgb 7-9 g/dL had 50% reduction in rebleeding and improved survival vs liberal strategy (Hgb 9-11 g/dL). Avoid over-resuscitation - permissive hypotension (SBP 90-100) acceptable before endoscopy. After hemostasis achieved, aim Hgb ~8 g/dL.
  • Start Octreotide and Antibiotics BEFORE Endoscopy: Don't wait for EGD to start octreotide (reduces bleeding, portal pressure) and prophylactic antibiotics (prevents SBP, bacteremia). Both improve mortality. Start in ED as soon as variceal bleeding suspected. Octreotide 50 mcg bolus then 50 mcg/hr infusion. Ceftriaxone 1 g IV x 7 days (more effective than quinolones in advanced cirrhosis). Antibiotics reduce mortality by 20% - this is standard of care.
  • Band Ligation Preferred Over Sclerotherapy: EVL (endoscopic variceal ligation) has higher success rate, lower rebleeding rate, fewer complications (strictures, ulcers, perforation) than sclerotherapy.
