Sclerotherapy involves injecting caustic sclerosant, causing inflammation, scarring, higher complication rate. Use EVL first-line. Sclerotherapy only if banding not technically feasible. Post-banding: schedule repeat sessions q2-4 weeks until varices eradicated.
  • Early TIPS (Within 72 Hours) in High-Risk Patients Improves Survival: Patients with Child-Pugh B/C with active bleeding at endoscopy or Child-Pugh C <14 points with active bleeding have high mortality. Early TIPS (within 72 hours) in this population reduces rebleeding and improves 1-year survival from 60% to 80%. Don't wait for rebleeding - consult IR for TIPS early if high-risk. Calculate Child-Pugh score at presentation.
  • HRS is Functional Renal Failure - Kidneys Are Structurally Normal: Unlike ATN or AIN, kidneys in HRS have no intrinsic damage - urinalysis is bland, kidney biopsy shows normal glomeruli. Renal failure is purely hemodynamic: severe hepatic dysfunction causes splanchnic vasodilation, effective hypovolemia, compensatory renal vasoconstriction, GFR drops. Kidneys work perfectly after liver transplant. But without transplant, HRS progresses to multiorgan failure and death. Median survival Type 1 HRS: 2 weeks without treatment.
  • Albumin Plus Vasoconstrictors (Norepinephrine or Midodrine/Octreotide) is Evidence-Based for HRS: Albumin alone doesn't reverse HRS. Need vasoconstrictor to increase systemic vascular resistance, counteract splanchnic vasodilation. Norepinephrine (ICU setting) most effective: 0.5-3 mg/hr IV, target MAP >10 mmHg increase. Alternative: midodrine (alpha-agonist) + octreotide (splanchnic vasoconstrictor). Give albumin 20-40 g IV daily. Response rate 40-50%. Continue until Cr <1.5 mg/dL or transplant.
  • Stop Diuretics in HRS - They Worsen Renal Perfusion: Common mistake: continuing spironolactone, furosemide in HRS patient with refractory ascites. Diuretics cause volume depletion, worsen renal hypoperfusion, accelerate renal failure. In HRS, hold ALL diuretics. Treat ascites with large-volume paracentesis + albumin (8 g per liter removed if >5 L removed). Accept some ascites - prioritize kidney function over comfort. Restart diuretics only if HRS resolves.
  • Large-Volume Paracentesis (>5 L) Requires Albumin Replacement: Removing >5 L ascites without albumin replacement causes post-paracentesis circulatory dysfunction (PPCD): effective hypovolemia, renal failure, hyponatremia. Give albumin 6-8 g per liter removed if >5 L total. Example: drain 8 L ascites, give 64 g albumin IV (8 L Ã— 8 g/L). Prevents PPCD, reduces mortality. <5 L: albumin not required.
  • Non-Selective Beta-Blockers (Propranolol, Nadolol) are First-Line for Primary and Secondary Variceal Prophylaxis: Reduce portal pressure by decreasing cardiac output (beta-1) and causing splanchnic vasoconstriction (beta-2 blockade on mesenteric vessels). Goal HR 55-60 bpm or 25% reduction from baseline. Start propranolol 20 mg PO BID or nadolol 20 mg daily, titrate up. Reduces bleeding risk by 40-50%. Contraindications: decompensated HF, severe COPD, severe bradycardia. Carvedilol (non-selective + alpha-blocker) may be more effective.
  • SAAG â‰¥1.1 g/dL Confirms Portal Hypertension as Cause of Ascites: Serum-Ascites Albumin Gradient = Serum albumin minus Ascitic fluid albumin. SAAG â‰¥1.1 g/dL (97% accurate) indicates portal hypertension etiology (cirrhosis, Budd-Chiari, cardiac ascites). SAAG <1.1 g/dL suggests non-portal hypertensive causes (peritoneal carcinomatosis, TB peritonitis, nephrotic syndrome, pancreatitis). Also check ascitic fluid PMN count: >250 cells/ÂµL = SBP (start ceftriaxone 2 g IV daily).
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Active variceal hemorrhage with hemodynamic instability (SBP <90, HR >120)
  • Massive GI bleeding (Hgb <7 despite transfusion, ongoing hematemesis)
  • Requires balloon tamponade (Minnesota/Sengstaken-Blakemore tube)
  • Refractory bleeding despite endoscopic therapy (needs TIPS)
  • HRS Type 1 requiring norepinephrine infusion for renal perfusion
  • Hepatic encephalopathy grade 3-4 (stupor, coma)
  • Acute liver failure or acute-on-chronic liver failure
  • Septic shock from SBP or bacteremia
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Variceal bleeding controlled, no rebleeding for 48-72 hours
  • Hemoglobin stable (>7 g/dL) without ongoing transfusion requirements
  • Hemodynamically stable (SBP >90, HR <100)
  • Tolerating PO diet without nausea/vomiting
  • On non-selective beta-blocker (nadolol 20-40 mg daily or propranolol 20 mg BID, titrate to HR 55-60 bpm) for secondary prophylaxis
  • Repeat EGD band ligation sessions scheduled (q2-4 weeks until varices eradicated)
  • Patient educated on avoiding NSAIDs, alcohol, hepatotoxic drugs
  • Hepatology follow-up within 1-2 weeks
  • If HRS: NOT a discharge diagnosis - requires ongoing treatment, transplant evaluation, or hospice discussion
  • Prophylactic antibiotics completed (7 days ceftriaxone)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

105. ACUTE-ON-CHRONIC LIVER FAILURE (ACLF)

Acute Decompensation â€¢ Organ Failure â€¢ High Short-Term Mortality â€¢ Precipitating Event
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Patient with known chronic liver disease presenting with acute decompensation and organ failure(s) - typically hepatic, renal, coagulation, circulatory, respiratory, or cerebral - triggered by a precipitating event (infection, alcohol binge, hepatotoxin), with high short-term mortality (28-day mortality 15-90% depending on grade).

  • Pathophysiology: ACLF is syndrome of acute deterioration in patients with chronic liver disease (cirrhosis or non-cirrhotic chronic liver disease) characterized by hepatic and/or extrahepatic organ failures and high short-term mortality. Unlike simple decompensated cirrhosis (ascites, variceal bleed, encephalopathy alone), ACLF involves systemic inflammatory response, multiorgan dysfunction. Precipitants: bacterial infections (SBP, pneumonia, UTI), alcohol binge, hepatotoxic drugs (acetaminophen), viral hepatitis superinfection (HBV reactivation, HEV, HSV), surgery/trauma, GI bleeding, portal vein thrombosis.
  • Risk Factors: Alcoholic cirrhosis (most common), chronic HBV/HCV, NASH, autoimmune hepatitis, active alcohol use, recent infection, immunosuppression, malnutrition, baseline MELD >15
  • Symptoms: Jaundice (rapid onset or worsening), abdominal pain/distension (ascites, peritonitis), confusion/altered mental status (hepatic encephalopathy grade 2-4), dyspnea (hepatopulmonary syndrome, pleural effusions, pulmonary edema), oliguria (HRS), hematemesis/melena (variceal bleeding), fever (infection)
  • Physical Exam: Jaundice, altered mental status (confusion, asterixis, obtundation, coma), signs of cirrhosis (spider angiomata, palmar erythema, gynecomastia, caput medusae), tense ascites, hypotension (circulatory failure, septic shock), tachypnea, hypoxia, decreased breath sounds (pleural effusions), bleeding (coagulopathy)
  • Variants/Subtypes: ACLF Grades (EASL-CLIF Consortium criteria): ACLF Grade 1 (single kidney failure, or single non-kidney organ failure with kidney dysfunction/hepatic encephalopathy), ACLF Grade 2 (2 organ failures), ACLF Grade 3 (â‰¥3 organ failures). 28-day mortality: Grade 1 (~22%), Grade 2 (~32%), Grade 3 (~76%)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Studies:

  • Complete Blood Count: Leukocytosis (infection), leukopenia (sepsis, bone marrow suppression), thrombocytopenia (<50k), anemia
  • Comprehensive Metabolic Panel: Elevated bilirubin (>5 mg/dL, often >12 mg/dL), elevated AST/ALT (can be >300-500 if acute hepatitis superimposed), hyponatremia (<130 mEq/L), elevated creatinine (HRS), hypoglycemia possible, elevated BUN
  • Coagulation Studies: Prolonged PT/INR (INR >2.0, often >2.5), prolonged PTT, low fibrinogen
  • Lactate: Elevated (>4 mmol/L) in septic shock, hepatic hypoperfusion
  • Ammonia: Often very elevated (>100 mcg/dL), correlates with hepatic encephalopathy severity
  • Arterial Blood Gas: Metabolic acidosis (sepsis, lactic acidosis), respiratory alkalosis (hepatopulmonary syndrome), hypoxemia
  • Blood Cultures: Before antibiotics; positive in 30-40% if bacteremia/SBP

Organ Failure Assessment (CLIF-SOFA Criteria):

  • Liver Failure: Bilirubin >12 mg/dL
  • Kidney Failure: Creatinine â‰¥2.0 mg/dL or RRT (dialysis)
  • Cerebral Failure: Hepatic encephalopathy grade 3-4 (West Haven criteria)
  • Coagulation Failure: INR >2.5 or platelets â‰¤20k/ÂµL
  • Circulatory Failure: MAP <70 mmHg or need for vasopressors
  • Respiratory Failure: PaO2/FiO2 <200 (or SpO2/FiO2 <214) or mechanical ventilation

Infectious Workup (CRITICAL - infection most common precipitant):

  • Paracentesis (if ascites): Cell count, culture, Gram stain. SBP: PMN >250/ÂµL. Send 10 mL into blood culture bottles at bedside
  • Chest X-ray: Pneumonia, pleural effusions
  • Urinalysis and Urine Culture: UTI common
  • Blood Cultures: X 2 sets from separate sites
  • Other: Sputum culture if pneumonia, stool studies if diarrhea

Imaging:

  • Chest X-ray: Pneumonia, pleural effusions, pulmonary edema, ARDS
  • CT Abdomen/Pelvis: Assess for intra-abdominal abscess, portal vein thrombosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, bowel perforation
  • Liver Ultrasound with Doppler: Assess portal vein patency (thrombosis), hepatic vein patency (Budd-Chiari), hepatic masses

Additional Testing:

  • Viral Hepatitis Panel: HBsAg, anti-HCV, HBV DNA/HCV RNA (check for reactivation), HEV IgM (acute hepatitis E - consider in travelers)
  • Acetaminophen Level: If concern for overdose (intentional or unintentional)
  • Alcohol Level: If intoxication suspected
  • Toxicology Screen: For other hepatotoxins
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Management (ICU Level Care):

  • Transfer to ICU (ACLF Grade 2-3 always ICU, Grade 1 consider ICU)
  • IV access, arterial line, central venous catheter if needed
  • Hemodynamic monitoring: continuous telemetry, frequent vitals
  • Airway protection: intubate if hepatic encephalopathy grade 3-4 (GCS <8)
  • Strict I&O, Foley catheter for accurate urine output monitoring

Identify and Treat Precipitating Factor:

  • Bacterial Infection (50-60% of ACLF cases):
    • Empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics (before culture results)
    • If SBP suspected/confirmed: Ceftriaxone 2 g IV daily or Piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375 g IV q6h
    • Add Albumin if SBP: 1.5 g/kg IV on day 1, then 1 g/kg on day 3 (reduces HRS, improves survival)
    • If healthcare-associated or prior antibiotic exposure: consider carbapenem (Meropenem 1 g IV q8h)
  • Alcohol-Related (30% of ACLF):
    • Abstinence counseling, addiction medicine consult
    • Nutritional support: thiamine 100 mg IV daily, folate 1 mg daily, multivitamin
    • Consider corticosteroids if alcoholic hepatitis (Maddrey Discriminant Function â‰¥32): Prednisolone 40 mg PO daily x 28 days
  • Hepatotoxic Drug (Acetaminophen, etc.):
    • N-acetylcysteine (NAC) if acetaminophen: 150 mg/kg IV loading dose over 1 hr, then 50 mg/kg over 4 hrs, then 100 mg/kg over 16 hrs
    • Stop all hepatotoxic medications
  • Viral Hepatitis Reactivation:
    • HBV: Entecavir 0.5 mg PO daily or Tenofovir 300 mg PO daily
    • HCV: Defer direct-acting antivirals until acute phase stabilizes
    • HSV hepatitis (rare): Acyclovir 10 mg/kg IV q8h
  • Variceal Bleeding: Octreotide, endoscopy, TIPS if refractory (see Condition 78)

Organ Support:

  • Hepatic Encephalopathy:
    • Lactulose: 30-45 mL PO/NG q2-4h until 2-3 soft bowel movements per day. Goal: reduce ammonia
    • Rifaximin: 550 mg PO BID (adjunct to lactulose)
    • Avoid sedatives (benzodiazepines, opioids worsen encephalopathy)
    • Correct precipitants: GI bleeding, infection, constipation, hypokalemia
  • Renal Support (HRS):
    • Albumin + Midodrine/Octreotide or Norepinephrine (see Condition 78)
    • Continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) if severe AKI, volume overload, refractory hyperkalemia
  • Circulatory Support:
    • Fluid resuscitation: Albumin preferred over crystalloid (25% albumin 100 mL IV boluses)
    • Vasopressors: Norepinephrine first-line (0.1-1 mcg/kg/min), target MAP >65 mmHg
    • Avoid over-resuscitation (worsens ascites, portal pressure)
  • Respiratory Support:
    • Supplemental oxygen to maintain SpO2 >92%
    • Mechanical ventilation if severe hypoxemia (PaO2/FiO2 <200), hepatic encephalopathy grade 3-4
    • Lung-protective ventilation if ARDS
  • Coagulopathy:
    • Do NOT routinely correct INR (worsens outcomes, causes volume overload)
    • Transfuse FFP/platelets ONLY if active bleeding or procedure (goal platelets >50k, INR <2.0 for high-risk procedure)
    • Consider prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) if urgent reversal needed

Nutrition:

  • Early enteral nutrition (within 48 hours) improves outcomes
  • High-protein diet (1.2-1.5 g/kg/day) - old myth about protein restriction is FALSE
  • Branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) may help encephalopathy
  • Avoid prolonged fasting (worsens muscle wasting, encephalopathy)

Liver Transplant Evaluation (URGENT):

  • Contact transplant center immediately for all ACLF Grade 2-3
  • ACLF patients may improve with supportive care OR deteriorate rapidly - need early transplant assessment
  • Criteria: Too sick to survive without transplant, not too sick to survive transplant (ACLF Grade 3 with multiorgan failure may have futile outcome even with transplant)
  • Contraindications: Active alcohol/drug use, extrahepatic malignancy, severe cardiopulmonary disease, active septic shock (relative)

Consultations:

  • Hepatology: Immediate consult for all ACLF, co-manage with ICU
  • Transplant Surgery: Urgent evaluation for Grade 2-3 ACLF
  • Nephrology: For HRS management, CRRT
  • Critical Care: ICU admission, multiorgan support
  • Infectious Disease: If multidrug-resistant organisms, fungal infection, or unusual infections

Disposition:

  • ICU: All ACLF Grade 2-3, ACLF Grade 1 with shock/encephalopathy, any organ failure requiring intensive monitoring/support
  • Floor: NOT appropriate for ACLF - this is ICU-level disease by definition
  • Hospice: Consider if ACLF Grade 3, not transplant candidate, multiorgan failure, poor prognosis despite maximal therapy
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • ACLF is NOT the Same as Simple Decompensated Cirrhosis: Decompensated cirrhosis (new onset ascites, variceal bleed, encephalopathy) is manageable on floor, has lower mortality. ACLF involves ORGAN FAILURES (hepatic, renal, cerebral, coag, circulatory, respiratory) and has very high short-term mortality (15-90%). ACLF Grade 3 with â‰¥3 organ failures has 28-day mortality 76%. ACLF requires ICU, aggressive intervention, urgent transplant evaluation. Don't confuse the two - ACLF is much more serious.
  • Infection is the Most Common Precipitant (50-60% of Cases): SBP, pneumonia, UTI, bacteremia trigger systemic inflammatory response, organ failures. Always have high suspicion for infection - do paracentesis if ascites (SBP), CXR (pneumonia), UA/UCx (UTI), blood cultures. Start empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics early (ceftriaxone 2 g IV daily). If SBP confirmed: add albumin 1.5 g/kg day 1, 1 g/kg day 3 (reduces HRS, improves survival by 30%). Don't delay antibiotics waiting for culture results.
  • ACLF Can Develop in Non-Cirrhotic Chronic Liver Disease: Most ACLF occurs in cirrhotic patients, but 30-40% develop in patients with chronic liver disease without established cirrhosis (chronic HBV/HCV, NASH, autoimmune hepatitis). Acute precipitant (HBV reactivation, alcohol binge, hepatotoxin) in patient with chronic liver disease causes acute hepatic injury, systemic inflammation, extrahepatic organ failures. These patients can still develop ACLF and have similar mortality to cirrhotic patients.
  • High-Protein Diet in Liver Disease is NOT Contraindicated: Old myth: protein restriction prevents hepatic encephalopathy. FALSE. Protein restriction causes malnutrition, sarcopenia, worse outcomes. Current guidelines: 1.2-1.5 g/kg/day protein for all liver disease patients. If encephalopathy develops: treat with lactulose/rifaximin, NOT protein restriction. Exception: acute hyperammonemia with hepatic encephalopathy grade 3-4 may temporarily reduce protein for 24-48 hours, then resume. Adequate nutrition is critical for survival in ACLF.
  • Albumin is More Than Just Volume Expander - It's Anti-Inflammatory in ACLF: Albumin has pleiotropic effects beyond oncotic pressure: binds endotoxins, reduces systemic inflammation, improves endothelial function, reduces oxidative stress. In SBP: albumin reduces HRS and improves survival. In large-volume paracentesis (>5 L): prevents circulatory dysfunction. In ACLF: albumin preferred over crystalloid for resuscitation. Dose: 25% albumin 100 mL (25 g) boluses. Don't just give saline - use albumin liberally in ACLF.
  • Grading ACLF (Grade 1, 2, 3) Predicts Mortality and Guides Transplant Urgency: CLIF-SOFA criteria define organ failures (liver, kidney, cerebral, coag, circulatory, respiratory). Grade 1 = 1 organ failure (22% mortality), Grade 2 = 2 organ failures (32% mortality), Grade 3 = â‰¥3 organ failures (76% mortality at 28 days). Grade 3 patients need urgent transplant evaluation but may be too sick to survive even with transplant. Grade 2 patients are ideal transplant candidates - sick enough to need it, well enough to survive it. Calculate ACLF grade on admission.
  • Do NOT Routinely Correct INR with FFP in ACLF: Elevated INR in cirrhosis reflects decreased synthesis of both pro-coagulant and anti-coagulant factors - patients are in rebalanced hemostasis, not actually "coagulopathic." Giving FFP causes volume overload, worsens ascites, increases portal pressure, no survival benefit. Transfuse FFP/platelets ONLY if active bleeding or high-risk procedure (goal platelets >50k, INR <2.0). Otherwise, accept elevated INR. Exception: severe coagulopathy (INR >5.0) with bleeding may warrant PCC (4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate).
  • Corticosteroids in Severe Alcoholic Hepatitis (Component of Some ACLF Cases): If ACLF precipitated by severe alcoholic hepatitis (AST:ALT ratio >2:1, bilirubin >5 mg/dL, recent heavy alcohol use), calculate Maddrey Discriminant Function (MDF) = 4.6 Ã— (PT patient - PT control) + Bilirubin. If MDF â‰¥32: consider prednisolone 40 mg PO daily x 28 days (reduces mortality). But corticosteroids controversial if active infection. Lille score at day 7 predicts response: if Lille score â‰¥0.45 (non-responder), stop steroids.
  • Liver Transplant is the Only Definitive Treatment for ACLF but Timing is Critical: ACLF patients are prioritized on transplant list (high MELD scores due to bilirubin, INR, creatinine). But transplanting patient in ACLF Grade 3 with â‰¥3 organ failures and septic shock has poor outcomes (may not survive surgery). Ideal candidates: ACLF Grade 2, improving with treatment but still need transplant, no active sepsis. Early transplant evaluation critical - don't wait until patient too sick. If ACLF Grade 3 persists despite maximal therapy, survival with or without transplant is dismal - consider palliative care.
  • N-Acetylcysteine (NAC) May Benefit Non-Acetaminophen ACLF: NAC traditionally used for acetaminophen overdose, but emerging data suggests benefit in non-acetaminophen acute liver failure and possibly ACLF (antioxidant, improves tissue oxygenation, reduces systemic inflammation). Some centers use NAC in ACLF patients even without acetaminophen exposure. Dose: 150 mg/kg IV over 1 hr, then 50 mg/kg over 4 hrs, then 100 mg/kg over 16 hrs (can continue longer). Low risk, may improve encephalopathy and survival. Not yet standard of care but consider in severe cases.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • ALL patients with ACLF Grade 2-3 (â‰¥2 organ failures) - ICU mandatory
  • ACLF Grade 1 with hemodynamic instability, shock, hepatic encephalopathy grade 3-4
  • Respiratory failure (PaO2/FiO2 <200, mechanical ventilation needed)
  • Circulatory failure (MAP <70 mmHg, vasopressor requirement)
  • Acute kidney injury requiring CRRT (Cr >2.0 mg/dL or oliguria)
  • Severe hepatic encephalopathy (grade 3-4, obtundation, coma)
  • Severe coagulopathy with active bleeding (INR >3.0, platelets <20k)
  • Septic shock, lactate >4 mmol/L
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • ACLF is NOT a discharge diagnosis - most patients either improve (downgrade to compensated cirrhosis) or deteriorate (transplant or death)
  • If patient improves from ACLF to compensated cirrhosis: precipitant treated, organ failures resolved, stable for 48-72 hours off organ support
  • Close hepatology follow-up within 1 week
  • Transplant evaluation completed or scheduled
  • Abstinence from alcohol if relevant
  • Medications optimized: diuretics, beta-blockers, lactulose/rifaximin if history of encephalopathy
  • Patient/family educated on red flags: jaundice, confusion, abdominal pain, fever, bleeding, dyspnea
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

106. ISCHEMIC BOWEL / MESENTERIC ISCHEMIA

Severe Abdominal Pain â€¢ Pain Out of Proportion â€¢ Lactic Acidosis â€¢ Bowel Necrosis
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Acute onset of severe, diffuse abdominal pain that is "out of proportion to physical exam findings" (severe pain with minimal tenderness), often with bloody diarrhea, lactic acidosis, and rapid clinical deterioration. Most common in elderly with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerotic disease.

  • Pathophysiology: Acute interruption of blood flow to intestines causes bowel ischemia, progressing to infarction and necrosis if not rapidly reversed. Four main types: (1) Arterial embolism (50%): AF, MI, valvular disease â†’ emboli to SMA; (2) Arterial thrombosis (15-25%): atherosclerotic plaque in SMA/celiac axis thromboses; (3) Non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia (NOMI, 20-30%): low cardiac output state (HF, shock, dialysis) causes mesenteric vasoconstriction; (4) Venous thrombosis (10%): hypercoagulable state â†’ SMV/portal vein thrombosis. Mortality 60-80% if bowel infarction occurs.
  • Risk Factors: Arterial: Atrial fibrillation (most important), recent MI, valvular heart disease (endocarditis), aortic atherosclerosis, prior embolism, hypotension, vasopressor use, cocaine. Venous: Hypercoagulable states (Factor V Leiden, protein C/S deficiency, malignancy, OCP use, pregnancy), portal hypertension, cirrhosis, pancreatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, intra-abdominal infection/abscess
  • Symptoms: Sudden onset severe, constant abdominal pain (often periumbilical or diffuse), early: pain out of proportion to exam (pathognomonic), nausea, vomiting, diarrhea (often bloody), urgency to defecate (early sign), abdominal distension (late - ileus, necrosis)
  • Physical Exam: Early (hours 0-6): Minimal abdominal tenderness despite severe pain (hallmark), normal or hypoactive bowel sounds, tachycardia, no peritoneal signs. Late (hours 6-24): Peritoneal signs develop (rebound, guarding, rigidity), absent bowel sounds (ileus), abdominal distension, hemodynamic instability (shock), bloody rectal exam (late finding). Classically described as "pain out of proportion" - patient writhing in agony but abdomen soft on exam (early).
  • Variants/Subtypes: Acute mesenteric ischemia (discussed here) vs Chronic mesenteric ischemia ("intestinal angina" - postprandial pain, weight loss, food fear, chronic). Colonic ischemia (separate entity, see pearl)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Studies:

  • Lactate: MOST IMPORTANT. Elevated (>2 mmol/L) in 90% of cases. Lactate >3 mmol/L highly concerning. Lactate >4-5 mmol/L suggests transmural ischemia/necrosis. Serial lactates: rising lactate = worsening ischemia. NOTE: normal lactate does NOT rule out mesenteric ischemia - 10% have normal lactate early
  • Complete Blood Count: Leukocytosis (>15k common, >20k suggests necrosis), hemoconcentration, later: leukopenia (sepsis)
  • Basic Metabolic Panel: Metabolic acidosis (elevated anion gap from lactic acidosis), elevated BUN/Cr (prerenal from hypovolemia), hyperkalemia (cell death)
  • Liver Function Tests: Elevated AST/ALT (hepatic hypoperfusion), elevated alkaline phosphatase, elevated LDH (nonspecific)
  • Amylase/Lipase: Can be mildly elevated (nonspecific); helps rule out pancreatitis
  • D-dimer: Often very elevated (>1000 ng/mL) but non-specific. Normal D-dimer has high negative predictive value (helps rule out)
  • Arterial Blood Gas: Metabolic acidosis (pH <7.35, low HCO3), elevated lactate, base deficit
  • Coagulation Studies: If venous thrombosis suspected, check PT/INR, PTT, consider hypercoagulability workup (protein C/S, Factor V Leiden, antiphospholipid antibodies, JAK2 mutation)

Imaging - CT Angiography (CTA) Abdomen/Pelvis (GOLD STANDARD):

  • Diagnostic test of choice - 90-95% sensitive and specific
  • MUST be done with IV contrast in arterial phase to visualize mesenteric vessels
  • Findings - Arterial occlusion: SMA filling defect/occlusion, lack of contrast enhancement of bowel wall, pneumatosis intestinalis (air in bowel wall - ominous), portal venous gas (late sign, poor prognosis), free air (perforation)
  • Findings - Venous thrombosis: SMV or portal vein thrombus, bowel wall thickening, mesenteric edema/stranding, ascites
  • Findings - NOMI: Patent but narrowed mesenteric vessels, bowel wall thinning or thickening, no discrete occlusion
  • Contraindications: Renal insufficiency (risk vs benefit - ischemic bowel is fatal without diagnosis, contrast nephropathy is manageable)

Alternative Imaging:

  • Abdominal X-ray (Supine and Upright): Low sensitivity (30%) but fast. Findings (late): pneumatosis intestinalis (air in bowel wall), portal venous gas, free air (perforation), ileus, "thumbprinting" (mucosal edema). Normal X-ray does NOT rule out mesenteric ischemia
  • Duplex Ultrasound: Can assess SMA/celiac artery stenosis, SMV thrombosis. Operator-dependent, bowel gas limits visualization. Not useful in acute setting
  • Conventional Angiography: Gold standard for diagnosis and potential intervention (intra-arterial vasodilators for NOMI, thrombolysis/embolectomy). Invasive, used therapeutically more than diagnostically now that CTA is excellent

Diagnostic Laparotomy/Laparoscopy:

  • If high clinical suspicion (severe pain, lactate elevated, peritonitis) but imaging non-diagnostic or unavailable, proceed to exploratory laparotomy
  • "Don't let the sun set on mesenteric ischemia" - early surgery improves survival
  • Directly visualize bowel: necrotic bowel (black, gangrenous), lack of peristalsis, lack of pulsations in mesenteric vessels
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Management (TIME IS BOWEL - Urgent Action Required):

  • NPO, NGT to suction (decompress bowel)
  • IV access: Two large-bore IVs
  • Aggressive fluid resuscitation: LR or NS 1-2 L bolus, continue at 200-300 mL/hr (maintain perfusion pressure)
  • Hemodynamic support: Target MAP >65 mmHg, maintain adequate perfusion
  • Correct acidosis: IV fluids, treat underlying ischemia (acidosis corrects with reperfusion)
  • URGENT Vascular Surgery + General Surgery Consultation (within 1 hour of suspected diagnosis)
  • URGENT CTA if patient stable enough for imaging; if unstable or peritonitis â†’ direct to OR

Antibiotics (Broad-Spectrum - Start Immediately):

  • Ischemic bowel â†’ bacterial translocation, high risk of sepsis and peritonitis
  • Piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375-4.5 g IV q6h
  • Or Meropenem 1 g IV q8h (if severe sepsis or recent antibiotics)
  • Or Ceftriaxone 2 g IV daily + Metronidazole 500 mg IV q8h
  • Continue until after surgery, typically 5-7 days postoperatively

Anticoagulation:

  • If Arterial Embolism or Thrombosis Confirmed (and no contraindications):
    • Heparin bolus 80 units/kg IV (max 5000 units), then infusion 18 units/kg/hr
    • Goal PTT 60-80 seconds
    • Prevents clot propagation, allows collateral flow to develop
    • Hold before surgery but restart postoperatively if feasible
  • If Venous Thrombosis (SMV/portal vein thrombosis):
    • Anticoagulation is primary treatment if NO bowel necrosis
    • Heparin drip (as above) or LMWH (enoxaparin 1 mg/kg SC q12h)
    • Transition to warfarin (INR 2-3) for 3-6 months minimum, possibly lifelong if unprovoked or hypercoagulable state
    • If bowel necrosis: surgery first, anticoagulate postoperatively

Specific Treatments by Etiology:

  • Arterial Embolism (50%):
    • EMERGENT SURGERY: Open embolectomy or bypass
    • Laparotomy â†’ SMA embolectomy via Fogarty catheter â†’ assess bowel viability â†’ resect necrotic segments
    • If viable bowel after revascularization: "second look" laparotomy in 24-48 hours to reassess (some bowel may declare itself non-viable later)
    • Postoperative anticoagulation (prevent recurrence)
  • Arterial Thrombosis (15-25%):
    • EMERGENT SURGERY: Bypass grafting (aorto-SMA bypass) or endarterectomy
    • More technically difficult than embolism (extensive atherosclerosis)
    • Higher mortality than embolic disease
  • Non-Occlusive Mesenteric Ischemia (NOMI, 20-30%):
    • Optimize hemodynamics: Fluids, stop vasopressors if possible, treat underlying shock/HF
    • Intra-arterial vasodilators via angiography: Papaverine 30-60 mg/hr continuous intra-arterial infusion into SMA (reverses vasoconstriction). Requires IR/angiography
    • If peritonitis or necrosis: SURGERY for bowel resection
    • NOMI has highest mortality (70-90%) because patients are critically ill at baseline
  • Venous Thrombosis (10%):
    • If NO peritonitis, NO bowel necrosis: MEDICAL management with anticoagulation alone (see above)
    • If peritonitis or suspected necrosis: SURGERY â†’ resect necrotic bowel â†’ postoperative anticoagulation
    • Better prognosis than arterial occlusion (slower onset, more collateral flow)

Surgical Principles:

  • Revascularization (embolectomy, thrombectomy, bypass) takes priority over resection
  • After revascularization, wait 15-30 minutes, reassess bowel viability: look for peristalsis, pink color, arterial pulsations
  • Resect clearly necrotic bowel (black, no pulses, no peristalsis)
  • Leave questionable bowel â†’ "second look" laparotomy in 24-48 hours
  • If extensive necrosis (>50% of small bowel): discuss prognosis with family, consider short bowel syndrome implications

Postoperative Care:

  • ICU monitoring
  • Serial lactates (should normalize after successful reperfusion/resection)
  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics continue 5-7 days
  • Anticoagulation (arterial and venous cases)
  • NPO, TPN until bowel function returns
  • Scheduled "second look" laparotomy if planned (24-48 hours after initial surgery)

Consultations:

  • Vascular Surgery: URGENT consult within 1 hour for arterial occlusion (embolectomy, bypass)
  • General Surgery: URGENT consult for bowel resection, exploratory laparotomy
  • Interventional Radiology: For angiography with papaverine infusion (NOMI), catheter-directed thrombolysis
  • Critical Care: ICU admission for hemodynamic support

Disposition:

  • ICU: ALL patients with mesenteric ischemia require ICU care (pre-op and post-op)
  • Operating Room: EMERGENTLY if peritonitis, bowel necrosis, or arterial occlusion
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • "Pain Out of Proportion to Physical Exam" is the Hallmark: Early mesenteric ischemia (hours 0-6): patient writhing in severe, unrelenting abdominal pain, but exam shows soft abdomen with minimal tenderness, no rebound, no guarding. This discrepancy is pathognomonic. Why? Ischemia causes visceral pain (poorly localized, severe) but no peritoneal irritation yet (bowel wall hasn't necro sed). Once peritoneal signs develop (6-24 hours later), bowel is necrotic - prognosis much worse. If you see severe pain with benign exam in elderly patient with AF â†’ think mesenteric ischemia, get CTA immediately.
  • "Don't Let the Sun Set on Mesenteric Ischemia" - Time is Bowel: Mortality increases dramatically with delay. If revascularization occurs within 6 hours: mortality 30-50%. If 12-24 hours: mortality 70-90%. Bowel can tolerate ischemia for only 3-6 hours before irreversible necrosis. This is analogous to "time is brain" in stroke. High index of suspicion â†’ immediate CTA â†’ emergent surgery. Don't wait overnight, don't "observe." If strong clinical suspicion and patient has peritoneal signs, skip imaging and go directly to OR for exploratory laparotomy.
  • Atrial Fibrillation is the #1 Risk Factor for Arterial Mesenteric Ischemia: AF â†’ left atrial thrombus â†’ embolus to superior mesenteric artery (SMA). SMA supplies entire small bowel and proximal colon - occlusion is catastrophic. Elderly patient with AF who suddenly develops severe abdominal pain = mesenteric embolism until proven otherwise. 50% of acute mesenteric ischemia is embolic. Risk highest with AF not on anticoagulation, or new-onset AF (before anticoagulation started). Lesson: anticoagulate AF patients (prevents stroke AND mesenteric ischemia).
  • Lactate is the Most Important Lab but Normal Lactate Does NOT Rule Out Mesenteric Ischemia: 90% of mesenteric ischemia cases have elevated lactate (>2 mmol/L). Lactate >4 mmol/L strongly suggests transmural necrosis. BUT 10% have normal lactate in early stages. Why? Ischemia is patchy initially, limited anaerobic metabolism, collateral flow. So: elevated lactate in right clinical context = order CTA immediately. Normal lactate with high clinical suspicion = still order CTA, don't be falsely reassured. Serial lactates: rising = worsening, falling after surgery = good sign (successful reperfusion).
  • CTA Abdomen/Pelvis with IV Contrast in Arterial Phase is Diagnostic Test of Choice: 90-95% sensitive and specific. Shows SMA occlusion, SMV thrombosis, pneumatosis (air in bowel wall - ominous), portal venous gas (very late, poor prognosis). CTA has replaced conventional angiography for diagnosis (angiography still used therapeutically for papaverine infusion in NOMI). Order CTA if patient hemodynamically stable. If patient hypotensive, peritonitis, or CTA not immediately available â†’ skip imaging, go directly to OR (exploratory laparotomy).
  • NOMI (Non-Occlusive Mesenteric Ischemia) Has Worst Prognosis: 20-30% of mesenteric ischemia cases. Occurs in critically ill patients: cardiogenic shock, septic shock, post-cardiac surgery, dialysis patients, cocaine users. Low cardiac output â†’ mesenteric vasoconstriction â†’ bowel ischemia WITHOUT discrete arterial occlusion. CTA shows patent but narrowed vessels, no thrombus. Treatment: optimize hemodynamics (fluids, inotropes, avoid vasoconstrictors), intra-arterial papaverine via angiography (reverses vasospasm). Mortality 70-90% because underlying critical illness + bowel ischemia = dismal prognosis. Surgery if bowel necrosis.
  • Mesenteric Venous Thrombosis Can Be Treated Medically if Caught Early: Unlike arterial occlusion (always requires surgery unless purely NOMI), mesenteric venous thrombosis WITHOUT peritonitis or necrosis can be managed with anticoagulation alone. SMV/portal vein thrombosis develops more slowly (days to weeks), allows collateral flow. If caught early (abdominal pain, CT showing thrombus, no peritoneal signs, no free air): start heparin drip, transition to warfarin INR 2-3 x 3-6 months. Surgery only if necrosis suspected. Check for hypercoagulable states (Factor V Leiden, protein C/S deficiency, JAK2, cancer).
  • Second-Look Laparotomy is Often Necessary: After initial revascularization and resection of obviously necrotic bowel, surgeons often leave "questionable" bowel (dusky, no obvious necrosis but poor perfusion). Plan "second look" laparotomy in 24-48 hours to reassess viability. Why? Some ischemic bowel may recover with reperfusion; some borderline bowel may declare itself necrotic over next 24 hours. Second-look allows reassessment, resection of newly necrotic segments, avoids over-resection initially. Decreases short bowel syndrome risk. Second-look is standard of care in mesenteric ischemia surgery.
  • Acute Mesenteric Ischemia vs Colonic Ischemia Are Different Entities: Acute mesenteric ischemia (discussed here): SMA/IMA/celiac occlusion, involves small bowel Â± colon, severe, high mortality, requires surgery. Colonic ischemia: isolated ischemia of colon (usually "watershed" areas: splenic flexure, sigmoid), caused by hypotension, low cardiac output, NOT embolic. Presents with bloody diarrhea, mild abdominal pain, benign exam. Diagnosed by CT (colonic wall thickening, "thumbprinting"). Treatment: supportive care (fluids, bowel rest, broad-spectrum antibiotics). Most resolve spontaneously. Surgery only if perforation, gangrene. Don't confuse the two - colonic ischemia is much less severe.
  • Pneumatosis Intestinalis and Portal Venous Gas are Late, Ominous Findings: Pneumatosis = air in bowel wall (CT shows linear lucencies in bowel wall). Portal venous gas = air in portal vein/hepatic veins (CT shows branching lucencies in liver periphery). These findings indicate transmural necrosis, bacterial translocation. Pneumatosis has 40-50% mortality, portal venous gas 50-75% mortality. If you see these on CT â†’ patient needs emergency surgery (likely already has necrotic bowel). These are NOT incidental findings - they signify advanced disease.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • ALL patients with suspected or confirmed acute mesenteric ischemia â†’ ICU
  • Severe abdominal pain out of proportion to exam
  • Lactate >2 mmol/L with clinical suspicion
  • Peritoneal signs (rebound, guarding, rigidity)
  • Hemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachycardia, shock)
  • Severe metabolic acidosis (pH <7.3, lactate >4 mmol/L)
  • Post-operative from bowel resection/revascularization
  • This is a surgical emergency with 60-80% mortality - ICU care is mandatory
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Mesenteric ischemia is NOT a discharge diagnosis - patients require surgery or die
  • Post-operative patients discharge when:
    • Bowel function returned (passing flatus/stool, tolerating PO diet)
    • No signs of infection (afebrile, WBC normalizing)
    • Adequate pain control on oral analgesics
    • Lactate normalized
    • Anticoagulation established if indicated (therapeutic INR 2-3 on warfarin, or DOAC started)
    • Cardiology follow-up for AF if relevant (rate/rhythm control, long-term anticoagulation)
    • Vascular surgery follow-up within 1-2 weeks
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

107. CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE COMPLICATIONS

Hyperkalemia â€¢ Volume Overload â€¢ Metabolic Acidosis â€¢ Uremia â€¢ Dialysis Urgency
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Patient with known CKD (GFR <60 mL/min/1.73mÂ²) presenting with acute decompensation: severe hyperkalemia, volume overload with pulmonary edema, worsening uremia, metabolic acidosis, or acute-on-chronic renal failure requiring urgent dialysis consideration.

  • Pathophysiology: Progressive nephron loss leads to inability to maintain fluid/electrolyte homeostasis, acid-base balance, and toxin excretion. Acute decompensation triggered by: medication non-compliance (missed dialysis, dietary indiscretion), infection, volume overload, NSAIDs/nephrotoxins, obstruction, hypotension. Key complications: (1) Hyperkalemia (K >6.0 mEq/L, cardiac arrest risk), (2) Volume overload (pulmonary edema, hypertensive urgency), (3) Metabolic acidosis (HCO3 <15 mEq/L), (4) Uremia (pericarditis, encephalopathy, bleeding), (5) Mineral-bone disease (hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, secondary hyperparathyroidism)
  • Risk Factors: CKD Stage 4-5 (GFR <30 mL/min), diabetes mellitus, hypertension, ESRD on dialysis (missed sessions), medication non-adherence, dietary indiscretion (high K, high Na, high fluid), ACE-I/ARB use, potassium-sparing diuretics, NSAIDs, contrast exposure, infections (UTI, sepsis), obstructive uropathy
  • Symptoms: Dyspnea (pulmonary edema), chest pain (pericarditis, ACS), muscle weakness (hyperkalemia), nausea/vomiting (uremia), confusion/altered mental status (uremic encephalopathy), pruritus (uremia), decreased urine output (oliguria/anuria), palpitations (arrhythmias from hyperkalemia)
  • Physical Exam: Hypertension (often severe, >180/110), rales/crackles (pulmonary edema), elevated JVP, peripheral edema (2-4+), pericardial friction rub (uremic pericarditis), altered mental status, asterixis, uremic frost (white crystalline deposits on skin - rare), pallor (anemia), excoriation marks (pruritus)
  • Variants/Subtypes: CKD Stage 3a (GFR 45-59, usually stable) vs Stage 3b (GFR 30-44) vs Stage 4 (GFR 15-29, pre-dialysis) vs Stage 5 (GFR <15, ESRD requiring RRT). Acute-on-chronic kidney injury (rapid GFR decline superimposed on CKD). Dialysis-dependent ESRD (missed dialysis sessions = acute decompensation)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Studies:

  • Basic Metabolic Panel: Elevated BUN/Cr (baseline Cr varies; acute rise >0.3 mg/dL concerning), hyperkalemia (K >5.5 mEq/L concerning, >6.5 mEq/L emergency), metabolic acidosis (HCO3 <22 mEq/L in CKD, <15 mEq/L severe), hyperphosphatemia (PO4 >5.5 mg/dL), hyponatremia or hypernatremia, elevated anion gap (uremic acidosis)
  • Complete Blood Count: Normocytic anemia (low Hgb typical 8-10 g/dL in CKD from low EPO), thrombocytopenia if uremia severe
  • Calcium/Magnesium: Hypocalcemia (ionized Ca <1.0 mmol/L), hyperphosphatemia, elevated PTH (secondary hyperparathyroidism)
  • Arterial Blood Gas: Metabolic acidosis (pH <7.35, low HCO3, elevated anion gap), assess for respiratory compensation
  • ECG (CRITICAL for hyperkalemia): Peaked T waves (K 5.5-6.5), loss of P waves (K 6.5-7.0), widened QRS (K >7.0), sine wave pattern (K >8.0, pre-cardiac arrest), bradycardia, AV blocks, ventricular arrhythmias
  • Urinalysis: Assess for infection (pyuria, bacteria), obstruction, new proteinuria/hematuria
  • Other: PTH (elevated in CKD-MBD), albumin, troponin (if chest pain), BNP (if dyspnea/volume overload)

Imaging:

  • Chest X-ray: Pulmonary edema (perihilar infiltrates, Kerley B lines, pleural effusions), cardiomegaly, pericardial effusion (uremic pericarditis)
  • Renal Ultrasound: Assess kidney size (small echogenic kidneys = chronic disease), hydronephrosis (obstruction), renal artery stenosis (Doppler). Helps differentiate acute vs chronic kidney disease
  • Echocardiogram: If pericardial effusion suspected (pericardial friction rub, muffled heart sounds), assess LV function, valvular disease

Assessment of Acute vs Chronic Kidney Injury:

  • Acute-on-chronic: Rapid rise in Cr (>0.3 mg/dL in 48 hours or >1.5x baseline in 7 days)
  • Chronic: Small kidneys (<9 cm), anemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, elevated PTH
  • Review prior Cr values (establish baseline renal function)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Management (Priority-Based):

  • 1. Hyperkalemia (MOST URGENT - cardiac arrest risk): See detailed protocol below
  • 2. Volume Overload/Pulmonary Edema: Oxygen, diuresis, consider dialysis
  • 3. Severe Metabolic Acidosis (pH <7.2): Sodium bicarbonate, consider dialysis
  • 4. Uremic Complications: Urgent dialysis if pericarditis, encephalopathy, bleeding

HYPERKALEMIA MANAGEMENT (K >6.0 mEq/L or ECG changes):

  • Step 1 - Cardiac Membrane Stabilization (if ECG changes present):
    • Calcium gluconate 10% 1-2 grams (10-20 mL) IV over 2-5 minutes
    • Or Calcium chloride 10% 0.5-1 gram (5-10 mL) IV over 2-5 minutes (via central line preferred)
    • Onset: 1-3 minutes, Duration: 30-60 minutes
    • Does NOT lower K, just stabilizes cardiac membranes
    • Repeat dose if ECG changes persist after 5 minutes
  • Step 2 - Shift Potassium Intracellularly:
    • Insulin + Glucose: Regular insulin 10 units IV + D50 50 mL (25 grams dextrose) IV push. Onset: 15-30 minutes, Duration: 4-6 hours, Lowers K by 0.5-1.2 mEq/L. Check glucose q1h (risk of hypoglycemia). If glucose >250 mg/dL, give insulin without dextrose
    • Albuterol Nebulized: 10-20 mg nebulized over 10 minutes (4-8 times standard dose). Onset: 30 minutes, Duration: 2 hours, Lowers K by 0.5-1.0 mEq/L. Synergistic with insulin
    • Sodium Bicarbonate (if acidotic): 150 mEq (3 amps, 50 mEq each) in 1 L D5W over 2-4 hours. Only effective if metabolic acidosis present (pH <7.2, HCO3 <15). Lowers K by 0.5 mEq/L
  • Step 3 - Remove Potassium from Body:
    • Diuretics (if residual kidney function): Furosemide 40-80 mg IV push (increase to 160-200 mg if CKD Stage 4-5). Promotes renal K excretion
    • Patiromer (Veltassa): 8.4 g PO daily, increase to 25.2 g daily. Onset: 4-7 hours. GI K binder. For non-emergent or chronic management
    • Sodium Zirconium Cyclosilicate (Lokelma): 10 g PO TID x 48 hours, then 10 g PO daily. Onset: 1 hour. Faster than patiromer
    • Sodium Polystyrene Sulfonate (Kayexalate) - AVOID if possible: 15-30 g PO/PR. Onset: 2-4 hours. Risk of bowel necrosis (especially with sorbitol). Use only if other binders unavailable
    • Hemodialysis: MOST EFFECTIVE. Removes 50-75 mEq K per session. Indicated if K >6.5 mEq/L with ECG changes, K >7.0 mEq/L, refractory to medical management, or anuric ESRD patient
  • Monitoring: Continuous telemetry, repeat K q2h until <5.5 mEq/L, repeat ECG after interventions

VOLUME OVERLOAD / PULMONARY EDEMA MANAGEMENT:

  • Oxygen: Supplemental O2 to maintain SpO2 >92%
  • Positioning: Upright position (reduces preload)
  • Diuretics (if residual kidney function, GFR >15 mL/min):
    • Furosemide 80-200 mg IV push (higher doses in CKD)
    • If inadequate response: Furosemide continuous infusion 10-40 mg/hr
    • Add thiazide diuretic for synergy: Metolazone 5-10 mg PO 30 minutes before furosemide
  • Nitroglycerin (if hypertensive): 0.4 mg SL q5min x 3, or IV infusion 10-200 mcg/min
  • Ultrafiltration/Dialysis: If minimal urine output (<400 mL/day), refractory pulmonary edema, or GFR <15 mL/min. Can remove 2-4 L fluid per session

METABOLIC ACIDOSIS MANAGEMENT:

  • Sodium Bicarbonate (if pH <7.2 or HCO3 <15 mEq/L):
    • Acute: 1-2 amps (50-100 mEq) IV push, can repeat
    • Infusion: 150 mEq (3 amps) in 1 L D5W at 100-150 mL/hr
    • Goal: pH >7.2, HCO3 >15-18 mEq/L (avoid over-correction)
    • Caution: worsens volume overload, hypernatremia
  • Dialysis: Most effective for severe acidosis in ESRD

URGENT DIALYSIS INDICATIONS ("AEIOU"):

  • A - Acidosis (refractory metabolic acidosis, pH <7.2)
  • E - Electrolytes (severe hyperkalemia K >6.5 mEq/L with ECG changes, refractory to medical therapy)
  • I - Intoxication (dialyzable toxins: methanol, ethylene glycol, lithium, salicylates)
  • O - Overload (volume overload, pulmonary edema refractory to diuretics)
  • U - Uremia (pericarditis, encephalopathy, bleeding diathesis)

Nephrology Consultation:

  • STAT consult for urgent dialysis consideration
  • All CKD Stage 4-5 admissions for ongoing management
  • Acute-on-chronic kidney injury
  • Dialysis catheter placement (if no AV fistula/graft available)

Chronic CKD Management (Once Stabilized):

  • Anemia: ESA (epoetin alfa, darbepoetin) if Hgb <10 g/dL, goal Hgb 10-11.5 g/dL. Iron supplementation (IV iron preferred in CKD)
  • Mineral-Bone Disease: Phosphate binders (calcium acetate, sevelamer), vitamin D analogs (calcitriol, paricalcitol), calcimimetics (cinacalcet) if elevated PTH
  • Dietary: Low potassium (<2-3 g/day), low phosphorus (<800-1000 mg/day), fluid restriction (1-1.5 L/day if oliguric), sodium restriction (<2 g/day)
  • Medications to Avoid: NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, IV contrast (if possible), metformin (hold if GFR <30), digoxin (reduce dose), renally-cleared drugs (adjust for GFR)

Disposition:

  • ICU: Severe hyperkalemia (K >7.0, ECG changes), pulmonary edema requiring BiPAP/intubation, hemodynamic instability, urgent dialysis needed, uremic pericarditis with tamponade
  • Floor with Telemetry: Moderate hyperkalemia (K 6.0-7.0), volume overload managed with diuretics, acute-on-chronic kidney injury
  • Discharge: Hyperkalemia resolved (K <5.5 mEq/L), euvolemic, stable renal function, follow-up arranged with nephrology
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • ECG Changes Predict Cardiac Arrest Risk Better Than Absolute K Level: Hyperkalemia is dangerous because of cardiac arrhythmias, not the number itself. K 6.5 mEq/L with peaked T waves is more dangerous than K 7.5 mEq/L with normal ECG. ECG progression: Peaked T waves (K 5.5-6.5) â†’ Loss of P waves + widened QRS (K 6.5-7.5) â†’ Sine wave pattern (K >8.0, pre-arrest). ANY ECG change from hyperkalemia = give calcium gluconate immediately to stabilize cardiac membrane, then shift K intracellularly (insulin+glucose, albuterol), then remove K (dialysis). Don't wait for "critical" K level.
  • Calcium Gluconate Does NOT Lower Potassium - It Stabilizes Cardiac Membranes: Common misconception: calcium lowers K. FALSE. Calcium antagonizes K's effect on cardiac myocyte membranes, preventing arrhythmias, but K level unchanged. Think of it as buying time (30-60 minutes) while you actually lower K with insulin/glucose, albuterol, dialysis. Give calcium if ANY ECG changes (peaked T, widened QRS), don't wait for sine wave. Can repeat calcium q5min if ECG changes persist. Calcium gluconate 1-2 g IV over 2-5 minutes (10-20 mL of 10% solution).
  • Insulin+Glucose+Albuterol is the Fastest Way to Lower K Acutely (Besides Dialysis): Insulin drives K into cells via Na-K-ATPase. Give regular insulin 10 units IV + D50 50 mL (if glucose <250 mg/dL). Lowers K by 0.5-1.2 mEq/L in 15-30 minutes, lasts 4-6 hours. Add albuterol 10-20 mg nebulized (4-8x standard dose) - synergistic, lowers K by another 0.5-1.0 mEq/L. Combined, can lower K by 1-2 mEq/L. Pitfall: insulin without glucose causes hypoglycemia (check glucose q1h x 4 hours). If glucose >250 mg/dL, give insulin alone without dextrose.
  • Hemodialysis is Most Effective K Removal - Lower Threshold in CKD Stage 4-5: Dialysis removes 50-75 mEq K per 4-hour session, lowering K by 2-3 mEq/L. Most definitive treatment. Indications: K >6.5 mEq/L with ECG changes, K >7.0 mEq/L regardless of ECG, refractory to medical therapy, or anuric ESRD patient (can't excrete K renally). Don't delay dialysis hoping medical management will work in CKD Stage 5 patient with K 7.0 - just dialyze. Medical management is temporizing; dialysis is definitive in these patients.
  • "AEIOU" Mnemonic for Urgent Dialysis Indications: A = Acidosis (pH <7.2 refractory), E = Electrolytes (severe hyperkalemia K >6.5 with ECG changes), I = Intoxication (methanol, ethylene glycol, lithium, salicylates - dialyzable toxins), O = Overload (volume overload, pulmonary edema refractory to diuretics), U = Uremia (pericarditis, encephalopathy, bleeding). If any AEIOU criterion met, consult nephrology STAT for urgent dialysis. Don't delay with prolonged medical management attempts.
  • Kayexalate (Sodium Polystyrene Sulfonate) is Obsolete and Dangerous: Old-school K binder with minimal efficacy (only lowers K by 0.5-1.0 mEq/L after 4-6 hours) and serious risk of bowel necrosis (especially with sorbitol). FDA black box warning. Newer K binders (patiromer, sodium zirconium cyclosilicate) are safer and faster. Use Lokelma (10 g PO, onset 1 hour) or Veltassa (8.4 g PO, onset 4-7 hours) instead. Reserve Kayexalate only if newer binders unavailable. Never give Kayexalate with sorbitol. For acute severe hyperkalemia, use insulin/glucose/albuterol/dialysis - not Kayexalate.
  • CKD Patients Need Much Higher Furosemide Doses for Diuresis: Loop diuretics work at thick ascending limb of loop of Henle. In CKD, reduced drug delivery to site of action (low GFR) + structural changes in nephrons = resistance to diuretics. Standard furosemide dose (20-40 mg IV) is inadequate. CKD Stage 3: 80 mg IV; Stage 4: 120-160 mg IV; Stage 5: 160-200 mg IV bolus. If inadequate diuresis, use continuous furosemide infusion 10-40 mg/hr or add metolazone 5-10 mg PO (thiazide + loop = synergistic diuresis). Alternatively, dialyze for volume removal (ultrafiltration).
  • Target Hgb 10-11.5 g/dL in CKD Anemia - Higher Targets Increase Mortality: CKD causes anemia (low erythropoietin production). Treat with ESAs (epoetin alfa, darbepoetin) + IV iron. But targeting higher Hgb (>13 g/dL) with aggressive ESA dosing increases stroke, MI, thrombosis, mortality (TREAT trial). Current guidelines: start ESA if Hgb <10 g/dL, target 10-11.5 g/dL. Never transfuse to Hgb >12 g/dL. Iron supplementation essential: check ferritin, TSAT; give IV iron if ferritin <500 ng/mL or TSAT <30% (oral iron poorly absorbed in CKD).
  • Secondary Hyperparathyroidism in CKD Requires Triple Therapy: CKD causes hyperphosphatemia (kidneys can't excrete PO4) â†’ binds Ca â†’ hypocalcemia â†’ elevated PTH â†’ bone disease. Management: (1) Phosphate binders with meals (calcium acetate, sevelamer, lanthanum) to reduce PO4 absorption, goal PO4 <5.5 mg/dL; (2) Vitamin D analogs (calcitriol 0.25-0.5 mcg daily or paricalcitol) to suppress PTH; (3) Calcimimetics (cinacalcet 30-180 mg daily) if PTH remains >300 pg/mL despite above. Goal PTH 150-300 pg/mL in CKD Stage 5. Uncontrolled secondary hyperparathyroidism causes renal osteodystrophy (bone pain, fractures) and vascular calcification.
  • Avoid Metformin if GFR <30 mL/min - Risk of Lactic Acidosis: Metformin is renally excreted. Accumulation in renal failure causes lactic acidosis (type B, non-hypoxic). Mortality 30-50% if metformin-associated lactic acidosis develops. FDA guidelines: Hold metformin if GFR <30 mL/min. If patient on metformin presents with AKI + lactic acidosis (lactate >5-10 mmol/L, pH <7.35, anion gap acidosis), assume metformin-induced until proven otherwise. Treatment: hemodialysis (removes metformin + lactate). Similarly, avoid contrast in CKD (risk of contrast-induced nephropathy); if unavoidable, IV fluids before/after, hold metformin 48 hours pre/post-contrast.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Severe hyperkalemia (K >7.0 mEq/L) or any hyperkalemia with ECG changes (peaked T, widened QRS, sine wave)
  • Refractory hyperkalemia despite medical management (requires urgent dialysis)
  • Pulmonary edema with respiratory failure (requiring BiPAP, intubation)
  • Severe metabolic acidosis (pH <7.1) refractory to bicarbonate
  • Uremic pericarditis with hemodynamic compromise or cardiac tamponade
  • Altered mental status from uremic encephalopathy
  • Hypertensive emergency (BP >220/120 with end-organ damage)
  • Dialysis catheter placement needed emergently but no existing access
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Potassium normalized (<5.5 mEq/L) and stable for 24 hours
  • Volume status optimized (euvolemic, no dyspnea at rest, SpO2 >92% on room air)
  • Renal function stable or improved (Cr at or near baseline for patient)
  • Metabolic acidosis corrected (HCO3 >18-20 mEq/L) or chronic compensated
  • Blood pressure controlled (<160/100 mmHg on oral regimen)
  • If new dialysis: first outpatient dialysis session scheduled within 48 hours, dialysis catheter functional
  • Patient educated on low-potassium diet, fluid restriction, medication adherence
  • Nephrology follow-up arranged within 1-2 weeks (sooner if dialysis-dependent)
  • Medications reconciled (nephrotoxins stopped, doses adjusted for GFR)
  • Patient/family understand signs of hyperkalemia, fluid overload, when to seek emergency care
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

108. UREMIC SYNDROME

End-Stage Renal Failure â€¢ Uremic Pericarditis â€¢ Encephalopathy â€¢ Bleeding â€¢ Dialysis Required
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Patient with ESRD (GFR <15 mL/min) or acute severe kidney injury presenting with systemic manifestations of uremic toxin accumulation: nausea/vomiting, altered mental status, pericarditis, bleeding, pruritus, asterixis - indicating urgent need for renal replacement therapy.

  • Pathophysiology: Accumulation of uremic toxins (urea, creatinine, guanidine compounds, middle molecules, protein-bound solutes) when kidneys fail to excrete metabolic waste. Affects multiple organ systems. Key manifestations: (1) Uremic pericarditis (fibrinous pericarditis, risk of tamponade), (2) Uremic encephalopathy (confusion, seizures, coma), (3) Platelet dysfunction (prolonged bleeding time despite normal platelet count), (4) Neuropathy (peripheral neuropathy, restless legs), (5) Pruritus, (6) GI symptoms (nausea, anorexia, uremic fetor - ammonia breath smell)
  • Risk Factors: ESRD (any cause: diabetic nephropathy, hypertensive nephrosclerosis, glomerulonephritis), missed dialysis sessions, acute kidney injury (AKI with BUN >100 mg/dL, Cr >8-10 mg/dL), delayed initiation of dialysis, malnutrition, elderly age
  • Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, anorexia (early), metallic taste, uremic fetor (ammonia or "fishy" breath smell), confusion/lethargy (uremic encephalopathy), seizures, chest pain (pericarditis), dyspnea, pruritus (intense, generalized itching), fatigue, weakness, restless legs syndrome, hiccups (persistent, from diaphragmatic irritation)
  • Physical Exam: Altered mental status (confusion, somnolence), asterixis (flapping tremor, similar to hepatic encephalopathy), pericardial friction rub (pathognomonic for uremic pericarditis), tachycardia, hypotension (if tamponade), pallor (anemia), uremic frost (white crystalline urea deposits on skin - very rare, extreme uremia), excoriations from scratching (pruritus), peripheral edema, peripheral neuropathy (decreased reflexes, sensory loss)
  • Variants/Subtypes: Uremic pericarditis vs Uremic encephalopathy vs Uremic bleeding diathesis. Acute uremia (AKI with rapid toxin accumulation) vs Chronic uremia (ESRD with gradual onset)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Studies:

  • Basic Metabolic Panel: Markedly elevated BUN (typically >80-100 mg/dL, can be >150-200 mg/dL), markedly elevated Cr (>8-10 mg/dL), hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, elevated anion gap
  • BUN/Cr Ratio: Usually >20:1 in uremia (indicates poor renal function with urea accumulation)
  • Complete Blood Count: Normocytic anemia (Hgb 6-10 g/dL), normal or elevated WBC, platelet count usually normal (dysfunction is qualitative, not quantitative)
  • Coagulation Studies: PT/INR normal, PTT normal, but bleeding time prolonged (platelet dysfunction from uremic toxins)
  • Arterial Blood Gas: Metabolic acidosis (pH <7.35, HCO3 <18 mEq/L)
  • Other: Elevated phosphate, low calcium, elevated PTH, hypoalbuminemia

ECG:

  • Pericarditis: Diffuse ST elevations (concave upward), PR depression (highly specific for pericarditis)
  • Hyperkalemia: Peaked T waves, widened QRS, loss of P waves (see CKD complications)
  • Low voltage (if pericardial effusion)

Imaging:

  • Echocardiogram (if pericarditis suspected): Pericardial effusion (can be small to large), fibrinous strands, assess for tamponade physiology (RV collapse, exaggerated respiratory variation in mitral inflow), assess LV function
  • Chest X-ray: Cardiomegaly (if effusion), pulmonary edema (if volume overload)

Diagnostic Criteria for Uremic Pericarditis:

  • Clinical: Chest pain, pericardial friction rub, dyspnea
  • ECG: Diffuse ST elevations, PR depression
  • Echo: Pericardial effusion
  • Context: ESRD or severe AKI (BUN >60-80 mg/dL)
  • Uremic pericarditis is "dialysis-requiring" pericarditis - absolute indication for urgent dialysis
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Management:

  • Assess hemodynamic stability (BP, HR, oxygen saturation)
  • IV access, continuous telemetry
  • NPO initially (nausea, vomiting common)
  • Antiemetics: Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV q8h PRN
  • URGENT Nephrology Consult for dialysis consideration

URGENT DIALYSIS - Primary Treatment for Uremic Syndrome:

  • Indications (Absolute for Uremia):
    • Uremic pericarditis (MOST IMPORTANT - prevents cardiac tamponade)
    • Uremic encephalopathy (confusion, seizures, coma)
    • Uremic bleeding (platelet dysfunction causing GI bleeding, epistaxis)
    • Intractable nausea/vomiting despite antiemetics
    • BUN >100 mg/dL with symptoms
    • Also: AEIOU criteria (see CKD complications - acidosis, electrolytes, intoxication, overload)
  • Modality: Hemodialysis preferred for urgent indications (faster clearance than peritoneal dialysis)
  • Access: Temporary dialysis catheter (internal jugular or femoral vein) if no AV fistula/graft. Place urgently
  • Frequency: Initially daily or every other day until uremia resolves, then 3x/week (standard ESRD schedule)
  • Response: Symptoms typically improve within 24-48 hours of initiating dialysis. Pericarditis resolves over 1-2 weeks

Specific Management by Complication:

  • Uremic Pericarditis:
    • Dialysis is PRIMARY treatment (resolves pericarditis in 85-90% of cases)
    • NSAIDs and Colchicine are CONTRAINDICATED (worsen renal function, ineffective for uremic pericarditis)
    • Heparin-free dialysis (avoid anticoagulation during dialysis if pericardial effusion, bleeding risk)
    • If large effusion (>2 cm on echo) or tamponade: Pericardiocentesis or pericardial window
    • Monitor with serial echos q2-3 days until effusion resolves
  • Uremic Encephalopathy:
    • Dialysis is treatment (clears uremic toxins)
    • Avoid sedatives (benzodiazepines worsen encephalopathy)
    • Seizures: Levetiracetam 500-1000 mg IV (renally cleared but safer than phenytoin in uremia)
    • Airway protection if altered mental status (GCS <8)
  • Uremic Bleeding (Platelet Dysfunction):
    • Dialysis improves platelet function (but takes days)
    • For acute bleeding:
      • DDAVP (Desmopressin): 0.3 mcg/kg IV over 30 minutes. Increases vWF release, improves platelet adhesion. Onset 1-2 hours, duration 4-8 hours. Can repeat q12-24h
      • Cryoprecipitate: 10 units IV. Contains vWF, Factor VIII. Onset 1 hour, duration 12-24 hours. More effective than DDAVP
      • Conjugated Estrogens: 0.6 mg/kg IV daily x 5 days. Improves platelet function, but onset 6-12 hours, used for refractory bleeding
      • Platelet Transfusion: Generally NOT effective (transfused platelets also become dysfunctional in uremic environment)
    • Correct anemia: Transfuse PRBCs if Hgb <7 g/dL (improves platelet function by increasing RBC-platelet interactions)
  • Pruritus:
    • Dialysis (most effective)
    • Topical: Moisturizing creams, capsaicin cream
    • Oral: Gabapentin 100-300 mg post-dialysis, Pregabalin 25-75 mg post-dialysis (both renally cleared, dose after dialysis)
    • UVB phototherapy if refractory
  • Nausea/Vomiting:
    • Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV q8h
    • Metoclopramide 5-10 mg IV q6h (use cautiously, risk of extrapyramidal symptoms in uremia)
    • Dialysis improves nausea within 24-48 hours

Supportive Care:

  • Nutrition: Protein restriction (0.8-1.0 g/kg/day pre-dialysis, 1.2 g/kg/day on dialysis), low potassium, low phosphorus
  • Phosphate binders with meals (prevent hyperphosphatemia)
  • Treat anemia: ESAs, IV iron
  • Avoid nephrotoxins: NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, IV contrast

Consultations:

  • Nephrology: URGENT - for dialysis initiation, access placement, ongoing management
  • Cardiology: If uremic pericarditis with large effusion or tamponade (may need pericardiocentesis)
  • Vascular Surgery: For AV fistula creation (long-term dialysis access)

Disposition:

  • ICU: Uremic pericarditis with tamponade, severe uremic encephalopathy (GCS <12, seizures), active bleeding from uremia, hemodynamic instability
  • Floor with Telemetry: Uremia requiring dialysis initiation, uremic encephalopathy (mild confusion), stable pericardial effusion
  • Discharge: Only after dialysis initiated, symptoms improved, effusion (if present) stable/resolving, outpatient dialysis arranged (3x/week)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Uremic Pericarditis is an ABSOLUTE Indication for Urgent Dialysis: Unlike viral or idiopathic pericarditis (treated with NSAIDs/colchicine), uremic pericarditis ONLY responds to dialysis. NSAIDs and colchicine are contraindicated (worsen renal function, ineffective). Uremic pericarditis = fibrinous "bread-and-butter" pericarditis from direct toxic effect of uremic toxins on pericardium. Friction rub is pathognomonic. Can progress to large effusion and tamponade. Dialysis resolves pericarditis in 85-90% of cases over 1-2 weeks. If large effusion or tamponade: consider pericardiocentesis, but still need dialysis as primary treatment.
  • BUN >100 mg/dL is Not Diagnostic of Uremia - Symptoms Define Uremia: Uremic syndrome is clinical diagnosis: presence of uremic symptoms (nausea, encephalopathy, pericarditis, bleeding, pruritus) in setting of kidney failure. BUN >80-100 mg/dL typically correlates with symptoms, but some patients tolerate BUN >150 mg/dL without symptoms (chronic uremia, gradual rise). Conversely, acute rise to BUN 60-80 mg/dL can cause symptoms (acute uremia). Diagnosis uremia based on symptoms + elevated BUN/Cr, not BUN number alone. Dialysis indicated if symptomatic uremia regardless of exact BUN level.
  • Uremic Frost is Pathognomonic but Extremely Rare: White crystalline deposits on skin from evaporation of sweat with high urea content (urea crystallizes on skin surface). Looks like white powder, typically on face, neck. Only occurs with extreme uremia (BUN >200 mg/dL). Historical curiosity - almost never seen in modern medicine because dialysis initiated before BUN reaches such levels. If you see uremic frost, patient has been severely neglected (missed dialysis x weeks-months). Immediately initiate dialysis.
  • Asterixis is Not Specific to Hepatic Encephalopathy - Also Seen in Uremic Encephalopathy: Asterixis = "flapping tremor," best elicited by having patient extend arms/wrists with fingers spread (like "stop" sign), observe for irregular lapses in wrist extension. Results from disruption of diencephalic-brain stem pathways controlling postural tone. Seen in any metabolic encephalopathy: hepatic, uremic, hypercapnia, drug toxicity. Not specific but helpful clinical sign. In uremic encephalopathy, asterixis indicates moderate-severe uremia - need urgent dialysis.
  • Uremic Platelet Dysfunction Causes Prolonged Bleeding Time Despite Normal Platelet Count and PT/INR/PTT: Uremia causes qualitative platelet defect (impaired adhesion/aggregation from uremic toxins interfering with vWF-platelet binding), not quantitative defect. CBC shows normal platelet count. PT/INR/PTT normal (coagulation cascade intact). But bleeding time prolonged (>10 minutes, normal <10 min). Clinically: mucosal bleeding (epistaxis, GI bleeding, menorrhagia), easy bruising. Treatment: dialysis (most effective, but takes days), DDAVP 0.3 mcg/kg IV (rapid onset 1-2 hr, short duration 4-8 hr), cryoprecipitate (10 units IV, more effective than DDAVP).
  • DDAVP vs Cryoprecipitate for Uremic Bleeding: Both improve uremic platelet dysfunction by increasing vWF (platelet adhesion). DDAVP (desmopressin) stimulates endogenous vWF release from endothelial cells - easier to give, onset 1-2 hours, duration 4-8 hours, can repeat q12-24h. Cryoprecipitate provides exogenous vWF + Factor VIII - more effective than DDAVP, onset 1 hour, duration 12-24 hours, but requires blood product. Use DDAVP first-line for mild bleeding; cryoprecipitate for severe/refractory bleeding. Platelet transfusion NOT effective (transfused platelets become dysfunctional in uremic environment).
  • NSAIDs are Absolutely Contraindicated in Uremic Pericarditis: Common error: treating chest pain from uremic pericarditis with NSAIDs (ibuprofen, indomethacin) like viral pericarditis. BAD. NSAIDs worsen renal function (inhibit prostaglandin-mediated renal blood flow), cause further AKI, and are ineffective for uremic pericarditis (doesn't respond to anti-inflammatory drugs). Similarly, colchicine ineffective. Uremic pericarditis is NOT an inflammatory process - it's direct toxic effect of uremic toxins on pericardium. Only treatment: DIALYSIS (clears toxins, resolves pericarditis). Pain control: use opioids (fentanyl, hydromorphone) or acetaminophen, not NSAIDs.
  • Heparin-Free Dialysis is Required if Pericardial Effusion or Bleeding Risk: Standard hemodialysis uses heparin anticoagulation (prevents clotting in dialysis circuit). But if patient has uremic pericarditis with pericardial effusion or active bleeding, heparin worsens bleeding/hemorrhagic pericardial effusion. Use "heparin-free" or "minimal heparin" dialysis: saline flushes of circuit, regional citrate anticoagulation, or frequent circuit changes. Discuss with nephrology before first dialysis session if pericardial effusion on echo. Hemorrhagic pericardial effusion can progress to tamponade.
  • Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome is Risk with First Dialysis in Severe Uremia: Rapid reduction in BUN during aggressive first dialysis (BUN drops from 150 to 50 mg/dL in 4 hours) creates osmotic gradient - brain slower to equilibrate than serum, causing cerebral edema. Symptoms during or after dialysis: headache, nausea, confusion, seizures, coma. More common when BUN >150-175 mg/dL, rapid/aggressive dialysis, first dialysis session. Prevention: "gentle" first dialysis (2 hours instead of 4, lower blood flow rate, limit BUN reduction to <40% per session), use higher dialysate sodium. If symptoms develop: slow/stop dialysis, mannitol 0.5-1 g/kg IV, supportive care.
  • Uremic Fetor is Pathognomonic for Uremia: Characteristic ammonia or "fishy" smell to breath. Caused by breakdown of urea in saliva by bacterial urease â†’ ammonia. Described as "urinous" odor. Can smell from across room in severe cases. Highly specific for uremia (BUN >80-100 mg/dL). Also associated with metallic taste, decreased appetite. Resolves with dialysis. If you smell uremic fetor, patient needs dialysis ASAP.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Cardiac tamponade from uremic pericarditis (hypotension, JVD, muffled heart sounds, pulsus paradoxus >10 mmHg)
  • Large pericardial effusion (>2 cm on echo) with hemodynamic compromise
  • Severe uremic encephalopathy (GCS <12, stupor, coma)
  • Seizures from uremic encephalopathy
  • Active life-threatening bleeding (GI bleed, intracranial hemorrhage) from uremic platelet dysfunction
  • Severe hyperkalemia (K >7.0 mEq/L) or ECG changes from hyperkalemia
  • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
  • Hemodynamic instability requiring vasopressors
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Dialysis initiated with at least 2-3 sessions completed
  • BUN trending down (goal <80 mg/dL, though may not fully normalize if ESRD)
  • Uremic symptoms resolved: no nausea/vomiting, mental status at baseline, no chest pain
  • If pericardial effusion: stable or decreasing in size, no tamponade physiology
  • Hemodynamically stable (normal BP, HR)
  • Tolerating PO intake without nausea
  • Outpatient dialysis center arranged (3x/week schedule)
  • Dialysis access functional (tunneled catheter or AV fistula/graft)
  • Nephrology follow-up within 1 week
  • Patient/family educated on dialysis schedule, dietary restrictions, medication compliance
  • If uremic pericarditis: cardiology follow-up arranged for repeat echo in 2-4 weeks
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

109. HYPOCALCEMIA

Tetany â€¢ Paresthesias â€¢ QT Prolongation â€¢ Seizures â€¢ Trousseau/Chvostek Signs
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Acute onset of perioral paresthesias, finger/toe tingling, muscle cramps, carpopedal spasm (tetany), with positive Chvostek and Trousseau signs, QT prolongation on ECG, and serum calcium <8.0 mg/dL (ionized Ca <1.0 mmol/L).

  • Pathophysiology: Hypocalcemia increases neuromuscular excitability (calcium normally stabilizes neuronal membranes). Low ionized calcium â†’ spontaneous neuronal depolarization â†’ tetany, paresthesias, seizures. Also impairs cardiac conduction (prolonged QT, torsades risk). Causes: (1) Hypoparathyroidism (post-thyroidectomy, autoimmune, genetic), (2) Vitamin D deficiency, (3) Hypomagnesemia (Mg required for PTH secretion and action), (4) CKD (hyperphosphatemia binds Ca), (5) Acute pancreatitis (fat saponification), (6) Tumor lysis syndrome, (7) Massive transfusion (citrate binds Ca), (8) Drugs (bisphosphonates, denosumab, cinacalcet, foscarnet)
  • Risk Factors: Post-thyroidectomy/parathyroidectomy surgery, CKD, vitamin D deficiency, malabsorption (Crohn's, celiac), chronic PPI use (impairs Ca absorption), alcoholism (low Mg), loop diuretics (renal Ca wasting), chemotherapy (tumor lysis), critical illness, sepsis, acute pancreatitis
  • Symptoms: Perioral paresthesias (numbness/tingling around mouth), acral paresthesias (fingers, toes), muscle cramps (calves, feet), carpopedal spasm (hand/foot spasms with flexion), laryngospasm (life-threatening - stridor, difficulty breathing), tetany, seizures (generalized tonic-clonic), confusion, irritability, anxiety, palpitations (arrhythmias)
  • Physical Exam: Chvostek Sign: Tap facial nerve anterior to ear â†’ ipsilateral facial muscle twitching (50% sensitive, can be positive in normals). Trousseau Sign: Inflate BP cuff above systolic BP for 3 minutes â†’ carpopedal spasm (hand contracts into flexion with thumb adduction, "obstetrician's hand" - 90% sensitive, more specific than Chvostek). Hyperreflexia, prolonged QT on ECG, papilledema (if chronic, increased ICP), cataracts (chronic hypocalcemia), basal ganglia calcifications (chronic), dry skin/brittle nails
  • Variants/Subtypes: Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia (tetany, seizures, laryngospasm - EMERGENCY) vs Chronic asymptomatic hypocalcemia (gradually compensated). Hypocalcemia with high PTH (secondary hyperparathyroidism from vit D deficiency, CKD) vs low PTH (hypoparathyroidism)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Studies:

  • Serum Calcium (Total and Ionized):
    • Total Calcium: Normal 8.5-10.5 mg/dL. Hypocalcemia <8.0 mg/dL. BUT must correct for albumin
    • Corrected Calcium: Corrected Ca = measured Ca + 0.8 Ã— (4.0 - albumin). Accounts for protein-bound Ca
    • Ionized Calcium (GOLD STANDARD): Normal 1.15-1.35 mmol/L (4.6-5.4 mg/dL). Hypocalcemia <1.0 mmol/L. Measures metabolically active (free) calcium, unaffected by albumin. Order ionized Ca if any doubt
  • Phosphate: Elevated in CKD, hypoparathyroidism, tumor lysis. Low in vitamin D deficiency, malabsorption
  • Magnesium: Check ALWAYS in hypocalcemia. Hypomagnesemia (<1.5 mg/dL) impairs PTH secretion and Ca reabsorption. Cannot correct hypocalcemia without correcting hypomagnesemia first
  • Parathyroid Hormone (PTH):
    • PTH Low/Inappropriately Normal: Hypoparathyroidism (post-surgical, autoimmune, genetic), hypomagnesemia
    • PTH Elevated: Appropriate response to hypocalcemia - indicates secondary hyperparathyroidism from vitamin D deficiency, CKD, malabsorption
  • 25-Hydroxyvitamin D: Assess vitamin D status. Deficiency <20 ng/mL (most common cause of hypocalcemia in general population)
  • 1,25-Dihydroxyvitamin D (Calcitriol): Active form. Low in CKD (kidneys can't activate vit D)
  • Albumin: For corrected calcium calculation
  • BUN/Creatinine: CKD common cause of hypocalcemia
  • Alkaline Phosphatase: Elevated in vitamin D deficiency (bone disease)
  • Lipase: If acute pancreatitis suspected

ECG (CRITICAL):

  • Prolonged QT interval (QTc >500 ms): Most important finding. Risk of torsades de pointes
  • T wave changes (flattening, inversion)
  • Bradycardia
  • Heart block (rare, severe hypocalcemia)
  • Compare to prior ECGs, calculate QTc (QT corrected for heart rate)

Imaging (if indicated):

  • Head CT (non-contrast): If chronic hypocalcemia, seizures, movement disorder. May show basal ganglia calcifications (Fahr's syndrome), cerebral calcifications
  • Neck Ultrasound/Sestamibi Scan: If hypoparathyroidism, assess for parathyroid glands (absent after surgery vs auto immune destruction)

Diagnostic Algorithm:

  • Step 1: Confirm hypocalcemia (ionized Ca <1.0 mmol/L or corrected Ca <8.0 mg/dL)
  • Step 2: Check Mg (if low, correct Mg first)
  • Step 3: Check PTH
    • If PTH low/normal â†’ Hypoparathyroidism (post-surgical, autoimmune)
    • If PTH elevated â†’ Check 25-OH vit D (low = vit D deficiency), check PO4 (high = CKD), check renal function
  • Step 4: Consider other causes (pancreatitis, tumor lysis, drugs)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

ACUTE SYMPTOMATIC HYPOCALCEMIA (Tetany, Seizures, Laryngospasm, QTc >500 ms) - EMERGENCY:

  • Step 1 - IV Calcium (Immediate Treatment):
    • Calcium Gluconate 10%: 1-2 grams (10-20 mL) IV over 10-20 minutes (SLOW push - rapid gives bradycardia, cardiac arrest). Can repeat q1-2h until symptoms resolve
    • Or Calcium Chloride 10%: 0.5-1 gram (5-10 mL) IV over 10 minutes via CENTRAL line only (scleroses peripheral veins, tissue necrosis if extravasation)
    • Calcium chloride has 3x more elemental calcium than gluconate (preferred for life-threatening hypocalcemia if central access)
    • Onset: 5-10 minutes, Duration: 2-4 hours
  • Step 2 - Continuous IV Calcium Infusion (if recurrent symptoms):
    • Calcium gluconate 10% 50-100 mL (5-10 grams) in 1000 mL D5W or NS at 50-100 mL/hr (0.5-1 mg/kg/hr elemental Ca)
    • Continue until symptoms controlled and able to transition to oral Ca
    • Monitor ionized Ca q4-6h, goal ionized Ca >1.0 mmol/L
    • Infuse via central line if possible (avoid phlebitis)
  • Step 3 - Correct Hypomagnesemia (CRITICAL):
    • If Mg <1.5 mg/dL: Magnesium sulfate 1-2 grams IV over 15-60 minutes, then 1-2 grams IV q6h until Mg >2.0 mg/dL
    • Or Magnesium sulfate 4-6 grams in 1000 mL NS at 100-150 mL/hr
    • CANNOT correct hypocalcemia without correcting hypomagnesemia first (Mg required for PTH secretion)
  • Airway Protection (if Laryngospasm):
    • Laryngospasm = vocal cord spasm, stridor, respiratory distress. LIFE-THREATENING
    • Immediate IV calcium (calcium gluconate 1-2 g IV push)
    • Bag-mask ventilation with 100% O2
    • If refractory: intubation (succinylcholine for paralysis), ICU
  • Seizure Management:
    • IV calcium (corrects underlying cause)
    • If ongoing seizure despite Ca: Lorazepam 2-4 mg IV
    • Avoid phenytoin (can worsen hypocalcemia, decreases Ca absorption)

CHRONIC/ASYMPTOMATIC HYPOCALCEMIA (Ca 7.0-8.0 mg/dL, No Tetany/Seizures):

  • Oral Calcium Supplementation:
    • Calcium carbonate 1000-1500 mg elemental Ca PO TID with meals (total 3000-4500 mg/day)
    • Or Calcium citrate 1000-1500 mg elemental Ca PO TID (better absorbed, preferred if achlorhydria, PPI use)
    • Start high dose, titrate based on Ca levels
  • Vitamin D Supplementation (if deficient):
    • Ergocalciferol (Vitamin D2) 50,000 units PO weekly x 8 weeks (if 25-OH vit D <20 ng/mL)
    • Or Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3) 1000-2000 units PO daily (maintenance)
    • In CKD: Calcitriol (active vit D) 0.25-0.5 mcg PO daily (kidneys can't activate vit D)
  • Correct Hypomagnesemia: Magnesium oxide 400 mg PO BID or Magnesium chloride 500 mg PO BID

HYPOPARATHYROIDISM-SPECIFIC TREATMENT:

  • High-dose oral calcium (3000-6000 mg/day divided TID-QID)
  • PLUS Active vitamin D (Calcitriol 0.5-2.0 mcg PO BID - higher doses than typical)
  • Goal: Ca 8.0-8.5 mg/dL (low-normal to avoid hypercalciuria, nephrolithiasis)
  • If refractory: Recombinant PTH (teriparatide, not FDA-approved for hypoparathyroidism but used off-label)

Monitoring:

  • Continuous telemetry (if QTc >500 ms or symptomatic)
  • Ionized calcium q2-4h until stable (acute treatment)
  • Serum Mg q4-6h until >2.0 mg/dL
  • ECG q4-8h to monitor QTc
  • Once transitioned to oral: Check Ca, Mg weekly x 4 weeks, then monthly
  • 24-hour urine calcium (monitor for hypercalciuria in hypoparathyroidism patients on high-dose Ca/vit D)

Cautions:

  • Do NOT give IV calcium in same line as bicarbonate or phosphate (precipitates)
  • Calcium infusion via peripheral IV can cause phlebitis (use central line if prolonged infusion)
  • Calcium chloride MUST go via central line (tissue necrosis if extravasation)
  • Rapid IV calcium causes bradycardia, cardiac arrest (push slowly over 10-20 minutes)
  • Avoid thiazide diuretics in hypocalcemia (decrease renal Ca excretion, risk of hypercalcemia once treated)

Consultations:

  • Endocrinology: All cases of hypoparathyroidism, refractory hypocalcemia, complex cases
  • Nephrology: If CKD-related hypocalcemia

Disposition:

  • ICU: Symptomatic hypocalcemia (tetany, seizures, laryngospasm), QTc >500 ms, requires continuous IV calcium infusion, hemodynamic instability
