  • Indirect (Unconjugated) Bilirubin: ELEVATED (>1.2 mg/dL, often 2-5 mg/dL) from heme breakdown. Predominantly indirect hyperbilirubinemia (direct <0.3 mg/dL)
  • Direct Antiglobulin Test (DAT, Coombs Test): POSITIVE in autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). Detects antibodies or complement on RBC surface. Warm AIHA: IgG positive. Cold agglutinin disease: C3d positive. Negative DAT rules out autoimmune cause

Peripheral Blood Smear (CRITICAL for Diagnosis):

  • Schistocytes (Fragmented RBCs): Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (TTP, HUS, DIC, HELLP, prosthetic valve). Helmet cells, triangular cells. If schistocytes present, URGENT evaluation for TTP
  • Spherocytes: Warm AIHA, hereditary spherocytosis. Small, round RBCs without central pallor
  • Bite Cells, Blister Cells, Heinz Bodies: G6PD deficiency (after oxidative stress). Heinz bodies require supravital stain (crystal violet)
  • Agglutination: Cold agglutinin disease (IgM antibodies cause RBC clumping at room temperature)
  • Sickle Cells: Sickle cell disease
  • Target Cells: Liver disease, thalassemia, hemoglobinopathies
  • Polychromasia: Reticulocytes (bluish-gray tinge on Wright-Giemsa stain)

Specialized Testing to Determine Etiology:

  • Direct Antiglobulin Test (DAT/Coombs): Positive = immune-mediated (AIHA, drug-induced). IgG positive = warm AIHA. C3 positive = cold agglutinin disease
  • Cold Agglutinin Titer: If DAT positive for C3. Titer >1:64 diagnostic of cold agglutinin disease
  • G6PD Level: If bite cells/Heinz bodies or hemolysis after oxidative stress (infection, fava beans, medications). NOTE: may be falsely normal during acute hemolysis (reticulocytes have normal G6PD); recheck 3 months after acute episode
  • Osmotic Fragility Test: If spherocytes and family history. Positive in hereditary spherocytosis
  • Flow Cytometry for CD55/CD59: If intravascular hemolysis (hemoglobinuria) + thrombosis + cytopenias. Diagnostic for PNH
  • Hemoglobin Electrophoresis: If sickle cells or family history. Diagnose sickle cell disease, thalassemia
  • ADAMTS13 Activity: If schistocytes + thrombocytopenia + neurologic symptoms. <10% diagnostic of TTP. SEND BEFORE PLASMAPHERESIS
  • Coagulation Studies (PT, PTT, Fibrinogen, D-dimer): If schistocytes or concern for DIC. DIC: prolonged PT/PTT, low fibrinogen (<200 mg/dL), elevated D-dimer (>500 ng/mL)
  • Free Hemoglobin (Plasma): Elevated in intravascular hemolysis (>25 mg/dL). Plasma appears pink or red
  • Urinalysis: Hemoglobinuria (positive blood without RBCs on microscopy). Indicates intravascular hemolysis. Also check for hemosiderinuria (chronic intravascular hemolysis)

Additional Testing Based on Clinical Suspicion:

  • Mycoplasma IgM, EBV serologies, HIV test (infection-triggered AIHA)
  • ANA, anti-dsDNA, complement levels (SLE-associated AIHA)
  • Peripheral lymphocyte flow cytometry (CLL, lymphoma)
  • Medication review (drug-induced hemolysis: penicillins, cephalosporins, methyldopa, quinine, sulfonamides)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Management:

  • Assess hemodynamic stability: BP, HR, orthostatics, signs of shock
  • Supplemental oxygen if symptomatic anemia or hypoxia
  • Type and screen, crossmatch (extended phenotyping if warm AIHA or history of alloantibodies)
  • IV access, continuous monitoring if severe anemia (Hgb <7 g/dL)
  • Identify and treat underlying cause (stop offending medication, treat infection, manage TTP/DIC)
  • Folic acid 1 mg PO daily (increased demand from RBC turnover)

Transfusion Therapy:

  • Indications: Symptomatic anemia (dyspnea, chest pain, altered mental status, hemodynamic instability), Hgb <7 g/dL, or rapid Hgb drop
  • Challenges in AIHA: Crossmatching difficult due to antibodies. All units may be "incompatible" but can still transfuse least incompatible units if life-threatening
  • Transfuse PRBCs slowly: 1 unit over 2-4 hours with close monitoring. Risk of hemolysis of transfused cells, transfusion reactions
  • Goal: Hgb 7-8 g/dL (avoid overtransfusion which suppresses reticulocyte response)
  • Washed RBCs: Consider if recurrent severe transfusion reactions

Treatment - Warm Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia (IgG, DAT positive):

  • First Line - Corticosteroids: Prednisone 1 mg/kg PO daily (60-80 mg daily) or methylprednisolone 1 mg/kg IV daily. Response in 7-14 days (reticulocyte count drops, Hgb stabilizes/rises). Taper slowly over 3-6 months once Hgb >10 g/dL
  • Second Line (if refractory or relapsing): Rituximab 375 mg/mÂ² IV weekly Ã— 4 weeks (anti-CD20 antibody depletes B cells). Response rate 80-90%, slower onset (4-8 weeks)
  • Third Line: Splenectomy (removes site of RBC destruction), immunosuppressants (azathioprine 1-2 mg/kg/day, mycophenolate 1000 mg BID, cyclophosphamide)
  • Refractory Severe: IVIG 1 g/kg IV daily Ã— 2 days (temporary response, days to weeks), plasmapheresis (limited efficacy in warm AIHA)

Treatment - Cold Agglutinin Disease (IgM, C3 positive DAT):

  • Avoid Cold Exposure: Keep patient warm (blankets, warm IV fluids, warm room). Cold triggers IgM binding and complement activation
  • Corticosteroids: Generally INEFFECTIVE (unlike warm AIHA)
  • First Line: Rituximab 375 mg/mÂ² IV weekly Ã— 4 weeks. Response rate 50-60%
  • Second Line: Rituximab + bendamustine or rituximab + fludarabine
  • Supportive: Transfuse through blood warmer if needed
  • Treat underlying disorder: Mycoplasma pneumoniae (azithromycin), lymphoproliferative disease

Treatment - Microangiopathic Hemolytic Anemia (TTP/HUS/DIC):

  • TTP (Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura): MEDICAL EMERGENCY. Plasmapheresis (plasma exchange) IMMEDIATELY, before confirmatory ADAMTS13 results. Delay increases mortality. Plasma exchange daily until platelets >150,000/ÂµL and LDH normalizing. Adjunct: rituximab, caplacizumab (anti-vWF antibody)
  • HUS (Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome): Supportive care (hydration, avoid antibiotics in Shiga toxin HUS), dialysis if needed. Eculizumab for atypical HUS (complement-mediated)
  • DIC: Treat underlying cause (sepsis, malignancy). Transfuse platelets if bleeding, FFP/cryoprecipitate if coagulopathy and bleeding
  • DO NOT TRANSFUSE PLATELETS in TTP (unless life-threatening bleeding) - may worsen thrombosis

Treatment - G6PD Deficiency:

  • STOP offending agent: sulfa drugs, antimalarials (primaquine, dapsone), fava beans, naphthalene (mothballs), rasburicase
  • Supportive care: hydration, transfuse if severe anemia
  • Self-limited: hemolysis resolves once oxidative stress removed
  • Patient education: avoid triggers lifelong

Treatment - Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH):

  • Eculizumab (Soliris): Monoclonal antibody inhibiting complement C5. 600 mg IV weekly Ã— 4 weeks, then 900 mg q2 weeks. Reduces hemolysis, thrombosis risk. MUST vaccinate against N. meningitidis before starting
  • Alternative: Ravulizumab (longer-acting C5 inhibitor), pegcetacoplan (C3 inhibitor)
  • Anticoagulation: For history of thrombosis (warfarin INR 2-3)
  • Transfuse for symptomatic anemia, treat iron deficiency
  • Allogeneic stem cell transplant: Curative for young patients with severe disease

Treatment - Drug-Induced Hemolytic Anemia:

  • STOP offending medication immediately
  • Hemolysis typically resolves within days to weeks after drug discontinuation
  • Supportive care, transfuse if severe
  • Corticosteroids if severe (prednisone 1 mg/kg/day)

Hematology Consultation:

  • MANDATORY for all cases of hemolytic anemia
  • URGENT consultation for TTP, severe AIHA, PNH, refractory hemolysis

Disposition:

  • ICU: Severe anemia (Hgb <5-6 g/dL), hemodynamic instability, TTP requiring plasmapheresis, acute kidney injury, transfusion-dependent, rapid hemolysis
  • Floor: Moderate anemia (Hgb 6-8 g/dL) requiring transfusion or IV steroids, new diagnosis requiring workup
  • Discharge: Mild hemolysis (Hgb >8-9 g/dL), chronic compensated hemolysis, hemolysis controlled on oral medications, close hematology follow-up arranged
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Haptoglobin is the Most Specific Marker for Intravascular Hemolysis: Haptoglobin binds free hemoglobin released from lysed RBCs. Low/undetectable haptoglobin (<25 mg/dL) is highly specific for hemolysis, particularly intravascular hemolysis. However, haptoglobin is an acute phase reactant - can be falsely elevated (normal) in inflammatory states even with hemolysis. Also, 1-2% of the population has genetic ahaptoglobinemia (congenitally absent haptoglobin). In these cases, rely on other markers: elevated LDH, indirect bilirubin, hemoglobinemia/hemoglobinuria.
  • Peripheral Smear is the Key to Diagnosis: The smear reveals the MECHANISM of hemolysis. Schistocytes = microangiopathic (TTP, HUS, DIC, prosthetic valve) - think mechanical destruction. Spherocytes = AIHA or hereditary spherocytosis - think membrane loss. Bite cells/Heinz bodies = G6PD deficiency - think oxidative damage. Sickle cells = sickle cell disease. Agglutination at room temperature = cold agglutinin disease. Always review the smear yourself or request hematopathology review - it guides the entire workup and treatment.
  • TTP is a "Do Not Miss" Emergency Requiring Immediate Plasmapheresis: Classic pentad: thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (schistocytes), neurologic changes, renal failure, fever - but only 40% have full pentad. If you see thrombocytopenia + schistocytes + any neurologic change (confusion, headache, focal deficit), treat as TTP immediately. Send ADAMTS13 level (<10% confirms TTP) but START PLASMAPHERESIS BEFORE results return. Mortality is 90% without treatment, 10-20% with treatment. Every hour of delay increases mortality.
  • Warm AIHA Responds to Steroids, Cold Agglutinin Disease Does NOT: Warm AIHA (IgG antibodies, DAT IgG-positive) responds well to corticosteroids (prednisone 1 mg/kg/day) with 70-85% response rate. Cold agglutinin disease (IgM antibodies, DAT C3-positive) does NOT respond to steroids. Instead, treat cold agglutinin disease with avoidance of cold, rituximab, and keeping the patient warm (heated blankets, warm IV fluids, warm room). Do NOT waste time with steroids in cold agglutinin disease.
  • G6PD Testing Can Be Falsely Normal During Acute Hemolysis: G6PD deficiency is X-linked; older RBCs have lower G6PD activity. During acute hemolytic crisis, the oldest (most deficient) cells are destroyed, and young reticulocytes (which have NORMAL G6PD levels) predominate. Testing during crisis may show falsely normal G6PD. If clinical suspicion is high (acute hemolysis after oxidative trigger in African or Mediterranean male), presume G6PD deficiency and recheck G6PD level 3 months after acute event when RBC population normalizes.
  • Don't Overtransfuse in Hemolytic Anemia: In hemolytic anemia, the bone marrow is actively producing RBCs (reticulocytosis). Overtransfusion (targeting Hgb >10 g/dL) suppresses erythropoietin and shuts down this compensatory response, making the patient transfusion-dependent. Additionally, in AIHA, transfused RBCs may also be destroyed by autoantibodies. Transfuse only for symptoms or critical anemia (Hgb <7 g/dL), target Hgb 7-8 g/dL, and allow the body's own reticulocyte response to recover the Hgb over time with definitive treatment.
  • PNH Triad: Hemolysis + Thrombosis + Cytopenias: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is an acquired clonal stem cell disorder causing deficiency of GPI-anchored complement regulatory proteins (CD55, CD59). Clinical triad: (1) intravascular hemolysis (worst at night/morning from nocturnal acidosis activating complement), (2) thrombosis in unusual sites (hepatic vein = Budd-Chiari, portal vein, cerebral venous sinus), (3) pancytopenia. Diagnose with flow cytometry showing absent CD55/CD59. Treat with eculizumab (complement inhibitor), which dramatically reduces hemolysis and thrombosis risk.
  • Crossmatching Blood is Difficult in AIHA: In warm AIHA, autoantibodies react with ALL donor RBCs, making crossmatch appear incompatible for every unit. Blood bank will provide "least incompatible" units. Transfuse these units if patient is symptomatic or critically anemic - they will be hemolyzed by autoantibodies but provide temporary oxygen-carrying capacity until definitive treatment (steroids, rituximab) takes effect. Communicate clearly with blood bank about diagnosis. Consider extended phenotype matching to avoid alloimmunization.
  • Drug-Induced Hemolytic Anemia Mechanisms Vary: Drugs cause hemolysis via three mechanisms: (1) Hapten mechanism - drug binds RBC, antibody forms against drug-RBC complex (penicillins, cephalosporins), (2) Immune complex mechanism - drug-antibody complexes activate complement (quinine, rifampin), (3) Autoantibody induction - drug induces true autoantibody formation (methyldopa, levodopa, fludarabine). All require DAT (Coombs) positive. Treatment: STOP THE DRUG. Hemolysis resolves in days to weeks. Corticosteroids may help if severe.
  • Splenectomy is Effective in Refractory Warm AIHA and Hereditary Spherocytosis: The spleen is the primary site of RBC destruction in warm AIHA and hereditary spherocytosis (extravascular hemolysis). Splenectomy has a 70-80% response rate in refractory warm AIHA (after failing steroids and rituximab) and is curative in hereditary spherocytosis. However, splenectomy increases lifelong risk of infection from encapsulated organisms (S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, N. meningitidis) and venous thromboembolism. Vaccinate 2 weeks before splenectomy (pneumococcal, H. influenzae, meningococcal) and give lifelong penicillin VK prophylaxis (250-500 mg PO BID).
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Severe anemia with hemoglobin <5-6 g/dL
  • Hemodynamic instability (hypotension SBP <90, tachycardia HR >120, shock)
  • Symptomatic anemia with chest pain, dyspnea, altered mental status, syncope
  • Suspected TTP (schistocytes + thrombocytopenia + neurologic changes) - requires urgent plasmapheresis
  • Acute kidney injury with oliguria or rising creatinine (>2 mg/dL or 2Ã— baseline)
  • Rapid hemolysis with Hgb dropping >2 g/dL per day despite treatment
  • Transfusion-dependent hemolysis requiring multiple units PRBCs
  • Severe hemoglobinuria with acute kidney injury (intravascular hemolysis)
  • DIC with active bleeding and coagulopathy
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemoglobin stable and >8-9 g/dL (or stable at patient's baseline for chronic hemolysis)
  • No symptoms of anemia (no dyspnea, chest pain, or significant fatigue at rest)
  • Hemodynamically stable (normal BP, HR <100, no orthostatic hypotension)
  • Hemolysis controlled or improving (LDH trending down, haptoglobin stabilizing)
  • Underlying cause identified or under investigation with outpatient plan
  • Appropriate therapy initiated (steroids for AIHA, eculizumab for PNH, offending drug stopped)
  • No evidence of TTP, DIC, or other life-threatening complications
  • Patient educated on medication compliance (steroids, immunosuppressants), avoidance of triggers (cold exposure, specific drugs)
  • Hematology follow-up arranged within 1-2 weeks
  • Folic acid 1 mg daily prescribed
  • Clear instructions on when to return: worsening fatigue, dyspnea, chest pain, jaundice, dark urine, bleeding
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

115. ONCOLOGIC EMERGENCIES

SVC Syndrome â€¢ Spinal Cord Compression â€¢ Hypercalcemia of Malignancy â€¢ Tumor Lysis
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Cancer patient presenting with life-threatening complication requiring urgent intervention: superior vena cava syndrome (facial edema, dilated chest veins), malignant spinal cord compression (back pain, weakness, bowel/bladder dysfunction), hypercalcemia of malignancy (confusion, polyuria), or tumor lysis syndrome (hyperkalemia, acute kidney injury).

  • Pathophysiology:
    • Superior Vena Cava (SVC) Syndrome: Obstruction of SVC by external compression (lung cancer, lymphoma, mediastinal mass, thrombus). Impaired venous drainage from head, neck, upper extremities causes facial/upper body edema, venous distension. Can progress to cerebral edema, respiratory compromise, death if untreated
    • Malignant Spinal Cord Compression (MSCC): Tumor invasion into epidural space (vertebral body metastases collapse onto cord, or direct invasion through intervertebral foramina). Compresses spinal cord causing ischemia and permanent neurologic damage. Irreversible paraplegia if not treated within 24-48 hours. Most common: thoracic spine (70%), then lumbar (20%), cervical (10%)
    • Hypercalcemia of Malignancy: (1) PTHrP-mediated (squamous cell lung cancer, RCC, breast, bladder - 80% of cases) - tumor secretes PTHrP mimicking PTH, increasing bone resorption and renal calcium reabsorption, OR (2) Osteolytic bone metastases (breast, multiple myeloma, lymphoma - 20% of cases) - direct bone destruction releases calcium. Causes polyuria, dehydration, worsening hypercalcemia (vicious cycle), confusion, coma
    • Tumor Lysis Syndrome (TLS): Massive tumor cell death (spontaneous or treatment-induced chemo/radiation) releases intracellular contents: potassium, phosphate, uric acid, nucleic acids. Causes hyperkalemia (cardiac arrhythmias), hyperphosphatemia â†’ hypocalcemia (tetany, seizures), hyperuricemia â†’ uric acid nephropathy (AKI), acute kidney injury from crystal deposition
  • Risk Factors: Lung cancer (SVC syndrome, MSCC, hypercalcemia), breast cancer (bone mets, MSCC, hypercalcemia), prostate cancer (bone mets, MSCC), multiple myeloma (hypercalcemia, MSCC), renal cell carcinoma (hypercalcemia), lymphoma (SVC syndrome, TLS), leukemia (TLS), cancers with high proliferation rates (Burkitt lymphoma, acute leukemias - highest TLS risk)
  • Symptoms by Emergency Type:
    • SVC Syndrome: Facial swelling (worse in morning, improves when upright), neck swelling, upper extremity edema, dyspnea, cough, dysphagia, hoarseness, headache (worse when bending forward/lying down), visual changes, chest pain
    • MSCC: Back pain (90% - progressive, severe, localized, worse at night or with Valsalva), lower extremity weakness (85%), sensory changes (paresthesias, numbness), bowel/bladder dysfunction (urinary retention, incontinence, constipation), gait difficulty
    • Hypercalcemia: "Stones, bones, groans, psychiatric overtones" - polyuria, polydipsia, nausea, vomiting, constipation, abdominal pain, confusion, lethargy, weakness, bone pain
    • TLS: Often asymptomatic initially, then nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy, muscle cramps/tetany (hypocalcemia), cardiac arrhythmias (hyperkalemia), decreased urine output, seizures
  • Physical Exam:
    • SVC Syndrome: Facial edema (especially periorbital), plethora, cyanosis, distended neck veins, dilated chest wall veins (collaterals), upper extremity edema (non-pitting), Pemberton sign (raising arms above head causes facial plethora/cyanosis), stridor if severe tracheal compression
    • MSCC: Focal tenderness to percussion over spinous processes, decreased strength (upper motor neuron pattern: spasticity, hyperreflexia, upgoing Babinski), sensory level, decreased rectal tone, saddle anesthesia
    • Hypercalcemia: Altered mental status, dry mucous membranes (dehydration), decreased skin turgor, bradycardia, shortened QT interval on ECG
    • TLS: Usually normal exam early, then lethargy, decreased urine output, muscle twitching/tetany (hypocalcemia), cardiac arrhythmias
  • Variants/Subtypes: Acute vs subacute presentation (SVC syndrome can present over days to weeks; MSCC can be acute/subacute). Complete vs incomplete cord compression. Symptomatic vs asymptomatic hypercalcemia (treatment based on symptoms AND calcium level). Laboratory TLS (abnormal labs only) vs Clinical TLS (labs + organ dysfunction)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Studies:

  • Basic Metabolic Panel: Hypercalcemia (>11 mg/dL moderate, >14 mg/dL severe), hyperkalemia (K >5.5 mEq/L in TLS), elevated Cr (AKI from hypercalcemia or TLS), hyperphosphatemia (PO4 >4.5 mg/dL in TLS)
  • Ionized Calcium: More accurate than total calcium. Ionized Ca >1.35 mmol/L (5.4 mg/dL) diagnostic of hypercalcemia. Correct total calcium for albumin: Corrected Ca = measured Ca + 0.8 Ã— (4.0 - albumin)
  • Complete Blood Count: Anemia, leukocytosis or leukopenia (underlying malignancy), thrombocytopenia
  • PTH Level: Suppressed (<20 pg/mL) in hypercalcemia of malignancy (negative feedback from high calcium). Normal/elevated PTH suggests primary hyperparathyroidism
  • PTHrP Level: Elevated in PTHrP-mediated hypercalcemia (squamous cell cancers, RCC). Helps differentiate mechanism
  • Uric Acid: Elevated (>8 mg/dL) in TLS from purine metabolism of lysed tumor cells
  • LDH: Markedly elevated in TLS (tumor lysis releases LDH). Also elevated in lymphoma/leukemia at baseline
  • Phosphate: Elevated in TLS (>4.5 mg/dL, can be >10 mg/dL). Low in hypercalcemia (PTHrP increases renal phosphate wasting)
  • ECG: Shortened QT interval (hypercalcemia), peaked T waves/widened QRS (hyperkalemia in TLS), prolonged QT (hypocalcemia in TLS)

Imaging:

  • SVC Syndrome:
    • CT Chest with IV Contrast (URGENT): Visualize SVC obstruction, identify cause (mass vs thrombus), assess collateral circulation, evaluate tracheal compression. Preferred initial test
    • Chest X-ray: May show widened mediastinum, right hilar mass, pleural effusion. Less sensitive than CT but can be done immediately
    • Venography or Doppler Ultrasound: If concern for SVC thrombus (for intervention planning)
  • Malignant Spinal Cord Compression:
    • MRI Spine with Gadolinium (STAT WITHIN 1 HOUR): Gold standard. Visualize entire spine (tumor can be at multiple levels). Shows epidural mass, cord compression, vertebral body involvement. If MRI unavailable or contraindicated, CT myelography is alternative
    • Plain X-rays Spine: Show vertebral body destruction (lytic or blastic lesions), compression fracture. Do NOT rule out cord compression - 10% of MSCC have normal X-rays. Cannot delay definitive imaging
  • Hypercalcemia/TLS:
    • Renal Ultrasound: Assess for hydronephrosis (can worsen kidney function), nephrocalcinosis
    • Skeletal Survey or PET-CT: Identify bone metastases (for hypercalcemia from osteolytic lesions)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

SUPERIOR VENA CAVA SYNDROME:

  • Immediate Stabilization:
    • Elevate head of bed 30-45 degrees (improve venous drainage)
    • Supplemental oxygen as needed
    • AVOID IV access in upper extremities (impaired venous drainage). Use lower extremity or central line if needed
    • Diuretics: Furosemide 20-40 mg IV (reduce edema, but use cautiously to avoid dehydration)
  • Corticosteroids (if lymphoma or chemosensitive tumor): Dexamethasone 10 mg IV, then 4 mg IV q6h. Rapidly reduces tumor burden and edema. Do NOT give if diagnosis uncertain (obscures histology)
  • Radiation Therapy (Definitive Treatment for Most Cases): Consult radiation oncology URGENTLY. Fractionated radiation (2-4 Gy per day Ã— 10-20 fractions) to mediastinal mass. Improvement in 70-90% of patients within 3-7 days. Preferred for non-small cell lung cancer, small cell lung cancer
  • Chemotherapy: For chemosensitive tumors (lymphoma, small cell lung cancer, germ cell tumors). Consult oncology. Can result in rapid tumor shrinkage
  • Endovascular Stenting: For severe symptoms or lack of response to radiation/chemo. Interventional radiology places expandable metallic stent in SVC. Immediate symptom relief in 90% of cases. Consider if: severe symptoms (stridor, respiratory distress, cerebral edema), previously radiated mediastinum, SVC thrombus
  • Anticoagulation: If SVC thrombus identified. Heparin or LMWH. Thrombolysis for acute severe thrombosis

MALIGNANT SPINAL CORD COMPRESSION (TRUE EMERGENCY - HOURS MATTER):

  • High-Dose Corticosteroids (START IMMEDIATELY, do not wait for MRI):
    • Dexamethasone 10 mg IV STAT, then 4-6 mg IV q6h. Reduces vasogenic edema, stabilizes/improves neurologic function in 75% if given early. Continue until definitive treatment
    • PPI prophylaxis (pantoprazole 40 mg IV daily) for GI protection with high-dose steroids
  • URGENT Radiation Oncology Consult (within 2 hours): Emergent radiation therapy (EBRT) is the definitive treatment for most patients. 30 Gy in 10 fractions over 2 weeks typical. Start within 24 hours of diagnosis. Effective in 70-80% for pain relief and neurologic stabilization
  • URGENT Neurosurgery Consult (within 2 hours): Surgical decompression (laminectomy) indications: (1) Neurologic deterioration despite radiation, (2) Spinal instability or pathologic fracture, (3) Unknown primary cancer (need tissue diagnosis), (4) Previously radiated area (cannot re-radiate), (5) Radioresistant tumor (RCC, melanoma, sarcoma). Surgery followed by radiation improves outcomes vs radiation alone in selected patients
  • Medical Oncology Consult: For concurrent chemotherapy if chemosensitive tumor (lymphoma, myeloma, prostate cancer)
  • Bowel/Bladder Management: Foley catheter if urinary retention. Bowel regimen to prevent constipation. Physical therapy/rehab consultation

HYPERCALCEMIA OF MALIGNANCY:

  • AGGRESSIVE IV HYDRATION (First-Line):
    • Normal saline 200-300 mL/hr initially (goal 3-4 L over first 24 hours). Enhances renal calcium excretion
    • Monitor for volume overload (especially in elderly, heart failure patients). Titrate based on urine output, clinical exam
    • Replace electrolytes: Hypomagnesemia (Mg <1.5 mg/dL) and hypokalemia common with saline diuresis
    • Goal urine output 100-150 mL/hr. This ALONE lowers calcium by 1-3 mg/dL over 24-48 hours
  • Bisphosphonates (Definitive Treatment):
    • Zoledronic Acid (Zometa) 4 mg IV over 15-30 minutes: Preferred. Inhibits osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. Calcium normalizes in 4-7 days, effect lasts 2-4 weeks. Dose-adjust for renal impairment (use 3.5 mg if CrCl 50-60, 3.3 mg if CrCl 40-49, 3 mg if CrCl 30-39, avoid if CrCl <30)
    • Pamidronate (Aredia) 60-90 mg IV over 2-4 hours: Alternative if zoledronic acid unavailable. Less potent. Normalizes calcium in 7-10 days
    • Precautions: Can cause acute kidney injury (ensure adequate hydration first). Risk of osteonecrosis of jaw (rare, with prolonged use). Hold if CrCl <30 mL/min
  • Calcitonin (Rapid Onset but Short Duration):
    • Calcitonin 4 units/kg SC or IM q12h. Lowers calcium within 4-6 hours (vs 4-7 days for bisphosphonates). Effect modest (decrease calcium 1-2 mg/dL) and short-lived (tachyphylaxis after 48 hours)
    • Use as BRIDGE therapy while waiting for bisphosphonates to work, especially if severe symptomatic hypercalcemia (Ca >14 mg/dL with altered mental status)
  • Denosumab (if refractory to bisphosphonates): Denosumab 120 mg SC weekly Ã— 4 weeks, then monthly. Fully humanized monoclonal antibody against RANKL (inhibits osteoclast activation). More potent than bisphosphonates. Use if CrCl <30 or bisphosphonate failure
  • Loop Diuretics (Controversial, USE CAUTIOUSLY): Furosemide 20-40 mg IV q6-12h ONLY AFTER adequate hydration (euvolemic/hypervolemic). Increases renal calcium excretion. AVOID if hypovolemic (worsens dehydration and hypercalcemia). Modern guidelines de-emphasize routine use
  • Hemodialysis (Severe Refractory Hypercalcemia): If Ca >18 mg/dL with severe symptoms, AKI, or heart failure precluding aggressive hydration. Rapidly lowers calcium. Calcium-free dialysate
  • Treat Underlying Malignancy: Oncology consult for chemotherapy/targeted therapy (definitive long-term treatment)

TUMOR LYSIS SYNDROME:

  • Prevention (High-Risk Patients Before Chemo):
    • Aggressive IV hydration: NS or D5Â½NS at 2-3 L/mÂ²/day (goal urine output >100 mL/mÂ²/hr or 2-3 mL/kg/hr)
    • Allopurinol 300-600 mg PO daily (or 200-400 mg/mÂ² IV if unable to take PO): Xanthine oxidase inhibitor, prevents uric acid formation from purine breakdown. Start 24-48 hours before chemotherapy
    • Rasburicase (Elitek) 0.2 mg/kg IV daily Ã— 1-7 days (HIGH RISK ONLY): Recombinant urate oxidase, converts uric acid to allantoin (10Ã— more soluble, easily excreted). Rapidly lowers uric acid within 4 hours. Indications: baseline uric acid >8 mg/dL, high tumor burden (Burkitt lymphoma, acute leukemias), baseline CrCl <60. Contraindications: G6PD deficiency (causes severe hemolysis), pregnancy
    • Avoid nephrotoxins (NSAIDs, contrast, aminoglycosides)
    • Monitor labs q6-8h during first 24-72 hours of chemotherapy: BMP, phosphate, uric acid, calcium, LDH
  • Treatment of Established TLS:
    • Aggressive IV Hydration: NS at 200-300 mL/hr (3-4 L/day). Goal urine output >100 mL/hr. Promotes excretion of uric acid, phosphate, potassium
    • Rasburicase (if not already given): 0.2 mg/kg IV Ã— 1 dose. Rapidly corrects hyperuricemia
    • Allopurinol: 300-600 mg PO daily. Prevents NEW uric acid formation (does not lower existing levels - that's rasburicase)
    • Manage Hyperkalemia: K >6.0 mEq/L or ECG changes:
      • Calcium gluconate 1-2 g (10-20 mL of 10% solution) IV over 2-3 min (cardiac membrane stabilization)
      • Insulin 10 units IV + Dextrose 50% 25 g (1 amp D50) IV (shifts K intracellularly)
      • Albuterol 10-20 mg nebulized (shifts K intracellularly)
      • Sodium polystyrene sulfonate (Kayexalate) 30 g PO or 50 g PR (GI K excretion, slow onset)
      • Hemodialysis if refractory or K >7.0 mEq/L
    • Manage Hyperphosphatemia: Phosphate binders: Sevelamer 800-1600 mg PO TID with meals, or calcium acetate 667 mg (169 mg elemental Ca) 2-3 tabs PO TID with meals. AVOID aluminum-based binders (neurotoxicity)
    • Manage Hypocalcemia: Usually asymptomatic (from calcium-phosphate binding). Treat only if symptomatic (tetany, seizures, QTc >500 ms): Calcium gluconate 1-2 g IV over 10 min, then infusion. Avoid aggressive calcium repletion if phosphate >5 mg/dL (risk of metastatic calcification)
    • Hemodialysis (if refractory): Indications: K >7 mEq/L despite treatment, severe AKI (Cr >5 mg/dL or oliguria), fluid overload, symptomatic hypocalcemia with high phosphate. Removes potassium, phosphate, uric acid rapidly

Oncology Consultation:

  • MANDATORY for all oncologic emergencies
  • URGENT consultation for SVC syndrome, MSCC, severe hypercalcemia, TLS

Disposition:

  • ICU: MSCC, severe SVC syndrome (respiratory distress, stridor, altered mental status), severe hypercalcemia (Ca >15 mg/dL or altered mental status), clinical TLS with AKI/hyperkalemia, need for emergent intervention (surgery, stenting, dialysis)
  • Floor: SVC syndrome (mild-moderate symptoms), hypercalcemia (Ca 12-14 mg/dL without severe symptoms), laboratory TLS without organ dysfunction
  • Discharge: Hypercalcemia resolved/controlled, close oncology follow-up for definitive treatment of underlying cancer
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Malignant Spinal Cord Compression is a "Hours Not Days" Emergency: Neurologic function at presentation predicts outcome. If patient is ambulatory at diagnosis, 80-90% remain ambulatory after treatment. If already paraplegic, only 10% regain ambulation. EVERY HOUR COUNTS. Give dexamethasone 10 mg IV IMMEDIATELY (even before MRI), get MRI within 1 hour, consult radiation oncology and neurosurgery within 2 hours. Do NOT delay for "routine" MRI scheduling - this is a STAT test. Back pain + new weakness = MSCC until proven otherwise.
  • SVC Syndrome is NOT Always an Emergency Requiring Immediate Biopsy: Classic teaching says "never biopsy before diagnosis" is WRONG. Most SVC syndrome cases develop gradually over days to weeks and are NOT immediately life-threatening. The vast majority of patients can safely undergo tissue diagnosis (biopsy, bronchoscopy) before definitive treatment. Tissue diagnosis is CRITICAL because treatment differs: lymphoma gets chemotherapy, NSCLC gets radiation, SCLC gets chemo+radiation. Only give empiric steroids/radiation for TRUE emergencies: stridor, respiratory failure, severe cerebral edema. Otherwise, GET TISSUE FIRST.
  • Hypercalcemia of Malignancy Has TWO Distinct Mechanisms Requiring Different Long-term Management: (1) PTHrP-mediated (80%): squamous cell lung, RCC, breast - tumor secretes PTHrP which is NOT detected on standard PTH assay (need specific PTHrP test). Treat with bisphosphonates + treat tumor. (2) Osteolytic metastases (20%): breast, myeloma - direct bone destruction. PTH suppressed in BOTH. Distinguish by PTHrP level, bone scan, or clinical context. Long-term: monthly bisphosphonates (zoledronic acid 4 mg IV) or denosumab 120 mg SC prevent recurrent hypercalcemia and reduce skeletal-related events.
  • Calcitonin Works Fast but Doesn't Last - Use as Bridge Therapy Only: Calcitonin lowers calcium within 4-6 hours (fastest acting agent) but effect is modest (1-2 mg/dL decrease) and short-lived (tachyphylaxis after 48 hours). Bisphosphonates take 4-7 days to work but last weeks. Strategy: Use calcitonin for severe symptomatic hypercalcemia (Ca >14 mg/dL with confusion) as a bridge while waiting for bisphosphonates to kick in. Give BOTH together initially. After 48-72 hours, calcitonin becomes ineffective so discontinue.
  • Tumor Lysis Syndrome Prevention is Better Than Treatment: High-risk patients (high tumor burden Burkitt lymphoma, acute leukemias with WBC >50,000/ÂµL, bulky lymphoma) should receive TLS prophylaxis BEFORE starting chemotherapy: aggressive hydration (3-4 L/day), allopurinol 300-600 mg daily, rasburicase for highest risk. Monitor labs q6-8h during first 48-72 hours after starting chemo. Once TLS develops with AKI, treatment is difficult and requires hemodialysis. Prevention saves kidneys.
  • Rasburicase is Contraindicated in G6PD Deficiency (Causes Severe Hemolysis): Rasburicase converts uric acid to hydrogen peroxide, which causes oxidative stress. In G6PD-deficient patients, this triggers massive hemolysis, methemoglobinemia, and can be fatal. ALWAYS check G6PD level before giving rasburicase. If G6PD deficient, use allopurinol + aggressive hydration only. African Americans, Mediterranean descent, Asians have higher G6PD deficiency prevalence.
  • Do NOT Aggressively Treat Hypocalcemia in Tumor Lysis Syndrome if Phosphate is Elevated: In TLS, calcium is LOW because it binds to phosphate (calcium-phosphate product). If you give IV calcium when phosphate is >5 mg/dL, you create metastatic calcification (calcium-phosphate crystals deposit in kidneys, heart, lungs, soft tissues), worsening organ damage. Only treat hypocalcemia if SYMPTOMATIC (tetany, seizures, QTc >500 ms) AND cautiously (small doses calcium gluconate 1 g IV slowly). Focus on lowering phosphate with binders and dialysis.
  • Loop Diuretics for Hypercalcemia Have Fallen Out of Favor: Old teaching: give aggressive saline PLUS furosemide to enhance calciuresis. Modern evidence shows loop diuretics provide minimal additional calcium lowering, increase risk of dehydration (which worsens hypercalcemia), cause electrolyte abnormalities, and may impair renal function. Current approach: aggressive saline hydration FIRST, then bisphosphonates. Only use furosemide if patient develops volume overload from aggressive fluids (CHF, renal failure). Do NOT use furosemide routinely.
  • Radiation Therapy is the Primary Treatment for MOST Malignant Spinal Cord Compression: Surgery is beneficial in SELECT patients: unknown primary (need tissue), spinal instability/fracture, radioresistant tumor (RCC, melanoma, sarcoma), previously irradiated spine, rapid neurologic decline despite radiation. For the majority of patients with known cancer and intact spine, EMERGENT radiation therapy (within 24 hours) is the standard. Exception: the landmark Patchell study showed surgical decompression FOLLOWED by radiation was superior to radiation alone in patients who were ambulatory, had good performance status, and had single-level compression from solid tumor metastases. Discuss with neurosurgery AND radiation oncology.
  • Denosumab is More Potent Than Bisphosphonates but Has Unique Toxicities: Denosumab (monoclonal antibody against RANKL) is superior to zoledronic acid for preventing skeletal-related events and treating hypercalcemia of malignancy. Advantages: can use in renal failure (unlike bisphosphonates), no renal toxicity, more potent. Disadvantages: (1) Rebound hypercalcemia when stopped (must transition to bisphosphonates if stopping), (2) Severe hypocalcemia if baseline low calcium or vitamin D deficiency (give calcium/vitamin D supplementation), (3) Increased osteonecrosis of jaw risk with long-term use. Dose: 120 mg SC weekly Ã— 4 weeks, then monthly.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Malignant spinal cord compression (ANY degree of weakness or bowel/bladder dysfunction) - neurosurgical emergency
  • Severe SVC syndrome with respiratory distress, stridor, or altered mental status
  • Severe hypercalcemia (ionized Ca >1.75 mmol/L or total Ca >15 mg/dL) with altered mental status
  • Clinical tumor lysis syndrome with acute kidney injury (Cr >2 mg/dL or oliguria)
  • Hyperkalemia >7.0 mEq/L or ECG changes (peaked T waves, widened QRS)
  • Need for emergent hemodialysis (refractory hyperkalemia, severe AKI, fluid overload)
  • Hemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachycardia)
  • Respiratory failure requiring intubation
  • Seizures (from hypercalcemia, hypocalcemia, or CNS involvement)
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • No acute life-threatening emergency (no MSCC, severe SVC syndrome, severe hypercalcemia/TLS)
  • Hypercalcemia corrected or controlled (calcium <11.5 mg/dL, asymptomatic)
  • Tumor lysis syndrome resolved (electrolytes normalized, renal function stable)
  • SVC syndrome mild and stable (minimal symptoms, no respiratory compromise)
  • Definitive treatment plan in place (radiation therapy scheduled, chemotherapy regimen determined)
  • Close oncology follow-up arranged (within 1-7 days depending on urgency)
  • Adequate hydration maintained (able to drink 2-3 L/day)
  • No need for ongoing IV medications or interventions
  • Patient/family educated on warning signs to return (worsening weakness, confusion, respiratory distress, severe nausea/vomiting)
  • Pain controlled on oral medications
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

116. ANTICOAGULATION REVERSAL / MAJOR BLEEDING

Warfarin Reversal â€¢ DOAC Reversal â€¢ Major Hemorrhage â€¢ Rapid Correction
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Patient on anticoagulation (warfarin, DOACs, heparin, LMWH) presenting with life-threatening bleeding (intracranial hemorrhage, GI bleed with hemodynamic instability, massive hemoptysis) OR need for urgent surgery/procedure requiring immediate anticoagulation reversal.

  • Pathophysiology: Anticoagulants impair hemostasis by various mechanisms: warfarin inhibits vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X, protein C/S), DOACs directly inhibit thrombin (dabigatran) or factor Xa (rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban), heparins enhance antithrombin activity. Excessive anticoagulation or trauma/bleeding while therapeutic increases bleeding risk. Reversal strategies target the specific mechanism: vitamin K and coagulation factor replacement for warfarin, specific reversal agents for DOACs, protamine for heparins.
  • Risk Factors: Supratherapeutic anticoagulation (INR >4 on warfarin, peak DOAC levels), elderly (>75 years), renal impairment (DOACs accumulate, especially dabigatran), concurrent antiplatelet therapy (aspirin, clopidogrel), liver disease, thrombocytopenia, recent trauma/fall, alcohol use, drug interactions (antibiotics, antifungals, amiodarone increase warfarin effect), medication non-adherence (dose errors)
  • Symptoms - Major Bleeding: Intracranial hemorrhage (severe headache, vomiting, altered mental status, focal neurologic deficits), GI bleeding (hematemesis, melena, hematochezia, hemodynamic instability), hemoptysis (massive, compromising airway), gross hematuria (persistent, with clots, hemodynamic instability), retroperitoneal hematoma (flank/back pain, falling hematocrit, hypotension), hemarthrosis (painful swollen joint), prolonged bleeding from trauma/procedure
  • Physical Exam: Tachycardia, hypotension (SBP <90 mmHg from blood loss), pallor, altered mental status (if intracranial hemorrhage or shock), melena/hematochezia on rectal exam, hematemesis, ecchymoses/petechiae (excessive), hematoma (expanding, tense), decreased breath sounds (hemothorax), neurologic deficits (if ICH)
  • Variants/Subtypes: Life-threatening major bleeding (intracranial hemorrhage, massive GI bleed with shock) vs non-life-threatening major bleeding (clinically significant but stable) vs supratherapeutic anticoagulation without bleeding. Urgent surgery/procedure requiring reversal. Type of anticoagulant: warfarin vs DOAC (dabigatran vs Xa inhibitor) vs heparin vs LMWH determines reversal strategy
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Studies:

  • Complete Blood Count: Hemoglobin/hematocrit (baseline and serial q2-4h to assess ongoing bleeding). Platelet count (thrombocytopenia worsens bleeding)
  • Coagulation Studies:
    • PT/INR: Elevated in warfarin use (therapeutic INR 2-3 for most indications, 2.5-3.5 for mechanical valves). Supratherapeutic if >4. Also prolonged in factor deficiency, liver disease
    • aPTT: Elevated in heparin use (therapeutic aPTT 60-80 sec or 1.5-2.5Ã— control). Also prolonged in hemophilia, factor deficiencies
    • Thrombin Time (TT) or Ecarin Clotting Time (ECT): Prolonged with dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor). Useful to confirm dabigatran effect
    • Anti-Xa Level: Elevated with Xa inhibitors (rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban) and heparins (LMWH, UFH). Quantifies drug activity. Useful if uncertain about DOAC effect
  • Type and Screen/Crossmatch: Prepare for transfusion (order 4-6 units PRBCs if massive bleeding)
  • Basic Metabolic Panel: Renal function (CrCl affects DOAC clearance). BUN/Cr ratio (elevated in upper GI bleed from blood protein absorption)
  • Liver Function Tests: Baseline liver function (affects warfarin metabolism, coagulation factor synthesis)
  • Fibrinogen: If massive transfusion/DIC suspected (fibrinogen <150 mg/dL concerning)

Imaging (Based on Bleeding Source):

  • CT Head Non-Contrast (STAT if altered mental status, headache, focal deficits): Rule out intracranial hemorrhage. ICH on anticoagulation has high mortality (40-50%)
  • CT Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis with IV Contrast: If retroperitoneal hematoma, hemothorax, or bleeding source uncertain. Can identify active arterial extravasation ("contrast blush") for IR embolization
  • Endoscopy (EGD/Colonoscopy): For upper/lower GI bleeding once hemodynamically stabilized. Therapeutic (can cauterize, clip, inject epinephrine)
  • Angiography: If active bleeding identified on CT and hemodynamically unstable. IR can perform embolization
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Resuscitation (All Patients with Major Bleeding):

  • 2 large-bore IV access (18G or larger), consider central line if massive transfusion anticipated
  • Aggressive IV fluid resuscitation: Bolus NS or LR 1-2 L (reassess after each liter)
  • Maintain SBP >90 mmHg (permissive hypotension for trauma, higher target for ICH)
  • Supplemental oxygen, continuous monitoring (telemetry, pulse ox)
  • NPO (if endoscopy or surgery anticipated)
  • STOP anticoagulant and antiplatelet agents immediately
  • Treat underlying bleeding source: endoscopy (GI bleed), neurosurgery (ICH evacuation if indicated), IR embolization (active arterial bleeding)

Transfusion Therapy (Major Hemorrhage):

  • Packed Red Blood Cells (PRBCs): Transfuse if Hgb <7 g/dL (or <8-9 g/dL if active bleeding/unstable). Massive transfusion protocol if hemodynamic instability despite 2 L crystalloid
  • Massive Transfusion Protocol (if ongoing massive bleeding): PRBCs : FFP : Platelets in 1:1:1 ratio. Example: 6 units PRBCs, 6 units FFP, 1 apheresis platelet unit (equivalent to 6 pooled platelets). Prevents dilutional coagulopathy
  • Platelets: Transfuse if platelet count <50,000/ÂµL and active bleeding (or <100,000/ÂµL for ICH or neurosurgery). Goal >50,000/ÂµL
  • Cryoprecipitate: If fibrinogen <150 mg/dL. 10 units cryoprecipitate raises fibrinogen ~50-70 mg/dL
  • Tranexamic Acid (TXA): 1 g IV over 10 min, then 1 g IV over 8 hours. Antifibrinolytic. Reduces mortality in trauma with hemorrhagic shock (CRASH-2 trial). Use within 3 hours of injury. Caution: increases VTE risk. Do NOT use in hematuria (risk of clot obstruction)

WARFARIN REVERSAL:

  • Four-Factor Prothrombin Complex Concentrate (4F-PCC, Kcentra) - FIRST LINE for Life-Threatening Bleeding:
    • Contains factors II, VII, IX, X + protein C and S. Reverses warfarin within 15-30 minutes
    • Dose based on INR and body weight:
      • INR 2-4: 25 units/kg IV (max 2500 units)
      • INR 4-6: 35 units/kg IV (max 3500 units)
      • INR >6: 50 units/kg IV (max 5000 units)
    • Give over 15 minutes (rate not to exceed 4 mL/min)
    • Recheck INR 30 min after infusion (goal INR <1.5). If still elevated, can repeat dose
    • Superior to FFP (faster, more reliable, no volume overload, no need for typing/crossmatch)
    • Risk: thrombosis (MI, CVA, PE, DVT - 1-3% incidence). Weigh risk vs benefit
  • Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) - Alternative if PCC Unavailable:
    • Dose 10-15 mL/kg (typically 4-6 units for 70 kg patient). Repeat INR after infusion
    • Slower reversal (requires thawing 30-45 min, typing/crossmatch), variable factor levels, volume overload risk (each unit = 250 mL), transfusion reactions
    • Use only if PCC not available or if coagulopathy from liver disease (FFP replaces ALL factors)
  • Vitamin K (Phytonadione) - ALWAYS GIVE WITH PCC/FFP:
    • Dose: 10 mg IV slow push over 10-30 minutes (or PO/SC if not bleeding). Prevents re-elevation of INR after PCC wears off (PCC half-life 6-8 hours, vitamin K restores factor production)
    • Onset 6-12 hours IV, peak effect 24 hours. Duration 1-2 weeks. Give with PCC/FFP for sustained reversal
    • IV vitamin K has anaphylaxis risk (0.1%) - give slow push, monitor closely. Do NOT give IM (hematoma risk)
  • Indications for Emergent Reversal: Intracranial hemorrhage, massive GI bleed with hemodynamic instability, retroperitoneal hematoma, need for urgent surgery/procedure, INR >10 with high bleeding risk

DOAC REVERSAL:

  • Dabigatran (Pradaxa) - Direct Thrombin Inhibitor:
    • Idarucizumab (Praxbind) - SPECIFIC REVERSAL AGENT (FIRST LINE):
      • Humanized monoclonal antibody fragment, binds dabigatran with 350Ã— higher affinity than thrombin
      • Dose: 5 g IV (two 2.5 g vials) given as two consecutive infusions 15 min apart, or as bolus
      • Reverses dabigatran effect within 5-10 minutes. Duration 24 hours
      • Check aPTT or thrombin time before and after (should normalize)
      • Very safe, no prothrombotic risk reported
    • Hemodialysis (if idarucizumab unavailable): Dabigatran is 35% protein-bound, can be dialyzed. 4-hour dialysis session removes ~60% of drug
    • PCC (off-label, if no other option): 50 units/kg (max 5000 units). Less effective than for warfarin reversal. Use only if idarucizumab unavailable and cannot dialyze
  • Factor Xa Inhibitors (Rivaroxaban, Apixaban, Edoxaban):
    • Andexanet Alfa (Andexxa) - SPECIFIC REVERSAL AGENT (FIRST LINE if available):
      • Modified recombinant factor Xa decoy protein, binds Xa inhibitors
      • Dose depends on DOAC, dose, and time since last dose:
        • LOW DOSE: 400 mg IV bolus over 15 min, then 4 mg/min infusion Ã— 2 hours (total 480 mg). For rivaroxaban â‰¤10 mg or apixaban â‰¤5 mg, last dose >8 hours ago
        • HIGH DOSE: 800 mg IV bolus over 30 min, then 8 mg/min infusion Ã— 2 hours (total 960 mg). For rivaroxaban >10 mg, apixaban >5 mg, edoxaban, or unknown dose/time
      • Reduces anti-Xa activity by 90% within minutes. Duration 2 hours (may need repeat dosing)
      • Risk: thrombosis (10% within 30 days in trials). Reserve for life-threatening bleeding
      • Very expensive (~$50,000 per dose), not universally available
    • Four-Factor PCC (Kcentra) - ALTERNATIVE if Andexanet Unavailable:
      • Off-label use. Replaces consumed clotting factors, partially reverses Xa inhibitor effect
      • Dose: 50 units/kg IV (max 5000 units)
      • Less effective than andexanet but widely available and much less expensive
    • Activated Prothrombin Complex Concentrate (aPCC, FEIBA): 50 units/kg (max 5000 units). Contains activated factor VII. Use if 4F-PCC unavailable. Higher thrombosis risk than 4F-PCC
  • Supportive Measures for All DOACs:
    • Activated charcoal (50 g PO) if last dose within 2-4 hours (prevents further absorption)
    • Hemodialysis generally NOT effective (except dabigatran) - DOACs are >80% protein-bound
    • Transfuse PRBCs, platelets, consider TXA

HEPARIN / LMWH REVERSAL:

  • Protamine Sulfate (Specific Reversal for Heparin):
    • Cationic protein, binds anionic heparin, neutralizes anticoagulant effect
    • Unfractionated Heparin (UFH): 1 mg protamine per 100 units heparin. Give dose based on total heparin received in last 2 hours (UFH half-life 60-90 min). Example: If patient received 5000 units UFH 1 hour ago, give 50 mg protamine IV
    • LMWH (enoxaparin, dalteparin): 1 mg protamine per 1 mg enoxaparin (or 100 units dalteparin) given in last 8 hours. If >8 hours, give 0.5 mg protamine per 1 mg enoxaparin. LMWH reversal is incomplete (~60% neutralization) because protamine only reverses anti-IIa activity, not anti-Xa
    • Max single dose: 50 mg protamine (risk of hypotension if faster)
    • Give slow IV push over 10 minutes (rate not to exceed 5 mg/min). Rapid infusion causes hypotension, bradycardia
    • Check aPTT (UFH) or anti-Xa level (LMWH) 5-15 min after dose. Repeat protamine if still prolonged
    • Adverse effects: Hypotension (slow infusion), anaphylaxis (fish allergy, prior protamine exposure from NPH insulin, prior vasectomy), pulmonary hypertension

Consultation:

  • Hematology: Urgent consult for all major bleeding on anticoagulation, guidance on reversal strategy
  • GI: Urgent endoscopy for upper/lower GI bleeding once stabilized
  • Neurosurgery: STAT consult for intracranial hemorrhage (surgical evacuation if indicated)
  • Interventional Radiology: For active arterial bleeding on CT (embolization)
  • Surgery: For intra-abdominal, retroperitoneal bleeding requiring operative management

Disposition:

  • ICU: Intracranial hemorrhage, hemodynamic instability (SBP <90, HR >120), massive transfusion, need for urgent surgery/procedure, ongoing bleeding despite reversal, need for serial neurologic exams
  • Floor: Stable after reversal, minor bleeding controlled, supratherapeutic INR without bleeding (INR >4 but <10, no bleeding)
  • Discharge: Supratherapeutic INR without bleeding, corrected with vitamin K, close follow-up arranged (INR recheck in 24 hours)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Four-Factor PCC is Superior to FFP for Warfarin Reversal: PCC reverses warfarin within 15-30 minutes (vs 6-12 hours for FFP), with smaller volume (100 mL vs 1-1.5 L), no need for typing/crossmatch (immediately available), and more predictable factor levels. FFP requires thawing (30-45 min delay), causes volume overload (especially problematic in elderly or CHF patients), and has variable factor content. For life-threatening bleeding (ICH, massive GI bleed), use PCC. FFP is reserved for situations where PCC is unavailable or if patient has liver disease with multifactorial coagulopathy needing ALL clotting factors replaced.
  • Always Give Vitamin K WITH PCC in Warfarin Reversal: PCC provides immediate reversal (factors II, VII, IX, X) but has short half-life (6-8 hours). Without vitamin K, warfarin continues to inhibit hepatic synthesis and INR re-elevates after PCC wears off. Vitamin K takes 6-12 hours to work but restores endogenous factor production and provides sustained reversal lasting 1-2 weeks. ALWAYS give vitamin K 10 mg IV (slow push) CONCURRENTLY with PCC. This combination prevents rebound INR elevation and need for repeat PCC dosing.
  • Idarucizumab (Praxbind) is Highly Effective and Safe for Dabigatran Reversal: Idarucizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment that binds dabigatran with 350Ã— higher affinity than thrombin, completely reversing its anticoagulant effect within 5-10 minutes. Dose is simple: 5 g IV (two 2.5 g vials). Unlike PCC, idarucizumab has NO prothrombotic risk - it's remarkably safe. Check aPTT or dilute thrombin time before and after (should normalize). If reversal incomplete, consider hemodialysis (dabigatran is dialyzable). Idarucizumab is now widely available and should be first-line for dabigatran-associated major bleeding or urgent surgery.
  • Andexanet Alfa is Expensive and Has Thrombosis Risk - Use Judiciously: Andexanet alfa (Andexxa) reverses factor Xa inhibitors (rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban) within minutes and reduces anti-Xa activity by 90%. However, it costs ~$50,000 per dose and is associated with 10% thrombosis rate (MI, stroke, VTE) within 30 days. Reserve for LIFE-THREATENING bleeding only (ICH, massive bleeding with shock). For non-life-threatening bleeding (e.g., stable GI bleed), consider supportive care Â± PCC rather than andexanet. Also, andexanet's effect wanes after 2 hours, so rebleeding is common.
  • PCC Has Thrombosis Risk - Balance Bleeding vs Thrombosis: Both 4F-PCC and andexanet alfa carry 1-3% thrombosis risk (arterial and venous). This creates a dilemma: patient is anticoagulated for a reason (atrial fibrillation, mechanical valve, prior VTE) so reversal increases thrombosis risk, but they're bleeding so need reversal. Clinical judgment: use reversal agents for LIFE-THREATENING bleeding (ICH, massive bleeding with hemodynamic instability) where immediate death risk outweighs delayed thrombosis risk. For minor bleeding or supratherapeutic INR without bleeding, use vitamin K alone or hold anticoagulation temporarily rather than PCC.
  • Protamine Reverses Unfractionated Heparin Completely, LMWH Only Partially: Protamine neutralizes UFH immediately and completely (1 mg protamine per 100 units heparin). However, LMWH reversal is incomplete - protamine only neutralizes ~60% of enoxaparin's anticoagulant effect because it reverses anti-IIa activity but NOT anti-Xa activity (which accounts for 40% of LMWH's effect). Dose: 1 mg protamine per 1 mg enoxaparin given in last 8 hours. For life-threatening LMWH-associated bleeding with incomplete protamine reversal, consider PCC or andexanet as adjunct.
  • Check INR 30 Minutes After PCC to Confirm Reversal: PCC effect is rapid but variable. After giving PCC for warfarin reversal, recheck INR 30 minutes later. Goal INR <1.5 for most bleeding, <1.3 for ICH or neurosurgery. If INR still elevated, can give additional PCC (25 units/kg). If INR normalized but patient continues bleeding, problem is NOT the INR - look for surgical bleeding source requiring intervention (endoscopy, IR embolization, surgery). Don't keep giving PCC if INR is <1.5 - you'll just increase thrombosis risk without additional benefit.
  • Massive Transfusion Protocol Uses 1:1:1 Ratio to Prevent Dilutional Coagulopathy: Massive transfusion (>10 units PRBCs in 24 hours) causes dilutional coagulopathy, thrombocytopenia, hypocalcemia, hypothermia, acidosis (trauma "lethal triad"). Modern massive transfusion protocols use 1:1:1 ratio: 1 unit PRBC : 1 unit FFP : 1 platelet unit (1 apheresis or 6 pooled). This prevents dilutional coagulopathy by replacing clotting factors and platelets proportionally. Old practice (crystalloid + PRBCs only) worsened coagulopathy and increased mortality. Activate massive transfusion protocol early if ongoing hemorrhage despite 2 L crystalloid.
  • Tranexamic Acid (TXA) Reduces Mortality in Trauma with Hemorrhagic Shock: The CRASH-2 trial showed TXA (1 g IV bolus, then 1 g infusion over 8 hours) given within 3 hours of traumatic injury reduced all-cause mortality by 10% without increasing VTE. Mechanism: antifibrinolytic (blocks plasminogen activation). Use for trauma patients with hemorrhagic shock (SBP <90 or HR >110) within 3 hours of injury. Do NOT use after 3 hours (increased mortality, possibly from late fibrinolysis impairing clot remodeling). Caution in hematuria (risk of ureteral clot obstruction).
  • When to Resume Anticoagulation After Major Bleeding: This is challenging. Balance thrombosis risk (stroke in atrial fibrillation, valve thrombosis, recurrent VTE) vs rebleeding risk. General approach: (1) ICH: usually permanently discontinue oral anticoagulation, consider left atrial appendage closure for atrial fibrillation. (2) Major GI bleed: resume in 7-14 days if source controlled endoscopically and hemostasis confirmed. (3) Mechanical heart valve: very high thrombosis risk - resume as soon as hemostasis achieved (24-48 hours), bridge with heparin. Consult hematology, cardiology, or neurology for individualized decision-making.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Intracranial hemorrhage (any size, any location) on anticoagulation
  • Hemodynamic instability (SBP <90 mmHg, HR >120 bpm, shock index >1)
  • Massive bleeding requiring massive transfusion protocol (>4 units PRBCs in 1 hour or >10 units in 24 hours)
  • Hemoglobin drop >3-4 g/dL or <7 g/dL despite transfusion
  • Active ongoing bleeding despite reversal and supportive measures
  • Retroperitoneal hematoma with hemodynamic instability
  • Need for urgent surgery or invasive procedure (neurosurgery, laparotomy)
  • Altered mental status (from ICH or shock)
  • Respiratory compromise (massive hemoptysis, hemothorax)
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable (SBP >100, HR <100, no orthostatic hypotension)
  • Bleeding source controlled or minor
  • Hemoglobin stable for >12-24 hours (no further drop)
  • INR or coagulation studies corrected or therapeutic (if restarting anticoagulation)
  • No signs of ongoing bleeding (stable Hgb, vital signs stable, no melena/hematochezia/hematuria)
  • No indication for ICU-level care (no ICH, no need for serial transfusions)
  • Clear plan for anticoagulation management (resume, change agent, or discontinue based on bleeding risk vs thrombosis risk)
  • Close follow-up arranged (hematology, cardiology, PCP within 1-7 days)
  • INR recheck scheduled if on warfarin (24-48 hours)
  • Patient/family educated on signs of rebleeding and when to return
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

117. SYSTEMIC LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS (SLE) FLARE

Multisystem Autoimmune â€¢ Rash â€¢ Arthritis â€¢ Serositis â€¢ Lupus Nephritis â€¢ Cytopenias
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Patient with known SLE (or new diagnosis) presenting with acute exacerbation of multisystem autoimmune disease: malar/discoid rash, polyarthritis, serositis (pleuritis, pericarditis), acute kidney injury from lupus nephritis, cytopenias, or CNS lupus (psychosis, seizures).

  • Pathophysiology: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by production of autoantibodies (ANA, anti-dsDNA, anti-Smith) causing immune complex deposition in multiple organs. Flares triggered by infections, UV exposure, medications (sulfa drugs, hydralazine), pregnancy, stress, medication non-compliance. Organ involvement: (1) Mucocutaneous (malar rash, discoid lesions, photosensitivity, oral ulcers), (2) Musculoskeletal (polyarthritis, myositis), (3) Renal (lupus nephritis - most serious, leading cause of morbidity), (4) Hematologic (autoimmune hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia), (5) Serositis (pleuritis, pericarditis), (6) Neuropsychiatric (psychosis, seizures, cognitive dysfunction, stroke from antiphospholipid antibodies), (7) Cardiac (Libman-Sacks endocarditis, myocarditis)
  • Risk Factors: Young women (90% of SLE patients), African American, Hispanic, Asian descent (higher prevalence and severity), family history (genetic predisposition), known SLE diagnosis, medication non-compliance (stopped hydroxychloroquine, steroids), triggers: infections (URI, UTI), UV light exposure, pregnancy (postpartum flares common), estrogen (OCPs, HRT), medications (sulfonamides, hydralazine, procainamide, isoniazid, minocycline)
  • Symptoms: Constitutional (fever, fatigue, weight loss), malar rash ("butterfly rash" across cheeks/nose), discoid rash (scarring, hyperpigmentation), photosensitive rash, oral/nasal ulcers (usually painless), polyarthralgia/polyarthritis (symmetric, non-erosive, hands/wrists/knees), pleuritic chest pain (pleuritis), pericardial chest pain (pericarditis), dyspnea (pleural effusion, pulmonary hemorrhage), Raynaud phenomenon, alopecia (non-scarring), headache, confusion/psychosis, seizures, vision changes (retinal vasculitis)
  • Physical Exam: Fever, malar rash (erythematous, flat or raised, spares nasolabial folds), discoid lesions (scarring alopecia, hyperpigmentation), oral ulcers, synovitis (swelling, tenderness in MCPs, PIPs, wrists, knees - symmetric), pleural friction rub, pericardial friction rub, muffled heart sounds (pericardial effusion), peripheral edema (nephrotic syndrome), hypertension (lupus nephritis), altered mental status, focal neurologic deficits, retinal hemorrhages/exudates on fundoscopy
  • Variants/Subtypes: Mild flare (rash, arthritis, mild serositis) vs Severe flare (lupus nephritis, CNS lupus, severe cytopenias, vasculitis, pulmonary hemorrhage). Lupus nephritis classes (I-VI): Class III/IV (proliferative) most severe, requires aggressive immunosuppression. Drug-induced lupus (procainamide, hydralazine, isoniazid, minocycline) - usually mild, resolves after stopping drug. Neonatal lupus (anti-Ro/La antibodies in pregnant mothers cross placenta, causes congenital heart block in fetus)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Studies:

  • Complete Blood Count: Leukopenia (WBC <4000/ÂµL, often lymphopenia), autoimmune hemolytic anemia (Hgb <10 g/dL, Coombs positive), thrombocytopenia (platelets <100,000/ÂµL). Pancytopenia in severe cases
  • Basic Metabolic Panel: Elevated creatinine (AKI from lupus nephritis), hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis (if severe renal involvement)
  • Urinalysis: CRITICAL for lupus nephritis. Proteinuria (>0.5 g/24hr or spot urine protein:creatinine ratio >0.5), hematuria (RBCs, RBC casts - pathognomonic for glomerulonephritis), pyuria (sterile, WBC casts). Active urine sediment (cellular casts) indicates active lupus nephritis
  • 24-Hour Urine or Spot Urine Protein:Creatinine Ratio: Quantify proteinuria. Nephrotic range proteinuria (>3.5 g/24hr or spot ratio >3.5) indicates severe lupus nephritis
  • Complement Levels (C3, C4): LOW in active SLE (immune complex formation consumes complement). Low C3 (<90 mg/dL) and C4 (<16 mg/dL) correlate with disease activity, especially lupus nephritis. Normal complement makes SLE flare less likely
  • Anti-dsDNA Antibody: ELEVATED in active SLE (especially lupus nephritis). High specificity (95%) for SLE. Titer correlates with disease activity. Rising anti-dsDNA suggests flare
  • Antinuclear Antibody (ANA): Positive (>1:80) in 95% of SLE patients (sensitive but not specific). Negative ANA makes SLE unlikely. Do NOT trend - stays positive even in remission
  • Anti-Smith Antibody: Highly specific (99%) for SLE but only 30% sensitive. Does NOT correlate with disease activity. Used for diagnosis, not monitoring
  • Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR): Often elevated (>30 mm/hr) in active SLE. Not specific but useful for trending
  • C-Reactive Protein (CRP): Usually NORMAL or mildly elevated in SLE flares (despite high ESR). Markedly elevated CRP (>10 mg/dL) suggests infection or serositis (pericarditis) rather than pure SLE flare
  • Hemolysis Labs (if anemia): Elevated LDH, indirect bilirubin, low haptoglobin, positive Coombs test (direct antiglobulin test). Indicates autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Antiphospholipid Antibodies: If thrombosis or recurrent pregnancy loss. Lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin IgG/IgM, anti-beta-2-glycoprotein I. Present in 30-40% of SLE patients (antiphospholipid syndrome)

Imaging:

  • Chest X-ray: Pleural effusion (pleuritis, common in SLE), pulmonary infiltrates (lupus pneumonitis, pulmonary hemorrhage, infection), cardiomegaly (pericardial effusion, myocarditis)
  • Echocardiogram: If pericardial chest pain, muffled heart sounds, or elevated JVP. Assess for pericardial effusion, tamponade physiology, Libman-Sacks endocarditis (verrucous vegetations, usually asymptomatic), myocarditis (reduced EF)
  • CT Chest (if pulmonary hemorrhage suspected): Ground-glass opacities (alveolar hemorrhage), consolidations. Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage is life-threatening SLE complication
  • MRI Brain (if CNS symptoms): Rule out stroke, posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES), transverse myelitis, CNS vasculitis. May be normal in neuropsychiatric lupus (diagnosis of exclusion)

Special Studies:

  • Kidney Biopsy (if lupus nephritis suspected): Indications: new-onset proteinuria >0.5 g/24hr, active urine sediment (RBC casts), rising creatinine. Biopsy determines lupus nephritis class (I-VI) and guides treatment. Class III (focal proliferative) and Class IV (diffuse proliferative) require aggressive immunosuppression (cyclophosphamide or mycophenolate + steroids)
  • Lumbar Puncture (if CNS lupus suspected): Elevated protein, lymphocytic pleocytosis. Rule out infection (bacterial, viral, fungal meningitis). CNS lupus is diagnosis of exclusion

Diagnostic Criteria (2019 EULAR/ACR Criteria):

  • Requires ANA â‰¥1:80 as entry criterion, then score â‰¥10 points from clinical/immunologic domains. Key features: arthritis, serositis, lupus nephritis, cytopenias, malar rash, fever, low complement, anti-dsDNA
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Management:

  • Assess severity of flare: organ-threatening (lupus nephritis, CNS lupus, pulmonary hemorrhage, severe cytopenia) vs mild (rash, arthritis, mild serositis)
  • IV access, continuous monitoring if severe
  • RULE OUT INFECTION (fever in SLE can be flare OR infection - both common). Blood cultures, urinalysis/urine culture, chest X-ray, consider procalcitonin (elevated in infection, normal in SLE flare)
  • Stop potential triggers (sulfa drugs, estrogens) if identified

Glucocorticoids (Cornerstone of Acute Flare Management):

  • Mild-Moderate Flare (rash, arthritis, mild serositis): Prednisone 0.5-1 mg/kg PO daily (typically 40-60 mg daily). Taper slowly over 6-12 weeks based on response
  • Severe Flare (lupus nephritis, CNS lupus, severe cytopenias, pulmonary hemorrhage): High-dose IV methylprednisolone (pulse therapy) 500-1000 mg IV daily Ã— 3 days, then prednisone 1 mg/kg PO daily (60-80 mg). Dramatic improvement within days. Taper very slowly (months)
  • Steroid-Sparing Agents: Start or increase immunosuppression concurrently (see below) to allow steroid taper
  • PPI Prophylaxis: Pantoprazole 40 mg PO daily for GI protection with high-dose steroids
  • Pneumocystis Prophylaxis: TMP-SMX DS 1 tab PO 3Ã—/week (or dapsone, atovaquone if sulfa allergy) if prednisone >20 mg/day for >1 month
  • Calcium/Vitamin D: Calcium carbonate 1200 mg + vitamin D 800-1000 IU daily (osteoporosis prevention)

Immunosuppressive Therapy (Steroid-Sparing, Disease-Modifying):

  • Hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil) - BASELINE for ALL SLE Patients: 200-400 mg PO daily (â‰¤5 mg/kg/day). Reduces flares by 50%, improves survival, prevents thrombosis. Minimal side effects. Requires annual ophthalmology exam (rare retinal toxicity). If patient not on hydroxychloroquine, START IT. If already on it, CONTINUE (don't stop during flare)
  • Mycophenolate Mofetil (CellCept) - First Line for Lupus Nephritis: 1000-1500 mg PO BID (total 2-3 g/day). Inhibits purine synthesis, suppresses T/B cells. Preferred over cyclophosphamide (equal efficacy, less toxicity). Side effects: GI upset, leukopenia. Monitor CBC weekly initially
  • Cyclophosphamide (Cytoxan) - Alternative for Severe Lupus Nephritis: IV pulse: 500-1000 mg/mÂ² IV monthly Ã— 6 months (Euro-Lupus protocol), or 500-750 mg/mÂ² IV q2 weeks Ã— 6 doses (NIH protocol). More toxic than mycophenolate (hemorrhagic cystitis, infertility, bladder cancer). Reserved for refractory disease. Give with mesna (bladder protection), aggressive hydration
  • Azathioprine (Imuran) - Maintenance Therapy: 1-2 mg/kg/day PO (typically 100-150 mg daily). Less potent than mycophenolate. Used for maintenance after induction with mycophenolate or cyclophosphamide. Check TPMT activity before starting (TPMT deficiency causes severe myelosuppression)
  • Methotrexate: 15-25 mg PO/SC weekly. For refractory arthritis, cutaneous lupus. NOT for lupus nephritis. Give with folic acid 1 mg daily
  • Rituximab (Rituxan) - Refractory SLE: 1000 mg IV on day 1 and day 15, or 375 mg/mÂ² IV weekly Ã— 4 weeks. Monoclonal anti-CD20 antibody, depletes B cells. For refractory lupus nephritis, severe cytopenias, CNS lupus despite conventional therapy. Off-label use. Requires premedication (acetaminophen, diphenhydramine)
  • Belimumab (Benlysta) - Biologic for Refractory SLE: 10 mg/kg IV every 2 weeks Ã— 3 doses, then q4 weeks. Or 200 mg SC weekly. Monoclonal antibody against BLyS (B-lymphocyte stimulator). FDA-approved for active SLE despite standard therapy. Reduces flares, steroid requirements. Do NOT use in severe active lupus nephritis or CNS lupus

Specific Organ-Based Treatment:

  • Lupus Nephritis (Class III/IV): URGENT nephrology consult. Induction: mycophenolate 2-3 g/day PO OR cyclophosphamide 500-1000 mg/mÂ² IV monthly Ã— 6 months, PLUS high-dose steroids (methylprednisolone 1 g IV daily Ã— 3 days, then prednisone 1 mg/kg). Maintenance: mycophenolate or azathioprine for 2-3 years. Target blood pressure <130/80. ACE-I/ARB for proteinuria (even if normotensive)
  • Neuropsychiatric Lupus: High-dose steroids (methylprednisolone 1 g IV daily Ã— 3-5 days), cyclophosphamide or rituximab. Rule out infection (LP), stroke (MRI). Anticoagulation if antiphospholipid antibodies. Psychiatric symptoms often require antipsychotics (quetiapine, olanzapine), antidepressants (SSRIs)
  • Severe Cytopenias (Hgb <7 g/dL, platelets <20,000/ÂµL): High-dose steroids, IVIG 1 g/kg IV daily Ã— 2 days (for thrombocytopenia), rituximab if refractory. Transfuse PRBCs if Hgb <7 g/dL, platelets if <10,000/ÂµL or bleeding
  • Pulmonary Hemorrhage: LIFE-THREATENING. High-dose steroids (methylprednisolone 1 g IV daily Ã— 3-5 days), cyclophosphamide 500-1000 mg/mÂ² IV, plasmapheresis (removes autoantibodies). Mechanical ventilation often required. ICU admission
  • Serositis (Pleuritis, Pericarditis): NSAIDs (indomethacin 50 mg PO TID, ibuprofen 600-800 mg PO TID) + prednisone 0.5 mg/kg/day. If pericardial effusion with tamponade: pericardiocentesis

Supportive Measures:

  • NSAIDs for arthritis/serositis (use cautiously if lupus nephritis - can worsen renal function)
  • Hypertension control: ACE-I/ARB preferred (renoprotective in lupus nephritis). Target BP <130/80
  • Thromboprophylaxis: Aspirin 81 mg daily for antiphospholipid antibodies (primary prevention). Warfarin INR 2-3 for history of thrombosis (secondary prevention)
  • Sun protection: Sunscreen SPF 50+, protective clothing, avoid peak sun (UV triggers flares)
  • Vaccinations: Pneumococcal, influenza (annual), Tdap. Give BEFORE starting immunosuppression if possible. Avoid live vaccines (MMR, varicella, yellow fever) on immunosuppression

Rheumatology Consultation:

  • MANDATORY for all SLE flares
  • URGENT consultation for severe flares (lupus nephritis, CNS lupus, severe cytopenias, pulmonary hemorrhage)

Disposition:

  • ICU: Pulmonary hemorrhage, respiratory failure, severe CNS lupus (seizures, psychosis, coma), severe cytopenias with bleeding, hemodynamic instability, need for plasmapheresis
  • Floor: Lupus nephritis requiring IV pulse steroids, moderate-severe flares requiring IV methylprednisolone, inability to tolerate PO medications
  • Discharge: Mild flares (rash, arthritis, mild serositis), stable on oral prednisone/immunosuppression, close rheumatology follow-up (within 1-2 weeks)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Lupus Nephritis is the Leading Cause of Morbidity and Mortality in SLE: 50% of SLE patients develop lupus nephritis, and it's the major determinant of long-term outcomes. Untreated proliferative lupus nephritis (Class III/IV) progresses to ESRD in 20-30% of patients. KEY: Screen ALL SLE patients with urinalysis and urine protein:creatinine ratio at EVERY visit. New proteinuria >0.5 g/24hr or active sediment (RBC casts) warrants kidney biopsy. Early aggressive treatment with mycophenolate or cyclophosphamide + high-dose steroids can prevent progression to ESRD. Don't wait - kidney damage is irreversible.
  • Low Complement (C3, C4) and High Anti-dsDNA Correlate with Active Disease, Especially Lupus Nephritis: SLE flares consume complement via immune complex formation, causing low C3 (<90 mg/dL) and C4 (<16 mg/dL). Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific (95%) for SLE and titer rises during flares. Lupus nephritis almost always has low complement + elevated anti-dsDNA. Normal complement makes active SLE flare unlikely. Use complement and anti-dsDNA to TREND disease activity (unlike ANA which stays positive even in remission). Caveat: infections can also lower complement, so correlate with clinical picture.
  • Hydroxychloroquine is the Most Important Drug in SLE - Never Stop It: Hydroxychloroquine reduces SLE flares by 50%, reduces thrombosis (especially in antiphospholipid syndrome), improves survival, lowers cholesterol, and has minimal side effects. ALL SLE patients should be on hydroxychloroquine 200-400 mg daily unless contraindicated (retinopathy, G6PD deficiency). Common mistake: stopping hydroxychloroquine during pregnancy or flare. Don't do it - hydroxychloroquine is SAFE in pregnancy and should be CONTINUED during flares (add steroids/immunosuppression on top). Only toxicity: rare retinal toxicity requiring annual ophthalmology screening after 5 years.
  • Fever in SLE Can Be Flare OR Infection - Both Are Common: SLE patients are immunosuppressed from disease itself and from medications (steroids, mycophenolate, cyclophosphamide), increasing infection risk. Fever differential: (1) SLE flare (low-grade, associated with other flare symptoms like rash/arthritis, low CRP), (2) Infection (high CRP >10 mg/dL, procalcitonin elevated, focal source). ALWAYS rule out infection before attributing fever to SLE and starting high-dose steroids (which worsen infection). Get blood cultures, urinalysis/urine culture, chest X-ray. If uncertain, start antibiotics AND steroids, reassess in 24-48 hours.
  • Mycophenolate Has Replaced Cyclophosphamide as First-Line for Lupus Nephritis: The ALMS and MAINTAIN trials showed mycophenolate (2-3 g/day) is AS effective as cyclophosphamide for inducing and maintaining remission in lupus nephritis, with significantly fewer side effects. Cyclophosphamide causes hemorrhagic cystitis (give mesna), infertility (20-40% premature ovarian failure), bladder cancer (long-term risk), and severe infections. Reserve cyclophosphamide for mycophenolate-refractory disease or when fertility concerns are secondary. Mycophenolate side effects are mainly GI (nausea, diarrhea) and leukopenia - much more tolerable.
  • Neuropsychiatric Lupus is a Diagnosis of Exclusion: CNS lupus manifests as psychosis, seizures, stroke, cognitive dysfunction, cranial neuropathies, transverse myelitis. However, MANY other causes can mimic CNS lupus in SLE patients: (1) Infection (CNS infections from immunosuppression: cryptococcal meningitis, toxoplasmosis, PML), (2) Stroke from antiphospholipid antibodies (not inflammatory), (3) Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES from hypertension, especially with lupus nephritis), (4) Medication toxicity (steroids cause psychosis), (5) Metabolic (uremia from renal failure, hypercalcemia). MUST rule out these before diagnosing CNS lupus. Get MRI brain, LP (rule out infection), check antiphospholipid antibodies.
  • Libman-Sacks Endocarditis is Sterile Verrucous Vegetations, Not Bacterial: Libman-Sacks endocarditis is aseptic thrombotic vegetations on heart valves (usually mitral, aortic) in SLE and antiphospholipid syndrome. Caused by immune complex deposition, NOT infection. Key differences from bacterial endocarditis: (1) Blood cultures negative, (2) No fever/sepsis (unless concurrent infection), (3) Usually asymptomatic (incidental finding on echo), (4) Treat SLE with steroids/immunosuppression, NOT antibiotics. However, Libman-Sacks valves ARE at increased risk of superimposed bacterial endocarditis, so antibiotic prophylaxis for dental procedures is recommended in these patients.
  • Antiphospholipid Syndrome Complicates 30-40% of SLE Cases: Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) causes arterial/venous thrombosis (DVT, PE, stroke, MI), recurrent pregnancy loss (â‰¥3 spontaneous abortions), and thrombocytopenia. Diagnosed by: (1) Clinical criterion (thrombosis or pregnancy morbidity) PLUS (2) Persistent positive antiphospholipid antibodies (lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin IgG/IgM, anti-beta-2-glycoprotein I) on TWO occasions 12 weeks apart. Treatment: lifelong anticoagulation with warfarin INR 2-3 for thrombosis history. Aspirin 81 mg daily for primary prevention if antibodies positive but no thrombosis. DOACs are NOT recommended for APS (inferior to warfarin in trials).
  • Drug-Induced Lupus Resolves After Stopping the Offending Drug: Classic drugs: procainamide (20% of patients), hydralazine (5-10%), isoniazid, minocycline, TNF-alpha inhibitors (infliximab, etanercept). Presents with arthralgia, myalgia, serositis (pleuritis, pericarditis), fever. Positive ANA and anti-histone antibodies (70-95%). KEY differences from idiopathic SLE: (1) NO renal involvement, (2) NO CNS involvement, (3) Rare rash, (4) Complement normal, (5) Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies NEGATIVE. Treatment: STOP THE DRUG - symptoms resolve in weeks to months. May need short course of prednisone for symptomatic relief. No long-term immunosuppression needed.
  • Pulse-Dose IV Methylprednisolone for Severe Flares Provides Rapid Control: For life-threatening SLE flares (severe lupus nephritis, CNS lupus, pulmonary hemorrhage, severe cytopenias), give pulse-dose IV methylprednisolone 500-1000 mg IV daily Ã— 3 days. This provides MUCH higher tissue steroid levels than oral prednisone and results in dramatic improvement within 24-72 hours. After 3 days of IV pulse, transition to high-dose oral prednisone 1 mg/kg/day and taper slowly over months. Pulse steroids are generally safe (main risks: hyperglycemia, infection, avascular necrosis with chronic use). Always start steroid-sparing immunosuppression (mycophenolate, cyclophosphamide) concurrently.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage / pulmonary hemorrhage (hemoptysis, hypoxia, diffuse infiltrates on CXR)
  • Respiratory failure requiring intubation or high-flow oxygen
  • Severe neuropsychiatric lupus (seizures, coma, stroke, acute psychosis with agitation)
  • Severe thrombocytopenia (<20,000/ÂµL) with active bleeding
  • Severe autoimmune hemolytic anemia (Hgb <5-6 g/dL) with hemodynamic instability
  • Cardiac tamponade from pericardial effusion
  • Acute kidney injury with oliguria and need for urgent dialysis
  • Hemodynamic instability (hypotension, shock)
  • Need for plasmapheresis
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Mild flare only (cutaneous, musculoskeletal, mild serositis without significant effusion)
  • No organ-threatening manifestations (no lupus nephritis, CNS lupus, severe cytopenias, pulmonary hemorrhage)
  • Able to tolerate oral medications (prednisone, immunosuppressants)
  • Stable vital signs, no hypoxia, no fever (or infection ruled out)
  • No evidence of infection (cultures negative or appropriate antibiotics started)
  • Renal function stable or improving (if lupus nephritis, proteinuria not worsening)
  • Hemoglobin stable (>8-9 g/dL if AIHA), platelets >30,000-50,000/ÂµL if ITP
  • Close rheumatology follow-up arranged (within 1-2 weeks)
  • Patient educated on medication compliance (hydroxychloroquine, prednisone taper), sun protection, when to return
