  • Prescriptions provided: prednisone with clear taper schedule, PPI, calcium/vitamin D, hydroxychloroquine
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

118. GIANT CELL ARTERITIS / TEMPORAL ARTERITIS

Vision Loss Risk â€¢ Jaw Claudication â€¢ New Headache â€¢ Age >50 â€¢ ESR >50
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Patient >50 years old presenting with new-onset severe headache (temporal region), jaw claudication, vision changes (transient or permanent vision loss), and markedly elevated ESR (>50 mm/hr, often >100 mm/hr). This is a medical emergency due to risk of irreversible blindness.

  • Pathophysiology: Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is a large-vessel granulomatous vasculitis affecting medium and large arteries, particularly branches of the external carotid artery (temporal, ophthalmic, posterior ciliary arteries) and aorta. Inflammatory infiltrate with multinucleated giant cells causes intimal hyperplasia, vessel wall thickening, and luminal narrowing/occlusion. Ischemia to ophthalmic artery branches causes anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION) - the most feared complication. Untreated, 50-70% develop permanent vision loss. Systemic inflammation causes constitutional symptoms. Strongly associated with polymyalgia rheumatica (50% have concurrent PMR).
  • Risk Factors: Age >50 years (rare below 50, peak incidence 70-80 years), female (2-3:1), Northern European descent (especially Scandinavian), polymyalgia rheumatica (15-20% of PMR patients develop GCA), positive family history
  • Symptoms - Classic Triad: (1) New headache (temporal, severe, unilateral or bilateral, different from prior headaches), (2) Jaw claudication (pain/fatigue in jaw/tongue with chewing, resolves with rest - 50% of patients, HIGHLY SPECIFIC for GCA), (3) Vision changes (transient vision loss/amaurosis fugax, diplopia, or permanent vision loss - 15-20%). Other symptoms: scalp tenderness (combing hair painful), constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss, anorexia), tongue claudication, neck/throat pain
  • Associated Polymyalgia Rheumatica (PMR): Bilateral shoulder and hip girdle pain/stiffness, worse in morning, difficulty raising arms or getting out of chair. 50% of GCA patients have concurrent PMR. PMR without GCA is more common
  • Physical Exam: Temporal artery abnormalities (prominent, tender, nodular, pulseless temporal artery - 50%), scalp tenderness over temporal region, visual field defects, decreased visual acuity, relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), fundoscopy shows swollen pale optic disc (AION) or normal (posterior AION), limited shoulder/hip range of motion (if PMR)
  • Variants/Subtypes: Cranial GCA (temporal artery involvement, classic symptoms) vs Large-vessel GCA (aorta, subclavian, axillary arteries, often subclinical but can cause limb claudication, aortic aneurysm/dissection). GCA with PMR vs GCA without PMR. Occult GCA (atypical presentation: fever of unknown origin, unexplained anemia, no headache)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Studies:

  • Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR): Markedly elevated (>50 mm/hr, often 70-120 mm/hr). ESR >100 mm/hr is 90% specific but only 40% sensitive. Normal ESR (<40 mm/hr) makes GCA unlikely but does NOT rule it out (10% of biopsy-proven GCA have ESR <50)
  • C-Reactive Protein (CRP): Elevated (>10 mg/dL, often 20-50 mg/dL). More sensitive than ESR. CRP >2.45 mg/dL has 97% negative predictive value (normal CRP makes GCA very unlikely)
  • Complete Blood Count: Normocytic anemia (anemia of chronic disease, Hgb 9-11 g/dL), thrombocytosis (platelets >400,000/ÂµL common)
  • Basic Metabolic Panel: Usually normal. Assess baseline renal function before high-dose steroids
  • Liver Function Tests: Alkaline phosphatase often elevated (2-3Ã— ULN). Transaminases may be mildly elevated

Temporal Artery Biopsy (Gold Standard):

  • Indications: All suspected GCA cases to confirm diagnosis (allows eventual steroid taper, confirms need for long-term treatment)
  • Timing: Can be done within 2 weeks of starting steroids (steroid effect on biopsy is delayed 2-4 weeks). Do NOT delay steroids to get biopsy - start prednisone immediately, then biopsy within 1-2 weeks
  • Technique: Excisional biopsy of 2-3 cm segment of temporal artery (skip lesions common, long segment needed). Bilateral biopsy increases yield by 10-15% if unilateral negative
  • Histopathology: Granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells (classic but present in only 50%), intimal hyperplasia, fragmentation of internal elastic lamina, transmural mononuclear infiltrate. Negative biopsy does NOT rule out GCA (skip lesions, sampling error)

Imaging:

  • Ultrasound Temporal Arteries: "Halo sign" - hypoechoic circumferential wall thickening around temporal artery lumen. 70-90% sensitive, 90-95% specific. Non-invasive, can be done at bedside. May replace biopsy in some centers if expertise available. Steroid therapy reduces sensitivity after 3-7 days
  • CT Angiography or MR Angiography (CTA/MRA): For large-vessel GCA. Shows aortic/subclavian/axillary artery wall thickening, stenosis, aneurysm. Useful if cranial symptoms absent but high clinical suspicion
  • PET-CT: Shows FDG uptake in inflamed large vessels (aorta, subclavian). High sensitivity for large-vessel GCA. Not readily available, expensive
  • Ophthalmology Evaluation (URGENT if vision symptoms): Visual acuity, visual fields, fundoscopy (optic disc edema/pallor), RAPD assessment. Repeat exams to monitor for progression
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

IMMEDIATE MANAGEMENT - START STEROIDS WITHOUT DELAY:

  • CRITICAL: Do NOT wait for temporal artery biopsy to start treatment. Permanent blindness can occur within hours to days if untreated. Start prednisone IMMEDIATELY based on clinical suspicion.
  • Temporal artery biopsy remains positive for 2-4 weeks after starting steroids - there is NO urgency to get biopsy before steroids

Glucocorticoid Therapy (Cornerstone of Treatment):

  • WITHOUT Vision Loss (Cranial Symptoms Only):
    • Prednisone 1 mg/kg PO daily (typically 40-60 mg daily). Start immediately
    • Clinical improvement (headache resolves) within 24-48 hours confirms diagnosis
    • Maintain 40-60 mg daily Ã— 4 weeks, then taper SLOWLY by 5-10 mg every 2-4 weeks
    • Total treatment duration: 12-24 months (or longer if relapse occurs)
    • Monitor ESR/CRP to guide taper (keep <20 mm/hr and <1 mg/dL)
  • WITH Vision Loss or Impending Vision Loss (Amaurosis Fugax, Diplopia):
    • High-Dose IV Methylprednisolone ("Pulse Therapy"): 500-1000 mg IV daily Ã— 3 days
    • After 3 days IV, transition to prednisone 1 mg/kg PO daily (60-80 mg)
    • Rationale: Higher tissue steroid levels may prevent progression to complete vision loss or involvement of contralateral eye. Evidence is limited but standard practice
    • Ophthalmology consult URGENT (same day)
  • Steroid Taper (Very Gradual):
    • Month 1-2: 40-60 mg daily
    • Month 2-4: Taper by 5-10 mg every 2 weeks to 20 mg daily
    • Month 4-12: Taper by 2.5 mg every 2-4 weeks to 10 mg daily
    • Month 12-24: Taper by 1 mg every 1-2 months, goal discontinuation at 12-24 months
    • Relapse rate 50% during taper - increase dose if symptoms recur or ESR/CRP rise
  • Steroid-Related Prophylaxis:
    • PPI (pantoprazole 40 mg PO daily) for GI protection
    • Calcium 1200 mg + Vitamin D 800-1000 IU daily for osteoporosis prevention
    • Consider bisphosphonate (alendronate 70 mg PO weekly) if high fracture risk (DEXA T-score <-1.5, age >65, prednisone >7.5 mg/day for >3 months)
    • Pneumocystis prophylaxis (TMP-SMX DS 3Ã—/week) if prednisone >20 mg/day for >1 month
    • Blood glucose monitoring (steroids cause hyperglycemia)

Steroid-Sparing Agents (For Relapsing Disease or Steroid Toxicity):

  • Methotrexate: 10-25 mg PO/SC weekly. Reduces steroid requirement and relapse rate. Start when prednisone <20 mg/day during taper. Give with folic acid 1 mg daily. Monitor CBC, LFTs, creatinine
  • Tocilizumab (Actemra) - FDA Approved for GCA: IL-6 receptor antagonist. 162 mg SC weekly or every other week. GiACTA trial showed 50% steroid-free remission at 1 year vs 10% with prednisone alone. Consider for: refractory GCA, relapsing disease, or high steroid toxicity risk (diabetes, osteoporosis, prior fractures). Very expensive (~$40,000/year)
  • Azathioprine: 1-2 mg/kg/day PO (typically 100-150 mg daily). Alternative steroid-sparing agent if methotrexate contraindicated or ineffective

Aspirin (Antiplatelet Therapy):

  • Aspirin 81-100 mg PO daily. Observational data suggests reduced ischemic complications (vision loss, stroke, MI). No contraindication â†’ start aspirin

Rheumatology Consultation:

  • MANDATORY for all suspected or confirmed GCA
  • Assists with diagnosis, steroid taper, management of relapses, steroid-sparing agents

Ophthalmology Consultation:

  • URGENT (same day) if ANY vision symptoms (vision loss, amaurosis fugax, diplopia)
  • Baseline evaluation if no vision symptoms, repeat if symptoms develop

Temporal Artery Biopsy:

  • Schedule within 1-2 weeks of starting steroids (no urgency, biopsy positive for 2-4 weeks after steroids)
  • Surgical/vascular surgery consultation for biopsy

Monitoring:

  • ESR/CRP at each visit (every 2-4 weeks during taper). Goal: ESR <20 mm/hr, CRP <1 mg/dL
  • Clinical symptoms (headache, jaw claudication, vision changes, PMR symptoms)
  • Monitor for steroid side effects: blood glucose, blood pressure, weight, mood, bone density (DEXA scan baseline and q1-2 years)
  • Vision monitoring: Any new vision symptoms â†’ URGENT ophthalmology evaluation

Disposition:

  • Admission: Vision loss (any degree), impending vision loss (amaurosis fugax, diplopia), inability to take oral medications, need for IV pulse steroids, need for close monitoring
  • Discharge: Stable without vision symptoms, able to take oral prednisone, close rheumatology follow-up arranged (within 1-2 weeks), temporal artery biopsy scheduled
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Giant Cell Arteritis is an Ophthalmologic Emergency - Start Prednisone Immediately: Untreated GCA causes permanent blindness in 50-70% of patients (anterior ischemic optic neuropathy from ophthalmic artery occlusion). Vision loss is IRREVERSIBLE once it occurs. Time to blindness after symptom onset is unpredictable - can be days to weeks. If clinical suspicion is high (age >50, new headache, jaw claudication, elevated ESR >50), START PREDNISONE 1 mg/kg (40-60 mg daily) IMMEDIATELY. Do NOT wait for temporal artery biopsy - biopsy remains positive for 2-4 weeks after starting steroids. Delaying treatment to get biopsy first is malpractice.
  • Jaw Claudication is the Most Specific Symptom for GCA: Jaw/tongue pain or fatigue with chewing that resolves with rest (jaw claudication) is present in 50% of GCA patients and is 90% specific for the diagnosis. Mechanism: ischemia of masseter muscles from facial/maxillary artery involvement. If patient has jaw claudication + elevated ESR, think GCA. Other specific symptoms: scalp tenderness (painful to comb hair, tender temporal artery), tongue claudication, diplopia from ischemic ophthalmoplegia. Headache alone is sensitive but NOT specific.
  • Normal ESR Does NOT Rule Out GCA: Classic teaching: ESR >50 mm/hr (often >100) is required for GCA. However, 10-15% of biopsy-proven GCA have ESR <50 mm/hr. If clinical suspicion is high (age >70, new headache, jaw claudication, vision symptoms), do NOT rely on ESR alone. Check CRP (more sensitive) - CRP >2.45 mg/dL has 97% NPV. If both ESR and CRP are normal, GCA is very unlikely. But if high clinical suspicion persists despite normal labs, still consider treatment and pursue biopsy/imaging.
  • Temporal Artery Biopsy Can Be Done Up to 2-4 Weeks After Starting Steroids: Histologic changes persist for 2-4 weeks after steroid initiation. This allows time to schedule biopsy without urgency. DO NOT delay steroids to rush biopsy - vision loss can occur while waiting. Instead: start prednisone immediately, schedule biopsy for next 1-2 weeks. Biopsy confirms diagnosis, allowing eventual steroid taper with confidence. Negative biopsy does NOT rule out GCA (skip lesions, sampling error) - treat based on clinical picture. Some centers use temporal artery ultrasound (halo sign) instead of biopsy if expertise available.
  • High-Dose IV Methylprednisolone for Vision Loss or Impending Vision Loss: If patient has vision loss (any degree) or transient vision loss (amaurosis fugax) or diplopia, give IV methylprednisolone 500-1000 mg daily Ã— 3 days before transitioning to oral prednisone. Rationale: higher tissue steroid concentration may prevent progression to complete blindness or involvement of second eye (15% develop bilateral blindness if first eye already affected). Evidence is limited but this is standard practice. Urgently consult ophthalmology. Vision loss is often permanent despite steroids, but early treatment may salvage some vision.
  • Steroid Taper in GCA is VERY Slow (12-24 Months Total): GCA requires prolonged steroid therapy. Too-rapid taper causes relapse (50% relapse rate). Typical taper: start 40-60 mg prednisone daily Ã— 4 weeks, taper by 5-10 mg every 2 weeks to 20 mg, then taper by 2.5 mg every 2-4 weeks to 10 mg, then taper by 1 mg every 1-2 months. Total duration 12-24 months. Monitor ESR/CRP at each visit (goal ESR <20, CRP <1). If relapse (symptoms recur, ESR/CRP rise), increase prednisone back to last effective dose, then resume slower taper. Patients need extensive education on long-term steroids and side effects.
  • Tocilizumab (Actemra) is FDA-Approved Steroid-Sparing Agent for GCA: Tocilizumab is an IL-6 receptor antagonist (GCA is IL-6 driven). GiACTA trial showed 162 mg SC weekly or every other week achieved steroid-free remission in 50% at 1 year (vs 10% with prednisone alone) and reduced cumulative steroid dose by 50%. Indications: relapsing GCA (cannot taper steroids without flare), high steroid toxicity risk (diabetes, osteoporosis, prior fractures, steroid psychosis), or inability to tolerate prolonged steroids. Very expensive (~$40,000/year) but can prevent steroid-related complications. Alternative steroid-sparing agents: methotrexate 15-25 mg weekly (less effective than tocilizumab but much cheaper).
  • Polymyalgia Rheumatica and GCA are Related - 50% Overlap: PMR is bilateral shoulder/hip girdle pain and stiffness (worse in morning, difficulty raising arms or getting out of chair) with elevated ESR. 50% of GCA patients have concurrent PMR. 15-20% of PMR patients develop GCA. PMR without GCA is treated with lower-dose prednisone (15-20 mg daily), GCA requires higher dose (40-60 mg). If patient with "PMR" develops headache, jaw claudication, or vision symptoms â†’ think GCA, increase steroids to GCA dose immediately. Always ask PMR patients about cranial symptoms at each visit.
  • Large-Vessel GCA Can Be Occult Without Cranial Symptoms: GCA affects aorta and large vessels (subclavian, axillary, carotid) in 30-40% of cases. Large-vessel GCA can present without temporal headache or jaw claudication. Clues: unexplained fever of unknown origin, elevated ESR/CRP, unexplained anemia, upper extremity claudication (subclavian stenosis), asymmetric blood pressures between arms, aortic aneurysm/dissection. Diagnose with CTA/MRA chest showing arterial wall thickening, stenosis. Treat with prednisone like cranial GCA. Prognosis same if treated, but diagnosis often delayed.
  • Aspirin Reduces Ischemic Complications in GCA: Observational studies show aspirin 75-100 mg daily reduces cranial ischemic events (vision loss, stroke, TIA) by 70-80% in GCA. Mechanism: antiplatelet effect prevents thrombosis in inflamed stenotic vessels. All GCA patients should receive aspirin 81-100 mg daily UNLESS contraindications (active bleeding, severe thrombocytopenia). Combine with steroids from day 1. Low bleeding risk on low-dose aspirin + prednisone. Aspirin is not a substitute for steroids - always give both.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Acute vision loss (any degree) in one or both eyes
  • Amaurosis fugax (transient vision loss) - high risk of permanent blindness
  • Stroke or TIA from GCA-related vasculitis
  • Aortic dissection or rupture (rare complication of aortic GCA)
  • Severe hypertension requiring IV antihypertensives
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Need for frequent neurologic or ophthalmologic monitoring
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • No vision loss or impending vision loss (no amaurosis fugax, no diplopia)
  • Able to take oral prednisone (1 mg/kg/day, typically 40-60 mg daily)
  • Clinical improvement of symptoms (headache improved within 24-48 hours confirms diagnosis and response)
  • Temporal artery biopsy scheduled (within 1-2 weeks of steroid initiation)
  • Close rheumatology follow-up arranged (within 1-2 weeks)
  • Ophthalmology follow-up arranged if any vision concerns
  • Patient educated on warning signs to return: vision changes, severe headache recurrence, jaw claudication recurrence
  • Prescriptions provided: prednisone with clear instructions, PPI, calcium/vitamin D, aspirin
  • Patient understands need for prolonged steroid therapy (12-24 months) with slow taper
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

119. ARDS (ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME)

Berlin Criteria â€¢ P/F Ratio â€¢ Lung-Protective Ventilation â€¢ Prone Positioning
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Acute onset of severe hypoxemic respiratory failure within 1 week of known clinical insult, with bilateral opacities on CXR/CT not fully explained by effusions, lobar collapse, or nodules.

Key Features:

  • Timing: Acute onset within 1 week of known clinical insult or new/worsening respiratory symptoms
  • Hypoxemia: PaO2/FiO2 ratio â‰¤300 mmHg with PEEP â‰¥5 cm H2O
  • Bilateral infiltrates: On CXR or CT, not fully explained by effusions, collapse, or nodules
  • Non-cardiogenic: Respiratory failure not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload (may need echo to rule out)

Common Etiologies:

  • Pulmonary (Direct): Pneumonia (most common), aspiration, pulmonary contusion, inhalation injury, drowning
  • Extrapulmonary (Indirect): Sepsis (most common), pancreatitis, trauma, massive transfusion (TRALI), burns, drug overdose
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Berlin Criteria (2012) - All 4 Required:

  • Timing: Within 1 week of known clinical insult or new/worsening respiratory symptoms
  • Imaging: Bilateral opacities not fully explained by effusions, lobar/lung collapse, or nodules
  • Origin of edema: Not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload
  • Oxygenation (with PEEP â‰¥5): Mild (P/F 200-300), Moderate (P/F 100-200), Severe (P/F <100)

Labs: ABG (P/F ratio calculation), CBC, CMP, lactate, procalcitonin, blood cultures, BNP/NT-proBNP (rule out cardiogenic)

Imaging: CXR (bilateral infiltrates), CT chest if diagnostic uncertainty, Echo (rule out cardiogenic pulmonary edema, assess RV function)

Additional: BAL if pneumonia suspected, respiratory viral panel, consider bronchoscopy

SEVERITY CLASSIFICATION (P/F Ratio with PEEP â‰¥5)
  • Mild ARDS: P/F 201-300 mmHg (mortality ~27%)
  • Moderate ARDS: P/F 101-200 mmHg (mortality ~32%)
  • Severe ARDS: P/F â‰¤100 mmHg (mortality ~45%)

P/F Ratio Calculation: PaO2 (from ABG) Ã· FiO2 (as decimal). Example: PaO2 80 on 60% FiO2 = 80/0.6 = 133 (moderate ARDS)

MANAGEMENT

Lung-Protective Ventilation (ARDSNet Protocol):

  • Low Tidal Volume: 6 mL/kg PREDICTED body weight (PBW), range 4-8 mL/kg
  • PBW Calculation: Male: 50 + 2.3 Ã— (height in inches - 60); Female: 45.5 + 2.3 Ã— (height in inches - 60)
  • Plateau Pressure Goal: â‰¤30 cm H2O (measure with inspiratory hold)
  • PEEP: Use ARDSNet PEEP/FiO2 tables, start moderate PEEP (8-12), titrate up for refractory hypoxemia
  • Driving Pressure: Target <15 cm H2O (Driving Pressure = Plateau Pressure - PEEP)
  • Permissive Hypercapnia: Accept pH >7.20, PaCO2 up to 60-80 if needed to maintain lung protection

Oxygenation Goals:

  • SpO2: 88-95% (avoid hyperoxia)
  • PaO2: 55-80 mmHg

Adjunctive Therapies for Moderate-Severe ARDS:

  • Prone Positioning: For P/F <150, prone for â‰¥16 hours/day. Reduces mortality by ~16% in severe ARDS (PROSEVA trial)
  • Neuromuscular Blockade: Consider cisatracurium for 48 hours in severe ARDS with ventilator dyssynchrony (controversial after ROSE trial)
  • Conservative Fluid Management: Target CVP <4 or PAOP <8 after initial resuscitation (FACTT trial - improved ventilator-free days)
  • Corticosteroids: Consider dexamethasone 20mg IV daily Ã— 5 days, then 10mg Ã— 5 days for moderate-severe ARDS (DEXA-ARDS trial)

Refractory Hypoxemia:

  • Recruitment Maneuvers: Brief sustained inflation (controversial, use with caution)
  • Inhaled Pulmonary Vasodilators: Inhaled nitric oxide or epoprostenol (rescue therapy, no mortality benefit)
  • ECMO: Consider VV-ECMO for refractory hypoxemia despite optimal ventilation (EOLIA trial)
TREAT UNDERLYING CAUSE
  • Sepsis: Early antibiotics, source control
  • Pneumonia: Broad-spectrum antibiotics, consider fungal/viral coverage
  • Aspiration: Antibiotics only if clear infection (not routine for aspiration pneumonitis)
  • Pancreatitis: Supportive care, NPO, IV fluids
  • TRALI: Supportive care, avoid implicated donor
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • PREDICTED Body Weight is Critical: ALWAYS use predicted (ideal) body weight for tidal volume calculation, NOT actual weight. Obese patients don't have bigger lungs. Using actual weight in obesity leads to dangerous over-ventilation and VILI.
  • Driving Pressure May Be the Best Predictor: Driving pressure (Plateau - PEEP) <15 is associated with survival benefit. It reflects lung stress better than tidal volume or plateau pressure alone. If Pplat is 28 and PEEP is 16, driving pressure is only 12 - that's good!
  • Prone Early and Prone Long: Don't wait until patient is moribund to prone. Start when P/F <150 and prone for at least 16 hours/day. The PROSEVA trial showed 16% absolute mortality reduction - one of the largest benefits in critical care.
  • Conservative Fluids AFTER Resuscitation: FACTT trial showed benefit of conservative fluid strategy, but this is AFTER initial sepsis resuscitation. Don't withhold fluids from a hypotensive septic patient to "keep lungs dry."
  • ARDS is a Syndrome, Not a Disease: Always search for and treat the underlying cause. ARDS from pneumonia needs antibiotics; ARDS from pancreatitis needs supportive care. The ventilator strategy is the same, but disease-specific treatment differs.
  • High PEEP vs. Low PEEP: Three major trials (ALVEOLI, LOV, ExPress) showed no mortality difference. Use PEEP/FiO2 tables, individualize based on mechanics, and avoid over-distension (watch plateau pressure).
  • Don't Anchor on the CXR: Bilateral infiltrates can look identical in ARDS vs cardiogenic pulmonary edema. Use BNP, echo, clinical context to differentiate. If uncertain, treat both empirically while sorting it out.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • All ARDS patients require ICU care
  • Need for invasive mechanical ventilation
  • Refractory hypoxemia despite high-flow nasal cannula or NIV
  • P/F ratio <200 (moderate-severe ARDS)
  • Hemodynamic instability requiring vasopressors
  • Need for prone positioning
  • Consideration for ECMO
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Liberated from mechanical ventilation for >48 hours
  • Stable on room air or low-flow O2 (â‰¤4L NC) with SpO2 >92%
  • P/F ratio >300 on room air or minimal supplemental O2
  • Underlying cause treated and resolving
  • No ongoing need for ICU-level monitoring
  • Pulmonary rehab referral if prolonged ventilation
  • Follow-up arranged (pulmonary clinic in 2-4 weeks)
  • Patient educated on gradual recovery timeline (weeks to months)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

120. ACUTE PULMONARY EDEMA / FLASH PULMONARY EDEMA

Cardiogenic vs Non-Cardiogenic â€¢ BiPAP â€¢ Diuresis â€¢ Afterload Reduction
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Acute onset severe dyspnea, orthopnea, pink frothy sputum, diffuse crackles/rales, hypoxemia. Often with hypertension, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and anxiety ("air hunger").

Flash Pulmonary Edema: Rapid onset (minutes to hours), often with severe hypertension, may occur without significant fluid overload. Common in renal artery stenosis, acute MR, acute MI, and hypertensive crisis.

Key Features:

  • Symptoms: Severe dyspnea, orthopnea, PND, cough with pink frothy sputum
  • Signs: Tachypnea, hypoxemia, diffuse crackles, JVD, S3 gallop, lower extremity edema (may be absent in flash)
  • Vital Signs: Hypertension common (may be hypotensive if cardiogenic shock), tachycardia, low SpO2

Differentiate from ARDS:

  • Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema: Elevated BNP (>500), elevated PCWP (>18), rapid response to diuretics/nitrates, cardiac history
  • ARDS/Non-cardiogenic: Normal/low BNP, normal PCWP, clear precipitant (sepsis, pneumonia), no response to diuretics
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Immediate: SpO2, ECG (ischemia, arrhythmia), CXR (cardiomegaly, cephalization, Kerley B lines, effusions, bat-wing infiltrates)

Labs: BNP/NT-proBNP (elevated in cardiogenic), troponin (rule out ACS), BMP (renal function, electrolytes), CBC, ABG if severe

Imaging: CXR portable, bedside echo (LV function, valve pathology, pericardial effusion), lung ultrasound (B-lines)

Consider: CT chest if uncertain etiology, cardiac catheterization if ACS suspected

BNP Interpretation:

  • BNP <100 pg/mL or NT-proBNP <300 pg/mL: Heart failure unlikely
  • BNP >400 pg/mL or NT-proBNP >900 pg/mL (age <50) / >1800 (age >50): Heart failure likely
  • Gray zone values: Use clinical context
MANAGEMENT

Immediate Interventions (First 30 Minutes):

  • Position: Sit patient upright (reduces preload)
  • Oxygen: High-flow O2, target SpO2 >92%
  • BiPAP/CPAP: First-line respiratory support. BiPAP 10/5, titrate to 15/10. Reduces preload, afterload, and work of breathing. Decreases intubation rates by 50%
  • IV Access: Establish immediately for medications

Medical Therapy:

  • Furosemide: 40-80mg IV (or 2.5Ã— home dose if on chronic diuretics). Can repeat in 30-60 min if inadequate response. Target urine output 100-150 mL/hr initially
  • Nitroglycerin: 400mcg SL q5min Ã— 3, then IV infusion 10-20 mcg/min, titrate to 200 mcg/min for BP control. AVOID if SBP <90 or recent PDE5 inhibitor
  • Morphine: 2-4mg IV - controversial, may cause respiratory depression. Consider for severe anxiety/dyspnea only. Generally avoid

Hypertensive Pulmonary Edema (SBP >140):

  • Goal: Reduce SBP by 25% in first hour
  • Preferred agents: IV nitroglycerin (vasodilator), IV nicardipine (if refractory HTN), nitroprusside (if severe, watch for cyanide toxicity)
  • Avoid: Beta-blockers acutely (negative inotropy), excessive diuresis before afterload reduction

Hypotensive Pulmonary Edema (Cardiogenic Shock):

  • Vasopressors: Norepinephrine first-line if SBP <90
  • Inotropes: Dobutamine or milrinone if low output state
  • Mechanical support: IABP, Impella, or ECMO if refractory
  • Avoid: Aggressive diuresis without hemodynamic support

Refractory Cases:

  • Ultrafiltration: Consider if diuretic-resistant
  • Intubation: If failing BiPAP, declining mental status, or severe acidosis
  • Urgent cardiology/cardiac surgery: If acute valvular pathology (acute MR, acute AI)
IDENTIFY AND TREAT PRECIPITANTS
  • ACS: Troponin, ECG â†’ cardiology/cath lab
  • Arrhythmia: Rate control for AF with RVR, cardioversion if unstable
  • Hypertensive crisis: Aggressive BP control
  • Acute valvular disease: Urgent echo, surgical evaluation
  • Medication non-adherence: Restart home medications
  • Dietary indiscretion: Sodium/fluid restriction education
  • Renal artery stenosis: Consider if flash pulmonary edema with minimal fluid overload
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • BiPAP is a Diuretic: Not really, but BiPAP reduces preload (positive intrathoracic pressure decreases venous return) and afterload (reduces LV transmural pressure). Many patients improve dramatically on BiPAP before diuretics even kick in. Don't skip BiPAP!
  • Flash Pulmonary Edema â‰  Fluid Overload: Flash pulmonary edema is often due to acute afterload increase (hypertensive crisis) or acute valvular pathology, NOT total body volume overload. These patients may have normal weight and no peripheral edema. Treat with vasodilators, not just diuretics.
  • Renal Artery Stenosis Pearl: Bilateral RAS is a classic cause of "flash pulmonary edema" - acute, severe pulmonary edema that resolves quickly but recurs. Suspect in patients with resistant hypertension, acute rise in creatinine with ACE-I, or minimal peripheral edema during episodes.
  • Morphine is Falling Out of Favor: Traditional teaching was "LMNOP" (Lasix, Morphine, Nitrates, Oxygen, Position). However, morphine may increase mortality in acute heart failure (observational data). Reserve for severe anxiety/dyspnea only, and use with caution.
  • Wet and Warm vs. Wet and Cold: "Wet and warm" (congested but adequate perfusion) - diurese aggressively. "Wet and cold" (congested AND hypoperfused) - need inotropes/vasopressors before aggressive diuresis or patient will crash.
  • The BNP Gray Zone: BNP 100-400 is the "gray zone." Use clinical context: obese patients have lower BNP, renal failure causes higher BNP, AF causes higher BNP. Trend from baseline is often more useful than absolute value.
  • Don't Forget the Echo: Bedside echo in the ED/ICU can rapidly differentiate cardiogenic (reduced EF, elevated E/e', valve pathology) from non-cardiogenic (normal LV function) pulmonary edema. This guides therapy immediately.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Requiring intubation or failing BiPAP
  • Hypotension (SBP <90) or cardiogenic shock
  • Need for IV vasoactive medications (pressors, inotropes, nitroprusside)
  • Acute coronary syndrome as precipitant
  • New/worsening acute valvular pathology
  • Refractory hypoxemia despite BiPAP
  • Hemodynamic instability or arrhythmias
  • Need for mechanical circulatory support
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Symptoms resolved or returned to baseline
  • Off supplemental O2 or at baseline O2 requirement
  • Stable on oral diuretics with adequate urine output
  • Weight stable or decreasing (not gaining)
  • No IV vasoactive medications for >24 hours
  • Precipitant identified and addressed
  • Transitioned to oral heart failure medications
  • Cardiology follow-up within 7 days
  • Patient educated on daily weights, sodium restriction, medication adherence
  • Clear return precautions given
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

121. VIRAL HEPATITIS (ACUTE)

HAV â€¢ HBV â€¢ HCV â€¢ Acute Liver Failure Risk â€¢ Serologic Diagnosis
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Prodrome of fatigue, malaise, anorexia, nausea, RUQ discomfort, followed by jaundice, dark urine (bilirubinuria), pale stools. May have low-grade fever. Many cases are anicteric (subclinical).

By Virus Type:

  • Hepatitis A (HAV): Fecal-oral transmission, travel to endemic areas, contaminated food/water, MSM, IVDU. Acute onset, self-limited, no chronic state. Peak ALT often >1000
  • Hepatitis B (HBV): Blood/body fluid exposure (sexual, perinatal, needlestick, IVDU). Incubation 6 weeks-6 months. May become chronic (90% if perinatal, 5% if adult-acquired)
  • Hepatitis C (HCV): Blood exposure (IVDU most common, transfusion before 1992, needlestick). Often asymptomatic acutely. 75-85% become chronic
  • Hepatitis D (HDV): Only with HBV co-infection (requires HBsAg). More severe disease
  • Hepatitis E (HEV): Fecal-oral, endemic in developing countries. Self-limited except in pregnancy (high mortality) and immunocompromised (can become chronic)

Severity Spectrum:

  • Mild: Elevated transaminases, no jaundice, preserved synthetic function
  • Moderate: Jaundice, symptoms, but normal INR and mental status
  • Severe/Fulminant: Coagulopathy (INR >1.5), encephalopathy â†’ acute liver failure (ALF)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Initial Labs: AST/ALT (often >10Ã— ULN in acute viral), total/direct bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, GGT, albumin, INR/PT, CBC

Viral Serologies:

  • Hepatitis A: IgM anti-HAV (acute), IgG anti-HAV (past infection/immunity)
  • Hepatitis B: HBsAg, anti-HBs, anti-HBc (IgM for acute, total for any exposure), HBeAg, anti-HBe, HBV DNA
  • Hepatitis C: Anti-HCV (screen), HCV RNA (confirmatory, also for acute infection before antibody develops)
  • Hepatitis D: Anti-HDV (only if HBsAg positive)
  • Hepatitis E: IgM anti-HEV (if travel to endemic area, pregnant, immunocompromised)

HBV Serology Interpretation:

  • Acute HBV: HBsAg+, IgM anti-HBc+, anti-HBs-
  • Chronic HBV: HBsAg+, IgM anti-HBc-, anti-HBs-
  • Resolved HBV: HBsAg-, anti-HBc+, anti-HBs+
  • Vaccinated: HBsAg-, anti-HBc-, anti-HBs+
  • Isolated anti-HBc: Window period, resolved with waned anti-HBs, occult HBV, or false positive

Additional Studies: RUQ ultrasound (rule out biliary obstruction), consider other causes of acute hepatitis (autoimmune hepatitis panel, Wilson's, drug-induced)

MANAGEMENT

General Supportive Care (All Types):

  • Hydration: IV fluids if poor oral intake or vomiting
  • Antiemetics: Ondansetron for nausea
  • Avoid hepatotoxins: No alcohol, minimize acetaminophen, review all medications
  • Avoid sedatives: Risk of encephalopathy if liver function declining
  • Contact precautions: HAV and HEV (fecal-oral)

Hepatitis A:

  • Supportive care only - self-limited
  • Post-exposure prophylaxis for close contacts: HAV vaccine (preferred if age 1-40) or IG (if <1 or >40, immunocompromised)
  • Rarely causes acute liver failure (<1%)

Hepatitis B (Acute):

  • Most adults clear spontaneously (95%) - supportive care
  • Antiviral therapy indicated if: Severe/protracted course, acute liver failure, immunocompromised
  • Preferred antivirals: Tenofovir or entecavir
  • Post-exposure prophylaxis: HBIG + vaccine series if unvaccinated exposure

Hepatitis C (Acute):

  • Spontaneous clearance in 15-25%
  • Consider antiviral therapy (direct-acting antivirals) in acute phase - may prevent chronicity
  • Consult hepatology - timing of treatment debated (some wait 12-16 weeks to see if spontaneous clearance)

Acute Liver Failure Management:

  • Transfer to liver transplant center
  • Monitor for cerebral edema, coagulopathy, hypoglycemia, infection
  • N-acetylcysteine may benefit even in non-acetaminophen ALF (grade I-II encephalopathy)
  • Early transplant evaluation - King's College Criteria for prognosis
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • The "Hepatitis A Doesn't Kill" Myth: While rare (<1%), HAV CAN cause acute liver failure, especially in older adults and those with underlying liver disease. Mortality increases significantly with age. HAV superinfection in chronic HBV or HCV can be devastating - vaccinate these patients!
  • IgM Anti-HBc is the Key to Acute HBV: During the "window period" of acute HBV, HBsAg may be negative (cleared) but anti-HBs hasn't appeared yet. IgM anti-HBc will be positive and is diagnostic. Don't miss acute HBV because you only checked HBsAg.
  • Acute HCV is a Diagnosis of Exclusion... Sort Of: Anti-HCV takes 8-12 weeks to become positive. In acute HCV, you'll have HCV RNA positive with anti-HCV negative or newly positive (document seroconversion). Recent exposure history is key.
  • AST/ALT >10,000 is Usually Ischemic, Not Viral: While viral hepatitis causes very high transaminases, levels >10,000 U/L are more suggestive of ischemic hepatitis (shock liver) or acetaminophen toxicity. Viral hepatitis typically peaks in the 1,000-3,000 range.
  • Always Check INR, Not Just Transaminases: A patient with ALT 50 and INR 3.0 is sicker than a patient with ALT 5000 and INR 1.0. Synthetic function (INR, albumin) reflects true liver function. Transaminases just reflect hepatocyte injury.
  • HBV Reactivation is a Real and Preventable Problem: Always screen for HBsAg and anti-HBc before immunosuppressive therapy (chemo, biologics, high-dose steroids). HBsAg+ or even isolated anti-HBc+ patients need antiviral prophylaxis to prevent potentially fatal reactivation.
  • Hepatitis E in Pregnancy is an Emergency: HEV has 20-25% mortality in pregnant women (especially 3rd trimester). If pregnant patient presents with acute hepatitis and travel to endemic area, test for HEV and consult OB/hepatology immediately.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • INR >1.5 (indicates severe hepatic dysfunction)
  • Any sign of hepatic encephalopathy (confusion, asterixis)
  • Hypoglycemia (liver unable to maintain glucose)
  • Acute kidney injury (hepatorenal physiology)
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Need for frequent monitoring (q1-2h labs)
  • Consideration for liver transplant evaluation
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Tolerating oral intake without significant nausea/vomiting
  • INR â‰¤1.5 and stable or improving
  • Bilirubin stable or downtrending (peak may take 1-2 weeks)
  • No hepatic encephalopathy
  • Transaminases downtrending (don't need to be normal)
  • Hepatology/GI follow-up arranged within 1-2 weeks
  • Patient educated on alcohol avoidance, hepatotoxic medication avoidance
  • Close contacts notified/prophylaxed if HAV or HBV
  • Return precautions: confusion, worsening jaundice, bleeding
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

122. ISCHEMIC HEPATITIS (SHOCK LIVER)

Hypoperfusion Injury â€¢ Massive Transaminase Elevation â€¢ Rapid Resolution
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Dramatic transaminase elevation (often >10,000 U/L) occurring 24-72 hours after an episode of systemic hypoperfusion (cardiogenic shock, septic shock, cardiac arrest, severe hypoxemia). Patient is often critically ill with underlying cause.

The Triad:

  • Underlying condition causing hypoperfusion: Heart failure, shock, cardiac arrest, respiratory failure, severe hypotension
  • Dramatic transaminase elevation: AST/ALT often >20Ã— ULN (frequently >5,000-10,000 U/L)
  • Rapid improvement: Transaminases fall 50% within 24-72 hours once perfusion restored

Common Causes:

  • Cardiac: Acute heart failure, cardiogenic shock, cardiac arrest, acute MI, arrhythmias with hypotension
  • Sepsis: Septic shock with hypotension
  • Respiratory: Severe hypoxemia, pulmonary embolism, respiratory failure
  • Hypovolemic: Hemorrhagic shock, severe dehydration
  • Obstructive: Massive PE, cardiac tamponade

Key Differentiator: Unlike viral hepatitis or drug-induced liver injury, ischemic hepatitis occurs in the setting of clear hemodynamic instability, and transaminases fall rapidly (often 50% decline in 24-48 hours) once perfusion is restored.

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Pattern:

  • AST/ALT: Massively elevated, often >5,000-10,000 U/L (can exceed 20,000)
  • AST > ALT: Typically AST predominates early (zone 3 hepatocyte injury)
  • LDH: Markedly elevated (often >5,000 U/L) - released from ischemic hepatocytes
  • Bilirubin: Mildly elevated initially, may rise as transaminases fall (delayed hepatic processing)
  • INR: May be elevated if severe, but often preserved unless prolonged shock
  • Lactate: Often elevated due to underlying shock

Timeline:

  • Peak transaminases: 24-72 hours after hypotensive event
  • Peak bilirubin: 48-96 hours (lags behind transaminases)
  • Resolution: Transaminases fall 50% within 24-72 hours if perfusion restored

Exclude Other Causes:

  • Acetaminophen toxicity: Check level, history
  • Viral hepatitis: HAV IgM, HBsAg, IgM anti-HBc, HCV RNA
  • Budd-Chiari syndrome: RUQ ultrasound with Doppler (hepatic vein thrombosis)
  • Biliary obstruction: RUQ ultrasound
  • Autoimmune hepatitis: ANA, ASMA, IgG levels (in appropriate clinical context)

Imaging: RUQ ultrasound with Doppler to rule out Budd-Chiari syndrome and biliary obstruction

MANAGEMENT

Primary Goal: Restore Hepatic Perfusion

  • Treat underlying cause: This is the definitive therapy
  • Optimize cardiac output: Treat heart failure, arrhythmias
  • Restore blood pressure: Vasopressors if shock (target MAP >65)
  • Correct hypoxemia: Oxygen, mechanical ventilation if needed
  • Volume resuscitation: If hypovolemic (caution if cardiogenic shock)

Supportive Care:

  • Avoid hepatotoxins: Hold unnecessary medications, avoid acetaminophen
  • Monitor for complications: Hypoglycemia (check glucose q4-6h), coagulopathy (INR), encephalopathy
  • Nutrition: Enteral nutrition when stable, avoid excessive protein restriction unless encephalopathy
  • No specific liver-directed therapy: N-acetylcysteine not proven beneficial (unlike acetaminophen toxicity)

Monitoring:

  • Daily LFTs initially - expect 50% reduction in transaminases within 24-72 hours
  • Monitor INR, glucose, mental status for hepatic dysfunction
  • If transaminases NOT falling as expected, reconsider diagnosis

Prognosis:

  • Mortality primarily determined by underlying condition, not liver injury itself
  • If patient survives underlying illness, liver typically recovers completely
  • Persistent elevation beyond 7-14 days suggests ongoing injury or alternate diagnosis
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • The "Shock Liver" Misnomer: Ischemic hepatitis often occurs WITHOUT overt shock. Passive hepatic congestion (right heart failure) + transient hypotension can cause it. Look for JVD, hepatomegaly, and elevated CVP - even brief hypotension in a congested liver can cause massive injury.
  • LDH is Your Friend: Markedly elevated LDH (often >5,000 U/L) with equally elevated AST/ALT strongly suggests ischemic hepatitis over viral or drug-induced. In viral hepatitis, LDH is only mildly elevated. LDH >AST is classic for ischemic hepatitis.
  • The 50% Rule: If transaminases don't fall by ~50% within 48-72 hours of restoring perfusion, reconsider the diagnosis. Viral hepatitis has a more prolonged course. Ongoing shock/hypoperfusion will prevent improvement.
  • Don't Chase the Transaminases: AST 15,000 sounds terrifying, but the absolute number is less important than the trend and synthetic function. A patient with ALT 15,000 and INR 1.1 who is clinically improving will likely be fine. A patient with ALT 500 and INR 4.0 may need transplant evaluation.
  • Congestive Hepatopathy vs. Ischemic Hepatitis: Chronic right heart failure causes congestive hepatopathy (mild transaminase elevation, elevated bilirubin, elevated INR). Acute-on-chronic decompensation with hypotension can cause superimposed ischemic hepatitis (sudden spike in transaminases).
  • The Bilirubin Lag: Don't be surprised when bilirubin rises as transaminases fall - this is expected. Damaged hepatocytes release transaminases immediately but take time to process bilirubin. Peak bilirubin occurs 48-96 hours after the event.
  • Zone 3 Necrosis: The centrilobular hepatocytes (zone 3, around the central vein) are most susceptible to hypoxia because they receive blood AFTER zones 1 and 2 have extracted oxygen. This explains the pattern of injury in ischemic hepatitis and why AST often exceeds ALT early.
  • Cardiac Arrest Pearl: After cardiac arrest with ROSC, expect transaminases to peak at 24-72 hours. This does NOT necessarily predict poor neurologic outcome. The liver usually recovers if the patient survives.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • All patients with ischemic hepatitis require ICU-level care (underlying shock/instability)
  • Hemodynamic instability requiring vasopressors
  • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
  • INR >2.0 (suggests severe hepatic dysfunction)
  • Hepatic encephalopathy
  • Hypoglycemia requiring dextrose infusion
  • Underlying cardiac arrest or cardiogenic shock
  • Multi-organ failure
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Underlying cause treated and hemodynamically stable
  • Transaminases clearly downtrending (usually >50% from peak)
  • INR normal or stable/improving
  • No hepatic encephalopathy
  • Glucose stable without IV dextrose
  • Off vasopressors and mechanical ventilation
  • Able to tolerate oral medications and nutrition
  • Follow-up arranged (may need cardiology, hepatology depending on underlying cause)
  • Patient and family understand diagnosis and expected recovery
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

123. AORTIC DISSECTION

Stanford Type A â€¢ Type B â€¢ Hypertensive Emergency
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Sudden-onset severe "tearing" or "ripping" chest/back pain, often migratory (follows dissection propagation). Maximum intensity at onset (unlike ACS which crescendos).

Stanford Classification:

  • Type A: Involves ascending aorta (regardless of origin) â€“ SURGICAL EMERGENCY
  • Type B: Descending aorta only (distal to left subclavian) â€“ usually medical management

Associated Findings:

  • Pulse deficits: Unequal BPs between arms (>20 mmHg difference), absent pulses
  • Neurologic: Stroke (carotid involvement), syncope, altered mental status, paraplegia (spinal artery involvement)
  • Cardiac: Aortic regurgitation murmur (diastolic, Type A), tamponade, MI (coronary ostia involvement)
  • Abdominal: Mesenteric ischemia, renal failure

Risk Factors: Hypertension (most common), Marfan syndrome, bicuspid aortic valve, Turner syndrome, pregnancy, cocaine use, recent aortic instrumentation, aortic aneurysm

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Imaging (Confirm Diagnosis):

  • CT Angiography (CTA): Gold standard, sensitivity >95%. Shows intimal flap, true and false lumens, extent of dissection, branch vessel involvement
  • TEE: Excellent for Type A, can be done at bedside in unstable patients
  • CXR: Widened mediastinum (suggestive but not diagnostic); NORMAL in 10-20%

Laboratory:

  • D-dimer: Often elevated (high sensitivity), but non-specific. Useful to rule out in low-risk patients.
  • Troponin: May be elevated if coronary involvement â€“ but elevated troponin does NOT rule out dissection
  • CBC, BMP, coags, type and screen: Baseline for potential surgery

ECG: Often normal or non-specific. May show LVH, ischemic changes if coronary involvement. STEMI + dissection = catastrophic combination.

MANAGEMENT

Immediate Goals (First 20 Minutes):

  • Pain control: IV opioids (morphine 2-4 mg IV or fentanyl 25-50 mcg IV)
  • Target HR <60 bpm: Reduces aortic shear stress (dP/dt)
  • Target SBP 100-120 mmHg: Lowest BP that maintains end-organ perfusion
  • BETA-BLOCKER FIRST: Must reduce HR before vasodilators

Anti-Impulse Therapy (HR Control FIRST):

  • Esmolol: 500 mcg/kg bolus, then 50-200 mcg/kg/min â€“ preferred (short-acting, titratable)
  • Labetalol: 20 mg IV bolus, then 1-2 mg/min infusion
  • If beta-blocker contraindicated: Diltiazem 0.25 mg/kg IV bolus, then 5-15 mg/hr

Blood Pressure Control (After HR Controlled):

  • Nicardipine: 5-15 mg/hr IV (preferred)
  • Nitroprusside: 0.25-10 mcg/kg/min (ONLY after adequate beta blockade)

Type A Dissection â€“ SURGICAL EMERGENCY:

  • IMMEDIATE cardiothoracic surgery consultation
  • Mortality increases 1-2% per hour without surgery

Type B Dissection â€“ Usually Medical Management:

  • Uncomplicated: HR/BP control, ICU monitoring, serial imaging
  • Complicated (requires intervention): Malperfusion, rupture, refractory pain, rapid expansion

AVOID: Anticoagulation, thrombolytics (even if STEMI present â€“ catastrophic if dissection), vasodilators before beta-blockade

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • The STEMI-Dissection Trap: Type A dissection can cause STEMI by occluding coronary ostia. Giving thrombolytics without considering dissection can be fatal. If ANY features suggest dissection, get CTA BEFORE heparin/cath.
  • Beta-Blocker BEFORE Vasodilator: Vasodilators cause reflex tachycardia, which increases aortic shear stress and can propagate dissection. Always achieve HR <60 first.
  • Pain Onset: ACS pain typically crescendos over minutes; dissection is classically maximum intensity at onset.
  • Normal CXR Does NOT Rule Out Dissection: 10-20% of dissections have normal CXR. If clinical suspicion is high, proceed to CTA.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU / OR IF:
  • ALL Type A dissections â€“ immediate surgical consult
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Signs of tamponade or rupture
  • End-organ malperfusion
  • Refractory hypertension or pain
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA (Type B Only)
  • Uncomplicated Type B with stable imaging
  • Pain controlled on oral medications
  • BP at goal on oral regimen (SBP <120)
  • Reliable follow-up with vascular surgery
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

124. CARDIAC TAMPONADE

Beck's Triad â€¢ Pulsus Paradoxus â€¢ Pericardiocentesis
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Beck's Triad (Present in Only ~30%):

  • Hypotension: Due to decreased cardiac output
  • Jugular Venous Distension (JVD): Due to impaired venous return
  • Muffled Heart Sounds: Fluid dampens sound transmission

Pulsus Paradoxus: >10 mmHg drop in systolic BP during inspiration. Most sensitive clinical sign.

Other Signs: Dyspnea, tachypnea, tachycardia, cool extremities, anxiety

Acute vs. Chronic:

  • Acute (trauma, dissection): Small volumes (150-200 mL) can cause tamponade
  • Chronic (malignancy, uremia): May accumulate 1-2L before tamponade

Common Etiologies: Malignancy (lung, breast, lymphoma), uremia, infection (viral, TB), post-cardiac surgery, post-MI, autoimmune, trauma, aortic dissection (Type A), idiopathic

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Echocardiography (Test of Choice):

  • Pericardial effusion: Anechoic space surrounding heart
  • Right atrial collapse: During late diastole â€“ earliest sign
  • Right ventricular diastolic collapse: More specific
  • IVC plethora: Dilated IVC with <50% inspiratory collapse
  • Respiratory variation: >25% mitral inflow variation

ECG: Low voltage, electrical alternans (specific but not sensitive), sinus tachycardia

CXR: "Water bottle" heart â€“ may be normal in acute tamponade

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ BMP Reference

MANAGEMENT

Hemodynamically UNSTABLE:

  • EMERGENT PERICARDIOCENTESIS: Cannot wait
  • Volume resuscitation: IV fluids to maintain preload while preparing for drainage
  • AVOID: Diuretics, vasodilators, positive pressure ventilation (all worsen tamponade)

Pericardiocentesis:

  • Echo guidance: Standard of care
  • Approach: Subxiphoid or apical
  • Leave catheter: For continued drainage in most cases

Specific Etiologies:

  • Malignancy: Pericardial window for recurrent effusions
  • Uremic: Intensify dialysis
  • Aortic dissection (Type A): Do NOT do pericardiocentesis â€“ emergent surgical repair
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Tamponade is CLINICAL, Not Radiographic: Large effusions can be well-tolerated; small acute effusions can kill. Treat the patient, not the echo.
  • Pulsus Paradoxus is KEY: >10 mmHg is abnormal. >20-25 mmHg strongly suggests tamponade.
  • Don't Rely on Beck's Triad: Classic triad is often incomplete. Trust pulsus paradoxus and echo findings.
  • NEVER Pericardiocentesis in Type A Dissection: Can cause exsanguination â€“ requires surgical repair.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU / CATH LAB IF:
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Pulsus paradoxus >15-20 mmHg
  • Echo evidence of chamber collapse
  • Need for emergent pericardiocentesis
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Tamponade drained, no reaccumulation
  • Underlying cause identified and being treated
  • Stable vital signs
  • Follow-up arranged
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

125. LOWER GI BLEED

Diverticular â€¢ Angiodysplasia â€¢ Risk Stratification
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz. Usually presents with hematochezia.

Key Point: ~15% of patients with hematochezia have a brisk UPPER GI source. Always consider UGIB in unstable patients.

Common Etiologies:

  • Diverticulosis (30-40%): Painless, massive bleeding; stops spontaneously in 80%
  • Angiodysplasia (10-15%): Common in elderly, associated with CKD and aortic stenosis (Heyde syndrome)
  • Hemorrhoids (10-15%): Bright red blood on toilet paper/bowl
  • Colitis (10%): IBD, infectious, ischemic â€“ bloody diarrhea with pain
  • Neoplasm (5-10%): Polyps, colorectal cancer
  • Post-polypectomy (5%): 1-2 weeks post-procedure

Distinguishing LGIB from UGIB:

  • BUN/Cr ratio >30: Suggests UGIB
  • Melena: Usually UGIB
  • Hemodynamic instability + hematochezia: Consider brisk UGIB
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory: CBC (trend q6-8h), BMP (BUN/Cr ratio), coags, type and screen/crossmatch, lactate if concern for ischemia

Risk Stratification â€“ Oakland Score: Score â‰¤8 = low risk (may be candidate for outpatient management)

Colonoscopy:

  • Timing: Within 24 hours for most patients
  • Bowel prep: 4-6L polyethylene glycol over 3-4 hours
  • Diagnostic AND therapeutic (clips, cautery, injection)

If Colonoscopy Non-Diagnostic:

  • Upper endoscopy: If UGIB not excluded
  • CT angiography: Detects bleeding >0.3-0.5 mL/min
  • Tagged RBC scan: Detects bleeding >0.1 mL/min (more sensitive, less specific)
  • Angiography: Detects >0.5-1 mL/min, can embolize

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ CBC Reference, ðŸ“š Upper GI Bleed

MANAGEMENT

Initial Resuscitation:

  • IV access: Two large-bore IVs (18G or larger)
  • Crystalloid resuscitation: Target MAP >65
  • Blood transfusion: Target Hgb >7 g/dL (>8-9 if active CAD)
  • Correct coagulopathy: FFP if INR >2.0, platelets if <50k

Endoscopic Therapy: Injection, thermal cautery, hemoclips, band ligation

Interventional Radiology: Angiography with embolization for failed endoscopy or massive bleeding

Surgery: For hemodynamic instability despite resuscitation, failed endoscopic/IR intervention, or >6 units PRBC in 24h

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Hematochezia â‰  LGIB: 15% have brisk UPPER GI bleed. Consider UGIB in unstable patients.
  • Most LGIB Stops Spontaneously: ~80% of diverticular bleeds stop on their own.
  • Hemoglobin Lag: Initial Hgb may be normal â€“ equilibration takes 8-24 hours.
  • Heyde Syndrome: Aortic stenosis + angiodysplasia + acquired vWF deficiency.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Massive transfusion requirement
  • Active ongoing hemorrhage
  • Need for emergent intervention
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Bleeding stopped, stable hemoglobin
  • Colonoscopy completed or follow-up arranged
  • Tolerating oral intake
  • GI follow-up arranged
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

126. TTP/HUS (THROMBOTIC MICROANGIOPATHY)

PLASMIC Score â€¢ Plasmapheresis â€¢ DO NOT Transfuse Platelets
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic "Pentad" (Full Pentad in <10%):

  • Microangiopathic Hemolytic Anemia (MAHA): Schistocytes, elevated LDH, low haptoglobin
  • Thrombocytopenia: Usually severe (median ~15,000)
  • Neurologic symptoms: Headache, confusion, seizures, focal deficits
  • Renal dysfunction: Mild in TTP, severe in HUS
  • Fever: Non-specific

TTP vs. HUS:

  • TTP: ADAMTS13 activity <10%. More neurologic, milder renal
  • STEC-HUS: Shiga toxin E. coli (O157:H7). Bloody diarrhea prodrome, severe renal
  • Atypical HUS: Complement dysregulation. Severe renal, no diarrhea
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Essential Labs:

  • CBC with smear: Thrombocytopenia + schistocytes (>1%)
  • Hemolysis labs: LDH (markedly elevated), haptoglobin (undetectable), indirect bilirubin, reticulocytes
  • Direct Coombs: NEGATIVE (rules out AIHA)
  • Coags: PT, PTT, fibrinogen â€“ typically NORMAL (vs. DIC)

ADAMTS13 Activity: SEND BEFORE PLASMA. Activity <10% confirms TTP. Don't wait for results to treat.

PLASMIC Score (Predicts ADAMTS13 <10%):

  • Platelet <30k (+1)
  • Lysis (hemolysis markers) (+1)
  • Active cancer absent (+1)
  • Stem cell/organ transplant absent (+1)
  • MCV <90 (+1)
  • INR <1.5 (+1)
  • Creatinine <2.0 (+1)
  • Score â‰¥6 = High risk (~72% ADAMTS13 <10%)

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ CBC Reference, ðŸ”¬ LDH Reference

MANAGEMENT
âš ï¸ CRITICAL: DO NOT TRANSFUSE PLATELETS

Platelet transfusion can precipitate thrombosis and worsen disease. Only if life-threatening bleeding.

Therapeutic Plasma Exchange (TPE):

  • START IMMEDIATELY: Don't wait for ADAMTS13. Mortality >90% untreated vs. <20% with TPE.
  • Regimen: Daily 1-1.5 plasma volumes until platelets >150k Ã— 2 days
  • If TPE not available: Give FFP 30 mL/kg as bridge

Corticosteroids: Prednisone 1 mg/kg/day OR methylprednisolone 1g IV daily Ã— 3 days

Rituximab: For refractory/relapsed TTP. 375 mg/mÂ² weekly Ã— 4 weeks

Caplacizumab: Anti-vWF nanobody. 11 mg IV before first TPE, then 11 mg SQ daily

STEC-HUS: Supportive care only. AVOID antibiotics (may worsen). NO TPE.

Atypical HUS: Eculizumab (C5 inhibitor) â€“ treatment of choice. Vaccinate for meningococcus.

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Don't Wait for Pentad: MAHA + thrombocytopenia alone is enough to suspect TTP and start treatment.
  • Coags are NORMAL: Unlike DIC, PT/PTT/fibrinogen are normal in TTP.
  • Send ADAMTS13 BEFORE Plasma: Plasma contains ADAMTS13 and falsely elevates levels.
  • NO PLATELETS: Can trigger catastrophic thrombosis. Exception: life-threatening bleeding.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • All suspected TTP â€“ hematologic emergency
  • Severe neurologic manifestations
  • Severe thrombocytopenia (<10k)
  • Need for emergent TPE
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Platelets >150k Ã— 2 consecutive days
  • LDH normalizing
  • No neurologic symptoms
  • TPE course completed
  • Hematology follow-up arranged
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

127. HEPARIN-INDUCED THROMBOCYTOPENIA (HIT)

4T Score â€¢ Argatroban/Bivalirudin â€¢ Warfarin Bridging
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Immune-mediated thrombocytopenia from antibodies against PF4-heparin complexes. Causes THROMBOSIS, not bleeding.

Timing:

  • Typical HIT: Platelet drop 5-10 days after heparin exposure
  • Rapid-onset HIT: Within 24 hours if heparin in past 100 days

Key Features:

  • Thrombocytopenia: ~50% drop from baseline (nadir usually 20,000-150,000)
  • Thrombosis: 50% of untreated HIT develop thrombosis (DVT, PE, limb ischemia, stroke)
  • Skin necrosis: At injection sites

Risk Factors: UFH > LMWH (10Ã— higher risk), surgical > medical patients, duration >4 days

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

4T Score:

Feature 2 Points 1 Point 0 Points
Thrombocytopenia>50% fall or nadir 20-100k30-50% fall or nadir 10-19k<30% fall or nadir <10k
TimingDays 5-10 or â‰¤1 day if recent heparinDays 5-10 unclearâ‰¤4 days without recent heparin
ThrombosisNew thrombosis or skin necrosisProgressive/suspected thrombosisNone
Other causesNone evidentPossible other causeDefinite other cause

Score: 0-3 = Low (<5%); 4-5 = Intermediate (10-30%); 6-8 = High (40-80%)

Laboratory:

  • Anti-PF4/heparin ELISA: High sensitivity (~99%), lower specificity
  • Serotonin release assay (SRA): Gold standard, high specificity (~99%)
MANAGEMENT

Immediate Actions:

  • STOP ALL HEPARIN: UFH, LMWH, heparin flushes, heparin-coated catheters
  • Start alternative anticoagulation: Even without thrombosis
  • Duplex legs: Screen for occult DVT

Alternative Anticoagulation:

  • Argatroban: 2 mcg/kg/min IV (no bolus), adjust to aPTT 1.5-3Ã— baseline. Hepatically cleared.
  • Bivalirudin: 0.15-0.2 mg/kg/hr IV. Renally cleared.
  • Fondaparinux: 7.5 mg SQ daily. No cross-reactivity with HIT antibodies.
  • DOACs: Can use in stable patients.

Warfarin Bridging (CRITICAL):

  • DO NOT start warfarin until platelets >150,000: Can cause venous limb gangrene
  • Start low dose (5 mg daily) when platelets recovered
  • Overlap â‰¥5 days with alternative anticoagulant until INR therapeutic Ã— 2 days
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • HIT Causes Thrombosis: Despite low platelets, HIT is hypercoagulable. Treat with anticoagulation.
  • 4T Score is Essential: Low score (<4) essentially rules out HIT.
  • Timing is Everything: Classic HIT = days 5-10. Day 2 drop without recent heparin is NOT HIT.
  • Warfarin Danger: Never start warfarin while platelets are low â€“ causes limb gangrene.
  • Argatroban Elevates INR: Target INR >4 before stopping argatroban when bridging.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Acute arterial thrombosis
  • Massive PE
  • Venous limb gangrene
  • Need for emergent surgery
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Platelets >150,000 and stable
  • On oral anticoagulation
  • No new thrombosis
  • Patient educated to avoid heparin
ðŸ“– Drug Reference: ðŸ’Š Argatroban, ðŸ’Š Fondaparinux
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

128. WERNICKE ENCEPHALOPATHY

Thiamine Deficiency â€¢ Give Thiamine BEFORE Glucose â€¢ Korsakoff Syndrome
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Triad (Present in Only ~30%):

  • Encephalopathy: Confusion, disorientation, apathy (most common, >80%)
  • Oculomotor dysfunction: Nystagmus, lateral rectus palsy, ophthalmoplegia
  • Gait ataxia: Wide-based, unsteady; may be unable to walk

High-Risk Populations:

  • Alcohol use disorder: Most common
  • Malnutrition: Anorexia, starvation, refeeding syndrome
  • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Bariatric surgery
  • Prolonged TPN without thiamine
  • Dialysis

Korsakoff Syndrome: Untreated Wernicke â†’ irreversible anterograde amnesia, confabulation. ~80% of untreated cases progress.

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

WERNICKE IS A CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS: Do NOT wait for labs or imaging to treat.

Laboratory (Supportive):

  • Thiamine level: Can confirm deficiency but takes days
  • Magnesium: Often low; required for thiamine utilization

MRI Brain: T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in medial thalami, mammillary bodies, periaqueductal gray. Sensitivity ~50% â€“ normal MRI does NOT rule out.

MANAGEMENT
âš ï¸ CRITICAL: THIAMINE BEFORE GLUCOSE

Glucose consumes thiamine in glycolysis. Giving glucose without thiamine can precipitate or worsen Wernicke. ALWAYS give thiamine before or with glucose.

Thiamine Dosing (TREATMENT):

  • High-dose IV: 500 mg IV TID Ã— 2-3 days
  • Then: 250 mg IV daily Ã— 3-5 days
  • Then: 100 mg PO TID until no longer at risk

Why IV and High-Dose? Oral absorption limited (~5 mg/day max). Brain stores depleted â€“ need aggressive repletion.

Prophylaxis (At-Risk Without Symptoms): 100-200 mg IV daily while NPO

Magnesium Repletion: Cofactor for thiamine-dependent enzymes. Target Mg >2.0 mg/dL.

Expected Response:

  • Oculomotor findings: Hours to days
  • Ataxia: Days to weeks; may not fully resolve
  • Encephalopathy: Days to weeks; may not fully resolve
  • Korsakoff amnesia: Usually irreversible

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ Magnesium Reference, ðŸ“š Alcohol Withdrawal

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Clinical Diagnosis: Don't wait for labs. If you suspect it, treat it.
  • Triad is a Myth: Only ~30% present with classic triad. Suspect in ANY confused patient with risk factors.
  • THIAMINE BEFORE GLUCOSE: Boards-relevant and clinically critical.
  • Low-Dose is Inadequate: "Banana bag" (100 mg) insufficient for established Wernicke. Use 500 mg IV TID.
  • Korsakoff is Irreversible: Early aggressive treatment prevents progression.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Severe encephalopathy (coma)
  • Concurrent severe alcohol withdrawal
  • Respiratory compromise
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Mental status improved
  • Gait stable
  • Tolerating oral thiamine
  • Magnesium repleted
  • Alcohol cessation resources provided
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

129. NEPHROTIC SYNDROME

>3.5g Proteinuria â€¢ Thrombosis Risk â€¢ Infection Risk
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Diagnostic Criteria:

  • Proteinuria >3.5 g/day (or UPCR >3.5)
  • Hypoalbuminemia (<3.0 g/dL)
  • Peripheral edema
  • Hyperlipidemia

Primary Causes:

  • Minimal Change: Most common in children; responds to steroids
  • FSGS: Most common primary cause in adults; often steroid-resistant
  • Membranous Nephropathy: Most common in older adults; high thrombosis risk; associated with malignancy

Secondary Causes: Diabetes (most common overall), SLE, amyloidosis, hepatitis B/C, HIV, malignancy, drugs (NSAIDs)

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Confirm Diagnosis: 24-hour urine protein or spot UPCR, serum albumin, lipid panel

Workup for Etiology:

  • HbA1c, fundoscopic exam (diabetes)
  • ANA, anti-dsDNA, C3/C4 (SLE)
  • Hepatitis B/C, HIV serologies
  • Anti-PLA2R antibody (primary membranous)
  • SPEP/UPEP, free light chains (amyloidosis)
  • Age-appropriate cancer screening

Renal Biopsy: Definitive diagnosis in most cases; not required if clear diabetic nephropathy

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ Albumin Reference

MANAGEMENT

Supportive Care (All Patients):

  • Sodium restriction: <2 g/day
  • Loop diuretics: Furosemide 40-80 mg daily; may need high doses
  • ACE-I or ARB: Reduces proteinuria; use even if BP normal
  • Statin: For hyperlipidemia

Thrombosis Prevention:

  • High risk â€“ loss of antithrombin III, protein S
  • VTE risk highest with membranous and albumin <2.5
  • Consider prophylactic anticoagulation in high-risk patients
  • Renal vein thrombosis: Classic complication â€“ flank pain, hematuria

Infection Risk: Loss of immunoglobulins â†’ increased infection risk. Ensure pneumococcal vaccination.

Disease-Specific:

  • Minimal change: High-dose prednisone
  • FSGS: Steroids; if resistant, calcineurin inhibitors or rituximab
  • Membranous: Rituximab or cyclophosphamide + steroids if high-risk
  • Diabetic: Glycemic control, ACE-I/ARB, SGLT2 inhibitors
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Nephrotic vs. Nephritic: Nephrotic = heavy proteinuria, low albumin, edema. Nephritic = hematuria, RBC casts, HTN.
  • Thrombosis is a Big Deal: VTE risk 10-40% in membranous. Consider DVT/PE in symptomatic patients.
  • Membranous + Cancer: In adults >50, consider occult malignancy workup.
  • SGLT2 Inhibitors: Standard of care for proteinuric CKD regardless of diabetes (DAPA-CKD, EMPA-KIDNEY).
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Massive PE
  • Severe AKI requiring dialysis
  • Severe pulmonary edema
  • Sepsis
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Edema controlled with oral diuretics
  • Renal function stable
  • On ACE-I/ARB
  • Nephrology follow-up arranged
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

130. ASPIRATION PNEUMONIA / PNEUMONITIS

Chemical Pneumonitis vs. Infection â€¢ Anaerobic Coverage Debate
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Pneumonitis vs. Pneumonia:

FeatureAspiration PneumonitisAspiration Pneumonia
PathophysiologyChemical inflammation from gastric acidBacterial infection
OnsetHours after witnessed aspirationDays (often no witnessed event)
CourseImproves 24-48 hrsProgressive without antibiotics
AntibioticsUsually NOT indicatedYes

Risk Factors: Decreased consciousness, dysphagia, impaired gag reflex, NG tube, GERD, poor dentition

Location: Right lower lobe (supine); dependent lung segments

MANAGEMENT

Aspiration Pneumonitis:

  • Supportive care, observation
  • Most resolve 24-48 hours
  • Antibiotics only if: no improvement after 48h, worsening, grossly contaminated material

Aspiration Pneumonia:

  • Community-Acquired: Ceftriaxone + Azithro OR levofloxacin (standard CAP coverage)
  • Anaerobic Coverage Debate: Recent evidence suggests NOT routinely necessary
  • Add anaerobic coverage if: Lung abscess, empyema, foul sputum, severe periodontal disease
  • Anaerobic options: Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h, Pip-tazo, Meropenem, or add Metronidazole

Prevention: HOB elevation 30-45Â°, oral hygiene, swallowing evaluation, thickened liquids if dysphagia

Cross-link: ðŸ¦  ID Guide: Respiratory Infections

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Pneumonitis â‰  Pneumonia: Pneumonitis is chemical, not infection. Usually resolves 24-48h without antibiotics.
  • 48-Hour Rule: After witnessed aspiration, observe 48h. If worsening â†’ start antibiotics.
  • Anaerobic Coverage Overprescribed: Reserve for abscess, empyema, foul sputum, poor dentition.
  • Procalcitonin Can Help: Low procalcitonin argues against bacterial infection.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Severe hypoxemia
  • Respiratory failure
  • Septic shock
  • ARDS
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Oxygenation adequate
  • Afebrile
  • Tolerating oral intake safely
  • Aspiration precautions in place
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

131. HOSPITAL-ACQUIRED / VENTILATOR-ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA (HAP/VAP)

MDR Risk Factors â€¢ Empiric Coverage â€¢ De-escalation
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definitions:

  • HAP: Pneumonia â‰¥48 hours after admission
  • VAP: Pneumonia >48 hours after intubation

Common Pathogens: Pseudomonas, Klebsiella, E. coli, Acinetobacter, MRSA, S. pneumoniae

MDR Risk Factors:

  • IV antibiotics in prior 90 days
  • Hospitalization â‰¥5 days
  • Septic shock at time of VAP
  • ARDS before VAP
  • Renal replacement therapy
  • Prior MRSA/Pseudomonas infection
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical: New infiltrate + â‰¥2 of: fever, leukocytosis/leukopenia, purulent secretions, declining oxygenation

Cultures: Sputum/ETA, blood cultures, consider BAL if not responding

MRSA Nasal PCR: High NPV (~95%). If negative, can discontinue MRSA coverage.

Cross-link: ðŸ¦  ID Guide: Respiratory Infections

MANAGEMENT

NO MDR Risk Factors:

  • Single anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam: Pip-tazo 4.5g q6h, Cefepime 2g q8h, OR Meropenem 1g q8h

WITH MDR Risk Factors:

  • Two anti-pseudomonal agents: Beta-lactam + fluoroquinolone or aminoglycoside
  • PLUS MRSA coverage if risk factors: Vancomycin 15-20 mg/kg q8-12h OR Linezolid 600mg q12h

De-escalation (at 48-72h):

  • Review cultures and narrow coverage
  • If MRSA nasal PCR negative â†’ stop vancomycin
  • If Pseudomonas not isolated â†’ narrow to single agent

Duration: 7 days for most HAP/VAP. Longer for Pseudomonas, MRSA bacteremia, abscess, empyema.

VAP Prevention Bundle: HOB elevation, daily sedation vacation, DVT/PUD prophylaxis, oral care with chlorhexidine

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • MDR Risk Assessment is Key: Not everyone needs double Pseudomonas coverage + vancomycin.
  • De-escalate Early: 48-72h culture review is critical. Narrow when possible.
  • MRSA Nasal PCR: Use it to stop unnecessary vancomycin.
  • 7 Days is Usually Enough: Longer courses = more resistance, more C. diff.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Most HAP/VAP patients already in ICU
  • Septic shock
  • Severe hypoxemia
  • Need for mechanical ventilation
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Afebrile >48 hours
  • Stable oxygenation
  • WBC normalizing
  • Able to take oral medications
  • Plan to complete antibiotic course
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

132. CRITICAL AORTIC STENOSIS

Valve Area <1.0 cmÂ² â€¢ Syncope/Angina/CHF â€¢ AVR Indications
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Symptom Triad:

  • Angina: Due to increased myocardial O2 demand + reduced coronary perfusion pressure. ~5 year survival once present.
  • Syncope: Exertional â€“ fixed cardiac output cannot meet demand. ~3 year survival.
  • Heart Failure: LV decompensation. ~2 year survival once symptomatic.

Physical Exam:

  • Murmur: Harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur at RUSB, radiates to carotids
  • Parvus et tardus: Weak and delayed carotid upstroke (classic but insensitive)
  • Paradoxical S2 split: Prolonged LV ejection delays A2
  • S4 gallop: Stiff, hypertrophied LV
  • Narrow pulse pressure: Reduced stroke volume

Severity Classification:

  • Severe AS: Valve area <1.0 cmÂ², mean gradient >40 mmHg, peak velocity >4 m/s
  • Critical AS: Valve area <0.6 cmÂ² (or indexed AVA <0.6 cmÂ²/mÂ²)

Etiologies: Calcific/degenerative (most common in elderly), bicuspid aortic valve (younger patients), rheumatic (rare in developed countries)

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Echocardiography (Diagnostic Standard):

  • Valve area by continuity equation
  • Mean and peak gradients
  • Peak aortic jet velocity
  • LV function (EF)
  • LV wall thickness (concentric hypertrophy typical)

Low-Flow, Low-Gradient AS:

  • Reduced EF with low gradient (<40 mmHg) but small valve area â€“ may be true severe AS or pseudo-severe AS
  • Dobutamine stress echo: Differentiates true severe from pseudo-severe

Other Studies:

  • ECG: LVH with strain pattern, LAE, conduction abnormalities
  • CXR: Cardiomegaly, calcified aortic valve, pulmonary congestion if decompensated
  • Cardiac cath: Pre-operative coronary assessment; direct gradient measurement if echo inconclusive
  • CT calcium scoring: Can help confirm severe AS in borderline cases

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ BNP Reference

MANAGEMENT

Medical Management (Temporizing Only):

  • No medical therapy prevents progression â€“ definitive treatment is valve replacement
  • Diuretics: Cautious use for pulmonary congestion. Avoid over-diuresis (preload dependent).
  • Avoid vasodilators: Can cause severe hypotension (fixed obstruction cannot increase CO)
  • Avoid negative inotropes: Beta-blockers should be used cautiously; avoid in decompensated state
  • Maintain sinus rhythm: Atrial kick contributes ~25% of LV filling in stiff ventricle

Indications for Intervention (2020 ACC/AHA Guidelines):

  • Class I: Symptomatic severe AS (angina, syncope, HF)
  • Class I: Asymptomatic severe AS with LVEF <50%
  • Class I: Severe AS undergoing other cardiac surgery
  • Class IIa: Asymptomatic very severe AS (Vmax â‰¥5 m/s)
  • Class IIa: Asymptomatic severe AS with exercise intolerance or BP drop on exercise testing

Intervention Options:

  • SAVR (Surgical AVR): Gold standard for low/intermediate surgical risk
  • TAVR (Transcatheter AVR): Preferred for high/prohibitive surgical risk; increasingly used in intermediate risk. Now approved for low-risk patients.
  • Balloon valvuloplasty: Bridge to definitive therapy in hemodynamically unstable patients. NOT definitive â€“ high restenosis rate.

Acute Decompensation Management:

  • ICU admission
  • Gentle diuresis (avoid hypotension)
  • Inotropes if needed (dobutamine preferred)
  • Avoid vasodilators
  • Urgent cardiology/cardiac surgery consultation
  • Consider emergent TAVR or balloon valvuloplasty as bridge
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Symptoms = Intervention: Once symptomatic, prognosis is poor without AVR. Median survival: angina 5yr, syncope 3yr, CHF 2yr.
  • Avoid Vasodilators: Nitrates, ACE-I, and other vasodilators can cause severe hypotension. The stenotic valve creates fixed obstruction â€“ CO cannot increase to compensate for decreased SVR.
  • The Murmur May Soften: As AS progresses and LV fails, the murmur may become softer (less flow across valve). Don't be fooled â€“ soft murmur â‰  mild AS in a failing ventricle.
  • Heyde Syndrome: AS + GI bleeding from angiodysplasia + acquired von Willebrand syndrome. Shear stress degrades vWF multimers. May resolve after AVR.
  • TAVR Revolution: TAVR now approved for all surgical risk categories. Discuss with heart team for optimal approach.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Acute pulmonary edema
  • Syncope with hemodynamic instability
  • New arrhythmias (especially AF with RVR)
  • Need for inotropic support
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Hemodynamically stable
  • Euvolemic on oral diuretics
  • Intervention plan established (SAVR/TAVR scheduled)
  • Cardiology follow-up arranged
  • Patient educated on activity restrictions and symptoms
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

133. ACUTE MITRAL REGURGITATION

Papillary Muscle Rupture â€¢ Chordae Tendineae â€¢ Surgical Emergency
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Key Distinction from Chronic MR: In acute MR, the LA is non-compliant (no time to dilate) â†’ acute elevation of LA pressure â†’ flash pulmonary edema. Chronic MR allows LA dilation, delaying symptoms.

Symptoms:

  • Acute, severe dyspnea
  • Flash pulmonary edema
  • Hypotension, cardiogenic shock
  • May have chest pain if ischemic etiology

Physical Exam:

  • Murmur may be SOFT or ABSENT: Rapid equilibration of LV and LA pressures limits murmur duration/intensity
  • S3 gallop: Volume overload
  • Rales: Pulmonary edema
  • Hypotension: Reduced forward cardiac output

Etiologies:

  • Papillary muscle rupture: Post-MI (usually 2-7 days after inferior MI, posteromedial papillary muscle most common)
  • Chordae tendineae rupture: Myxomatous degeneration (MVP), endocarditis, trauma
  • Infective endocarditis: Valve perforation, vegetation interference
  • Prosthetic valve dysfunction: Dehiscence, stuck leaflet
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Echocardiography (Urgent):

  • TTE: Initial study â€“ shows flail leaflet, ruptured chordae/papillary muscle, severe MR jet
  • TEE: Better visualization of mitral apparatus, essential for surgical planning
  • Findings: Hyperdynamic LV (volume overload), dilated LA (if any chronicity), pulmonary hypertension, flail leaflet

Other Studies:

  • CXR: Pulmonary edema, often asymmetric (MR jet directed posteriorly â†’ right-sided edema)
  • ECG: May show ischemia if post-MI; AF common
  • BNP: Markedly elevated
  • Coronary angiography: If ischemic etiology suspected and patient stable enough

Cross-link: ðŸ“š Acute Coronary Syndrome, ðŸ“š Infective Endocarditis

MANAGEMENT

Medical Stabilization (Bridge to Surgery):

  • Afterload reduction: Nitroprusside (if BP tolerates) â€“ reduces regurgitant fraction by promoting forward flow
  • Inotropes: Dobutamine if hypotensive
  • Diuretics: For pulmonary edema
  • IABP: Reduces afterload, augments diastolic coronary perfusion, stabilizes hemodynamics
  • Avoid: Pure vasoconstrictors (increase afterload, worsen MR)

Definitive Treatment = SURGERY:

  • Urgent/emergent mitral valve surgery â€“ repair preferred if feasible, replacement if not
  • Timing: As soon as possible once diagnosis confirmed. Delay increases mortality.
  • Post-MI papillary rupture: Extremely high mortality without surgery (~75% in 24h). Emergent OR.

Specific Etiologies:

  • Post-MI: Emergent surgery Â± CABG
  • Endocarditis: Surgery for hemodynamic instability, plus antibiotics
  • Prosthetic valve: Re-operation or transcatheter intervention depending on mechanism
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Murmur May Be Soft: Unlike chronic MR, acute severe MR may have a soft or short murmur due to rapid pressure equilibration. Don't rely on murmur intensity to assess severity.
  • Post-MI Timing: Papillary muscle rupture typically occurs 2-7 days post-MI. Patient may have been improving, then sudden deterioration.
  • Posteromedial > Anterolateral: Posteromedial papillary muscle (single blood supply from PDA) ruptures more often than anterolateral (dual supply).
  • IABP is Your Friend: In acute MR, IABP reduces afterload (decreases regurgitant fraction) and augments coronary perfusion. Use as bridge to OR.
  • Surgery is the Treatment: Medical therapy is temporizing only. Mortality without surgery is extremely high.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU/OR IF:
  • All acute severe MR â€“ surgical emergency
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Flash pulmonary edema
  • Need for IABP or mechanical support
âœ“ POST-OP CONSIDERATIONS
  • ICU monitoring post-operatively
  • Anticoagulation if mechanical valve
  • Endocarditis prophylaxis education
  • Cardiac rehab referral
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

134. SUPRAVENTRICULAR TACHYCARDIA (SVT)

AVNRT â€¢ AVRT â€¢ Adenosine â€¢ Cardioversion
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Narrow-complex tachycardia (QRS <120ms) originating above the ventricles, typically 150-250 bpm, regular rhythm.

Types of SVT:

  • AVNRT (60%): Re-entry circuit within AV node. Most common. P waves buried in QRS or pseudo-R' in V1.
  • AVRT (30%): Accessory pathway (e.g., WPW). Orthodromic (antegrade via AV node) = narrow complex. P waves after QRS.
  • Atrial tachycardia (10%): Focal or re-entrant atrial source. P wave morphology differs from sinus.

Symptoms:

  • Palpitations (sudden onset, sudden offset)
  • Lightheadedness, presyncope
  • Chest discomfort, dyspnea
  • Polyuria post-episode (ANP release from atrial stretch)
  • Rarely syncope or hemodynamic collapse

Triggers: Caffeine, alcohol, stress, decongestants, hyperthyroidism, electrolyte abnormalities

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

ECG During Tachycardia:

  • Narrow QRS (<120ms) â€“ if wide, consider aberrancy or VT
  • Regular R-R intervals
  • Rate typically 150-250 bpm
  • P wave location helps identify mechanism

Baseline ECG (After Conversion):

  • Look for delta wave (WPW) â€“ short PR, slurred QRS upstroke
  • Pre-excitation syndromes have risk of rapid AF with accessory pathway conduction

Labs:

  • Electrolytes (K, Mg)
  • TSH
  • Troponin if chest pain or hemodynamic compromise

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ Electrolytes Reference, ðŸ©º Palpitations Framework

MANAGEMENT

Hemodynamically UNSTABLE:

  • Synchronized cardioversion: 50-100J biphasic, escalate as needed
  • Don't delay for vagal maneuvers or adenosine if truly unstable

Hemodynamically STABLE â€“ Step-wise Approach:

Step 1: Vagal Maneuvers

  • Valsalva (modified): Blow into 10mL syringe for 15 sec, then immediately lie supine with legs elevated 45Â° for 15 sec. Success rate ~40-50% with modified technique.
