  • Carotid sinus massage: 5-10 sec unilateral pressure. Contraindicated if carotid bruit, recent stroke, known carotid disease.
  • Ice water to face: Dive reflex â€“ cold water or ice bag to face for 15-30 sec.

Step 2: Adenosine

  • First dose: 6 mg rapid IV push through large proximal IV, followed immediately by 20 mL NS flush and arm elevation
  • Second dose: 12 mg if no response in 1-2 minutes
  • Third dose: 12 mg if needed
  • Warn patient: Transient chest discomfort, flushing, sense of "impending doom" â€“ resolves in seconds
  • Contraindications: Known WPW with pre-excited AF (can accelerate ventricular rate), severe asthma (relative)

Step 3: If Adenosine Fails

  • Diltiazem: 0.25 mg/kg IV over 2 min (typically 15-20 mg), may repeat 0.35 mg/kg in 15 min. Then infusion 5-15 mg/hr.
  • Verapamil: 5-10 mg IV over 2 min
  • Beta-blockers: Metoprolol 5 mg IV q5min Ã— 3, or esmolol infusion
  • Avoid in WPW with pre-excitation: AV nodal blockers can accelerate accessory pathway conduction

Step 4: Cardioversion

  • If refractory to medications or patient decompensates
  • Synchronized cardioversion 50-100J

Long-Term Management:

  • EP study and ablation: Curative for AVNRT and AVRT (~95% success)
  • Medical therapy: AV nodal blockers (beta-blocker, diltiazem) for rate control if ablation not desired
  • Pill-in-pocket: Diltiazem or propafenone for infrequent episodes
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Modified Valsalva Works Better: The modified Valsalva (strain then supine with leg elevation) has ~40% success vs. ~20% for standard Valsalva.
  • Adenosine Technique Matters: Must be rapid push through large, proximal IV with immediate flush. Slow administration = degradation before reaching heart.
  • WPW Danger: If pre-excited AF (irregular, wide-complex with varying morphology), AV nodal blockers (adenosine, diltiazem, digoxin) are CONTRAINDICATED â€“ can cause VF. Use procainamide or cardioversion.
  • Record the Strip: Always record continuous ECG during adenosine â€“ even if it doesn't terminate SVT, it may reveal underlying rhythm (flutter waves, P waves) during AV block.
  • Ablation is Curative: For recurrent SVT, refer to EP. Ablation success rate >95% for AVNRT/AVRT with low complication rate.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE IF:
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Refractory to adenosine and rate control
  • Wide-complex tachycardia (may be VT)
  • Pre-excited AF (WPW with AF)
  • Associated ischemia or heart failure
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Converted to sinus rhythm
  • Hemodynamically stable
  • No ongoing symptoms
  • Rate control medication if recurrent
  • EP/Cardiology follow-up for ablation discussion
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

135. MASSIVE HEMOPTYSIS

Airway Protection â€¢ Bronchial Artery Embolization â€¢ Positioning
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Variably defined as 100-600 mL/24h or any amount causing hemodynamic instability or respiratory compromise. Clinically, "massive" = life-threatening.

Key Point: Death from massive hemoptysis is usually due to ASPHYXIATION (airway flooding), not exsanguination. Airway protection is priority #1.

Common Etiologies:

  • Bronchiectasis: Most common cause worldwide
  • Lung cancer: Common in developed countries
  • Tuberculosis: Active or post-TB bronchiectasis, Rasmussen aneurysm
  • Aspergilloma: Fungus ball in pre-existing cavity
  • Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation (AVM)
  • Anticoagulation: May unmask underlying lesion
  • Iatrogenic: Post-biopsy, post-bronchoscopy, PA catheter rupture

Distinguishing Hemoptysis from Hematemesis:

  • Hemoptysis: Bright red, frothy, alkaline pH, mixed with sputum, preceded by cough
  • Hematemesis: Dark red/"coffee grounds", acidic pH, mixed with food, preceded by nausea
MANAGEMENT

Immediate Actions:

  • Position bleeding lung DOWN: If known laterality, place patient with bleeding side dependent to protect good lung from blood spillage
  • Supplemental O2: High-flow
  • Large-bore IV access: Prepare for resuscitation
  • Type and crossmatch: Have blood available
  • Reverse anticoagulation: If applicable (see Anticoagulation Reversal)
  • Avoid cough suppressants initially: May prevent clearing of blood from airways

Airway Management:

  • Early intubation if: Unable to protect airway, respiratory failure, ongoing massive bleeding
  • Use large ETT (â‰¥8.0): Allows bronchoscopy through tube
  • Mainstem intubation: If bleeding side known and bronchoscopy not immediately available, can intubate mainstem of non-bleeding lung to isolate
  • Double-lumen ETT: Allows lung isolation â€“ requires expertise

Diagnostic and Therapeutic Bronchoscopy:

  • Localize bleeding: Essential for directing therapy
  • Therapeutic options: Cold saline lavage, topical epinephrine (1:20,000), balloon tamponade, electrocautery
  • Rigid bronchoscopy: Better suction, airway control; requires anesthesia support

Bronchial Artery Embolization (BAE):

  • First-line definitive therapy for massive hemoptysis in most cases
  • 90%+ of hemoptysis from bronchial arteries (systemic circulation)
  • Success rate 70-90% for immediate control
  • Recurrence rate 10-30% â€“ may need repeat embolization or surgery

Surgery:

  • Reserved for: BAE failure, recurrent hemoptysis, localized disease amenable to resection, Rasmussen aneurysm, AVM
  • High operative mortality in emergency setting

Specific Etiologies:

  • TB: Anti-TB therapy + BAE
  • Aspergilloma: BAE; consider antifungals and surgical resection if localized
  • Malignancy: BAE for palliation; radiation therapy
  • AVM: Embolization or surgical resection

Cross-link: ðŸ¦  ID Guide: Fungal Infections

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Bleeding Lung DOWN: Position patient with suspected bleeding lung dependent. This protects the good lung from blood spillage. Asphyxiation, not exsanguination, is the main cause of death.
  • Don't Estimate Volume: Patients (and providers) are poor at estimating blood volume. Focus on physiologic impact: hemodynamic status, respiratory status, rate of bleeding.
  • Bronchial Arteries are the Source: 90%+ of massive hemoptysis is from bronchial arteries (high pressure, systemic). Pulmonary artery bleeding (low pressure) is rare but can occur (PA catheter rupture, Rasmussen aneurysm).
  • CT Before Bronchoscopy? If patient is stable enough, CTA chest can help localize bleeding and guide bronchoscopy/BAE. If unstable, proceed directly to bronchoscopy/OR.
  • Rasmussen Aneurysm: Pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm in TB cavity. High mortality. Requires embolization or surgery.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • All massive hemoptysis â€“ ICU mandatory
  • Respiratory failure
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Need for intubation
  • Urgent bronchoscopy or BAE needed
âœ“ POST-STABILIZATION
  • Identify and treat underlying cause
  • Pulmonology and IR follow-up
  • Consider thoracic surgery if recurrent
  • Address anticoagulation needs
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

136. PULMONARY HYPERTENSION CRISIS

RV Failure â€¢ Avoid Systemic Hypotension â€¢ Pulmonary Vasodilators
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Acute RV failure in setting of pulmonary hypertension, often triggered by an acute event. Life-threatening emergency.

Symptoms:

  • Severe dyspnea, worsening exercise intolerance
  • Syncope or presyncope
  • Chest pain (RV ischemia)
  • Altered mental status (low cardiac output)

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia
  • Elevated JVP, RV heave
  • Loud P2, TR murmur
  • Peripheral edema, hepatomegaly
  • Cool extremities (low output)

Common Triggers:

  • Infection/sepsis
  • Arrhythmia (especially AF)
  • PE (acute-on-chronic)
  • Non-compliance with PH therapy
  • Anesthesia/surgery
  • Pregnancy (high mortality in PH)
  • Volume overload
  • Hypoxemia
MANAGEMENT

Goals:

  • Maintain systemic BP (RV coronary perfusion occurs in systole AND diastole â€“ need MAP)
  • Reduce RV afterload (pulmonary vasodilation)
  • Optimize RV preload (gentle diuresis if overloaded, avoid aggressive volume removal)
  • Maintain contractility
  • Treat underlying trigger

Immediate Interventions:

  • Oxygen: Hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction worsens PH. Target SpO2 >90%.
  • Avoid intubation if possible: Positive pressure ventilation reduces RV preload. If necessary, use low PEEP, avoid hypoxia, maintain systemic BP during induction.
  • IV access, arterial line: Close hemodynamic monitoring essential

Hemodynamic Support:

  • Norepinephrine: First-line vasopressor. Maintains systemic BP for RV perfusion.
  • Vasopressin: May add as second agent; causes systemic vasoconstriction with less pulmonary vasoconstriction than other agents.
  • Dobutamine: Inotropic support for RV; may cause systemic hypotension (vasodilation).
  • Avoid pure vasodilators: Will drop systemic BP without proportional drop in PVR â†’ RV ischemia.

Pulmonary Vasodilators:

  • Inhaled nitric oxide (iNO): Selective pulmonary vasodilator; no systemic hypotension. Start 10-20 ppm.
  • Inhaled epoprostenol: Alternative to iNO; cheaper, more available.
  • IV epoprostenol: Potent but causes systemic hypotension. Use with systemic vasopressor support.
  • Continue home PH medications: Do NOT stop chronic PH therapies (prostacyclins, ERA, PDE5i). Rebound PH can be fatal.

Diuresis:

  • Gentle diuresis if RV volume overloaded (elevated CVP, peripheral edema)
  • Avoid aggressive diuresis â€“ RV is preload-dependent

Treat Underlying Trigger: Infection, PE, arrhythmia, etc.

Refractory Cases:

  • ECMO (VA-ECMO) as bridge to recovery or transplant
  • Atrial septostomy (decompresses RV)
  • Urgent transplant evaluation
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • RV Needs Systemic Pressure: Unlike LV (perfused mainly in diastole), the RV is perfused throughout cardiac cycle. Systemic hypotension â†’ RV ischemia â†’ RV failure spiral.
  • Never Stop Home PH Meds: Abruptly stopping prostacyclins (especially IV) causes rebound PH and death. Ensure continuous infusion even in crisis.
  • Avoid Intubation if Possible: Positive pressure ventilation decreases RV preload and can precipitate cardiovascular collapse. If intubation required, use experienced provider, maintain BP, use low PEEP.
  • Inhaled Pulmonary Vasodilators: iNO and inhaled epoprostenol selectively vasodilate pulmonary vasculature without systemic hypotension. Ideal in PH crisis.
  • The Death Spiral: RV dilation â†’ TR worsens â†’ RV CO drops â†’ systemic hypotension â†’ RV ischemia â†’ RV fails further. Must break this cycle early.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • All PH crisis â€“ ICU mandatory
  • Hypotension, shock
  • Need for vasopressors or inotropes
  • Respiratory failure
  • Syncope
âœ“ STABILIZATION GOALS
  • MAP >65 mmHg
  • SpO2 >90%
  • Resolving end-organ dysfunction
  • Weaning vasopressors
  • PH specialist consultation
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

137. DISSEMINATED INTRAVASCULAR COAGULATION (DIC)

Consumption Coagulopathy â€¢ Treat Underlying Cause â€¢ ISTH Score
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Systemic activation of coagulation causing widespread microvascular thrombosis AND consumption of clotting factors/platelets â†’ simultaneous bleeding and clotting.

Clinical Features:

  • Bleeding: Oozing from IV sites, surgical wounds, mucosal bleeding, petechiae, ecchymoses
  • Thrombosis: Digital ischemia, skin necrosis, organ dysfunction (renal, hepatic)
  • Purpura fulminans: Large ecchymoses with central necrosis (protein C depletion)

Underlying Causes (DIC is ALWAYS Secondary):

  • Sepsis: Most common cause (~35%)
  • Malignancy: Solid tumors (mucin-secreting), acute leukemia (especially APL)
  • Trauma: Massive tissue injury, burns
  • Obstetric: Placental abruption, amniotic fluid embolism, HELLP, septic abortion
  • Vascular: Large aortic aneurysm, giant hemangioma (Kasabach-Merritt)
  • Toxic: Snake envenomation, transfusion reaction, drug reactions
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

No Single Test is Diagnostic: DIC is diagnosed by pattern of abnormalities + clinical context.

Laboratory Findings:

  • Platelets: Low or rapidly falling
  • PT/INR: Prolonged (consumption of factors)
  • PTT: Prolonged (but may be normal early)
  • Fibrinogen: Low (consumed) â€“ but may be normal/elevated if acute phase reactant effect
  • D-dimer/FDP: Markedly elevated (fibrinolysis)
  • Peripheral smear: Schistocytes (microangiopathic hemolysis from fibrin strands)

ISTH DIC Score:

  • Platelet count: >100k (0), 50-100k (1), <50k (2)
  • D-dimer: No increase (0), moderate (2), strong (3)
  • PT prolongation: <3 sec (0), 3-6 sec (1), >6 sec (2)
  • Fibrinogen: >1 g/L (0), <1 g/L (1)
  • Score â‰¥5: Compatible with overt DIC

Distinguish from Other Conditions:

  • TTP/HUS: Coags (PT/PTT/fibrinogen) are NORMAL in TTP
  • Liver failure: Similar coagulopathy but different clinical context; factor VIII normal or elevated (synthesized outside liver)
  • HIT: Thrombocytopenia + thrombosis but coags usually normal

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ Coagulation Reference, ðŸ“š TTP/HUS

MANAGEMENT

Treat Underlying Cause: This is the ONLY definitive treatment. DIC will not resolve until trigger is eliminated.

  • Sepsis â†’ antibiotics, source control
  • Obstetric â†’ delivery, surgical intervention
  • Malignancy â†’ chemotherapy (especially APL â€“ ATRA)
  • Trauma â†’ hemorrhage control, damage control surgery

Supportive Therapy (Replace What's Consumed):

  • Platelets: Transfuse if <10k (or <50k with bleeding/procedure). Don't chase a number â€“ will be consumed.
  • FFP: For active bleeding with prolonged PT/PTT. Give 15-30 mL/kg.
  • Cryoprecipitate: If fibrinogen <100-150 mg/dL. Target fibrinogen >100-150.
  • PRBC: For anemia/hemorrhage

Anticoagulation â€“ Controversial:

  • Generally NOT recommended in bleeding-predominant DIC
  • May consider: If thrombosis-predominant (e.g., purpura fulminans, acral ischemia) and bleeding controlled
  • APL with DIC: ATRA is treatment; heparin not beneficial

Antifibrinolytics (TXA, aminocaproic acid):

  • Generally contraindicated (can worsen microvascular thrombosis)
  • Exception: Hyperfibrinolytic DIC (trauma, APL) â€“ use with caution
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • DIC is Always Secondary: Never treat DIC in isolation. Find and treat the underlying cause â€“ DIC won't resolve otherwise.
  • Coags are Deranged in DIC, NOT in TTP: This is a key distinguishing feature. TTP has normal PT/PTT/fibrinogen; DIC has abnormal coags.
  • Don't Chase Numbers: Platelet and FFP transfusions are consumed rapidly in active DIC. Transfuse for active bleeding or procedures, not to normalize labs.
  • Fibrinogen Can Be Misleading: Fibrinogen is an acute phase reactant. In sepsis-associated DIC, fibrinogen may be "normal" even while being consumed. A "normal" fibrinogen in septic patient may actually represent significant consumption.
  • APL is Special: Acute promyelocytic leukemia has characteristic DIC. ATRA (all-trans retinoic acid) is treatment â€“ improves coagulopathy as it treats disease.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Active bleeding requiring transfusion
  • End-organ dysfunction
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Need for massive transfusion
âœ“ RESOLUTION CRITERIA
  • Underlying cause treated/resolving
  • Improving platelet count
  • Normalizing PT/PTT
  • Rising fibrinogen
  • Decreasing D-dimer
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

138. TUMOR LYSIS SYNDROME (TLS)

Hyperuricemia â€¢ Hyperkalemia â€¢ Hyperphosphatemia â€¢ Hypocalcemia
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Metabolic emergency from rapid tumor cell death releasing intracellular contents. Can be spontaneous or treatment-induced.

Classic Metabolic Abnormalities:

  • Hyperuricemia: Nucleic acid breakdown â†’ uric acid
  • Hyperkalemia: Intracellular K+ release
  • Hyperphosphatemia: Intracellular PO4 release
  • Hypocalcemia: Ca binds to elevated phosphate â†’ precipitation

Clinical Manifestations:

  • AKI: Uric acid and calcium phosphate crystal deposition in tubules
  • Arrhythmias: From hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia
  • Seizures: Hypocalcemia
  • Muscle cramps, tetany: Hypocalcemia
  • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea

High-Risk Malignancies:

  • Highest risk: Burkitt lymphoma, ALL (especially with high WBC), AML (especially with high WBC)
  • Moderate risk: Other aggressive lymphomas, solid tumors with rapid response to therapy
  • Risk factors: High tumor burden, high LDH, high WBC, pre-existing renal impairment, dehydration
DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA

Cairo-Bishop Criteria:

Laboratory TLS: â‰¥2 of the following within 3 days before or 7 days after chemotherapy:

  • Uric acid â‰¥8 mg/dL or 25% increase from baseline
  • Potassium â‰¥6.0 mEq/L or 25% increase
  • Phosphorus â‰¥4.5 mg/dL (adults) or 25% increase
  • Calcium â‰¤7.0 mg/dL or 25% decrease

Clinical TLS: Laboratory TLS + â‰¥1 of:

  • Creatinine â‰¥1.5Ã— ULN
  • Cardiac arrhythmia or sudden death
  • Seizure

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ Electrolytes Reference, ðŸ“š Hyperkalemia

MANAGEMENT

Prevention (High-Risk Patients):

  • IV hydration: 2-3 L/mÂ²/day NS. Target urine output 80-100 mL/mÂ²/hr (or ~200 mL/hr adult).
  • Allopurinol: 300-600 mg/day, start 1-2 days before chemotherapy. Prevents NEW uric acid formation.
  • Rasburicase: For high-risk patients or established hyperuricemia. 0.2 mg/kg IV Ã— 1. Breaks down EXISTING uric acid. Contraindicated in G6PD deficiency (hemolysis).
  • Avoid alkalinization: Previously used to increase uric acid solubility, but promotes calcium phosphate precipitation. Not routinely recommended.

Treatment of Established TLS:

  • Aggressive IV hydration: 3 L/mÂ²/day with close monitoring
  • Rasburicase: For hyperuricemia (0.2 mg/kg IV Ã— 1, may repeat)
  • Hyperkalemia management: Calcium gluconate (cardiac protection), insulin/glucose, kayexalate, diuretics, dialysis if severe (see Hyperkalemia)
  • Hyperphosphatemia: Phosphate binders (sevelamer, calcium-free if hypocalcemic), dialysis if severe
  • Hypocalcemia: Treat only if symptomatic (tetany, seizures, arrhythmia). Asymptomatic hypocalcemia â€“ avoid Ca supplementation (can worsen calcium phosphate precipitation).

Dialysis Indications:

  • Severe hyperkalemia refractory to medical management
  • Severe hyperphosphatemia
  • Volume overload
  • Symptomatic hypocalcemia with high phosphate (can't give Ca without worsening precipitation)
  • Uremia
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Prevention is Key: High-risk patients should receive prophylaxis (hydration + allopurinol or rasburicase) BEFORE chemotherapy. Once TLS is established, management is more difficult.
  • Rasburicase is a Game-Changer: Unlike allopurinol (prevents new uric acid), rasburicase breaks down existing uric acid. Works in hours, not days. First-line for established hyperuricemia or very high-risk patients.
  • G6PD and Rasburicase: Rasburicase is CONTRAINDICATED in G6PD deficiency â€“ causes severe hemolysis. Screen if possible, especially in high-risk populations.
  • Don't Treat Asymptomatic Hypocalcemia: Giving calcium when phosphate is high causes calcium phosphate precipitation â†’ worsens renal injury. Only treat symptomatic hypocalcemia.
  • Alkalinization is OUT: Old teaching was to alkalinize urine to solubilize uric acid. This promotes calcium phosphate precipitation and is NOT recommended.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Clinical TLS (AKI, arrhythmia, seizure)
  • Severe hyperkalemia (>6.5 or ECG changes)
  • Need for dialysis
  • Symptomatic hypocalcemia
âœ“ RESOLUTION CRITERIA
  • Normalizing electrolytes
  • Improving renal function
  • Adequate urine output
  • No arrhythmias
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

139. HYPERVISCOSITY SYNDROME

Waldenstrom's â€¢ Multiple Myeloma â€¢ Plasmapheresis
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Increased blood viscosity causing impaired microvascular flow. Classic triad: bleeding, neurologic symptoms, visual disturbances.

Classic Triad:

  • Bleeding: Mucosal bleeding (epistaxis, gingival), GI bleeding, menorrhagia. Paraprotein interferes with platelet function and coagulation factors.
  • Neurologic: Headache, confusion, altered mental status, ataxia, vertigo, hearing loss, stroke-like symptoms
  • Visual: Blurred vision, diplopia, vision loss. Fundoscopy shows "sausage-link" or "boxcar" retinal veins, retinal hemorrhages, papilledema.

Other Manifestations:

  • Dyspnea, hypoxia (pulmonary infiltrates)
  • Heart failure (increased cardiac workload)
  • Cryoglobulinemia (if cryoglobulins present)

Common Causes:

  • Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (IgM): Most common cause. IgM is large pentamer â€“ small increases cause large viscosity changes.
  • Multiple myeloma (IgA, IgG3): Less common than WM. IgA tends to polymerize.
  • Polycythemia vera / Leukostasis: Cellular hyperviscosity (WBC >100k or Hct >60%)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Serum Viscosity:

  • Normal: 1.4-1.8 centipoise (relative to water)
  • Symptoms typically occur at >4 cp (but varies by individual)
  • Some patients symptomatic at lower levels; others asymptomatic at higher levels

Laboratory:

  • SPEP/UPEP: M-spike
  • Immunofixation: Identifies paraprotein type (IgM, IgA, IgG)
  • Quantitative immunoglobulins: Elevated monoclonal Ig
  • CBC: Anemia common (dilutional, marrow infiltration)
  • Coagulation studies: May be abnormal (paraprotein interference)

Fundoscopic Exam: Essential â€“ look for retinal vein engorgement, hemorrhages, papilledema

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ SPEP Reference

MANAGEMENT

Emergent Treatment â€“ Plasmapheresis:

  • Removes circulating paraprotein â€“ rapidly reduces viscosity
  • Single session can reduce IgM by 30-50%
  • Usually 1-2 exchanges initially, then as needed
  • Bridge to definitive chemotherapy

Supportive Measures:

  • IV hydration: Improves rheology
  • AVOID transfusion of PRBC: Will worsen viscosity. If anemia severe and transfusion necessary, do after plasmapheresis.
  • Treat bleeding: Supportive; may need platelet transfusion

Definitive Treatment â€“ Chemotherapy:

  • Waldenstrom: Rituximab-based regimens (but rituximab can cause IgM flare â€“ sometimes defer until after plasmapheresis), BTK inhibitors (ibrutinib)
  • Multiple myeloma: Bortezomib-based regimens, IMiDs

Rituximab Flare: Rituximab can cause transient increase in IgM (tumor lysis or cytokine release). In hyperviscosity, may need plasmapheresis before rituximab.

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • IgM is the Worst Offender: IgM is a pentamer (large) â€“ small increases cause disproportionate viscosity increase. Waldenstrom's is more likely to cause hyperviscosity than myeloma at same paraprotein level.
  • Check the Eyes: Fundoscopic exam is essential. "Sausage-link" retinal veins are classic. Visual changes may be the presenting symptom.
  • Don't Transfuse RBCs: This will worsen viscosity. If patient needs blood, do plasmapheresis first.
  • Plasmapheresis is Temporary: Reduces paraprotein but doesn't treat underlying disease. Chemotherapy is definitive treatment.
  • Symptoms Don't Correlate Perfectly with Viscosity: Some patients are symptomatic at viscosity 3, others asymptomatic at 6. Treat symptoms, not just numbers.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Altered mental status, obtundation
  • Stroke-like symptoms
  • Severe bleeding
  • Respiratory failure
  • Urgent plasmapheresis needed
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Symptoms resolved
  • Viscosity improved
  • Chemotherapy plan established
  • Hematology/Oncology follow-up
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

140. MYASTHENIC CRISIS

Respiratory Failure â€¢ IVIG/Plasmapheresis â€¢ Avoid Certain Medications
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Life-threatening weakness in myasthenia gravis requiring mechanical ventilation or airway protection due to respiratory muscle or bulbar weakness.

Warning Signs of Impending Crisis:

  • Worsening dyspnea, orthopnea
  • Dysphagia, difficulty managing secretions
  • Weak cough
  • Rapid shallow breathing
  • Use of accessory muscles

Common Triggers:

  • Infection: Most common trigger (especially respiratory infections)
  • Medications: Aminoglycosides, fluoroquinolones, beta-blockers, magnesium, neuromuscular blockers
  • Surgery/Anesthesia
  • Medication changes: Reduction of immunotherapy, missed doses
  • Pregnancy/Postpartum
  • Emotional/Physical stress

Distinguish from Cholinergic Crisis:

  • Cholinergic crisis = excessive acetylcholinesterase inhibitor (pyridostigmine)
  • Features: SLUDGE (salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, GI cramping, emesis), miosis, bradycardia
  • Both can cause weakness â€“ history and exam help differentiate
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Bedside Pulmonary Function:

  • FVC (Forced Vital Capacity): Most important parameter. <1 L or <15-20 mL/kg = impending respiratory failure
  • NIF (Negative Inspiratory Force): More negative is better. Less negative than -30 cmH2O = weakness
  • Trend is critical: Declining FVC even if still "normal" is concerning
  • 20-30-40 Rule: Consider intubation if FVC <20 mL/kg, NIF > -30, or FVC decline >30% from baseline

Laboratory:

  • ABG (late finding â€“ don't wait for hypercapnia)
  • Infectious workup (CXR, UA, blood cultures)
  • TSH (thyroid disease associated with MG)

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ ABG Reference

MANAGEMENT

Airway Management:

  • Low threshold for intubation: Don't wait for respiratory failure. Intubate early for declining FVC or bulbar dysfunction with aspiration risk.
  • Avoid depolarizing neuromuscular blockers: Succinylcholine â€“ MG patients are resistant (need higher dose) and may have prolonged weakness
  • Non-depolarizing NMBs: Use reduced dose (MG patients are very sensitive)

Immunomodulatory Therapy (Rescue Therapy):

  • Plasmapheresis: 5-7 exchanges over 10-14 days. Removes acetylcholine receptor antibodies. Effect in 2-5 days.
  • IVIG: 2 g/kg divided over 2-5 days. Similar efficacy to plasmapheresis. Effect in 4-5 days.
  • Both are first-line for crisis â€“ choice often based on availability and patient factors (vascular access, renal function)

Medications to HOLD or AVOID:

  • HOLD pyridostigmine: During intubation â€“ reduces secretions, allows better assessment
  • Avoid: Aminoglycosides, fluoroquinolones, macrolides (use with caution), beta-blockers, magnesium, procainamide, lithium, phenytoin

Long-Term Immunotherapy (After Stabilization):

  • Corticosteroids (may cause initial worsening â€“ start in hospital)
  • Azathioprine, mycophenolate, cyclosporine
  • Rituximab for refractory cases
  • Thymectomy if thymoma or generalized MG
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • FVC is Your Friend: Serial FVC measurements are the best predictor of impending respiratory failure. ABG changes late â€“ don't wait for hypercarbia.
  • 20-30-40 Rule: Intubate if FVC <20 mL/kg, NIF > -30 cmH2O (less negative than -30), or >30% decline from baseline.
  • Infection is the #1 Trigger: Aggressively look for and treat infection, but be mindful of antibiotic choice â€“ avoid aminoglycosides and fluoroquinolones if possible.
  • PLEX vs. IVIG: Both work. PLEX slightly faster onset. IVIG easier to administer. Choice often pragmatic.
  • Hold Pyridostigmine When Intubated: Reduces secretions, easier to manage. Restart when weaning.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • All myasthenic crisis â€“ ICU mandatory
  • FVC <20 mL/kg or declining
  • Bulbar weakness with aspiration risk
  • Need for intubation
âœ“ EXTUBATION CRITERIA
  • FVC >15-20 mL/kg
  • NIF < -30 cmH2O
  • Adequate cough and secretion management
  • Completed PLEX or IVIG course
  • Underlying trigger treated
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

141. GUILLAIN-BARRÃ‰ SYNDROME (GBS)

Ascending Paralysis â€¢ IVIG/Plasmapheresis â€¢ Autonomic Instability
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Features:

  • Ascending weakness: Starts distally in legs, progresses proximally over days to weeks
  • Areflexia: Absent or reduced deep tendon reflexes
  • Sensory symptoms: Paresthesias, pain (often less prominent than weakness)
  • Facial weakness: Bilateral in ~50%
  • Respiratory failure: 15-30% require ventilation

Preceding Illness: 2/3 have antecedent infection 1-4 weeks prior (Campylobacter, CMV, EBV, Zika, influenza, COVID-19)

Variants:

  • AIDP: Classic demyelinating form (most common in Western countries)
  • AMAN/AMSAN: Axonal variants (more common in Asia, associated with Campylobacter)
  • Miller Fisher: Ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, areflexia (anti-GQ1b antibodies)

Red Flags for Respiratory Failure:

  • Rapid progression (<7 days to unable to walk)
  • Bulbar weakness
  • Bilateral facial weakness
  • Autonomic dysfunction
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

CSF Analysis (Lumbar Puncture):

  • Albuminocytologic dissociation: Elevated protein with normal cell count
  • May be normal early (first week) â€“ repeat if negative and high suspicion

Electrodiagnostic Studies (EMG/NCS):

  • Confirms diagnosis, distinguishes AIDP from axonal variants
  • May be normal in first 1-2 weeks

Pulmonary Function:

  • Serial FVC and NIF (same as myasthenic crisis)
  • Same 20-30-40 rule applies

Anti-Ganglioside Antibodies: GQ1b (Miller Fisher), GM1 (AMAN). Not required for diagnosis but can help classify.

MANAGEMENT

Immunomodulatory Therapy:

  • IVIG: 0.4 g/kg/day Ã— 5 days (total 2 g/kg). First-line in most centers.
  • Plasmapheresis: 5 exchanges over 1-2 weeks. Equally effective to IVIG.
  • Start within 2-4 weeks of symptom onset for best efficacy
  • Steroids are NOT effective (unlike other inflammatory neuropathies)

Supportive Care:

  • Serial respiratory monitoring: FVC q4-6h initially
  • DVT prophylaxis: High risk due to immobility
  • Pain management: Gabapentin, opioids if needed
  • Physical therapy: Early mobilization

Autonomic Dysfunction:

  • Occurs in 70% â€“ can be life-threatening
  • Manifestations: Tachycardia, bradycardia, hypertension, hypotension, arrhythmias, ileus, urinary retention
  • Continuous cardiac monitoring in ICU
  • Use short-acting agents for BP management
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Ascending Weakness + Areflexia = GBS Until Proven Otherwise: Classic pattern. Sensory symptoms often present but less prominent than weakness.
  • Serial FVC is Critical: Same monitoring principles as myasthenic crisis. Don't wait for ABG abnormalities.
  • Steroids Don't Work: Unlike CIDP or other inflammatory conditions. Don't give steroids for GBS.
  • Autonomic Instability Kills: Cardiac arrhythmias are a major cause of death in GBS. Monitor continuously, use short-acting agents.
  • CSF Can Be Normal Early: Protein may not elevate until week 2. Don't exclude GBS based on normal early LP.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Declining FVC (<20-25 mL/kg)
  • Bulbar weakness
  • Autonomic instability
  • Rapid progression
âœ“ PROGNOSIS
  • ~80% walk independently at 6 months
  • ~5-10% mortality (respiratory, autonomic)
  • Residual deficits common (fatigue, pain)
  • Recovery can take months to years
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

142. SPINAL CORD COMPRESSION

Oncologic Emergency â€¢ MRI Whole Spine â€¢ Dexamethasone
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Presentation:

  • Back pain: Most common initial symptom (90%+). Worse supine, with Valsalva
  • Weakness: Progresses over hours to days. Level depends on compression site.
  • Sensory level: Decreased sensation below level of compression
  • Bladder/bowel dysfunction: Late finding â€“ urinary retention, overflow incontinence, constipation

Etiologies:

  • Malignancy (Most Common): Metastatic (lung, breast, prostate, renal, lymphoma, myeloma). 5-10% of cancer patients.
  • Epidural abscess: Fever, back pain, risk factors (IVDU, bacteremia, spinal procedure)
  • Epidural hematoma: Anticoagulation, trauma, post-procedure
  • Disc herniation: Trauma, degenerative

Red Flags: New back pain in cancer patient, fever + back pain, urinary retention, rapidly progressive weakness, saddle anesthesia

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

MRI Spine (URGENT):

  • WHOLE SPINE with and without contrast: Multiple levels of compression common in malignancy
  • Gold standard for diagnosis
  • Must be done EMERGENTLY â€“ prognosis depends on neurologic status at treatment initiation

CT Myelography: Alternative if MRI contraindicated (pacemaker, etc.)

Laboratory:

  • If epidural abscess suspected: Blood cultures, CBC, ESR, CRP
  • If malignancy: Staging workup as indicated
MANAGEMENT

Immediate Management (Don't Delay for Imaging):

  • Dexamethasone: 10 mg IV bolus, then 4 mg IV q6h. Reduces edema, preserves neurologic function.
  • Start immediately if high suspicion â€“ don't wait for MRI confirmation

Definitive Treatment â€“ Malignant Cord Compression:

  • Radiation therapy: First-line for most radiosensitive tumors (lymphoma, myeloma, small cell lung, breast, prostate)
  • Surgery (decompressive laminectomy) followed by radiation: Superior outcomes in selected patients (single site, radioresistant tumor, spinal instability, unknown primary, progression during/after RT)
  • Emergent surgery: If rapid neurologic decline

Epidural Abscess:

  • Emergent surgical decompression: Usually required
  • IV antibiotics: Broad-spectrum initially (vancomycin + cefepime or similar), then tailored to culture
  • Duration: 4-8 weeks IV antibiotics

Epidural Hematoma:

  • Reverse anticoagulation (see Anticoagulation Reversal)
  • Emergent surgical evacuation if neurologic deficits

Cross-link: ðŸ¦  ID Guide: Bone & Joint Infections

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Time is Function: Neurologic status at treatment initiation predicts outcome. Ambulatory patients often remain ambulatory; paraplegic patients rarely recover. Treat urgently.
  • Give Steroids NOW: Don't wait for MRI. Dexamethasone is safe and can preserve function. Give it with first suspicion.
  • Image the WHOLE Spine: In malignancy, multiple levels of compression are common. Miss one, patient still has cord compression.
  • Epidural Abscess is Surgical: Unlike vertebral osteomyelitis, epidural abscess with neurologic deficits requires emergent surgery. Antibiotics alone are insufficient.
  • Bladder Dysfunction = Late Finding: Once present, prognosis for recovery is worse. Don't wait for this to act.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE IF:
  • Any suspicion for cord compression
  • Progressive neurologic deficits
  • New bladder/bowel dysfunction
  • Need for emergent surgery
âœ“ PROGNOSIS FACTORS
  • Pre-treatment ambulatory status
  • Speed of deficit onset
  • Duration of deficits before treatment
  • Tumor type (radiosensitivity)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

143. ACETAMINOPHEN OVERDOSE

Rumack-Matthew Nomogram â€¢ N-Acetylcysteine â€¢ Acute Liver Failure
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Stages of Toxicity:

  • Stage 1 (0-24h): Often asymptomatic or nonspecific (nausea, vomiting, malaise). Labs normal.
  • Stage 2 (24-72h): RUQ pain, elevated AST/ALT. Stage 1 symptoms may resolve.
  • Stage 3 (72-96h): Peak hepatotoxicity. Markedly elevated transaminases, coagulopathy, encephalopathy, possible renal failure.
  • Stage 4 (4d-2wk): Recovery (if survived) or death from fulminant hepatic failure.

Key Point: Patients may appear well initially. Don't be reassured by lack of early symptoms.

Toxic Dose:

  • >150 mg/kg (or >7.5-10g in adults) acute ingestion â€“ potential for hepatotoxicity
  • Chronic ingestion: lower thresholds, nomogram doesn't apply
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Serum Acetaminophen Level:

  • Draw at 4 hours post-ingestion (or immediately if >4h since ingestion)
  • Plot on Rumack-Matthew Nomogram

Rumack-Matthew Nomogram:

  • Treatment line starts at 150 mcg/mL at 4h post-ingestion
  • Level above the line â†’ treat with NAC
  • Only valid for single acute ingestion with known time

Other Labs:

  • AST/ALT (may be normal initially)
  • INR, bilirubin
  • BMP (creatinine â€“ renal failure can occur)
  • Serum salicylate (common co-ingestant)

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ LFT Reference

MANAGEMENT

Decontamination:

  • Activated charcoal: If <4h from ingestion and patient alert. 1 g/kg (max 50g).

N-Acetylcysteine (NAC) â€“ The Antidote:

  • Indication: Level above treatment line, unknown ingestion time with detectable level and transaminitis, massive ingestion, late presentation with hepatotoxicity
  • Most effective if started within 8 hours â€“ but give even if late if hepatotoxicity present

IV NAC Protocol (21-hour):

  • Loading: 150 mg/kg in 200mL D5W over 1 hour
  • Second dose: 50 mg/kg in 500mL D5W over 4 hours
  • Third dose: 100 mg/kg in 1000mL D5W over 16 hours
  • If ongoing hepatotoxicity, continue third dose rate until INR <2, AST/ALT declining, and no encephalopathy

Oral NAC Protocol (72-hour):

  • Loading: 140 mg/kg PO Ã— 1
  • Maintenance: 70 mg/kg PO q4h Ã— 17 doses

Anaphylactoid Reactions to IV NAC:

  • Common (10-20%) â€“ flushing, urticaria, bronchospasm
  • Usually rate-related â€“ slow or pause infusion, give antihistamines
  • True anaphylaxis rare â€“ can usually rechallenge at slower rate

Liver Transplant Criteria (King's College Criteria):

  • pH <7.3 after resuscitation, OR
  • All three: INR >6.5, Cr >3.4, Grade 3-4 encephalopathy
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • 8-Hour Window: NAC is nearly 100% effective if started within 8 hours. Efficacy decreases after that but still give it.
  • Patients Look Well Initially: Stage 1 is asymptomatic. Don't discharge early based on how patient "looks."
  • Nomogram Only for Acute Single Ingestion: Chronic supratherapeutic ingestion, staggered dosing, or unknown time â†’ nomogram doesn't apply. Use clinical judgment, lower threshold to treat.
  • AST >1000: This should make you think of APAP toxicity (or ischemic/viral hepatitis). Not typical of other drug reactions.
  • Anaphylactoid â‰  Stop NAC: Slow the rate, give antihistamines, usually can resume. Don't withhold life-saving antidote.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Elevated INR or transaminases
  • Encephalopathy
  • Massive ingestion (>500 mg/kg)
  • Concerning trajectory
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Level below treatment line at 4h+ post-ingestion
  • Normal AST/ALT, INR
  • Psychiatry clearance if intentional
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

144. SALICYLATE TOXICITY

Mixed Acid-Base â€¢ Alkalinization â€¢ Dialysis Indications
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Early (Mild): Tinnitus, nausea, vomiting, tachypnea (respiratory alkalosis from direct CNS stimulation)

Moderate: Hyperthermia, diaphoresis, altered mental status, mixed acid-base disorder

Severe: Seizures, coma, cerebral edema, pulmonary edema, cardiovascular collapse, hypoglycemia, coagulopathy

Classic Acid-Base Pattern:

  • Early: Respiratory alkalosis (CNS stimulation of respiratory center)
  • Later: Anion gap metabolic acidosis (uncoupled oxidative phosphorylation, lactate, ketones)
  • Mixed: Often see combined respiratory alkalosis + metabolic acidosis

Toxic Dose: >150 mg/kg acute ingestion (single dose >6.5g in adults)

MANAGEMENT

Decontamination:

  • Activated charcoal: Effective even several hours post-ingestion (enteric-coated formulations, bezoar formation)
  • May repeat charcoal doses for significant ingestions

Urinary Alkalinization:

  • Goal: Urine pH 7.5-8.0. Traps ionized salicylate in urine, enhances elimination.
  • Method: Sodium bicarbonate 150 mEq in 1L D5W at 1.5-2Ã— maintenance
  • Monitor: Urine pH, serum K (alkalinization causes hypokalemia â€“ must replace K to achieve urinary alkalinization)

Hemodialysis Indications:

  • Salicylate level >100 mg/dL (acute) or >80 mg/dL (chronic)
  • Severe altered mental status or coma
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Seizures
  • Renal failure (can't alkalinize)
  • Clinical deterioration despite treatment

DO NOT INTUBATE without Good Reason:

  • Patients with salicylate toxicity have massive compensatory hyperventilation
  • If intubated, must match their minute ventilation â€“ otherwise pH drops rapidly, salicylate enters CNS, death
  • If intubation required, use high RR and tidal volume

Cross-link: ðŸ©º Acid-Base Framework

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • The Intubation Trap: Salicylate-toxic patients hyperventilate massively to compensate. If you intubate and normalize their CO2, pH crashes, salicylate enters brain, they die. Avoid intubation if possible; if required, match their high minute ventilation.
  • Alkalemia is Protective: At alkaline pH, salicylate is ionized and can't cross blood-brain barrier. Acidemia allows uncharged salicylate into CNS â†’ cerebral toxicity.
  • Chronic Toxicity is More Dangerous: Chronic salicylate toxicity presents at lower levels with worse symptoms. Older patients on chronic aspirin are at high risk.
  • Check K Before Alkalinizing: Hypokalemia prevents urinary alkalinization. Must replace K aggressively.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Level >50 mg/dL
  • Altered mental status
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Need for dialysis
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Declining salicylate levels
  • Resolved symptoms
  • Normal pH
  • Psychiatry clearance if intentional
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

145. TOXIC ALCOHOL INGESTION

Methanol â€¢ Ethylene Glycol â€¢ Osmol Gap â€¢ Fomepizole
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

General Features: Inebriation without ethanol smell, anion gap metabolic acidosis, elevated osmol gap

Methanol:

  • Sources: Windshield washer fluid, wood alcohol, moonshine
  • Toxic metabolite: Formic acid
  • Features: Visual disturbances (blurred vision, "snowfield" vision, blindness), headache, abdominal pain
  • Classically causes basal ganglia hemorrhage

Ethylene Glycol:

  • Sources: Antifreeze (sweet-tasting)
  • Toxic metabolites: Glycolic acid, oxalic acid
  • Features: Renal failure (calcium oxalate crystal deposition), hypocalcemia
  • Calcium oxalate crystals on urinalysis (envelope-shaped)

Isopropanol:

  • Sources: Rubbing alcohol
  • Metabolite: Acetone (ketosis without acidosis)
  • Features: CNS depression, GI irritation, NO anion gap acidosis
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Osmol Gap:

  • Calculated Osm = 2[Na] + [Glucose]/18 + [BUN]/2.8 + [EtOH]/4.6
  • Osmol gap = Measured Osm â€“ Calculated Osm
  • Normal <10. Elevated in toxic alcohol ingestion (before metabolism)

Anion Gap:

  • Elevated AG indicates toxic metabolites present
  • Early: High osmol gap, low/normal AG (parent compound present)
  • Late: Low osmol gap, high AG (metabolized to acids)

Specific Levels: Methanol and ethylene glycol levels (send but don't wait for results to treat)

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ Electrolytes Reference

MANAGEMENT

Fomepizole (Antidote):

  • Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase â€“ prevents formation of toxic metabolites
  • Dosing: 15 mg/kg IV load, then 10 mg/kg IV q12h Ã— 4 doses, then 15 mg/kg q12h
  • Continue until level <20 mg/dL and patient asymptomatic with normal pH

Ethanol (Alternative if Fomepizole Unavailable):

  • Same mechanism (competitive ADH inhibition)
  • Target serum ethanol 100-150 mg/dL
  • More difficult to titrate, more side effects

Hemodialysis Indications:

  • Severe metabolic acidosis (pH <7.25)
  • Visual disturbances (methanol)
  • Renal failure (ethylene glycol)
  • Level >50 mg/dL
  • Clinical deterioration

Adjunctive Therapy:

  • Methanol: Folic acid 50 mg IV q4h (enhances formate metabolism)
  • Ethylene glycol: Pyridoxine 100 mg IV q6h, Thiamine 100 mg IV q6h (enhance metabolism to nontoxic metabolites)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Osmol vs. Anion Gap Timing: Early = high osmol gap (parent compound). Late = high anion gap (metabolites). Both gaps may not be elevated simultaneously.
  • Visual Symptoms = Methanol: Formic acid is toxic to the optic nerve. Any visual symptoms â†’ think methanol.
  • Renal Failure + Crystals = Ethylene Glycol: Calcium oxalate crystals in urine are classic but not always present.
  • Fomepizole is First-Line: Easier to use than ethanol, fewer side effects. Give empirically if high suspicion â€“ don't wait for specific levels.
  • Isopropanol is Different: Causes ketosis (acetone) but NOT acidosis. Osmol gap without anion gap.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • All significant toxic alcohol ingestions
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Need for dialysis
  • Visual changes or AKI
âœ“ TREATMENT ENDPOINTS
  • Level <20 mg/dL
  • Normal pH
  • Resolved symptoms
  • Improving renal function (EG)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

146. OPIOID OVERDOSE

Naloxone â€¢ Respiratory Depression â€¢ Harm Reduction
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Triad:

  • Miosis: Pinpoint pupils
  • CNS depression: Decreased LOC, coma
  • Respiratory depression: Decreased RR, hypoxia, apnea

Other Features: Hypotension, bradycardia, hypothermia, decreased bowel sounds, track marks

Complications:

  • Aspiration pneumonia
  • Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema
  • Rhabdomyolysis (from prolonged immobility)
  • Compartment syndrome
MANAGEMENT

Immediate:

  • Airway: Open airway, provide ventilation if needed
  • Naloxone: See below

Naloxone (Narcan):

  • Initial dose: 0.04-0.4 mg IV/IM/SC/IN. Start low if opioid-dependent (avoid precipitating severe withdrawal).
  • Goal: Restore adequate spontaneous respiration â€“ NOT full alertness
  • Repeat: q2-3 min until adequate respiration (can give up to 10-15 mg total for synthetic opioids)
  • Half-life: 30-90 min â€“ shorter than most opioids. Watch for recurrent sedation.

Special Considerations:

  • Fentanyl and analogues: May require higher naloxone doses (2-10+ mg)
  • Long-acting opioids (methadone): May need naloxone infusion (2/3 of reversal dose per hour)
  • Precipitated withdrawal: Severe but not life-threatening. Supportive care.

Observation Period:

  • Short-acting opioid (heroin): 4-6 hours post-naloxone
  • Long-acting/sustained-release: 12-24 hours (consider admission)

Harm Reduction at Discharge:

  • Prescribe naloxone kit (Narcan nasal spray)
  • Offer MAT (medication-assisted treatment): buprenorphine, methadone
  • Connect to addiction medicine resources
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Titrate to Respiration, Not Alertness: Goal is adequate breathing, not fully awake patient. Over-reversal causes severe withdrawal.
  • Fentanyl Needs More Naloxone: Synthetic opioids are highly potent. May need 10Ã— typical naloxone dose.
  • Watch for Re-sedation: Naloxone wears off before most opioids. Observe 4-6h minimum; longer for long-acting opioids.
  • Prescribe Naloxone at Discharge: This saves lives. Ensure patient and family have take-home naloxone.
  • Offer Treatment: Every overdose is an opportunity to offer MAT. ED-initiated buprenorphine improves outcomes.
âš ï¸ ADMIT IF:
  • Long-acting opioid ingestion
  • Recurrent sedation
  • Needed naloxone infusion
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Concern for co-ingestion
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Alert and oriented
  • Adequate respiration off naloxone â‰¥4h
  • Ambulating safely
  • Naloxone kit prescribed
  • Harm reduction resources provided
ðŸ“– Drug Reference: ðŸ’Š Naloxone
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

147. VASCULITIS EMERGENCIES

DAH â€¢ Rapidly Progressive GN â€¢ Pulse Steroids + Cyclophosphamide
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Life-Threatening Manifestations:

  • Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage (DAH): Hemoptysis (may be absent), dyspnea, hypoxia, diffuse infiltrates, dropping hemoglobin. BAL shows progressively bloodier returns.
  • Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN): AKI over days-weeks, hematuria, RBC casts, proteinuria
  • Pulmonary-Renal Syndrome: DAH + RPGN = classic for ANCA vasculitis or anti-GBM disease

Vasculitides Causing Emergencies:

  • GPA (Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis): cANCA/PR3+. Upper airway, lung, kidney involvement.
  • MPA (Microscopic Polyangiitis): pANCA/MPO+. Lung and kidney predominant.
  • Anti-GBM Disease (Goodpasture): Anti-GBM antibodies. Classic pulmonary-renal syndrome.
  • EGPA (Eosinophilic GPA): Asthma, eosinophilia, vasculitis.
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Serologies:

  • ANCA: cANCA/PR3 (GPA), pANCA/MPO (MPA)
  • Anti-GBM antibodies: Goodpasture syndrome
  • ANA, complement: Evaluate for SLE

Urinalysis: RBC casts = glomerulonephritis

Bronchoscopy with BAL: Confirms DAH (serial aliquots increasingly bloody, hemosiderin-laden macrophages)

Renal Biopsy: Pauci-immune crescentic GN (ANCA vasculitis), linear IgG staining (anti-GBM)

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ Autoimmune Labs Reference, ðŸ“š Glomerulonephritis

MANAGEMENT

Pulse Steroids (First-Line):

  • Methylprednisolone: 500-1000 mg IV daily Ã— 3 days
  • Then prednisone 1 mg/kg/day (max 80mg) with taper

Cyclophosphamide or Rituximab:

  • Cyclophosphamide: 15 mg/kg IV q2weeks Ã— 3, then q3weeks OR 2 mg/kg/day PO
  • Rituximab: 375 mg/mÂ² weekly Ã— 4 OR 1g Ã— 2 doses 2 weeks apart. Now considered first-line for many patients (RAVE trial).

Plasmapheresis:

  • Indications: Anti-GBM disease (removes antibody), severe ANCA vasculitis with DAH or dialysis-dependent renal failure
  • PEXIVAS trial: Showed benefit primarily in patients with severe AKI

Supportive Care:

  • Respiratory support (may need intubation for DAH)
  • Renal replacement therapy if needed
  • PJP prophylaxis (TMP-SMX) with immunosuppression
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Pulmonary-Renal Syndrome: DAH + RPGN = think ANCA vasculitis or anti-GBM disease. Requires aggressive immunosuppression.
  • Anti-GBM Needs Plasmapheresis: Unlike ANCA vasculitis where PLEX is selective, anti-GBM disease benefits clearly from antibody removal.
  • Don't Wait for Biopsy: In life-threatening vasculitis, start treatment empirically based on clinical picture and serologies. Biopsy can confirm but shouldn't delay therapy.
  • Rituximab is an Option: RAVE trial showed rituximab non-inferior to cyclophosphamide. Often preferred in younger patients (fertility) and relapsing disease.
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
  • Respiratory failure
  • Dialysis-dependent AKI
  • Need for plasmapheresis
âœ“ TREATMENT GOALS
  • Stabilize respiratory status
  • Preserve/recover renal function
  • Induce remission with immunosuppression
  • Transition to maintenance therapy
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

148. SCLERODERMA RENAL CRISIS

ACE Inhibitors â€¢ Malignant Hypertension â€¢ MAHA
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Life-threatening complication of systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) characterized by acute renal failure and severe hypertension.

Classic Presentation:

  • Severe hypertension: Often >150/90, may be malignant (>180/120 with end-organ damage)
  • Rapidly progressive AKI: Over days
  • MAHA: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (schistocytes, elevated LDH, low haptoglobin)
  • Thrombocytopenia: May mimic TTP/HUS

Associated Features:

  • Hypertensive encephalopathy (headache, confusion, seizures)
  • Flash pulmonary edema
  • Cardiac involvement (pericardial effusion, arrhythmias)

Risk Factors:

  • Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (especially early, rapidly progressive skin disease)
  • Anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies (strongest association)
  • High-dose corticosteroids (may precipitate SRC)
  • First 5 years of disease
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory:

  • BMP (elevated creatinine, hyperkalemia)
  • CBC with smear (MAHA â€“ schistocytes, thrombocytopenia)
  • LDH, haptoglobin, bilirubin (hemolysis)
  • Urinalysis (proteinuria, possible hematuria)
  • Coagulation studies (usually normal, unlike DIC)

Differentiate from TTP:

  • SRC has severe hypertension (TTP usually doesn't)
  • SRC occurs in scleroderma patients
  • ADAMTS13 normal in SRC

Renal Biopsy: Not usually required for diagnosis. Shows thrombotic microangiopathy, "onion-skin" arterial lesions.

Cross-link: ðŸ”¬ BMP Reference, ðŸ“š TTP/HUS

MANAGEMENT
âš ï¸ ACE INHIBITORS ARE LIFE-SAVING

ACE inhibitors are the cornerstone of treatment. Start immediately and titrate aggressively. Do NOT withhold due to elevated creatinine.

ACE Inhibitor Therapy:

  • Captopril: Preferred due to short half-life and rapid titration. Start 6.25-12.5 mg PO q8h, titrate up rapidly (can increase every few hours).
  • Goal: Normalize BP within 72 hours. May need very high doses (up to 450 mg/day).
  • Continue even if dialysis required: Renal recovery can occur weeks-months later if ACE-I continued.

If ACE-I Insufficient for BP Control:

  • Add IV calcium channel blocker (nicardipine) or nitroprusside
  • ARBs can be added but not first-line
  • Avoid beta-blockers (can worsen Raynaud's and peripheral vasoconstriction)

Dialysis:

  • Required in ~50% of patients acutely
  • Continue ACE-I even on dialysis â€“ 30-50% may recover renal function over months

Avoid or Use Cautiously:

  • Corticosteroids: May precipitate SRC. If needed for other scleroderma manifestations, use lowest effective dose.
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • ACE-I is THE Treatment: Before ACE inhibitors, SRC was uniformly fatal. Now ~80% survive. Do not withhold ACE-I due to creatinine â€“ it saves lives.
  • Steroids Can Precipitate SRC: High-dose corticosteroids are a risk factor. Use with extreme caution in scleroderma, especially early diffuse disease.
  • Continue ACE-I on Dialysis: Unlike typical AKI where ACE-I might be held, in SRC continue treatment. Renal recovery possible even after months of dialysis.
  • Normotensive SRC Exists: 10% of SRC patients have normal or only mildly elevated BP. Consider diagnosis in scleroderma patient with unexplained AKI + MAHA.
  • MAHA + Severe HTN + Scleroderma = SRC: This triad is essentially diagnostic. Don't confuse with TTP (no hypertension in TTP).
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Malignant hypertension
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy
  • Flash pulmonary edema
  • Need for IV antihypertensives
  • Severe hyperkalemia
âœ“ TREATMENT GOALS
  • BP normalization within 72h
  • Maximum-tolerated ACE-I dose
  • Dialysis as needed
  • Monitor for renal recovery (may take months)
  • Rheumatology follow-up
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

149. GERD / ESOPHAGITIS

Erosive â€¢ Non-Erosive â€¢ Eosinophilic â€¢ Pill-Induced
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Typical GERD Symptoms: Heartburn (retrosternal burning, worse post-prandial/supine), regurgitation (sour/bitter taste), dysphagia. Worse with large meals, fatty/spicy food, alcohol, caffeine, chocolate, lying down after eating

Atypical/Extraesophageal: Chronic cough (especially nocturnal), hoarseness/laryngitis, asthma exacerbation, dental erosions, globus sensation, chest pain (can mimic ACS)

Alarm Features (Need EGD): Dysphagia (progressive), odynophagia, weight loss, GI bleeding/anemia, persistent vomiting, age >60 with new symptoms, family history esophageal/gastric cancer

Types of Esophagitis:

  • Erosive (GERD): Mucosal breaks visible on EGD. LA Classification A-D (A = <5mm, D = >75% circumference)
  • Non-Erosive Reflux Disease (NERD): Symptoms but normal EGD. 60% of GERD patients. pH testing confirms
  • Eosinophilic Esophagitis (EoE): Young men, atopy history, solid food dysphagia, food impaction. EGD: rings, furrows, strictures. Bx: >15 eos/hpf
  • Pill Esophagitis: NSAIDs, doxycycline, bisphosphonates, KCl, iron. Sharp odynophagia, discrete ulcer at aortic arch level
  • Infectious: Candida (immunocompromised, white plaques), HSV (punched-out ulcers), CMV (large shallow ulcers)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical Diagnosis: Typical symptoms (heartburn + regurgitation) without alarm features â†’ empiric PPI trial (8 weeks). If responds, confirms GERD

EGD Indications: Alarm features, refractory to PPI (8 weeks bid), atypical symptoms, Barrett's surveillance, pre-fundoplication

pH/Impedance Testing: Refractory symptoms, normal EGD, pre-surgical evaluation. Off PPI Ã— 7 days for diagnosis, on PPI if evaluating refractory symptoms

Esophageal Manometry: Pre-fundoplication (rule out motility disorder), evaluate dysphagia if EGD negative

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Lifestyle Modifications:

  • Weight loss (if overweight - most effective lifestyle change)
  • Elevate head of bed 6-8 inches (blocks, not pillows)
  • Avoid eating 2-3 hours before bedtime
  • Avoid triggers: fatty foods, chocolate, caffeine, alcohol, mint, citrus, tomatoes
  • Stop smoking
  • Avoid tight-fitting clothes

Pharmacotherapy:

  • PPI (First-Line): Omeprazole 20mg, Pantoprazole 40mg, Esomeprazole 20-40mg daily. Take 30-60 min before breakfast. 8-week course for healing
  • Refractory: Increase to BID dosing (before breakfast AND dinner). If still refractory, confirm diagnosis with pH testing
  • H2 Blockers: Famotidine 20mg BID. Less effective than PPI. Use for mild/intermittent symptoms or nocturnal breakthrough
  • Antacids/Alginates: PRN for breakthrough. Calcium carbonate, Gaviscon (alginate forms raft)
  • Maintenance: Lowest effective PPI dose. Step-down to H2 blocker or on-demand PPI if controlled

PPI Long-Term Risks (generally overstated but consider): C. diff, pneumonia, hypomagnesemia, B12 deficiency, hip fractures (osteoporosis), CKD. Benefits usually outweigh risks. Don't stop for fear of side effects if truly needed

Surgical: Fundoplication (Nissen) if: refractory despite max medical therapy, intolerant of PPIs, large hiatal hernia, regurgitation-predominant. Requires manometry pre-op

Specific Esophagitis Treatment:

  • Eosinophilic: PPI trial first (PPI-responsive EoE), then swallowed fluticasone or budesonide slurry, elimination diet, dilation if stricture
  • Pill: Stop offending med, liquid alternatives, take pills with full glass water, stay upright 30 min
  • Candida: Fluconazole 200mg day 1, then 100mg Ã— 14 days
  • HSV: Acyclovir 400mg 5Ã—/day Ã— 14-21 days (or valacyclovir)
  • CMV: Ganciclovir or valganciclovir Ã— 3-6 weeks
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Upper GI bleeding with hemodynamic instability
  • Esophageal perforation (Boerhaave's - post-vomiting chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema)
  • Complete esophageal obstruction/food impaction with respiratory compromise
  • Severe infectious esophagitis with sepsis
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Tolerating oral intake
  • Pain controlled
  • No signs of bleeding or perforation
  • On appropriate PPI regimen
  • EGD performed or scheduled if alarm features
  • Lifestyle modifications reviewed
  • GI follow-up if needed
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Chest pain workup: Always rule out cardiac cause first. GERD is diagnosis of exclusion for chest pain
  • PPI timing matters: Take 30-60 min before meal for maximum efficacy (needs acid to activate)
  • NERD is common: 60% have symptoms with normal EGD. pH testing confirms. May respond less well to PPI
  • Young man with food impaction = EoE: Think eosinophilic esophagitis. Get biopsies even if EGD looks normal
  • Doxycycline esophagitis: Always take with full glass of water, stay upright. Mid-esophagus (aortic arch level)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

150. BARRETT'S ESOPHAGUS

Intestinal Metaplasia â€¢ Dysplasia â€¢ Cancer Surveillance
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Replacement of normal squamous esophageal epithelium with intestinal-type columnar epithelium (intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells). Complication of chronic GERD. Premalignant - risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma

Risk Factors: Chronic GERD (>5 years), male sex (8:1), age >50, Caucasian, obesity (central), smoking, family history Barrett's/esophageal cancer, hiatal hernia

Presentation: Often asymptomatic (GERD symptoms may actually improve as metaplastic epithelium is less sensitive). Found incidentally on EGD for GERD evaluation

Cancer Risk: 0.5% per year progression to adenocarcinoma (without dysplasia). Higher with dysplasia. Esophageal adenocarcinoma has increased 6-fold in past 40 years

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

EGD Findings: Salmon-colored mucosa extending above GE junction (replacing normal pale squamous mucosa). Described by length: short-segment (<3cm) vs long-segment (â‰¥3cm). Prague classification: C (circumferential) and M (maximum extent)

Histology (Required for Diagnosis): Intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells. Must have goblet cells to diagnose Barrett's in US (European criteria differ)

Biopsy Protocol: Seattle protocol - 4-quadrant biopsies every 1-2cm throughout Barrett's segment + any visible lesions. Look for dysplasia

Dysplasia Classification:

  • No dysplasia: Intestinal metaplasia only. Lowest risk
  • Indefinite for dysplasia: Inflammation makes interpretation difficult. Repeat after aggressive PPI
  • Low-grade dysplasia (LGD): Confirmed by expert GI pathologist. 0.5-1% annual progression to cancer
  • High-grade dysplasia (HGD): 6-19% annual progression to cancer. Often has occult cancer

Screening Recommendations: Consider one-time screening EGD in patients with chronic GERD (>5 years) AND multiple risk factors (male, age >50, white, obesity, smoking, family history). Not recommended for general population

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

All Barrett's Patients:

  • PPI daily (reduces progression, even if asymptomatic)
  • Lifestyle modifications (weight loss, smoking cessation)
  • Surveillance EGD per guidelines

Surveillance Intervals:

  • No dysplasia: EGD every 3-5 years (if segment <3cm and no risk factors, can extend to 5 years)
  • Indefinite for dysplasia: Optimize PPI, repeat EGD in 3-6 months
  • Low-grade dysplasia: Confirm with expert pathologist. Options: surveillance every 6-12 months OR endoscopic eradication therapy (preferred if confirmed LGD)
  • High-grade dysplasia: Endoscopic eradication therapy (radiofrequency ablation Â± EMR). Esophagectomy rarely needed now

Endoscopic Eradication Therapy:

  • Endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR): For visible lesions, nodules. Removes tissue for staging
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA): For flat dysplasia/Barrett's. Burns away metaplastic epithelium. Multiple sessions needed. 90%+ eradication rates
  • Cryotherapy: Alternative ablation technique
  • Continue PPI after ablation. Surveillance continues (recurrence possible)

Surgery (Esophagectomy): Reserved for: invasive cancer, failed endoscopic therapy, patient preference. High morbidity (leak, stricture, mortality 2-5% at high-volume centers)

âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Post-procedure perforation or bleeding
  • Esophageal cancer with obstruction or bleeding
  • Post-esophagectomy complications (anastomotic leak, respiratory failure)
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Tolerating diet after EGD/ablation
  • No signs of perforation or bleeding
  • On daily PPI
  • Surveillance interval established
  • GI follow-up scheduled
  • Pathology results reviewed and plan communicated
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Barrett's doesn't reverse with PPI: Metaplasia persists. PPI reduces further damage and may reduce dysplasia/cancer progression
  • Long-segment = higher risk: â‰¥3cm has higher cancer risk than short-segment
  • Symptoms may improve: Metaplastic epithelium is less acid-sensitive. Fewer symptoms â‰  less disease
  • Expert pathology confirmation: Dysplasia diagnosis should be confirmed by second expert GI pathologist before treatment decisions
  • RFA changed management: Endoscopic therapy now standard for dysplasia. Esophagectomy rarely needed
  • Surveillance continues after ablation: Recurrence can occur. Lifelong follow-up needed
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

151. ESOPHAGEAL SPASM / MOTILITY DISORDERS

DES â€¢ Jackhammer â€¢ Achalasia â€¢ Nutcracker
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

General Features: Chest pain (can be severe, mimic angina), dysphagia (to solids AND liquids - vs mechanical obstruction which is solids first), odynophagia. Symptoms often intermittent, triggered by stress, hot/cold foods

Specific Disorders:

  • Diffuse Esophageal Spasm (DES): Uncoordinated, simultaneous contractions. Intermittent dysphagia + chest pain. "Corkscrew esophagus" on barium swallow. Manometry: â‰¥20% premature (simultaneous) contractions
  • Hypercontractile Esophagus (Jackhammer): Extremely high-amplitude contractions. Severe chest pain. Manometry: distal contractile integral (DCI) >8000 mmHgÂ·sÂ·cm
  • Achalasia: Failure of LES relaxation + absent peristalsis. Progressive dysphagia (solids AND liquids), regurgitation of undigested food, weight loss, aspiration. "Bird's beak" on barium swallow. Manometry: absent peristalsis + impaired LES relaxation. EGD to rule out pseudoachalasia (GE junction cancer)
  • Ineffective Esophageal Motility: Weak contractions. Often with GERD. Dysphagia, heartburn

Important DDx: Always rule out cardiac chest pain first! Also consider: GERD, eosinophilic esophagitis, esophageal cancer, stricture

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Step 1 - Rule Out Cardiac: ECG, troponin if acute chest pain. Stress test/cath if indicated. Esophageal spasm is diagnosis of exclusion for chest pain

Step 2 - EGD: Rule out mechanical obstruction, stricture, eosinophilic esophagitis, cancer (especially at GE junction for achalasia symptoms - pseudoachalasia)

Step 3 - Barium Swallow: Corkscrew esophagus (DES), bird's beak with dilated proximal esophagus (achalasia), stricture

Step 4 - High-Resolution Manometry (Gold Standard): Defines specific motility disorder per Chicago Classification. Required before surgical intervention

Manometry Findings:

  • Achalasia Type I: No esophageal pressurization, absent peristalsis
  • Achalasia Type II: Panesophageal pressurization (best prognosis for treatment)
  • Achalasia Type III: Spastic contractions (worst prognosis)
  • DES: â‰¥20% premature contractions, normal LES relaxation
  • Jackhammer: DCI >8000 mmHgÂ·sÂ·cm in â‰¥20% of swallows
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm / Jackhammer:

  • First-line: Smooth muscle relaxants - nitrates (isosorbide dinitrate 10-20mg before meals), calcium channel blockers (diltiazem 60-90mg TID or nifedipine 10-30mg TID)
  • Second-line: Tricyclic antidepressants (imipramine 25-50mg qhs) - visceral pain modulation
  • PPI trial: Many have coexisting GERD
  • Botox injection: Temporary relief. Effect wanes in 6-12 months
  • POEM (peroral endoscopic myotomy): For refractory cases. Emerging therapy

Achalasia (Definitive Treatment Required):

  • Pneumatic dilation: 30-40mm balloon at LES. 60-90% effective. Risk perforation 2-5%. May need repeat
  • Heller myotomy (laparoscopic): Surgical division of LES muscle. 90% effective. Add partial fundoplication (Dor/Toupet) to prevent reflux. Durable
  • POEM: Endoscopic myotomy. Comparable efficacy to Heller. Higher GERD rates post-procedure. Growing experience
  • Botox injection: Temporary (3-12 months). Reserve for poor surgical candidates
  • Medical therapy (nitrates/CCB): Least effective. Bridge to definitive therapy or if not surgical candidate

Treatment Selection (Achalasia): Type II responds best to all treatments. Young patients â†’ Heller myotomy (most durable). Older/comorbid â†’ pneumatic dilation or POEM. Poor surgical candidates â†’ Botox or medical

âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Esophageal perforation (post-dilation or spontaneous)
  • Aspiration pneumonia with respiratory failure
  • Severe dehydration/malnutrition from inability to eat
  • Chest pain with hemodynamic instability (rule out cardiac)
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Tolerating oral intake
  • Chest pain controlled
  • Cardiac causes excluded
  • Treatment plan established (medications or procedure scheduled)
  • No signs of perforation post-procedure
  • GI follow-up arranged
  • Dietary modifications reviewed (small bites, upright eating, avoid triggers)
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Dysphagia to solids AND liquids = motility: Mechanical obstruction (stricture, cancer) â†’ solids first, then liquids. Motility â†’ both from start
  • Rule out cardiac first: Esophageal spasm can perfectly mimic angina. Even responds to nitrates! Always exclude cardiac before diagnosing
  • Pseudoachalasia: GE junction cancer mimics achalasia. EGD with biopsies mandatory. Older patient, rapid symptom onset, significant weight loss = red flags
  • Achalasia increases cancer risk: 3% lifetime risk of squamous cell carcinoma. Some recommend surveillance EGD
  • Type II achalasia = best prognosis: Responds well to all treatments. Type III (spastic) = worst outcomes
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

152. COSTOCHONDRITIS / CHEST WALL PAIN

Tietze Syndrome â€¢ Musculoskeletal Chest Pain
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Costochondritis: Inflammation of costochondral junctions (where ribs meet cartilage). Sharp, localized chest pain. Reproducible with palpation. Worse with movement, deep breathing, coughing. No swelling. Most common at ribs 2-5. Often bilateral

Tietze Syndrome: Similar to costochondritis BUT with visible swelling at costochondral junction. Usually single site, ribs 2-3. Younger patients. Less common

Risk Factors/Triggers: Recent upper respiratory infection (repetitive coughing), physical strain, repetitive activities, trauma, recent exercise, fibromyalgia, inflammatory arthritis

Key Features:

  • Reproducible tenderness on palpation (most important finding)
  • Sharp or pressure-like pain
  • Worse with movement, twisting, deep breathing
  • May radiate to arm or back
  • Duration: weeks to months (often chronic/recurrent)

Differential Diagnosis (Must Exclude):

  • Cardiac: ACS, pericarditis, aortic dissection
  • Pulmonary: PE, pneumonia, pneumothorax, pleuritis
  • GI: GERD, esophageal spasm, PUD
  • Other MSK: Rib fracture, muscle strain, herpes zoster (pre-rash), xiphodynia, slipping rib syndrome
  • Malignancy: Metastatic disease to ribs/sternum
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical Diagnosis: Costochondritis is a clinical diagnosis of exclusion. Key: reproducible tenderness on palpation + no concerning features

When to Test:

  • ECG: If ANY cardiac concern (risk factors, exertional, associated symptoms). Low threshold
  • Troponin: If ACS concern
  • CXR: If pulmonary symptoms, trauma, concern for pneumothorax
  • D-dimer/CTPA: If PE concern (Wells score, risk factors)
  • CT chest/MRI: If concern for malignancy, persistent unexplained pain
  • Labs (ESR, CRP): If inflammatory arthritis suspected or Tietze syndrome

Red Flags Requiring Further Workup:

  • Exertional chest pain
  • Associated dyspnea, diaphoresis, nausea
  • Cardiac risk factors (DM, HTN, smoking, family history, hyperlipidemia)
  • Age >40 with new chest pain
  • Abnormal vital signs
  • Radiation to jaw/arm
  • Recent immobilization/surgery (PE risk)
  • Fever, weight loss (malignancy, infection)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

First-Line (Conservative):

  • NSAIDs: Ibuprofen 400-800mg TID or Naproxen 500mg BID Ã— 1-2 weeks. Most effective
  • Topical NSAIDs: Diclofenac gel to affected area TID-QID. Fewer systemic side effects
  • Heat/Ice: Local application for comfort
  • Rest: Avoid aggravating activities, repetitive movements
  • Acetaminophen: If NSAIDs contraindicated

Second-Line (Refractory):

  • Local corticosteroid injection: Triamcinolone 20-40mg + lidocaine into costochondral junction. Consider if failed NSAIDs Ã— 2-4 weeks
  • Physical therapy: Stretching exercises, posture correction
  • Intercostal nerve block: For severe refractory cases

Patient Education:

  • Benign condition, not dangerous
  • May take weeks to months to resolve
  • Can be recurrent
  • Activity modification during flares
  • Return precautions: exertional pain, dyspnea, radiation, new symptoms
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Not applicable - costochondritis does not require ICU
  • If patient has costochondritis AND develops cardiac symptoms, treat as ACS until proven otherwise
  • Misdiagnosis concern: Always reconsider if patient deteriorates or develops new symptoms
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Cardiac causes confidently excluded
  • Reproducible tenderness on exam
  • No red flag symptoms
  • Pain controlled with oral medications
  • Clear return precautions provided
  • PCP follow-up if symptoms persist >2-4 weeks
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Reproducible = reassuring: Pain reproduced by palpation strongly suggests MSK cause. BUT can coexist with cardiac disease - still need to exclude
  • Costochondritis is diagnosis of exclusion: Rule out life-threatening causes first, especially in patients with risk factors
  • Tietze has swelling: Visible/palpable swelling at costochondral junction. Costochondritis = tenderness without swelling
  • Can mimic ACS: Chest pain, radiation to arm, worse with exertion (if using arms). Low threshold to evaluate cardiac
  • Duration weeks-months: Set expectations. Not a quick fix. Recurrence common
  • NSAIDs work: First-line, most effective. Try for at least 1-2 weeks before declaring failure
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

153. UROSEPSIS

Sepsis from Urinary Source â€¢ UTI with SIRS/Organ Dysfunction
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Sepsis (life-threatening organ dysfunction from dysregulated host response) caused by urinary tract infection. 20-30% of all sepsis cases. Second most common source after pneumonia

Risk Factors:

  • Urinary obstruction (kidney stones, BPH, stricture, tumor) - MOST IMPORTANT
  • Indwelling urinary catheter
  • Recent urologic procedure/instrumentation
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Immunosuppression
  • Neurogenic bladder
  • Pregnancy
  • Elderly, nursing home residents
  • Anatomic abnormalities

Presentation:

  • Urinary symptoms: Dysuria, frequency, urgency, suprapubic pain, flank pain (pyelonephritis), CVA tenderness, hematuria. May be absent in elderly/catheterized
  • Sepsis features: Fever (or hypothermia), tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, altered mental status
  • Severe sepsis/Septic shock: Hypotension (SBP <90 or MAP <65) refractory to fluids, lactate >2 mmol/L, organ dysfunction (AKI, coagulopathy, altered mental status)

Common Organisms:

  • E. coli: Most common (50-80%)
  • Klebsiella, Proteus, Enterobacter: Other gram-negatives
  • Pseudomonas: Healthcare-associated, catheter-related
  • Enterococcus: Especially with instrumentation
  • Candida: Immunocompromised, prolonged antibiotics, catheters
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory:

  • Urinalysis: Pyuria (WBC), bacteriuria, nitrites (gram-negatives), leukocyte esterase. May be absent early
  • Urine culture: BEFORE antibiotics (but don't delay antibiotics). >10âµ CFU/mL significant (lower threshold with catheter or symptoms)
  • Blood cultures: Ã— 2 sets before antibiotics. Positive in 20-40% of pyelonephritis, higher in urosepsis
  • CBC: Leukocytosis (or leukopenia = worse prognosis), left shift, thrombocytopenia (DIC)
  • BMP: AKI (Cr elevation), electrolyte abnormalities
  • Lactate: >2 mmol/L indicates tissue hypoperfusion. Prognostic. Trend to assess response
  • Procalcitonin: Elevated in bacterial sepsis. Can guide antibiotic duration
  • Coagulation: PT/INR, fibrinogen, D-dimer if DIC concern

Imaging:

  • CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast: First-line if obstruction suspected. Identifies hydronephrosis, stones, abscess, emphysematous pyelonephritis
  • Renal ultrasound: If CT contraindicated (contrast allergy, AKI). Good for hydronephrosis, less sensitive for stones/abscess
  • Urgent imaging indications: Not responding to antibiotics 48-72hr, concern for obstruction, abscess, emphysematous infection
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Hour-1 Bundle (Sepsis):

  • Measure lactate - remeasure if initial >2
  • Blood cultures before antibiotics
  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics within 1 hour
  • IV crystalloid 30 mL/kg for hypotension or lactate â‰¥4
  • Vasopressors if hypotensive despite fluids (target MAP â‰¥65)

Empiric Antibiotics (Start Broad, Narrow Based on Culture):

  • Community-acquired, no risk factors: Ceftriaxone 1g IV daily OR Fluoroquinolone (ciprofloxacin 400mg IV q12h or levofloxacin 750mg IV daily) - check local resistance patterns
  • Healthcare-associated or resistant organism risk: Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h OR Cefepime 2g IV q8h OR Meropenem 1g IV q8h (if ESBL concern)
  • Pseudomonas risk (catheter, recent hospitalization, structural abnormality): Antipseudomonal coverage - pip-tazo, cefepime, or meropenem
  • MRSA risk (rare in UTI): Add vancomycin
  • Enterococcus concern: Ampicillin 2g IV q4h (if susceptible) or vancomycin

Source Control (CRITICAL):

  • Obstruction: Urgent decompression within 24 hours. Options: percutaneous nephrostomy (IR) or ureteral stent (urology). Antibiotics alone will fail
  • Abscess: Drainage (percutaneous or surgical) if >3-5 cm or not responding to antibiotics
  • Emphysematous pyelonephritis: Life-threatening. Drainage Â± nephrectomy. High mortality
  • Infected catheter: Replace or remove if possible

Duration:

  • Uncomplicated pyelonephritis: 7-14 days (can be as short as 5-7 days with fluoroquinolones if responding)
  • Complicated UTI/urosepsis: 10-14 days
  • Abscess, prostatitis: 4-6 weeks
  • Procalcitonin-guided discontinuation if available
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Septic shock (hypotension despite adequate fluid resuscitation requiring vasopressors)
  • Lactate >4 mmol/L or rising despite treatment
  • Respiratory failure requiring intubation
  • Multi-organ dysfunction (AKI + coagulopathy + encephalopathy)
  • Emphysematous pyelonephritis or necrotizing infection
  • Failure to respond to initial resuscitation
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Afebrile >24-48 hours
  • Hemodynamically stable off vasopressors
  • Lactate normalized
  • WBC normalizing
  • Tolerating oral antibiotics and fluids
  • Source control achieved (obstruction relieved, abscess drained)
  • Creatinine at baseline or improving
  • Culture sensitivities back, on appropriate narrow-spectrum oral antibiotic
  • Urology follow-up if structural abnormality or stones
  • Duration of antibiotics clearly documented
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Obstruction = emergency: Infected, obstructed kidney is urologic emergency. Antibiotics won't penetrate. Needs drainage within 24hr
  • E. coli is king: Causes 50-80% of UTI/urosepsis. But consider Pseudomonas, ESBL if healthcare-associated
  • Catheter = think Pseudomonas and Enterococcus: Broader coverage needed. Remove/replace catheter
  • CT if not improving at 48-72hr: Look for abscess, obstruction, emphysematous pyelonephritis
  • Emphysematous = high mortality: Gas in renal parenchyma on CT. Usually diabetics. Aggressive drainage, may need nephrectomy
  • Procalcitonin guides duration: Can shorten antibiotic course safely. Trend to assess response
  • Better prognosis than other sepsis: Urosepsis generally has lower mortality than pneumonia-related sepsis (with appropriate source control)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

154. ACUTE RESPIRATORY FAILURE

Type 1 (Hypoxic) â€¢ Type 2 (Hypercapnic) â€¢ Mixed â€¢ Oxygen Delivery â€¢ Ventilation
CLASSIFICATION

Definition: Inability of the respiratory system to meet the metabolic demands of the body â€” failure to oxygenate (Type 1), failure to ventilate (Type 2), or both (Mixed)

Type 1 â€” Hypoxic Respiratory Failure:

  • Definition: PaO2 <60 mmHg on room air (or P/F ratio <300 on supplemental O2)
  • Mechanism: V/Q mismatch, shunt, diffusion impairment, low FiO2
  • PaCO2: Normal or LOW (patient hyperventilating to compensate)
  • A-a Gradient: ELEVATED (>15 mmHg) â€” problem is at alveolar-capillary interface
  • Common Causes: Pneumonia, ARDS, pulmonary edema (cardiogenic), PE, ILD, atelectasis

Type 2 â€” Hypercapnic Respiratory Failure:

  • Definition: PaCO2 >45 mmHg with respiratory acidosis (pH <7.35)
  • Mechanism: Alveolar hypoventilation â€” inadequate minute ventilation
  • PaO2: May be low (from hypoventilation) but responds well to supplemental O2
  • A-a Gradient: Often NORMAL â€” lungs are fine, ventilation is the problem
  • Common Causes: COPD exacerbation, opioid overdose, neuromuscular disease (GBS, MG), obesity hypoventilation, severe asthma
  • â†’ See Condition 50: Acute Hypercapnic Respiratory Failure for detailed management

Mixed (Type 1 + Type 2):

  • Definition: Both hypoxemia AND hypercapnia
  • Mechanism: Severe parenchymal disease with respiratory muscle fatigue
  • Common Causes: Severe COPD with pneumonia, late-stage ARDS, cardiogenic shock with pulmonary edema, severe asthma with fatigue
  • Prognosis: Worse than isolated Type 1 or Type 2 â€” often indicates impending respiratory arrest
RAPID ASSESSMENT

ABCs + Vital Signs:

  • Airway: Patent? Secretions? Stridor? Can patient speak in full sentences?
  • Breathing: RR (>30 = severe), accessory muscle use, paradoxical breathing, SpO2
  • Circulation: HR, BP (hypotension = shock, may need intubation for resuscitation)
  • Disability: Mental status (confusion, agitation, somnolence = ominous)

Immediate Red Flags (Consider Immediate Intubation):

  • Apnea or agonal breathing
  • Severe altered mental status / inability to protect airway
  • Refractory hypoxemia (SpO2 <88% despite high-flow O2)
  • Hemodynamic instability / cardiac arrest
  • Severe respiratory acidosis (pH <7.20) with declining mental status
