  • Respiratory muscle fatigue (paradoxical breathing, declining RR with worsening status)

ABG Interpretation:

  • P/F Ratio (PaO2 Ã· FiO2):
    • Normal: >400
    • Mild impairment: 300-400
    • Moderate (mild ARDS): 200-300
    • Severe (moderate ARDS): 100-200
    • Very severe (severe ARDS): <100
  • A-a Gradient: PAO2 - PaO2, where PAO2 = (FiO2 Ã— 713) - (PaCO2 Ã· 0.8)
    • Normal: <15 mmHg (or Age/4 + 4)
    • Elevated = V/Q mismatch, shunt, diffusion defect (parenchymal disease)
    • Normal = pure hypoventilation (CNS, neuromuscular, chest wall)
  • Acute vs Chronic Respiratory Acidosis:
    • Acute: â†‘ HCO3 1 mEq/L per 10 mmHg â†‘ PaCO2
    • Chronic: â†‘ HCO3 3.5 mEq/L per 10 mmHg â†‘ PaCO2
OXYGEN DELIVERY LADDER

Escalate based on response. Don't delay escalation if patient deteriorating.

1. Nasal Cannula (NC):

  • Flow: 1-6 L/min â†’ ~24-44% FiO2 (variable, depends on patient's minute ventilation)
  • Use: Mild hypoxemia, stable patients
  • Limitation: FiO2 unreliable, max ~44% even at 6L

2. Simple Face Mask:

  • Flow: 6-10 L/min â†’ ~35-55% FiO2
  • Use: Moderate hypoxemia, short-term (procedures, transport)
  • Limitation: Must run â‰¥5 L/min to avoid CO2 rebreathing

3. Venturi Mask:

  • Flow: Set to specific FiO2 (24%, 28%, 31%, 35%, 40%, 50%)
  • Use: COPD / chronic CO2 retainers â€” need precise, controlled FiO2
  • Advantage: Reliable FiO2 regardless of patient's breathing pattern

4. Non-Rebreather Mask (NRB):

  • Flow: 10-15 L/min â†’ ~60-90% FiO2
  • Use: Severe hypoxemia, CO poisoning, trauma
  • Limitation: Max FiO2 ~90% (not truly 100%), uncomfortable for prolonged use

5. High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC):

  • Flow: 20-60 L/min, FiO2 21-100%, heated/humidified
  • Mechanism: Matches/exceeds patient's inspiratory flow â†’ reliable FiO2, PEEP effect (2-5 cm H2O), dead space washout, reduced work of breathing
  • Use: Moderate-severe hypoxemia (P/F 100-300), post-extubation, may avoid intubation in some patients
  • Starting Settings: Flow 40-60 L/min, FiO2 titrate to SpO2 >92%
  • Evidence: FLORALI trial â€” reduced intubation vs NRB in hypoxic respiratory failure; ROX index predicts failure (SpO2/FiO2 Ã· RR; <4.88 at 12h = high failure risk)
  • Advantages over NIPPV: Better tolerated, allows eating/speaking, less claustrophobia
  • When to escalate: Persistent hypoxemia, rising FiO2 requirements, RR >30, ROX <4.88

6. Non-Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NIPPV):

  • CPAP: Single pressure throughout cycle (e.g., 5-10 cm H2O)
    • Best for: Cardiogenic pulmonary edema (reduces preload/afterload), OSA
  • BiPAP: IPAP (inspiratory) + EPAP (expiratory) â€” provides pressure support
    • Best for: Hypercapnic failure (COPD), provides ventilatory assistance
    • Starting settings: IPAP 10-12, EPAP 5, FiO2 to SpO2 >88-92%
    • Titrate: â†‘ IPAP to improve ventilation (â†“ CO2), â†‘ EPAP to improve oxygenation
  • Contraindications: Inability to protect airway, AMS (GCS <10), hemodynamic instability, facial trauma, recent upper GI surgery, copious secretions, uncooperative patient
  • Failure Signs: Worsening pH/PaCO2, declining mental status, persistent hypoxemia after 1-2 hours â†’ intubate

7. Intubation / Mechanical Ventilation:

  • See "Intubation Indications" and "Initial Vent Settings" below
INTUBATION

Indications (SOAP ME):

  • Secretions â€” unable to clear, aspiration risk
  • Oxygenation failure â€” refractory hypoxemia despite max non-invasive support
  • Airway protection â€” GCS â‰¤8, loss of gag/cough, inability to protect from aspiration
  • Patient trajectory â€” worsening despite treatment, impending arrest
  • Mechanical ventilation needed â€” severe acidosis, fatigue, anticipated prolonged failure
  • Expected course â€” OR, procedures, transport of unstable patient

Clinical Triggers:

  • Respiratory rate >35-40/min with distress
  • SpO2 <88% on maximal non-invasive O2
  • PaO2 <60 mmHg on FiO2 >0.6
  • PaCO2 >50 with pH <7.25 and declining mental status
  • Signs of fatigue: paradoxical breathing, decreasing RR with worsening mental status
  • "Intubate the trajectory, not the number" â€” if rapidly worsening, don't wait

Pre-Intubation Checklist:

  • Prepare: Suction, BVM, ETT (7.0-8.0), laryngoscope, bougie, video laryngoscope if available
  • Preoxygenate: 3-5 min NRB or HFNC at 100% (denitrogenate), apneic oxygenation during attempt
  • Push-dose pressors: Have phenylephrine/epinephrine ready for post-induction hypotension
  • RSI Medications: Induction (etomidate, ketamine, propofol) + paralytic (succinylcholine or rocuronium)
  • Position: Sniffing position, ramped if obese
  • Plan B: Supraglottic airway (LMA), surgical airway equipment available

Initial Ventilator Settings (Post-Intubation):

  • Mode: Volume-Assist Control (AC/VC) or Pressure-Assist Control (AC/PC)
  • Tidal Volume: 6-8 mL/kg IBW (lung-protective; use 6 mL/kg if ARDS)
    • IBW (kg): Males = 50 + 2.3 Ã— (height in inches - 60); Females = 45.5 + 2.3 Ã— (height in inches - 60)
  • Respiratory Rate: 14-20/min (adjust for pH/PaCO2)
  • FiO2: Start 100%, wean to SpO2 92-96% (88-92% if COPD)
  • PEEP: Start 5 cm H2O, increase if hypoxemia persists (ARDS may need 10-20)
  • Plateau Pressure Goal: <30 cm H2O (to avoid barotrauma)

Post-Intubation:

  • Confirm placement: End-tidal CO2 (gold standard), bilateral breath sounds, CXR
  • Secure tube, note depth at teeth (typically 21-23 cm)
  • Sedation: Propofol or fentanyl/midazolam drip (target RASS -2 to 0)
  • ABG in 30-60 min, adjust vent settings
  • OG/NG tube, DVT prophylaxis, stress ulcer prophylaxis, HOB 30-45Â°
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Immediate (Bedside):

  • ABG: Defines type (hypoxic vs hypercapnic vs mixed), severity, acid-base status
  • CXR (portable): Infiltrates (pneumonia, ARDS, edema), effusion, pneumothorax, cardiomegaly
  • ECG: Ischemia, arrhythmia, RV strain (PE)
  • Bedside Echo (POCUS): LV function, RV dilation (PE), pericardial effusion, IVC for volume status

Laboratory:

  • CBC: Anemia (reduced O2 carrying capacity), leukocytosis (infection)
  • BMP: Metabolic derangements, renal function
  • BNP/NT-proBNP: Elevated in cardiogenic pulmonary edema (>500 pg/mL suggestive)
  • Troponin: ACS, PE with RV strain, demand ischemia
  • Lactate: Tissue hypoxia, shock
  • Procalcitonin: Bacterial infection (pneumonia, sepsis)
  • D-dimer: If PE suspected (use Wells score first)

Advanced Imaging:

  • CT Chest: Characterize infiltrates, ILD, malignancy
  • CTPA: If PE suspected
  • CT Pulmonary Angiogram: PE diagnosis
  • Formal Echo: Detailed cardiac assessment if cardiogenic cause suspected

Etiology-Based Workup:

Clinical Picture Consider Key Tests
Fever + productive cough + infiltrate Pneumonia Sputum Cx, blood Cx, procalcitonin, urine Legionella/pneumococcal Ag
Orthopnea + JVD + crackles + edema CHF / Pulmonary Edema BNP, TTE, CXR (cephalization, Kerley B lines)
Pleuritic CP + hypoxia out of proportion to CXR PE D-dimer, CTPA, RV strain on echo/ECG
Bilateral infiltrates + known risk factor + P/F <300 ARDS Berlin criteria, echo to exclude cardiogenic cause
COPD history + wheezing + â†‘ PaCO2 COPD Exacerbation ABG, CXR, sputum if purulent
Wheezing + air trapping + young patient Asthma Exacerbation Peak flow, ABG if severe
Pinpoint pupils + â†“RR + â†‘ PaCO2 Opioid Overdose Tox screen, response to naloxone
Ascending weakness + â†“ NIF GBS / Neuromuscular NIF, VC, LP, EMG/NCS
Absent breath sounds + tracheal deviation Tension Pneumothorax Clinical diagnosis â†’ needle decompression before CXR
TREATMENT BY ETIOLOGY (QUICK REFERENCE)

All patients: Supplemental O2 to target SpO2 (92-96% most; 88-92% COPD), treat underlying cause, monitor closely for deterioration

  • Pneumonia: Antibiotics (CAP vs HAP/VAP coverage), supportive care â†’ CAP, HAP/VAP
  • CHF / Pulmonary Edema: Diuresis (furosemide), CPAP/BiPAP, nitrates if hypertensive, reduce afterload â†’ Heart Failure
  • PE: Anticoagulation, consider thrombolytics if massive/submassive â†’ PE
  • ARDS: Lung-protective ventilation (6 mL/kg, Pplat <30), prone positioning, conservative fluids â†’ ARDS
  • COPD Exacerbation: Bronchodilators, steroids, BiPAP, antibiotics if purulent sputum â†’ COPD, Hypercapnic Failure
  • Asthma: Bronchodilators, steroids, magnesium if severe â†’ Asthma
  • Opioid Overdose: Naloxone, support ventilation â†’ Opioid Overdose
  • Pneumothorax: Needle decompression (tension) or chest tube â†’ Pneumothorax
  • Neuromuscular: IVIG/PLEX (GBS, MG crisis), intubation often needed â†’ GBS, MG Crisis
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Need for HFNC, NIPPV, or mechanical ventilation
  • P/F ratio <200 (moderate-severe hypoxemia)
  • Respiratory acidosis with pH <7.30
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Altered mental status from respiratory failure
  • High likelihood of deterioration / need for close monitoring
  • Requiring FiO2 >50% to maintain adequate SpO2
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • SpO2 >92% on â‰¤2L NC (or baseline O2 requirement)
  • Respiratory rate <24, no accessory muscle use
  • Underlying cause treated or controlled
  • ABG normalized or at baseline (chronic CO2 retainers)
  • Off NIPPV/HFNC for >24 hours
  • Able to ambulate without significant desaturation
  • Home O2 arranged if needed
  • Pulmonary/cardiology follow-up as appropriate
  • Clear return precautions (worsening dyspnea, chest pain, fever)
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Intubate the trajectory: If patient is rapidly deteriorating, don't wait for a specific number. A patient who "looks bad" and is getting worse needs the tube before they arrest.
  • HFNC is not just "fancy nasal cannula": It delivers reliable FiO2, provides PEEP effect (2-5 cm H2O), washes out dead space, and reduces work of breathing. Can prevent intubation in moderate hypoxic failure.
  • ROX index predicts HFNC failure: (SpO2/FiO2) Ã· RR. If <4.88 at 12 hours, high risk of needing intubation â€” escalate early.
  • BiPAP for CO2, CPAP for cardiogenic edema: BiPAP provides pressure support to augment ventilation (lowers CO2). CPAP reduces preload/afterload (treats pulmonary edema). Both provide PEEP.
  • Normal A-a gradient = hypoventilation: If A-a gradient is normal, the lungs are fine â€” problem is inadequate respiratory drive (opioids, CNS) or pump failure (neuromuscular). Give naloxone and support ventilation.
  • SpO2 88-92% for chronic CO2 retainers: High O2 in COPD can worsen hypercapnia (loss of hypoxic drive, Haldane effect). Target lower SpO2, use Venturi mask for precise FiO2.
  • 6 mL/kg IBW saves lives in ARDS: Lung-protective ventilation reduces mortality. Use ideal body weight (based on height, not actual weight), keep plateau pressure <30.
  • Post-intubation hypotension is common: Loss of catecholamine surge, positive pressure reduces venous return, sedation causes vasodilation. Have push-dose pressors ready.
  • Don't forget the simple stuff: Before intubating, make sure you've tried positioning (upright), suctioning secretions, treating bronchospasm, and draining large effusions.
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

155. ACUTE LIVER FAILURE

Fulminant Hepatic Failure â€¢ Coagulopathy â€¢ Encephalopathy â€¢ Transplant Evaluation
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Severe acute liver injury with encephalopathy and coagulopathy (INR â‰¥1.5) in a patient WITHOUT pre-existing liver disease, developing within 26 weeks of initial symptoms. Hyperacute (<7 days), acute (7-21 days), subacute (21 days-26 weeks)

Etiologies:

  • Acetaminophen Toxicity (46% in US): Intentional OD or unintentional (chronic use + alcohol, fasting). Dose-dependent hepatotoxicity >10g acute or >4g/day chronic
  • Drug-Induced (11%): Isoniazid, phenytoin, valproate, sulfonamides, statins, herbal supplements (kava, green tea extract), mushroom poisoning (Amanita phalloides)
  • Viral Hepatitis: Hepatitis A (rare), Hepatitis B (reactivation or acute), Hepatitis E (pregnant women), HSV, CMV, EBV
  • Autoimmune Hepatitis: May present acutely, check ANA, ASMA, IgG
  • Ischemic/Hypoxic: Shock liver, Budd-Chiari syndrome, acute portal vein thrombosis
  • Wilson's Disease: Young patients, hemolytic anemia, low alkaline phosphatase, Kayser-Fleischer rings
  • Pregnancy-Related: HELLP, acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP)
  • Indeterminate (15%): No cause found despite workup

Clinical Features:

  • Jaundice: Rapidly progressive
  • Coagulopathy: INR â‰¥1.5, bleeding diathesis
  • Hepatic Encephalopathy: Confusion â†’ somnolence â†’ coma (Grade I-IV)
  • Cerebral Edema: Major cause of death. Cushing's triad (HTN, bradycardia, irregular respirations)
  • Hypoglycemia: Impaired gluconeogenesis â€” check frequently
  • Infections: High risk (impaired immunity) â€” often bacterial, fungal
  • Multi-organ failure: AKI, ARDS, circulatory failure
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Confirm ALF:

  • INR â‰¥1.5 + hepatic encephalopathy + acute illness (<26 weeks)
  • NO pre-existing cirrhosis (distinguishes from acute-on-chronic liver failure)

Etiology Workup:

  • Acetaminophen level + Rumack-Matthew nomogram (if timed ingestion known)
  • Viral: HAV IgM, HBsAg, HBV DNA, HBc IgM, HCV Ab/RNA, HSV PCR, CMV, EBV
  • Autoimmune: ANA, ASMA, IgG levels
  • Wilson's: Ceruloplasmin, 24-hr urine copper, slit lamp exam
  • Pregnancy test in women of childbearing age
  • Toxicology screen
  • Imaging: RUQ US with Doppler (Budd-Chiari, portal vein thrombosis), CT if needed

Severity/Prognosis:

  • King's College Criteria (Non-Acetaminophen): INR >6.5 OR any 3 of: Age <10 or >40, etiology (non-A/non-B hepatitis, drug), jaundice >7 days before encephalopathy, INR >3.5, bilirubin >17.5 mg/dL
  • King's College Criteria (Acetaminophen): pH <7.3 (after resuscitation) OR all 3: INR >6.5, Cr >3.4, Grade III-IV encephalopathy
  • MELD score: Used for transplant listing
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate:

  • ICU admission â€” all ALF patients
  • Contact transplant center early â€” even if uncertain; transfer before too unstable
  • N-acetylcysteine (NAC): Give to ALL ALF patients (not just acetaminophen). IV: 150 mg/kg over 1 hr, then 50 mg/kg over 4 hr, then 100 mg/kg over 16 hr. Continue until INR <1.5 or transplant

Supportive Care:

  • Coagulopathy: Do NOT correct prophylactically (INR is prognostic marker). Give FFP/platelets only for active bleeding or procedures
  • Hypoglycemia: Check glucose q1-2h, D10 infusion to maintain >100 mg/dL
  • Cerebral Edema: HOB 30Â°, avoid stimulation, hypertonic saline (goal Na 145-155), mannitol 0.5-1 g/kg for herniation signs, consider ICP monitoring
  • Infections: Low threshold to culture and treat; surveillance cultures. Prophylactic antibiotics controversial but often given
  • Renal Failure: Avoid nephrotoxins, CRRT preferred over intermittent HD (less hemodynamic instability)
  • Avoid sedation if possible (obscures encephalopathy assessment)
  • Stress ulcer prophylaxis: PPI

Etiology-Specific:

  • Acetaminophen: NAC (most effective <8-10 hr but give regardless of timing)
  • Mushroom (Amanita): Penicillin G, silibinin, NAC
  • Autoimmune: Steroids (controversial in ALF, consult hepatology)
  • HSV: Acyclovir
  • HBV reactivation: Nucleos(t)ide analogs (tenofovir, entecavir)
  • Wilson's: Plasmapheresis, transplant often needed
  • Budd-Chiari: Anticoagulation, TIPS, transplant
  • AFLP/HELLP: Emergent delivery

Transplant:

  • Liver transplant is definitive treatment for ALF not responding to medical therapy
  • List as Status 1A (highest priority)
  • Contraindications: Uncontrolled sepsis, severe cardiopulmonary disease, active malignancy, irreversible brain injury
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • ALL patients with acute liver failure require ICU
  • Hepatic encephalopathy grade II or higher
  • INR >2.0
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Cerebral edema signs
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Rarely discharged â€” most require transplant or die
  • If spontaneous recovery: INR normalizing, encephalopathy resolved, stable synthetic function
  • Etiology identified and treated
  • Close hepatology follow-up
  • Acetaminophen: Psychiatric evaluation if intentional OD
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • NAC for ALL ALF: Not just acetaminophen. Improves transplant-free survival in non-acetaminophen ALF too (especially grade I-II encephalopathy)
  • Don't correct the INR: It's your best prognostic marker. Only give FFP for active bleeding or invasive procedures
  • Transfer early: Patients deteriorate rapidly. Transfer to transplant center before too unstable to move
  • Acetaminophen ALF has best prognosis: 65% spontaneous survival vs 25% for other causes
  • Hyperacute has paradoxically better prognosis: Often acetaminophen, higher spontaneous recovery rate
  • Wilson's ALF = emergent transplant: Almost never recovers spontaneously. Hemolytic anemia + low ALP:bilirubin ratio are clues
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

156. ALCOHOLIC HEPATITIS

Acute Alcohol-Associated Hepatitis â€¢ Maddrey Score â€¢ Lille Model â€¢ Steroids
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Acute inflammatory liver injury from heavy alcohol use, typically presenting with jaundice, tender hepatomegaly, and systemic inflammation. Usually in setting of >40g/day (women) or >60g/day (men) alcohol for >6 months, often with recent heavy binge

Classic Presentation:

  • Jaundice: Rapid onset, often severe (bilirubin >3 mg/dL, frequently >10-20)
  • Tender hepatomegaly: RUQ pain and tenderness
  • Fever: Low-grade, even without infection (inflammatory response)
  • Malnutrition: Muscle wasting, low albumin
  • Signs of chronic liver disease: Spider angiomata, palmar erythema, gynecomastia
  • Ascites, encephalopathy: If decompensated

Lab Pattern:

  • AST:ALT ratio >2:1 (classic, due to B6 deficiency and mitochondrial injury)
  • AST and ALT typically <300-500 (if >500, consider other causes)
  • Elevated bilirubin (often >5-10 mg/dL, key prognostic marker)
  • Elevated INR (synthetic dysfunction)
  • Leukocytosis (often 12-20k, WBC >20k concerning for infection)
  • Low albumin
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical Diagnosis (Biopsy Not Required If Classic Presentation):

  • Heavy alcohol use (>40g/day women, >60g/day men for >6 months)
  • Rapid onset jaundice (bilirubin >3 mg/dL)
  • AST 50-300, AST:ALT >1.5 (typically >2)
  • No other explanation for liver disease

Rule Out Other Causes:

  • Viral hepatitis serologies (HBV, HCV)
  • RUQ US: Rule out biliary obstruction, assess for cirrhosis
  • Consider: Autoimmune markers (ANA, ASMA), ceruloplasmin if young

Rule Out Infection (Critical Before Steroids):

  • Blood cultures
  • Urine culture
  • Diagnostic paracentesis if ascites (rule out SBP)
  • CXR

Severity Scoring:

  • Maddrey Discriminant Function (mDF): 4.6 Ã— (PT - control PT) + bilirubin
    • mDF â‰¥32 = severe alcoholic hepatitis, ~35% 30-day mortality without treatment
    • mDF <32 = mild-moderate, supportive care
  • MELD Score: >20 indicates severe disease
  • Lille Score: Calculate at day 7 of steroids to assess response
    • Lille <0.45 = responder, complete 28 days steroids
    • Lille â‰¥0.45 = non-responder, stop steroids (futile, increases infection risk)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

All Patients:

  • Alcohol cessation (most important long-term intervention)
  • Nutrition: 1.2-1.5 g/kg/day protein, 30-40 kcal/kg/day. Enteral preferred. Zinc supplementation
  • Thiamine: 100-250 mg IV/IM Ã— 3-5 days, then oral (prevent Wernicke's)
  • Folate, multivitamin
  • Manage alcohol withdrawal: CIWA protocol, benzodiazepines PRN
  • Treat complications: Ascites (diuretics, paracentesis), encephalopathy (lactulose, rifaximin)

Severe Alcoholic Hepatitis (mDF â‰¥32 or MELD >20):

  • Prednisolone 40 mg PO daily Ã— 28 days (or methylprednisolone 32 mg IV if unable to take PO)
    • Use prednisolone (not prednisone) â€” doesn't require hepatic conversion
    • Contraindications: Active infection (GI bleeding, sepsis, SBP), HBV, uncontrolled DM, GI bleeding
  • Calculate Lille score at day 7:
    • Lille <0.45: Continue steroids for full 28 days, then taper
    • Lille â‰¥0.45: Stop steroids (non-responder), consider transplant evaluation
  • Pentoxifylline: No longer recommended (STOPAH trial showed no benefit)

Transplant Evaluation:

  • Consider for steroid non-responders, severe AH not responding to medical therapy
  • Traditionally required 6 months abstinence, but early transplant protocols exist at select centers for carefully selected patients
  • Excellent outcomes in selected patients with severe AH failing medical therapy
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • MELD >30 or mDF >54 (very severe)
  • Grade III-IV hepatic encephalopathy
  • GI bleeding
  • Sepsis or severe infection
  • Renal failure (hepatorenal syndrome)
  • Respiratory failure
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Bilirubin downtrending
  • INR improving or stable
  • Encephalopathy resolved or at baseline
  • Tolerating oral nutrition
  • No active infection
  • Alcohol cessation resources arranged
  • Hepatology follow-up within 1-2 weeks
  • If on steroids: Clear taper plan, glucose monitoring
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • AST:ALT >2 is classic: Alcohol depletes B6 (pyridoxine) needed for ALT synthesis. If ratio <1, think viral or other causes
  • Transaminases NOT dramatically elevated: AST/ALT usually <300. If >500, look for acetaminophen, ischemia, viral superinfection
  • Lille at day 7 guides therapy: Don't continue steroids in non-responders â€” increases infection risk without benefit
  • Nutrition is critical: These patients are severely malnourished. High protein (1.5 g/kg) improves outcomes
  • Rule out infection before steroids: Steroids in setting of undiagnosed infection = disaster. Get cultures, paracentesis if ascites
  • Pentoxifylline doesn't work: STOPAH trial buried it. Don't use
  • Early transplant is evolving: Select centers offer transplant without 6-month abstinence for carefully chosen patients failing medical therapy
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

157. ISCHEMIC COLITIS

Colonic Ischemia â€¢ Watershed Areas â€¢ Thumbprinting â€¢ Supportive Care
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Ischemic injury to the colon from reduced blood flow. Most common form of GI ischemia. Usually transient and self-limited (80-85%), but can progress to gangrene/perforation

Classic Triad:

  • Sudden crampy abdominal pain (usually left-sided)
  • Urgent need to defecate
  • Bloody diarrhea (maroon or bright red) within 24 hours of pain onset

Risk Factors:

  • Age >60 (most common)
  • Cardiovascular disease: HTN, CAD, CHF, AFib, PVD
  • Hypotensive episodes: Surgery, sepsis, hemodialysis, cardiac arrest
  • Medications: Vasopressors, cocaine, digoxin, NSAIDs, oral contraceptives, immunosuppressants
  • Coagulopathy / Hypercoagulable states
  • Constipation / Obstruction: Increased intraluminal pressure
  • Aortic surgery: IMA ligation
  • Long-distance running (marathon colitis)

Watershed Areas (Most Susceptible):

  • Splenic flexure: Junction of SMA and IMA territories (Griffith's point)
  • Rectosigmoid junction: Junction of IMA and internal iliac (Sudeck's point)
  • Rectum usually spared (dual blood supply from IMA and internal iliac)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Labs:

  • CBC: Leukocytosis (WBC >15k concerning for severe ischemia)
  • BMP: Metabolic acidosis, elevated lactate = severe ischemia
  • Lactate: If elevated, concerning for transmural ischemia/necrosis
  • LDH, CPK: May be elevated in severe cases

Imaging:

  • CT Abdomen/Pelvis with IV Contrast: First-line imaging
    • Segmental colonic wall thickening
    • "Thumbprinting" (submucosal edema/hemorrhage)
    • Pericolonic fat stranding
    • Pneumatosis (air in bowel wall) = severe ischemia
    • Portal venous gas, free air = perforation/gangrene
  • CT Angiography: If concerned for acute mesenteric ischemia (isolated right colon involvement, severe presentation)

Colonoscopy (Gold Standard for Diagnosis):

  • Perform within 48 hours if diagnosis uncertain
  • Findings: Segmental erythema, edema, hemorrhagic mucosa, ulcerations. Sharp demarcation between affected and normal mucosa
  • Contraindicated if: Peritonitis, pneumatosis, hemodynamic instability (risk of perforation)

Severity Classification:

  • Mild: No risk factors, non-isolated right colon, no peritonitis
  • Moderate: 1-3 risk factors (right colon involvement, hypotension, tachycardia, male sex, BUN >20, Hgb <12, LDH >350, Na <136, WBC >15k)
  • Severe: â‰¥3 risk factors OR peritonitis OR pneumatosis
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Supportive Care (Majority of Cases):

  • Bowel rest: NPO initially
  • IV fluids: Gentle hydration (avoid hypotension)
  • Avoid/discontinue offending medications: Vasoconstrictors, NSAIDs, digoxin, diuretics
  • Optimize cardiac output: Treat CHF, arrhythmias
  • Antibiotics: If moderate-severe, signs of sepsis, or mucosal compromise. Ciprofloxacin + metronidazole or piperacillin-tazobactam
  • Serial abdominal exams: Monitor for peritonitis
  • DVT prophylaxis

Surgical Consultation (Emergent if):

  • Peritonitis or free perforation
  • Pneumatosis intestinalis or portal venous gas
  • Hemodynamic instability despite resuscitation
  • Worsening despite 24-48 hours of conservative management
  • Massive GI bleeding
  • Fulminant colitis with sepsis

Prognosis:

  • 80-85% resolve with conservative management
  • 15-20% progress to gangrene, perforation, or stricture
  • Surgery required in ~20%
  • Mortality: 5% overall, 50-60% if surgery required
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Peritonitis or signs of perforation
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Pneumatosis or portal venous gas on imaging
  • Isolated right colon involvement (IMA not involved â€” suggests SMA occlusion)
  • Severe sepsis
  • Need for emergent surgery
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Abdominal pain resolved
  • Tolerating regular diet
  • Normal bowel function returning
  • No fever, leukocytosis resolving
  • Lactate normal (if previously elevated)
  • Offending medications discontinued
  • Follow-up colonoscopy in 1-2 weeks to assess healing (and rule out underlying mass/stricture)
  • GI follow-up arranged
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Pain â†’ urge â†’ bloody stool: Classic sequence within 24 hours. Distinguishes from infectious colitis (diarrhea first, then bloody)
  • Isolated right colon = worrisome: Right colon supplied by SMA, not IMA. Isolated right colon ischemia suggests more proximal occlusion â€” higher mortality, often needs CTA and surgery
  • Rectal sparing: Rectum has dual blood supply. If rectum involved, consider other diagnoses (IBD, infectious)
  • Thumbprinting on imaging: Classic CT finding â€” thickened haustral folds from submucosal edema/hemorrhage
  • Most cases self-limited: 80-85% resolve with supportive care. Don't rush to surgery unless peritonitis
  • Follow-up colonoscopy important: Rule out underlying malignancy (especially in older patients) and assess for stricture formation
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

158. CHOLEDOCHOLITHIASIS

Common Bile Duct Stone â€¢ Obstructive Jaundice â€¢ ERCP â€¢ MRCP
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Gallstone(s) in the common bile duct (CBD). Usually migrated from gallbladder. Can cause biliary obstruction, jaundice, cholangitis, or pancreatitis

Presentation Spectrum:

  • Asymptomatic: Found incidentally on imaging
  • Biliary colic: Episodic RUQ/epigastric pain, may be more prolonged than gallbladder colic
  • Obstructive jaundice: Painless or painful jaundice, dark urine, pale stools, pruritus
  • Acute cholangitis: â†’ See Cholangitis (Charcot's triad: fever, jaundice, RUQ pain)
  • Gallstone pancreatitis: â†’ See Pancreatitis

Lab Pattern:

  • Elevated bilirubin: Direct (conjugated) > indirect
  • Elevated ALP and GGT: Cholestatic pattern
  • Transaminases: May be elevated (especially with acute obstruction â€” can be >1000 transiently)
  • If cholangitis: Leukocytosis, elevated inflammatory markers
  • If pancreatitis: Elevated lipase
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Risk Stratification (ASGE Guidelines):

  • Very High Risk (Confirmed CBD Stone): Stone visible on US/CT, clinical cholangitis, bilirubin >4 + dilated CBD
    • â†’ Proceed directly to ERCP
  • High Risk: Dilated CBD (>6mm or >8mm post-cholecystectomy) + elevated bilirubin, OR any very high risk predictor
    • â†’ ERCP or intraoperative cholangiogram
  • Intermediate Risk: Abnormal LFTs (other than bilirubin), age >55, gallstone pancreatitis
    • â†’ EUS or MRCP first (avoid unnecessary ERCP)
  • Low Risk: None of the above
    • â†’ Proceed to cholecystectomy, no CBD evaluation needed

Imaging:

  • RUQ Ultrasound: First-line. Sees dilated CBD (>6mm), gallstones. May not see CBD stones directly (50-70% sensitivity)
  • MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography):
    • Non-invasive, no sedation, no radiation
    • Sensitivity 90-95% for CBD stones
    • Use for intermediate probability
  • EUS (Endoscopic Ultrasound):
    • Highest sensitivity (95%+) for CBD stones
    • Requires sedation but can proceed to ERCP in same session if stone found
    • Alternative to MRCP for intermediate risk
  • ERCP: Diagnostic AND therapeutic. Reserve for high probability (risk of pancreatitis 3-5%)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Definitive Treatment:

  • ERCP with Sphincterotomy and Stone Extraction:
    • First-line therapeutic intervention
    • Success rate >90%
    • Balloon or basket extraction
    • Mechanical lithotripsy for large stones
    • Stent placement if incomplete clearance
  • Cholecystectomy: Should follow ERCP (same admission or within 2 weeks) to prevent recurrent stones

Alternative Approaches:

  • Laparoscopic CBD exploration: Can be done during cholecystectomy at experienced centers
  • Choledochotomy: Open surgical CBD exploration (rarely needed now)
  • Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC): If ERCP fails or inaccessible (altered anatomy)

If Cholangitis Present:

  • Urgent ERCP within 24-48 hours (emergent if severe/septic)
  • IV antibiotics (piperacillin-tazobactam or ceftriaxone + metronidazole)
  • Volume resuscitation, pressors if needed
  • â†’ See Cholangitis

If Pancreatitis Present:

  • Urgent ERCP (within 24 hours) ONLY if concurrent cholangitis or biliary obstruction
  • Otherwise, manage pancreatitis supportively, ERCP can be semi-elective
  • Cholecystectomy during same admission (once pancreatitis resolved)
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Concurrent cholangitis with sepsis/shock
  • Severe gallstone pancreatitis
  • Post-ERCP complications (perforation, severe pancreatitis, bleeding)
  • Multi-organ dysfunction
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • CBD cleared (stone extracted or stent placed)
  • Cholecystectomy completed (or scheduled)
  • LFTs improving
  • Tolerating diet
  • Pain controlled
  • Afebrile, WBC normalizing
  • GI follow-up for stent removal if placed
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Transient transaminase spike: ALT/AST can spike >1000 with acute CBD obstruction (higher than typical biliary pattern), then fall rapidly. Don't assume viral hepatitis
  • CBD dilates with age: Normal CBD <6mm, but add 1mm per decade over age 60. Post-cholecystectomy CBD can be up to 10mm and still be normal
  • Don't ERCP everyone: ERCP has risks (pancreatitis, bleeding, perforation). Use MRCP or EUS for intermediate probability to avoid unnecessary procedures
  • Cholecystectomy on same admission: After ERCP, do cholecystectomy before discharge to prevent recurrence (unless patient too sick)
  • Gallstone pancreatitis + cholangitis = urgent ERCP: Pancreatitis alone doesn't need urgent ERCP, but if there's ongoing biliary obstruction or cholangitis, decompress urgently
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

159. GASTROPARESIS

Delayed Gastric Emptying â€¢ Diabetic Gastroparesis â€¢ Prokinetics â€¢ Gastric Stimulation
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Delayed gastric emptying in the absence of mechanical obstruction. Symptoms: nausea, vomiting, early satiety, bloating, abdominal pain

Etiologies:

  • Diabetic (38%): Most common known cause. Usually longstanding DM with neuropathy. Type 1 > Type 2
  • Idiopathic (36%): No identifiable cause, often post-viral
  • Post-surgical: Vagal nerve injury (fundoplication, bariatric surgery, esophagectomy)
  • Medications: Opioids, anticholinergics, GLP-1 agonists, dopamine agonists
  • Neurologic: Parkinson's, MS, brainstem lesions
  • Connective tissue: Scleroderma, amyloidosis

Cardinal Symptoms:

  • Nausea: Most common and bothersome symptom
  • Vomiting: Often partially digested food, may occur hours after eating
  • Early satiety / postprandial fullness
  • Bloating / abdominal distension
  • Abdominal pain: Present in 90%, often epigastric, can be severe
  • Weight loss / malnutrition

Complications:

  • Malnutrition, weight loss
  • Bezoar formation
  • Erratic glycemic control in diabetics
  • Aspiration pneumonia
  • Electrolyte abnormalities (from vomiting)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Step 1 â€” Rule Out Mechanical Obstruction:

  • EGD: Required before diagnosing gastroparesis. Rule out pyloric stenosis, gastric outlet obstruction, ulcer, malignancy, bezoar
  • CT or UGI series: If EGD incomplete or structural abnormality suspected

Step 2 â€” Confirm Delayed Gastric Emptying:

  • Gastric Emptying Scintigraphy (Gold Standard):
    • Standardized low-fat meal with Tc-99m
    • Measure retention at 1, 2, and 4 hours
    • Diagnostic: >60% retention at 2 hours OR >10% at 4 hours
    • Stop prokinetics 48-72 hr before, opioids 72 hr before
  • Wireless Motility Capsule (SmartPill): Alternative, measures pH, pressure, transit through entire GI tract
  • 13C-Breath Test: Alternative, less available

Additional Workup:

  • HbA1c (glycemic control in diabetics)
  • TSH (hypothyroidism can slow motility)
  • ANA, SCL-70 if scleroderma suspected
  • Review medications for offenders
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Acute Flare / Hospitalized Patient:

  • NPO initially, then advance to small-volume clear liquids
  • IV fluids: Correct dehydration, electrolytes
  • Glycemic control: Critical in diabetics â€” hyperglycemia (>200 mg/dL) delays gastric emptying further
  • IV antiemetics: Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV q6-8h, promethazine, prochlorperazine
  • IV metoclopramide: 5-10 mg IV q6-8h (before meals and at bedtime)
  • NG tube decompression: If severe distension, obstruction, or refractory vomiting
  • Discontinue offending medications: Opioids, anticholinergics, GLP-1 agonists

Dietary Modifications:

  • Small, frequent meals (4-6/day)
  • Low fat, low fiber (slows emptying)
  • Liquids and pureed foods empty faster than solids
  • Avoid carbonated beverages
  • Walk after meals (promotes emptying)

Pharmacotherapy:

  • Metoclopramide: 5-10 mg PO 15-30 min before meals + bedtime. Most effective but BLACK BOX WARNING for tardive dyskinesia. Limit to <12 weeks if possible
  • Domperidone: 10 mg TID-QID. Not FDA approved, available via FDA IND program. Fewer CNS effects (doesn't cross BBB)
  • Erythromycin: 40-250 mg PO before meals. Motilin agonist. Tolerance develops in weeks. Best for short-term/acute use
  • Prucalopride: 5-HT4 agonist, may help some patients
  • Antiemetics: Ondansetron, promethazine, prochlorperazine for symptom relief

Refractory Cases:

  • Gastric electrical stimulation (Enterra): Implanted pacemaker, reduces nausea/vomiting in select patients
  • Pyloric interventions: Botox injection (temporary), G-POEM (gastric peroral endoscopic myotomy), pyloroplasty
  • Enteral feeding: J-tube (bypasses stomach) for nutrition in severe refractory cases
  • TPN: Last resort if enteral feeding fails
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Aspiration pneumonia with respiratory failure
  • Severe electrolyte abnormalities (hypokalemia, hypochloremia)
  • DKA in diabetic gastroparesis
  • Severe malnutrition requiring TPN initiation
  • Hemodynamic instability from dehydration
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Tolerating oral liquids/soft diet
  • Nausea/vomiting controlled
  • Electrolytes normalized
  • Glycemic control optimized (diabetics)
  • On effective antiemetic/prokinetic regimen
  • Dietary education completed
  • GI follow-up arranged
  • Offending medications discontinued or alternatives provided
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • EGD before diagnosing: Must rule out mechanical obstruction. Don't diagnose gastroparesis without it
  • Hyperglycemia worsens emptying: Blood glucose >200 mg/dL delays gastric emptying independent of neuropathy. Control glucose first
  • Stop offending meds for testing: Opioids, metoclopramide must be stopped before gastric emptying study or results invalid
  • Metoclopramide has a black box: Risk of tardive dyskinesia. Use lowest effective dose, limit duration. Counsel patient
  • Erythromycin tolerance develops quickly: Best for acute flares, not long-term maintenance
  • Liquids empty by gravity: Liquids empty faster than solids. Prioritize liquid calories in severe cases
  • G-POEM is emerging: Endoscopic pyloric myotomy showing promise for refractory gastroparesis
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

160. SEROTONIN SYNDROME

Drug-Induced Hyperserotonergic State â€¢ Clonus â€¢ Cyproheptadine â€¢ Hunter Criteria
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Potentially life-threatening drug-induced condition caused by excessive serotonergic activity in the CNS, typically from drug interactions or overdose. Onset usually within 24 hours of drug initiation, dose change, or adding another serotonergic agent

Classic Triad:

  • Mental Status Changes: Agitation, anxiety, confusion, hypomania, hallucinations
  • Autonomic Instability: Hyperthermia, diaphoresis, tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis, diarrhea
  • Neuromuscular Abnormalities: Clonus (spontaneous, inducible, or ocular), hyperreflexia, tremor, rigidity, ataxia

Key Clinical Features:

  • Clonus: Most important diagnostic finding. Look for ankle clonus, patellar clonus, or ocular clonus (slow horizontal eye movements)
  • Hyperreflexia: More pronounced in lower extremities
  • Hyperthermia: May be severe (>41Â°C/106Â°F in severe cases)
  • Onset: Usually within 6-24 hours of causative agent; 60% within 6 hours

Causative Agents (Drug Classes):

  • SSRIs: Fluoxetine, sertraline, paroxetine, citalopram, escitalopram
  • SNRIs: Venlafaxine, duloxetine, desvenlafaxine
  • MAOIs: Phenelzine, tranylcypromine, selegiline (highest risk combinations)
  • TCAs: Amitriptyline, nortriptyline, clomipramine
  • Opioids: Tramadol, meperidine, fentanyl, methadone (serotonin reuptake inhibition)
  • Triptans: Sumatriptan and other migraine medications
  • Antibiotics: Linezolid (weak MAOI), tedizolid
  • Antiemetics: Ondansetron, metoclopramide
  • Illicit Drugs: MDMA (ecstasy), cocaine, amphetamines
  • Supplements: St. John's wort, tryptophan
  • Other: Methylene blue (MAOI), dextromethorphan, lithium

High-Risk Combinations:

  • MAOI + ANY serotonergic agent = highest risk (potentially fatal)
  • SSRI + tramadol or meperidine
  • SSRI + linezolid or methylene blue
  • Multiple serotonergic agents at high doses
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Hunter Criteria (Most Accurate â€” Sensitivity 84%, Specificity 97%):

  • Must have taken a serotonergic agent AND one of the following:
  • 1. Spontaneous clonus
  • 2. Inducible clonus + agitation OR diaphoresis
  • 3. Ocular clonus + agitation OR diaphoresis
  • 4. Tremor + hyperreflexia
  • 5. Hypertonia + temperature >38Â°C + ocular clonus OR inducible clonus

Laboratory (Supportive, Not Diagnostic):

  • CBC: Leukocytosis common
  • BMP: Electrolyte abnormalities, AKI if severe
  • CK: Elevated if rhabdomyolysis (from muscle rigidity, agitation)
  • LFTs: Transaminitis in severe cases
  • Coagulation: DIC in severe cases
  • Lactate: Elevated in severe cases
  • No specific diagnostic test â€” diagnosis is clinical

Differential Diagnosis:

Condition Key Differentiating Features
Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) Lead-pipe rigidity (not clonus), bradyreflexia, develops over days (not hours), caused by dopamine antagonists
Malignant Hyperthermia Exposure to inhaled anesthetics or succinylcholine, OR setting
Anticholinergic Toxicity Dry skin (not diaphoretic), urinary retention, decreased bowel sounds, mydriasis
Sympathomimetic Toxicity Similar features but no clonus, often with significant hypertension
Meningitis/Encephalitis Nuchal rigidity, focal neurologic findings, CSF abnormalities

Key distinguishing feature of serotonin syndrome: CLONUS and hyperreflexia (vs rigidity and bradyreflexia in NMS)

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Management:

  • Stop ALL serotonergic agents â€” most important step
  • Supportive care: IV fluids, continuous monitoring
  • Benzodiazepines: First-line for agitation, muscle rigidity, seizure prevention
    • Lorazepam 2-4 mg IV or diazepam 5-10 mg IV, repeat as needed
    • Controls agitation and reduces muscle hyperactivity

Hyperthermia Management:

  • External cooling: Ice packs, cooling blankets, evaporative cooling
  • Avoid antipyretics: Acetaminophen/NSAIDs ineffective (not prostaglandin-mediated fever)
  • If temp >41Â°C: Consider intubation and paralysis with non-depolarizing agent (stops muscle hyperactivity generating heat)

Cyproheptadine (Serotonin Antagonist):

  • Mechanism: 5-HT2A receptor antagonist
  • Dose: 12 mg initial dose, then 2 mg q2h until improvement
  • Maintenance: 8 mg q6h once stabilized
  • Max: 32 mg/day
  • Route: PO only (can crush and give via NG if intubated)
  • Side effects: Sedation (often beneficial), anticholinergic effects
  • Note: Evidence is anecdotal but widely recommended

Severe Cases (ICU):

  • Intubation for airway protection or severe hyperthermia
  • Paralysis (non-depolarizing NMB) for refractory hyperthermia
  • Avoid succinylcholine (risk of hyperkalemia with rhabdomyolysis)
  • Aggressive IV fluids for rhabdomyolysis
  • Pressors if needed (avoid serotonergic agents like dopamine; use norepinephrine or phenylephrine)

What to Avoid:

  • Physical restraints: Increase muscle rigidity â†’ worsen rhabdomyolysis and hyperthermia
  • Antipyretics: Ineffective
  • Succinylcholine: Hyperkalemia risk
  • Dopamine: Theoretical serotonergic activity
  • Bromocriptine/dantrolene: These are for NMS, not serotonin syndrome
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Temperature >40Â°C (104Â°F)
  • Severe muscle rigidity
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Altered mental status (GCS <13)
  • Seizures
  • Rhabdomyolysis with AKI
  • DIC or multi-organ dysfunction
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Symptoms resolved (typically within 24-72 hours after stopping agent)
  • Afebrile
  • Mental status at baseline
  • No clonus or hyperreflexia
  • CK normalizing (if elevated)
  • Clear plan for psychiatric medication management
  • Offending agent(s) documented and patient educated
  • Psychiatry or PCP follow-up arranged for medication reconciliation
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Clonus is the key: The most distinguishing feature from NMS. If you see clonus + serotonergic drug exposure = serotonin syndrome until proven otherwise
  • NMS is slow, SS is fast: NMS develops over days with gradual rigidity. Serotonin syndrome develops within hours with hyperreflexia/clonus
  • Stop the drug and most cases resolve: 70% resolve within 24 hours of stopping the offending agent. Supportive care is often sufficient
  • Cyproheptadine only works orally: No IV formulation. Crush and give via NG if patient intubated
  • Linezolid is a sneaky cause: Weak MAOI activity. Avoid with SSRIs/SNRIs if possible. Also methylene blue (used in methemoglobinemia, sentinel lymph node mapping)
  • Tramadol is a common culprit: Often overlooked as a serotonergic agent. Avoid with SSRIs/MAOIs
  • MAOI washout periods matter: MAOIs require 2-week washout before starting serotonergic agents. Fluoxetine requires 5-week washout before MAOI (long half-life)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

161. HYPOGLYCEMIA

Glucose <70 mg/dL â€¢ Whipple's Triad â€¢ Insulin vs Sulfonylurea â€¢ Insulinoma
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Blood glucose <70 mg/dL. Severe hypoglycemia = requiring assistance from another person. Whipple's Triad: (1) Symptoms consistent with hypoglycemia, (2) Low plasma glucose, (3) Resolution with glucose correction

Autonomic (Adrenergic) Symptoms:

  • Tremor, palpitations, anxiety, diaphoresis, hunger, paresthesias
  • Occur at glucose ~55-65 mg/dL
  • May be blunted in diabetics with hypoglycemia unawareness, beta-blocker use

Neuroglycopenic Symptoms:

  • Confusion, difficulty concentrating, behavioral changes, slurred speech
  • Visual disturbances, weakness, fatigue, dizziness
  • Seizures, loss of consciousness, coma (severe)
  • Occur at glucose ~50 mg/dL and below

Etiologies in Hospitalized Patients:

  • Insulin excess (most common): Too much insulin for intake, missed meal, insulin stacking
  • Sulfonylureas: Glipizide, glyburide, glimepiride â€” long-acting, accumulate in renal failure
  • Reduced oral intake: NPO status without adjusting insulin, anorexia, N/V
  • Renal failure: Reduced insulin clearance, reduced gluconeogenesis
  • Hepatic failure: Impaired gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis
  • Sepsis: Increased glucose utilization, hepatic dysfunction
  • Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisol is counter-regulatory hormone
  • Alcohol: Inhibits gluconeogenesis

Etiologies in Non-Diabetics (Rare):

  • Insulinoma: Fasting hypoglycemia, elevated insulin/C-peptide, negative sulfonylurea screen
  • Factitious hypoglycemia: Exogenous insulin (high insulin, LOW C-peptide) or sulfonylurea ingestion
  • Non-islet cell tumor hypoglycemia: IGF-2 producing tumors (mesenchymal tumors)
  • Autoimmune: Anti-insulin antibodies, insulin receptor antibodies
  • Post-gastric bypass: Reactive/postprandial hypoglycemia
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Immediate:

  • Point-of-care glucose â€” confirm hypoglycemia
  • If cause unclear, draw labs BEFORE treating: Glucose, insulin, C-peptide, proinsulin, Î²-hydroxybutyrate, sulfonylurea screen

Interpretation (drawn during hypoglycemia):

Diagnosis Insulin C-peptide Proinsulin SU Screen
Insulinoma â†‘ â†‘ â†‘ Negative
Sulfonylurea â†‘ â†‘ â†‘ Positive
Exogenous Insulin â†‘ â†“/Low â†“ Negative
IGF-2 tumor â†“ â†“ â†“ Negative

Additional Workup (if etiology unclear):

  • Cortisol (8 AM or random if acute) â€” rule out adrenal insufficiency
  • LFTs, renal function
  • 72-hour fast with serial glucose/insulin/C-peptide (for suspected insulinoma)
  • CT/MRI pancreas if insulinoma suspected
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Treatment:

  • Conscious, able to swallow: 15-20g fast-acting carbs (4 oz juice, glucose tabs, 3-4 sugar packets). Recheck in 15 min, repeat if still <70
  • Altered/unable to swallow:
    • D50: 25-50 mL (12.5-25g glucose) IV push. Can repeat
    • D10: 100-250 mL if no D50 or prefer slower correction
    • Glucagon: 1 mg IM/SQ if no IV access (less effective in alcoholics, liver failure)
  • Follow with complex carbs/meal once glucose >100 and patient alert

Sulfonylurea-Induced Hypoglycemia (CRITICAL):

  • Prolonged hypoglycemia expected â€” sulfonylureas have long half-lives (12-24+ hours)
  • ADMIT for observation â€” minimum 24 hours, longer for glyburide or renal impairment
  • Continuous D10 infusion: Often required to maintain euglycemia
  • Octreotide: 50-100 mcg SQ q8h â€” inhibits insulin release, helps prevent recurrent hypoglycemia
  • Frequent glucose monitoring: q1h initially, can space if stable

Prevention in Hospitalized Diabetics:

  • Reduce/hold insulin if NPO or reduced intake
  • Reduce insulin in AKI (decreased clearance)
  • Avoid sliding-scale-only regimens (reactive, not preventive)
  • Coordinate insulin with meal delivery
  • Hypoglycemia protocol: nurse-driven treatment for glucose <70
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Refractory hypoglycemia requiring continuous dextrose infusion
  • Seizures or prolonged altered mental status
  • Sulfonylurea overdose (intentional)
  • Recurrent hypoglycemia despite treatment
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Euglycemic for â‰¥24 hours off dextrose infusion
  • Cause identified and addressed
  • Diabetes regimen adjusted if needed
  • Patient educated on recognition and treatment
  • Follow-up arranged
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Sulfonylurea hypoglycemia = admit: Long half-life means recurrent hypoglycemia for 24-72 hours. Never discharge after single correction
  • Octreotide for sulfonylurea OD: Inhibits insulin release. Give 50-100 mcg SQ q8h. Game-changer for refractory cases
  • Draw labs BEFORE treating: If cause unclear, get insulin/C-peptide/SU screen before giving dextrose â€” opportunity lost once treated
  • Low C-peptide = exogenous insulin: Endogenous insulin secretion includes C-peptide. Exogenous insulin does not
  • Hypoglycemia unawareness: Diabetics with frequent hypoglycemia lose adrenergic warning symptoms. First sign may be neuroglycopenic (confusion, seizure)
  • Glucagon doesn't work in liver failure/alcoholics: Requires hepatic glycogen stores. These patients need IV dextrose
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

162. NEUROLEPTIC MALIGNANT SYNDROME (NMS)

Antipsychotic-Induced â€¢ Lead-Pipe Rigidity â€¢ Hyperthermia â€¢ Bromocriptine/Dantrolene
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Life-threatening idiosyncratic reaction to dopamine antagonists (antipsychotics, antiemetics) characterized by hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, altered mental status, and autonomic instability. Mortality 5-20% even with treatment

Classic Tetrad:

  • Hyperthermia: Often >40Â°C (104Â°F), can exceed 41Â°C
  • Muscle Rigidity: "Lead-pipe" rigidity (constant resistance throughout ROM), NOT clonus
  • Altered Mental Status: Confusion, agitation, stupor, coma
  • Autonomic Instability: Tachycardia, labile BP (hyper- or hypotension), diaphoresis, tachypnea

Time Course:

  • Onset typically within 2 weeks of starting/increasing antipsychotic (90% within 10 days)
  • Can occur after years of stable therapy (rare)
  • Develops over 24-72 hours (slower than serotonin syndrome)
  • Duration: Days to weeks even after stopping offending agent

Causative Agents:

  • Typical Antipsychotics (Higher Risk): Haloperidol, fluphenazine, chlorpromazine
  • Atypical Antipsychotics: Risperidone, olanzapine, quetiapine, aripiprazole, clozapine (all can cause)
  • Antiemetics: Metoclopramide, prochlorperazine, promethazine
  • Dopamine Withdrawal: Abrupt discontinuation of levodopa/dopamine agonists in Parkinson's

Risk Factors:

  • High-potency typical antipsychotics
  • Rapid dose escalation, IM administration
  • Dehydration, agitation, exhaustion
  • Prior NMS episode (17-30% recurrence risk)
  • Organic brain disease
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical Diagnosis â€” No Specific Test:

  • Recent dopamine antagonist exposure + classic tetrad
  • Rule out other causes (infection, other drug toxicity)

Laboratory Findings (Supportive):

  • CK: Markedly elevated (often >1000, can be >100,000) â€” from rigidity-induced rhabdomyolysis
  • WBC: Leukocytosis (10-40k) â€” not infection
  • LFTs: Often elevated
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Myoglobinuria
  • Electrolytes: Hypocalcemia, hyper/hyponatremia
  • Iron: Low serum iron (acute phase reactant â€” sensitive early marker)

Differential Diagnosis (NMS vs Serotonin Syndrome):

Feature NMS Serotonin Syndrome
Causative Agent Dopamine antagonists Serotonergic drugs
Onset Days (24-72 hrs) Hours (<24 hrs)
Muscle Findings Lead-pipe rigidity Clonus, hyperreflexia
Reflexes Normal or decreased Hyperreflexia
Pupils Normal Mydriasis
Bowel Sounds Decreased/absent Hyperactive
Resolution Days to weeks 24-72 hours
Treatment Bromocriptine, dantrolene Cyproheptadine
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate:

  • STOP offending agent â€” most important step
  • ICU admission
  • Supportive care: IV fluids, cooling, monitoring

Cooling:

  • External cooling (ice packs, cooling blankets, evaporative)
  • Antipyretics NOT effective (not prostaglandin-mediated)
  • Target temperature <38.5Â°C

Specific Pharmacotherapy:

  • Bromocriptine (Dopamine Agonist):
    • 2.5 mg PO/NG q8h, increase to 5 mg q8h as needed
    • Max 40 mg/day
    • Continue until symptoms resolve, then taper over 10 days
  • Dantrolene (Muscle Relaxant):
    • 1-2.5 mg/kg IV q6h (max 10 mg/kg/day)
    • Reduces rigidity and heat production
    • Monitor for hepatotoxicity
  • Benzodiazepines: For agitation (lorazepam 1-2 mg IV q4-6h PRN)
  • Amantadine: 100 mg PO BID â€” alternative dopaminergic agent

Supportive Measures:

  • Aggressive IV fluids (prevent AKI from rhabdomyolysis)
  • DVT prophylaxis
  • Intubation if needed for airway protection or severe rigidity
  • Avoid succinylcholine (hyperkalemia risk from rhabdo)
  • ECT may be considered for refractory cases

Duration:

  • Symptoms resolve over 7-14 days with treatment
  • Longer with depot antipsychotics (weeks)
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • ALL NMS patients require ICU
  • Hyperthermia >40Â°C
  • Severe rigidity
  • Rhabdomyolysis (CK >10,000)
  • Respiratory compromise
  • Hemodynamic instability
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Afebrile for >48 hours
  • Rigidity resolved
  • Mental status at baseline
  • CK downtrending/normalized
  • Renal function stable
  • Psychiatric plan for alternative antipsychotic (if needed)
  • May cautiously rechallenge with low-potency agent after 2+ weeks if psychiatrically necessary
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Lead-pipe rigidity, NOT clonus: Key distinction from serotonin syndrome. NMS = rigid. SS = hyperreflexic/clonus
  • NMS is slow, SS is fast: NMS develops over days. SS develops within hours
  • CK is massively elevated: Often >1000, frequently >10,000. Rhabdomyolysis is the rule, not the exception
  • Low iron is early marker: Serum iron drops before CK rises. Useful for early diagnosis
  • Metoclopramide can cause NMS: Often forgotten. It's a dopamine antagonist
  • Parkinson's patients at risk from dopamine withdrawal: Abruptly stopping levodopa can trigger NMS-like syndrome
  • 17-30% recurrence: If antipsychotic needed in future, wait 2+ weeks, use low-potency atypical, start very low dose
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

163. OSTEOMYELITIS

Vertebral â€¢ Diabetic Foot â€¢ Hematogenous â€¢ MRI Gold Standard
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Infection of bone, classified by mechanism (hematogenous vs contiguous vs direct inoculation), duration (acute <2 weeks vs chronic), and location

Vertebral Osteomyelitis:

  • Presentation: Back pain (>90%), fever (50%), neurologic deficits (30% â€” epidural abscess)
  • Risk factors: IVDU, endocarditis, recent bacteremia, spinal procedures, immunosuppression
  • Location: Lumbar > thoracic > cervical
  • Organisms: S. aureus (50%), Strep species, gram-negatives (UTI source), TB (Pott's disease)
  • Complications: Epidural abscess (urgent), psoas abscess, spinal instability, cord compression

Diabetic Foot Osteomyelitis:

  • Presentation: Non-healing ulcer, probe-to-bone positive, may lack systemic signs (neuropathy masks pain)
  • Organisms: Polymicrobial â€” S. aureus, streptococci, enterococci, Pseudomonas, anaerobes
  • Key question: Can probe touch bone through ulcer? â†’ ~85% predictive of osteomyelitis

Contiguous/Post-Traumatic:

  • Open fractures, surgical site infections, hardware infections
  • Often polymicrobial including skin flora and gram-negatives

Hematogenous (Children > Adults):

  • Metaphysis of long bones in children
  • Vertebrae in adults
  • Usually monomicrobial (S. aureus dominant)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Labs:

  • ESR and CRP: Elevated in >90%. CRP normalizes faster (good for monitoring treatment)
  • WBC: May be normal in chronic osteomyelitis
  • Blood cultures: Positive in 50% of vertebral, less in other types. GET BEFORE ANTIBIOTICS
  • Procalcitonin: May help distinguish soft tissue vs bone infection

Imaging:

  • Plain X-ray: First-line but insensitive early (changes take 10-14 days). Shows periosteal elevation, lytic lesions, sequestra
  • MRI with Contrast: GOLD STANDARD
    • Sensitivity 90-100%, Specificity 80-90%
    • Shows bone marrow edema, soft tissue involvement, abscesses
    • Essential for vertebral osteo (epidural abscess?)
  • CT: Good for cortical bone detail, sequestrum, surgical planning
  • Nuclear Medicine: Triple-phase bone scan if MRI contraindicated. WBC scan more specific but less sensitive

Bone Biopsy/Culture (CRITICAL):

  • Obtain BEFORE antibiotics if possible
  • CT-guided biopsy: For vertebral osteomyelitis â€” 75% yield if not on antibiotics
  • Surgical debridement specimens: Best yield
  • Diabetic foot: Bone biopsy through non-infected tissue (not through ulcer base)
  • Send for: Aerobic, anaerobic, fungal, mycobacterial cultures + histopathology
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Empiric Antibiotics (While Awaiting Culture):

  • Vertebral: Vancomycin + ceftriaxone (or ciprofloxacin if gram-neg suspected)
  • Diabetic Foot: Vancomycin + piperacillin-tazobactam (or vancomycin + ceftriaxone + metronidazole)
  • Hardware-associated: Vancomycin + cefepime (cover Pseudomonas)

Duration:

  • Vertebral osteomyelitis: 6 weeks IV minimum (some transition to oral after 2-3 weeks if appropriate agent, adherent patient)
  • Diabetic foot:
    • Soft tissue only: 1-2 weeks
    • Osteomyelitis with residual infected bone: 4-6 weeks
    • Osteomyelitis with amputation/complete resection: 2-5 days post-op
  • Chronic osteomyelitis: Often requires surgical debridement + 4-6 weeks antibiotics

Surgical Indications:

  • Vertebral: Epidural abscess with neuro deficits (emergent), spinal instability, failure of medical therapy
  • Diabetic foot: Extensive necrosis, abscess, failure of antibiotics, exposed bone. Amputation if limb-threatening
  • Hardware-associated: Often requires hardware removal for cure

Monitoring:

  • CRP weekly â€” should decline by 2 weeks
  • ESR slower to normalize (follows over months)
  • Repeat imaging if not improving clinically
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Epidural abscess with neurologic compromise (SURGICAL EMERGENCY)
  • Sepsis or septic shock
  • Spinal cord compression
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Culture data available, on appropriate antibiotics
  • CRP downtrending
  • Afebrile, pain controlled
  • PICC line placed (if IV antibiotics continuing)
  • Outpatient IV antibiotic plan established
  • ID and/or orthopedic surgery follow-up
  • No surgical emergency
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • GET CULTURES BEFORE ANTIBIOTICS: Bone biopsy yield drops significantly after antibiotics started. Hold antibiotics for biopsy if patient stable
  • Probe-to-bone = osteomyelitis: If metal probe reaches bone through diabetic foot ulcer, PPV ~85% for osteomyelitis
  • MRI is essential for vertebral: Must rule out epidural abscess. Clinical exam cannot reliably exclude it
  • Staph aureus dominates: ~50% of all osteomyelitis. Get blood cultures â€” positive in half of hematogenous cases
  • Epidural abscess = emergency: Progressive neuro deficits need emergent surgical decompression. Don't wait
  • X-ray changes take 2 weeks: Normal X-ray doesn't rule out early osteomyelitis. MRI is far more sensitive
  • IVDU + back pain = vertebral osteo: Until proven otherwise. Get MRI, blood cultures, echocardiogram
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

164. SEPTIC ARTHRITIS

Joint Emergency â€¢ Arthrocentesis â€¢ Synovial WBC >50,000 â€¢ Urgent Drainage
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Bacterial infection of a joint â€” orthopedic emergency requiring urgent diagnosis and drainage to prevent permanent joint destruction

Classic Presentation:

  • Monoarticular (90%) â€” knee most common (50%), then hip, ankle, wrist, shoulder
  • Acute onset joint pain, swelling, warmth, erythema
  • Severely limited ROM â€” patient guards joint
  • Fever (50-75%)
  • Unable to bear weight (if lower extremity)

Risk Factors:

  • Pre-existing joint disease (RA, OA, gout)
  • Prosthetic joint
  • Recent joint surgery or injection
  • Skin infection, bacteremia
  • IVDU
  • Immunosuppression (DM, steroids, biologics)
  • Age >80

Organisms:

  • S. aureus: Most common overall (40-50%), including MRSA
  • Streptococci: Group A, B, pneumococcus
  • N. gonorrhoeae: Young sexually active adults â€” often migratory polyarthralgia â†’ monoarthritis, rash, tenosynovitis
  • Gram-negatives: Elderly, immunocompromised, IVDU
  • Prosthetic joints: Coagulase-negative staph, Propionibacterium, S. aureus
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

ARTHROCENTESIS â€” MANDATORY:

  • Do not delay for imaging â€” clinical diagnosis + tap
  • Send: Cell count with differential, Gram stain, culture, crystal analysis

Synovial Fluid Interpretation:

Finding Normal Non-inflammatory Inflammatory Septic
WBC/mmÂ³ <200 200-2,000 2,000-50,000 >50,000
PMN % <25% <25% 50-70% >90%

Key Points:

  • WBC >50,000 with >90% PMNs = septic until proven otherwise
  • WBC >100,000 = almost always septic
  • Gram stain: Positive in only 50-75% (low sensitivity)
  • Culture: Positive in 80-90% (gold standard)
  • Crystals don't rule out infection: Gout and septic arthritis can coexist!

Additional Workup:

  • Blood cultures: Positive in 50%
  • CBC, CRP, ESR: Usually elevated but non-specific
  • X-ray: Usually normal early. Shows soft tissue swelling. Late: joint space narrowing, erosions
  • MRI: If suspect adjacent osteomyelitis, or deep joint (hip, SI joint)
  • Gonococcal: NAAT from urethra, cervix, pharynx, rectum + blood/synovial culture
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Empiric Antibiotics (Start Immediately After Arthrocentesis):

  • Standard: Vancomycin 15-20 mg/kg IV q8-12h (cover MRSA)
  • Add gram-negative coverage if: Immunocompromised, IVDU, elderly, recent surgery
    • Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily OR cefepime 2g IV q8h
  • Suspected gonococcal: Ceftriaxone 1g IV daily + azithromycin 1g PO Ã— 1

DRAINAGE â€” ESSENTIAL:

  • Joint destruction occurs within days without adequate drainage
  • Options:
    • Serial arthrocentesis: Daily needle drainage until effusion resolves (often adequate for accessible joints)
    • Arthroscopic lavage: If fails serial taps, large joint, loculations
    • Open arthrotomy: Hip (difficult to aspirate), shoulder, failed arthroscopy
  • HIP = SURGICAL EMERGENCY: Difficult to drain percutaneously, high risk of AVN. Early surgical drainage recommended

Duration of Antibiotics:

  • Native joint: 2-4 weeks (2 weeks often adequate for uncomplicated)
  • Gonococcal: 7-14 days (often responds rapidly)
  • Prosthetic joint: 6 weeks + often requires hardware removal or exchange
  • Adjacent osteomyelitis: 6 weeks
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Sepsis or septic shock
  • Hip septic arthritis (surgical emergency)
  • Polyarticular septic arthritis (suggests bacteremia/endocarditis)
  • Rapid joint destruction
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Joint adequately drained (no reaccumulation)
  • Improving pain, ROM, swelling
  • Afebrile
  • CRP downtrending
  • Culture results available, on appropriate antibiotics
  • PICC line if continuing IV antibiotics
  • PT/OT arranged for rehabilitation
  • Orthopedic/ID follow-up
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Tap before antibiotics, but don't delay antibiotics for tap: If significant delay, start antibiotics. Joint damage is worse than slightly lower culture yield
  • WBC >50k, >90% PMNs = septic: This is the threshold. Don't wait for culture
  • Crystals â‰  not infected: Gout and septic arthritis coexist in 1.5% of gout flares. If high suspicion, treat for both
  • Hip = urgent surgery: Hard to drain, high AVN risk. Don't attempt serial aspiration â€” call ortho early
  • Gonococcal is different: Young, healthy, sexually active. Often polyarticular then localizes. Skin lesions, tenosynovitis. Responds well to antibiotics
  • Prosthetic joint infection needs ID + ortho: Often requires hardware removal. Long-term antibiotics. Complex management
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

165. SPINAL EPIDURAL ABSCESS

Neurologic Emergency â€¢ Classic Triad â€¢ MRI Whole Spine â€¢ Urgent Decompression
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Pyogenic infection in the epidural space â€” neurologic emergency requiring urgent diagnosis and often surgical decompression to prevent permanent paralysis

Classic Triad (Present in Only 10-15%):

  • Fever
  • Back pain
  • Neurologic deficit

Clinical Stages (Progressive Over Days):

  1. Stage 1: Back pain (often severe, localized), fever
  2. Stage 2: Radicular pain (nerve root irritation)
  3. Stage 3: Motor weakness, sensory deficits, bowel/bladder dysfunction
  4. Stage 4: Paralysis (often irreversible if >24-48 hours)

Risk Factors:

  • IVDU (most common in many series)
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Spinal procedures (epidural injection, surgery)
  • Bacteremia from any source
  • Immunosuppression
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Alcohol use disorder
  • Adjacent vertebral osteomyelitis

Location:

  • Posterior epidural space (most common)
  • Thoracolumbar > lumbar > cervical
  • May span multiple vertebral levels

Organisms:

  • S. aureus: 60-70% (including MRSA)
  • Streptococci, gram-negatives (10-15% each)
  • Coagulase-negative staph (post-procedure)
  • TB (Pott's disease with epidural extension)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

MRI WITH GADOLINIUM â€” GOLD STANDARD:

  • Image ENTIRE spine â€” can be multifocal
  • Sensitivity >90%
  • Shows epidural collection, cord compression, vertebral osteomyelitis, paraspinal abscess
  • Do NOT delay for MRI if clinical picture clear â€” emergent surgical consultation

CT Myelogram:

  • If MRI contraindicated (pacemaker, severe claustrophobia)
  • Less sensitive than MRI

Labs:

  • WBC: Elevated in 60-80%
  • ESR: Elevated in >95% (often >50)
  • CRP: Elevated in >90%
  • Blood cultures: Positive in 60% â€” GET BEFORE ANTIBIOTICS

Image-Guided Aspiration/Biopsy:

  • If blood cultures negative and diagnosis uncertain
  • Don't delay treatment for culture
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Emergent Surgical Consultation:

  • ANY neurologic deficit = emergent surgical decompression
  • Goal: Decompression within 24 hours (ideally <12 hours) of motor deficit
  • Recovery correlates with pre-op neurologic status and time to surgery

Surgical Indications (Absolute):

  • Neurologic deficit (weakness, bowel/bladder dysfunction)
  • Spinal instability
  • Failure of medical therapy
  • Large abscess with significant cord compression

Medical Management Alone (Select Cases):

  • No neurologic deficit
  • High surgical risk
  • Extensive multilevel disease
  • CLOSE monitoring: Neuro checks q4h, serial imaging, low threshold for surgery

Empiric Antibiotics:

  • Vancomycin 15-20 mg/kg IV q8-12h (cover MRSA)
  • PLUS Ceftriaxone 2g IV q24h or Cefepime 2g IV q8h (cover gram-negatives)
  • Adjust based on cultures

Duration:

  • Epidural abscess alone: 4-6 weeks
  • With vertebral osteomyelitis: 6-8 weeks
  • Transition to oral therapy possible with appropriate agents and good source control
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Any neurologic deficit (surgical emergency)
  • Sepsis or septic shock
  • Respiratory compromise (cervical involvement)
  • Post-operative monitoring
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Neurologically stable or improving
  • Post-surgical wound healing
  • Afebrile
  • CRP downtrending
  • On appropriate IV antibiotics (PICC line)
  • Rehab placement if neurologic deficits
  • ID and neurosurgery/orthopedic follow-up
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Back pain + fever + IVDU = epidural abscess until proven otherwise: Get emergent MRI
  • Classic triad present in only 10-15%: Back pain is most consistent symptom. Don't wait for neuro deficits
  • Time is paralysis: Pre-op neurologic status predicts outcome. Surgery within 24 hours of motor deficit is critical
  • Image the WHOLE spine: Can have multiple non-contiguous abscesses
  • ESR almost always elevated: ESR >20 has 98% sensitivity. Normal ESR + CRP makes diagnosis very unlikely
  • Don't LP if you suspect epidural abscess: Risk of meningitis from seeding. MRI first
  • Medical management requires close monitoring: Neuro checks q4h. Any decline = emergent surgery
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

166. CATHETER-RELATED BLOODSTREAM INFECTION (CLABSI)

Central Line Infection â€¢ Line Removal â€¢ Differential Time to Positivity
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Bacteremia/fungemia in a patient with central venous catheter (CVC) where the catheter is the attributable source. One of the most common healthcare-associated infections

Clinical Features:

  • Fever, chills, rigors
  • Hypotension, sepsis
  • May have no localizing signs
  • Exit site findings (may or may not be present): Erythema, purulence, tenderness
  • Tunnel infection: Erythema/tenderness along subcutaneous tract (tunneled catheters)

Risk Factors:

  • Duration of catheterization (risk increases after day 5-7)
  • Femoral > internal jugular > subclavian site
  • TPN administration
  • Multiple lumens
  • Frequent manipulation
  • Neutropenia, immunosuppression
  • Poor insertion/maintenance technique

Common Organisms:

  • Coagulase-negative staphylococci: Most common (30-40%), often low virulence
  • S. aureus: 15-20%, high virulence, metastatic complications
  • Enterococci: 10-15%
  • Gram-negatives: 15-20% (Klebsiella, E. coli, Pseudomonas, Enterobacter)
  • Candida: 5-10%, especially TPN, broad-spectrum antibiotics
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Blood Cultures:

  • Paired cultures: One from catheter, one from peripheral vein (BEFORE antibiotics)
  • Differential time to positivity (DTTP): Catheter culture positive â‰¥2 hours before peripheral = catheter source (sensitivity 85%, specificity 90%)
  • If no peripheral access: Draw from two different lumens

Catheter Tip Culture (If Removed):

  • Roll-plate method (Maki technique)
  • â‰¥15 CFU = colonization/infection
  • Same organism in tip and blood = confirmed CLABSI

Definitions:

  • Definite CLABSI: Same organism from catheter tip (â‰¥15 CFU) and peripheral blood
  • Probable CLABSI: Bacteremia with CVC, defervescence after removal, no other source
  • DTTP-defined: Catheter blood positive â‰¥2 hours before peripheral

Additional Workup Based on Organism:

  • S. aureus bacteremia: Echocardiogram (TEE preferred), consider ophthalmology exam, repeat cultures until negative
  • Candida: Ophthalmology exam (endophthalmitis), echocardiogram
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Catheter Removal â€” Definite Indications:

  • S. aureus â€” ALWAYS remove (high complication rate)
  • Candida â€” ALWAYS remove
  • Pseudomonas â€” usually remove
  • Tunnel infection or port pocket infection
  • Septic shock
  • Suppurative thrombophlebitis
  • Persistent bacteremia (>72 hours on appropriate antibiotics)
  • Metastatic infection (endocarditis, osteomyelitis)

Catheter Salvage (May Attempt in Select Cases):

  • Coagulase-negative staph (low virulence)
  • No tunnel/pocket infection
  • Limited vascular access
  • Hemodynamically stable
  • Use antibiotic lock therapy + systemic antibiotics
  • If persistent bacteremia >72 hours, REMOVE

Empiric Antibiotics:

  • Vancomycin (cover MRSA, CoNS)
  • ADD gram-negative coverage if: Septic, immunocompromised, femoral catheter, known colonization
    • Cefepime 2g IV q8h OR piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h
  • ADD antifungal if: TPN, prolonged antibiotics, Candida colonization, immunocompromised
    • Micafungin 100mg IV daily or fluconazole 400mg IV daily

Duration (From First Negative Culture):

  • Coagulase-negative staph: 5-7 days (if catheter removed and uncomplicated)
  • S. aureus: Minimum 4 weeks (2 weeks only if TEE negative, no hardware, rapid clearance, catheter removed)
  • Gram-negatives: 7-14 days
  • Candida: 14 days after first negative culture
  • Complicated (endocarditis, septic thrombosis): 4-6 weeks
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Septic shock
  • S. aureus bacteremia with hemodynamic instability
  • Suppurative thrombophlebitis
  • Endocarditis with acute decompensation
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Catheter removed (or salvaged with documented clearance)
  • Blood cultures negative
  • Afebrile
  • Hemodynamically stable
  • If S. aureus/Candida: Echo completed, no endocarditis
  • PICC line for ongoing antibiotics if needed
  • ID follow-up for duration guidance
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • S. aureus = remove the line: No exceptions. High rate of endocarditis and metastatic infection with retained catheter
  • Candida = remove the line: Fungal biofilms don't respond to antifungals. Also get ophthalmology consult
  • Coag-neg staph = can consider salvage: Low virulence, may try antibiotic lock. But if persistent >72h, remove
  • S. aureus needs echo: TEE preferred. 25% of S. aureus bacteremia has endocarditis. Changes duration dramatically
  • Repeat cultures until negative: For S. aureus and Candida. Persistent positivity = look for metastatic focus
  • DTTP helps when can't remove: Catheter culture positive â‰¥2 hours before peripheral confirms catheter source
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

167. DIABETIC FOOT INFECTION

IDSA/IWGDF Classification â€¢ Polymicrobial â€¢ Osteomyelitis â€¢ Limb Salvage vs Amputation
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Soft tissue and/or bone infection of the foot in a patient with diabetes, typically arising from neuropathic ulcers. Leading cause of non-traumatic amputation

Why Diabetic Feet Get Infected:

  • Neuropathy: Loss of protective sensation â†’ unrecognized trauma â†’ ulcer
  • Vascular disease: Poor perfusion â†’ impaired healing, antibiotic delivery
  • Immune dysfunction: Impaired neutrophil function in hyperglycemia
  • Structural deformity: Charcot foot, hammertoes â†’ pressure points

Signs of Infection (May Be Subtle):

  • Purulent drainage
  • Erythema, warmth, swelling, tenderness (may be masked by neuropathy)
  • Foul odor
  • Unexplained hyperglycemia
  • Systemic signs (fever, chills) = severe infection

IDSA/IWGDF Severity Classification:

Grade Clinical Features Setting
Mild (1-2) Local infection, cellulitis <2 cm, no systemic signs Outpatient
Moderate (3) Cellulitis >2 cm, lymphangitis, deep abscess, gangrene, muscle/bone involvement, no SIRS Inpatient
Severe (4) Any foot infection + SIRS (fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, leukocytosis) or hemodynamic instability Inpatient/ICU
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Probe-to-Bone Test:

  • Insert sterile metal probe through ulcer
  • If probe reaches bone = high probability of osteomyelitis (PPV 85%)

Labs:

  • CBC, BMP, HbA1c
  • ESR, CRP (elevated in osteo, but non-specific)
  • Blood cultures if systemic signs
  • Procalcitonin (may help differentiate soft tissue vs bone infection)

Cultures:

  • Superficial swabs are UNRELIABLE â€” don't guide therapy
  • Deep tissue/bone culture: Gold standard. Obtain at debridement
  • Bone biopsy: Through non-infected tissue if possible (not through ulcer base)

Imaging:

  • X-ray: First-line. May show soft tissue gas, bony destruction, foreign body. Insensitive for early osteomyelitis
  • MRI: Gold standard for osteomyelitis (sensitivity 90%, specificity 80%). Can distinguish cellulitis from osteo
  • CT: Alternative if MRI contraindicated. Good for surgical planning

Vascular Assessment:

  • ABI (Ankle-Brachial Index): <0.9 suggests PAD. May be falsely elevated if calcified
  • Toe pressures: More reliable in diabetics
  • Vascular surgery consult: If significant PAD â€” may need revascularization before wound will heal
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Empiric Antibiotics (Based on Severity):

  • Mild: Oral â€” Amoxicillin-clavulanate, or TMP-SMX + cephalexin, or clindamycin
  • Moderate: IV â€” Ampicillin-sulbactam, or piperacillin-tazobactam, or ceftriaxone + metronidazole
  • Severe / MRSA risk: ADD Vancomycin
  • Pseudomonas risk (wet/macerated, prior treatment): Piperacillin-tazobactam or cefepime + metronidazole

Organisms to Cover:

  • Acute, antibiotic-naive: Gram-positive cocci (Staph, Strep)
  • Chronic, previously treated: Polymicrobial â€” add gram-negatives, anaerobes
  • Wet/macerated/severe: Add Pseudomonas coverage

Duration:

  • Soft tissue only: 1-2 weeks
  • Osteomyelitis with residual infected bone: 4-6 weeks
  • Osteomyelitis with amputation (no residual infected bone): 2-5 days post-op

Surgical Considerations:

  • Debridement: Remove necrotic tissue, drain abscesses
  • Amputation: Consider if extensive necrosis, uncontrolled infection, non-reconstructable PAD, threatened life
  • Revascularization: If significant PAD, may be needed for wound healing

Wound Care:

  • Off-loading (total contact cast, removable walker)
  • Regular debridement
  • Moist wound environment
  • Glycemic control
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Sepsis or septic shock
  • Necrotizing fasciitis
  • Wet gangrene with systemic toxicity
  • Gas in deep tissues
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Systemic signs resolved (afebrile, WBC normalizing)
  • Local infection controlled (decreasing erythema, drainage)
  • Adequate debridement completed
  • Appropriate oral antibiotic if continuing
  • Off-loading device arranged
  • Wound care plan established
  • Vascular assessment completed (revascularization if needed)
  • Podiatry/wound care/vascular follow-up
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Probe-to-bone = osteomyelitis: If sterile probe reaches bone through ulcer, PPV 85% for osteo
  • Superficial swabs are useless: They grow colonizers, not pathogens. Get deep tissue/bone cultures
  • Check the vessels: Wounds won't heal without adequate perfusion. Always assess vascular status
  • Antibiotics don't heal wounds: Off-loading, debridement, and perfusion heal wounds. Antibiotics treat infection
  • MRSA is common in diabetic foot: Especially if prior antibiotics, hospitalization, or chronic wound
  • Wet gangrene = emergency: Rapidly progressive, life-threatening. Needs emergent debridement/amputation
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

168. BETA BLOCKER / CALCIUM CHANNEL BLOCKER TOXICITY

Bradycardia â€¢ Hypotension â€¢ High-Dose Insulin â€¢ Glucagon â€¢ Lipid Emulsion
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Life-threatening overdose of beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers causing cardiovascular collapse. Different mechanisms but similar hemodynamic effects

Beta Blocker Toxicity:

  • Mechanism: Blocks Î²1 (cardiac) and Î²2 (vascular, metabolic) receptors
  • Cardiovascular: Bradycardia, hypotension, AV block, cardiogenic shock
  • CNS: Lethargy, seizures (especially propranolol â€” lipophilic, crosses BBB)
  • Metabolic: Hypoglycemia (blocks glycogenolysis), hyperkalemia
  • Respiratory: Bronchospasm (Î²2 blockade)
  • High-risk agents: Propranolol (lipophilic, Na-channel blockade), sotalol (QT prolongation)

Calcium Channel Blocker Toxicity:

  • Mechanism: Blocks L-type Ca channels â†’ decreased cardiac contractility, vasodilation
  • Dihydropyridines (amlodipine, nifedipine): More vasodilation, reflex tachycardia (may be preserved initially)
  • Non-dihydropyridines (verapamil, diltiazem): More cardiodepression, bradycardia
  • Cardiovascular: Hypotension, bradycardia (non-DHP), heart block, cardiogenic shock
  • Metabolic: HYPERGLYCEMIA (distinguishes from BB â€” Ca needed for insulin release)
  • GI: Nausea, vomiting, ileus

Distinguishing BB vs CCB:

  • BB â†’ Hypoglycemia; CCB â†’ Hyperglycemia
  • BB (propranolol) â†’ QRS widening, seizures; CCB â†’ usually not
  • Both â†’ Bradycardia, hypotension (though DHP CCB may have tachycardia early)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Initial Stabilization:

  • ABCs, IV access, continuous monitoring
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal 1 g/kg if within 1-2 hours and airway protected. Consider whole bowel irrigation for sustained-release formulations
  • IV fluids: Bolus for hypotension (caution: may worsen pulmonary edema if cardiogenic)
  • Atropine: 0.5-1 mg IV for bradycardia (often ineffective in severe toxicity)

HIGH-DOSE INSULIN EUGLYCEMIA THERAPY (HIET) â€” First-Line for Severe Toxicity:

  • Mechanism: Insulin has positive inotropic effects independent of glucose metabolism
  • Bolus: Regular insulin 1 unit/kg IV
  • Infusion: 0.5-1 unit/kg/hr, titrate to hemodynamic effect (may need up to 10 units/kg/hr)
  • Glucose supplementation: D10 or D25 infusion to maintain glucose 100-200 mg/dL
  • Potassium: Monitor closely, supplement to keep K >2.8-3.0
  • Why it works: Shocked heart preferentially uses glucose. Insulin improves myocardial glucose uptake and contractility

Glucagon (Primarily for BB):

  • Mechanism: Bypasses Î²-receptor to activate adenylate cyclase
  • Dose: 3-5 mg IV bolus (50-150 mcg/kg), may repeat. Infusion: 3-5 mg/hr
