  • Limitations: Limited supply, tachyphylaxis, causes vomiting

Calcium (Primarily for CCB):

  • Calcium chloride: 1-2 g IV (via central line â€” caustic)
  • Calcium gluconate: 3-6 g IV (can give peripherally)
  • May repeat q15-20 min or start infusion
  • Helps temporarily but rarely sufficient alone

Vasopressors:

  • Norepinephrine: First-line for hypotension
  • Epinephrine: If refractory, provides both inotropy and vasoconstriction
  • High doses often required due to receptor blockade

Lipid Emulsion Therapy (Intralipid):

  • Indication: Refractory/peri-arrest, lipophilic agents (propranolol, verapamil)
  • Dose: 20% lipid emulsion 1.5 mL/kg IV bolus, then 0.25 mL/kg/min infusion
  • May repeat bolus twice if persistent cardiovascular collapse

Advanced/Refractory:

  • Pacing: Transcutaneous or transvenous for bradycardia
  • ECMO/VA-ECMO: Consider for refractory shock (bridge to recovery)
  • Methylene blue: For vasoplegic shock refractory to vasopressors (1-2 mg/kg IV)
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • ALL significant BB/CCB overdose requires ICU
  • Symptomatic bradycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Altered mental status
  • Any cardiovascular effects
  • Sustained-release ingestion (delayed toxicity)
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Asymptomatic >24 hours post-ingestion (longer for sustained-release)
  • Normal vital signs off all supportive therapy
  • Normal ECG
  • Psychiatric evaluation if intentional
  • Toxicology/poison center follow-up
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • High-dose insulin is first-line: Often more effective than glucagon or calcium. Don't be afraid of doses up to 10 units/kg/hr
  • Glucose distinguishes BB from CCB: Hypoglycemia = BB. Hyperglycemia = CCB
  • Sustained-release = prolonged observation: Toxicity may be delayed 12-24 hours. Observe at least 24 hours
  • Glucagon supply is limited: Pharmacy may not have enough for continuous infusion. Insulin is more available
  • Whole bowel irrigation for SR formulations: GoLYTELY until rectal effluent clear. Especially for verapamil SR
  • ECMO saves lives: Consider early for refractory shock. Bridge to drug elimination
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

169. DIGOXIN TOXICITY

Narrow Therapeutic Index â€¢ DigiFab â€¢ Bidirectional VT â€¢ Visual Disturbances
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Toxicity from cardiac glycoside with narrow therapeutic window (therapeutic 0.8-2.0 ng/mL, toxic often >2.0). Acute overdose vs chronic toxicity have different presentations

Mechanism:

  • Inhibits Na/K-ATPase â†’ increased intracellular Ca â†’ positive inotropy
  • Increases vagal tone (parasympathetic) â†’ slows AV conduction
  • At toxic levels â†’ increased automaticity (ectopy) + AV block

Risk Factors for Toxicity:

  • Renal impairment: Digoxin renally cleared (80%)
  • Hypokalemia: Increases myocardial sensitivity (K+ and digoxin compete for Na/K-ATPase)
  • Hypomagnesemia: Similar effect
  • Hypercalcemia: Potentiates digoxin effects
  • Drug interactions: Amiodarone, verapamil, quinidine (increase levels)
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Advanced age

Clinical Features:

  • GI (Often First): Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, abdominal pain
  • Neurologic: Confusion, lethargy, weakness
  • Visual (Classic): Yellow-green halos (xanthopsia), blurred vision, photophobia
  • Cardiac: Virtually any arrhythmia except rapidly conducted atrial arrhythmias

Classic Arrhythmias:

  • Bidirectional VT: Pathognomonic â€” alternating QRS axis
  • Regularized atrial fibrillation: AF with complete heart block and junctional escape
  • Atrial tachycardia with AV block
  • Frequent PVCs, bigeminy
  • Sinus bradycardia, AV block
  • Accelerated junctional rhythm
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Digoxin Level:

  • Draw level at least 6 hours post-dose (for distribution)
  • Therapeutic: 0.8-2.0 ng/mL (some use 0.5-1.0 for HF)
  • Toxicity more likely >2.0 but can occur at "therapeutic" levels with hypokalemia
  • After Fab treatment: Level will be falsely elevated (measures bound digoxin)

Electrolytes:

  • Potassium: Critical â€” hypokalemia increases toxicity. Hyperkalemia in acute massive overdose (Na/K-ATPase blocked systemically)
  • Magnesium: Check and replete
  • Calcium
  • Renal function

ECG:

  • Digoxin effect (not toxicity): Scooped ST depression ("Salvador Dali mustache"), QT shortening
  • Digoxin toxicity: Arrhythmias as listed above
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

General Measures:

  • Stop digoxin
  • Activated charcoal: If within 1-2 hours of acute ingestion
  • Correct electrolytes:
    • Replete K+ to 4.0-5.0 (but avoid in hyperkalemia of acute overdose)
    • Replete Mg to >2.0
  • Continuous cardiac monitoring

DIGOXIN-SPECIFIC ANTIBODY FRAGMENTS (DigiFab):

  • Indications:
    • Life-threatening arrhythmias (VT, VF, high-grade AV block)
    • Hemodynamic instability
    • Potassium >5.5 in acute overdose
    • Acute ingestion >10 mg (adult) or >4 mg (child)
    • Digoxin level >15 ng/mL at any time or >10 ng/mL 6 hours post-ingestion
  • Dosing (Chronic Toxicity):
    • Known level: # vials = (level ng/mL Ã— weight kg) / 100
    • Empiric: 3-6 vials for life-threatening arrhythmia
  • Dosing (Acute Overdose):
    • Known amount ingested: # vials = (amount in mg Ã— 0.8) / 0.5
    • Empiric large ingestion: 10-20 vials
  • Response: Usually within 30-60 minutes

Arrhythmia Management:

  • Bradycardia: Atropine (often ineffective). DigiFab. Pacing if refractory
  • Ventricular arrhythmias: DigiFab first. Lidocaine or phenytoin (don't prolong QT). Avoid amiodarone if possible
  • Avoid: Calcium (may worsen digoxin toxicity â€” "stone heart"), cardioversion for AFib (may precipitate VF â€” use only if unstable, lowest effective energy)

Hyperkalemia (Acute Overdose):

  • Treat with insulin/glucose, bicarb, albuterol
  • Avoid calcium: Controversial â€” may worsen digoxin cardiotoxicity (though used if life-threatening hyperkalemia)
  • DigiFab will correct hyperkalemia (restores Na/K-ATPase function)
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Any significant arrhythmia
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Hyperkalemia (acute overdose)
  • Symptomatic toxicity
  • Level >4 ng/mL with symptoms
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Arrhythmias resolved
  • Hemodynamically stable
  • Electrolytes normalized
  • Symptoms resolved
  • Cause of toxicity identified (AKI, drug interaction, accidental)
  • Medication reconciliation â€” safe to restart at lower dose?
  • Cardiology/toxicology follow-up
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Bidirectional VT = digoxin until proven otherwise: Pathognomonic. Also seen in catecholaminergic polymorphic VT and aconitine poisoning
  • Hypokalemia kills: Even "therapeutic" digoxin levels can be toxic in hypokalemia. Replete K+ aggressively
  • Avoid calcium in digoxin toxicity: Historical concern for "stone heart" (refractory cardiac arrest). Though data is limited, avoid unless hyperkalemia is immediately life-threatening
  • DigiFab fixes hyperkalemia: In acute overdose, hyperkalemia is from Na/K-ATPase inhibition. Fab antibodies restore pump function
  • Level is falsely elevated after Fab: Assay measures total digoxin (bound + free). Only free digoxin is active
  • AF that becomes regular = complete heart block: Classic sign. AF with regularized ventricular response = AV block with junctional escape
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

170. LITHIUM TOXICITY

Narrow Therapeutic Index â€¢ Nephrogenic DI â€¢ Dialysis Indications â€¢ SILENT Trial
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Toxicity from lithium, a mood stabilizer with narrow therapeutic window (0.6-1.2 mEq/L). Primarily neurologic toxicity with renal elimination

Types of Toxicity:

  • Acute overdose: GI symptoms first, then neuro. Peak effects delayed (slow tissue distribution)
  • Chronic toxicity: Insidious neurologic symptoms at lower levels. More dangerous
  • Acute-on-chronic: Most common and most dangerous combination

Precipitants of Chronic Toxicity:

  • Volume depletion: Diarrhea, vomiting, decreased intake
  • Renal impairment: AKI, CKD progression
  • Drug interactions:
    • NSAIDs (reduce renal Li clearance)
    • ACE inhibitors, ARBs (reduce clearance)
    • Thiazides (reduce clearance via Na depletion)
    • Loops less problematic but still caution

Clinical Features by Severity:

  • Mild (1.5-2.5 mEq/L): Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, tremor, lethargy, ataxia
  • Moderate (2.5-3.5 mEq/L): Confusion, agitation, dysarthria, nystagmus, myoclonus, hyperreflexia
  • Severe (>3.5 mEq/L): Seizures, coma, hyperthermia, cardiovascular collapse

Chronic Effects of Lithium (Not Acute Toxicity):

  • Nephrogenic DI: Polyuria, polydipsia (Li inhibits ADH action on collecting duct)
  • Hypothyroidism: Common, often subclinical
  • Hyperparathyroidism: Hypercalcemia
  • Chronic kidney disease

SILENT (Syndrome of Irreversible Lithium-Effectuated Neurotoxicity):

  • Persistent neurologic deficits (cerebellar, cognitive, extrapyramidal) after lithium cleared
  • Risk factors: Prolonged toxicity, high levels, delayed treatment
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Lithium Level:

  • Therapeutic: 0.6-1.2 mEq/L
  • Check q4-6h until trending down (levels may rise in acute overdose)
  • Chronic toxicity can occur at lower levels (tissue saturation)

Additional Labs:

  • BMP: Renal function, electrolytes (Na, K)
  • Calcium, TSH: Chronic lithium effects
  • Serum osmolality, urine osmolality: If DI suspected
  • ECG: T wave flattening/inversion, QT prolongation, bradycardia
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

General Measures:

  • Stop lithium
  • IV fluids: Normal saline â€” restores volume, enhances renal clearance. Avoid hypotonic fluids
  • Activated charcoal: NOT effective (Li not adsorbed to charcoal)
  • Whole bowel irrigation: Consider for large acute ingestions or extended-release
  • Stop interacting drugs: NSAIDs, ACEi, ARBs, thiazides

HEMODIALYSIS â€” Indications (EXTRIP Guidelines):

  • Recommended:
    • Decreased level of consciousness, seizures, life-threatening dysrhythmias
    • Level >4.0 mEq/L AND impaired kidney function
  • Suggested:
    • Confusion (not just lethargy)
    • Level >5.0 mEq/L
    • Expected time to Li <1.0 mEq/L exceeds 36 hours

Hemodialysis Specifics:

  • Lithium is ideal for dialysis: Low molecular weight, low protein binding, small volume of distribution
  • HD reduces level by 1 mEq/L per hour
  • Rebound: Level may rise after HD (redistribution from tissues). Repeat level 6 hours post-HD
  • May need repeated HD sessions
  • CRRT: Alternative if hemodynamically unstable, but less efficient

Seizure Management:

  • Benzodiazepines first-line
âš ï¸ ESCALATE TO ICU IF:
  • Altered mental status
  • Seizures
  • Level >2.5 mEq/L with symptoms
  • Level >4.0 mEq/L regardless of symptoms
  • Requires hemodialysis
  • Hemodynamic instability
âœ“ DISCHARGE CRITERIA
  • Level <1.5 mEq/L and stable (no rebound)
  • Neurologically at baseline
  • Renal function stable
  • Cause of toxicity identified and addressed
  • Medication reconciliation (is lithium still indicated? dose adjustment?)
  • Psychiatry follow-up
  • Education on drug interactions, hydration
ðŸ’Ž PEARLS
  • Chronic toxicity is worse than acute: Tissues are saturated. Neurologic toxicity at lower levels. Higher risk of SILENT
  • Charcoal doesn't work: Lithium is not adsorbed. Don't waste time with it
  • Volume, volume, volume: NS restores renal perfusion and enhances lithium clearance. First-line treatment
  • Check for drug interactions: NSAIDs, ACEi, ARBs, thiazides all increase lithium levels. Stop them
  • Expect rebound after HD: Lithium redistributes from tissues. Recheck level 6 hours post-dialysis
  • SILENT is preventable: Early, aggressive treatment reduces risk of permanent neurologic injury
  • Nephrogenic DI is common: Chronic lithium use causes polyuria. If hospitalized, monitor fluid balance carefully
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

171. TICK-BORNE ILLNESS

Lyme Disease â€¢ Anaplasmosis â€¢ Ehrlichiosis â€¢ Babesiosis
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Lyme Disease (Borrelia burgdorferi):

  • Early Localized (3-30 days): Erythema migrans (EM) - expanding red/pink patch â‰¥5cm, central clearing ("bull's eye") in 20%, warm but not painful. 70-80% have EM. Flu-like symptoms common
  • Early Disseminated (weeks-months): Multiple EM lesions, cranial neuropathy (especially VII - facial palsy, often bilateral), meningitis, AV block (can be high-grade), migratory arthralgias
  • Late (months-years): Lyme arthritis (large joint, especially knee - recurrent, brief attacks), chronic encephalopathy (rare)

Anaplasmosis (Anaplasma phagocytophilum):

  • Classic Triad: Fever + leukopenia + thrombocytopenia (1-2 weeks after tick bite)
  • Symptoms: High fever, severe headache, myalgias, malaise. NO RASH (unlike Lyme/RMSF)
  • Labs: Leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, elevated transaminases (70%), morulae in granulocytes (rare but pathognomonic)
  • Severity: Can be severe in elderly/immunocompromised. ICU admission in 5-7%

Ehrlichiosis (Ehrlichia chaffeensis):

  • Similar to Anaplasmosis: Fever, headache, myalgias, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, elevated LFTs
  • Differences: More common in Southeast/South-central US (Lone Star tick). Rash in 30% (adults), 60% (children). More severe GI symptoms
  • Morulae: Found in monocytes (vs granulocytes in anaplasmosis)

Babesiosis (Babesia microti):

  • Presentation: Fever, fatigue, myalgias, hemolytic anemia (can be severe). Dark urine from hemoglobinuria
  • Risk for Severe Disease: Asplenia (can be fatal), elderly, immunocompromised, HIV
  • Labs: Hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, elevated LDH, low haptoglobin. Parasitemia on smear (ring forms, "Maltese cross")

Geographic Distribution: Lyme/Anaplasmosis/Babesiosis: Northeast + Upper Midwest (Ixodes scapularis tick). Ehrlichiosis: Southeast + South-central (Lone Star tick)

Co-infection: 10-20% of Lyme patients co-infected with Anaplasma or Babesia. Consider if atypical features or poor response to Lyme treatment

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Lyme Disease:

  • Erythema Migrans: CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS - no testing needed. Treat empirically. Serology often negative early
  • Disseminated/Late Lyme: Two-tier serology: ELISA/EIA â†’ if positive/equivocal â†’ Western blot. Both must be positive
  • CSF: If meningitis suspected - lymphocytic pleocytosis, CSF Lyme antibody index
  • Cardiac: ECG for all (PR interval). Echo if AV block or myocarditis suspected

Anaplasmosis/Ehrlichiosis:

  • PCR: Most sensitive early in disease (first week). Order Anaplasma or Ehrlichia PCR based on geography
  • Serology: Acute and convalescent titers (4-fold rise). Often negative in first week
  • Blood Smear: Morulae in granulocytes (Anaplasma) or monocytes (Ehrlichia) - seen in 20-80% but specific
  • DO NOT WAIT for confirmatory tests - treat empirically if clinical suspicion high

Babesiosis:

  • Blood Smear: Ring forms (similar to malaria), "Maltese cross" tetrads (pathognomonic but rare)
  • PCR: More sensitive than smear, especially low-level parasitemia
  • Serology: Babesia IgM/IgG (may take 2-4 weeks to become positive)
  • Hemolysis Labs: CBC (anemia, thrombocytopenia), retic count, LDH, haptoglobin, bilirubin

Standard Labs for All Tick-borne Illness:

  • CBC with differential (leukopenia, thrombocytopenia)
  • CMP including LFTs (transaminitis common)
  • Blood smear if Babesiosis or Anaplasmosis suspected
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Lyme Disease:

  • Early Localized/Early Disseminated (EM, facial palsy, mild carditis): Doxycycline 100mg BID Ã— 10-14 days (preferred - also treats co-infection)
  • Alternatives: Amoxicillin 500mg TID Ã— 14 days (pregnancy, children <8), Cefuroxime 500mg BID Ã— 14 days
  • Lyme Arthritis: Doxycycline 100mg BID Ã— 28 days OR Amoxicillin 500mg TID Ã— 28 days
  • Lyme Meningitis/High-grade AV block: Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily Ã— 14-21 days. May need temporary pacemaker for heart block

Anaplasmosis/Ehrlichiosis:

  • First-line: Doxycycline 100mg BID until afebrile for â‰¥3 days (minimum 5-7 days total)
  • DO NOT DELAY treatment for confirmatory testing
  • Pregnancy: Doxycycline still recommended (short course) - risk of severe disease outweighs fetal risk. Rifampin is alternative but less effective
  • Response: Dramatic improvement within 24-48 hours. If no response, reconsider diagnosis

Babesiosis:

  • Mild-Moderate: Atovaquone 750mg BID + Azithromycin 500-1000mg day 1, then 250-500mg daily Ã— 7-10 days
  • Severe (parasitemia >10%, significant hemolysis, organ dysfunction): Clindamycin 600mg IV q8h + Quinine 650mg PO q8h Ã— 7-10 days. Consider exchange transfusion if parasitemia >10% or severe hemolysis/end-organ damage
  • Asplenic/Immunocompromised: Treat for â‰¥6 weeks + 2 weeks after parasitemia clears. High relapse risk

Prophylaxis After Tick Bite (Lyme only):

  • Single dose Doxycycline 200mg if: Ixodes tick attached â‰¥36 hours, within 72 hours of removal, in endemic area
  • Not recommended routinely - most tick bites don't transmit disease
CLINICAL PEARLS
  • Erythema migrans = treat, don't test: Serology is often negative early. EM is a clinical diagnosis. Start doxycycline
  • No rash + fever + cytopenias: Think Anaplasmosis/Ehrlichiosis, not Lyme. Doxycycline covers all
  • Doxycycline is the answer: Treats Lyme, Anaplasmosis, Ehrlichiosis, and RMSF. When in doubt in endemic area, treat empirically
  • Hemolytic anemia after tick bite: Think Babesiosis. Check smear, especially in asplenic patients (can be fatal)
  • Co-infection is common: If patient not improving on Lyme treatment, consider Babesiosis (needs different regimen)
  • Bilateral facial palsy: Highly suggestive of Lyme disease. Check serology and treat
  • Heart block in young patient: Consider Lyme carditis. Usually resolves with antibiotics, but may need temporary pacing
  • Post-treatment Lyme disease syndrome: Fatigue, arthralgias persisting after treatment. NOT indication for prolonged antibiotics (no benefit in trials)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

172. PELVIC INFLAMMATORY DISEASE

Salpingitis â€¢ Endometritis â€¢ Tubo-ovarian Abscess
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Presentation: Lower abdominal/pelvic pain (usually bilateral), vaginal discharge, fever, dyspareunia. May have irregular bleeding. Often subacute onset over days

Minimum Criteria for Diagnosis (CDC): Sexually active woman with pelvic/lower abdominal pain AND at least ONE of:

  • Cervical motion tenderness (CMT) - "chandelier sign"
  • Uterine tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness

Additional Criteria (Increase Specificity):

  • Oral temperature >101Â°F (38.3Â°C)
  • Mucopurulent cervical discharge or cervical friability
  • WBC on saline wet prep of vaginal fluid
  • Elevated ESR or CRP
  • Positive GC/CT NAAT

Causative Organisms:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Often more acute presentation
  • Chlamydia trachomatis: Often subclinical, more likely to cause tubal damage
  • Vaginal flora: Anaerobes, G. vaginalis, H. influenzae, enteric GNRs, Streptococcus
  • Mycoplasma genitalium: Increasingly recognized, may require specific testing

Risk Factors: Age 15-25, multiple sexual partners, prior STI, prior PID, IUD insertion within 3 weeks (risk returns to baseline after), douching

Tubo-ovarian Abscess (TOA): Complication in 15-30% of hospitalized PID. Palpable adnexal mass, higher fever, more toxic. Can rupture (surgical emergency). Higher risk of infertility

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Required Testing:

  • Pregnancy Test: ALWAYS - rule out ectopic pregnancy (similar presentation)
  • GC/CT NAAT: Cervical or urine. Positive in 30-40% of PID cases
  • Wet Mount: WBCs, clue cells (BV), trichomonads
  • HIV Testing: Offer to all patients with STI
  • RPR/VDRL: Syphilis screening

Additional Labs:

  • CBC (leukocytosis common)
  • ESR/CRP (elevated, can follow for response)
  • UA (rule out UTI)

Imaging:

  • Pelvic Ultrasound: If TOA suspected, palpable mass, or not improving on therapy. Transvaginal preferred
  • CT Abdomen/Pelvis: If uncertain diagnosis or concern for other pathology (appendicitis)

Laparoscopy: Gold standard but rarely needed. Consider if: diagnosis uncertain, no response to treatment, surgical emergency suspected

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Ectopic pregnancy (always rule out!)
  • Appendicitis (RLQ predominant, anorexia, migration of pain)
  • Ovarian cyst rupture/torsion (sudden onset, unilateral)
  • Endometriosis
  • UTI/pyelonephritis
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Outpatient Treatment (Mild-Moderate):

  • Preferred: Ceftriaxone 500mg IM Ã— 1 PLUS Doxycycline 100mg PO BID Ã— 14 days PLUS Metronidazole 500mg PO BID Ã— 14 days
  • Alternative (if ceftriaxone unavailable): Cefoxitin 2g IM Ã— 1 + Probenecid 1g PO PLUS Doxycycline 100mg PO BID Ã— 14 days + Metronidazole 500mg PO BID Ã— 14 days
  • Metronidazole: Recommended to cover anaerobes and BV (which often coexists)

Indications for Hospitalization:

  • Surgical emergency cannot be excluded (appendicitis, ectopic)
  • Tubo-ovarian abscess
  • Pregnancy
  • Severe illness (high fever, nausea/vomiting, peritoneal signs)
  • Unable to tolerate or follow outpatient regimen
  • No clinical response to oral therapy within 72 hours

Inpatient Treatment:

  • Preferred: Cefotetan 2g IV q12h OR Cefoxitin 2g IV q6h PLUS Doxycycline 100mg IV/PO q12h
  • Alternative: Clindamycin 900mg IV q8h PLUS Gentamicin 2mg/kg load, then 1.5mg/kg q8h (or 5mg/kg daily)
  • Alternative: Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h PLUS Doxycycline 100mg IV/PO q12h
  • Transition to oral: After 24-48h of clinical improvement, complete 14 days with Doxycycline 100mg PO BID + Metronidazole 500mg PO BID

Tubo-ovarian Abscess:

  • IV antibiotics as above
  • If no improvement in 48-72h or abscess >9cm: consider IR drainage or surgical intervention
  • Ruptured TOA: Surgical emergency - laparoscopy/laparotomy

Partner Management: All sexual partners in past 60 days should be evaluated and treated empirically for GC/CT. Patient should abstain from intercourse until treatment complete and partners treated

CLINICAL PEARLS
  • Low threshold to treat: Consequences of untreated PID (infertility, ectopic pregnancy, chronic pelvic pain) are severe. Treat empirically if clinical suspicion
  • Negative GC/CT doesn't rule out PID: Only 30-40% of PID is GC/CT positive. Treat regardless of NAAT result
  • Always rule out ectopic: Pregnancy test is mandatory. Ectopic can present identically to PID
  • IUD can stay in: No need to remove IUD unless no clinical improvement in 48-72h. Risk is mainly in first 3 weeks after insertion
  • Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome: RUQ pain from perihepatitis. Can mimic cholecystitis. "Violin string" adhesions on laparoscopy
  • Infertility risk: ~10% after 1 episode, ~20% after 2, ~40% after 3 episodes. Emphasize treatment completion and partner treatment
  • Consider M. genitalium: If not improving on standard therapy, test and treat with Moxifloxacin if positive
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

173. EMPYEMA / PARAPNEUMONIC EFFUSION

Complicated vs Uncomplicated â€¢ Pleural Space Infection
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definitions:

  • Simple Parapneumonic Effusion: Sterile exudative effusion adjacent to pneumonia. Often small, free-flowing, resolves with antibiotics alone
  • Complicated Parapneumonic Effusion: pH <7.2, glucose <60, LDH >1000, or positive Gram stain. Will NOT resolve without drainage
  • Empyema: Frank pus in pleural space OR positive pleural fluid culture. Requires drainage

Clinical Features:

  • Persistent/worsening fever despite appropriate antibiotics for pneumonia
  • Pleuritic chest pain (may decrease as fluid accumulates)
  • Dyspnea (from lung compression)
  • Dullness to percussion, decreased breath sounds, egophony at upper border
  • Signs of sepsis in severe cases

Risk Factors: Alcoholism, IVDU, aspiration, poor dentition, diabetes, immunosuppression, GERD, esophageal disorders

Common Organisms:

  • Community-acquired: Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common), other streptococci, S. aureus, anaerobes (especially if aspiration)
  • Hospital-acquired: S. aureus (including MRSA), gram-negative bacilli, anaerobes
  • Anaerobes: Often from aspiration. Foul-smelling pus is diagnostic

Stages of Empyema:

  • Exudative (Stage 1): Days 1-3. Free-flowing fluid, low WBC, normal pH/glucose. May resolve with antibiotics alone
  • Fibrinopurulent (Stage 2): Days 3-14. Loculations form, â†‘WBC, â†“pH, â†“glucose. Requires drainage
  • Organizing (Stage 3): Weeks. Thick fibrous peel ("rind") encases lung. May need decortication
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Imaging:

  • CXR: Blunting of costophrenic angle (>200mL), meniscus sign, loculated fluid. Lateral decubitus shows layering vs loculation
  • CT Chest with Contrast: Gold standard. Shows loculations, lung abscess, "split pleura sign" (enhancing visceral and parietal pleura). Helps plan drainage
  • Ultrasound: Bedside, identifies septations/loculations, guides thoracentesis. Can distinguish simple from complex effusion

Thoracentesis (ALWAYS indicated if new effusion with pneumonia):

  • Appearance: Frank pus = empyema (no further analysis needed, go to drainage)
  • Cell count: WBC >50,000 strongly suggests infection
  • Chemistry: pH, glucose, LDH, protein
  • Microbiology: Gram stain, culture (aerobic + anaerobic), consider AFB/fungal if risk factors

Criteria for Complicated Effusion (ANY ONE = needs drainage):

  • pH <7.2 (most important predictor)
  • Glucose <60 mg/dL
  • LDH >1000 IU/L or >3Ã— serum
  • Positive Gram stain or culture
  • Frank pus
  • Loculated effusion

Blood Tests: CBC, BMP, blood cultures, CRP/procalcitonin

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Antibiotics:

  • Community-acquired: Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily + Metronidazole 500mg IV q8h (covers anaerobes) OR Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h
  • Hospital-acquired/MRSA risk: Vancomycin + Piperacillin-tazobactam OR Meropenem
  • Duration: Minimum 2-4 weeks, often longer (4-6 weeks) depending on clinical response. Transition to oral when afebrile, clinically improved

Drainage - Indications:

  • Frank pus
  • Positive Gram stain or culture
  • pH <7.2
  • Loculated effusion
  • Large effusion (>Â½ hemithorax)

Drainage Options:

  • Chest Tube (Image-guided): First-line for most complicated effusions. Use large-bore (â‰¥24 Fr) or small-bore with fibrinolytics
  • Intrapleural Fibrinolytics (tPA/DNase): tPA 10mg + DNase 5mg in 30mL saline, instill via chest tube, clamp 1h, then drain. BID Ã— 3 days. Indicated for loculated effusions
  • VATS (Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery): If chest tube + fibrinolytics fail, multiloculated, or organizing stage. Can break adhesions and debride
  • Thoracotomy with Decortication: Stage 3 (organized) empyema with trapped lung. Major surgery

Monitoring:

  • Daily chest tubes output (should decrease over time)
  • Serial imaging to assess drainage
  • Clinical improvement (fever, WBC, inflammatory markers)
  • Remove tube when output <150mL/day and lung re-expanded
CLINICAL PEARLS
  • Tap it early: Any patient with pneumonia and pleural effusion should have thoracentesis. Don't wait for antibiotics to fail
  • pH is the key: pH <7.2 is the single best predictor of need for drainage. Must be measured on ABG machine (not chemistry lab)
  • Don't send fluid in heparinized tube: Affects pH measurement. Use plain syringe, send immediately on ice
  • If in doubt, drain: The consequences of not draining a complicated effusion (lung entrapment, sepsis) far outweigh risks of chest tube
  • tPA/DNase works: MIST2 trial showed reduced surgery and hospital stay. Standard of care for loculated effusions
  • Poor dentition = anaerobes: Cover with metronidazole or use amp-sulbactam/pip-tazo
  • Trapped lung: If lung doesn't re-expand after drainage, consider organizing empyema or endobronchial obstruction
  • Pulmonary/thoracic surgery consult early: Complex cases benefit from multidisciplinary approach
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

174. LUNG ABSCESS

Cavitary Pulmonary Infection â€¢ Aspiration-related
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Typical Presentation: Indolent course (weeks) with fever, productive cough (often foul-smelling/putrid sputum if anaerobic), weight loss, night sweats. May have pleuritic chest pain, hemoptysis

Primary vs Secondary:

  • Primary (80%): Aspiration in patient with risk factors. Often polymicrobial with anaerobes
  • Secondary (20%): Complication of existing condition - pneumonia, septic emboli (endocarditis, IVDU), malignancy, bronchial obstruction

Risk Factors for Aspiration:

  • Altered consciousness (alcoholism, seizures, overdose, anesthesia, stroke)
  • Dysphagia (neurologic disease, esophageal disorders)
  • Poor dental hygiene (anaerobic oral flora)
  • GERD, gastroparesis
  • Periodontal disease

Location: Aspiration abscesses favor dependent segments: posterior segment RUL, superior segments of lower lobes (if supine during aspiration)

Microbiology:

  • Anaerobes (most common in aspiration): Peptostreptococcus, Prevotella, Fusobacterium, Bacteroides. Often polymicrobial
  • Aerobes: S. aureus (especially MRSA if recent healthcare), Klebsiella (alcoholics, diabetics - "currant jelly" sputum), Streptococcus, Pseudomonas
  • Consider if not responding: TB, Nocardia, fungi (Aspergillus, endemic mycoses), Actinomyces
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Imaging:

  • CXR: Cavitary lesion with air-fluid level. Thick, irregular walls suggest abscess (vs thin-walled = bulla, cyst)
  • CT Chest with Contrast: Gold standard. Defines size, location, complications. Can distinguish abscess from empyema with air-fluid level ("split pleura" sign = empyema)

Microbiologic Workup:

  • Sputum Culture: Often contaminated with oral flora. Anaerobic culture difficult
  • Blood Cultures: Low yield but should be obtained
  • Bronchoscopy with BAL: Consider if: not responding to therapy, atypical presentation, immunocompromised, concern for malignancy/obstruction. Protected brush specimen best for anaerobes
  • CT-guided Aspiration: Can confirm diagnosis and get culture, but risk of pneumothorax, bronchopleural fistula

Additional Testing:

  • CBC, BMP, LFTs
  • HIV test (opportunistic causes)
  • Sputum AFB Ã— 3, fungal cultures if risk factors
  • Consider Nocardia (immunocompromised), Actinomyces (poor dentition, sulfur granules)

Rule Out Malignancy: Cavitary lung cancer can mimic abscess. Higher risk if: age >45, smoker, no fever, not responding to antibiotics. Bronchoscopy or follow-up imaging to resolution

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Antibiotic Therapy (Mainstay of Treatment):

  • First-line: Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h OR Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h (covers anaerobes + aerobes)
  • Alternative: Meropenem 1g IV q8h OR Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily + Metronidazole 500mg IV q8h
  • MRSA coverage (if risk factors): Add Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h or Linezolid 600mg IV/PO q12h
  • Clindamycin monotherapy: Previously standard but increasing resistance. Not recommended as sole agent

Duration:

  • Minimum 4-6 weeks, often longer
  • Continue until: afebrile, clinically improved, AND CXR shows resolution or stable small residual cavity
  • IV â†’ PO transition when clinically improved (afebrile 3-5 days, tolerating PO)
  • Oral options: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg BID, or Clindamycin 450mg QID + Fluoroquinolone

Indications for Drainage/Surgery:

  • Abscess >6 cm (poor response to antibiotics alone)
  • No clinical improvement after 7-10 days of appropriate antibiotics
  • Massive hemoptysis
  • Suspected malignancy
  • Bronchopleural fistula

Drainage Options:

  • Postural drainage: Position affected side down to promote drainage via bronchus
  • CT-guided percutaneous drainage: For peripheral abscesses not communicating with bronchus
  • Bronchoscopic drainage: Can position catheter in abscess cavity
  • Surgical resection: Reserved for complications, failed medical/drainage therapy, or malignancy concern
CLINICAL PEARLS
  • Most resolve with antibiotics alone: Unlike empyema, lung abscess usually doesn't require drainage if <6cm
  • Putrid sputum = anaerobes: Foul-smelling sputum is pathognomonic for anaerobic infection. Ensure anaerobic coverage
  • Think aspiration: Ask about recent intoxication, seizure, procedure under anesthesia, dysphagia
  • Location matters: Right-sided and dependent segments favor aspiration. Left upper lobe or bilateral should raise concern for other causes
  • Klebsiella in alcoholics: "Currant jelly" sputum, bulging fissure sign on CXR. Can be rapidly progressive
  • Response takes time: Expect gradual improvement over 1-2 weeks. Cavity may persist for weeks after clinical cure
  • Always consider TB: Especially if upper lobe, immigrant, homeless, HIV. Get AFB smears before starting standard antibiotics
  • Follow to resolution: Repeat imaging to ensure cavity resolves. Persistent cavity after treatment â†’ bronchoscopy to rule out malignancy
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

175. HERPES ZOSTER (SHINGLES)

VZV Reactivation â€¢ Postherpetic Neuralgia
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Presentation:

  • Prodrome (2-4 days before rash): Pain, burning, tingling, or itching in dermatomal distribution. May be mistaken for other conditions (MI, renal colic, appendicitis)
  • Rash: Unilateral, dermatomal distribution. Erythematous macules â†’ papules â†’ vesicles â†’ pustules â†’ crusting over 7-10 days
  • Pain: Often severe, described as burning, stabbing, or electric. May persist after rash heals (PHN)

Common Dermatomes: Thoracic (>50%), trigeminal (especially V1 - ophthalmic), cervical, lumbar

Special Presentations:

  • Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO): V1 involvement. Hutchinson sign (vesicles on nose tip) = nasociliary nerve involvement = HIGH risk of ocular disease. Requires URGENT ophthalmology consult
  • Ramsay Hunt Syndrome: VZV involving geniculate ganglion. Facial palsy + vesicles in ear canal/pinna + hearing loss/vertigo. Poor prognosis for facial nerve recovery
  • Disseminated Zoster: >20 lesions outside primary dermatome, or visceral involvement. Indicates immunocompromise. Can involve lungs, liver, brain
  • Zoster Sine Herpete: Dermatomal pain without rash. Difficult diagnosis, may need PCR of skin or CSF

Risk Factors: Age >50 (incidence increases with age), immunocompromise (HIV, transplant, chemo, steroids), prior history (can recur)

Postherpetic Neuralgia (PHN): Pain persisting >90 days after rash. Risk factors: age >50, severe acute pain, severe rash, prodromal pain. May last months to years

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical Diagnosis: Usually straightforward based on characteristic dermatomal vesicular rash. Testing rarely needed for typical presentation

Testing (Consider if Atypical):

  • VZV PCR: Most sensitive. Swab base of vesicle. Useful for atypical presentations, disseminated disease, or CNS involvement
  • Direct Fluorescent Antibody (DFA): Rapid, specific, but less sensitive than PCR
  • Tzanck Smear: Shows multinucleated giant cells. Quick but cannot distinguish VZV from HSV

If CNS Involvement Suspected:

  • LP: CSF VZV PCR and VZV IgG
  • MRI brain if encephalitis/myelitis suspected

HIV Testing: Consider in young patients (<50) or disseminated/recurrent zoster

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Antiviral Therapy (Most Effective if Started Within 72h of Rash):

  • Valacyclovir: 1g PO TID Ã— 7 days (preferred - better bioavailability)
  • Famciclovir: 500mg PO TID Ã— 7 days
  • Acyclovir: 800mg PO 5Ã— daily Ã— 7 days (less convenient dosing)

Indications for IV Acyclovir (10mg/kg IV q8h):

  • Disseminated zoster
  • Immunocompromised patients with severe disease
  • CNS involvement (encephalitis, myelitis)
  • Herpes zoster ophthalmicus with severe disease
  • Unable to tolerate oral medications

Who to Treat (Even if >72h):

  • New vesicles still forming
  • Immunocompromised
  • HZO (any stage)
  • Age >50

Pain Management:

  • Acute: Acetaminophen, NSAIDs, opioids for severe pain
  • Neuropathic Pain/PHN:
    • Gabapentin: Start 300mg daily, titrate to 300-600mg TID
    • Pregabalin: Start 75mg BID, titrate to 150-300mg BID
    • TCAs (amitriptyline, nortriptyline): 10-25mg at bedtime, titrate up
    • Lidocaine 5% patch: Apply to affected area
    • Capsaicin 8% patch: Applied by specialist

Corticosteroids: Prednisone 60mg Ã— 7 days, taper over 21 days. May improve acute pain and quality of life. Does NOT prevent PHN. Contraindicated if immunocompromised

Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus:

  • URGENT ophthalmology referral
  • Antiviral therapy (may need prolonged course)
  • Topical steroids under ophthalmology guidance
CLINICAL PEARLS
  • Hutchinson sign: Vesicles on nose tip predicts ocular involvement. Get ophthalmology involved emergently
  • Treat early: Antivirals most effective within 72h but still beneficial later if new lesions forming
  • Pain before rash: Prodromal pain can mimic MI, appendicitis, renal colic. Keep zoster in differential for unexplained dermatomal pain
  • Immunocompromised patients: Higher risk of dissemination, complications. Lower threshold for IV therapy and hospitalization
  • Contagious: Can transmit VZV to non-immune contacts (causes primary varicella, not zoster). Cover lesions until crusted
  • HCW with zoster: Exclude from work until lesions crusted. If able to cover lesions completely, may work in non-high-risk areas
  • PHN is devastating: Can cause severe chronic pain. Early aggressive treatment of acute zoster may reduce risk
  • Shingrix vaccine: Recombinant vaccine, 2 doses. >90% effective. Recommended for all adults â‰¥50, even prior zoster or Zostavax
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

176. ACUTE BACTERIAL PROSTATITIS

Prostatic Infection â€¢ Urinary Retention
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Presentation: Acute onset fever, chills, dysuria, frequency, urgency, pelvic/perineal pain, low back pain. May have difficulty voiding or urinary retention

Physical Exam:

  • Prostate: Exquisitely tender, boggy, warm on digital rectal exam
  • DO NOT massage prostate vigorously - risk of bacteremia
  • May have suprapubic tenderness

NIH Classification:

  • Category I: Acute bacterial prostatitis (this section)
  • Category II: Chronic bacterial prostatitis (recurrent UTIs, prostatic focus)
  • Category III: Chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CPPS) - most common, no bacteria
  • Category IV: Asymptomatic inflammatory prostatitis

Common Organisms:

  • Gram-negatives (80%): E. coli (most common), Klebsiella, Proteus, Pseudomonas
  • Gram-positives: Enterococcus, S. aureus
  • STI-related: N. gonorrhoeae, C. trachomatis (especially younger patients)

Risk Factors: UTI, urethral instrumentation (catheter, cystoscopy), prostatic biopsy, unprotected anal intercourse, BPH with urinary retention

Complications: Prostatic abscess (especially diabetics, immunocompromised), chronic prostatitis, epididymitis, sepsis

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Labs:

  • Urinalysis: Pyuria, bacteriuria
  • Urine Culture: Essential - guides therapy
  • Blood Cultures: If febrile or septic
  • CBC: Leukocytosis common
  • PSA: Will be elevated (don't use for cancer screening during acute infection)

STI Testing: GC/CT NAAT in sexually active patients, especially if <35 or STI risk factors

Imaging:

  • Not routinely needed for uncomplicated acute prostatitis
  • CT or Transrectal US: If abscess suspected (no improvement after 48-72h, fluctuant prostate on exam, immunocompromised)
  • Post-void Residual: If urinary retention suspected

Do NOT Perform: Vigorous prostatic massage - risk of bacteremia

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Outpatient (Mild-Moderate, Non-toxic):

  • Fluoroquinolone (preferred): Ciprofloxacin 500mg BID OR Levofloxacin 500-750mg daily Ã— 4-6 weeks
  • Alternative: TMP-SMX DS BID Ã— 4-6 weeks (if susceptible)
  • Long duration needed: Poor penetration into inflamed prostate. 4-6 weeks minimum to prevent chronic prostatitis

Inpatient (Severe, Septic, Urinary Retention):

  • Empiric IV: Ceftriaxone 2g daily OR Ciprofloxacin 400mg IV q12h PLUS Ampicillin 2g IV q6h (enterococcal coverage if risk factors)
  • If ESBL/MDR risk: Ertapenem or Meropenem
  • Transition to oral: After clinical improvement, complete 4-6 weeks total

If STI Suspected:

  • Ceftriaxone 500mg IM Ã— 1 PLUS Doxycycline 100mg BID Ã— 10-14 days

Urinary Retention:

  • Suprapubic catheter preferred (urethral catheter may worsen prostatitis)
  • If urethral catheter used, remove as soon as possible

Prostatic Abscess:

  • IV antibiotics
  • Transrectal or transperineal drainage (usually by urology)

Supportive Care: Hydration, NSAIDs/acetaminophen, stool softeners (defecation can be painful), alpha-blockers if retention

CLINICAL PEARLS
  • Don't massage: Gentle palpation only on DRE. Vigorous massage can cause bacteremia
  • Long treatment course: 4-6 weeks is essential. Undertreated acute prostatitis becomes chronic prostatitis
  • Fluoroquinolones penetrate: FQs have excellent prostatic tissue penetration, making them first-line despite stewardship concerns
  • Elevated PSA: Will be elevated during infection. Don't use for cancer screening. Recheck 4-6 weeks after treatment
  • Consider abscess if not improving: Especially in diabetics. CT or transrectal US can diagnose
  • Sexual partners: Treat if GC/CT positive
  • Retention is common: Inflamed prostate causes obstruction. May need catheter
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

177. BRAIN ABSCESS

Intracranial Suppurative Infection
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Triad (present in <50%): Headache + Fever + Focal neurologic deficit

Common Symptoms:

  • Headache: Most common (70%), often severe, may be localized or diffuse
  • Focal Deficits: Depend on location - hemiparesis, aphasia, visual field cuts (40-50%)
  • Fever: Present in only 50% (may be absent especially if on antibiotics)
  • Altered Mental Status: Confusion, lethargy, coma
  • Seizures: 25-35%, can be presenting symptom
  • Nausea/Vomiting: From increased ICP
  • Papilledema: Sign of elevated ICP

Sources/Routes of Infection:

  • Contiguous Spread (40-50%): Sinusitis, otitis media, mastoiditis, dental infection. Frontal lobe (sinusitis), temporal lobe/cerebellum (otitis)
  • Hematogenous (25%): Endocarditis, lung abscess, skin/soft tissue infection, congenital heart disease with R-to-L shunt. Often multiple abscesses
  • Post-traumatic/Neurosurgical: Penetrating trauma, craniotomy
  • Cryptogenic (25%): No source identified

Microbiology:

  • Streptococci: Viridans strep most common overall, S. anginosus group (milleri)
  • Staphylococci: Especially post-trauma/neurosurgery, MRSA if healthcare-associated
  • Anaerobes: Bacteroides, Fusobacterium, Peptostreptococcus (dental/sinus source)
  • Gram-negatives: Enterobacteriaceae, Pseudomonas (chronic otitis)
  • Immunocompromised: Nocardia, Toxoplasma, Aspergillus, Mucor, Listeria
  • Often polymicrobial
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Neuroimaging (URGENT):

  • MRI with Contrast: Gold standard. Ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding edema. Restricted diffusion on DWI (high signal) is highly specific for abscess vs tumor
  • CT with Contrast: Ring-enhancing hypodense lesion if MRI unavailable. Less sensitive for early cerebritis

Stages on Imaging:

  • Early Cerebritis (days 1-3): Ill-defined hypodense area, minimal enhancement
  • Late Cerebritis (days 4-9): Ring enhancement developing
  • Early Capsule (days 10-14): Well-defined ring enhancement
  • Late Capsule (>14 days): Thick capsule, decreased edema

Lumbar Puncture:

  • CONTRAINDICATED if: Mass effect, elevated ICP, posterior fossa abscess. Risk of herniation
  • Low yield (positive culture in only 10-20%)
  • CSF often shows elevated protein, mild pleocytosis, normal glucose

Identify Source:

  • CT sinuses/mastoids (if sinus/otogenic suspected)
  • Echocardiogram (TTE â†’ TEE if negative with high suspicion)
  • CT chest (lung abscess, septic emboli)
  • Dental evaluation
  • Blood cultures (positive in 10-40%)

Aspiration/Biopsy:

  • Stereotactic aspiration for diagnosis AND decompression
  • Send for Gram stain, aerobic + anaerobic culture, fungal, AFB, Nocardia
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Empiric Antibiotic Therapy:

  • Standard: Ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h + Metronidazole 500mg IV q8h + Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h
  • Covers: Streptococci, staphylococci (including MRSA), gram-negatives, anaerobes

Special Situations:

  • Post-neurosurgery/trauma: Vancomycin + Cefepime or Meropenem (Pseudomonas coverage)
  • HIV/Immunocompromised: Add coverage for Toxoplasma (Pyrimethamine + Sulfadiazine), consider Nocardia, fungal
  • Known source: Tailor to likely organisms (e.g., dental â†’ emphasize anaerobic coverage)

Duration:

  • 6-8 weeks IV therapy (minimum)
  • May need longer if: poor drainage, immunocompromised, osteomyelitis
  • Follow with serial imaging (MRI every 2-4 weeks initially)

Surgical Management:

  • Stereotactic Aspiration: Preferred for most abscesses. Diagnostic + therapeutic. May need repeat aspiration
  • Craniotomy/Excision: Consider if: multiloculated, posterior fossa (risk of hydrocephalus), failed aspiration, fungal abscess, traumatic abscess with foreign body

Indications for Surgery:

  • Abscess >2.5 cm (poor response to antibiotics alone)
  • Significant mass effect
  • Neurologic deterioration
  • No improvement after 1 week of antibiotics
  • Intraventricular rupture

Adjunctive Therapy:

  • Corticosteroids: Consider if significant edema/mass effect. May slow capsule formation. Use short course
  • Antiepileptic Drugs: Prophylaxis controversial. Treat if seizures occur. Consider prophylaxis for frontal lobe abscess
  • ICP Management: Elevate head of bed, mannitol/hypertonic saline if elevated ICP
CLINICAL PEARLS
  • No LP with brain abscess: Risk of herniation. Imaging first, always
  • Fever is often absent: Don't rely on fever to make diagnosis. Headache + focal deficit should prompt imaging
  • DWI is key: Restricted diffusion distinguishes abscess (bright on DWI) from tumor (not restricted)
  • Find the source: Treat source (dental extraction, sinus surgery, etc.) or abscess will recur
  • Metronidazole is essential: Excellent CNS penetration and anaerobic coverage. Always include in regimen
  • Serial imaging: Abscess may enlarge initially despite appropriate treatment. Follow with MRI every 2-4 weeks
  • Long treatment: 6-8 weeks minimum. Stopping early leads to relapse
  • Multidisciplinary: Neurosurgery, infectious disease, and source specialists all involved
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

178. PROSTHETIC JOINT INFECTION

Periprosthetic Infection â€¢ Arthroplasty Infection
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classification by Timing:

  • Early (<3 months post-op): Typically virulent organisms (S. aureus, GNRs). Wound dehiscence, drainage, acute pain, fever. Often surgical site contamination
  • Delayed (3-12 months): Less virulent organisms (CoNS, Cutibacterium acnes). Insidious onset, chronic pain, implant loosening
  • Late (>12 months): Usually hematogenous seeding. Acute onset with pain, swelling, fever. Prior well-functioning joint

Clinical Features:

  • Joint pain (most common) - may be only symptom in chronic infection
  • Joint swelling, effusion
  • Wound drainage, sinus tract (if present = definite infection)
  • Fever (often absent in chronic infection)
  • Implant loosening on imaging

Common Organisms:

  • Staphylococci (60%): CoNS (most common overall), S. aureus (virulent, worse outcomes)
  • Streptococci: Often hematogenous
  • Gram-negatives (10-20%): E. coli, Pseudomonas
  • Cutibacterium acnes: Especially shoulder arthroplasty. Slow-growing, needs prolonged culture incubation
  • Culture-negative (10-15%): Prior antibiotics, fastidious organisms

Risk Factors: Prior revision surgery, rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes, immunosuppression, obesity, wound healing problems, prior PJI, bacteremia, dental procedures

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Serum Markers:

  • ESR and CRP: Both elevated suggests infection. CRP more specific. Normal values essentially rule out infection
  • D-dimer: Elevated in PJI (newer marker)

Joint Aspiration (CRITICAL - if any concern for PJI):

  • Hold antibiotics: At least 2 weeks before aspiration if patient stable
  • Synovial WBC: >3,000/Î¼L (chronic) or >10,000/Î¼L (acute) suggests infection
  • PMN %: >80% (acute) or >70% (chronic)
  • Culture: Aerobic + anaerobic, hold 14 days (Cutibacterium needs time)
  • Alpha-defensin: Highly sensitive and specific synovial marker for PJI
  • Leukocyte esterase: Urine dipstick on synovial fluid (++ = likely infection)

Imaging:

  • X-ray: Loosening (lucency around implant), periosteal reaction. Normal X-ray doesn't exclude infection
  • CT: Better for loosening, bone destruction
  • MRI: Limited by metal artifact but can show soft tissue collections
  • Nuclear Medicine: WBC-labeled scan if diagnosis uncertain

Intraoperative:

  • â‰¥3 tissue cultures from different sites (most important for diagnosis)
  • Histopathology (>5 PMNs per high-power field = infection)
  • Sonication of explanted prosthesis improves culture yield

MSIS Criteria for PJI (2 major OR 4 minor):

  • Major: Sinus tract, 2 positive cultures with same organism
  • Minor: Elevated CRP/ESR, elevated synovial WBC, elevated PMN%, positive histology, single positive culture
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Treatment Strategy Depends on:

  • Duration of symptoms
  • Timing since implantation
  • Implant stability
  • Soft tissue condition
  • Organism virulence
  • Host factors

DAIR (Debridement, Antibiotics, Implant Retention):

  • Indications: Early infection (<4 weeks post-op) OR acute hematogenous (<3 weeks symptoms) AND stable implant AND good soft tissue AND susceptible organism
  • Procedure: Surgical debridement, exchange of modular components (poly liner, femoral head), irrigation, retain prosthesis
  • Success rate: 50-70% (higher for strep, lower for staph)

Two-Stage Exchange (Gold Standard):

  • Indications: Chronic infection, failed DAIR, difficult organism (MRSA, resistant GNR)
  • Stage 1: Remove all components, debride, place antibiotic-loaded cement spacer
  • Interim: 6 weeks IV antibiotics, then 2-8 week antibiotic holiday, confirm infection cleared
  • Stage 2: Reimplant new prosthesis
  • Success rate: >90%

One-Stage Exchange: Remove and reimplant same surgery. Selected cases: healthy host, known susceptible organism, good bone stock. Success rate 80-90%

Antibiotic Therapy:

  • IV Phase: 4-6 weeks, organism-directed
  • Oral Phase: Often prolonged (3-6 months for DAIR)
  • Rifampin: Essential for staphylococcal PJI with retained implant. Add to backbone antibiotic. Prevents biofilm formation
  • Staphylococcal regimen (DAIR): IV Vancomycin or Daptomycin Ã— 2-6 weeks â†’ then oral Rifampin 300mg BID + companion drug (FQ, TMP-SMX, doxycycline) Ã— 3-6 months

Suppressive Therapy: Lifelong oral antibiotics if: cannot undergo surgery, retained infected prosthesis. TMP-SMX or doxycycline commonly used

CLINICAL PEARLS
  • Pain is the key symptom: Persistent or new pain in prosthetic joint should prompt PJI workup
  • Hold antibiotics before aspiration: Culture yield drops dramatically if patient recently on antibiotics
  • Rifampin is magic for staph: Penetrates biofilm. Never use as monotherapy (rapid resistance). Always add to backbone agent
  • CoNS is not a contaminant: In prosthetic joint, CoNS is a true pathogen. Treat it
  • Shoulders = think Cutibacterium: C. acnes common in shoulder PJI. Request extended culture incubation (14 days)
  • Sinus tract = definite infection: No aspiration needed. Plan for surgery
  • ID + Orthopedics partnership: Complex decisions require multidisciplinary approach
  • Two-stage is more reliable: Higher cure rate than DAIR. Choose based on patient factors and organism
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

179. CIED INFECTION

Pacemaker â€¢ ICD â€¢ CRT Device Infection
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Types of CIED Infection:

  • Pocket Infection: Infection limited to generator pocket. Erythema, warmth, swelling, drainage, dehiscence over device. May or may not have fever
  • Lead Infection/Endocarditis: Bacteremia with lead vegetations. Fever, positive blood cultures, may have septic emboli (pulmonary if right-sided). Often no pocket changes
  • Combined: Pocket infection with secondary bacteremia and lead involvement

Clinical Features:

  • Fever, chills (especially with lead infection)
  • Pocket: erythema, swelling, pain, warmth, drainage
  • Erosion: device or lead visible through skin
  • Septic pulmonary emboli: dyspnea, cough, hypoxia (if lead vegetation)
  • May have subtle presentation - chronically ill with low-grade fever

Timing:

  • Early (<1 year): Usually perioperative contamination. S. aureus common
  • Late (>1 year): Often hematogenous seeding. CoNS, other organisms

Common Organisms:

  • Staphylococci (60-80%): CoNS most common. S. aureus (more virulent, higher mortality)
  • Gram-negatives (10%): Especially healthcare-associated
  • Cutibacterium acnes: May cause indolent infection
  • Fungi: Rare, usually immunocompromised

Risk Factors: Diabetes, renal failure, anticoagulation, repeat procedures, multiple leads, temporary pacing wire, longer procedure time, hematoma

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Blood Cultures:

  • Minimum 2 sets from peripheral sites
  • Multiple sets over time if subacute presentation
  • Hold antibiotics before cultures if patient stable

Echocardiography:

  • TEE: Required for all suspected CIED infections. Much more sensitive than TTE for lead vegetations
  • Findings: Vegetations on leads, tricuspid valve involvement, pulmonary emboli

Imaging:

  • CT Chest: Pulmonary septic emboli (nodules, cavities)
  • PET-CT: Increasingly used. FDG uptake in pocket or along leads suggests infection. Useful when diagnosis uncertain

Pocket Assessment:

  • Inspect for erythema, swelling, erosion, dehiscence
  • If drainage present: Gram stain and culture
  • Do NOT needle aspirate pocket (can introduce infection, damage leads)

Labs: CBC, BMP, inflammatory markers (CRP, ESR)

Lead Tip Culture: Most important culture. Send after extraction

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

âš ï¸ COMPLETE DEVICE AND LEAD EXTRACTION IS REQUIRED FOR CURE
Antibiotics alone without extraction have very high failure rate

Device Extraction:

  • Indicated for: All definite CIED infections (pocket or lead)
  • Percutaneous extraction: Preferred. Done by experienced electrophysiologist
  • Surgical extraction: If percutaneous fails, large vegetations (>20mm relative contraindication to percutaneous), tricuspid valve destruction

Empiric Antibiotic Therapy:

  • Vancomycin: 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h (covers MRSA, CoNS)
  • + Cefepime or Pip-tazo: If gram-negative suspected or healthcare-associated
  • Tailor to cultures

Duration of Antibiotics:

  • Pocket infection only, no bacteremia: 10-14 days after extraction
  • Bacteremia, no vegetation: At least 2 weeks after extraction
  • Lead vegetation: 4 weeks after extraction
  • Complicated (osteomyelitis, septic emboli, paravalvular abscess): 4-6 weeks or longer

Reimplantation:

  • Timing: Wait until blood cultures negative for at least 72 hours
  • S. aureus: Wait at least 14 days after first negative culture
  • Site: Contralateral side preferred
  • Reassess need: Some patients may no longer need device (recovered EF, transient bradycardia)

If Extraction Not Possible (Unacceptable Surgical Risk):

  • Chronic suppressive antibiotics (oral, organism-directed)
  • High failure rate, poor long-term outcomes
  • Palliative approach
CLINICAL PEARLS
  • Extraction is essential: Cannot cure CIED infection without removing all hardware. Antibiotics alone fail in >50%
  • TEE for everyone: TTE misses lead vegetations. All suspected CIED infections need TEE
  • Erosion = infection: Even if no purulence, device eroding through skin is infected. Extract
  • S. aureus bacteremia + CIED: Even without obvious pocket infection or vegetation, assume CIED infection. TEE and strongly consider extraction
  • PET-CT is helpful: When diagnosis is uncertain, FDG-PET can identify occult infection
  • Don't aspirate the pocket: Can introduce infection or damage leads. If drainage present, swab it
  • Extraction is safe in experienced hands: Major complication rate <2% at high-volume centers
  • ID + EP partnership: Complex management requires collaboration
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

180. TRANSFUSION REACTIONS

TRALI â€¢ TACO â€¢ Hemolytic â€¢ Febrile
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Acute Hemolytic Transfusion Reaction (AHTR):

  • Cause: ABO incompatibility (usually clerical error)
  • Timing: Minutes to hours, often within first 15 mL
  • Symptoms: Fever, chills, rigors, flank/back pain, chest pain, hypotension, hemoglobinuria (dark urine), anxiety, "sense of doom"
  • Labs: â†“Hgb, â†‘LDH, â†‘bilirubin, â†“haptoglobin, positive DAT, hemoglobinuria
  • Complications: DIC, acute kidney injury, death

Febrile Non-Hemolytic Transfusion Reaction (FNHTR):

  • Cause: Cytokines in product, recipient antibodies to donor WBCs
  • Timing: During or within 4 hours
  • Symptoms: Fever (â‰¥1Â°C rise), chills, rigors. NO hemolysis, NO hypotension
  • Most common reaction overall

TRALI (Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury):

  • Cause: Donor antibodies to recipient WBCs â†’ neutrophil activation â†’ lung injury
  • Timing: Within 6 hours of transfusion (usually 1-2 hours)
  • Symptoms: Acute respiratory distress, hypoxia, bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, fever. NO volume overload/cardiac failure
  • Leading cause of transfusion-related death

TACO (Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload):

  • Cause: Volume overload, especially rapid transfusion or underlying cardiac/renal disease
  • Timing: During or within 6-12 hours
  • Symptoms: Dyspnea, orthopnea, JVD, peripheral edema, hypertension, elevated BNP
  • Risk factors: CHF, renal failure, elderly, multiple units, rapid infusion

Allergic Reactions:

  • Minor: Urticaria, pruritus, flushing (1-3% of transfusions)
  • Anaphylaxis: Rare. Hypotension, bronchospasm, angioedema. Often IgA deficiency

Delayed Hemolytic Transfusion Reaction:

  • Timing: 3-14 days post-transfusion
  • Cause: Anamnestic antibody response to minor RBC antigens
  • Symptoms: Falling Hgb, mild jaundice, positive DAT. Often asymptomatic
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Immediate Steps (Any Reaction):

  • STOP the transfusion
  • Maintain IV access with saline
  • Verify patient ID and product label (clerical check)
  • Notify blood bank
  • Return blood product and tubing to blood bank

Labs for Suspected Hemolytic Reaction:

  • Repeat type and screen, crossmatch
  • Direct antiglobulin test (DAT/Coombs)
  • Plasma free hemoglobin
  • LDH, bilirubin, haptoglobin
  • Urinalysis (hemoglobinuria)
  • CBC, coagulation studies (DIC screen)

TRALI vs TACO - Key Distinctions:

FeatureTRALITACO
BNPNormal or lowElevated (>1.5Ã— baseline)
Blood pressureHypotensionHypertension
JVDAbsentPresent
Response to diureticsNo improvementRapid improvement
FeverCommonUncommon
EchoNormal EFMay show elevated filling pressures

Imaging: CXR for any respiratory symptoms (infiltrates in TRALI, pulmonary edema in TACO)

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Acute Hemolytic Transfusion Reaction:

  • STOP transfusion immediately
  • Aggressive IV fluids to maintain urine output >1 mL/kg/hr (prevents renal failure)
  • Vasopressors if hypotensive despite fluids
  • Monitor for DIC, treat supportively
  • May need dialysis if AKI develops

FNHTR:

  • Stop transfusion, evaluate for hemolysis
  • Acetaminophen for fever
  • If hemolysis ruled out, may carefully restart transfusion
  • Future: Use leukoreduced products, premedicate

TRALI:

  • STOP transfusion
  • Supportive care: O2, mechanical ventilation if needed (lung-protective)
  • NO diuretics (not volume overloaded)
  • Usually resolves within 48-96 hours with supportive care
  • Report to blood bank (donor may need to be deferred)

TACO:

  • STOP transfusion
  • Sit patient upright
  • Supplemental O2
  • IV furosemide 20-40mg (diuresis is cornerstone)
  • Future: Slower transfusion rate, diuretics between units, single-unit transfusions

Allergic Reactions:

  • Urticaria: Stop transfusion, diphenhydramine 25-50mg IV. If symptoms resolve, may restart slowly
  • Anaphylaxis: Epinephrine 0.3-0.5mg IM, aggressive resuscitation. Future transfusions: washed products, IgA-deficient donor if IgA deficiency

Prevention:

  • Strict patient ID verification (prevents AHTR)
  • Leukoreduced products (prevents FNHTR)
  • Male-only plasma donors (reduces TRALI)
  • Slow transfusion rate in at-risk patients (prevents TACO)
  • Restrictive transfusion thresholds
CLINICAL PEARLS
  • Stop the transfusion first: Any suspected reaction â†’ stop immediately. Can always restart if benign
  • Verify, verify, verify: Most fatal AHTR due to clerical errors. Check patient ID and product label at bedside
  • TRALI vs TACO: BNP is your friend. Elevated = TACO. Normal = think TRALI
  • Diuretics for TACO, NOT TRALI: TRALI is permeability problem, not volume. Diuretics make it worse
  • Fever â‰  always stop: FNHTR is common and benign. Rule out hemolysis, then may restart with premedication
  • Back pain during transfusion: Red flag for hemolysis. Stop and evaluate
  • Leukoreduction prevents FNHTR: Most products now leukoreduced. Significantly reduced FNHTR rates
  • Report to blood bank: All reactions should be reported. Critical for donor safety (TRALI) and patient safety
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

181. TOXIC MEGACOLON

Acute Colonic Dilation â€¢ IBD Emergency
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Acute colonic dilation (>6 cm) with signs of systemic toxicity in the setting of colitis

Diagnostic Criteria (Jalan Criteria - 3 of 4 + 1 additional):

  • Fever >38.6Â°C (101.5Â°F)
  • Heart rate >120 bpm
  • WBC >10,500/Î¼L
  • Anemia
  • PLUS at least one of: Dehydration, altered mental status, electrolyte abnormality, hypotension

Clinical Features:

  • Abdominal distension and tenderness
  • Decreased or absent bowel sounds
  • Bloody diarrhea (may actually DECREASE as colon dilates)
  • Fever, tachycardia, hypotension
  • Signs of peritonitis if perforation occurs

Causes:

  • Inflammatory Bowel Disease: Ulcerative colitis (more common), Crohn's disease. Often first presentation or severe flare
  • Infectious Colitis: C. difficile (increasingly common cause), CMV (immunocompromised), Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter
  • Ischemic Colitis
  • Medications: Opioids, anticholinergics, antidiarrheals (can precipitate in colitis)

Precipitating Factors in IBD:

  • Hypokalemia (impairs colonic motility)
  • Opioids, anticholinergics, antidiarrheals
  • Barium enema, colonoscopy (instrumentation)
  • Abrupt steroid withdrawal
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Imaging:

  • Abdominal X-ray: Colonic dilation >6 cm (transverse colon), loss of haustral markings, "thumbprinting" (mucosal edema)
  • CT Abdomen/Pelvis: More sensitive. Shows dilation, wall thickening, pericolic fat stranding, free air if perforated
  • AVOID barium enema: Risk of perforation

Laboratory:

  • CBC (leukocytosis, anemia)
  • CMP (electrolytes - hypokalemia/hypomagnesemia worsen dilation)
  • Albumin (low = poor prognosis)
  • Blood cultures (if febrile)
  • Stool studies: C. diff PCR, stool culture, O&P
  • CMV PCR (if immunocompromised or refractory IBD)

Colonoscopy:

  • Generally CONTRAINDICATED (risk of perforation)
  • Limited flexible sigmoidoscopy may be done carefully if: diagnosis uncertain, need to rule out CMV/C. diff superinfection in IBD
  • Minimal insufflation, do not advance past dilated segment

Surgical Consultation: Get involved EARLY - may need emergent colectomy

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

General Supportive Measures:

  • NPO: Complete bowel rest
  • NG tube decompression: May help decompress proximal GI tract
  • IV fluids: Aggressive resuscitation, correct electrolytes
  • Correct hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia: Essential for colonic motility
  • STOP all motility-altering medications: Opioids, anticholinergics, antidiarrheals
  • DVT prophylaxis: SCDs (avoid anticoagulation if surgery imminent)
  • Position changes: Rolling patient may help decompress colon

Medical Therapy (IBD-related):

  • IV Corticosteroids: Methylprednisolone 60mg IV daily or Hydrocortisone 100mg IV q8h
  • Antibiotics: Broad-spectrum (Ciprofloxacin + Metronidazole OR Pip-tazo) - cover translocation
  • Cyclosporine or Infliximab: Consider as rescue therapy if no improvement on steroids (GI and surgery input)

Medical Therapy (C. diff-related):

  • Vancomycin 500mg PO/NG QID (high dose)
  • + Metronidazole 500mg IV q8h
  • Consider Vancomycin retention enemas if ileus prevents oral delivery
  • Consider Fidaxomicin or fecal transplant in appropriate settings

Indications for URGENT Surgery (Colectomy):

  • Perforation (free air)
  • Uncontrolled hemorrhage
  • Increasing colonic dilation despite treatment
  • No improvement after 24-72 hours of medical therapy
  • Worsening clinical status (increasing WBC, fever, peritonitis)

Surgical Procedure: Subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy. Preserves rectum for potential future IPAA (in UC)

Monitoring:

  • Serial abdominal exams (q4-6h)
  • Daily abdominal X-ray to assess colonic diameter
  • Labs q12-24h (WBC, electrolytes, lactate)
CLINICAL PEARLS
  • Diarrhea may STOP: Paradoxically, as colon dilates, diarrhea may decrease. Don't be falsely reassured
  • Surgery saves lives: Don't delay colectomy if not improving. Mortality much higher with perforation
  • C. diff is increasingly common cause: Always test for C. diff, even in known IBD patients
  • Correct potassium and magnesium: Hypokalemia impairs colonic motility. Aggressive replacement essential
  • Stop the opioids: Opioids precipitate and worsen toxic megacolon. Use alternatives for pain
  • Colonoscopy is dangerous: Avoid unless absolutely necessary. Risk of perforation very high
  • 24-72 hour window: If no improvement with medical therapy in 24-72h, surgery indicated
  • Multidisciplinary care: GI, surgery, and ID (if infectious) should all be involved early
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

182. POLYMYALGIA RHEUMATICA

PMR â€¢ Giant Cell Arteritis Association
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Presentation: Bilateral shoulder and hip girdle pain/stiffness in patient >50 years. Morning stiffness lasting >45 minutes. Difficulty with ADLs (combing hair, rising from chair)

Key Features:

  • Age: Almost always >50 years (peak 70-80)
  • Symmetric proximal pain: Shoulders (most common), neck, hips, thighs
  • Morning stiffness: Prolonged (>45 min), improves with activity
  • Sudden onset: Patients can often pinpoint when symptoms started
  • Constitutional symptoms: Fatigue, malaise, low-grade fever, weight loss (30-50%)
  • NO true muscle weakness: Weakness is from pain, not myopathy. Normal CK

Physical Exam:

  • Limited active ROM of shoulders and hips (passive ROM preserved)
  • Tenderness over shoulder and hip girdles
  • No synovitis of small joints (unlike RA)
  • Normal muscle strength on formal testing

Association with Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA):

  • 10-30% of PMR patients have GCA
  • 40-60% of GCA patients have PMR symptoms
  • RED FLAGS for GCA: New headache, jaw claudication, visual symptoms, scalp tenderness, temporal artery abnormality

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Late-onset RA: More small joint involvement, RF/CCP positive
  • Inflammatory myopathy: True weakness, elevated CK
  • Hypothyroidism: Check TSH
  • Malignancy: Consider if atypical features or not responding to steroids
  • Infection: Endocarditis, TB can mimic
  • Fibromyalgia: Tender points, normal inflammatory markers
  • RS3PE: Pitting edema of hands, good prognosis
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Laboratory Findings:

  • ESR: Elevated (often >40-50, frequently >100). Normal ESR makes diagnosis unlikely
  • CRP: Elevated. May be more sensitive than ESR
  • CBC: Normocytic anemia (anemia of chronic disease), thrombocytosis
  • CK: NORMAL (distinguishes from myositis)
  • RF, Anti-CCP: Negative (distinguishes from RA)
  • ANA: Negative
  • Liver enzymes: Mild elevation (especially Alk phos) in some patients

Imaging:

  • Ultrasound: Biceps tenosynovitis, subacromial/subdeltoid bursitis, hip synovitis. Can support diagnosis
  • MRI: Shows bursitis and synovitis. Not routinely needed
  • PET-CT: Shows FDG uptake in shoulders, hips, spinous processes. Research tool, not standard

Evaluate for GCA (if any concerning features):

  • Temporal artery biopsy
  • Temporal artery ultrasound ("halo sign")

2012 ACR/EULAR Classification Criteria:

  • Age â‰¥50 years
  • Bilateral shoulder aching
  • Abnormal ESR (>40) or CRP
  • Plus scoring system including morning stiffness, hip involvement, absence of RF/CCP, absence of peripheral joint involvement

Response to Steroids: DRAMATIC improvement within 24-72 hours of prednisone is virtually diagnostic. If no response, reconsider diagnosis

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Initial Treatment - Prednisone:

  • Starting dose: Prednisone 12.5-25 mg daily (lower doses than GCA)
  • Response: Dramatic improvement expected within 24-72 hours
  • If no response in 1 week: Consider higher dose (up to 30mg) or alternative diagnosis

Tapering Schedule (Gradual - total duration 1-2 years):

  • Initial taper: After 2-4 weeks of symptom control, reduce by 2.5mg every 2-4 weeks until 10mg
  • Below 10mg: Reduce by 1mg every 4-8 weeks
  • Maintenance: Most patients need 5-10 mg for many months
  • Monitor: ESR/CRP with each taper. Symptoms should stay controlled

Relapse Management:

  • Relapse common (30-50%) especially during taper below 10mg
  • Increase to last effective dose, then taper more slowly
  • Consider steroid-sparing agent if multiple relapses

Steroid-Sparing Agents:

  • Methotrexate: 7.5-15mg weekly. May allow lower steroid dose and faster taper. Mixed evidence
  • Tocilizumab: IL-6 inhibitor. Emerging evidence for refractory cases. GiACTA trial showed benefit in GCA

Monitoring and Prevention of Steroid Complications:

  • Bone protection: Calcium 1000-1200mg + Vitamin D 800-1000 IU daily. DEXA scan. Consider bisphosphonate
  • PPI if GI risk factors
  • Monitor glucose, blood pressure
  • Pneumococcal and influenza vaccination
  • Consider PJP prophylaxis if high-dose steroids prolonged (controversial in PMR)

If GCA Suspected:

  • START high-dose steroids immediately (prednisone 40-60mg or 1mg/kg) - don't wait for biopsy
  • Add aspirin 81mg daily
  • Urgent temporal artery biopsy or ultrasound
CLINICAL PEARLS
  • Dramatic steroid response: If patient doesn't feel significantly better within 1-3 days of prednisone, reconsider the diagnosis
  • Always think about GCA: Ask about headache, jaw claudication, visual symptoms at every visit. PMR can evolve to GCA
  • Normal CK: Elevated CK means it's not PMR. Consider myositis
  • Age matters: PMR essentially doesn't occur before age 50. If <50, wrong diagnosis
  • Slow taper below 10mg: This is where relapses happen. Go slowly (1mg every 4-8 weeks)
  • Flares during taper: Common. Increase dose, control symptoms, then try slower taper
  • Can't get off steroids: If can't taper below 5mg after 2 years, consider alternative diagnosis or steroid-sparing agent
  • Screen for malignancy: Age-appropriate cancer screening. PMR can be paraneoplastic
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

183. MAJOR DEPRESSIVE DISORDER

SIG E CAPS Criteria â€¢ SSRIs First-Line â€¢ Screen for Bipolar
DIAGNOSIS (DSM-5)

Criteria: â‰¥5 symptoms for â‰¥2 weeks (must include #1 or #2)

SIG E CAPS Mnemonic:

  • Sleep disturbance (insomnia or hypersomnia)
  • Interest loss (anhedonia) â€” REQUIRED
  • Guilt or worthlessness
  • Energy loss / fatigue
  • Concentration problems
  • Appetite changes (increased or decreased)
  • Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  • Suicidal ideation

Plus: Depressed mood â€” REQUIRED (one of the two)

Screening Tools:

  • PHQ-2: Depressed mood + anhedonia. Score â‰¥3 = positive â†’ do PHQ-9
  • PHQ-9: 5-9 mild, 10-14 moderate, 15-19 mod-severe, â‰¥20 severe

Rule Out: Hypothyroidism, anemia, B12 deficiency, medications (Î²-blockers, steroids), substance use, BIPOLAR (screen before starting antidepressant!)

TREATMENT

Mild: Psychotherapy (CBT) OR medication (patient preference)

Moderate-Severe: Medication + psychotherapy

First-Line Medications (SSRIs):

  • Sertraline 50mg daily â€” Good safety, fewer drug interactions
  • Escitalopram 10mg daily â€” Well tolerated
  • Fluoxetine 20mg daily â€” Long half-life, activating

Alternatives:

  • SNRIs: Venlafaxine, duloxetine (also for neuropathic pain)
  • Bupropion: No sexual side effects; good for fatigue; avoid in seizures/eating disorders
  • Mirtazapine: Sedating, weight gain; good for insomnia, poor appetite

Timeline: 2-4 weeks for initial response; 6-8 weeks for full effect. Continue 6-9 months after remission (lifelong if recurrent)

ðŸ’Ž TEACHING PEARLS
  • Always screen for bipolar before starting antidepressant: "Have you ever had a period of unusually elevated mood, decreased need for sleep, racing thoughts?" Antidepressants can trigger mania
  • Black box warning <25 years: Monitor closely for suicidal ideation in first weeks
  • Sexual dysfunction common with SSRIs: Switch to bupropion or mirtazapine, or add bupropion
  • QTc prolongation: Citalopram max 40mg (20mg if elderly or hepatic impairment)
SUICIDE RISK ASSESSMENT

SAD PERSONS Risk Factors: Sex (male), Age (elderly/young), Depression, Previous attempt (strongest), Ethanol/drugs, Rational thinking loss, Social support lacking, Organized plan, No spouse, Sickness

Ask Directly: Ideation (passive vs active), plan, intent, access to means, protective factors

High Risk: Plan + intent + means â†’ Psychiatric hospitalization

â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

184. ANXIETY DISORDERS (GAD / PANIC)

SSRIs/SNRIs First-Line â€¢ CBT Effective â€¢ Avoid Long-Term Benzos
GENERALIZED ANXIETY DISORDER (GAD)

Criteria: Excessive worry about multiple events, more days than not for â‰¥6 months, difficult to control

Plus â‰¥3 of: Restlessness, fatigue, concentration difficulty, irritability, muscle tension, sleep disturbance

Treatment:

  • First-line: SSRIs (escitalopram, sertraline) or SNRIs (venlafaxine XR, duloxetine)
  • CBT: Equally effective as medication; combination often best
  • Buspirone: Non-sedating, no dependence; takes 2-4 weeks; good adjunct
  • Avoid long-term benzodiazepines: Dependence, falls in elderly, cognitive impairment
PANIC DISORDER

Panic Attack (â‰¥4 symptoms, peak within minutes):

  • Palpitations, sweating, trembling, SOB, choking sensation
  • Chest pain, nausea, dizziness, chills/hot flashes
  • Paresthesias, derealization, fear of losing control, fear of dying

Panic Disorder: Recurrent unexpected panic attacks + â‰¥1 month of concern about attacks OR maladaptive behavior

Treatment:

  • First-line: SSRIs (sertraline, paroxetine) or SNRIs
  • CBT with exposure therapy: Highly effective
  • Acute attacks: Benzodiazepine PRN (lorazepam 0.5-1mg) â€” limit use

Rule Out: Hyperthyroidism, pheochromocytoma, cardiac arrhythmia, PE, stimulant use

PTSD

Criteria: Exposure to trauma + symptoms >1 month from each category:

  • Intrusion: Flashbacks, nightmares, distressing memories
  • Avoidance: Avoiding reminders
  • Negative cognition/mood: Detachment, anhedonia, negative beliefs
  • Arousal: Hypervigilance, exaggerated startle, sleep disturbance

Treatment: Trauma-focused therapy (PE, CPT, EMDR); SSRIs (sertraline, paroxetine FDA-approved); Prazosin for nightmares. Avoid benzodiazepines (may worsen outcomes)

ðŸ’Ž TEACHING PEARLS
  • Beta-blockers only for performance anxiety: Not effective for GAD or panic disorder
  • Benzodiazepines are NOT first-line: Use short-term only; risk of dependence, falls, cognitive impairment
  • SSRIs take 2-4 weeks: Warn patients; may initially worsen anxiety briefly
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

185. BIPOLAR DISORDER

DIG FAST Criteria â€¢ Mood Stabilizers â€¢ NO Antidepressant Monotherapy
DIAGNOSIS

Bipolar I: â‰¥1 manic episode (may have depressive episodes)

Bipolar II: â‰¥1 hypomanic episode + â‰¥1 major depressive episode (no full mania)

Manic Episode â€” DIG FAST (â‰¥3 symptoms, â‰¥1 week or any duration if hospitalized):

  • Distractibility
  • Indiscretion / impulsivity (risky behavior, spending sprees)
  • Grandiosity
  • Flight of ideas / racing thoughts
  • Activity/Agitation increased
  • Sleep decreased (feels rested with little sleep)
  • Talkativeness (pressured speech)

Hypomania vs Mania:

  • Hypomania: â‰¥4 days, no marked impairment, no psychosis, no hospitalization
  • Mania: â‰¥7 days, marked impairment, may have psychosis, often hospitalized
TREATMENT

Acute Mania:

  • Mood stabilizers: Lithium, valproate
  • Atypical antipsychotics: Quetiapine, aripiprazole, olanzapine, risperidone
  • Benzodiazepines: Adjunct for agitation/insomnia

Bipolar Depression:

  • Quetiapine (monotherapy) â€” FDA-approved
  • Lurasidone (monotherapy or with mood stabilizer)
  • Lamotrigine (maintenance, depression prevention)
  • Olanzapine-fluoxetine combination (OFC)
âš ï¸ NEVER USE ANTIDEPRESSANT MONOTHERAPY

Can trigger mania or rapid cycling. If antidepressant needed, must use WITH mood stabilizer.

Lithium Monitoring:

  • Therapeutic range: 0.6-1.2 mEq/L
  • Baseline: TSH, Cr, Ca, ECG, pregnancy test
  • Monitoring: Lithium level, TSH, Cr every 6 months
  • Toxicity: Tremor â†’ ataxia â†’ confusion â†’ seizures
  • Drug interactions: NSAIDs, ACEi, ARBs, thiazides INCREASE lithium levels
ðŸ’Ž TEACHING PEARLS
  • Screen for mania before starting any antidepressant: "Have you ever had periods of elevated mood, decreased sleep, racing thoughts, impulsive behavior?"
  • Valproate is teratogenic: Neural tube defects â€” avoid in pregnancy
  • Lithium narrow therapeutic window: Dehydration, NSAIDs, ACEi can precipitate toxicity
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

186. CHRONIC URTICARIA

â‰¥6 Weeks Duration â€¢ Antihistamines First-Line â€¢ Omalizumab for Refractory
CLASSIFICATION & WORKUP

Definition: Wheals (hives) â€” raised, erythematous, pruritic plaques that blanch and resolve within 24 hours

Classification:

  • Acute: <6 weeks (often identifiable cause: infection, drug, food)
  • Chronic spontaneous: â‰¥6 weeks, usually idiopathic
  • Chronic inducible: Physical trigger (cold, pressure, cholinergic, solar)

Chronic Spontaneous Urticaria:

  • Cause identified in <10%
  • NOT typically allergic â€” extensive allergy testing not indicated
  • May be associated with autoimmune thyroid disease

Limited Workup: CBC, TSH, CRP/ESR. Avoid extensive testing without specific indications.

TREATMENT

Stepwise Approach:

  1. Step 1: Second-generation H1 antihistamine daily (cetirizine, loratadine, fexofenadine)
  2. Step 2: Increase to 2-4Ã— standard dose (guideline-recommended, off-label)
  3. Step 3: Add H2 blocker OR leukotriene antagonist OR switch antihistamine
  4. Step 4: Add omalizumab (anti-IgE; FDA-approved for chronic urticaria)
  5. Step 5: Cyclosporine (refractory cases)

Avoid:

  • First-generation antihistamines: Sedation, anticholinergic effects (especially in elderly)
  • Long-term corticosteroids: Use only for short flares
  • NSAIDs: May exacerbate urticaria in some patients
ðŸ’Ž TEACHING PEARLS
  • Up-dosing antihistamines is evidence-based: 2-4Ã— standard dose before adding other agents
  • Omalizumab (Xolair): Highly effective for chronic urticaria; works within weeks
  • Individual wheals lasting >24 hours: Consider urticarial vasculitis â€” biopsy may be needed
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

187. HEREDITARY ANGIOEDEMA (HAE)

C1-INH Deficiency â€¢ Low C4 â€¢ Epinephrine/Antihistamines INEFFECTIVE
DIAGNOSIS

Types:

  • Type 1 (85%): Low C1-INH level AND function
  • Type 2 (15%): Normal level, LOW function
  • Type 3 (rare): Normal C1-INH; often Factor XII mutation

Clinical Features:

  • Recurrent angioedema WITHOUT urticaria
  • Affects face, lips, tongue, throat, extremities, genitalia, GI tract
  • GI attacks: Severe abdominal pain, vomiting (can mimic surgical abdomen)
  • Laryngeal edema can be fatal
  • Family history often present

Laboratory Findings:

  • C4 LOW (screening test â€” low during AND between attacks)
