  • C1-INH level low (Type 1) or function low (Type 2)
  • C3 is NORMAL (unlike acquired deficiency)

Triggers: Trauma, surgery, dental procedures, stress, infections, estrogen (OCPs), ACE inhibitors (CONTRAINDICATED)

TREATMENT
âš ï¸ EPINEPHRINE, ANTIHISTAMINES, STEROIDS DO NOT WORK

HAE is bradykinin-mediated, NOT histamine-mediated. Standard anaphylaxis treatment is INEFFECTIVE.

Acute Attack:

  • C1-INH concentrate: Berinert (plasma-derived), Ruconest (recombinant)
  • Icatibant: Bradykinin B2 receptor antagonist (SC injection)
  • Ecallantide: Kallikrein inhibitor
  • Fresh frozen plasma: If above unavailable (contains C1-INH)

Long-Term Prophylaxis:

  • Lanadelumab: Anti-kallikrein antibody (SC every 2 weeks)
  • Berotralstat: Oral kallikrein inhibitor (daily)
  • C1-INH concentrate: IV/SC prophylaxis

Short-Term Prophylaxis (before procedures): C1-INH concentrate 1-6 hours before

HAE vs ACE INHIBITOR ANGIOEDEMA
  • Both bradykinin-mediated
  • Both present WITHOUT urticaria
  • ACEi: Can occur at any time (even after years)
  • ACEi: 5Ã— more common in Black patients
  • ACEi: Stop drug permanently; do NOT substitute ARB
HAE vs ALLERGIC ANGIOEDEMA
  • HAE: NO urticaria; C4 low
  • Allergic: Often WITH urticaria; responds to epinephrine
  • HAE: Family history common
  • HAE: Recurrent without clear trigger
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

188. ALLERGIC RHINITIS

Intranasal Steroids First-Line â€¢ Allergen Avoidance â€¢ Immunotherapy for Refractory
DIAGNOSIS & CLASSIFICATION

Symptoms: Nasal congestion, rhinorrhea (clear), sneezing, nasal pruritus, postnasal drip, ocular symptoms (itching, tearing)

Physical Exam: Allergic shiners (dark circles), allergic salute (transverse nasal crease), pale/boggy turbinates

Classification:

  • Seasonal: Pollens (trees spring, grasses summer, weeds fall)
  • Perennial: Dust mites, mold, animal dander, cockroach
  • Intermittent: <4 days/week or <4 weeks
  • Persistent: â‰¥4 days/week AND â‰¥4 weeks
TREATMENT

Stepwise Approach:

  1. Allergen avoidance (if feasible): HEPA filters, dust mite covers, pet removal
  2. Intranasal corticosteroids â€” MOST EFFECTIVE for moderate-severe
    • Fluticasone, mometasone, budesonide
    • Use daily for best effect; takes days-weeks
  3. Second-generation oral antihistamines â€” for mild or PRN
    • Cetirizine 10mg, loratadine 10mg, fexofenadine 180mg
  4. Combination: Intranasal steroid + intranasal antihistamine (azelastine)
  5. Add-ons: Leukotriene antagonist (montelukast), nasal saline irrigation
  6. Allergen immunotherapy â€” for refractory cases (SCIT or SLIT)

Avoid:

  • Decongestant nasal sprays >3-5 days: Rhinitis medicamentosa (rebound congestion)
  • First-generation antihistamines: Sedation, anticholinergic effects
ðŸ’Ž TEACHING PEARLS
  • Intranasal steroids are most effective: Superior to antihistamines for nasal congestion
  • Allergen immunotherapy modifies disease: Only treatment that changes natural history; 3-5 years
  • Non-allergic rhinitis exists: Vasomotor rhinitis â€” triggered by irritants, temperature; treat with ipratropium nasal
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

189. FOOD ALLERGY

IgE-Mediated = Epinephrine â€¢ Big 9 Allergens â€¢ Oral Immunotherapy Emerging
TYPES & DIAGNOSIS

IgE-Mediated (Type I): Minutes to 2 hours; urticaria, angioedema, anaphylaxis, vomiting

Non-IgE-Mediated: Hours to days; enterocolitis (FPIES), eosinophilic esophagitis

Food Intolerance (Non-Immune): Lactose intolerance â€” GI symptoms only, not allergic

"Big 9" Allergens: Peanut, tree nuts, milk, egg, wheat, soy, fish, shellfish, sesame

Diagnosis:

  • History is most important: Timing, symptoms, reproducibility
  • Skin prick testing: High NPV; positive doesn't confirm clinical allergy
  • Specific IgE: Same limitations
  • Oral food challenge: Gold standard (supervised)
MANAGEMENT

All Patients with IgE-Mediated Food Allergy:

  • Strict avoidance of allergen
  • Epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen) â€” carry at all times
  • Education on label reading
  • Anaphylaxis action plan
  • Medic-Alert bracelet

Oral Immunotherapy (OIT):

  • FDA-approved for peanut (Palforzia) in children/adolescents
  • Reduces risk of severe reaction to accidental exposure
  • Does NOT cure allergy; must continue avoidance
ðŸ’Ž TEACHING PEARLS
  • Food-dependent exercise-induced anaphylaxis: Anaphylaxis occurs when exercise follows specific food (wheat, shellfish). Either alone doesn't cause symptoms
  • Oral allergy syndrome: Pollen-food cross-reactivity; oral tingling with raw fruits/vegetables; usually not systemic
  • Most children outgrow milk, egg, soy, wheat allergy: Peanut, tree nut, fish, shellfish usually lifelong
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

190. GERIATRIC SYNDROMES (FALLS / BEERS / ELDER ABUSE)

Multifactorial Falls Assessment â€¢ Beers Criteria â€¢ Mandatory Reporting
FALL PREVENTION

Annual Screening: "Have you fallen in the past year? Do you feel unsteady? Do you worry about falling?" â€” Yes to any â†’ Full assessment

Assessment:

  • Timed Up and Go (TUG): Rise, walk 3m, return, sit. â‰¥12 seconds = increased risk
  • Orthostatic vitals
  • Vision screening
  • Medication review (see Beers Criteria)
  • Footwear assessment
  • Home safety evaluation

Evidence-Based Interventions:

  • Exercise (balance + strength): Most effective (Tai Chi, PT)
  • Vitamin D 800-1000 IU daily if deficient
  • Medication reduction: Stop fall-risk medications
  • Home modifications: Remove rugs, improve lighting, grab bars
BEERS CRITERIA â€” MEDICATIONS TO AVOID

High-Risk Medications in Elderly:

ClassExamplesConcern
First-gen antihistaminesDiphenhydramine, hydroxyzineAnticholinergic; confusion, falls
BenzodiazepinesAllFalls, fractures, cognitive impairment
Non-benzo hypnoticsZolpidem, eszopicloneFalls, minimal benefit
Muscle relaxantsCyclobenzaprine, methocarbamolAnticholinergic; poorly tolerated
Long-acting sulfonylureasGlyburideProlonged hypoglycemia
NSAIDs (chronic)AllGI bleed, AKI, CV events
PPIs (>8 weeks)All without indicationC. diff, fractures, hypomagnesemia
AnticholinergicsOxybutynin, TCAsConfusion, falls, constipation

Deprescribing Approach: Review all medications â†’ Identify PIMs â†’ Assess ongoing indication â†’ Prioritize by harm â†’ Taper appropriately â†’ Monitor

ELDER ABUSE

Types: Physical, emotional, sexual, financial, neglect, self-neglect

Red Flags:

  • Unexplained injuries or injuries in various stages of healing
  • Delay in seeking care
  • Inconsistent history
  • Poor hygiene, malnutrition, dehydration
  • Fearful behavior around caregiver
  • Caregiver speaks for patient, won't leave room
âš ï¸ MANDATORY REPORTING

Most states require reporting suspected elder abuse to Adult Protective Services (APS). Document carefully. Report even if not certain.

â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

191. PREVENTIVE CARE & CANCER SCREENING

USPSTF Grades â€¢ Age-Appropriate Screening â€¢ Know When to Stop
USPSTF GRADING
  • Grade A: High certainty of substantial benefit â†’ RECOMMEND
  • Grade B: Moderate-high certainty of moderate benefit â†’ RECOMMEND
  • Grade C: Small benefit â†’ OFFER SELECTIVELY (shared decision-making)
  • Grade D: No benefit or harms outweigh â†’ DO NOT OFFER
  • Grade I: Insufficient evidence
CANCER SCREENING (USPSTF A/B)
CancerPopulationMethodInterval
ColorectalAge 45-75Colonoscopy OR FIT OR FIT-DNA10y / 1y / 1-3y
BreastWomen 40-74MammographyEvery 2 years
CervicalWomen 21-65Pap Â± HPVEvery 3-5 years
Lung50-80, â‰¥20 pack-years, current/quit <15yLow-dose CTAnnual

When to STOP Screening:

  • Life expectancy <10 years
  • Age >75 for CRC (individualize 76-85; stop >85)
  • Age >65 for cervical if adequate prior screening
OTHER SCREENINGS

Recommended:

  • AAA: Men 65-75 who ever smoked â€” ONE TIME ultrasound
  • Hepatitis C: All adults 18-79 at least once
  • Hepatitis B: All adults at least once
  • HIV: All adults 15-65 at least once
  • Diabetes: Adults 35-70 with overweight/obesity
  • Depression: All adults (PHQ-2)
  • Osteoporosis (DEXA): Women â‰¥65

Grade D (Do NOT Screen):

  • Ovarian cancer (CA-125, ultrasound)
  • Routine PSA (shared decision 55-69)
  • Thyroid cancer (palpation, ultrasound)
  • Carotid stenosis in asymptomatic
  • Routine ECG in asymptomatic low-risk
  • Aspirin for primary prevention age â‰¥60
IMMUNIZATIONS (ADULTS)
  • Influenza: Annual, all adults (high-dose for â‰¥65)
  • COVID-19: Updated vaccine annually
  • Tdap: Once, then Td every 10 years
  • Pneumococcal: PCV20 OR PCV15â†’PPSV23 for all â‰¥65
  • Shingles (RZV): 2 doses, age â‰¥50
  • Hepatitis B: 3-dose series if not immune
  • RSV: Single dose, age â‰¥60 (shared decision)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

192. MEDICAL ETHICS & CAPACITY ASSESSMENT

Four Principles â€¢ Decision-Specific Capacity â€¢ Advance Directives
FOUR PRINCIPLES OF MEDICAL ETHICS
  • Autonomy: Respect patient's right to make decisions (informed consent, right to refuse)
  • Beneficence: Act in patient's best interest
  • Non-maleficence: Do no harm
  • Justice: Fair distribution of resources
INFORMED CONSENT

Elements:

  1. Disclosure: Nature of procedure, risks, benefits, alternatives
  2. Understanding: Patient comprehends information
  3. Voluntariness: Decision made without coercion
  4. Competence: Patient has capacity to decide
  5. Consent: Patient agrees to proceed

Exceptions: Emergency (imminent threat, no surrogate), waiver, therapeutic privilege (rare), incapacity (surrogate consents)

CAPACITY ASSESSMENT

Capacity vs Competence:

  • Capacity: Clinical determination by physician; decision-specific
  • Competence: Legal determination by court; global

Four Elements of Capacity:

  1. Understanding: Can state the medical problem and proposed treatment
  2. Appreciation: Acknowledges how this applies to their situation
  3. Reasoning: Can weigh risks/benefits and consider alternatives
  4. Choice: Can clearly communicate a decision
âš ï¸ KEY PRINCIPLES
  • Capacity is decision-specific â€” patient may have capacity for some decisions but not others
  • Capacity can fluctuate (delirium, time of day)
  • Disagreement with physician â‰  lack of capacity
  • Patient WITH capacity can refuse any treatment, even life-saving
ADVANCE DIRECTIVES

Types:

  • Living Will: Written preferences for specific situations (terminal illness, PVS)
  • Healthcare Proxy/Durable POA: Designates decision-maker if patient loses capacity
  • POLST/MOLST: Physician orders for life-sustaining treatment â€” actionable medical orders

DNR/DNI:

  • DNR = No CPR; DNI = No intubation
  • DNR/DNI does NOT mean "do not treat"
  • Address before surgery â€” may suspend during procedure with consent

Surrogate Hierarchy (if no proxy): Spouse â†’ Adult children â†’ Parents â†’ Siblings â†’ Other family

Decision Standards:

  • Substituted judgment: What would patient want? (preferred)
  • Best interest: If patient's wishes unknown
ðŸ’Ž TEACHING PEARLS
  • Withholding = Withdrawing treatment: Ethically and legally equivalent
  • Palliative care â‰  Hospice: Palliative can be concurrent with curative treatment
  • Break confidentiality when: Imminent harm to identifiable third party, mandatory reporting (abuse, certain diseases), court order
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

193. POLYCYSTIC OVARY SYNDROME (PCOS)

Rotterdam Criteria â€¢ Insulin Resistance â€¢ Metabolic Syndrome
DIAGNOSIS â€” ROTTERDAM CRITERIA (2 of 3)
  1. Oligo/anovulation: Irregular menses (<8 cycles/year or cycles >35 days)
  2. Clinical or biochemical hyperandrogenism: Hirsutism, acne, alopecia; elevated free testosterone
  3. Polycystic ovaries on ultrasound: â‰¥12 follicles (2-9mm) per ovary OR ovarian volume >10mL

Rule Out: Thyroid disease (TSH), hyperprolactinemia, non-classic CAH (17-OH progesterone), Cushing's

Labs: Total/free testosterone, DHEA-S, LH:FSH ratio often >2:1 (not diagnostic), fasting glucose/insulin, lipid panel

TREATMENT

Lifestyle: Weight loss (5-10% improves ovulation and metabolic parameters)

Menstrual Irregularity/Hyperandrogenism:

  • Combined OCPs: First-line for menstrual regulation and hirsutism
  • Spironolactone: Anti-androgen for hirsutism (teratogenic â€” requires contraception)
  • Metformin: Insulin sensitizer; second-line for metabolic features

Infertility: Letrozole (first-line for ovulation induction), clomiphene (second-line)

Screen for: Metabolic syndrome, T2DM (OGTT preferred), OSA, depression, endometrial hyperplasia (unopposed estrogen)

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Letrozole > clomiphene for ovulation induction (higher live birth rates)
  • Endometrial protection required: OCPs or cyclic progestins to prevent hyperplasia/cancer
  • OGTT preferred over fasting glucose for diabetes screening in PCOS
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

194. INFECTIOUS MONONUCLEOSIS

EBV â€¢ Heterophile Antibody â€¢ Avoid Contact Sports
CLINICAL FEATURES & DIAGNOSIS

Classic Triad: Fever, pharyngitis (exudative), lymphadenopathy (posterior cervical)

Other Features: Fatigue (can be prolonged), splenomegaly (50%), hepatomegaly, palatal petechiae, periorbital edema

Labs:

  • Atypical lymphocytosis (>10% atypical lymphocytes)
  • Heterophile antibody (Monospot): 85% sensitive by week 2; may be negative early or in children
  • EBV-specific antibodies: VCA IgM (acute), VCA IgG (past), EBNA (appears later = past infection)
  • Mild transaminitis common

Differential: CMV (heterophile-negative mono), HIV acute infection, strep pharyngitis, toxoplasmosis

MANAGEMENT

Supportive: Rest, hydration, acetaminophen/NSAIDs for pain/fever

Avoid:

  • Contact sports for 3-4 weeks (splenic rupture risk) â€” some recommend until spleen normalizes
  • Amoxicillin/ampicillin: Causes diffuse maculopapular rash (not true allergy â€” do NOT label as penicillin allergic)

Steroids: Only if airway obstruction from tonsillar enlargement

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Ampicillin rash â‰  penicillin allergy: EBV-specific phenomenon; don't mislabel
  • Heterophile-negative mono: Think CMV, HIV, or early EBV (check EBV-specific serology)
  • Splenic rupture: Rare but life-threatening; avoid contact sports Ã— 3-4 weeks minimum
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

195. ADULT-ONSET STILL'S DISEASE (AOSD)

Quotidian Fever â€¢ Salmon-Colored Rash â€¢ Ferritin >10,000
CLINICAL FEATURES â€” YAMAGUCHI CRITERIA

Major Criteria:

  • Quotidian fever â‰¥39Â°C for â‰¥1 week: Daily spikes, returns to normal
  • Arthralgia/arthritis â‰¥2 weeks
  • Typical rash: Salmon-colored, evanescent, maculopapular; appears with fever
  • Leukocytosis â‰¥10,000 with â‰¥80% granulocytes

Minor Criteria: Sore throat, lymphadenopathy/splenomegaly, liver dysfunction, negative ANA and RF

Diagnosis: â‰¥5 criteria (â‰¥2 major) + exclusion of infection, malignancy, other rheumatic diseases

LABS & TREATMENT

Characteristic Labs:

  • Ferritin markedly elevated (often >10,000 ng/mL) â€” highly suggestive
  • Glycosylated ferritin <20% (more specific)
  • Elevated ESR/CRP, leukocytosis, anemia of chronic disease, elevated LFTs
  • ANA and RF typically NEGATIVE

Treatment:

  • NSAIDs: Mild disease
  • Corticosteroids: Moderate-severe (prednisone 0.5-1 mg/kg)
  • IL-1 inhibitors (anakinra, canakinumab): Highly effective, often first-line steroid-sparing
  • IL-6 inhibitors (tocilizumab): Alternative
  • Methotrexate for chronic arthritis

Complications: Macrophage activation syndrome (MAS) â€” medical emergency

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Ferritin >10,000: Think Still's disease (or MAS, HLH)
  • Quotidian fever + salmon rash + negative ANA/RF + sky-high ferritin = AOSD
  • IL-1 inhibitors highly effective: Anakinra often dramatic response
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

196. BEHÃ‡ET'S DISEASE

Oral + Genital Ulcers â€¢ Uveitis â€¢ Pathergy â€¢ Silk Road Disease
CLINICAL FEATURES

Required: Recurrent oral ulcers (â‰¥3 episodes/year) â€” painful aphthous ulcers

Plus â‰¥2 of:

  • Genital ulcers: Painful, scarring (scrotal/vulvar)
  • Eye involvement: Anterior/posterior uveitis, retinal vasculitis â€” can cause blindness
  • Skin lesions: Erythema nodosum, pseudofolliculitis, papulopustular lesions
  • Positive pathergy test: Papule/pustule at site of needle prick (24-48h)

Other Features: CNS (neuro-BehÃ§et's â€” meningoencephalitis, sinus thrombosis), vascular (arterial aneurysms, DVT), GI (ileocecal ulcers like Crohn's), arthritis

Demographics: "Silk Road" â€” Turkey, Middle East, East Asia; young adults; HLA-B51 associated

TREATMENT

Mucocutaneous: Topical steroids, colchicine, apremilast

Ocular (sight-threatening): High-dose steroids + azathioprine or anti-TNF (infliximab, adalimumab)

Vascular/Neurologic: High-dose steroids + immunosuppression (azathioprine, cyclophosphamide, anti-TNF)

Venous thrombosis: Anticoagulation controversial; immunosuppression may be more important

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Oral + genital ulcers + uveitis = BehÃ§et's until proven otherwise
  • Pathergy test: Pustule at needle stick site â€” fairly specific but not sensitive
  • Leading cause of blindness in BehÃ§et's: Posterior uveitis â€” requires aggressive treatment
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

197. RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

Symmetric Polyarthritis â€¢ RF/Anti-CCP â€¢ Early DMARD Therapy
CLINICAL FEATURES & DIAGNOSIS

Classic Presentation: Symmetric polyarthritis affecting small joints â€” MCP, PIP, wrists, MTP. Morning stiffness >1 hour (inflammatory)

Joints Spared: DIP joints (think OA, psoriatic), thoracolumbar spine

Deformities (Late): Ulnar deviation, swan-neck, boutonniÃ¨re, Z-thumb

Extra-Articular: Rheumatoid nodules (extensor surfaces), interstitial lung disease, pericarditis, Felty syndrome (RA + splenomegaly + neutropenia), scleritis, vasculitis

Labs:

  • RF: 70-80% sensitive; not specific (also in SjÃ¶gren's, HCV, elderly)
  • Anti-CCP: More specific (~95%); predicts erosive disease
  • Elevated ESR/CRP, anemia of chronic disease

Imaging: X-ray â€” periarticular osteopenia, joint space narrowing, erosions (marginal). MRI/US more sensitive early

TREATMENT â€” TREAT TO TARGET

Principle: Early aggressive treatment prevents joint damage. Target = remission or low disease activity

First-Line:

  • Methotrexate: Anchor drug; 15-25mg weekly + folic acid
  • Monitor: CBC, LFTs, creatinine; avoid alcohol; teratogenic

If Inadequate Response:

  • Add biologic DMARD: TNF inhibitors (adalimumab, etanercept), IL-6 inhibitors (tocilizumab), T-cell costimulation blocker (abatacept), B-cell depletion (rituximab)
  • JAK inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, upadacitinib

Adjuncts: NSAIDs (symptom control only), low-dose prednisone (bridge, â‰¤3 months)

Screening Before Biologics: TB (quantiferon/PPD), hepatitis B/C, assess infection risk

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Anti-CCP + RF = high specificity and predicts erosive disease
  • Methotrexate is first-line â€” start early to prevent joint destruction
  • Screen for latent TB before starting biologics (especially TNF inhibitors)
  • C-spine instability: Atlantoaxial subluxation â€” assess before intubation/surgery
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

198. SPONDYLOARTHROPATHIES

HLA-B27 â€¢ Axial Involvement â€¢ Enthesitis â€¢ RF-Negative
OVERVIEW

Common Features: Inflammatory back pain, sacroiliitis, enthesitis (tendon/ligament insertions), dactylitis ("sausage digit"), uveitis, HLA-B27 association, RF-negative

Types:

  • Ankylosing Spondylitis: Axial predominant; young men; bamboo spine
  • Psoriatic Arthritis: Skin psoriasis + arthritis (DIP involvement, dactylitis, pencil-in-cup)
  • Reactive Arthritis: Post-infectious (Chlamydia, enteric); "can't see, can't pee, can't climb a tree"
  • Enteropathic Arthritis: Associated with IBD
ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

Inflammatory Back Pain (â‰¥4 of 5): Age onset <40, insidious, improves with exercise, no improvement with rest, night pain

Imaging: Sacroiliitis on X-ray (bilateral, symmetric) or MRI (bone marrow edema). Late: bamboo spine, squaring of vertebrae

Extra-Articular: Acute anterior uveitis (30%), aortitis/AR, apical pulmonary fibrosis, IgA nephropathy

Treatment: NSAIDs (first-line â€” continuous), physical therapy. If inadequate: TNF inhibitors or IL-17 inhibitors (secukinumab). Methotrexate NOT effective for axial disease

PSORIATIC ARTHRITIS

Patterns: DIP arthritis (classic), asymmetric oligoarthritis, symmetric polyarthritis (RA-like), spondylitis, arthritis mutilans

Clues: Nail pitting/onycholysis, dactylitis, enthesitis, skin psoriasis (may be hidden â€” scalp, umbilicus, gluteal cleft)

X-ray: Pencil-in-cup deformity, periostitis, DIP erosions

Treatment: NSAIDs, DMARDs (methotrexate for peripheral), TNF inhibitors, IL-17 inhibitors, IL-12/23 inhibitors (ustekinumab)

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Inflammatory back pain + young male + HLA-B27 = ankylosing spondylitis
  • DIP involvement: Psoriatic arthritis or OA (NOT RA)
  • TNF inhibitors first-line biologic for axial spondyloarthropathy
  • Methotrexate doesn't work for axial disease â€” only peripheral arthritis
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

199. OSTEOARTHRITIS

Degenerative â€¢ DIP/PIP/Knee/Hip â€¢ Osteophytes â€¢ Non-Inflammatory
CLINICAL FEATURES

Presentation: Joint pain worse with use, better with rest. Stiffness <30 minutes (vs >1 hour in RA)

Joints Affected: DIP (Heberden's nodes), PIP (Bouchard's nodes), first CMC, knees, hips, cervical/lumbar spine. MCP spared (think RA)

Exam: Bony enlargement, crepitus, reduced ROM, no warmth/erythema (non-inflammatory)

X-ray Findings: Joint space narrowing (asymmetric), osteophytes, subchondral sclerosis, subchondral cysts

Labs: Normal ESR/CRP, RF negative, synovial fluid non-inflammatory (WBC <2000)

TREATMENT

Non-Pharmacologic (First-Line): Weight loss, exercise (strengthening, aerobic), physical therapy, assistive devices

Pharmacologic:

  • Topical NSAIDs: First-line for knee OA
  • Acetaminophen: Modest benefit; safer than oral NSAIDs
  • Oral NSAIDs: Effective but GI/CV/renal risks; use lowest dose, shortest duration
  • Intra-articular steroids: Short-term relief; limit frequency
  • Duloxetine: Adjunct for chronic OA pain

NOT Recommended: Glucosamine/chondroitin (no proven benefit), hyaluronic acid injections (mixed evidence), opioids

Surgery: Joint replacement for severe, refractory disease

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • DIP + PIP involvement = OA; MCP + PIP = RA
  • Topical NSAIDs first-line for knee OA (better safety profile)
  • Inflammatory OA of hands: Erosive OA â€” DIP/PIP erosions, more pain; can mimic inflammatory arthritis
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

200. LUPUS NEPHRITIS

ISN/RPS Classification â€¢ Class III/IV Most Severe â€¢ Biopsy Required
CLASSIFICATION (ISN/RPS)
ClassDescriptionTreatment
IMinimal mesangialSupportive
IIMesangial proliferativeSupportive Â± low-dose steroids
IIIFocal proliferative (<50% glomeruli)Immunosuppression
IVDiffuse proliferative (>50% glomeruli) â€” MOST COMMON, MOST SEVEREAggressive immunosuppression
VMembranousImmunosuppression if nephrotic
VISclerosing (>90% sclerosed)Supportive; consider transplant
DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

When to Suspect: SLE patient with proteinuria (>500mg/day), hematuria, RBC casts, rising creatinine

Labs: Low C3/C4 (consumed), positive anti-dsDNA (correlates with activity), elevated anti-dsDNA titers

Biopsy: Required to determine class and guide treatment

Treatment (Class III/IV):

  • Induction: Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) + glucocorticoids (preferred) OR cyclophosphamide + glucocorticoids
  • Maintenance: MMF or azathioprine + low-dose steroids
  • Add voclosporin or belimumab for enhanced response

Adjuncts: Hydroxychloroquine (ALL SLE patients), ACEi/ARB for proteinuria, BP control

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Class IV = diffuse proliferative = worst prognosis without treatment
  • All SLE patients should be on hydroxychloroquine (reduces flares, mortality)
  • Anti-dsDNA and complement levels correlate with disease activity
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

201. DRUG-INDUCED LUPUS

Anti-Histone Antibodies â€¢ Resolves with Drug Cessation â€¢ Renal/CNS Rare
CLINICAL FEATURES & DIAGNOSIS

Common Culprits (HIGH RISK):

  • Hydralazine (most common)
  • Procainamide (highest incidence with chronic use)
  • Isoniazid
  • Minocycline, TNF inhibitors, methyldopa, quinidine

Clinical Features: Arthralgia/arthritis, myalgia, serositis (pleuritis, pericarditis), fever, rash. Typically milder than SLE

Usually ABSENT: Renal disease, CNS involvement, severe cytopenias (major distinguishing feature from SLE)

Labs:

  • ANA positive (usually homogeneous pattern)
  • Anti-histone antibodies positive (~95%) â€” most specific
  • Anti-dsDNA typically NEGATIVE (unlike SLE)
  • Complement levels usually NORMAL
MANAGEMENT

Primary Treatment: Discontinue offending drug â€” symptoms resolve within weeks to months

Symptomatic: NSAIDs for arthralgia/myalgia; short-course steroids if severe

Serologies: ANA may remain positive for months after drug cessation

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Anti-histone antibodies + drug exposure + no renal/CNS = drug-induced lupus
  • Hydralazine #1 cause; procainamide highest incidence with prolonged use
  • Resolves with drug discontinuation â€” don't need long-term immunosuppression
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

202. SYSTEMIC SCLEROSIS (SCLERODERMA)

Limited (CREST) vs Diffuse â€¢ Anti-Scl-70 vs Anti-Centromere â€¢ Renal Crisis
CLASSIFICATION
FeatureLimited (CREST)Diffuse
Skin involvementDistal to elbows/knees, faceProximal (trunk, upper arms/thighs)
Raynaud'sYears before skin changesWithin 1 year of skin changes
AntibodyAnti-centromereAnti-Scl-70 (topoisomerase I)
Organ involvementPulmonary HTN (late), less ILDILD, renal crisis, cardiac
PrognosisBetter (except PAH)Worse

CREST: Calcinosis, Raynaud's, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, Telangiectasias

CLINICAL FEATURES & MANAGEMENT

Skin: Tight, thickened skin; "salt and pepper" pigmentation; digital ulcers

GI: Esophageal dysmotility (GERD, dysphagia), gastroparesis, small bowel dysmotility (bacterial overgrowth), watermelon stomach (GAVE)

Pulmonary: ILD (ground-glass â†’ fibrosis on HRCT), pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH)

Treatments by Manifestation:

  • Raynaud's: CCBs (nifedipine), avoid cold
  • GI: PPI, prokinetics, antibiotics for bacterial overgrowth
  • ILD: Mycophenolate, nintedanib, tocilizumab
  • PAH: PDE5 inhibitors, endothelin receptor antagonists, prostacyclins
  • Renal crisis: See below
âš ï¸ SCLERODERMA RENAL CRISIS
  • Presentation: Acute HTN, AKI, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Risk factors: Diffuse disease, early disease, high-dose steroids, anti-RNA polymerase III
  • Treatment: ACE INHIBITORS (captopril) â€” even if creatinine rising
  • Do NOT use steroids â€” can precipitate crisis
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Anti-centromere = limited/CREST; Anti-Scl-70 = diffuse
  • ACE inhibitors for scleroderma renal crisis â€” continue even if Cr rises
  • High-dose steroids can precipitate renal crisis
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

203. INFLAMMATORY MYOPATHIES

Dermatomyositis vs Polymyositis â€¢ Proximal Weakness â€¢ CK Elevated
CLASSIFICATION & FEATURES
FeatureDermatomyositisPolymyositisInclusion Body Myositis
WeaknessProximal, symmetricProximal, symmetricAsymmetric, distal (finger flexors, quads)
Skin findingsHeliotrope rash, Gottron's papulesNoneNone
CKElevated (10-50Ã—)Elevated (10-50Ã—)Normal or mildly elevated
Malignancy riskHIGH (screen)ModerateLow
Treatment responseGoodGoodPoor

Dermatomyositis Skin Findings:

  • Heliotrope rash: Violaceous eyelid discoloration
  • Gottron's papules: Erythematous papules over MCP, PIP, DIP
  • V-sign: Rash on anterior chest/neck
  • Shawl sign: Rash on upper back/shoulders
  • Mechanic's hands: Cracked, fissured skin on fingers
DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Diagnosis:

  • CK elevated (can be very high)
  • EMG: Myopathic pattern (short, small polyphasic potentials)
  • MRI: Muscle edema
  • Muscle biopsy: Gold standard (perifascicular atrophy in DM, endomysial inflammation in PM)
  • Myositis-specific antibodies: Anti-Jo-1 (antisynthetase syndrome â€” ILD, arthritis, Raynaud's, mechanic's hands)

Treatment:

  • High-dose glucocorticoids (prednisone 1mg/kg) first-line
  • Steroid-sparing: Methotrexate, azathioprine, IVIG
  • Rituximab for refractory cases

Malignancy Screening (Dermatomyositis): Age-appropriate cancer screening + CT chest/abdomen/pelvis; ovarian cancer screen in women

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Heliotrope + Gottron's = dermatomyositis â€” screen for malignancy
  • Anti-Jo-1: Antisynthetase syndrome â€” ILD + arthritis + mechanic's hands
  • Inclusion body myositis: Older men, asymmetric, distal weakness, poor treatment response
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

204. SJÃ–GREN'S SYNDROME

Sicca Symptoms â€¢ Anti-SSA/SSB â€¢ Lymphoma Risk
CLINICAL FEATURES

Sicca Symptoms:

  • Dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca): Gritty sensation, burning
  • Dry mouth (xerostomia): Difficulty swallowing dry foods, dental caries

Extraglandular: Arthralgia/arthritis, Raynaud's, interstitial nephritis (RTA type 1), peripheral neuropathy, ILD, parotid enlargement

Primary vs Secondary: Secondary occurs with other autoimmune diseases (RA, SLE, scleroderma)

DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Labs:

  • Anti-SSA (Ro): 70% â€” also seen in SLE; associated with neonatal lupus, congenital heart block
  • Anti-SSB (La): 40% â€” more specific for SjÃ¶gren's
  • RF positive (common), ANA positive

Tests: Schirmer test (tear production), salivary gland biopsy (focal lymphocytic infiltration â€” most specific)

Treatment:

  • Dry eyes: Artificial tears, cyclosporine drops (Restasis), punctal plugs
  • Dry mouth: Saliva substitutes, pilocarpine, cevimeline (muscarinic agonists), good dental care
  • Systemic: Hydroxychloroquine (fatigue, arthralgia), immunosuppression for severe organ involvement
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Anti-SSA in pregnancy: Risk of neonatal lupus and congenital heart block â€” monitor fetal heart
  • Lymphoma risk increased (especially MALT, marginal zone) â€” monitor for parotid enlargement, lymphadenopathy
  • Type 1 RTA: Distal RTA with hypokalemia â€” think SjÃ¶gren's
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

205. MIXED CONNECTIVE TISSUE DISEASE (MCTD)

Overlap Syndrome â€¢ High-Titer Anti-U1 RNP â€¢ Raynaud's Universal
CLINICAL FEATURES

Definition: Overlap of features from SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis with high-titer anti-U1 RNP antibodies

Common Features:

  • Raynaud's phenomenon: Nearly universal
  • Swollen "sausage" fingers
  • Arthritis/arthralgia
  • Myositis
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Pulmonary HTN (leading cause of death)

Usually Spared: Severe renal disease, CNS involvement (unlike SLE)

DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Labs:

  • High-titer anti-U1 RNP (required for diagnosis)
  • ANA positive (speckled pattern)
  • RF may be positive

Treatment: Treat specific manifestations â€” NSAIDs/hydroxychloroquine for arthritis, steroids for myositis/serositis, CCBs for Raynaud's, PAH-specific therapy

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • High-titer anti-U1 RNP + Raynaud's + overlap features = MCTD
  • Pulmonary HTN is major cause of morbidity/mortality
  • May evolve into a single defined CTD over time
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

206. ANTIPHOSPHOLIPID SYNDROME (APS)

Thrombosis + Pregnancy Loss â€¢ Lupus Anticoagulant â€¢ Lifelong Anticoagulation
CLINICAL CRITERIA (SYDNEY)

Clinical (â‰¥1 required):

  • Vascular thrombosis: Arterial, venous, or small vessel (DVT, PE, stroke, MI)
  • Pregnancy morbidity: â‰¥1 unexplained fetal death â‰¥10 weeks, â‰¥1 premature birth <34 weeks due to preeclampsia/placental insufficiency, â‰¥3 consecutive spontaneous abortions <10 weeks

Laboratory (â‰¥1 required, positive on 2 occasions â‰¥12 weeks apart):

  • Lupus anticoagulant (LA): Most specific; prolongs PTT but is prothrombotic
  • Anticardiolipin antibodies (IgG or IgM, medium-high titer)
  • Anti-Î²2 glycoprotein I antibodies (IgG or IgM)
TREATMENT

Thrombosis:

  • First venous thrombosis: Warfarin (INR 2-3) â€” lifelong if unprovoked
  • Arterial thrombosis: Warfarin (INR 2-3) Â± aspirin
  • Recurrent thrombosis on warfarin: Higher INR (3-4) or add aspirin or LMWH
  • DOACs: NOT recommended (inferior to warfarin in APS, especially triple-positive)

Pregnancy: LMWH + low-dose aspirin

Primary Prevention (asymptomatic antibodies): Low-dose aspirin if high-risk (triple positive)

âš ï¸ CATASTROPHIC APS (CAPS)

Multi-organ thrombosis over days-weeks. High mortality. Treat with anticoagulation + steroids + plasma exchange or IVIG.

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Prolonged PTT + thrombosis = think lupus anticoagulant (PTT doesn't correct with mixing study)
  • Warfarin preferred over DOACs in APS (especially triple-positive)
  • False-positive VDRL/RPR can occur with antiphospholipid antibodies
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

207. SARCOIDOSIS

Non-Caseating Granulomas â€¢ Bilateral Hilar LAD â€¢ Multi-Organ
CLINICAL FEATURES

Demographics: African Americans, Northern Europeans, women; age 25-45

Pulmonary (>90%): Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (BHL), ILD, cough, dyspnea

Staging: Stage 0 = normal CXR; I = BHL only; II = BHL + parenchymal; III = parenchymal only; IV = fibrosis

Extrapulmonary:

  • Skin: Erythema nodosum (good prognosis), lupus pernio (violaceous facial plaques â€” poor prognosis)
  • Eyes: Uveitis (anterior most common) â€” screen all patients
  • Cardiac: Heart block, cardiomyopathy, sudden death
  • Neuro: CN VII palsy (most common), meningitis, hypothalamic involvement
  • Renal: Hypercalcemia/hypercalciuria (granulomas produce 1,25-vitamin D), nephrolithiasis
  • Liver/spleen: Hepatomegaly, elevated ALP

LÃ¶fgren Syndrome: BHL + erythema nodosum + ankle arthritis + fever â€” excellent prognosis

DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Labs: ACE level (non-specific, not for diagnosis), hypercalcemia, elevated ALP

Diagnosis: Biopsy showing non-caseating granulomas + compatible clinical/radiographic findings + exclusion of other causes (TB, fungal)

Treatment:

  • Observation: Stage I often resolves spontaneously
  • Corticosteroids: First-line for symptomatic pulmonary, cardiac, neuro, ocular, hypercalcemia
  • Steroid-sparing: Methotrexate, azathioprine; anti-TNF for refractory
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Bilateral hilar LAD on CXR in young adult = think sarcoidosis
  • LÃ¶fgren syndrome: Erythema nodosum + BHL + arthritis = excellent prognosis, often resolves
  • Hypercalcemia: Granulomas convert 25-OH to 1,25-OH vitamin D
  • Lupus pernio = poor prognosis; erythema nodosum = good prognosis
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

208. IgG4-RELATED DISEASE

Tumefactive Lesions â€¢ Elevated Serum IgG4 â€¢ Autoimmune Pancreatitis
CLINICAL FEATURES

Overview: Fibroinflammatory condition with tumefactive (mass-forming) lesions; can mimic malignancy

Organ Involvement:

  • Pancreas: Type 1 autoimmune pancreatitis (diffuse pancreatic enlargement "sausage pancreas")
  • Biliary: Sclerosing cholangitis (mimics cholangiocarcinoma)
  • Salivary/lacrimal glands: Mikulicz disease (bilateral gland enlargement)
  • Retroperitoneum: Retroperitoneal fibrosis
  • Kidney: Tubulointerstitial nephritis
  • Aorta: Periaortitis
  • Thyroid: Riedel's thyroiditis
DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Labs: Elevated serum IgG4 (>135 mg/dL) â€” not required for diagnosis; can be normal in 30%

Histology: Dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate with IgG4+ plasma cells, storiform fibrosis, obliterative phlebitis

Treatment:

  • Glucocorticoids: First-line â€” typically dramatic response
  • Rituximab: Steroid-sparing, relapsed/refractory
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Painless jaundice + "sausage pancreas" = autoimmune pancreatitis (IgG4-related)
  • Can mimic pancreatic cancer â€” check IgG4, consider biopsy before Whipple
  • Responds dramatically to steroids â€” diagnostic and therapeutic
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

209. AMYLOIDOSIS

AL vs AA vs ATTR â€¢ Congo Red Birefringence â€¢ Multi-Organ
TYPES
TypePrecursor ProteinAssociated ConditionsKey Features
AL (Primary)Immunoglobulin light chainsMultiple myeloma, plasma cell dyscrasiasHeart, kidney, nerve, liver, tongue
AA (Secondary)Serum amyloid AChronic inflammation (RA, IBD, chronic infections)Kidney (nephrotic), liver, spleen
ATTR (hereditary)Transthyretin (mutant)Familial (Val30Met common)Neuropathy, cardiomyopathy
ATTR (wild-type)Transthyretin (wild-type)Elderly menCardiomyopathy, carpal tunnel
CLINICAL FEATURES & DIAGNOSIS

Clues to AL Amyloidosis:

  • Nephrotic syndrome (most common renal manifestation)
  • Restrictive cardiomyopathy with low-voltage ECG and "sparkling" myocardium on echo
  • Macroglossia (pathognomonic)
  • Periorbital purpura ("raccoon eyes")
  • Peripheral/autonomic neuropathy
  • Hepatomegaly with elevated ALP
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome (bilateral)

Diagnosis:

  • Tissue biopsy: Fat pad aspirate, bone marrow, or affected organ
  • Congo red stain: Apple-green birefringence under polarized light
  • Mass spectrometry: Identify amyloid type
  • Workup for AL: SPEP/UPEP, serum free light chains, bone marrow biopsy
TREATMENT

AL Amyloidosis: Treat underlying plasma cell dyscrasia â€” daratumumab + CyBorD, autologous stem cell transplant if eligible

AA Amyloidosis: Treat underlying inflammatory condition

ATTR: Tafamidis (TTR stabilizer) for cardiomyopathy; liver transplant (hereditary); patisiran/inotersen (gene silencers)

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Nephrotic syndrome + cardiomyopathy + neuropathy = think AL amyloidosis
  • Macroglossia is pathognomonic for AL amyloidosis
  • Low-voltage ECG + thick walls on echo = infiltrative cardiomyopathy (amyloid)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

210. OSTEOPOROSIS

T-Score â‰¤-2.5 â€¢ FRAX Risk â€¢ Bisphosphonates First-Line
DIAGNOSIS & SCREENING

DEXA Screening: Women â‰¥65, men â‰¥70, younger if risk factors

Definitions (T-score):

  • Normal: T-score â‰¥ -1.0
  • Osteopenia: T-score -1.0 to -2.5
  • Osteoporosis: T-score â‰¤ -2.5

FRAX: 10-year fracture risk calculator. Treat if hip fracture risk â‰¥3% or major osteoporotic fracture risk â‰¥20%

Secondary Causes: Vitamin D deficiency, hyperparathyroidism, hyperthyroidism, Cushing's, celiac, chronic steroids, hypogonadism

TREATMENT

Non-Pharmacologic: Weight-bearing exercise, fall prevention, calcium 1000-1200mg/day, vitamin D 800-1000 IU/day

First-Line:

  • Bisphosphonates: Alendronate 70mg weekly, risedronate, zoledronic acid 5mg IV yearly
  • Take on empty stomach, remain upright 30 min, adequate calcium/vitamin D
  • Side effects: GI (oral), osteonecrosis of jaw (rare), atypical femur fractures (rare, with prolonged use)

Alternatives:

  • Denosumab: Anti-RANKL; 60mg SC q6 months (rapid bone loss if stopped â€” must transition)
  • Teriparatide/abaloparatide: Anabolic (PTH analog); for severe/refractory; max 2 years
  • Romosozumab: Anti-sclerostin; very high fracture risk (avoid if recent MI/stroke)

Drug Holiday: Consider after 5 years oral or 3 years IV bisphosphonate in moderate-risk patients

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Bisphosphonates first-line; use FRAX if osteopenia to guide treatment
  • Denosumab: rebound bone loss if stopped â€” must transition to bisphosphonate
  • Zoledronic acid: Give after hip fracture repair (reduces future fractures and mortality)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

211. PAGET'S DISEASE OF BONE

Elevated ALP â€¢ Normal Ca/Phos â€¢ Bisphosphonates
CLINICAL FEATURES

Pathophysiology: Increased osteoclast â†’ osteoblast activity; disorganized bone remodeling

Common Sites: Pelvis, spine, skull, femur, tibia

Presentation:

  • Often asymptomatic (incidental elevated ALP)
  • Bone pain (most common symptom)
  • Skeletal deformities (bowing of tibia, skull enlargement)
  • Hearing loss (skull involvement)

Complications: Fractures, osteoarthritis (adjacent joints), high-output heart failure (rare, extensive disease), osteosarcoma (rare but serious â€” sudden pain increase)

DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Labs:

  • Elevated alkaline phosphatase (reflects disease activity)
  • Normal calcium and phosphorus
  • Normal PTH

Imaging: X-ray shows lytic and sclerotic lesions, cortical thickening, bone enlargement. Bone scan shows increased uptake

Treatment:

  • Bisphosphonates: Zoledronic acid 5mg IV Ã— 1 (first-line); alendronate
  • Indications: Symptoms, elevated ALP, involvement at high-risk sites (skull, spine, weight-bearing bones), before orthopedic surgery
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Isolated elevated ALP + normal Ca/Phos = Paget's disease
  • Sudden increase in pain: Think fracture or osteosarcoma
  • Zoledronic acid single dose often sufficient for years
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

212. OSTEONECROSIS (AVASCULAR NECROSIS)

Hip Most Common â€¢ Steroids/Alcohol â€¢ MRI Most Sensitive
ETIOLOGY & CLINICAL FEATURES

Risk Factors:

  • Corticosteroids (most common non-traumatic cause)
  • Alcohol abuse
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Hip fracture/dislocation (traumatic)
  • SLE, antiphospholipid syndrome
  • Radiation, Gaucher disease, decompression sickness (Caisson disease)

Common Sites: Femoral head (hip) most common, humeral head, femoral condyles, talus

Presentation: Gradual onset of joint pain, worse with weight-bearing; may be bilateral

DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Imaging:

  • X-ray: May be normal early; later shows crescent sign, subchondral collapse, sclerosis
  • MRI: Most sensitive for early detection â€” "double-line sign" (pathognomonic)

Treatment:

  • Early (pre-collapse): Protected weight-bearing, bisphosphonates (limited evidence), core decompression
  • Late (collapse): Total joint arthroplasty
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Hip pain + steroid use = think AVN (MRI if X-ray negative)
  • MRI most sensitive â€” order if high suspicion and normal X-ray
  • Screen contralateral hip â€” often bilateral
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

213. FIBROMYALGIA

Widespread Pain â€¢ Normal Labs â€¢ Central Sensitization
DIAGNOSIS

Criteria (2010/2016):

  • Widespread pain index (WPI) + symptom severity scale (SSS)
  • Symptoms present â‰¥3 months
  • No other disorder that would explain symptoms

Clinical Features:

  • Widespread pain: Both sides, above and below waist
  • Fatigue
  • Non-restorative sleep
  • Cognitive symptoms ("fibro fog")
  • Associated: Headache, IBS, interstitial cystitis, depression, anxiety

Labs: All normal â€” CBC, CMP, TSH, ESR/CRP. Order only to rule out other conditions

TREATMENT

Non-Pharmacologic (Cornerstone):

  • Exercise: Aerobic + strength training â€” most effective intervention
  • Sleep hygiene
  • Cognitive behavioral therapy

Pharmacologic:

  • Duloxetine (SNRI): FDA-approved; also helps depression
  • Milnacipran (SNRI): FDA-approved
  • Pregabalin: FDA-approved; helps pain and sleep
  • Amitriptyline (low-dose): Helps pain and sleep
  • Avoid: Opioids (ineffective, harmful), NSAIDs (limited benefit)
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Normal labs + widespread pain + fatigue + sleep problems = fibromyalgia
  • Exercise is most effective treatment
  • Avoid opioids â€” not effective and may worsen outcomes
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

214. CAUDA EQUINA SYNDROME

Surgical Emergency â€¢ Saddle Anesthesia â€¢ Urinary Retention
CLINICAL FEATURES

Etiology: Large central disc herniation (most common), tumor, abscess, hematoma, trauma

Red Flag Symptoms:

  • Saddle anesthesia: Numbness in perineum/perianal area
  • Urinary retention (most common) or incontinence
  • Fecal incontinence
  • Bilateral leg weakness/numbness
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Low back pain with bilateral sciatica

Exam: Decreased anal tone, absent bulbocavernosus reflex, post-void residual >100-200mL

DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT
âš ï¸ SURGICAL EMERGENCY

Delay in decompression leads to permanent neurologic deficits. Emergent MRI + neurosurgical consultation

Imaging: MRI lumbar spine (emergent) â€” CT myelogram if MRI unavailable

Treatment: Emergent surgical decompression â€” ideally within 24-48 hours for best outcomes

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Back pain + saddle anesthesia + urinary retention = cauda equina until proven otherwise
  • Check post-void residual â€” urinary retention is the most consistent finding
  • Emergent MRI and surgical decompression â€” delays worsen outcomes
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

215. CUSHING SYNDROME

Hypercortisolism â€¢ ACTH-Dependent vs Independent â€¢ Dexamethasone Suppression
CLINICAL FEATURES

Classic Features:

  • Central obesity with thin extremities
  • Moon facies, buffalo hump, supraclavicular fat pads
  • Purple striae (>1cm wide) â€” most specific
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Easy bruising, thin skin
  • Hypertension, hyperglycemia, hypokalemia
  • Osteoporosis, menstrual irregularities, hirsutism
  • Depression, cognitive changes

Etiology:

  • Exogenous steroids: Most common cause overall
  • ACTH-dependent (80%): Pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease 70%), ectopic ACTH (lung cancer, carcinoid)
  • ACTH-independent (20%): Adrenal adenoma, adrenal carcinoma
DIAGNOSIS

Step 1 â€” Confirm Hypercortisolism (â‰¥2 abnormal):

  • 24-hour urine free cortisol (elevated)
  • Late-night salivary cortisol (elevated â€” loss of diurnal variation)
  • 1mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test: Morning cortisol >1.8 Î¼g/dL = abnormal (fails to suppress)

Step 2 â€” Determine ACTH Dependence:

  • ACTH suppressed (<5 pg/mL): ACTH-independent â†’ Adrenal imaging (CT)
  • ACTH normal/elevated: ACTH-dependent â†’ Pituitary MRI

Step 3 â€” Localize (if ACTH-dependent):

  • High-dose (8mg) dexamethasone suppression: Suppresses = pituitary; No suppression = ectopic
  • Inferior petrosal sinus sampling (IPSS): Gold standard to distinguish pituitary vs ectopic
TREATMENT

Pituitary (Cushing Disease): Transsphenoidal surgery (first-line)

Adrenal Adenoma: Adrenalectomy

Ectopic ACTH: Resect tumor if possible; medical therapy if not

Medical Therapy: Ketoconazole, metyrapone, osilodrostat (steroidogenesis inhibitors); mifepristone (glucocorticoid receptor antagonist); pasireotide (pituitary)

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Wide purple striae most specific for Cushing (vs obesity)
  • Exogenous steroids most common cause â€” always ask about steroid use
  • Ectopic ACTH: Often severe, rapid onset, hypokalemia prominent (small cell lung cancer)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

216. PRIMARY ALDOSTERONISM (CONN SYNDROME)

HTN + Hypokalemia â€¢ ARR Screening â€¢ Adrenal Adenoma vs Hyperplasia
CLINICAL FEATURES & SCREENING

Suspect When:

  • Resistant hypertension (uncontrolled on â‰¥3 drugs)
  • Hypertension + hypokalemia (spontaneous or diuretic-induced severe)
  • Hypertension + adrenal incidentaloma
  • Early-onset HTN or family history of early stroke
  • Hypertension with OSA

Note: Most patients are normokalemic â€” hypokalemia is specific but not sensitive

Screening â€” Aldosterone-to-Renin Ratio (ARR):

  • ARR >30 + aldosterone >15 ng/dL = positive screen
  • Hold interfering meds: spironolactone (6 weeks), MRAs, ACEi/ARBs, diuretics (2-4 weeks)
  • Can continue CCBs, alpha-blockers, hydralazine
CONFIRMATORY TESTING & SUBTYPE

Confirmatory Tests (after positive ARR):

  • Oral sodium loading test or IV saline infusion test
  • Failure to suppress aldosterone confirms diagnosis

Subtype Differentiation:

  • Adrenal CT: First imaging study
  • Adrenal vein sampling (AVS): Gold standard to distinguish unilateral (adenoma) vs bilateral (hyperplasia) â€” required if surgery considered
FeatureAldosterone-Producing AdenomaBilateral Hyperplasia
LateralityUnilateralBilateral
TreatmentAdrenalectomy (curative)MRA (spironolactone, eplerenone)
Prevalence~35%~60%
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Most patients are normokalemic â€” screen based on resistant HTN
  • ARR >30 + aldo >15 = positive screen â†’ confirm with salt loading
  • Adrenal vein sampling before surgery â€” CT alone insufficient
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

217. PROLACTINOMA

Most Common Pituitary Tumor â€¢ Dopamine Agonists First-Line
CLINICAL FEATURES

Hyperprolactinemia Effects:

  • Women: Amenorrhea, galactorrhea, infertility, decreased libido
  • Men: Decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, gynecomastia, infertility (often present late with large tumors)
  • Both: Osteoporosis (hypogonadism)

Mass Effects (macroadenoma >10mm):

  • Headache
  • Visual field defects: Bitemporal hemianopia (optic chiasm compression)
  • Hypopituitarism (compression of normal pituitary)
DIAGNOSIS

Labs: Serum prolactin

  • Prolactin level generally correlates with tumor size
  • >200 ng/mL almost always prolactinoma
  • Mild elevation (25-100) â€” rule out other causes first

Rule Out Other Causes of Hyperprolactinemia:

  • Medications: Antipsychotics (most common), metoclopramide, SSRIs
  • Pregnancy (always check Î²-hCG)
  • Primary hypothyroidism (check TSH â€” TRH stimulates prolactin)
  • Stalk effect: Non-functioning pituitary mass compressing stalk (prolactin usually <100)

Imaging: Pituitary MRI with gadolinium

TREATMENT

First-Line â€” Dopamine Agonists (even for large tumors):

  • Cabergoline: Preferred â€” more effective, better tolerated, twice weekly
  • Bromocriptine: Alternative (daily dosing, more side effects)
  • Normalize prolactin and shrink tumor in >90%

Surgery: Only if medication intolerance/failure, CSF leak, or patient preference

Pregnancy: Discontinue cabergoline once pregnant (for microprolactinomas); bromocriptine has more safety data

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Dopamine agonists first-line even for macroprolactinomas â€” NOT surgery
  • Prolactin >200 = prolactinoma; mild elevation = rule out meds, hypothyroid, pregnancy
  • Stalk effect: Large non-functioning adenoma with mild prolactin elevation (<100)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

218. ACROMEGALY

GH Excess â€¢ IGF-1 Screening â€¢ Transsphenoidal Surgery
CLINICAL FEATURES

Gradual Onset (often delayed diagnosis 7-10 years):

  • Acral enlargement: Hands (rings don't fit), feet (shoe size increases)
  • Facial changes: Frontal bossing, prognathism (jaw protrusion), coarsened features, macroglossia
  • Skin: Thickened, oily, hyperhidrosis, skin tags
  • Soft tissue: Carpal tunnel syndrome, deepening voice

Systemic Complications:

  • Cardiovascular: Hypertension, cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias (major cause of death)
  • Metabolic: Diabetes/glucose intolerance, hyperlipidemia
  • Respiratory: Sleep apnea (very common)
  • Rheumatologic: Arthropathy, osteoarthritis
  • Neoplastic: Increased colon polyps â†’ colonoscopy recommended

Local Mass Effects: Headache, visual field defects, hypopituitarism

DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Screening: IGF-1 level (reflects integrated GH secretion; age/sex adjusted)

Confirmation: Oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) â€” GH should suppress to <1 ng/mL; failure to suppress confirms diagnosis

Imaging: Pituitary MRI

Treatment:

  • First-line: Transsphenoidal surgery â€” curative if complete resection
  • Medical therapy (if surgery fails/incomplete):
    • Somatostatin analogs: Octreotide LAR, lanreotide (first-line medical)
    • GH receptor antagonist: Pegvisomant (normalizes IGF-1)
    • Dopamine agonist: Cabergoline (if mild, co-secreting prolactin)
  • Radiation: For residual/recurrent disease
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • IGF-1 for screening; OGTT for confirmation
  • Surgery first-line (unlike prolactinoma where meds are first)
  • Screen for colon polyps, sleep apnea, cardiac disease
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

219. MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA (MEN) SYNDROMES

Autosomal Dominant â€¢ Screen Family Members â€¢ Prophylactic Thyroidectomy in MEN2
CLASSIFICATION
SyndromeGeneComponents (3 P's / 2 M's)
MEN1
("3 P's")		 MEN1 (menin)
Tumor suppressor		 Parathyroid hyperplasia (95%) â€” most common/earliest
Pituitary adenomas (40%) â€” prolactinoma most common
Pancreatic NETs (40%) â€” gastrinoma most common, insulinoma
MEN2A
("2 M's + P")		 RET proto-oncogene Medullary thyroid carcinoma (95%) â€” most lethal
Pheochromocytoma (50%)
Parathyroid hyperplasia (20-30%)
MEN2B RET proto-oncogene Medullary thyroid carcinoma (100%) â€” aggressive, early
Pheochromocytoma (50%)
Marfanoid habitus, mucosal neuromas (lips, tongue)
NO hyperparathyroidism
KEY MANAGEMENT POINTS

MEN1:

  • Screen for hypercalcemia (PTH, calcium), prolactin, fasting glucose/insulin
  • Gastrinoma: Check fasting gastrin; may cause Zollinger-Ellison syndrome

MEN2:

  • RET mutation testing for all family members
  • Prophylactic thyroidectomy in RET carriers (timing based on mutation risk category)
  • Always screen for pheochromocytoma BEFORE thyroid surgery (plasma/urine metanephrines)
  • MTC: Check calcitonin, CEA
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • MEN1 = 3 P's: Parathyroid, Pituitary, Pancreas
  • MEN2 = MTC + Pheo Â± Parathyroid; MEN2B adds marfanoid + neuromas
  • Always rule out pheo before thyroid surgery in MEN2
  • Prophylactic thyroidectomy for RET mutation carriers
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

220. PRIMARY BILIARY CHOLANGITIS (PBC)

Anti-Mitochondrial Antibody â€¢ Cholestatic LFTs â€¢ Ursodiol
CLINICAL FEATURES

Demographics: Middle-aged women (90%); often associated with other autoimmune diseases (SjÃ¶gren's, thyroiditis, scleroderma)

Presentation:

  • Fatigue (most common symptom)
  • Pruritus (often precedes jaundice by years)
  • May be asymptomatic (detected by elevated ALP)
  • Later: Jaundice, xanthomas/xanthelasmas, hepatomegaly

Complications: Cirrhosis, portal hypertension, fat-soluble vitamin deficiency (A, D, E, K), osteoporosis

DIAGNOSIS

Labs:

  • Cholestatic pattern: Elevated ALP (predominant), elevated GGT, bilirubin rises later
  • Anti-mitochondrial antibody (AMA): Positive in >95% â€” highly specific
  • Elevated IgM
  • Mildly elevated aminotransferases

Diagnosis Criteria (2 of 3):

  1. Cholestatic biochemistry (elevated ALP)
  2. Positive AMA (or PBC-specific ANA if AMA negative)
  3. Liver biopsy showing non-suppurative cholangitis (not required if AMA+ and cholestasis)
TREATMENT

First-Line:

  • Ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA): 13-15 mg/kg/day â€” slows progression, improves survival

Inadequate Response to UDCA:

  • Obeticholic acid: FXR agonist; add-on therapy (avoid in decompensated cirrhosis)
  • Elafibranor, seladelpar: Newer PPAR agonists

Symptom Management:

  • Pruritus: Cholestyramine (first-line), rifampin, naltrexone, sertraline
  • Osteoporosis: Calcium, vitamin D, bisphosphonates
  • Fat-soluble vitamins: Supplement A, D, E, K if deficient

Liver Transplant: For decompensated cirrhosis, intractable pruritus

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • AMA >95% specific â€” diagnosis often doesn't require biopsy
  • Middle-aged woman + elevated ALP + pruritus = think PBC
  • UDCA improves survival â€” start early
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

221. NAFLD / NASH / MASLD

Metabolic Syndrome Association â€¢ FIB-4 Staging â€¢ Weight Loss Primary Treatment
DEFINITIONS & SPECTRUM

Updated Nomenclature (2023):

  • MASLD (Metabolic dysfunction-Associated Steatotic Liver Disease): Replaces NAFLD
  • MASH (Metabolic dysfunction-Associated Steatohepatitis): Replaces NASH

Spectrum:

  • Simple steatosis (NAFL): Fat >5% hepatocytes; minimal inflammation; low progression risk
  • Steatohepatitis (NASH/MASH): Steatosis + inflammation + hepatocyte injury (ballooning); can progress to fibrosis
  • Cirrhosis: End-stage; HCC risk

Risk Factors: Obesity, type 2 diabetes, metabolic syndrome, dyslipidemia, PCOS

DIAGNOSIS

Clinical Suspicion: Elevated ALT (often ALT > AST), metabolic risk factors, hepatic steatosis on imaging

Exclude Other Causes: Alcohol (>21 drinks/week men, >14 women), viral hepatitis, autoimmune, Wilson's, hemochromatosis, medications

Non-Invasive Fibrosis Assessment:

  • FIB-4 Index: Age, AST, ALT, platelets â€” <1.3 low risk, >2.67 high risk
  • NAFLD Fibrosis Score (NFS)
  • Transient elastography (FibroScan): Liver stiffness measurement
  • MR elastography: Most accurate non-invasive

Liver Biopsy: Gold standard; indicated when diagnosis uncertain or to stage NASH

TREATMENT

Lifestyle (Cornerstone):

  • Weight loss: â‰¥5% improves steatosis; â‰¥7-10% can improve NASH/fibrosis
  • Mediterranean diet, exercise
  • Avoid alcohol

Pharmacotherapy (for NASH with fibrosis):

  • Resmetirom (Rezdiffra): FDA-approved 2024 for NASH with moderate-advanced fibrosis
  • GLP-1 agonists: Semaglutide â€” improves NASH, weight loss (not yet FDA-approved for NASH indication)
  • Pioglitazone: Improves NASH histology (weight gain, fracture risk)
  • Vitamin E (800 IU): For non-diabetic NASH (concern for long-term safety)

Manage Comorbidities: Diabetes control (SGLT2i, GLP-1), statins for dyslipidemia (safe in NAFLD), hypertension

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • FIB-4 <1.3 rules out advanced fibrosis; >2.67 rules in
  • 7-10% weight loss can reverse NASH
  • Statins are SAFE in NAFLD â€” do not withhold for elevated LFTs
  • Screen for HCC in NASH cirrhosis (US Â± AFP every 6 months)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

222. CHRONIC CORONARY DISEASE

Stable Angina â€¢ GDMT â€¢ Revascularization Indications
CLINICAL FEATURES & DIAGNOSIS

Stable Angina: Predictable chest discomfort with exertion, relieved by rest or nitroglycerin within 5 minutes

Canadian Cardiovascular Society (CCS) Classification:

  • Class I: Angina with strenuous activity only
  • Class II: Slight limitation; angina walking >2 blocks or >1 flight stairs
  • Class III: Marked limitation; angina walking 1-2 blocks or 1 flight
  • Class IV: Angina at rest or minimal activity

Pretest Probability: Use age, sex, symptoms to estimate CAD likelihood before testing

GUIDELINE-DIRECTED MEDICAL THERAPY (GDMT)

Anti-Anginal Therapy:

  • Beta-blockers: First-line; reduce HR and myocardial O2 demand
  • CCBs: Alternative or add-on (non-DHP for rate control, DHP for vasospasm)
  • Long-acting nitrates: Add if persistent symptoms; nitrate-free interval required
  • Ranolazine: Add-on for refractory angina (blocks late Na+ current)

Risk-Reducing Therapy:

  • Aspirin 81mg daily (clopidogrel if intolerant)
  • High-intensity statin (atorvastatin 40-80mg, rosuvastatin 20-40mg)
  • ACEi/ARB if EF â‰¤40%, HTN, DM, or CKD
  • BP goal <130/80
  • LDL goal <70 mg/dL (consider <55 if very high risk)
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Beta-blockers improve mortality post-MI but benefit in stable CAD without prior MI is less clear
  • Ranolazine: No mortality benefit but reduces angina; prolongs QT
  • Nitrate tolerance: Requires 10-14 hour nitrate-free interval
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

223. STRESS TESTING SELECTION

Exercise vs Pharmacologic â€¢ Echo vs Nuclear â€¢ Appropriate Use
MODALITY SELECTION

Exercise vs Pharmacologic:

  • Exercise preferred if patient can achieve â‰¥85% max HR (220 - age)
  • Pharmacologic if: Unable to exercise, LBBB, paced rhythm, severe deconditioning

Pharmacologic Agents:

  • Regadenoson/Adenosine/Dipyridamole: Vasodilators (nuclear imaging). AVOID in asthma/severe COPD, 2nd/3rd degree AV block, SBP <90
  • Dobutamine: Î²1-agonist (echo). AVOID in severe HTN, arrhythmias, severe AS
ModalityImagingBest ForAvoid If
Exercise ECGNoneIntermediate risk, can exercise, interpretable ECGLBBB, paced, WPW, ST abnormalities, digoxin
Exercise EchoEchoCan exercise, uninterpretable ECGPoor acoustic windows
Exercise NuclearSPECT/PETCan exercise, uninterpretable ECG, need quantificationRecent nuclear study
Pharm Echo (dobutamine)EchoCan't exercise, viability assessmentArrhythmias, severe AS
Pharm Nuclear (regadenoson)SPECT/PETCan't exercise, need quantificationAsthma, AV block
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • LBBB or paced rhythm: Use vasodilator stress (NOT dobutamine) â€” can cause false septal perfusion defects
  • Hold caffeine 12-24h before adenosine/regadenoson
  • Aminophylline reverses adenosine/regadenoson side effects
  • Duke Treadmill Score: Exercise time - (5 Ã— ST deviation) - (4 Ã— angina index)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

224. PCI vs CABG INDICATIONS

SYNTAX Score â€¢ Left Main â€¢ Multivessel Disease
REVASCULARIZATION INDICATIONS

Indications for Revascularization:

  • Unacceptable angina despite GDMT
  • Left main stenosis â‰¥50%
  • 3-vessel disease with EF <35%
  • 2-vessel disease with proximal LAD involvement
  • Large area of ischemia (>10% myocardium)

SYNTAX Score: Anatomic complexity score based on coronary lesion characteristics

  • Low (0-22): PCI and CABG comparable
  • Intermediate (23-32): Heart Team discussion
  • High (>32): CABG preferred
PCI vs CABG COMPARISON
FeatureFavors PCIFavors CABG
Anatomy1-2 vessel, low SYNTAX3-vessel, left main, high SYNTAX
DiabetesNon-diabeticDiabetic with multivessel disease
EFPreserved EFReduced EF (<35%)
Surgical riskHigh surgical risk (STS >8%)Low-moderate surgical risk
CompletenessComplete revascularization achievableComplete revascularization needed
Life expectancyLimited life expectancyLong life expectancy

CABG Survival Benefit Established:

  • Left main â‰¥50%
  • 3-vessel disease (especially with DM or LV dysfunction)
  • 2-vessel with proximal LAD + EF <50%
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Diabetics with multivessel disease: CABG superior to PCI (FREEDOM trial)
  • LIMA to LAD: Best long-term patency; CABG advantage
  • Heart Team approach: Recommended for complex decisions
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

225. ICD / CRT DEVICE THERAPY

Primary vs Secondary Prevention â€¢ CRT Indications â€¢ EF Criteria
ICD INDICATIONS

Secondary Prevention (survived SCD):

  • Survived VF arrest or hemodynamically unstable VT not due to reversible cause
  • Sustained VT with structural heart disease

Primary Prevention:

  • Ischemic cardiomyopathy: EF â‰¤35%, â‰¥40 days post-MI, â‰¥90 days post-revascularization, NYHA II-III on GDMT
  • Non-ischemic cardiomyopathy: EF â‰¤35%, NYHA II-III on GDMT, â‰¥3 months optimal therapy
  • Specific conditions: HCM with risk factors, ARVC, Long QT with syncope, Brugada with syncope

Wait periods:

  • 40 days post-MI (SCD-HeFT)
  • 90 days post-revascularization
  • 3 months of GDMT for new HF diagnosis
CRT INDICATIONS

CRT-D or CRT-P (Class I):

  • EF â‰¤35%
  • NYHA II-IV (ambulatory) on GDMT
  • LBBB with QRS â‰¥150ms (strongest indication)
  • Sinus rhythm

Weaker Indications (Class IIa):

  • LBBB with QRS 120-149ms
  • Non-LBBB with QRS â‰¥150ms
  • AFib if expect >70% biventricular pacing
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • LBBB + wide QRS benefits most from CRT; Non-LBBB benefit less clear
  • Wait 40 days post-MI â€” early ICD no benefit (DINAMIT, IRIS)
  • EF may recover: Reassess before implant; wearable defibrillator (LifeVest) can bridge
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

226. HYPERTROPHIC CARDIOMYOPATHY

Asymmetric Septal Hypertrophy â€¢ LVOT Obstruction â€¢ SCD Risk
CLINICAL FEATURES & DIAGNOSIS

Definition: LV wall thickness â‰¥15mm (or â‰¥13mm with family history) not explained by loading conditions

Symptoms: Dyspnea, angina, syncope (exertional), palpitations. Often asymptomatic

Physical Exam:

  • Harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur at LLSB
  • Murmur increases with: Valsalva, standing (decreased preload)
  • Murmur decreases with: Squatting, handgrip (increased afterload/preload)
  • Bifid carotid pulse ("spike and dome")

Echo: Asymmetric septal hypertrophy (septum:posterior wall >1.3:1), SAM of mitral valve, LVOT gradient â‰¥30mmHg (obstructive)

TREATMENT

Obstructive HCM (gradient â‰¥30mmHg):

  • First-line: Beta-blockers (negative inotropy, slows HR)
  • Second-line: Verapamil or diltiazem (if beta-blocker intolerant)
  • Add disopyramide if persistent symptoms (negative inotropy)
  • Mavacamten: Cardiac myosin inhibitor; FDA-approved for obstructive HCM
  • Septal reduction: Surgical myectomy (preferred) or alcohol septal ablation if refractory

AVOID:

  • Vasodilators (nitrates, ACEi, ARBs) â€” worsen gradient
  • Diuretics (unless volume overloaded)
  • Digoxin, dobutamine (positive inotropes)
  • High-intensity exercise
SCD RISK STRATIFICATION

Major Risk Factors for ICD:

  • Prior cardiac arrest or sustained VT
  • Family history of SCD from HCM
  • Unexplained syncope
  • Massive LVH (â‰¥30mm)
  • NSVT on Holter
  • Abnormal BP response to exercise
  • LGE on CMR (extensive scarring)

Use HCM Risk-SCD Calculator: â‰¥6% 5-year risk â†’ consider ICD

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Murmur dynamics: Only HCM and MVP increase with Valsalva/standing
  • Screen first-degree relatives with echo and/or genetic testing
  • Mavacamten: New therapy that reduces LVOT gradient
  • Athletes: Disqualify from competitive sports if diagnosed
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

227. DILATED & RESTRICTIVE CARDIOMYOPATHY

DCM Causes â€¢ RCM vs Constrictive â€¢ Infiltrative Diseases
DILATED CARDIOMYOPATHY (DCM)

Definition: LV dilation with reduced systolic function (EF <40%) not explained by CAD or abnormal loading

Causes:

  • Idiopathic (30-40% â€” many genetic)
  • Ischemic (exclude with angiography)
  • Familial/Genetic: TTN, LMNA, MYH7
  • Toxic: Alcohol, cocaine, chemotherapy (anthracyclines, trastuzumab)
  • Infectious: Viral myocarditis, Chagas, HIV
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy
  • Tachycardia-induced
  • Stress cardiomyopathy (Takotsubo)

Treatment: Standard HFrEF GDMT (ACEi/ARB/ARNI, beta-blocker, MRA, SGLT2i). ICD/CRT if indicated. Treat underlying cause

RESTRICTIVE CARDIOMYOPATHY (RCM)

Definition: Impaired ventricular filling due to stiff, non-compliant ventricles; usually preserved EF

Causes:

  • Amyloidosis (AL, ATTR) â€” most common infiltrative
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Radiation
  • Storage diseases: Fabry, glycogen storage
  • Fibrosis: Scleroderma, endomyocardial fibrosis

Echo: Biatrial enlargement, normal/small ventricles, preserved EF, diastolic dysfunction, "sparkling" myocardium (amyloid)

Low-voltage ECG + thick walls = amyloid (discordance)

RCM vs Constrictive Pericarditis
FeatureRCMConstrictive
Septal bounceAbsentPresent
Respiratory variationAbsentPresent (>25%)
PericardiumNormalThickened/calcified
Kussmaul signVariablePresent
BNPElevatedNormal/low
Key Diagnostic Clues
  • Amyloid: Low voltage + thick walls, diastolic dysfunction
  • Sarcoid: Heart block, VT, patchy LGE on CMR
  • Hemochromatosis: Increased T2* on CMR, liver iron
  • Fabry: LVH, angiokeratomas, Î±-galactosidase deficiency
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

228. CONSTRICTIVE PERICARDITIS

Post-Cardiac Surgery â€¢ Ventricular Interdependence â€¢ Pericardiectomy
ETIOLOGY & CLINICAL FEATURES

Causes:

  • Idiopathic/viral (most common in developed countries)
  • Post-cardiac surgery
  • Radiation therapy
  • TB (common in endemic areas)
  • Connective tissue disease, uremia, malignancy

Symptoms: Dyspnea, fatigue, peripheral edema, ascites (often out of proportion to peripheral edema)

Physical Exam:

  • Elevated JVP with prominent y-descent
  • Kussmaul sign: JVP rises with inspiration (paradoxical)
  • Pericardial knock: High-pitched early diastolic sound
  • Hepatomegaly, ascites, peripheral edema
DIAGNOSIS

Echo:

  • Septal bounce (ventricular interdependence)
  • Respiratory variation in mitral/tricuspid inflow (>25%)
  • Dilated IVC without respiratory variation
  • Preserved/increased medial e' velocity

CT/MRI: Pericardial thickening (>4mm), calcification

Cath: Equalization of diastolic pressures, "square root" sign, discordant ventricular pressure changes with respiration

BNP: Normal or mildly elevated (vs elevated in RCM)

TREATMENT

Medical: Diuretics for congestion; treat underlying cause; anti-inflammatory if transient/inflammatory

Definitive: Pericardiectomy â€” surgical removal of pericardium; high morbidity/mortality but curative

Prognosis: Poor without surgery; radiation-induced has worst surgical outcomes

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Kussmaul sign + pericardial knock + ascites = constrictive pericarditis
  • Septal bounce on echo â€” key finding distinguishing from RCM
  • Normal BNP favors constriction over restriction
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

229. BRADYARRHYTHMIAS & PACING

Sick Sinus Syndrome â€¢ AV Blocks â€¢ Pacemaker Indications
SICK SINUS SYNDROME

Definition: SA node dysfunction causing symptomatic bradycardia

Manifestations:

  • Sinus bradycardia
  • Sinus pauses/arrest
  • Sinoatrial exit block
  • Tachy-brady syndrome: Alternating tachycardia (usually AFib) and bradycardia
  • Chronotropic incompetence (inadequate HR response to exercise)

Treatment: Pacemaker if symptomatic; treat tachycardia component after pacing secured

AV BLOCKS
TypeECG FindingTreatment
First-degreePR >200ms, all P waves conductedNone (usually benign)
Second-degree Type I (Wenckebach)Progressive PR prolongation â†’ dropped beat; grouped beatingUsually benign; pacing if symptomatic
Second-degree Type IIFixed PR interval â†’ sudden dropped beatPacemaker (high risk of progression)
Third-degree (Complete)AV dissociation; P waves and QRS independentPacemaker
High-grade AV blockâ‰¥2 consecutive non-conducted P wavesPacemaker

Reversible Causes: Drugs (beta-blockers, CCBs, digoxin, amiodarone), hyperkalemia, Lyme disease, ischemia (inferior MI), post-cardiac surgery

PACEMAKER INDICATIONS & MODES

Class I Indications:

  • Symptomatic bradycardia
  • Third-degree or advanced second-degree AV block
  • Alternating bundle branch block
  • Post-AV node ablation

Pacemaker Mode Codes: [Chamber Paced]-[Chamber Sensed]-[Response]

  • VVI: Paces ventricle, senses ventricle, inhibits when sensed (backup)
  • DDD: Dual chamber pacing and sensing; maintains AV synchrony
  • AAI: Paces atrium only; for SSS with intact AV conduction
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Mobitz II always needs pacemaker â€” high progression risk to complete block
  • Inferior MI + AV block: Often transient (AV nodal); may resolve
  • Anterior MI + AV block: Infranodal; worse prognosis, often needs pacing
  • Lyme disease: Can cause reversible heart block; treat with antibiotics first
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

230. SUDDEN CARDIAC DEATH PREVENTION

Channelopathies â€¢ Inherited Arrhythmias â€¢ Risk Stratification
CHANNELOPATHIES

Long QT Syndrome (LQTS):

  • QTc: >470ms (males), >480ms (females)
  • LQT1: Exercise-triggered (swimming); responds to beta-blockers
  • LQT2: Emotional/auditory triggers; responds to beta-blockers
  • LQT3: Rest/sleep triggers; less responsive to beta-blockers
  • Treatment: Beta-blockers (all), ICD if high-risk, avoid QT-prolonging drugs

Brugada Syndrome:

  • Type 1 pattern: Coved ST elevation â‰¥2mm in V1-V3 + spontaneous or provoked
  • Associated with SCN5A mutation
  • VF typically at rest or during sleep
  • Treatment: ICD for survivors or high-risk; quinidine; avoid fever, certain drugs

CPVT (Catecholaminergic Polymorphic VT):

  • Exercise/stress-induced bidirectional or polymorphic VT
  • Normal resting ECG and structurally normal heart
  • Treatment: Beta-blockers (nadolol), flecainide, ICD for refractory
OTHER SCD RISK CONDITIONS

ARVC (Arrhythmogenic RV Cardiomyopathy):

  • Fibrofatty replacement of RV myocardium
  • ECG: Epsilon wave (V1-V3), T-wave inversions V1-V3
  • VT with LBBB morphology (RV origin)
  • Common cause of SCD in young athletes

Commotio Cordis: VF from blunt chest trauma during vulnerable repolarization phase

WPW with Preexcited AFib:

  • Irregular wide-complex tachycardia
  • AVOID: AV nodal blockers (digoxin, CCB, beta-blockers, adenosine)
  • Treat with: Procainamide or cardioversion
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Long QT + syncope = high risk â€” needs ICD evaluation
  • Brugada can be unmasked by: Fever, class I antiarrhythmics, cocaine
  • Epsilon wave = ARVC
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

231. PERIPHERAL ARTERY DISEASE

ABI â€¢ Claudication â€¢ Critical Limb Ischemia
DIAGNOSIS

Symptoms:

  • Intermittent claudication: Calf pain with walking, relieved by rest (within 10 min)
  • Critical limb ischemia (CLI): Rest pain, non-healing wounds, gangrene

Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI):

  • >1.3: Non-compressible (calcified) â€” unreliable; use toe pressures
  • 1.0-1.3: Normal
  • 0.9-1.0: Borderline
  • <0.9: PAD (diagnosis)
  • <0.4: Severe PAD / CLI

Additional Testing: Exercise ABI (if normal at rest but symptomatic), duplex ultrasound, CTA/MRA for revascularization planning

TREATMENT

All PAD Patients:

  • Smoking cessation (most important modifiable risk factor)
  • Antiplatelet: Aspirin or clopidogrel (clopidogrel may be preferred)
  • Statin: High-intensity
  • BP control, diabetes management
  • Supervised exercise therapy: First-line for claudication; 30-45 min, 3Ã—/week

Claudication:

  • Cilostazol: PDE3 inhibitor; improves walking distance; avoid in HF
  • Revascularization if lifestyle-limiting despite medical therapy

Critical Limb Ischemia:

  • Revascularization urgent (endovascular or surgical)
  • Wound care, pain management
  • Amputation if non-revascularizable
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • ABI <0.9 = PAD; ABI >1.3 = calcified arteries (diabetics)
  • Cilostazol contraindicated in HF
  • Supervised exercise therapy is first-line for claudication â€” as effective as revascularization
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

232. STATIN THERAPY GUIDELINES

ASCVD Risk â€¢ Primary vs Secondary Prevention â€¢ LDL Goals
STATIN BENEFIT GROUPS (2018 ACC/AHA)

Four Groups Who Benefit:

  1. Clinical ASCVD: ACS, stable angina, prior MI/stroke/TIA, PAD
  2. LDL â‰¥190 mg/dL (severe hypercholesterolemia)
  3. Diabetes age 40-75 with LDL 70-189
  4. Primary prevention age 40-75 with LDL 70-189 + 10-year ASCVD risk â‰¥7.5%

Statin Intensity:

IntensityLDL ReductionDrugs
Highâ‰¥50%Atorvastatin 40-80mg, Rosuvastatin 20-40mg
Moderate30-49%Atorvastatin 10-20mg, Rosuvastatin 5-10mg, Simvastatin 20-40mg, Pravastatin 40mg
Low<30%Simvastatin 10mg, Pravastatin 10-20mg
LDL GOALS & ADD-ON THERAPY

LDL Goals:

  • Very high-risk ASCVD: LDL <70 mg/dL (consider <55)
  • High-risk: LDL <70 mg/dL
  • Primary prevention: â‰¥50% reduction; LDL <100

Non-Statin Therapies (if LDL not at goal on max statin):

  • Ezetimibe: 10mg daily; reduces LDL ~15-20%
  • PCSK9 inhibitors: Evolocumab, alirocumab; reduce LDL ~60%; for very high-risk or familial hypercholesterolemia
  • Bempedoic acid: ACL inhibitor; for statin-intolerant
  • Inclisiran: siRNA targeting PCSK9; twice-yearly injection
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • High-intensity statin for all ASCVD (secondary prevention)
  • Statin + ezetimibe before PCSK9 inhibitor
  • Statins safe in NAFLD/elevated LFTs â€” do not withhold
  • True statin intolerance rare (~5-10%); rechallenge with different statin or lower dose
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

233. INPATIENT INSULIN MANAGEMENT

Basal-Bolus â€¢ Sliding Scale Pitfalls â€¢ Transition to Outpatient
GLYCEMIC TARGETS

General Inpatient Goal: 140-180 mg/dL (ADA 2024)

Tighter Control (110-140): Select patients if achievable without hypoglycemia

Less Stringent (180-200): Terminal illness, limited life expectancy, high hypoglycemia risk

Avoid: BG <70 (hypoglycemia) and >250 (hyperglycemia)

BASAL-BOLUS INSULIN PROTOCOL

Total Daily Dose (TDD) Calculation:

  • Insulin-naive: 0.4-0.5 units/kg/day
  • Insulin-sensitive (elderly, CKD, thin): 0.2-0.3 units/kg/day
  • Insulin-resistant (obese, high-dose steroids): 0.5-0.6 units/kg/day

Distribution:

  • 50% Basal: Glargine or detemir once daily (or NPH BID)
  • 50% Bolus: Divided among meals (rapid-acting: lispro, aspart, glulisine)

Correction Scale: Added to meal-time insulin for hyperglycemia

  • Correction factor = 1800 / TDD (how much 1 unit drops BG)
  • Typically 1 unit per 50 mg/dL above target

NPO Patients: Give basal insulin (reduce by 20-25%); hold bolus; use correction-only sliding scale

AVOID SLIDING SCALE ONLY
âš ï¸ SLIDING SCALE MONOTHERAPY IS REACTIVE, NOT PROACTIVE

Treats hyperglycemia after it occurs; causes glucose variability; delays appropriate management. Always use scheduled basal insulin in hospitalized diabetics.

TRANSITION TO OUTPATIENT
  • Give long-acting insulin the evening before or morning of discharge
  • Overlap with IV insulin by 2-4 hours before discontinuing drip
  • Resume home regimen if A1c at goal; adjust if not
  • Hold metformin if receiving contrast; restart 48h later if renal function stable
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Never use sliding scale alone â€” always add basal insulin
  • Continue basal insulin even when NPO (reduce dose 20-25%)
  • Hold oral agents in hospital (except maybe SGLT2i in selected patients)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

234. INSULIN TYPES & PHARMACOLOGY

Onset â€¢ Peak â€¢ Duration â€¢ Clinical Use
INSULIN PHARMACOKINETICS
TypeExamplesOnsetPeakDurationUse
Rapid-actingLispro, Aspart, Glulisine15 min1-2 hr3-5 hrBolus/meals
Ultra-rapidFiasp, Lyumjev5-10 min1 hr3-5 hrBolus/meals
Short-actingRegular (Humulin R)30 min2-4 hr6-8 hrIV drip, meals
IntermediateNPH2-4 hr4-10 hr12-18 hrBasal (BID)
Long-actingGlargine (Lantus), Detemir2-4 hrMinimal20-24 hrBasal (daily)
Ultra-longDegludec (Tresiba), Glargine U-3001-2 hrNone36-42 hrBasal (daily)
CONCENTRATED INSULINS
  • U-500 Regular: 5Ã— concentrated; for severe insulin resistance (>200 units/day)
  • Glargine U-300 (Toujeo): 3Ã— concentrated; flatter profile than U-100
  • Lispro U-200 (Humalog): 2Ã— concentrated; same dosing, smaller volume

Caution: High risk of dosing errors with concentrated insulins

PREMIXED INSULINS
  • 70/30: 70% NPH + 30% regular
  • 75/25: 75% protamine lispro + 25% lispro
  • Given BID (before breakfast and dinner)
  • Less flexible; higher hypoglycemia risk
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Only Regular insulin can be given IV
  • NPH has a peak â€” risk of nocturnal hypoglycemia if given at bedtime
  • Glargine/Detemir are "peakless" â€” lower hypoglycemia risk
  • Degludec has longest half-life â€” flexible dosing timing
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

235. EUGLYCEMIC DKA

SGLT2 Inhibitor-Associated â€¢ Normal Glucose DKA â€¢ Delayed Recognition
DEFINITION & PATHOPHYSIOLOGY

Definition: DKA with blood glucose <250 mg/dL (sometimes <200)

Mechanism with SGLT2i:

  • Glycosuria lowers blood glucose
  • Decreased insulin secretion (lower glucose stimulus)
  • Increased glucagon â†’ lipolysis â†’ ketogenesis
  • Volume depletion from osmotic diuresis

Triggers: Surgery, fasting, illness, reduced carbohydrate intake, dehydration, alcohol

DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Diagnostic Criteria (same as DKA except glucose):

  • pH <7.3 or bicarb <18
  • Anion gap >12
  • Positive ketones (serum Î²-hydroxybutyrate)
  • Glucose may be normal or only mildly elevated

Treatment:

  • Stop SGLT2 inhibitor
  • IV fluids (often more volume depleted than apparent)
  • Dextrose-containing fluids earlier (D5 + insulin to clear ketones)
  • IV insulin infusion (same as standard DKA)
  • Electrolyte replacement (K+, etc.)

Key Difference: Need dextrose earlier in treatment since glucose already low; continue insulin until ketones clear

PREVENTION
  • Hold SGLT2i 3-4 days before surgery
  • Hold during acute illness, fasting, or reduced oral intake
  • Educate patients on symptoms (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, fatigue)
  • Check ketones if symptomatic even with normal glucose
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Normal glucose doesn't rule out DKA â€” check ketones and anion gap
  • SGLT2i-associated DKA can occur in Type 2 diabetics
  • Hold SGLT2i perioperatively (3-4 days before)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

236. DIABETIC MICROVASCULAR COMPLICATIONS

Retinopathy â€¢ Nephropathy â€¢ Neuropathy
DIABETIC RETINOPATHY

Screening:

  • Type 1: Annual dilated exam starting 5 years after diagnosis
  • Type 2: At diagnosis, then annually
  • Pregnancy: Before conception and each trimester

Classification:

  • Non-proliferative (NPDR): Microaneurysms, hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, hard exudates
  • Proliferative (PDR): Neovascularization â€” sight-threatening; needs urgent referral
  • Diabetic macular edema: Can occur at any stage; leading cause of vision loss

Treatment: Glycemic control, BP control, anti-VEGF injections (ranibizumab, aflibercept), laser photocoagulation for PDR

DIABETIC NEPHROPATHY

Screening: Annual urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio (UACR) + eGFR

  • Normal: UACR <30 mg/g
  • Moderately increased (microalbuminuria): 30-300 mg/g
  • Severely increased (macroalbuminuria): >300 mg/g

Treatment:

  • ACEi or ARB: First-line if UACR â‰¥30 (even if normotensive)
  • SGLT2 inhibitor: Add if eGFR â‰¥20 â€” nephroprotective
  • Finerenone: Non-steroidal MRA; add if persistent albuminuria on ACEi/ARB + SGLT2i
  • BP goal <130/80; glycemic control
DIABETIC NEUROPATHY

Types:

  • Distal symmetric polyneuropathy (DSPN): Most common; "stocking-glove" numbness, burning, tingling
