  • Autonomic: Gastroparesis, orthostatic hypotension, erectile dysfunction, neurogenic bladder
  • Mononeuropathies: CN III palsy (pupil-sparing), carpal tunnel
  • Diabetic amyotrophy: Painful proximal weakness (femoral neuropathy)

Screening: Annual monofilament testing + vibration sense

Painful Neuropathy Treatment:

  • First-line: Duloxetine, pregabalin, gabapentin
  • Second-line: TCAs (amitriptyline), tapentadol
  • Topical: Capsaicin, lidocaine patch
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Proliferative retinopathy = urgent ophthalmology referral
  • SGLT2i + finerenone provide additive renal protection beyond ACEi/ARB
  • CN III palsy with pupil sparing = diabetic; pupil involved = aneurysm (urgent)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

237. SUBCLINICAL HYPOTHYROIDISM

Elevated TSH â€¢ Normal T4 â€¢ When to Treat
DEFINITION & CAUSES

Definition: Elevated TSH (typically 4.5-10 mIU/L) with normal free T4

Causes:

  • Early Hashimoto's thyroiditis (most common)
  • Recovery from non-thyroidal illness
  • Medications (lithium, amiodarone, immune checkpoint inhibitors)
  • Post-radioactive iodine or thyroid surgery
  • Iodine deficiency or excess
WHEN TO TREAT

Treat with Levothyroxine if:

  • TSH >10 mIU/L (consensus to treat)
  • TSH 4.5-10 + symptoms consistent with hypothyroidism
  • Pregnancy or planning pregnancy (TSH goal <2.5)
  • Positive TPO antibodies (higher progression risk)
  • Goiter
  • Infertility

Observation Appropriate if:

  • TSH 4.5-10, asymptomatic, TPO negative
  • Elderly (>70-80 years) â€” higher TSH may be normal
  • Recent illness (recheck in 6-8 weeks)

Follow-up if Not Treating: Recheck TSH in 6-12 months

TREATMENT

Levothyroxine Dosing:

  • Start low: 25-50 mcg daily
  • Elderly or CAD: Start 12.5-25 mcg
  • Take on empty stomach, 30-60 min before eating
  • Separate from calcium, iron, PPIs by 4 hours

Monitoring: Recheck TSH in 6-8 weeks; goal TSH 0.5-2.5

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • TSH >10 = treat; TSH 4.5-10 = individualize
  • Elderly may not benefit from treatment â€” higher TSH may be protective
  • Always treat in pregnancy â€” goal TSH <2.5 in first trimester
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

238. THYROID NODULES

FNA Criteria â€¢ TI-RADS â€¢ Bethesda System
INITIAL EVALUATION

First Step: Check TSH

  • Low TSH: Thyroid scan â€” "hot" nodules rarely malignant; no FNA needed
  • Normal/High TSH: Ultrasound evaluation

Suspicious US Features:

  • Hypoechoic
  • Irregular margins
  • Taller than wide
  • Microcalcifications
  • Extrathyroidal extension
  • Abnormal cervical lymph nodes
FNA INDICATIONS (ATA Guidelines)
US PatternFNA Threshold
High suspicion (solid hypoechoic + suspicious features)â‰¥1 cm
Intermediate suspicion (hypoechoic, smooth margins)â‰¥1 cm
Low suspicion (isoechoic/hyperechoic, partially cystic)â‰¥1.5 cm
Very low suspicion (spongiform, purely cystic)â‰¥2 cm or observe
Benign (purely cystic)No FNA
BETHESDA SYSTEM (FNA RESULTS)
CategoryMalignancy RiskManagement
I. Non-diagnostic5-10%Repeat FNA
II. Benign0-3%Follow-up US
III. AUS/FLUS10-30%Repeat FNA or molecular testing
IV. Follicular neoplasm25-40%Molecular testing or lobectomy
V. Suspicious for malignancy50-75%Lobectomy or total thyroidectomy
VI. Malignant97-99%Total thyroidectomy
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Hot nodule on scan = benign; no FNA needed
  • Microcalcifications most specific for papillary thyroid cancer
  • Bethesda III/IV = indeterminate; molecular testing (Afirma, ThyroSeq) helps guide surgery
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

239. THYROIDITIS

Subacute â€¢ Silent â€¢ Postpartum â€¢ Hashimoto's
TYPES OF THYROIDITIS
TypeCausePainRAIUClinical Course
Subacute (de Quervain)Post-viralYES â€” tender thyroidLOWHyper â†’ Hypo â†’ Recovery (weeks-months)
Silent/PainlessAutoimmuneNoLOWHyper â†’ Hypo â†’ Recovery
PostpartumAutoimmuneNoLOWHyper (2-6mo) â†’ Hypo (4-8mo) â†’ Recovery (most)
Hashimoto'sAutoimmune (TPO Ab)NoVariableProgressive hypothyroidism
Drug-inducedAmiodarone, checkpoint inhibitorsVariableVariableDepends on type
SUBACUTE THYROIDITIS (de Quervain)

Presentation: Painful, tender thyroid after viral URI; fever, fatigue, neck pain radiating to jaw/ear

Labs: Elevated ESR (often >50), low TSH initially (thyrotoxic phase), low RAIU

Treatment:

  • NSAIDs for mild pain
  • Prednisone 40mg tapering for severe pain (dramatic response)
  • Beta-blockers for thyrotoxic symptoms
  • No antithyroid drugs (not increased hormone synthesis)
POSTPARTUM THYROIDITIS

Timing: 2-6 months postpartum (hyperthyroid phase), 4-8 months (hypothyroid phase)

Risk Factors: TPO antibody positive, Type 1 DM, prior postpartum thyroiditis

Management:

  • Hyperthyroid phase: Beta-blockers (no thionamides)
  • Hypothyroid phase: Levothyroxine if symptomatic
  • Most recover; 20-30% develop permanent hypothyroidism
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Painful thyroid + elevated ESR + low RAIU = subacute thyroiditis
  • Low RAIU distinguishes thyroiditis from Graves' (high RAIU)
  • Steroids dramatically improve subacute thyroiditis pain
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

240. MALE HYPOGONADISM

Primary vs Secondary â€¢ Testosterone Replacement â€¢ Monitoring
CLASSIFICATION
TypeLocationLH/FSHCauses
Primary (Hypergonadotropic)Testicular failureHIGHKlinefelter (XXY), orchitis, trauma, radiation, chemotherapy
Secondary (Hypogonadotropic)Pituitary/hypothalamicLOW/NormalPituitary tumor, hyperprolactinemia, Kallmann syndrome, opioids, obesity
CLINICAL FEATURES & DIAGNOSIS

Symptoms: Decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, fatigue, decreased muscle mass, increased body fat, mood changes, decreased bone density

Diagnosis:

  • Two morning testosterone levels (8-10 AM) both low (<300 ng/dL)
  • Check LH, FSH to differentiate primary vs secondary
  • If secondary: Check prolactin, pituitary MRI if indicated
  • Consider SHBG and free testosterone if total T borderline
TREATMENT

Testosterone Replacement Options:

  • IM injection: Testosterone cypionate/enanthate every 1-2 weeks
  • Topical gel: Daily application; risk of transfer
  • Transdermal patch: Daily
  • Nasal gel: TID dosing
  • SC pellets: Every 3-6 months

Contraindications:

  • Prostate or breast cancer
  • PSA >4 or palpable nodule (without evaluation)
  • Hematocrit >50%
  • Severe untreated sleep apnea
  • Desire for fertility (suppresses spermatogenesis)

Monitoring: Testosterone level, hematocrit (q3-6mo first year), PSA, lipids, BMD

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Two AM testosterone levels required before diagnosis
  • Testosterone replacement suppresses fertility â€” use hCG/clomiphene if fertility desired
  • Monitor hematocrit â€” polycythemia is common side effect
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

241. ZOLLINGER-ELLISON SYNDROME

Gastrinoma â€¢ Refractory PUD â€¢ MEN1 Association
CLINICAL FEATURES

Presentation:

  • Refractory or recurrent peptic ulcers (especially distal duodenum/jejunum)
  • Multiple ulcers
  • Diarrhea/steatorrhea (acid inactivates lipase)
  • GERD symptoms

Location: Gastrinoma triangle (pancreas, duodenum); 60-90% malignant; 25% associated with MEN1

DIAGNOSIS

Fasting Serum Gastrin: >1000 pg/mL diagnostic (with gastric pH <2)

Secretin Stimulation Test: Paradoxical rise in gastrin (>120 pg/mL increase) â€” confirms diagnosis

Must Confirm Gastric Acid Hypersecretion: pH <2 rules out achlorhydria/PPI effect

Localization: CT/MRI, EUS, somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (Octreoscan)

Rule Out MEN1: Calcium, PTH, prolactin, pituitary imaging

TREATMENT
  • High-dose PPI: Control acid secretion (often 2-4Ã— standard dose)
  • Surgical resection: Curative if localized; not if metastatic or MEN1
  • Somatostatin analogs: For metastatic disease
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Gastrin >1000 + pH <2 = diagnostic
  • Stop PPI before testing â€” PPIs elevate gastrin
  • Screen for MEN1 in all ZES patients
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

242. SMALL INTESTINAL BACTERIAL OVERGROWTH (SIBO)

Malabsorption â€¢ Breath Testing â€¢ Rifaximin
RISK FACTORS & PRESENTATION

Risk Factors:

  • Anatomic: Blind loops, strictures, diverticula, post-surgical (Roux-en-Y)
  • Motility disorders: Scleroderma, diabetes gastroparesis, chronic intestinal pseudo-obstruction
  • Hypochlorhydria: Chronic PPI use, atrophic gastritis
  • Immune: IgA deficiency, HIV

Symptoms: Bloating, flatulence, abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, weight loss, steatorrhea

Deficiencies: B12 (bacteria consume), fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K)

DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Diagnosis:

  • Glucose or lactulose hydrogen breath test: Most practical
  • Small bowel aspirate >10Â³ CFU/mL: Gold standard but invasive

Treatment:

  • Rifaximin 550mg TID Ã— 14 days: First-line (non-absorbable)
  • Alternatives: Metronidazole + fluoroquinolone, amoxicillin-clavulanate, doxycycline
  • Recurrence common: May need cyclic antibiotics
  • Treat underlying cause when possible
  • Nutritional supplementation: B12, fat-soluble vitamins
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • B12 deficiency (not folate) â€” bacteria consume B12 but produce folate
  • Rifaximin first-line â€” well-tolerated, minimal systemic absorption
  • Consider in scleroderma, post-surgical patients with GI symptoms
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

243. MALABSORPTION SYNDROMES

Fat vs Carbohydrate â€¢ Workup â€¢ Etiology-Specific Treatment
CLINICAL FEATURES

General Symptoms: Diarrhea, weight loss, bloating, flatulence

Fat Malabsorption (Steatorrhea): Greasy, foul-smelling, floating stools; fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies (A, D, E, K)

Carbohydrate Malabsorption: Watery diarrhea, bloating, flatulence (osmotic)

Specific Deficiencies:

  • Iron: Anemia (proximal small bowel)
  • B12: Anemia, neuropathy (terminal ileum)
  • Calcium/Vitamin D: Osteoporosis, hypocalcemia
DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSIS
LocationCausesKey Features
Luminal (digestion)Pancreatic insufficiency, bile salt deficiencySteatorrhea, low fecal elastase
Mucosal (absorption)Celiac, tropical sprue, Whipple's, Crohn's, radiationVillous atrophy, specific antibodies
Post-mucosal (lymphatic)Intestinal lymphangiectasia, lymphomaProtein-losing enteropathy, chylous ascites
WORKUP
  • Qualitative fecal fat: Sudan stain (screening)
  • Quantitative fecal fat: >7g/day on 100g fat diet (72-hour collection)
  • Fecal elastase: <200 Î¼g/g suggests pancreatic insufficiency
  • D-xylose test: Normal = luminal problem; Abnormal = mucosal disease
  • Celiac serology: TTG-IgA (check total IgA)
  • Small bowel biopsy: If celiac suspected or unexplained
  • Imaging: CT/MRI enterography, capsule endoscopy
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Low fecal elastase = pancreatic insufficiency; treat with pancreatic enzymes
  • D-xylose normal = pancreatic/biliary; abnormal = mucosal disease
  • Check IgA level when ordering TTG-IgA (IgA deficiency gives false negative)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

244. MICROSCOPIC COLITIS

Collagenous vs Lymphocytic â€¢ Normal Colonoscopy â€¢ Budesonide
CLINICAL FEATURES

Presentation:

  • Chronic watery, non-bloody diarrhea
  • Typically middle-aged to elderly women
  • Nocturnal diarrhea common
  • Associated with autoimmune diseases (celiac, thyroid)

Drug Associations: NSAIDs, PPIs, SSRIs, checkpoint inhibitors

DIAGNOSIS

Colonoscopy: Grossly normal (hence "microscopic")

Diagnosis requires random biopsies:

  • Collagenous colitis: Thickened subepithelial collagen band (>10 Î¼m)
  • Lymphocytic colitis: Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes (>20 per 100 epithelial cells)

Labs: May have elevated inflammatory markers; rule out celiac disease

TREATMENT

Step 1: Discontinue offending medications (NSAIDs, PPIs)

Step 2: Antidiarrheals (loperamide) for mild symptoms

Step 3: Budesonide 9mg daily Ã— 6-8 weeks â€” first-line for moderate-severe; high response rate

Maintenance: Budesonide 6mg; relapses common after stopping

Refractory: Bismuth subsalicylate, cholestyramine, immunomodulators, biologics (rare)

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Normal colonoscopy + chronic watery diarrhea = biopsy for microscopic colitis
  • Budesonide highly effective â€” topically active, low systemic absorption
  • Screen for celiac disease â€” commonly coexists
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

245. HEREDITARY CRC SYNDROMES

Lynch Syndrome â€¢ FAP â€¢ Screening Protocols
LYNCH SYNDROME (HNPCC)

Genetics: Autosomal dominant; MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2 mutations (mismatch repair genes)

Features:

  • Early-onset CRC (mean age 45)
  • Right-sided predominance
  • Synchronous/metachronous CRC
  • Microsatellite instability (MSI-high)

Extra-Colonic Cancers: Endometrial (most common), ovarian, gastric, urinary tract, small bowel, brain (Turcot), sebaceous tumors (Muir-Torre)

Amsterdam II Criteria (3-2-1 rule): 3 relatives with Lynch-associated cancer, 2 generations, 1 diagnosed <50

Screening: Colonoscopy every 1-2 years starting age 20-25 (or 2-5 years before youngest case)

FAMILIAL ADENOMATOUS POLYPOSIS (FAP)

Genetics: Autosomal dominant; APC gene mutation

Features:

  • >100 colorectal adenomatous polyps (often thousands)
  • 100% CRC risk if untreated (by age 40)
  • Polyps develop in teens

Extra-Colonic: Duodenal adenomas/cancer (second most common cancer), desmoid tumors, thyroid cancer, osteomas (Gardner syndrome), brain tumors (Turcot)

Attenuated FAP: 10-100 polyps, later onset

Screening: Annual sigmoidoscopy/colonoscopy starting age 10-12

Treatment: Prophylactic colectomy when polyps develop (usually late teens/20s)

OTHER SYNDROMES
  • Peutz-Jeghers: Hamartomatous polyps + mucocutaneous pigmentation; STK11 mutation; GI/breast/pancreas/ovarian cancer risk
  • Juvenile Polyposis: >5 juvenile polyps; SMAD4/BMPR1A; CRC risk
  • MUTYH-associated: Autosomal recessive; 10-100 adenomas; similar to attenuated FAP
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Lynch = MSI-high, right-sided, endometrial cancer
  • FAP = thousands of polyps, 100% cancer risk, prophylactic colectomy
  • Universal tumor testing for Lynch now recommended for all CRC
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

246. PRIMARY SCLEROSING CHOLANGITIS (PSC)

IBD Association â€¢ Beading on MRCP â€¢ Cholangiocarcinoma Risk
CLINICAL FEATURES

Demographics: Young to middle-aged men; 70-80% have IBD (usually UC)

Presentation:

  • Fatigue, pruritus
  • RUQ pain, jaundice (later)
  • May be asymptomatic (elevated ALP on labs)
  • Recurrent cholangitis (fever, RUQ pain, jaundice)
DIAGNOSIS

Labs:

  • Cholestatic pattern: Elevated ALP (predominant), GGT, bilirubin
  • p-ANCA positive (70%) â€” non-specific
  • AMA negative (unlike PBC)

Imaging:

  • MRCP (first-line): Multifocal strictures and dilations ("beading") of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts
  • ERCP: More invasive; used therapeutically

Biopsy: "Onion-skin" periductal fibrosis (not required for diagnosis)

COMPLICATIONS & TREATMENT

Complications:

  • Cholangiocarcinoma: 10-15% lifetime risk; difficult to detect
  • Cirrhosis, portal hypertension
  • Dominant stricture (may need ERCP dilation/stenting)
  • Fat-soluble vitamin deficiency
  • Increased CRC risk (need annual colonoscopy if UC)

Treatment:

  • No proven medical therapy to slow progression
  • UDCA: May improve labs but no survival benefit; high-dose harmful
  • Pruritus management: Cholestyramine, rifampin
  • Liver transplant: Only curative option; can recur
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • PSC + UC: Must do colonoscopy even if colectomy (rectal stump cancer)
  • Beading on MRCP = PSC; AMA negative (unlike PBC)
  • No medical therapy slows progression â€” transplant only cure
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

247. WILSON DISEASE

Copper Overload â€¢ Kayser-Fleischer Rings â€¢ Ceruloplasmin
CLINICAL FEATURES

Age of Onset: 5-35 years (hepatic earlier, neuropsych later)

Hepatic: Ranges from asymptomatic elevated LFTs to cirrhosis to acute liver failure (Coombs-negative hemolytic anemia)

Neurologic: Tremor, dystonia, dysarthria, parkinsonism, psychiatric symptoms (depression, personality change)

Ophthalmologic: Kayser-Fleischer rings â€” copper deposits in Descemet's membrane (requires slit-lamp); present in 95% with neurologic disease

Other: Coombs-negative hemolytic anemia, renal tubular acidosis, arthritis

DIAGNOSIS

Labs:

  • Low serum ceruloplasmin (<20 mg/dL) â€” 85% sensitive
  • Elevated 24-hour urine copper (>100 Î¼g/day; >40 Î¼g suggests)
  • Elevated hepatic copper on liver biopsy (>250 Î¼g/g dry weight) â€” gold standard
  • Low serum copper (bound to ceruloplasmin); high free copper

Genetic Testing: ATP7B gene mutations (autosomal recessive)

Imaging: Brain MRI may show basal ganglia changes

TREATMENT
  • Chelation therapy: D-penicillamine (first-line) or trientine
  • Zinc: Blocks intestinal copper absorption; maintenance or mild disease
  • Low copper diet: Avoid shellfish, liver, nuts, chocolate, mushrooms
  • Liver transplant: Curative for liver failure; may improve neurologic symptoms
  • Screen siblings (25% risk)
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Young patient + liver disease + neuropsych symptoms = Wilson
  • Low ceruloplasmin + Kayser-Fleischer rings = diagnostic
  • Acute liver failure + Coombs-negative hemolysis = Wilson until proven otherwise
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

248. HEREDITARY HEMOCHROMATOSIS

Iron Overload â€¢ HFE Gene â€¢ Phlebotomy
CLINICAL FEATURES

Classic Triad: Cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, skin hyperpigmentation ("bronze diabetes")

Other Manifestations:

  • Liver: Elevated LFTs, cirrhosis, HCC (leading cause of death)
  • Heart: Dilated cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias
  • Endocrine: Diabetes, hypogonadism
  • Joints: Arthropathy (2nd/3rd MCP â€” "iron fist"), chondrocalcinosis (pseudogout)
  • Skin: Bronze/gray pigmentation

Demographics: Northern European descent; men symptomatic earlier (women protected by menses)

DIAGNOSIS

Initial Testing:

  • Transferrin saturation >45% â€” most sensitive screening test
  • Ferritin elevated (but non-specific; acute phase reactant)

Confirmatory:

  • HFE gene testing: C282Y homozygosity (most common); C282Y/H63D compound heterozygosity
  • MRI: Quantify liver/cardiac iron (T2*)
  • Liver biopsy: If ferritin >1000 or elevated LFTs (assess fibrosis)
TREATMENT
  • Phlebotomy: First-line; 500mL weekly until ferritin <50-100; then maintenance q2-4 months
  • Goal: Ferritin 50-100 ng/mL, transferrin saturation <50%
  • Chelation (deferasirox): If phlebotomy contraindicated
  • Avoid: Iron supplements, vitamin C (increases absorption), excess alcohol
  • Screen first-degree relatives
  • HCC surveillance: If cirrhosis (US Â± AFP every 6 months)
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Transferrin saturation >45% = screen with HFE genotyping
  • C282Y homozygous most common genotype in symptomatic patients
  • Arthropathy may not improve with phlebotomy
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

249. EOSINOPHILIC ESOPHAGITIS (EoE)

Dysphagia â€¢ Food Impaction â€¢ Ringed Esophagus
CLINICAL FEATURES

Demographics: Young adults (20s-30s), predominantly male; often atopic history (asthma, allergies, eczema)

Symptoms:

  • Dysphagia to solids (most common)
  • Food impaction (may be presenting symptom)
  • Heartburn (often PPI-refractory)
  • Chest pain
  • Children: Feeding difficulties, failure to thrive
DIAGNOSIS

EGD Findings:

  • Rings/trachealization ("feline esophagus")
  • Linear furrows
  • White exudates/plaques
  • Strictures, narrow caliber
  • May appear normal

Histology Required:

  • â‰¥15 eosinophils per high-power field on esophageal biopsy
  • Multiple biopsies from proximal and distal esophagus (patchy)

Rule Out: GERD (but can coexist), other causes of esophageal eosinophilia

TREATMENT

First-Line Options:

  • PPI: Omeprazole 40mg BID Ã— 8 weeks (PPI-responsive EoE)
  • Topical corticosteroids: Swallowed fluticasone (from MDI, don't inhale) or budesonide slurry
  • Dietary elimination: 6-food elimination (milk, wheat, egg, soy, nuts, seafood) or elemental diet

Refractory: Dupilumab (IL-4/IL-13 inhibitor) â€” FDA approved for EoE

Dilation: For symptomatic strictures (careful â€” mucosal tears common)

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Young atopic male + dysphagia + food impaction = EoE
  • â‰¥15 eos/hpf required for diagnosis
  • Swallowed topical steroids â€” not inhaled
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

250. IDIOPATHIC PULMONARY FIBROSIS (IPF)

UIP Pattern â€¢ Progressive Fibrosis â€¢ Antifibrotics
CLINICAL FEATURES

Demographics: Age >50, male predominance, smoking history

Symptoms: Progressive dyspnea, dry cough (months to years)

Exam: Bibasilar inspiratory "Velcro" crackles, clubbing (25-50%)

PFTs: Restrictive pattern (â†“FVC, â†“TLC), â†“DLCO (often early and disproportionate)

DIAGNOSIS

HRCT Pattern â€” UIP (Usual Interstitial Pneumonia):

  • Honeycombing (clustered cystic airspaces) â€” most specific
  • Reticular opacities
  • Traction bronchiectasis
  • Basal and peripheral predominance
  • Absence of features inconsistent with UIP

Definite UIP on HRCT + compatible clinical = IPF (no biopsy needed)

Surgical Lung Biopsy: If HRCT indeterminate; shows UIP pattern histologically

Rule Out: CTD-ILD, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, drug-induced, asbestosis

TREATMENT

Antifibrotic Therapy (slow progression):

  • Nintedanib: Tyrosine kinase inhibitor; diarrhea common side effect
  • Pirfenidone: Anti-fibrotic/anti-inflammatory; GI side effects, photosensitivity

Neither is curative; both slow FVC decline

Supportive: Supplemental O2, pulmonary rehabilitation, vaccination

Lung Transplant: Only curative option; refer early (median survival 3-5 years without)

AVOID: Steroids and immunosuppressants (no benefit, may harm in IPF)

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Honeycombing + basal/peripheral = UIP pattern = IPF
  • Steroids don't help IPF (unlike other ILDs)
  • Early transplant referral â€” median survival only 3-5 years
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

251. CYSTIC FIBROSIS

CFTR Mutation â€¢ Bronchiectasis â€¢ CFTR Modulators
PATHOPHYSIOLOGY & CLINICAL FEATURES

Genetics: Autosomal recessive; CFTR gene mutations (F508del most common)

Pulmonary:

  • Thick secretions, bronchiectasis, recurrent infections
  • Pathogens: Pseudomonas aeruginosa (most significant), S. aureus, Burkholderia cepacia, NTM
  • Progressive decline â†’ respiratory failure

GI:

  • Pancreatic insufficiency (85%) â€” steatorrhea, malnutrition
  • Meconium ileus (neonates), DIOS (adults)
  • CF-related diabetes (CFRD)
  • Hepatobiliary disease

Other: Male infertility (absent vas deferens), sinus disease, osteoporosis

DIAGNOSIS
  • Sweat chloride >60 mEq/L â€” diagnostic
  • Newborn screening (immunoreactive trypsinogen)
  • CFTR genetic testing
TREATMENT

CFTR Modulators (Disease-Modifying):

  • Elexacaftor/Tezacaftor/Ivacaftor (Trikafta): Highly effective for F508del (90% of patients); dramatically improves lung function and outcomes
  • Ivacaftor alone for gating mutations (G551D)

Airway Clearance:

  • Chest physiotherapy, oscillating devices
  • Dornase alfa (Pulmozyme): DNase; reduces mucus viscosity
  • Hypertonic saline: Nebulized 7%

Infections: Aggressive treatment of exacerbations; chronic suppressive therapy for Pseudomonas (inhaled tobramycin, aztreonam)

Nutrition: Pancreatic enzyme replacement, fat-soluble vitamins, high-calorie diet

Transplant: For advanced disease

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Sweat chloride >60 = CF; 30-59 = intermediate
  • Trikafta transformed CF care â€” now chronic disease with near-normal lifespan for many
  • Pseudomonas eradication attempted at first isolation
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

252. ALPHA-1 ANTITRYPSIN DEFICIENCY

Early COPD â€¢ Panacinar Emphysema â€¢ Augmentation Therapy
CLINICAL FEATURES

When to Suspect:

  • COPD/emphysema at young age (<45)
  • COPD in non-smoker or minimal smoking
  • Basilar-predominant emphysema (panacinar)
  • Family history of emphysema or liver disease
  • Unexplained liver disease
  • Necrotizing panniculitis

Pulmonary: Early-onset COPD; accelerated by smoking

Hepatic: Cirrhosis (AAT polymers accumulate in liver); HCC risk

DIAGNOSIS
  • Serum AAT level: <11 Î¼M (or <80 mg/dL) = severe deficiency
  • Phenotype/genotype testing: PI*ZZ most common severe; PI*MZ heterozygotes have intermediate levels

Who to Test: All COPD patients should be tested at least once (ATS/ERS recommendation)

TREATMENT
  • Smoking cessation: Most important intervention
  • Standard COPD treatment: Bronchodilators, ICS if indicated
  • AAT augmentation therapy: IV pooled human AAT (Prolastin) weekly for severe deficiency with evidence of emphysema; slows FEV1 decline
  • Lung transplant: For advanced disease
  • Liver transplant: For end-stage liver disease (curative â€” liver produces normal AAT)
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Test ALL COPD patients for AAT deficiency at least once
  • Basilar emphysema in young non-smoker = think AAT deficiency
  • PI*ZZ = severe deficiency; PI*MZ = carrier
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

253. BRONCHIECTASIS

Chronic Productive Cough â€¢ Airway Clearance â€¢ NTM
ETIOLOGY

Post-Infectious: Childhood pneumonia, TB, NTM, pertussis

Immune: CVID, IgA deficiency, HIV

Genetic: Cystic fibrosis, primary ciliary dyskinesia, AAT deficiency

Aspiration/Obstruction: Foreign body, tumor, ABPA

Autoimmune: RA, SjÃ¶gren's, IBD

Idiopathic: ~50% of cases

CLINICAL FEATURES & DIAGNOSIS

Symptoms: Chronic productive cough (purulent sputum), hemoptysis, recurrent infections, dyspnea

Exam: Crackles, wheezing, clubbing

HRCT: Bronchial dilation (internal diameter > adjacent pulmonary artery = "signet ring sign"), lack of tapering, bronchial wall thickening

Workup for Etiology:

  • Immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, IgM)
  • CFTR testing (even in adults)
  • Sputum for AFB and fungal cultures
  • Aspergillus IgE, IgG (ABPA)
  • Consider PCD testing if suggestive history
TREATMENT

Airway Clearance: Chest physiotherapy, oscillating devices, hypertonic saline

Mucolytics: Hypertonic saline (7%); dornase alfa only for CF

Antibiotics:

  • Acute exacerbations: 14 days, culture-directed
  • Chronic macrolide therapy (azithromycin 3Ã—/week): Reduces exacerbations (rule out NTM first)
  • Inhaled antibiotics for Pseudomonas colonization

Bronchodilators: If coexisting airflow obstruction

Surgery: Resection for localized disease with recurrent infections/hemoptysis

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Rule out NTM before starting chronic azithromycin (resistance)
  • Test immunoglobulins and consider CF even in adults
  • Signet ring sign on CT = bronchiectasis
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

254. HYPERSENSITIVITY PNEUMONITIS

Antigen Exposure â€¢ Acute vs Chronic â€¢ Ground Glass + Mosaic
ETIOLOGY & CLASSIFICATION

Common Antigens:

  • Bird fancier's lung: Avian proteins (pigeons, parakeets)
  • Farmer's lung: Thermophilic actinomycetes (moldy hay)
  • Hot tub lung: Mycobacterium avium complex
  • Humidifier/AC lung: Bacteria, fungi in water reservoirs
TypeOnsetFeatures
Acute4-8 hours post-exposureFlu-like symptoms, dyspnea, cough; resolves with avoidance
SubacuteWeeks-monthsProgressive dyspnea, cough, fatigue
ChronicMonths-yearsProgressive fibrosis, may be irreversible
DIAGNOSIS

History: Exposure history crucial (occupational, hobbies, home environment)

Labs: Serum precipitins (IgG to specific antigens) â€” supportive but not diagnostic

HRCT:

  • Acute/Subacute: Ground-glass opacities, centrilobular nodules, mosaic attenuation (air trapping)
  • Chronic: Fibrosis, traction bronchiectasis; upper/mid lung predominant

BAL: Lymphocytosis (>20-30%); CD4/CD8 ratio variable

Biopsy: Poorly formed non-caseating granulomas, cellular bronchiolitis

TREATMENT
  • Antigen avoidance: Most important; often curative in acute/subacute
  • Corticosteroids: For severe or progressive disease (prednisone 0.5-1 mg/kg)
  • Immunosuppression: Mycophenolate, azathioprine for chronic progressive
  • Antifibrotics: Consider in fibrotic HP (nintedanib approved)
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Detailed exposure history is key â€” birds, hot tubs, moldy environments
  • Upper/mid lung predominance (vs IPF which is basal)
  • BAL lymphocytosis supports diagnosis
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

255. PULMONARY NODULE EVALUATION

Fleischner Criteria â€¢ Solid vs Ground-Glass â€¢ Malignancy Risk
DEFINITIONS

Pulmonary Nodule: <3 cm; if >3 cm = mass (higher malignancy risk)

Types:

  • Solid: Completely obscures lung parenchyma
  • Ground-glass (subsolid): Does not obscure lung; slower growing but higher malignancy rate
  • Part-solid: Both components; highest malignancy risk
RISK STRATIFICATION

Higher Malignancy Risk:

  • Larger size (>8mm especially concerning)
  • Spiculated margins
  • Upper lobe location
  • Part-solid or ground-glass
  • Smoking history, older age
  • History of cancer
  • Growth on serial imaging

Lower Malignancy Risk:

  • Smooth margins
  • Calcification patterns (central, popcorn, laminated)
  • Stable for >2 years
  • Multiple nodules (often infectious/inflammatory)
FLEISCHNER SOCIETY GUIDELINES (2017) â€” SOLID NODULES
SizeLow RiskHigh Risk
<6mmNo follow-upOptional CT at 12 months
6-8mmCT at 6-12 months, then consider 18-24moCT at 6-12 months, then 18-24 months
>8mmCT at 3 months, PET/CT, or biopsy

Ground-Glass/Part-Solid: More conservative approach; longer follow-up intervals but ultimately may need resection

EVALUATION OPTIONS
  • Serial CT: For low-intermediate risk
  • PET-CT: For nodules >8mm; sensitivity ~90% for malignancy
  • Biopsy: CT-guided, bronchoscopy (navigational), surgical
  • Surgical resection: High-risk nodules or positive biopsy
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • <6mm solid nodule in low-risk patient = no follow-up needed
  • Part-solid nodules have highest malignancy risk
  • Stability >2 years suggests benign (but ground-glass needs longer follow-up)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

256. THALASSEMIAS

Alpha vs Beta â€¢ Microcytic Anemia â€¢ Iron Overload
OVERVIEW

Definition: Inherited disorders of reduced globin chain synthesis (Î± or Î² chains)

Result: Microcytic anemia with ineffective erythropoiesis; hemolysis in severe forms

BETA-THALASSEMIA
TypeGenotypeClinical
Minor (trait)Î²/Î²âº or Î²/Î²â°Mild microcytic anemia; usually asymptomatic
IntermediaÎ²âº/Î²âº or Î²âº/Î²â°Moderate anemia; occasional transfusions
Major (Cooley's)Î²â°/Î²â°Severe transfusion-dependent anemia; presents in infancy

Labs: Microcytic anemia, target cells, elevated HbA2 (>3.5%) on electrophoresis

Complications (Major): Iron overload (transfusions + increased absorption), extramedullary hematopoiesis, bone deformities, growth retardation

ALPHA-THALASSEMIA
Genes DeletedNameClinical
1 (Î±Î±/Î±-)Silent carrierNormal
2 (Î±-/Î±- or Î±Î±/--)TraitMild microcytic anemia
3 (Î±-/--)HbH diseaseModerate hemolytic anemia; HbH (Î²4) on electrophoresis
4 (--/--)Hb Bart's hydrops fetalisFatal in utero

Note: Î±-thalassemia trait has NORMAL hemoglobin electrophoresis (need genetic testing)

TREATMENT
  • Trait: No treatment; avoid unnecessary iron supplementation
  • Transfusion-dependent: Regular transfusions to maintain Hb 9-10
  • Iron chelation: Deferasirox (oral daily), deferoxamine (SC/IV), deferiprone
  • Splenectomy: If hypersplenism increasing transfusion needs
  • Curative: Allogeneic stem cell transplant; gene therapy (new)
  • Luspatercept: For transfusion-dependent Î²-thalassemia (reduces transfusion burden)
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Î²-thal trait: elevated HbA2; Î±-thal trait: normal electrophoresis
  • Don't give iron for thalassemia trait (already iron-loaded)
  • Mentzer index <13 (MCV/RBC) suggests thalassemia over iron deficiency
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

257. MYELOPROLIFERATIVE NEOPLASMS

PV â€¢ ET â€¢ MF â€¢ JAK2 Mutation
OVERVIEW
DiseasePrimary FindingJAK2 V617FOther Mutations
Polycythemia Vera (PV)Elevated RBC mass95%JAK2 exon 12
Essential Thrombocythemia (ET)Elevated platelets50-60%CALR, MPL
Primary Myelofibrosis (MF)Bone marrow fibrosis50-60%CALR, MPL
POLYCYTHEMIA VERA

Diagnosis: Hb >16.5 (M) or >16 (F), OR Hct >49%/48% + JAK2 mutation + low EPO

Symptoms: Hyperviscosity (headache, visual changes, dizziness), aquagenic pruritus, erythromelalgia, splenomegaly, thrombosis (including unusual sites â€” Budd-Chiari, portal vein)

Treatment:

  • Phlebotomy: Goal Hct <45%
  • Aspirin 81mg (all patients unless contraindicated)
  • Cytoreduction if high-risk: Hydroxyurea first-line; ruxolitinib (JAK inhibitor) if refractory
ESSENTIAL THROMBOCYTHEMIA

Diagnosis: Platelets â‰¥450K, bone marrow biopsy (megakaryocyte proliferation), JAK2/CALR/MPL mutation, exclusion of other causes

Complications: Thrombosis AND bleeding (acquired vWD if platelets very high)

Treatment:

  • Low-risk: Aspirin alone (or observation if CALR+ low-risk)
  • High-risk: Hydroxyurea + aspirin; anagrelide alternative
PRIMARY MYELOFIBROSIS

Features: Bone marrow fibrosis, cytopenias, massive splenomegaly, constitutional symptoms, leukoerythroblastic smear (teardrop cells, nucleated RBCs)

Treatment:

  • Ruxolitinib: First-line for symptomatic splenomegaly/symptoms
  • Allogeneic SCT: Only curative option (for eligible high-risk patients)
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • PV: Hct goal <45% reduces thrombosis
  • Aquagenic pruritus classic for PV
  • Teardrop cells + nucleated RBCs = myelofibrosis
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

258. CHRONIC MYELOID LEUKEMIA

BCR-ABL â€¢ Philadelphia Chromosome â€¢ Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors
CLINICAL FEATURES

Presentation: Often asymptomatic (incidental leukocytosis); fatigue, weight loss, early satiety, splenomegaly

Labs:

  • Marked leukocytosis (often 50-200K) with left shift
  • Basophilia and eosinophilia
  • Low LAP (leukocyte alkaline phosphatase) score
  • Anemia, thrombocytosis (or thrombocytopenia in advanced phase)
DIAGNOSIS

Philadelphia Chromosome: t(9;22) â€” BCR-ABL1 fusion gene

Testing:

  • Bone marrow biopsy with cytogenetics
  • FISH for BCR-ABL
  • PCR for BCR-ABL (quantitative â€” used for monitoring)
PHASES & TREATMENT
PhaseFeatures
Chronic<10% blasts; most present here
Accelerated10-19% blasts, other criteria
Blast crisisâ‰¥20% blasts; like acute leukemia

Treatment:

  • Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors (TKIs): First-line for all patients
    • Imatinib: First-generation; well-tolerated
    • Dasatinib, Nilotinib, Bosutinib: Second-generation; more potent
    • Ponatinib: For T315I mutation (resistant to others)
  • Monitoring: Quantitative BCR-ABL PCR every 3 months; goal is major molecular response (MMR)
  • TKI discontinuation: Possible in select patients with deep molecular response
  • Allogeneic SCT: Reserved for TKI failure or blast crisis
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • BCR-ABL = Philadelphia chromosome = CML
  • TKIs transformed CML â€” near-normal life expectancy in chronic phase
  • T315I mutation = resistance; use ponatinib
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

259. CHRONIC LYMPHOCYTIC LEUKEMIA

CD5+ B-cells â€¢ Smudge Cells â€¢ Watch and Wait
CLINICAL FEATURES

Demographics: Median age 70; most common adult leukemia in Western countries

Presentation: Often asymptomatic (incidental lymphocytosis); lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, B symptoms

Labs:

  • Lymphocytosis (â‰¥5000/Î¼L clonal B-lymphocytes)
  • Smudge cells on peripheral smear
  • Flow cytometry: CD5+, CD19+, CD20 (dim), CD23+

Complications: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, ITP, infections (hypogammaglobulinemia), Richter transformation (to DLBCL)

STAGING & PROGNOSIS
Rai StageFeaturesRisk
0Lymphocytosis onlyLow
I+ LymphadenopathyIntermediate
II+ HepatosplenomegalyIntermediate
III+ Anemia (Hb <11)High
IV+ Thrombocytopenia (<100K)High

Poor Prognostic Markers: del(17p), TP53 mutation, unmutated IGHV, del(11q)

TREATMENT

Early Stage (Rai 0-II) Asymptomatic: Watch and wait â€” treatment doesn't improve survival

Indications to Treat: Progressive cytopenias, massive/symptomatic splenomegaly/lymphadenopathy, B symptoms, AIHA/ITP refractory to steroids

First-Line Options:

  • BTK inhibitors: Ibrutinib, acalabrutinib, zanubrutinib â€” can be used regardless of del(17p)
  • BCL-2 inhibitor: Venetoclax (+ obinutuzumab for fixed duration)
  • Chemoimmunotherapy (FCR, BR) less commonly used now
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Smudge cells + CD5+ B-cells = CLL
  • Watch and wait for early-stage asymptomatic
  • del(17p)/TP53 = poor prognosis; BTK inhibitors preferred
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

260. MULTIPLE MYELOMA

CRAB Criteria â€¢ M-Protein â€¢ Bone Disease
CLINICAL FEATURES â€” CRAB
  • C â€” Calcium elevation (hypercalcemia)
  • R â€” Renal insufficiency (light chain cast nephropathy)
  • A â€” Anemia (normocytic)
  • B â€” Bone disease (lytic lesions, pathologic fractures, bone pain)

Other: Recurrent infections, hyperviscosity (rare), amyloidosis

DIAGNOSIS

Diagnostic Criteria (â‰¥10% clonal plasma cells + end-organ damage OR biomarker):

  • Bone marrow clonal plasma cells â‰¥10%
  • PLUS: CRAB criteria OR biomarkers (sFLC ratio â‰¥100, bone marrow plasma cells â‰¥60%, >1 focal lesion on MRI)

Workup:

  • SPEP/UPEP with immunofixation: M-protein (monoclonal spike)
  • Serum free light chains
  • Bone marrow biopsy
  • Skeletal survey or whole-body low-dose CT (lytic lesions)
  • Î²2-microglobulin, LDH (prognosis)
TREATMENT

Transplant-Eligible:

  • Induction: VRd (bortezomib, lenalidomide, dexamethasone) Â± daratumumab
  • Autologous stem cell transplant
  • Maintenance: Lenalidomide

Transplant-Ineligible: VRd or DRd (daratumumab, lenalidomide, dex) until progression

Supportive:

  • Bisphosphonates (zoledronic acid) or denosumab for bone disease
  • Avoid NSAIDs (nephrotoxic)
  • VTE prophylaxis with IMiDs
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Lytic lesions (not blastic) â€” bone scan often negative
  • Rouleaux formation on smear
  • MGUS â†’ smoldering â†’ myeloma progression spectrum
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

261. VON WILLEBRAND DISEASE

Most Common Inherited Bleeding Disorder â€¢ DDAVP
TYPES
TypeDefectInheritanceSeverity
Type 1Partial quantitative deficiencyADMild-moderate (75%)
Type 2Qualitative defect (multiple subtypes)ADModerate
Type 3Complete deficiencyARSevere (rare)
CLINICAL FEATURES & DIAGNOSIS

Bleeding Pattern: Mucocutaneous â€” epistaxis, easy bruising, menorrhagia, GI bleeding, prolonged bleeding after surgery/dental procedures

Labs:

  • Prolonged PTT (vWF carries factor VIII)
  • Normal PT, platelets
  • Prolonged bleeding time (or abnormal PFA-100)

Specific Tests:

  • vWF antigen (vWF:Ag)
  • vWF activity (ristocetin cofactor â€” vWF:RCo)
  • Factor VIII level
  • vWF multimer analysis (for Type 2 subtypes)
TREATMENT

Type 1:

  • DDAVP (desmopressin): First-line; releases vWF from endothelial stores
  • Test with DDAVP trial before planned procedures

Type 2 & 3 (or DDAVP-unresponsive):

  • vWF-containing factor concentrates (Humate-P)

Adjuncts:

  • Tranexamic acid: For mucosal bleeding, menorrhagia
  • Avoid aspirin/NSAIDs
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Prolonged PTT + mucosal bleeding + normal platelets = vWD
  • DDAVP for Type 1; contraindicated in Type 2B (worsens thrombocytopenia)
  • Most common inherited bleeding disorder
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

262. HEMOPHILIA

Factor VIII (A) vs IX (B) â€¢ Hemarthrosis â€¢ Factor Replacement
CLASSIFICATION
TypeDeficiencyInheritanceFrequency
Hemophilia AFactor VIIIX-linked recessive80-85%
Hemophilia BFactor IXX-linked recessive15-20%

Severity:

  • Severe: <1% factor activity â€” spontaneous bleeding
  • Moderate: 1-5% â€” bleeding with minor trauma
  • Mild: 5-40% â€” bleeding with surgery/major trauma
CLINICAL FEATURES

Bleeding Pattern: Deep tissue/joint bleeding (unlike vWD)

  • Hemarthrosis (knees, elbows, ankles) â€” hallmark; leads to arthropathy
  • Muscle hematomas (including iliopsoas)
  • Intracranial hemorrhage
  • Prolonged bleeding after circumcision, dental work, surgery

Labs:

  • Prolonged PTT
  • Normal PT, platelets, bleeding time
  • Mixing study corrects (factor deficiency, not inhibitor)
TREATMENT

Factor Replacement:

  • On-demand: For acute bleeding
  • Prophylaxis: Regular infusions to prevent bleeding (severe patients)
  • Recombinant factors preferred over plasma-derived
  • Extended half-life products available

Hemophilia A with Inhibitors:

  • Emicizumab: Bispecific antibody mimicking factor VIII function; prophylaxis
  • Bypassing agents: rFVIIa, FEIBA

DDAVP: May work for mild Hemophilia A (releases vWF-bound FVIII)

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Hemarthrosis = hemophilia; mucosal = vWD
  • Prolonged PTT that corrects with mixing = factor deficiency
  • Emicizumab revolutionized care for severe Hemophilia A
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

263. MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS

Demyelinating â€¢ McDonald Criteria â€¢ Disease-Modifying Therapy
CLINICAL FEATURES

Demographics: Young adults (20-40), female predominance

Classic Presentations:

  • Optic neuritis: Unilateral vision loss, pain with eye movement, afferent pupillary defect
  • Transverse myelitis: Sensory level, weakness, bowel/bladder dysfunction
  • Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO): Impaired adduction, nystagmus in abducting eye
  • Lhermitte sign: Electric shock down spine with neck flexion
  • Cerebellar symptoms, trigeminal neuralgia

Patterns:

  • Relapsing-remitting (RRMS): 85% at onset; discrete attacks with recovery
  • Secondary progressive (SPMS): Gradual progression after RRMS
  • Primary progressive (PPMS): Progressive from onset (15%)
DIAGNOSIS â€” McDONALD CRITERIA (2017)

Requires: Dissemination in space (DIS) AND time (DIT)

  • DIS: â‰¥1 T2 lesion in â‰¥2 typical locations (periventricular, cortical/juxtacortical, infratentorial, spinal cord)
  • DIT: Simultaneous gadolinium-enhancing and non-enhancing lesions OR new T2/enhancing lesion on follow-up MRI OR CSF oligoclonal bands

CSF: Oligoclonal bands (>90%), elevated IgG index

MRI: T2/FLAIR hyperintense lesions, "Dawson's fingers" (periventricular)

TREATMENT

Acute Relapse: High-dose IV methylprednisolone (1g daily Ã— 3-5 days)

Disease-Modifying Therapy (DMT):

  • High-efficacy: Natalizumab, ocrelizumab, ofatumumab, alemtuzumab
  • Moderate-efficacy: Dimethyl fumarate, fingolimod, teriflunomide
  • Injectable: Interferons, glatiramer (less commonly used now)

PPMS: Ocrelizumab (only FDA-approved DMT)

Symptomatic: Fatigue (modafinil), spasticity (baclofen), bladder dysfunction

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • INO in young adult = MS until proven otherwise
  • Oligoclonal bands can satisfy DIT
  • Natalizumab risk: PML (check JC virus antibody)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

264. PARKINSON DISEASE

TRAP â€¢ Dopaminergic Therapy â€¢ Motor Fluctuations
CLINICAL FEATURES â€” TRAP
  • T â€” Tremor: Resting, "pill-rolling," 4-6 Hz; improves with action
  • R â€” Rigidity: Cogwheel (with tremor) or lead-pipe
  • A â€” Akinesia/Bradykinesia: Slowness of movement; masked facies, micrographia
  • P â€” Postural instability: Later feature; falls

Asymmetric onset is typical

Non-Motor: Anosmia (early), constipation, REM sleep behavior disorder, depression, cognitive impairment

TREATMENT

Dopaminergic Therapy:

  • Carbidopa-levodopa: Most effective; start when symptoms affect function
  • Dopamine agonists: Pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine â€” can use early; risk of impulse control disorders
  • MAO-B inhibitors: Selegiline, rasagiline â€” mild benefit; can be initial monotherapy
  • COMT inhibitors: Entacapone â€” extends levodopa effect

Motor Complications (after years of levodopa):

  • "Wearing off": End-of-dose deterioration â€” add COMT inhibitor, increase frequency
  • Dyskinesias: Peak-dose involuntary movements â€” reduce levodopa dose, add amantadine
  • "On-off" phenomenon: Unpredictable fluctuations

Advanced: Deep brain stimulation (subthalamic nucleus)

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Asymmetric resting tremor + bradykinesia = PD
  • Dopamine agonists: Impulse control disorders (gambling, hypersexuality)
  • Drug-induced parkinsonism: Antipsychotics, metoclopramide â€” symmetric, no tremor
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

265. ESSENTIAL TREMOR

Action Tremor â€¢ Alcohol-Responsive â€¢ Beta-Blockers
CLINICAL FEATURES

Characteristics:

  • Action/postural tremor (opposite of PD resting tremor)
  • Bilateral and symmetric (vs asymmetric in PD)
  • Affects hands, head ("no-no" or "yes-yes"), voice
  • Frequency 4-12 Hz
  • Improves with alcohol
  • Family history often positive (autosomal dominant)

No other neurologic findings (vs PD which has bradykinesia, rigidity)

TREATMENT

First-Line:

  • Propranolol: 20-80mg BID (or long-acting)
  • Primidone: Start low (25mg), titrate slowly (sedation)

Second-Line: Topiramate, gabapentin, benzodiazepines

Refractory: Deep brain stimulation (VIM thalamus), focused ultrasound thalamotomy

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Action tremor + improves with alcohol = essential tremor
  • Resting tremor + bradykinesia = Parkinson
  • Propranolol or primidone first-line
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

266. AMYOTROPHIC LATERAL SCLEROSIS (ALS)

UMN + LMN Signs â€¢ Bulbar Symptoms â€¢ Riluzole
CLINICAL FEATURES

Combined Upper AND Lower Motor Neuron Signs:

  • UMN: Spasticity, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign
  • LMN: Weakness, atrophy, fasciculations

Preserved: Sensation, cognition (mostly), eye movements, bowel/bladder (early)

Onset Patterns:

  • Limb-onset (70%): Asymmetric weakness, often hand
  • Bulbar-onset (25%): Dysarthria, dysphagia â€” worse prognosis

Progression: Relentless; respiratory failure is usual cause of death

DIAGNOSIS

Clinical Diagnosis: UMN + LMN signs in multiple regions, progressive course

El Escorial Criteria: Definite, probable, possible ALS based on regions involved

EMG: Widespread denervation (fibrillations, positive sharp waves, fasciculations) in multiple regions

Rule Out: Cervical myelopathy, multifocal motor neuropathy, Kennedy disease

TREATMENT
  • Riluzole: Glutamate antagonist; prolongs survival by ~3 months
  • Edaravone: Free radical scavenger; may slow functional decline
  • Multidisciplinary care: Pulmonology, nutrition, PT/OT, speech therapy
  • Non-invasive ventilation: Prolongs survival, improves quality of life
  • PEG tube: When dysphagia compromises nutrition

Prognosis: Median survival 3-5 years; bulbar-onset worse

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • UMN + LMN signs without sensory loss = ALS
  • Fasciculations + atrophy + hyperreflexia in same limb = classic
  • Riluzole is disease-modifying but effect is modest
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

267. NORMAL PRESSURE HYDROCEPHALUS

Wet â€¢ Wobbly â€¢ Wacky â€¢ LP Trial
CLINICAL FEATURES â€” TRIAD
  • Gait disturbance: Magnetic/apraxic gait ("feet stuck to floor"), wide-based, shuffling â€” earliest and most responsive to treatment
  • Urinary incontinence: Urge incontinence; later frank incontinence
  • Dementia: Subcortical pattern; psychomotor slowing, executive dysfunction

Mnemonic: "Wet, Wobbly, Wacky" (or "Wacky, Wobbly, Wet" â€” in order of appearance)

DIAGNOSIS

Imaging:

  • CT/MRI: Ventriculomegaly out of proportion to sulcal enlargement
  • Evans index >0.3 (ratio of frontal horns to maximum brain width)
  • Periventricular white matter changes

Lumbar Puncture: Normal opening pressure (hence "normal pressure")

LP Trial (High-Volume Tap):

  • Remove 30-50 mL CSF
  • Assess gait before and after (video)
  • Improvement predicts response to shunting

Extended Lumbar Drainage: 3-day trial if LP inconclusive

TREATMENT
  • VP (ventriculoperitoneal) shunt: Definitive treatment
  • Gait improves most; dementia may improve less
  • Risks: Infection, subdural hematoma, shunt malfunction
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Gait responds best to shunting; dementia may not improve
  • LP trial predicts surgical response
  • Ventriculomegaly + triad + improvement with LP = NPH
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

268. HEADACHE SYNDROMES

Migraine â€¢ Tension â€¢ Cluster â€¢ Trigeminal Neuralgia
COMPARISON
FeatureMigraineTensionCluster
LocationUnilateral (often)Bilateral, band-likeUnilateral, periorbital
QualityPulsating/throbbingPressing/tighteningExcruciating, stabbing
Duration4-72 hours30 min - 7 days15-180 minutes
AssociatedN/V, photophobia, phonophobia, auraNone typicallyLacrimation, rhinorrhea, ptosis, restlessness
BehaviorSeeks quiet dark roomContinues activityPacing, agitated
CLUSTER HEADACHE

Features: "Suicide headache" â€” severe; occurs in clusters (weeks-months) then remission; often nocturnal; male predominance

Autonomic Features: Ipsilateral lacrimation, conjunctival injection, nasal congestion, ptosis, miosis

Abortive: High-flow O2 (100%, 12-15 L/min) â€” first-line; sumatriptan SC/nasal

Preventive: Verapamil (first-line), lithium, galcanezumab

TRIGEMINAL NEURALGIA

Features: Brief (seconds) electric shock-like pain in V2/V3 distribution; triggered by touch, chewing, talking

Treatment:

  • Carbamazepine: First-line
  • Oxcarbazepine, lamotrigine, baclofen
  • Surgery: Microvascular decompression if refractory (often vascular loop compressing nerve)
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Cluster: High-flow O2 and sumatriptan abortive; verapamil preventive
  • Trigeminal neuralgia: Carbamazepine first-line
  • Young woman + visual aura + migraine + OCP = increased stroke risk
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

269. PERIPHERAL NEUROPATHY

Length-Dependent â€¢ Workup â€¢ Treatable Causes
CLASSIFICATION

By Pattern:

  • Length-dependent (distal symmetric): Stocking-glove; most common
  • Mononeuropathy: Single nerve (carpal tunnel, peroneal palsy)
  • Mononeuritis multiplex: Multiple individual nerves (vasculitis, diabetes)
  • Polyradiculopathy: Multiple nerve roots

By Fiber Type:

  • Large fiber: Vibration, proprioception, reflexes lost first
  • Small fiber: Pain, temperature; burning/stinging pain
COMMON CAUSES
  • Diabetes â€” most common in US
  • Alcohol
  • B12 deficiency â€” can cause combined sensory + UMN signs
  • Chemotherapy â€” platinum, taxanes, vinca alkaloids
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Hereditary â€” Charcot-Marie-Tooth
  • Inflammatory â€” GBS, CIDP
  • Paraproteinemia â€” MGUS, myeloma, amyloid
WORKUP

Initial Labs:

  • Fasting glucose / HbA1c
  • B12 (with MMA if borderline)
  • TSH
  • CBC, CMP
  • SPEP/UPEP with immunofixation

If Initial Negative: ANA, HIV, hepatitis B/C, Lyme, heavy metals, genetic testing

EMG/NCS: Confirms neuropathy; distinguishes axonal vs demyelinating; important for CIDP

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Diabetes + alcohol account for majority
  • B12 deficiency can cause neuropathy + myelopathy
  • Demyelinating pattern on EMG: Think GBS, CIDP, or hereditary
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

270. DEMENTIA SYNDROMES

Alzheimer's â€¢ Vascular â€¢ Lewy Body â€¢ FTD
COMPARISON
TypeKey FeaturesPathology
Alzheimer'sMemory loss earliest; gradual declineAmyloid plaques, tau tangles
VascularStepwise decline; focal signs; CV risk factorsInfarcts, white matter disease
Lewy BodyVisual hallucinations, parkinsonism, fluctuations, REM sleep disorderÎ±-synuclein inclusions
FrontotemporalEarly personality/behavior change OR language dysfunction; younger onsetTau or TDP-43
Parkinson dementiaPD for â‰¥1 year before dementiaÎ±-synuclein
WORKUP

Rule Out Reversible Causes:

  • B12 deficiency
  • Thyroid disease (TSH)
  • Depression ("pseudodementia")
  • NPH
  • Medication effect
  • Neurosyphilis, HIV (if risk factors)

Imaging: MRI (atrophy pattern, vascular changes, masses)

Biomarkers: CSF AÎ²42/tau, amyloid PET (for Alzheimer's confirmation)

TREATMENT

Alzheimer's:

  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: Donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine â€” modest benefit
  • Memantine: NMDA antagonist â€” moderate-severe AD
  • Lecanemab, donanemab: Anti-amyloid monoclonals â€” early AD

Lewy Body:

  • Cholinesterase inhibitors helpful
  • AVOID antipsychotics â€” severe sensitivity; use quetiapine if necessary

FTD: No proven disease-modifying therapy; SSRIs for behavioral symptoms

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Visual hallucinations + parkinsonism + fluctuations = Lewy Body
  • Antipsychotics contraindicated in Lewy Body
  • Behavioral variant FTD: Disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy â€” often misdiagnosed as psychiatric
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

271. VERTIGO

Central vs Peripheral â€¢ BPPV â€¢ HINTS Exam
CENTRAL VS PERIPHERAL
FeaturePeripheralCentral
OnsetSuddenGradual or sudden
NystagmusHorizontal/torsional; inhibited by fixationAny direction; not inhibited by fixation
Hearing lossMay be presentUsually absent
Neurologic signsAbsentPresent (diplopia, dysarthria, ataxia)
SeverityOften more severe vertigoMay be less severe
HINTS EXAM (for Acute Vestibular Syndrome)
  • Head Impulse: Abnormal (corrective saccade) = peripheral; Normal = central (BAD)
  • Nystagmus: Direction-changing = central
  • Test of Skew: Vertical skew deviation = central

Central Pattern (any one): Normal head impulse, direction-changing nystagmus, or skew â†’ MRI/stroke workup

COMMON PERIPHERAL CAUSES

BPPV:

  • Brief episodes (<1 min) triggered by position change
  • Dix-Hallpike positive (torsional upbeat nystagmus with latency)
  • Treatment: Epley maneuver (canalith repositioning)

Vestibular Neuritis:

  • Acute prolonged vertigo (days); often post-viral
  • No hearing loss (vs labyrinthitis)
  • Treatment: Supportive; vestibular rehabilitation; short-term meclizine

Meniere's Disease:

  • Episodic vertigo (20 min - hours) + hearing loss + tinnitus + aural fullness
  • Treatment: Low-sodium diet, diuretics
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • HINTS beats MRI for detecting stroke in acute vestibular syndrome
  • Normal head impulse test is concerning â€” suggests central cause
  • BPPV: Posterior canal most common; Epley maneuver curative
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

272. ANCA VASCULITIS

GPA â€¢ MPA â€¢ EGPA â€¢ Pulmonary-Renal Syndrome
CLASSIFICATION
DiseaseANCAKey Features
GPA (Wegener's)PR3-ANCA (c-ANCA)Upper airway (sinusitis, saddle nose), lung nodules/hemorrhage, glomerulonephritis
MPAMPO-ANCA (p-ANCA)Glomerulonephritis (pauci-immune), pulmonary hemorrhage; NO upper airway
EGPA (Churg-Strauss)MPO-ANCA (50%)Asthma, eosinophilia, neuropathy, cardiac involvement
GPA (GRANULOMATOSIS WITH POLYANGIITIS)

Classic Triad:

  • Upper airway: Chronic sinusitis, nasal crusting, saddle nose deformity, subglottic stenosis
  • Lungs: Nodules (may cavitate), infiltrates, hemorrhage
  • Kidneys: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (pauci-immune crescentic)
DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Labs: PR3-ANCA or MPO-ANCA; elevated ESR/CRP; urinalysis (RBC casts)

Induction (Severe):

  • Rituximab OR cyclophosphamide + glucocorticoids
  • Plasmapheresis: For severe renal disease or pulmonary hemorrhage

Maintenance: Rituximab or azathioprine

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Pulmonary-renal syndrome: Think ANCA vasculitis or anti-GBM
  • PR3-ANCA = GPA; MPO-ANCA = MPA or EGPA
  • Saddle nose deformity is classic for GPA
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

273. POLYARTERITIS NODOSA

Medium-Vessel Vasculitis â€¢ HBV Association â€¢ Microaneurysms
CLINICAL FEATURES

Key Features:

  • Constitutional: Fever, weight loss, malaise
  • Neurologic: Mononeuritis multiplex (foot drop, wrist drop)
  • Renal: Hypertension, renal infarcts (NOT glomerulonephritis)
  • GI: Mesenteric ischemia, bowel perforation
  • Skin: Livedo reticularis, subcutaneous nodules

SPARES lungs (unlike ANCA vasculitis)

DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Association: Hepatitis B (10-30%)

ANCA: Negative

Angiography: Microaneurysms and stenoses

Treatment: Glucocorticoids Â± cyclophosphamide; treat HBV if present

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Medium vessel + mononeuritis multiplex + spares lungs = PAN
  • Always check Hepatitis B
  • Microaneurysms on angiography
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

274. REACTIVE ARTHRITIS

Post-Infectious â€¢ HLA-B27 â€¢ Can't See, Can't Pee, Can't Climb a Tree
CLINICAL FEATURES

Classic Triad: Arthritis + urethritis + conjunctivitis

Triggering Infections: Chlamydia (GU); Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, Yersinia (GI)

Arthritis: Asymmetric oligoarthritis, lower extremity; 1-4 weeks post-infection

Other: Enthesitis, dactylitis, keratoderma blennorrhagicum, circinate balanitis

TREATMENT
  • NSAIDs: First-line
  • Treat active Chlamydia if present
  • DMARDs: Sulfasalazine, MTX for chronic
  • TNF inhibitors: If DMARD failure
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis + recent GU/GI infection = reactive arthritis
  • HLA-B27 associated
  • Keratoderma blennorrhagicum looks like pustular psoriasis
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

275. RAYNAUD PHENOMENON

Primary vs Secondary â€¢ Tricolor Change â€¢ CCB Treatment
PRIMARY VS SECONDARY

Tricolor Change: White â†’ Blue â†’ Red

FeaturePrimarySecondary
Age onset15-30>30
Tissue damageNoneUlcers, gangrene
ANANegativeOften positive
Nailfold capillariesNormalAbnormal

Secondary Causes: Scleroderma (most common), SLE, MCTD

TREATMENT
  • All: Avoid cold, smoking cessation
  • First-line: Dihydropyridine CCBs (nifedipine, amlodipine)
  • Severe: Phosphodiesterase inhibitors, prostacyclin
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Digital ulcers = secondary; think scleroderma
  • Abnormal nailfold capillaries predict CTD
  • CCBs are first-line
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

276. CRYOGLOBULINEMIA

HCV Association â€¢ Palpable Purpura â€¢ MPGN
CLINICAL FEATURES

Meltzer's Triad: Palpable purpura + arthralgias + weakness

HCV causes 90% of mixed cryoglobulinemia

Other: MPGN, peripheral neuropathy, Raynaud

DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Labs: Cryoglobulins (transport at 37Â°C), low C4, positive RF, HCV RNA

Treatment: Treat HCV (DAAs); rituximab for severe disease

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • HCV causes 90% of mixed cryoglobulinemia
  • Low C4 + positive RF + purpura = cryoglobulinemia
  • Treat HCV first
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

277. INVASIVE CANDIDIASIS

Candidemia â€¢ Echinocandins â€¢ Line Removal
RISK FACTORS & PRESENTATION

Risk Factors: Central lines, TPN, broad-spectrum antibiotics, immunosuppression, GI surgery, ICU stay

Presentation: Fever unresponsive to antibiotics, sepsis

Metastatic Complications: Endophthalmitis (fundoscopic exam required), endocarditis, osteomyelitis, hepatosplenic candidiasis

DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Diagnosis: Blood cultures (often low sensitivity); Î²-D-glucan (sensitive but not specific)

Treatment:

  • Echinocandin first-line: Caspofungin, micafungin, anidulafungin
  • Fluconazole: Step-down if susceptible and clinically stable
  • Remove all central lines
  • Dilated fundoscopic exam within first week
  • Duration: 14 days from first negative blood culture

Repeat blood cultures daily until negative

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Echinocandin first-line; remove all lines
  • Fundoscopic exam required to rule out endophthalmitis
  • 14 days from first negative culture
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

278. PNEUMOCYSTIS PNEUMONIA (PCP)

HIV/AIDS â€¢ TMP-SMX â€¢ Adjunctive Steroids
RISK FACTORS & PRESENTATION

At Risk: HIV with CD4 <200; solid organ transplant; high-dose steroids; hematologic malignancy

Presentation:

  • Subacute progressive dyspnea (weeks)
  • Dry cough, fever
  • Hypoxemia, especially with exertion
  • HIV patients: Indolent; Non-HIV: More acute/severe
DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Imaging: Bilateral diffuse ground-glass infiltrates; pneumatoceles; can be normal early

Labs: Elevated LDH (nonspecific), Î²-D-glucan

Diagnosis: Induced sputum or BAL for PCR or DFA staining

Treatment:

  • TMP-SMX: 15-20 mg/kg/day TMP divided q6-8h Ã— 21 days
  • Alternatives: Pentamidine IV, atovaquone, dapsone + TMP, clindamycin + primaquine
  • Adjunctive steroids if PaO2 <70 or A-a gradient â‰¥35: Prednisone 40mg BID Ã— 5d, then taper
PROPHYLAXIS
  • HIV: CD4 <200 or CD4 <14% or history of OI
  • TMP-SMX DS daily (or 3Ã—/week); alternatives: dapsone, atovaquone, pentamidine inhaled
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • TMP-SMX + steroids if hypoxic
  • Elevated LDH + bilateral GGO in immunocompromised = PCP
  • 21 days treatment
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

279. INVASIVE ASPERGILLOSIS

Neutropenia â€¢ Halo Sign â€¢ Voriconazole
RISK FACTORS & PRESENTATION

At Risk: Prolonged neutropenia, HSCT, solid organ transplant, high-dose steroids, CGD

Pulmonary: Fever unresponsive to antibiotics, cough, hemoptysis, pleuritic chest pain

Other Sites: Sinuses, CNS, disseminated

DIAGNOSIS

CT Findings:

  • Halo sign: Ground-glass surrounding nodule (early)
  • Air-crescent sign: Cavitation (later, with neutrophil recovery)

Biomarkers: Galactomannan (serum, BAL), Î²-D-glucan

Definitive: Culture/histopath from tissue (septate hyphae, acute angle branching)

TREATMENT
  • Voriconazole: First-line
  • Alternatives: Isavuconazole, liposomal amphotericin B
  • Duration: Minimum 6-12 weeks; until resolution + immune recovery
  • Reduce immunosuppression if possible
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Halo sign on CT in neutropenic patient = aspergillosis
  • Voriconazole first-line; check drug levels
  • Galactomannan useful for diagnosis and monitoring
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

280. CRYPTOCOCCAL MENINGITIS

HIV/AIDS â€¢ India Ink â€¢ Amphotericin + Flucytosine
CLINICAL FEATURES

At Risk: HIV with CD4 <100, solid organ transplant, prolonged steroids

Presentation: Subacute meningitis â€” headache, fever, altered mental status; may lack meningismus

Elevated Intracranial Pressure: Common; requires serial LPs or drain

DIAGNOSIS
  • CSF cryptococcal antigen: Highly sensitive/specific
  • Serum cryptococcal antigen: Often positive
  • India ink: Encapsulated yeast (less sensitive)
  • CSF: Elevated opening pressure, lymphocytic pleocytosis, low glucose, elevated protein
TREATMENT

HIV-associated (Induction):

  • Liposomal amphotericin B + flucytosine Ã— 2 weeks
  • Followed by fluconazole consolidation (8 weeks) then maintenance

ICP Management: Serial therapeutic LPs (remove 20-30 mL) or lumbar drain; goal OP <20 cm H2O

ART: Delay 4-6 weeks to avoid IRIS

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Cryptococcal antigen is key diagnostic test
  • Elevated ICP management critical â€” serial LPs
  • Delay ART 4-6 weeks to reduce IRIS risk
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

281. ENDEMIC MYCOSES

Histoplasmosis â€¢ Blastomycosis â€¢ Coccidioidomycosis
GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION
FungusRegionExposure
HistoplasmaOhio/Mississippi River valleysBird/bat droppings, caves
BlastomycesGreat Lakes, Ohio/Mississippi valleysDecaying wood, soil
CoccidioidesSouthwest US (Arizona, California)Desert soil (dust storms)
CLINICAL FEATURES

Histoplasmosis:

  • Usually self-limited; can cause chronic pulmonary (mimics TB), disseminated in immunocompromised
  • Mediastinal lymphadenopathy, fibrosing mediastinitis (rare)

Blastomycosis:

  • Pulmonary, skin (verrucous lesions), bone, prostate
  • Less likely to resolve spontaneously â€” usually treat

Coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever):

  • 60% asymptomatic; can cause pneumonia, erythema nodosum, disseminated (meningitis, bone)
  • Risk of dissemination: Filipinos, African Americans, immunocompromised, pregnancy
DIAGNOSIS & TREATMENT

Diagnosis: Urine/serum antigen (Histo, Blasto), serology, culture, histopathology

Treatment:

  • Mild-moderate: Itraconazole
  • Severe/disseminated: Amphotericin B â†’ itraconazole
  • Cocci meningitis: Lifelong fluconazole
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Know the geography: Histo=Midwest caves; Cocci=Southwest desert; Blasto=Great Lakes
  • Cocci meningitis requires lifelong fluconazole
  • Always treat blastomycosis
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

282. STEVENS-JOHNSON SYNDROME / TEN

Drug Reaction â€¢ Mucosal Involvement â€¢ Burn Unit Care
DEFINITION & CAUSES

Spectrum:

  • SJS: <10% BSA detachment
  • SJS-TEN overlap: 10-30% BSA
  • TEN: >30% BSA detachment

Common Drug Causes:

  • Sulfonamides (TMP-SMX)
  • Anticonvulsants: Carbamazepine, phenytoin, lamotrigine, phenobarbital
  • Allopurinol
  • NSAIDs (especially piroxicam)
  • Antibiotics: Fluoroquinolones, penicillins
CLINICAL FEATURES

Prodrome: Fever, malaise, URI symptoms 1-3 weeks after drug exposure

Skin: Painful erythema â†’ targetoid lesions â†’ bullae â†’ epidermal detachment; positive Nikolsky sign

Mucosal Involvement (â‰¥2 sites): Oral, ocular (conjunctivitis, corneal ulceration), genital

MANAGEMENT
  • Immediate drug withdrawal
  • Transfer to burn unit/ICU for TEN
  • Supportive care: Fluids, wound care, temperature regulation, nutrition
  • Ophthalmology consultation (prevent scarring/blindness)
  • Avoid systemic steroids (controversial; some use early)
  • SCORTEN for prognosis
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Mucosal involvement distinguishes from other drug reactions
  • Stop the drug immediately
  • HLA-B*5801 + allopurinol = high SJS/TEN risk (screen in high-risk populations)
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

283. DRESS SYNDROME

Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms
CLINICAL FEATURES

Timing: 2-8 weeks after drug initiation (longer latency than SJS/TEN)

Features:

  • Rash: Morbilliform, may become edematous; facial edema common
  • Fever
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Eosinophilia and/or atypical lymphocytosis
  • Internal organ involvement: Liver (most common), kidney, heart (myocarditis), lung, thyroid
COMMON CAUSES
  • Anticonvulsants: Carbamazepine, phenytoin, lamotrigine, phenobarbital
  • Allopurinol
  • Sulfonamides
  • Vancomycin, minocycline, dapsone

HLA Associations: HLA-B*5801 (allopurinol), HLA-A*3101 (carbamazepine)

TREATMENT
  • Stop offending drug
  • Systemic corticosteroids: Prednisone 1 mg/kg with slow taper (weeks to months)
  • Monitor for organ involvement
  • Late complications: Thyroiditis, autoimmune disease
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • 2-8 week latency (longer than SJS/TEN)
  • Eosinophilia + liver involvement + facial edema = DRESS
  • Slow steroid taper â€” rebound common
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

284. PRIMARY IMMUNODEFICIENCIES

CVID â€¢ IgA Deficiency â€¢ When to Suspect
WARNING SIGNS IN ADULTS
  • â‰¥2 serious bacterial infections in one year
  • â‰¥3 bacterial sinusitis or pneumonia in one year
  • Infections requiring prolonged antibiotics
  • Recurrent skin abscesses
  • Opportunistic infections
  • Unexplained bronchiectasis
COMMON VARIABLE IMMUNODEFICIENCY (CVID)

Most common symptomatic primary immunodeficiency in adults

Features:

  • Recurrent sinopulmonary infections
  • Low IgG + low IgA and/or IgM
  • Poor vaccine responses
  • Autoimmune disease (ITP, AIHA)
  • Increased lymphoma risk
  • GI disease (chronic diarrhea, malabsorption)

Treatment: IVIG or SCIG replacement

IgA DEFICIENCY

Most common immunodeficiency overall (1:500)

Most asymptomatic; some have recurrent sinopulmonary/GI infections

Associations: Celiac disease, autoimmune disease

Caution: Risk of anaphylaxis to blood products containing IgA

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • CVID: Low IgG + recurrent infections + poor vaccine response
  • IgA deficiency: Most common; usually asymptomatic
  • IVIG is treatment for CVID
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

285. EATING DISORDERS

Anorexia Nervosa â€¢ Bulimia â€¢ Refeeding Syndrome
ANOREXIA NERVOSA

DSM-5 Criteria:

  • Restriction of intake leading to significantly low body weight
  • Intense fear of gaining weight
  • Distorted body image

Medical Complications:

  • Cardiac: Bradycardia, hypotension, QTc prolongation, arrhythmias
  • Metabolic: Hypothermia, hypoglycemia
  • Endocrine: Amenorrhea, low T3, elevated cortisol
  • Bone: Osteoporosis
  • GI: Constipation, gastroparesis
  • Heme: Pancytopenia
BULIMIA NERVOSA

Features: Binge eating + compensatory behaviors (purging, laxatives, exercise); normal or elevated weight

Medical Complications:

  • Electrolytes: Hypokalemia, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis
  • Dental: Enamel erosion
  • Parotid hypertrophy
  • Russell's sign: Calluses on knuckles
  • Esophageal: Mallory-Weiss tears, rarely Boerhaave
REFEEDING SYNDROME

Risk: Severely malnourished patients (BMI <16, minimal intake >10 days)

Pathophysiology: Insulin surge with refeeding â†’ intracellular shift of phosphorus, potassium, magnesium

Complications: Hypophosphatemia (most important), hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia â†’ arrhythmias, respiratory failure, cardiac failure

Prevention:

  • Start low, go slow with calories
  • Replace thiamine before feeding
  • Monitor and replace electrolytes
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Hypokalemia + metabolic alkalosis = purging
  • Refeeding syndrome: Hypophosphatemia is key; give thiamine first
  • Anorexia has highest mortality of psychiatric disorders
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

286. SLEEP DISORDERS

Insomnia â€¢ OSA â€¢ Narcolepsy â€¢ Restless Legs
INSOMNIA

Chronic Insomnia: â‰¥3 nights/week for â‰¥3 months

Treatment:

  • CBT-I (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia): First-line
  • Pharmacotherapy: Z-drugs (zolpidem), low-dose trazodone, doxepin; melatonin for circadian disorders
  • Avoid benzodiazepines long-term (dependence, falls in elderly)
OBSTRUCTIVE SLEEP APNEA

Symptoms: Snoring, witnessed apneas, daytime somnolence, morning headaches

Diagnosis: Polysomnography or home sleep test; AHI â‰¥5 with symptoms

Treatment:

  • CPAP: First-line for moderate-severe
  • Weight loss, positional therapy
  • Oral appliances for mild-moderate
NARCOLEPSY

Type 1: Excessive daytime sleepiness + cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone with emotion)

Type 2: EDS without cataplexy

Other Features: Sleep paralysis, hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations

Diagnosis: PSG + MSLT (mean sleep latency <8 min, â‰¥2 SOREMPs); low CSF orexin in Type 1

Treatment: Modafinil/armodafinil for EDS; sodium oxybate for cataplexy

RESTLESS LEGS SYNDROME

Features: Urge to move legs, worse at rest/evening, relieved by movement

Associations: Iron deficiency (check ferritin), pregnancy, CKD

Treatment:

  • Iron supplementation if ferritin <75
  • First-line: Alpha-2-delta ligands (gabapentin, pregabalin)
  • Dopamine agonists (pramipexole) â€” risk of augmentation with long-term use
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • CBT-I is first-line for chronic insomnia
  • Cataplexy = narcolepsy Type 1
  • Check ferritin in RLS â€” treat if <75
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

287. GLOMERULAR DISEASES

IgA Nephropathy â€¢ FSGS â€¢ Minimal Change â€¢ Membranous
NEPHRITIC VS NEPHROTIC
FeatureNephriticNephrotic
Proteinuria<3.5 g/dayâ‰¥3.5 g/day
HematuriaPresent (RBC casts)Minimal
EdemaMildSevere (anasarca)
OtherHTN, oliguria, AKIHyperlipidemia, lipiduria
KEY GLOMERULAR DISEASES

IgA Nephropathy:

  • Most common GN worldwide
  • Episodic gross hematuria with URI ("synpharyngitic")
  • Biopsy: Mesangial IgA deposits
  • Treatment: ACEi/ARB; steroids if progressive

Minimal Change Disease:

  • Most common nephrotic syndrome in children
  • Biopsy: Normal LM, podocyte effacement on EM
  • Treatment: Highly steroid-responsive

FSGS:

  • Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults (especially African Americans)
  • Primary vs secondary (HIV, heroin, obesity, reflux)
  • Treatment: Steroids (less responsive); SGLT2i

Membranous Nephropathy:

  • Most common nephrotic in white adults
  • Primary: Anti-PLA2R antibodies (70%)
  • Secondary: Malignancy, hepatitis B, lupus, drugs (NSAIDs, gold)
  • High thrombosis risk (renal vein thrombosis)
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • IgA nephropathy: Hematuria with URI (synpharyngitic)
  • Minimal change: Kids, steroid-responsive
  • Anti-PLA2R positive = primary membranous
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

288. ANTI-GBM DISEASE / GOODPASTURE

Pulmonary-Renal Syndrome â€¢ Linear IF â€¢ Plasmapheresis
CLINICAL FEATURES

Anti-GBM Disease: Antibodies against type IV collagen in glomerular/alveolar basement membrane

Goodpasture Syndrome: Anti-GBM disease with both lung and kidney involvement

Pulmonary: Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage â€” hemoptysis, dyspnea, infiltrates

Renal: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis â€” hematuria, AKI

Associations: Smoking (exposes pulmonary basement membrane), hydrocarbons

DIAGNOSIS
  • Anti-GBM antibodies (serum)
  • Kidney biopsy: Linear IgG staining on immunofluorescence (pathognomonic)
  • Crescentic GN on light microscopy

Note: ~30% are also ANCA-positive (double-positive)

TREATMENT
  • Plasmapheresis: To remove anti-GBM antibodies (daily Ã— 14 days or until antibodies clear)
  • Cyclophosphamide + high-dose corticosteroids
  • Prognosis depends on creatinine at presentation
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Linear IF staining = anti-GBM (granular = immune complex)
  • Plasmapheresis essential
  • Pulmonary-renal syndrome DDx: Anti-GBM, ANCA vasculitis, SLE
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

289. CONTRAST-INDUCED NEPHROPATHY

AKI Prevention â€¢ IV Fluids â€¢ Risk Factors
DEFINITION & RISK FACTORS

Definition: AKI within 48-72 hours of contrast exposure; Cr rise â‰¥0.3 or â‰¥50%

High-Risk Patients:

  • Pre-existing CKD (eGFR <45)
  • Diabetes with CKD
  • Heart failure
  • Volume depletion
  • High contrast volume
  • Intra-arterial contrast
  • Concurrent nephrotoxins
PREVENTION

Pre-Procedure:

  • IV isotonic fluids: Normal saline or isotonic bicarbonate (1-1.5 mL/kg/hr starting 3-12h before and continuing 6-24h after)
  • Hold nephrotoxins: NSAIDs
  • Minimize contrast volume
  • Use iso-osmolar or low-osmolar contrast

Metformin: Hold at time of contrast if eGFR <30; restart 48h after if renal function stable

Not Proven Effective: N-acetylcysteine, sodium bicarbonate (beyond isotonic fluids)

MANAGEMENT

If CI-AKI Occurs:

  • Supportive care
  • Usually self-limited (peaks 3-5 days, resolves 7-10 days)
  • Avoid additional nephrotoxic insults
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • IV fluids are the only proven prevention
  • NAC does not prevent CI-AKI (PRESERVE trial)
  • Don't delay emergent procedures for CI-AKI concerns
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

290. PERIOPERATIVE EVALUATION

RCRI â€¢ Cardiac Risk â€¢ Medication Management
CARDIAC RISK ASSESSMENT

Revised Cardiac Risk Index (RCRI) â€” 1 point each:

  • High-risk surgery (intraperitoneal, intrathoracic, suprainguinal vascular)
  • History of ischemic heart disease
  • History of heart failure
  • History of cerebrovascular disease
  • Diabetes requiring insulin
  • Creatinine >2.0

Risk: 0 points = 0.4%; 1 = 0.9%; 2 = 6.6%; â‰¥3 = 11%

STEPWISE APPROACH (ACC/AHA)
  1. Emergency surgery? â†’ Proceed
  2. Active cardiac condition? (ACS, decompensated HF, severe AS, significant arrhythmia) â†’ Evaluate/treat first
  3. Low-risk surgery? â†’ Proceed without testing
  4. Functional capacity â‰¥4 METs? â†’ Proceed
  5. <4 METs or unknown + elevated risk? â†’ Consider stress testing if it will change management

Preoperative Testing: ECG if known CAD or risk factors; Echo if dyspnea of unknown etiology or worsening symptoms

MEDICATION MANAGEMENT
DrugPerioperative Management
Beta-blockersContinue if on chronically; do NOT start new high-dose
StatinsContinue
ACEi/ARBsHold morning of surgery (hypotension risk); restart postop
AspirinContinue if recent stent; otherwise hold 7 days for major surgery
ClopidogrelHold 5 days if safe; continue if recent stent
WarfarinHold 5 days; bridge if high-risk (mechanical valve, recent VTE)
DOACsHold 1-2 days (2-3 if renal impairment)
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Don't start beta-blockers day of surgery
  • Continue statins perioperatively
  • 4 METs = climb flight of stairs
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

291. VTE PROPHYLAXIS

Padua Score â€¢ Caprini Score â€¢ Medical vs Surgical
MEDICAL PATIENTS â€” PADUA SCORE

High Risk (â‰¥4 points): Pharmacologic prophylaxis indicated

FactorPoints
Active cancer3
Previous VTE3
Reduced mobility3
Thrombophilia3
Recent trauma/surgery2
Age â‰¥701
Heart failure or respiratory failure1
Acute MI or stroke1
Acute infection or rheumatic disorder1
Obesity (BMI â‰¥30)1
Hormonal therapy1
PROPHYLAXIS OPTIONS

Pharmacologic:

  • Enoxaparin 40mg SC daily (most common)
  • Heparin 5000 units SC q8h
  • Fondaparinux 2.5mg SC daily (if HIT history)

Mechanical: SCDs, IPC; use if bleeding risk high; combine with pharmacologic if very high VTE risk

Contraindications to Pharmacologic: Active bleeding, severe thrombocytopenia, recent CNS bleed/surgery

SPECIAL POPULATIONS
  • Hip/knee replacement: Extended prophylaxis 35 days (LMWH, rivaroxaban, aspirin)
  • Cancer surgery: Extended prophylaxis 4 weeks
  • ICU: All patients should receive prophylaxis unless contraindicated
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Padua â‰¥4 = pharmacologic prophylaxis
  • Extended prophylaxis for orthopedic and cancer surgery
  • Mechanical + pharmacologic for highest risk
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

292. OBESITY MANAGEMENT

GLP-1 Agonists â€¢ Bariatric Surgery Criteria â€¢ Pharmacotherapy
CLASSIFICATION & INDICATIONS

BMI Classification:

  • Overweight: 25-29.9
  • Class I obesity: 30-34.9
  • Class II obesity: 35-39.9
  • Class III obesity: â‰¥40

Pharmacotherapy Indicated: BMI â‰¥30 OR BMI â‰¥27 with comorbidity

Bariatric Surgery Indicated: BMI â‰¥40 OR BMI â‰¥35 with comorbidity; consider for BMI 30-35 with poorly controlled T2DM

PHARMACOTHERAPY
DrugMechanismNotes
Semaglutide (Wegovy)GLP-1 agonistMost effective (~15% weight loss); weekly injection
Tirzepatide (Zepbound)GLP-1/GIP dual agonist~20% weight loss; weekly injection
Phentermine-topiramateAppetite suppressant + anticonvulsantEffective; contraindicated in pregnancy (teratogenic)
Naltrexone-bupropionOpioid antagonist + NDRIAvoid in seizures, eating disorders
OrlistatLipase inhibitorGI side effects; modest efficacy
BARIATRIC SURGERY

Types:

  • Sleeve gastrectomy: Most common now; restrictive
  • Roux-en-Y gastric bypass: Restrictive + malabsorptive; greater T2DM remission

Long-term Requirements: Lifelong vitamin supplementation (B12, iron, calcium, vitamin D), protein intake, follow-up

ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • GLP-1 agonists most effective for weight loss
  • Bariatric surgery leads to T2DM remission in many patients
  • Lifelong vitamin supplementation after bypass
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

293. SMOKING CESSATION

5 A's â€¢ Varenicline â€¢ NRT
5 A's FRAMEWORK
  • Ask about tobacco use
  • Advise to quit (clear, strong, personalized)
  • Assess willingness to quit
  • Assist with quit attempt (pharmacotherapy, counseling)
  • Arrange follow-up
PHARMACOTHERAPY
DrugMechanismNotes
VareniclinePartial nicotinic agonistMost effective; start 1 week before quit date; 12 weeks
Bupropion SRNDRIStart 1-2 weeks before quit; avoid in seizure disorder
NRT (patch, gum, lozenge)Nicotine replacementCan combine patch + short-acting (gum/lozenge)

Combination therapy: Varenicline + NRT, or NRT patch + short-acting NRT = more effective than monotherapy

SPECIAL CONSIDERATIONS
  • Hospitalized patients: Use NRT for withdrawal; counsel before discharge
  • Pregnancy: Behavioral counseling first-line; NRT if needed (safer than smoking)
  • Psychiatric illness: Varenicline and bupropion safe; monitor mood
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Varenicline is most effective
  • Combination NRT more effective than single agent
  • Bupropion contraindicated in seizure disorder
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

294. ALCOHOL & OPIOID USE DISORDERS

MOUD â€¢ Naltrexone â€¢ Buprenorphine
ALCOHOL USE DISORDER

Pharmacotherapy for AUD:

  • Naltrexone: Opioid antagonist; reduces craving and heavy drinking; PO daily or IM monthly (Vivitrol); contraindicated if on opioids
  • Acamprosate: GABA/glutamate modulator; reduces craving; renally cleared (avoid in CKD); safe in liver disease
  • Disulfiram: Causes aversive reaction with alcohol (flushing, nausea); requires high motivation/supervision

Gabapentin: May help with craving and anxiety; useful if comorbid sleep or anxiety issues

OPIOID USE DISORDER â€” MOUD

Medications for Opioid Use Disorder (MOUD):

MedicationMechanismKey Points
BuprenorphinePartial Î¼ agonistOffice-based; wait for withdrawal before starting (COWS â‰¥8-12); ceiling effect (safer)
MethadoneFull Î¼ agonistOTP (clinic) only for OUD; daily observed dosing initially; QTc prolongation risk
Naltrexone (XR)Î¼ antagonistMust be opioid-free 7-10 days; monthly IM; prevents relapse but doesn't treat withdrawal

Buprenorphine Induction: Patient must be in withdrawal (COWS score); start low, titrate to effect; can start in ED/hospital

HARM REDUCTION
  • Naloxone prescribing: All patients at risk for overdose
  • Syringe exchange programs
  • Fentanyl test strips
ðŸ’Ž BOARD PEARLS
  • Buprenorphine: Wait for withdrawal (COWS â‰¥8) to avoid precipitated withdrawal
  • Naltrexone for AUD or OUD: Cannot be on opioids
  • MOUD is gold standard for OUD â€” reduces mortality
â†‘ Back to Table of Contents

295. VARICEAL BLEEDING

Life-Threatening GI Hemorrhage in Portal Hypertension
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Hematemesis (bright red blood or coffee grounds), melena, signs of hypovolemic shock

Associated Findings: Stigmata of chronic liver disease (spider angiomata, ascites, splenomegaly, caput medusae)

Risk Stratification:
