  • High-risk features: Active bleeding at endoscopy, large varices, red wale marks, Child-Pugh C
  • Mortality: 15-20% per episode; 6-week mortality correlates with Child-Pugh class
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Labs: CBC, CMP, LFTs, coagulation studies (PT/INR, fibrinogen), type & screen (crossmatch 6 units), lactate

Risk Scores:

  • Child-Pugh: Predicts mortality (Class A: 5-6 pts, B: 7-9 pts, C: 10-15 pts)
  • MELD: Predicts 90-day mortality; prioritizes transplant listing

Endoscopy: EGD within 12 hours of presentation (after resuscitation and hemodynamic stability)

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

1. Resuscitation:

  • 2 large-bore IVs, crystalloid resuscitation
  • Restrictive transfusion: Target Hgb 7-8 g/dL (liberal transfusion increases portal pressure and rebleeding)
  • Correct coagulopathy: FFP if INR >2.5, platelets if <50K, consider fibrinogen replacement

2. Pharmacologic Therapy (Start Immediately):

  • Octreotide: 50 mcg IV bolus, then 50 mcg/hr infusion Ã— 3-5 days (reduces splanchnic blood flow)
  • PPI: Pantoprazole 80 mg IV bolus, then 8 mg/hr infusion (for concurrent ulcer disease)
  • Antibiotics: Ceftriaxone 1g IV daily Ã— 7 days (reduces mortality, prevents SBP)

3. Endoscopic Therapy:

  • Esophageal varices: Endoscopic variceal ligation (EVL/banding) â€” first-line
  • Gastric varices: Cyanoacrylate glue injection or balloon-occluded retrograde transvenous obliteration (BRTO)
  • Repeat EGD every 2-4 weeks until varices eradicated

4. Rescue Therapies (If Endoscopy Fails):

  • Balloon tamponade: Sengstaken-Blakemore or Minnesota tube (bridge to definitive therapy, max 24h)
  • TIPS: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt â€” for refractory bleeding
  • Early TIPS: Consider within 72h for high-risk patients (Child-Pugh C or B with active bleeding)

5. Secondary Prophylaxis:

  • Non-selective beta-blocker: Propranolol or nadolol (target HR 55-60 or 25% reduction)
  • EVL: Repeat banding every 2-4 weeks until varices obliterated
  • Combination therapy (beta-blocker + EVL) most effective
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Restrictive transfusion: Overtransfusion increases portal pressure â†’ more bleeding. Target Hgb 7-8
  • Antibiotics save lives: Prophylactic ceftriaxone reduces mortality by 20% â€” don't skip it!
  • Octreotide timing: Start BEFORE endoscopy. Works within minutes to reduce portal pressure
  • Balloon tamponade: Last resort bridge therapy only. High complication rate (aspiration, esophageal necrosis)
  • Early TIPS: New paradigm â€” consider within 72h for high-risk patients, improves survival

296. OGILVIE SYNDROME (Acute Colonic Pseudo-Obstruction)

Massive Colonic Dilation Without Mechanical Obstruction
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Massive abdominal distension, absent or hypoactive bowel sounds, nausea/vomiting

Key Features: Often in hospitalized, post-operative, or critically ill patients

Risk Factors:

  • Recent surgery (especially orthopedic, cardiac, obstetric)
  • Trauma, sepsis, respiratory failure
  • Medications (opioids, anticholinergics, CCBs)
  • Electrolyte disturbances (hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia)
  • Neurologic conditions (Parkinson's, MS, spinal cord injury)

Warning Signs: Cecal diameter >12 cm = high perforation risk; fever, peritoneal signs = possible ischemia/perforation

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Imaging:

  • Abdominal X-ray: Massively dilated colon (cecum often >10 cm), air-fluid levels, no transition point
  • CT abdomen/pelvis: Confirms no mechanical obstruction, assesses for perforation/ischemia

Labs: CBC, CMP (especially K, Mg, Ca), lactate, TSH

Critical Measurement: Cecal diameter â€” risk of perforation increases significantly when >12 cm or >6 days duration

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

1. Supportive Care (Initial 24-48h):

  • NPO, NG tube decompression
  • Correct electrolytes aggressively
  • Discontinue offending medications (opioids, anticholinergics)
  • Mobilization, knee-to-chest positioning
  • Rectal tube for decompression

2. Neostigmine (If No Improvement in 24-48h or Cecum >12 cm):

  • Dose: 2 mg IV over 3-5 minutes
  • Monitoring: Continuous cardiac monitoring during administration (bradycardia risk)
  • Contraindications: Bradycardia, recent MI, mechanical obstruction, GI perforation
  • Success rate: 80-90% response
  • Have atropine at bedside for symptomatic bradycardia
  • May repeat Ã— 1 if inadequate response after 3-4 hours

3. Colonoscopic Decompression:

  • If neostigmine fails or contraindicated
  • Success rate ~70%; recurrence common
  • Place decompression tube if possible

4. Surgery:

  • Indications: Perforation, peritonitis, ischemia, failed conservative/endoscopic management
  • Options: Cecostomy tube, subtotal colectomy
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Cecal diameter cutoff: >12 cm = high perforation risk. Measure on imaging and trend!
  • Neostigmine works: 80-90% effective but requires cardiac monitoring. Keep atropine ready
  • Duration matters: >6 days of dilation also increases perforation risk independent of diameter
  • Rule out mechanical obstruction: CT scan essential before treating as pseudo-obstruction
  • Fix the basics first: Electrolyte correction and stopping offending meds often sufficient

297. ACALCULOUS CHOLECYSTITIS

Gallbladder Inflammation Without Stones â€¢ ICU-Associated
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: RUQ pain, fever, leukocytosis in critically ill patient WITHOUT gallstones

Challenge: Often subtle in sedated/intubated ICU patients â€” may present only as unexplained sepsis

Risk Factors:

  • Critical illness (sepsis, trauma, burns, major surgery)
  • Prolonged NPO status, TPN
  • Mechanical ventilation
  • Multiple transfusions
  • Vasopressor support (gallbladder ischemia)
  • Immunosuppression, HIV/AIDS

Pathophysiology: Bile stasis + gallbladder ischemia â†’ inflammation â†’ necrosis/gangrene

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Labs: Leukocytosis (may be absent in immunocompromised), elevated LFTs, elevated lipase (if concurrent pancreatitis)

Imaging:

  • RUQ Ultrasound: Gallbladder wall thickening >3.5 mm, pericholecystic fluid, distension, NO stones, positive sonographic Murphy's sign
  • CT Abdomen: Wall thickening, pericholecystic stranding, enhancement defects (gangrene)
  • HIDA Scan: Non-visualization of gallbladder = positive (but slow, less useful in ICU)

Diagnostic Criteria (â‰¥2 of):

  • Gallbladder distension (>5 cm transverse)
  • Wall thickening >3.5 mm
  • Pericholecystic fluid
  • Mucosal sloughing
  • Intramural gas (gangrene)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

1. Antibiotics:

  • Empiric: Piperacillin-tazobactam OR ceftriaxone + metronidazole
  • Cover gram-negatives + anaerobes

2. Source Control:

  • Percutaneous cholecystostomy: Preferred in critically ill/high surgical risk patients
  • Place drain under US or CT guidance
  • Can be converted to cholecystectomy once patient stabilized
  • Cholecystectomy: Definitive treatment when patient stable enough for surgery

3. Supportive Care:

  • NPO, IV fluids
  • Optimize hemodynamics
  • Monitor for complications (gangrene, perforation)

Complications: Gangrenous cholecystitis (50% of cases!), perforation, emphysematous cholecystitis, sepsis

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Think of it: Unexplained sepsis in ICU patient + RUQ findings = consider acalculous cholecystitis
  • High mortality: 30-50% mortality (vs 1-4% for calculous cholecystitis) due to delayed diagnosis
  • Gangrene is common: 50% have gangrenous changes at intervention â€” don't delay!
  • Perc chole works: Percutaneous drainage is effective bridge in unstable patients
  • No stones needed: Absence of stones does NOT rule out cholecystitis in ICU patients

298. COAGULOPATHY OF LIVER DISEASE

Rebalanced Hemostasis â€¢ Complex Bleeding/Thrombosis Risk
PATHOPHYSIOLOGY

Key Concept: Liver disease affects BOTH pro-coagulant AND anti-coagulant factors â†’ "rebalanced hemostasis"

Decreased Pro-coagulants: Factors II, V, VII, IX, X, XI, fibrinogen

Decreased Anti-coagulants: Protein C, Protein S, Antithrombin III

Platelet Issues: Thrombocytopenia (splenic sequestration), platelet dysfunction

Fibrinolysis: Enhanced (decreased PAI-1, Î±2-antiplasmin) but also decreased plasminogen

Clinical Implication: INR does NOT predict bleeding risk in cirrhosis â€” patients can bleed OR clot

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Standard Labs: PT/INR, PTT, fibrinogen, platelet count, D-dimer

Advanced Testing:

  • TEG/ROTEM: Viscoelastic testing provides global hemostasis assessment
  • More useful than PT/INR for predicting bleeding in cirrhosis
  • Can guide targeted component therapy

Distinguish from DIC:

  • DIC: Rapidly falling fibrinogen, rising D-dimer, schistocytes
  • Chronic liver disease: Stable coagulopathy, no schistocytes
MANAGEMENT

General Principles:

  • Do NOT routinely correct INR for procedures â€” INR doesn't predict bleeding in cirrhosis
  • Correct only if actively bleeding or high-risk procedure
  • Avoid excessive FFP (volume overload, transfusion reactions)

For Active Bleeding:

  • Fibrinogen <100-120: Cryoprecipitate (10 units) or fibrinogen concentrate
  • Platelets <50K with bleeding: Platelet transfusion
  • FFP: Only if significant bleeding; use TEG/ROTEM to guide if available
  • PCC (4-factor): Consider for life-threatening bleeding (lower volume than FFP)
  • Tranexamic acid: Consider for hyperfibrinolysis (topical or IV)

Procedure Thresholds (General Guidance):

  • Paracentesis/thoracentesis: Usually safe regardless of INR if platelets >20-50K
  • Central line: Platelets >20K, fibrinogen >100
  • Liver biopsy: Platelets >50-60K, INR <1.5 (though INR threshold controversial)

VTE Prophylaxis:

  • Cirrhotic patients ARE at VTE risk despite elevated INR
  • Pharmacologic prophylaxis generally safe if no active bleeding, platelets >50K
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • INR is misleading: Elevated INR does NOT mean bleeding risk in cirrhosis â€” "rebalanced hemostasis"
  • Cirrhotics clot too: Portal vein thrombosis, DVT/PE occur. Don't withhold prophylaxis based on INR alone
  • Fibrinogen is key: Often the critical factor. Check and replace if <100-120
  • Paracentesis is safe: Large volume paracentesis safe even with INR 2-3, platelets >20K
  • TEG/ROTEM superior: Viscoelastic testing better predicts bleeding than INR in liver disease
  • Avoid FFP reflex: Giving FFP to "correct INR" before procedures often unnecessary and harmful (volume overload)

299. TAKOTSUBO CARDIOMYOPATHY

Stress-Induced Cardiomyopathy â€¢ "Broken Heart Syndrome"
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Post-menopausal woman with acute chest pain and dyspnea following intense emotional or physical stress

Triggers:

  • Emotional: Death of loved one, divorce, job loss, argument
  • Physical: Surgery, sepsis, respiratory failure, SAH, pheochromocytoma
  • No trigger identified: ~30% of cases

Demographics: 90% women, mean age 65-70, often without traditional cardiac risk factors

Important: Can occur in men and younger patients â€” don't exclude based on demographics

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

ECG: ST elevation (mimics STEMI), T-wave inversions, QTc prolongation

Biomarkers: Troponin elevated but disproportionately LOW relative to degree of wall motion abnormality

Echocardiogram:

  • Classic "apical ballooning": Apical and mid-ventricular akinesis with hyperdynamic base
  • Variants: Mid-ventricular, basal (reverse takotsubo), focal
  • Wall motion abnormality extends beyond single coronary distribution

Coronary Angiography: No obstructive CAD (or stenosis doesn't explain wall motion abnormality)

Mayo Criteria (Modified InterTAK):

  • Transient LV dysfunction (akinesis/dyskinesis) extending beyond single epicardial territory
  • Absence of obstructive coronary disease or plaque rupture
  • New ECG changes (ST elevation and/or T-wave inversion) or troponin elevation
  • Absence of pheochromocytoma or myocarditis
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Acute Management:

  • Treat initially as ACS until diagnosis confirmed (cath often needed)
  • Supportive care â€” monitor for complications
  • Beta-blockers (if not in cardiogenic shock) â€” may blunt catecholamine effect
  • ACE inhibitors if LV dysfunction

Cardiogenic Shock (10-15%):

  • Avoid inotropes (catecholamines worsen condition)
  • Mechanical support: IABP, Impella, ECMO
  • Levosimendan (if available) â€” inotrope without catecholamine effect

LVOT Obstruction (if present):

  • Beta-blockers, IV fluids
  • AVOID inotropes, vasodilators (worsen obstruction)
  • Phenylephrine if hypotensive

Complications to Monitor:

  • Cardiogenic shock, LV thrombus, arrhythmias (VT, VF)
  • Mitral regurgitation, LVOT obstruction
  • Torsades de pointes (QTc prolongation)

Prognosis: Recovery of LV function within days to weeks; in-hospital mortality ~5%; recurrence 5-10%

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Troponin-wall motion mismatch: Low troponin relative to severe wall motion abnormality suggests takotsubo vs ACS
  • Goes to cath lab: Often diagnosed at angiography when no culprit lesion found in STEMI presentation
  • Avoid catecholamines: Dobutamine/dopamine can worsen condition â€” catecholamine excess is the problem!
  • Check for LVOT obstruction: SAM of mitral valve can cause hypotension; treat with beta-blockers, not inotropes
  • Consider LV thrombus: Anticoagulation if LV thrombus or severe apical akinesis
  • Can be fatal: 5% mortality â€” not a benign condition despite "stress-induced" name

300. MITRAL STENOSIS

Rheumatic Heart Disease â€¢ LA Pressure Overload
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, palpitations (atrial fibrillation), hemoptysis

Precipitants of Decompensation: Atrial fibrillation (loss of atrial kick + tachycardia), pregnancy, anemia, infection, thyrotoxicosis

Physical Exam:

  • Low-pitched diastolic rumble: Best heard at apex with bell in left lateral decubitus
  • Opening snap: Higher pitch, follows S2 (closer to S2 = more severe stenosis)
  • Loud S1: Due to abrupt closure of stenotic valve
  • Signs of RV failure: Late finding (JVD, edema, ascites)

Etiology: Rheumatic heart disease (>90%), degenerative calcification, carcinoid, SLE

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

ECG: Left atrial enlargement (P mitrale), atrial fibrillation (common), RVH (late)

CXR: Left atrial enlargement (straightening of left heart border), pulmonary congestion, Kerley B lines

Echocardiography:

  • Mitral valve area (MVA): Normal 4-6 cmÂ²
  • Mild: >1.5 cmÂ²
  • Moderate: 1.0-1.5 cmÂ²
  • Severe: <1.0 cmÂ²
  • Mean gradient: Severe if >10 mmHg
  • Valve morphology: Wilkins score for balloon candidacy

Wilkins Score (Echocardiographic):

  • Leaflet mobility, thickening, calcification, subvalvular thickening (each 1-4 points)
  • Score â‰¤8: Favorable for percutaneous balloon mitral valvotomy (PBMV)
  • Score >8: Consider surgical mitral valve replacement
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Medical Management:

  • Rate control: Beta-blockers, CCBs (diltiazem, verapamil) â€” slower HR = longer diastolic filling time
  • Diuretics: For pulmonary congestion
  • Anticoagulation: Warfarin if AF, LA thrombus, prior embolism, or severe MS with LA enlargement
  • AF cardioversion: After 3 weeks anticoagulation or TEE-guided

Intervention Indications:

  • Symptomatic severe MS (MVA â‰¤1.5 cmÂ²)
  • Asymptomatic severe MS with PASP >50 mmHg or new-onset AF

Intervention Options:

  • PBMV (Balloon valvotomy): First-line if favorable anatomy (Wilkins â‰¤8), no LA thrombus, no significant MR
  • Surgical MVR: Unfavorable anatomy, significant MR, LA thrombus, or PBMV failure

Special Situations:

  • Pregnancy: PBMV can be performed if symptoms refractory to medical therapy
  • Acute decompensation: Rate control critical; diuretics; cardioversion if new AF
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Tachycardia is the enemy: Faster HR = less diastolic filling time = pulmonary edema. Control rate aggressively
  • Opening snap timing: Shorter S2-OS interval = more severe stenosis (higher LA pressure opens valve earlier)
  • Wilkins score â‰¤8: Favorable for PBMV â€” commissures split nicely
  • Anticoagulate: High stroke risk with AF + MS. Warfarin preferred (no DOAC data)
  • Think rheumatic: Still most common cause worldwide. Ask about childhood illness, endemic areas

301. AORTIC REGURGITATION

Acute vs Chronic â€¢ Wide Pulse Pressure
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Chronic AR: May be asymptomatic for years â†’ exertional dyspnea, fatigue, palpitations, angina

Acute AR: Fulminant pulmonary edema, cardiogenic shock â€” EMERGENCY

Physical Exam (Chronic Severe AR):

  • Wide pulse pressure: High systolic, low diastolic (e.g., 170/50)
  • Diastolic decrescendo murmur: Left sternal border, sitting up, leaning forward
  • Austin Flint murmur: Low-pitched diastolic rumble at apex (AR jet hitting anterior MV leaflet)
  • Eponymous signs: Corrigan's (water-hammer) pulse, de Musset's (head bobbing), Quincke's (nail bed pulsations), Traube's (pistol shot femorals)

Acute AR: May NOT have classic findings â€” no wide pulse pressure (LV hasn't dilated), soft murmur, tachycardia

Etiology:

  • Chronic: Bicuspid aortic valve, rheumatic, degenerative, connective tissue disease (Marfan)
  • Acute: Infective endocarditis, aortic dissection, trauma
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

ECG: LVH (chronic), may be normal in acute

CXR: Cardiomegaly (chronic), pulmonary edema (acute)

Echocardiography:

  • Chronic severe AR: Holodiastolic flow reversal in descending aorta, vena contracta >6mm, regurgitant volume â‰¥60 mL, ERO â‰¥0.3 cmÂ²
  • Acute AR: Early mitral valve closure (pathognomonic), elevated LV filling pressures, normal LV size
  • Assess etiology: Bicuspid valve, endocarditis, aortic root dilation

If Aortic Dissection Suspected: CT angiography or TEE urgently

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Acute Severe AR (Emergency):

  • Surgery is definitive: Urgent AVR â€” medical therapy is bridge only
  • Vasodilators: Nitroprusside to reduce afterload (decreases regurgitant volume)
  • Inotropes: Dobutamine if cardiogenic shock
  • AVOID: Beta-blockers (removes compensatory tachycardia), IABP (worsens regurgitation during diastole)

Chronic AR â€” Indications for Surgery:

  • Symptomatic severe AR
  • Asymptomatic severe AR with LV dysfunction (LVEF â‰¤55%)
  • Asymptomatic severe AR with LV dilation (LVESD >50mm or indexed >25mm/mÂ²)
  • Undergoing other cardiac surgery

Medical Therapy (Chronic):

  • Vasodilators (ACEi, ARB, dihydropyridine CCB) if hypertensive
  • No proven benefit of vasodilators in normotensive asymptomatic patients
  • Serial echo every 6-12 months for severe AR; yearly for moderate
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Acute AR is an emergency: LV can't compensate â†’ cardiogenic shock. Surgery ASAP
  • No IABP in AR: Balloon inflation in diastole worsens regurgitation!
  • Wide pulse pressure: Classic for chronic AR. Absent in acute AR (LV hasn't dilated yet)
  • Austin Flint â‰  MS: AR jet causes functional mitral stenosis physiology without actual stenosis
  • Early MV closure: Pathognomonic of acute severe AR on echo
  • Check the aorta: Aortic root dilation is common cause â€” screen for aneurysm, Marfan

302. PROSTHETIC VALVE DYSFUNCTION

Mechanical & Bioprosthetic Valve Complications
VALVE TYPES

Mechanical Valves: Durable (20+ years), require lifelong anticoagulation (INR 2.5-3.5 for mitral, 2-3 for aortic)

Bioprosthetic Valves: Limited durability (10-15 years), typically no anticoagulation after 3-6 months

TAVR Valves: Increasingly common for aortic stenosis, unique complications

CLINICAL PRESENTATIONS

Prosthetic Valve Obstruction:

  • Thrombosis: Usually mechanical valves with subtherapeutic INR; acute onset dyspnea, CHF
  • Pannus: Tissue ingrowth; more gradual onset
  • Exam: Muffled or absent valve clicks (mechanical), new murmur, CHF signs

Prosthetic Valve Regurgitation:

  • Paravalvular leak: Around the sewing ring; can be early (technical) or late (endocarditis, dehiscence)
  • Intrinsic regurgitation: Leaflet degeneration (bioprosthetic), disc malfunction (mechanical)
  • Symptoms: CHF, hemolytic anemia (from turbulent flow)

Prosthetic Valve Endocarditis (PVE):

  • Early (<1 year): Staph aureus, coagulase-negative staph, gram-negatives
  • Late (>1 year): Similar to native valve endocarditis pathogens
  • Higher risk: Mechanical > bioprosthetic; mitral > aortic

Structural Valve Deterioration (Bioprosthetic):

  • Leaflet calcification, tearing, stenosis, regurgitation
  • More rapid in younger patients, renal failure, calcium disorders
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

TTE: Initial assessment â€” gradients, regurgitation, vegetation

TEE: More sensitive for:

  • Valve thrombosis
  • Paravalvular abscess
  • Vegetations (especially mechanical valves with acoustic shadowing)

Fluoroscopy: Assess mechanical valve leaflet motion

CT: Pannus vs thrombus differentiation, paravalvular leak localization

Labs: INR, hemolysis labs (LDH, haptoglobin, reticulocyte count, peripheral smear), blood cultures

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Valve Thrombosis:

  • Non-obstructive, small thrombus: Optimize anticoagulation, serial imaging
  • Obstructive thrombosis â€” stable: Fibrinolysis (tPA) vs surgery based on surgical risk
  • Obstructive thrombosis â€” unstable: Surgery preferred if available; fibrinolysis if not

Prosthetic Valve Endocarditis:

  • Prolonged antibiotics (6 weeks minimum)
  • Surgery indications: Heart failure, uncontrolled infection, paravalvular abscess, large/mobile vegetation, recurrent emboli
  • Early PVE has high mortality â€” aggressive management

Paravalvular Leak:

  • Small asymptomatic: Monitor
  • Symptomatic or hemolysis: Percutaneous closure or surgical repair

Structural Deterioration:

  • Redo surgery (SAVR) or valve-in-valve TAVR for failed bioprosthetic valves
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Absent clicks = obstruction: Mechanical valve clicks should be audible. Muffled/absent = suspect thrombosis
  • Check the INR: Most mechanical valve thromboses occur with subtherapeutic anticoagulation
  • TEE for endocarditis: TTE misses many prosthetic valve vegetations due to shadowing
  • Hemolysis = paravalvular leak: Unexplained anemia with elevated LDH/retics in prosthetic valve patient
  • Bioprosthetic durability: ~10-15 years â€” earlier failure in younger patients, dialysis patients
  • PVE is dangerous: Mortality 20-40%. Low threshold for surgery

303. PRES (Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome)

Hypertensive Emergency Neurologic Complication
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Tetrad: Headache, altered mental status, seizures, visual disturbances

Visual Symptoms: Cortical blindness, visual field deficits, blurred vision (posterior circulation involvement)

Seizures: Occur in 60-75% of cases; may be presenting symptom

Risk Factors/Triggers:

  • Hypertension: Hypertensive emergency most common; but 20-30% have normal BP!
  • Preeclampsia/Eclampsia: Leading cause in pregnancy
  • Immunosuppressants: Cyclosporine, tacrolimus, sirolimus
  • Chemotherapy: Cisplatin, bevacizumab, tyrosine kinase inhibitors
  • Renal disease: Uremia, dialysis
  • Autoimmune: SLE, thrombotic microangiopathies (TTP, HUS)
  • Sepsis, organ transplantation

Pathophysiology: Endothelial dysfunction â†’ failure of cerebral autoregulation â†’ vasogenic edema (predominantly posterior circulation)

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

MRI Brain (Diagnostic Standard):

  • Classic: Bilateral symmetric T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in parietal-occipital white matter
  • Other locations: Frontal, temporal, brainstem, cerebellum (not limited to posterior)
  • DWI: Usually normal or shows facilitated diffusion (vasogenic, not cytotoxic edema)
  • Important: Restricted diffusion = infarction = irreversible damage

CT Head: May show hypodensities but less sensitive than MRI

Labs: BMP, LFTs, CBC, UA, drug levels (cyclosporine, tacrolimus), uric acid (preeclampsia)

Differential: CVA/stroke, venous sinus thrombosis, encephalitis, metabolic encephalopathy

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

1. Blood Pressure Control:

  • Goal: Reduce MAP by 20-25% over first few hours
  • IV agents: Nicardipine, labetalol, clevidipine
  • Eclampsia: Magnesium sulfate + hydralazine or labetalol + delivery
  • Avoid: Precipitous BP drops (can cause watershed infarcts)

2. Seizure Management:

  • Benzodiazepines for acute seizures
  • Levetiracetam, phenytoin, or lacosamide for seizure prophylaxis
  • AEDs often not needed long-term once PRES resolves

3. Remove/Treat Underlying Cause:

  • Discontinue or reduce offending immunosuppressant
  • Deliver fetus in eclampsia
  • Treat underlying infection, autoimmune condition

4. Supportive Care:

  • ICU monitoring for severe cases
  • Manage increased ICP if present

Prognosis: Generally reversible with treatment within days to weeks; MRI normalizes. Permanent deficits if cytotoxic edema/infarction develops

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Not always posterior: Can involve frontal lobes, brainstem â€” "PRES" is a misnomer
  • Not always hypertensive: 20-30% have normal BP at presentation
  • DWI is key: Restricted diffusion = cytotoxic edema = worse prognosis (infarct, not reversible)
  • Think immunosuppressants: Calcineurin inhibitors (cyclosporine, tacrolimus) are common culprits
  • Eclampsia is PRES: Classic PRES trigger â€” treat with magnesium + delivery
  • Can recur: Especially if underlying condition not addressed

304. OSMOTIC DEMYELINATION SYNDROME (ODS)

Central Pontine Myelinolysis (CPM) â€¢ Sodium Correction Injury
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Timeline: Symptoms develop 2-6 days AFTER overly rapid sodium correction

Biphasic Course:

  • Phase 1: Initial improvement as hyponatremia corrects
  • Phase 2 (day 2-6): Neurologic deterioration â€” dysarthria, dysphagia, quadriparesis

Central Pontine Myelinolysis:

  • Spastic quadriparesis, pseudobulbar palsy (dysarthria, dysphagia)
  • "Locked-in syndrome": Severe cases â€” awake but unable to move except eye movements

Extrapontine Myelinolysis (EPM): Movement disorders, ataxia, cognitive changes (basal ganglia, thalamus involvement)

High-Risk Patients:

  • Chronic alcoholism, malnutrition
  • Liver transplantation
  • Hypokalemia (concurrent)
  • Severely hyponatremic (<105 mEq/L) or chronic hyponatremia (>48h)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

MRI Brain (Diagnostic Standard):

  • Classic "trident" or "bat wing": T2/FLAIR hyperintensity in central pons, sparing periphery
  • EPM: Symmetric lesions in basal ganglia, thalami, cerebral white matter
  • Timing: MRI may be NORMAL in first 2 weeks; repeat if clinical suspicion high
  • DWI may show early changes before T2/FLAIR

Review Sodium Correction: Calculate rate of sodium rise â€” was it too fast?

Safe Correction Rate: â‰¤10 mEq/L in first 24h, â‰¤18 mEq/L in first 48h (some recommend â‰¤8 mEq/L in high-risk patients)

PREVENTION & TREATMENT

PREVENTION IS KEY:

  • Monitor sodium frequently during correction (q2-4h)
  • Goal: Raise sodium â‰¤10 mEq/L in 24 hours, â‰¤8 mEq/L in high-risk patients
  • If overcorrecting: D5W infusion Â± DDAVP to re-lower sodium

Rescue Therapy (If Overcorrection Detected):

  • D5W: 3 mL/kg/hr to lower sodium back
  • DDAVP: 2-4 mcg IV/SQ to prevent free water excretion
  • Target: Re-lower sodium to stay within safe correction limits

Treatment of Established ODS:

  • No proven specific treatment
  • Supportive care, rehabilitation
  • Plasmapheresis: Anecdotal reports, not proven
  • Steroids: Sometimes used, no clear evidence

Prognosis:

  • Previously considered uniformly fatal
  • Now: Many patients improve over weeks to months with supportive care
  • Full recovery possible in some; others have permanent deficits
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Prevention, prevention, prevention: ODS is almost entirely iatrogenic. Monitor sodium closely during correction
  • 10 in 24, 18 in 48: Safe sodium correction limits. Use 8 in 24 for high-risk patients
  • Biphasic course is classic: Initial improvement then deterioration days later
  • MRI may be negative early: Changes may not appear for 2 weeks. Repeat MRI if suspicious
  • DDAVP rescue: If correcting too fast, give DDAVP + D5W to re-lower sodium
  • Not always fatal: With supportive care, many patients have meaningful recovery

305. IIH (Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension)

Pseudotumor Cerebri â€¢ Elevated ICP Without Mass
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Patient: Obese woman of childbearing age with headache and papilledema

Headache: Daily, generalized or retro-orbital, worse with Valsalva, may wake from sleep, positional component

Visual Symptoms:

  • Transient visual obscurations: Brief (seconds) episodes of vision loss, often with position changes
  • Diplopia: CN VI palsy (false localizing sign from elevated ICP)
  • Permanent vision loss: Can occur without treatment â€” optic nerve damage

Other Symptoms: Pulsatile tinnitus (whooshing in ears), neck/back pain, nausea

Papilledema: Bilateral in >95% â€” MUST examine fundi

Risk Factors:

  • Obesity: 90%+ of patients; weight gain often precedes symptoms
  • Female sex, reproductive age
  • Medications: Vitamin A, tetracyclines (minocycline, doxycycline), growth hormone, lithium
DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA (Modified Dandy)

Required:

  • Signs/symptoms of elevated ICP (headache, papilledema, CN VI palsy)
  • Elevated opening pressure on LP: >250 mm Hâ‚‚O (lateral decubitus)
  • Normal CSF composition
  • No other cause identified (normal neuroimaging, no mass, no venous thrombosis)

MRI Brain + MRV:

  • Rule out mass, hydrocephalus, venous sinus thrombosis
  • IIH findings: Empty sella, flattened posterior globes, optic nerve sheath distension, transverse sinus stenosis

Lumbar Puncture:

  • Opening pressure >250 mm Hâ‚‚O (some use >200 with symptoms)
  • Normal CSF protein, glucose, cell count
  • Diagnostic AND therapeutic (temporary symptom relief)

Visual Assessment: Formal visual field testing (Humphrey), OCT â€” baseline and serial monitoring

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

1. Weight Loss:

  • Most effective long-term treatment
  • 5-10% weight loss often produces significant improvement
  • Consider bariatric surgery referral for severe cases

2. Acetazolamide (First-Line Medical Therapy):

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor â€” decreases CSF production
  • Dose: Start 500 mg BID, titrate to 1-2 g/day (max 4 g/day)
  • Side effects: Paresthesias, dysgeusia, metabolic acidosis, nephrolithiasis

3. Topiramate (Alternative):

  • Weak carbonic anhydrase inhibitor + promotes weight loss
  • May be preferred if weight loss desired

4. Stop Offending Medications: Vitamin A, tetracyclines, growth hormone

5. Surgical Options (Vision-Threatening or Refractory):

  • Optic nerve sheath fenestration: Directly protects optic nerve
  • CSF shunting: Ventriculoperitoneal or lumboperitoneal shunt
  • Venous sinus stenting: If significant transverse sinus stenosis

Monitoring: Serial visual field testing and OCT â€” vision loss can be permanent!

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Check the fundi: Papilledema is the key finding â€” don't miss it!
  • Vision loss is real: Despite "benign" ICP elevation, permanent optic nerve damage occurs. Monitor closely
  • Transient visual obscurations: Classic symptom â€” brief blackouts of vision with position change
  • Weight loss works: Even 5-10% weight loss can resolve symptoms
  • Rule out venous thrombosis: MRV is essential â€” cerebral venous thrombosis mimics IIH
  • LP is diagnostic AND therapeutic: Provides immediate (temporary) relief

306. MEDICATION OVERUSE HEADACHE (MOH)

Rebound Headache â€¢ Analgesic Overuse
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Chronic daily headache (â‰¥15 days/month) in patient with pre-existing headache disorder who overuses acute medications

Pattern: Worsening headache frequency â†’ increased medication use â†’ more headaches (vicious cycle)

Morning headache: Often present upon waking (medication wearing off)

Medication Thresholds for Overuse:

  • Simple analgesics (acetaminophen, NSAIDs): â‰¥15 days/month
  • Triptans: â‰¥10 days/month
  • Opioids: â‰¥10 days/month
  • Combination analgesics (butalbital-containing): â‰¥10 days/month
  • Ergots: â‰¥10 days/month

Risk Factors:

  • Pre-existing migraine or tension-type headache
  • History of anxiety, depression
  • Escalating use of acute medications
DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA (ICHD-3)

Criteria:

  • Headache present â‰¥15 days/month
  • Pre-existing headache disorder
  • Regular overuse of acute headache medication for >3 months
  • Headache not better accounted for by another diagnosis

Highest Risk Medications:

  • Opioids: Highest risk of MOH, hardest to withdraw
  • Butalbital combinations: Very high risk
  • Triptans: Moderate risk (but may be easier to withdraw)
  • NSAIDs/Acetaminophen: Lower risk but still occurs
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

1. Education:

  • Explain the cycle of medication overuse and rebound
  • Set expectations: Initial worsening (1-2 weeks) before improvement
  • Most patients improve within 2 months of withdrawal

2. Withdrawal Approaches:

  • Abrupt withdrawal: Preferred for most (triptans, NSAIDs, acetaminophen)
  • Gradual taper: Required for opioids, butalbital (withdrawal symptoms)
  • Inpatient detox: Consider for severe cases, opioid dependence, failed outpatient attempts

3. Bridge Therapy (During Withdrawal):

  • NSAIDs (scheduled): Naproxen 500 mg BID for 1-2 weeks (if not overusing NSAIDs)
  • Steroids: Prednisone 60-80 mg Ã— 2-5 days taper (limited evidence)
  • Anti-emetics: PRN for nausea
  • DHE infusion: Consider for inpatient protocol

4. Start Preventive Therapy:

  • Begin during or shortly after withdrawal
  • Options: Topiramate, amitriptyline, propranolol, CGRP monoclonal antibodies
  • CGRP antagonists may be effective even before withdrawal complete

5. Limit Future Acute Medication Use:

  • Restrict acute medications to â‰¤2 days/week
  • Keep headache diary
  • Avoid butalbital and opioids for primary headaches
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Ask about medication use: Many patients don't recognize overuse as the problem
  • Opioids are worst: Highest risk of MOH, hardest to withdraw, least effective for headache
  • Warn about worsening: First 1-2 weeks after withdrawal are usually worse before better
  • â‰¤2 days/week rule: After recovery, acute medications should be used â‰¤2 days/week to prevent recurrence
  • Preventive therapy is key: Must address underlying headache disorder, not just stop the overused medication
  • CGRP antibodies help: Newer agents (erenumab, fremanezumab) effective for MOH prevention

307. HLH (Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis)

Cytokine Storm Syndrome â€¢ Life-Threatening Hyperinflammation
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Persistent fever, cytopenias, hepatosplenomegaly, multi-organ dysfunction

Systemic Inflammation: Often mimics sepsis or severe infection with rapid deterioration

Key Features:

  • Fever: Prolonged, high-grade, unresponsive to antibiotics
  • Hepatosplenomegaly: Present in >90%
  • Cytopenias: â‰¥2 cell lines affected (anemia, thrombocytopenia, neutropenia)
  • CNS involvement: Altered mental status, seizures (30-50%)
  • Coagulopathy: DIC-like picture, hypofibrinogenemia

Triggers (Secondary HLH in Adults):

  • Infections: EBV (most common), CMV, HIV, other viruses; bacterial, fungal
  • Malignancy: Lymphoma (especially T-cell, NK-cell), leukemia
  • Autoimmune: SLE, Adult-onset Still's disease, sJIA â†’ "MAS" (macrophage activation syndrome)
  • Medications: Immunosuppressants, checkpoint inhibitors
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

HLH-2004 Criteria (â‰¥5 of 8):

  • Fever â‰¥38.5Â°C
  • Splenomegaly
  • Cytopenias (â‰¥2 lines): Hgb <9, Plt <100K, ANC <1K
  • Hypertriglyceridemia â‰¥265 mg/dL OR hypofibrinogenemia <150 mg/dL
  • Hemophagocytosis in bone marrow, spleen, or lymph nodes
  • Low/absent NK-cell activity
  • Ferritin â‰¥500 ng/mL (often >10,000 â€” very elevated ferritin is clue!)
  • Elevated soluble CD25 (sIL-2R) â‰¥2,400 U/mL

H-Score Calculator: Clinical scoring system; score >169 = 93% probability of HLH

Key Labs:

  • Ferritin: Often >10,000 (very high = think HLH); ferritin >500 is criterion
  • Triglycerides: Elevated
  • Fibrinogen: Low (unusual in other inflammatory states)
  • LDH: Very elevated
  • Soluble IL-2 receptor: Markedly elevated
  • D-dimer: Elevated

Bone Marrow Biopsy: May show hemophagocytosis, but absence doesn't rule out HLH

Workup for Trigger: EBV/CMV viral loads, HIV, CT for lymphoma, PET scan, autoimmune serologies

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Urgency: HLH is rapidly fatal without treatment â€” mortality >50% untreated. Do not wait for all criteria

1. Treat Underlying Trigger:

  • Treat infection (antivirals for EBV/CMV)
  • Chemotherapy for malignancy-associated HLH
  • Discontinue offending medications

2. Immunosuppression (HLH-94/2004 Protocol):

  • Dexamethasone: 10 mg/mÂ² (potent CNS penetration)
  • Etoposide: 150 mg/mÂ² twice weekly initially
  • Cyclosporine A: Added at week 9 or earlier
  • Intrathecal methotrexate + hydrocortisone: If CNS involvement

3. Alternative/Newer Therapies:

  • Anakinra: IL-1 receptor antagonist â€” especially for MAS/autoimmune HLH
  • Ruxolitinib: JAK inhibitor â€” increasing use for refractory HLH
  • Emapalumab: Anti-interferon-gamma â€” FDA approved for primary HLH

4. Supportive Care:

  • ICU monitoring
  • Transfusion support, coagulopathy management
  • IVIG sometimes used (especially if infection-triggered)

5. Consider Allogeneic HSCT: For primary/familial HLH or refractory cases

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Sky-high ferritin: Ferritin >10,000 is highly specific for HLH. Think HLH when ferritin very elevated
  • Low fibrinogen paradox: Inflammatory state with LOW fibrinogen is unusual â€” suggests HLH or DIC
  • Don't wait for hemophagocytosis: Bone marrow hemophagocytosis absent in 20-30% â€” treat based on clinical picture
  • Find the trigger: EBV and lymphoma are common in adults â€” PET scan, viral PCRs
  • HLH vs sepsis: Both cause cytopenias, organ failure; HLH has very high ferritin, low fibrinogen, splenomegaly
  • Rapid treatment: HLH is a medical emergency â€” mortality is high without immunosuppression

308. IRON DEFICIENCY ANEMIA

Most Common Anemia Worldwide â€¢ GI Evaluation Required
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Symptoms: Fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, palpitations, headache, dizziness

Specific to Iron Deficiency:

  • Pica: Craving non-food items (ice â€” pagophagia, dirt, starch)
  • Restless legs syndrome
  • Koilonychia: Spoon-shaped nails (late finding)
  • Angular cheilitis, glossitis
  • Plummer-Vinson syndrome: Esophageal web + IDA + dysphagia (rare)

Causes by Population:

  • Premenopausal women: Menstrual blood loss (most common)
  • Men and postmenopausal women: GI blood loss until proven otherwise
  • Dietary: Vegans, restrictive diets (less common in adults)
  • Malabsorption: Celiac disease, gastric bypass, H. pylori, PPI use
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

CBC: Microcytic (low MCV), hypochromic anemia; elevated RDW

Iron Studies:

  • Serum iron: Low
  • Ferritin: Low (<30 ng/mL diagnostic; <15 very specific)
  • TIBC: Elevated (>400 mcg/dL)
  • Transferrin saturation: Low (<20%)

Ferritin Interpretation:

  • Ferritin <15: Diagnostic for IDA
  • Ferritin 15-30: Probable IDA
  • Ferritin >100: IDA unlikely (but can occur with inflammation)
  • Note: Ferritin is acute phase reactant â€” can be "normal" in IDA + inflammation

Peripheral Smear: Microcytic, hypochromic RBCs, pencil cells, target cells

Reticulocyte Count: Inappropriately low for degree of anemia (inadequate response)

GI EVALUATION (Men and Postmenopausal Women):

  • Colonoscopy: Evaluate for colon cancer, polyps, angiodysplasia
  • EGD: Evaluate for gastric/esophageal pathology, H. pylori
  • Celiac serologies: TTG-IgA (malabsorption)
  • Consider capsule endoscopy: If upper and lower endoscopy negative (small bowel evaluation)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

1. Oral Iron (First-Line for Mild-Moderate):

  • Ferrous sulfate: 325 mg (65 mg elemental iron) daily to TID
  • Every-other-day dosing: May improve absorption and tolerability
  • Take on empty stomach with vitamin C (enhances absorption)
  • Avoid: Antacids, PPIs, calcium, tea, coffee (inhibit absorption)
  • Duration: Continue 3-6 months after Hgb normalizes to replete stores

2. IV Iron (Indications):

  • Oral iron intolerance or non-adherence
  • Malabsorption (celiac, gastric bypass, IBD)
  • Ongoing blood loss exceeding oral replacement
  • CKD on dialysis or ESA therapy
  • Need for rapid repletion (severe symptomatic anemia, preoperative)

IV Iron Formulations:

  • Iron sucrose: 200-300 mg per infusion, well tolerated
  • Ferric carboxymaltose (Injectafer): 750 mg Ã— 2 doses (can give full repletion in 2 visits)
  • Ferric derisomaltose (Monoferric): Single 1000 mg dose possible
  • Iron dextran: Test dose required, higher anaphylaxis risk

3. Treat Underlying Cause:

  • Treat H. pylori if positive
  • Gluten-free diet for celiac disease
  • Manage menorrhagia (hormonal therapy, GYN evaluation)
  • Surgical intervention for GI malignancy

Response Monitoring:

  • Reticulocyte count rises in 3-5 days
  • Hemoglobin rises 1-2 g/dL per month
  • Recheck ferritin at 3 months (goal >100 for adequate stores)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • IDA in men = GI workup: Colon cancer until proven otherwise. Don't just give iron without investigating
  • Ferritin <30: Diagnostic for IDA in non-inflammatory states
  • Every-other-day dosing: Better absorbed than daily (hepcidin physiology)
  • Pica (especially ice craving): Highly specific for iron deficiency
  • Think celiac: Unexplained IDA, especially with diarrhea or family history â€” check TTG-IgA
  • IV iron is underused: Safe, effective, and faster than oral. Use it when indicated

309. PARANEOPLASTIC SYNDROMES

Remote Effects of Malignancy â€¢ Not Direct Tumor Invasion
OVERVIEW

Definition: Symptoms caused by tumor-secreted substances or immune cross-reactivity, NOT direct tumor invasion or metastasis

Importance: May be presenting symptom of occult malignancy; can precede cancer diagnosis by months to years

Categories: Endocrine, neurologic, hematologic, dermatologic, rheumatologic

ENDOCRINE PARANEOPLASTIC SYNDROMES

SIADH (Hyponatremia):

  • Cancer: Small cell lung cancer (most common), head/neck cancers
  • Mechanism: Ectopic ADH production
  • Treatment: Fluid restriction, treat underlying cancer

Hypercalcemia of Malignancy:

  • PTHrP: Squamous cell carcinomas (lung, head/neck, renal)
  • 1,25-vitamin D: Lymphoma
  • Osteolytic metastases: Breast cancer, myeloma
  • Treatment: IV fluids, bisphosphonates, denosumab, calcitonin

Cushing Syndrome (Ectopic ACTH):

  • Cancer: Small cell lung cancer, carcinoid tumors, medullary thyroid
  • Features: Hypokalemia, hypertension, hyperglycemia (often without classic cushingoid features due to rapid onset)

Hypoglycemia (Non-islet Cell Tumor):

  • Cancer: Large mesenchymal tumors, hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Mechanism: IGF-2 secretion
NEUROLOGIC PARANEOPLASTIC SYNDROMES

Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS):

  • Cancer: Small cell lung cancer (60%)
  • Antibody: Anti-VGCC (voltage-gated calcium channel)
  • Features: Proximal weakness that IMPROVES with exercise, autonomic dysfunction, hyporeflexia
  • Diagnosis: EMG shows incremental response, anti-VGCC antibodies

Paraneoplastic Cerebellar Degeneration:

  • Cancer: Ovarian, breast, SCLC, Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Antibodies: Anti-Yo (ovarian/breast), Anti-Hu (SCLC)
  • Features: Rapidly progressive ataxia, dysarthria, nystagmus

Limbic Encephalitis:

  • Cancer: SCLC, testicular (seminoma), thymoma
  • Antibodies: Anti-Hu, Anti-NMDAR, Anti-LGI1
  • Features: Memory loss, seizures, psychiatric symptoms

Anti-NMDA Receptor Encephalitis:

  • Cancer: Ovarian teratoma (young women)
  • Features: Psychiatric symptoms â†’ seizures â†’ movement disorders â†’ autonomic instability
  • Treatment: Tumor removal, immunotherapy (IVIG, steroids, rituximab)
OTHER PARANEOPLASTIC SYNDROMES

Dermatologic:

  • Acanthosis nigricans (malignant): GI adenocarcinomas (especially gastric)
  • Dermatomyositis: Various solid tumors (ovarian, lung, GI, breast)
  • Sweet syndrome: AML, MDS
  • Erythema gyratum repens: Lung, breast, GI cancers
  • Leser-TrÃ©lat sign: Explosive seborrheic keratoses â€” GI malignancy

Hematologic:

  • Polycythemia: Renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma (EPO production)
  • Thrombocytosis: Many solid tumors
  • Trousseau syndrome: Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis â€” pancreatic, lung cancer

Rheumatologic:

  • Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy: Lung cancer â€” digital clubbing, periostitis
  • Polymyalgia-like syndrome: Various malignancies
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Think cancer: Unexplained hyponatremia, hypercalcemia, or neurologic syndrome â†’ search for malignancy
  • SCLC is the "paraneoplastic cancer": Associated with SIADH, Cushing, LEMS, many neurologic syndromes
  • LEMS vs Myasthenia: LEMS improves with exercise, MG worsens. Check for SCLC in LEMS
  • Dermatomyositis: Cancer screening essential â€” CT chest/abdomen/pelvis, age-appropriate screening, consider PET
  • Anti-NMDAR encephalitis: Young woman with psychiatric symptoms â†’ check for ovarian teratoma
  • Treatment is cancer treatment: Paraneoplastic syndromes often improve with treatment of underlying malignancy

310. PRIMARY HYPERALDOSTERONISM

Conn Syndrome â€¢ Most Common Secondary Hypertension
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic: Resistant hypertension + hypokalemia (but 50%+ have normal potassium)

Features:

  • Resistant or severe hypertension (often requiring â‰¥3 medications)
  • Hypokalemia (may be absent â€” don't exclude PA based on normal K)
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Muscle weakness, cramping (if significant hypokalemia)

Prevalence: 5-10% of all hypertensive patients; 20% of resistant hypertension

Screening Indications (Endocrine Society Guidelines):

  • Sustained BP >150/100 on 3 occasions
  • Resistant hypertension (BP >140/90 despite 3 drugs including diuretic)
  • Hypertension + hypokalemia (spontaneous or diuretic-induced)
  • Hypertension + adrenal incidentaloma
  • Hypertension + sleep apnea
  • Family history of early-onset hypertension or stroke (<40 years)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Step 1: Screening â€” Aldosterone-to-Renin Ratio (ARR):

  • Positive screen: ARR >30 AND aldosterone >15 ng/dL
  • Conditions: Morning sample, seated, potassium repleted
  • Interfering medications:
    • Stop spironolactone/eplerenone 4-6 weeks before
    • Stop other K-sparing diuretics, thiazides 2-4 weeks before
    • Beta-blockers lower renin â†’ false positive (continue if needed for BP)
    • ACEi/ARBs may cause false negatives (but can screen on them if ARR elevated)

Step 2: Confirmatory Testing (If Screening Positive):

  • Oral sodium loading test: 3 days high-salt diet, then 24h urine aldosterone (>12 mcg/24h = positive)
  • IV saline suppression test: 2L NS over 4 hours, then serum aldosterone (>10 ng/dL = positive)
  • Fludrocortisone suppression test: Alternative confirmatory test

Step 3: Subtype Differentiation:

  • CT Adrenals: Identify unilateral adenoma vs bilateral hyperplasia
  • Adrenal Vein Sampling (AVS): Gold standard for lateralization if surgery considered
    • Required if CT shows bilateral disease or normal adrenals
    • May skip if <35 years with clear unilateral adenoma
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Unilateral Disease (Adenoma/Unilateral Hyperplasia):

  • Laparoscopic adrenalectomy: Treatment of choice
  • Cure/improvement of hypertension in 50-70%
  • Pre-operative: MRA (spironolactone) to normalize potassium, improve BP

Bilateral Disease or Non-Surgical Candidates:

  • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists:
    • Spironolactone: 25-100 mg daily (start low, titrate); gynecomastia common
    • Eplerenone: 25-50 mg BID; fewer anti-androgen effects, more expensive
  • May need additional antihypertensives
  • Monitor potassium (risk of hyperkalemia, especially with CKD)

Outcomes:

  • Surgery cures hypokalemia in nearly all patients
  • Hypertension cure rate depends on duration and severity pre-op
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Screen liberally: PA is underdiagnosed. Screen anyone with resistant HTN or HTN + hypokalemia
  • Normal K doesn't exclude PA: 50%+ of PA patients are normokalemic
  • ARR is a ratio: Low renin is the key finding â€” aldosterone may be only mildly elevated
  • Stop spironolactone before testing: Interferes with ARR for weeks
  • AVS before surgery: CT can miss small adenomas and misidentify incidentalomas â€” AVS confirms lateralization
  • Long-term CV benefit: Treating PA reduces CV events beyond BP control alone

311. CARCINOID SYNDROME

Neuroendocrine Tumor Hormone Excess â€¢ Serotonin-Mediated
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Triad: Flushing, diarrhea, wheezing (but full triad uncommon)

Symptoms:

  • Flushing (90%): Episodic, dry (vs sweating), face/neck, triggered by alcohol, stress, tyramine-rich foods
  • Diarrhea (70%): Secretory, watery, can be severe
  • Bronchospasm (15%): Wheezing, dyspnea
  • Carcinoid heart disease (40-50%): Right-sided valvular disease (tricuspid regurgitation, pulmonic stenosis)

Key Point: Carcinoid syndrome occurs only when tumor products reach systemic circulation

  • GI carcinoids: Syndrome occurs with LIVER METASTASES (hepatic metabolism normally clears serotonin)
  • Bronchial/ovarian carcinoids: Can cause syndrome without liver mets (drain directly to systemic circulation)

Carcinoid Crisis:

  • Life-threatening release of vasoactive substances
  • Triggers: Surgery, anesthesia, biopsy, chemoembolization
  • Features: Severe hypotension/hypertension, flushing, bronchospasm, arrhythmias
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Biochemical Testing:

  • 24-hour urine 5-HIAA: Serotonin metabolite; elevated in 70% with carcinoid syndrome
  • Plasma chromogranin A: Elevated in most NETs (not specific)
  • Serum serotonin: Less commonly used

Avoid Before Testing: Tryptophan-rich foods (bananas, avocados, walnuts), medications (acetaminophen, cough syrups)

Localization:

  • CT/MRI: Identify primary tumor, liver metastases
  • Octreotide scan (Octreoscan): Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • Ga-68 DOTATATE PET/CT: Superior sensitivity for somatostatin receptor-positive tumors

Cardiac Evaluation:

  • Echocardiogram: Screen for carcinoid heart disease (tricuspid/pulmonic valve thickening)
  • Obtain in all patients with carcinoid syndrome
  • NT-proBNP and 5-HIAA levels correlate with cardiac involvement
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

1. Somatostatin Analogs (First-Line for Symptoms):

  • Octreotide LAR: 20-30 mg IM every 4 weeks (long-acting)
  • Lanreotide: 120 mg deep SQ every 4 weeks
  • Also have antiproliferative effect (slow tumor growth)
  • For breakthrough: Octreotide 100-500 mcg SQ PRN

2. Carcinoid Crisis Prevention:

  • Pre-operative octreotide: 250-500 mcg IV bolus before any procedure
  • Continuous infusion during surgery (50-100 mcg/hr)
  • Avoid: Catecholamines, morphine, succinylcholine (can trigger crisis)

3. Managing Refractory Symptoms:

  • Telotristat: Tryptophan hydroxylase inhibitor for refractory diarrhea
  • Hepatic-directed therapy: Embolization, ablation, surgical debulking

4. Tumor-Directed Therapy:

  • Surgery: Resection of primary and/or metastases when feasible
  • PRRT: Lutetium-177 DOTATATE for progressive disease
  • Everolimus, sunitinib: For progressive NETs
  • Liver-directed: TACE, radioembolization, ablation

5. Carcinoid Heart Disease:

  • Medical optimization, diuretics
  • Valve surgery for severe symptomatic disease
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Liver mets = syndrome: GI carcinoids cause syndrome only after hepatic metastasis (liver normally clears serotonin)
  • Flushing is dry: Unlike pheochromocytoma (sweating), carcinoid flushing is typically dry
  • Right heart involvement: Serotonin damages right-sided valves â†’ tricuspid regurgitation most common
  • Octreotide before surgery: Always give octreotide prophylaxis before procedures to prevent carcinoid crisis
  • 5-HIAA for diagnosis: 24-hour urine 5-HIAA is key diagnostic test
  • PRRT is effective: Lutetium-177 DOTATATE improves survival in progressive NETs

312. HEMOTHORAX

Blood in Pleural Space â€¢ Trauma vs Spontaneous
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Symptoms: Chest pain, dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension (if massive)

Physical Exam: Decreased breath sounds, dullness to percussion, tracheal deviation (massive)

Classification by Size:

  • Small: <300 mL
  • Moderate: 300-1000 mL
  • Massive: >1000-1500 mL (or >200 mL/hr output)

Etiology:

  • Traumatic (most common): Blunt or penetrating chest trauma, rib fractures
  • Iatrogenic: Central line placement, thoracentesis, chest tube, cardiac surgery
  • Spontaneous:
    • Anticoagulation (warfarin, DOACs)
    • Malignancy (primary or metastatic)
    • Pulmonary embolism with infarction
    • Aortic dissection/rupture
    • Arteriovenous malformation
    • Coagulopathy, thrombocytopenia
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

CXR: Blunting of costophrenic angle (>200-300 mL to visualize), opacification, meniscus sign

Ultrasound: Sensitive for small effusions; echogenic fluid suggests blood

CT Chest: Quantifies volume, identifies source, associated injuries

Pleural Fluid Analysis:

  • Hematocrit: Pleural fluid Hct >50% of peripheral blood Hct = hemothorax
  • Bloody effusion (Hct <50%) can be from malignancy, PE, parapneumonic

Labs: CBC (trending Hgb), coagulation studies, type & screen

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

1. Resuscitation:

  • Large-bore IV access, crystalloid resuscitation
  • Blood transfusion as needed
  • Correct coagulopathy (reverse anticoagulation if applicable)

2. Tube Thoracostomy (Chest Tube):

  • Indication: Most hemothoraces require drainage
  • Size: Large-bore (28-36 Fr) preferred for blood (clots clog small tubes)
  • Position: Posterior-lateral, 5th intercostal space
  • Connect to drainage system, monitor output

3. Indications for Surgery (VATS or Thoracotomy):

  • Immediate thoracotomy:
    • Initial output >1500 mL
    • Ongoing output >200 mL/hr for 2-4 hours
    • Hemodynamic instability despite resuscitation
  • VATS (Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery):
    • Retained/clotted hemothorax (incomplete drainage)
    • Early VATS (within 3-7 days) reduces empyema risk

4. Complications:

  • Retained hemothorax: Leads to empyema, fibrothorax
  • Empyema: Infected hemothorax â€” requires drainage, antibiotics, possibly decortication
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • 1500 mL or 200 mL/hr: Thresholds for surgical intervention â€” memorize these numbers
  • Large-bore chest tube: Use 28-36 Fr for hemothorax â€” small tubes clot off
  • Early VATS for retained: Don't wait â€” early evacuation prevents empyema and fibrothorax
  • Check pleural Hct: Hct >50% of blood Hct confirms hemothorax
  • Spontaneous hemothorax: Think anticoagulation, malignancy, aortic pathology
  • Complete evacuation: Goal is complete drainage â€” retained blood causes complications

313. CHYLOTHORAX

Lymphatic Fluid in Pleural Space â€¢ Thoracic Duct Injury
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Symptoms: Progressive dyspnea, chest discomfort (typically non-painful)

Course: May accumulate rapidly; significant nutritional and immune consequences

Etiology:

  • Traumatic/Surgical (50%):
    • Thoracic surgery (esophagectomy, lung resection, cardiac surgery)
    • Central line placement (especially left subclavian)
    • Blunt/penetrating trauma
  • Non-traumatic (50%):
    • Malignancy (lymphoma most common, lung cancer, metastatic)
    • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Sarcoidosis, tuberculosis
    • Superior vena cava thrombosis
    • Congenital lymphatic abnormalities

Complications:

  • Malnutrition (loss of proteins, fats, vitamins)
  • Immunodeficiency (loss of T lymphocytes, immunoglobulins)
  • Electrolyte abnormalities
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Pleural Fluid Appearance: Milky, white, or turbid (if patient fasting, may be less milky)

Pleural Fluid Analysis:

  • Triglycerides >110 mg/dL: Diagnostic of chylothorax
  • Triglycerides <50 mg/dL: Rules out chylothorax
  • Triglycerides 50-110 mg/dL: Check lipoprotein electrophoresis for chylomicrons (definitive)
  • Chylomicrons present: Confirms chylothorax

Other Fluid Features:

  • Lymphocyte-predominant (>80% lymphocytes)
  • Exudative by Light's criteria
  • pH >7.4, glucose similar to serum

Imaging:

  • CT chest: Identify mass, lymphadenopathy, thoracic duct injury
  • Lymphangiography: Can localize leak (rarely needed)

DDx for Milky Effusion:

  • Chylothorax: High triglycerides, chylomicrons present
  • Pseudochylothorax: High cholesterol (>200 mg/dL), cholesterol crystals; seen in chronic effusions (TB, RA)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

1. Conservative Management (First-Line, 2-4 weeks):

  • Drainage: Chest tube or repeated thoracentesis
  • Dietary modification:
    • NPO or low-fat diet with medium-chain triglycerides (MCT)
    • MCTs absorbed directly into portal circulation, bypass thoracic duct
  • TPN: If NPO required or high-output chyle leak
  • Octreotide: Reduces chyle production (decreases splanchnic blood flow)

2. Interventional/Surgical (If Conservative Fails):

  • Thoracic duct embolization: Interventional radiology; first-line invasive option
  • Thoracic duct ligation: VATS or open; if embolization fails/unavailable
  • Pleurodesis: For malignant or recurrent chylothorax
  • Pleuroperitoneal shunt: Refractory cases

3. Treat Underlying Cause:

  • Chemotherapy/radiation for lymphoma
  • Anticoagulation for SVC thrombosis

Nutritional Support:

  • Monitor albumin, prealbumin, lymphocyte count
  • Replace immunoglobulins if significantly depleted
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Triglycerides >110: Diagnostic cutoff for chylothorax â€” always check on milky effusion
  • Post-surgical: Consider chylothorax after esophagectomy, cardiac surgery, or central line placement
  • Lymphoma: Most common non-traumatic cause â€” look for mediastinal lymphadenopathy
  • MCT diet works: Medium-chain triglycerides bypass thoracic duct â†’ reduce chyle flow
  • Nutritional emergency: Losing chyle = losing protein, fat, lymphocytes. Support aggressively
  • Pseudochylothorax: Chronic effusions with high cholesterol, NOT triglycerides â€” different entity

314. RENAL VEIN THROMBOSIS

Nephrotic Syndrome Complication â€¢ Hypercoagulable State
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Acute RVT: Flank pain, hematuria, acute kidney injury, nausea/vomiting

Chronic RVT: Often asymptomatic; may present with pulmonary embolism or progressive renal dysfunction

Risk Factors:

  • Nephrotic syndrome (most common in adults): Especially membranous nephropathy (highest risk)
  • Malignancy (renal cell carcinoma with IVC extension)
  • Trauma, surgery
  • Severe dehydration (neonates)
  • Hypercoagulable states (factor V Leiden, antiphospholipid syndrome)
  • Oral contraceptives, pregnancy

Nephrotic Syndrome & Thrombosis:

  • Loss of antithrombin III in urine
  • Increased hepatic synthesis of procoagulant factors
  • Membranous nephropathy has highest thrombosis risk (25-35%)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Labs:

  • Urinalysis: Hematuria, proteinuria
  • BMP: Acute rise in creatinine (especially bilateral RVT)
  • LDH: Elevated in acute thrombosis
  • D-dimer: Elevated (non-specific)

Imaging:

  • CT venography: Test of choice; filling defect in renal vein, enlarged kidney
  • Doppler ultrasound: Absent or reversed diastolic flow; less sensitive than CT
  • MR venography: Alternative if CT contrast contraindicated

Evaluate for Underlying Cause:

  • 24-hour urine protein if not already known
  • Hypercoagulability workup (if not nephrotic)
  • Consider renal malignancy (CT with contrast)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Anticoagulation (Mainstay of Treatment):

  • Acute: Heparin (UFH or LMWH) initially
  • Transition: Warfarin (target INR 2-3) or DOAC
  • Duration: Minimum 6 months; longer if underlying risk persists (e.g., ongoing nephrotic syndrome)

Thrombolysis/Thrombectomy (Rare Indications):

  • Acute bilateral RVT with severe AKI
  • Extension into IVC
  • Failure of anticoagulation

Treat Underlying Condition:

  • Immunosuppression for nephrotic syndrome (steroids, CNI, rituximab depending on etiology)
  • Surgical resection for renal cell carcinoma

Prophylaxis in Nephrotic Syndrome:

  • Consider prophylactic anticoagulation in membranous nephropathy with albumin <2.5 g/dL
  • Risk-benefit analysis required (bleeding vs thrombosis risk)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Membranous = highest risk: Up to 35% develop VTE. Consider prophylactic anticoagulation if albumin <2.5
  • Often asymptomatic: Many cases discovered incidentally or when PE occurs
  • Think RVT: Nephrotic syndrome + flank pain or unexplained AKI worsening
  • Bilateral = AKI: Unilateral usually compensated; bilateral causes acute kidney injury
  • Anticoagulation duration: Continue as long as nephrotic state persists
  • Antithrombin III loss: Heparin may be less effective in severe nephrotic syndrome (AT-III depleted)

315. ATHEROEMBOLIC RENAL DISEASE

Cholesterol Crystal Embolization â€¢ Post-Procedural AKI
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Scenario: Elderly patient with atherosclerosis develops AKI days to weeks after arterial catheterization, vascular surgery, or anticoagulation initiation

Renal Manifestations:

  • Subacute AKI: Progressive over weeks (contrast nephropathy improves; atheroemboli worsen)
  • May be acute or chronic/stuttering course
  • Proteinuria (usually subnephrotic)
  • Hypertension (new or worsening)

Extra-Renal Manifestations:

  • Skin: Livedo reticularis, blue toe syndrome, digital gangrene, ulceration
  • GI: Abdominal pain, GI bleeding, pancreatitis
  • CNS: Stroke, TIA, confusion (if cerebral emboli)
  • Retinal: Hollenhorst plaques (cholesterol crystals in retinal arteries)

Triggers:

  • Arterial catheterization (cardiac cath, angiography)
  • Vascular surgery
  • Anticoagulation initiation (destabilizes plaque)
  • Thrombolytic therapy
  • Spontaneous (rare)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Labs:

  • Eosinophilia: Present in 60-80% (key clue!)
  • Eosinophiluria: May be present
  • Hypocomplementemia: Low C3, C4 (transient)
  • Elevated ESR/CRP
  • Progressive rise in creatinine over days to weeks

Tissue Diagnosis (Gold Standard):

  • Skin biopsy: If livedo or skin lesions present (least invasive)
  • Renal biopsy: Needle-shaped cholesterol clefts in arterioles (pathognomonic)
  • Biopsy shows empty clefts (cholesterol dissolved during processing)

Clinical Diagnosis Often Made Without Biopsy:

  • Typical clinical setting (recent procedure)
  • Characteristic skin findings
  • Eosinophilia + progressive AKI

Differentiate from Contrast Nephropathy:

  • Contrast: Peaks 2-3 days, improves by 7-10 days
  • Atheroemboli: Progressive worsening over weeks, systemic signs
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

No Specific Treatment â€” Supportive Care:

  • Supportive renal care; dialysis if needed
  • Blood pressure control
  • Wound care for skin lesions

Controversial Interventions:

  • Statins: May stabilize plaque, possibly beneficial
  • Anticoagulation: Controversial â€” may trigger more emboli, but needed if other indication (AF, mechanical valve)
  • Steroids: Anecdotal benefit, not proven

Prevention:

  • Minimize arterial manipulation in high-risk patients
  • Radial (vs femoral) access when possible
  • Statin therapy before procedures

Prognosis:

  • Poor: 1-year mortality 60-80% in older series
  • ~30-40% require dialysis
  • Spontaneous improvement can occur in some cases
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Blue toes, livedo, eosinophilia: Classic triad after arterial procedure = atheroemboli
  • Timing distinguishes: Contrast nephropathy improves by day 7-10; atheroemboli worsen progressively
  • Eosinophilia is key: Present in 60-80%; helps differentiate from other causes of AKI
  • Hollenhorst plaques: Fundoscopy may show cholesterol crystals in retinal arteries
  • Anticoagulation paradox: Can actually trigger atheroemboli by destabilizing plaque
  • Poor prognosis: Significant mortality â€” prevention is key

316. CATATONIA

Psychomotor Syndrome â€¢ Medical Emergency
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Core Features (DSM-5 â€” â‰¥3 required):

  • Stupor: No psychomotor activity, not relating to environment
  • Catalepsy: Passive induction and maintenance of postures
  • Waxy flexibility: Slight resistance to positioning by examiner
  • Mutism: No or minimal verbal response
  • Negativism: Opposition or no response to instructions
  • Posturing: Spontaneous maintenance of posture against gravity
  • Mannerisms: Odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions
  • Stereotypy: Repetitive, non-goal-directed movements
  • Agitation: Not influenced by external stimuli
  • Grimacing
  • Echolalia: Mimicking another's speech
  • Echopraxia: Mimicking another's movements

Subtypes:

  • Retarded (hypokinetic): Stupor, mutism, immobility â€” most common
  • Excited (hyperkinetic): Agitation, stereotypies, impulsivity â€” can be dangerous
  • Malignant catatonia: Fever, autonomic instability, rigidity â€” medical emergency

Underlying Causes:

  • Psychiatric: Mood disorders (most common), schizophrenia, autism
  • Medical: Encephalitis (anti-NMDAR), seizures, metabolic (hepatic, uremic), drugs/toxins
  • Medication-induced: Neuroleptics (NMS overlap), withdrawal (benzodiazepines)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Bush-Francis Catatonia Rating Scale (BFCRS):

  • Screening: 14 items (presence/absence)
  • Score â‰¥2 = likely catatonia
  • Full scale rates severity (23 items)

Lorazepam Challenge Test:

  • Procedure: Lorazepam 1-2 mg IV
  • Positive response: Marked improvement within 5-10 minutes
  • Diagnostic and therapeutic: Response supports catatonia diagnosis

Medical Workup (Rule Out Organic Causes):

  • CBC, CMP, LFTs, TFTs, ammonia
  • Urine drug screen
  • Lumbar puncture (encephalitis, anti-NMDAR)
  • MRI brain, EEG (nonconvulsive status epilepticus)
  • CPK (elevated in malignant catatonia)

Differentiate Catatonia vs NMS:

  • Both have rigidity, fever, autonomic instability
  • NMS: Recent neuroleptic exposure, lead-pipe rigidity
  • Catatonia: May have waxy flexibility, responds to benzodiazepines
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

1. Benzodiazepines (First-Line):

  • Lorazepam: 1-2 mg IV/IM/PO q4-8h, titrate up to 8-24 mg/day
  • Response often rapid (within hours)
  • ~70% respond to benzodiazepines
  • Continue for days to weeks, then taper slowly

2. ECT (Electroconvulsive Therapy):

  • Indications: Benzodiazepine-resistant, malignant catatonia, severe/life-threatening
  • Highly effective (>80% response)
  • Bilateral electrode placement, daily treatments initially
  • Often needed urgently â€” don't delay if not responding to benzos

3. Supportive Care:

  • DVT prophylaxis (immobility risk)
  • Nutrition: NG tube or TPN if prolonged mutism/refusal
  • Monitor for aspiration, pressure ulcers
  • Hydration, temperature management

4. Stop Offending Agents:

  • Discontinue antipsychotics if NMS suspected
  • Hold neuroleptics until catatonia resolves

5. Treat Underlying Cause:

  • Immunotherapy for anti-NMDAR encephalitis
  • Mood stabilizers/antidepressants once catatonia resolves
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Lorazepam challenge: Rapid improvement with 1-2 mg IV lorazepam is diagnostic AND therapeutic
  • Mood disorders > schizophrenia: Catatonia is more often from depression/bipolar than schizophrenia
  • Avoid antipsychotics initially: Can worsen catatonia or precipitate NMS
  • Malignant catatonia = emergency: Fever + rigidity + autonomic instability â†’ needs urgent ECT if not responding to benzos
  • Don't miss anti-NMDAR: Young woman with psychiatric symptoms â†’ check for ovarian teratoma, send antibodies
  • ECT works: Highly effective, even in treatment-resistant cases. Don't delay if benzos fail

317. MALIGNANT HYPERTHERMIA

Anesthetic Emergency â€¢ Hypermetabolic Crisis
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Setting: Occurs during or shortly after general anesthesia with triggering agents

Triggering Agents:

  • Volatile anesthetics: Sevoflurane, isoflurane, desflurane, halothane
  • Succinylcholine: Depolarizing neuromuscular blocker

Safe Agents: Propofol, opioids, benzodiazepines, nitrous oxide, non-depolarizing NMBs

Clinical Features (in Order of Appearance):

  • Early:
    • Masseter muscle rigidity (especially after succinylcholine) â€” may be first sign
    • Unexplained tachycardia
    • Rising ETCOâ‚‚ (earliest and most sensitive sign)
    • Tachypnea (in spontaneously breathing patients)
  • Progressive:
    • Hyperthermia (may rise 1-2Â°C every 5 minutes)
    • Generalized muscle rigidity
    • Mottled skin, diaphoresis
  • Late:
    • Rhabdomyolysis (massively elevated CPK)
    • Hyperkalemia â†’ arrhythmias
    • DIC, myoglobinuria, renal failure
    • Cardiac arrest

Genetics: Autosomal dominant; RYR1 gene mutations (ryanodine receptor) most common

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical Diagnosis (During Crisis): Recognize pattern â€” rising ETCOâ‚‚, tachycardia, rigidity, hyperthermia in OR setting

Labs (During Crisis):

  • ABG: Respiratory AND metabolic acidosis, hypercarbia
  • Potassium: Hyperkalemia (life-threatening)
  • CPK: Massively elevated (>10,000 to >100,000)
  • Myoglobin: Elevated (myoglobinuria â†’ AKI)
  • Lactate: Elevated
  • Coagulation studies: May show DIC

Definitive Diagnosis (Post-Crisis Susceptibility Testing):

  • Caffeine-halothane contracture test (CHCT): Gold standard; muscle biopsy required
  • Genetic testing: RYR1 mutation testing; if positive, confirms susceptibility
  • Test patient AND family members
TREATMENT PROTOCOL (EMERGENCY)

1. STOP TRIGGERING AGENTS IMMEDIATELY:

  • Discontinue volatile anesthetics and succinylcholine
  • Hyperventilate with 100% Oâ‚‚ at high flows (â‰¥10 L/min)
  • Do NOT delay surgery termination if possible

2. DANTROLENE (CRITICAL â€” GIVE IMMEDIATELY):

  • Dose: 2.5 mg/kg IV bolus
  • Repeat every 5 minutes until symptoms resolve (up to 10 mg/kg or more)
  • Continue 1 mg/kg q4-6h for 24-48 hours (recrudescence risk)
  • Dantrolene is the specific antidote â€” mechanism: blocks calcium release from sarcoplasmic reticulum

3. Treat Hyperkalemia:

  • Calcium chloride or gluconate (cardiac stabilization)
  • Insulin + glucose
  • Sodium bicarbonate
  • Avoid calcium channel blockers (interaction with dantrolene â†’ cardiovascular collapse)

4. Active Cooling:

  • Cold IV saline
  • Ice packs to axillae, groin
  • Cooling blankets
  • Target: <38.5Â°C

5. Treat Arrhythmias:

  • Standard ACLS protocols
  • Avoid calcium channel blockers

6. Prevent Renal Failure:

  • Aggressive IV fluids
  • Maintain UOP >2 mL/kg/hr (force diuresis)
  • Consider mannitol or sodium bicarbonate for myoglobinuria

7. Monitor: ICU admission, serial CPK, K, renal function, coags

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Rising ETCOâ‚‚ is earliest sign: Unexplained hypercarbia during anesthesia = think MH
  • Dantrolene saves lives: Mortality dropped from 80% to <5% with dantrolene. Give early, give enough
  • Avoid CCBs: Calcium channel blockers + dantrolene = cardiovascular collapse
  • Fever may be late: Don't wait for fever â€” other signs appear first
  • Masseter rigidity: Especially after succinylcholine, may be early warning sign
  • Family screening: Autosomal dominant â€” test and warn family members
  • MH hotline: 1-800-644-9737 (MHAUS) â€” 24/7 expert consultation

318. HEPATORENAL SYNDROME

Functional Renal Failure in Cirrhosis â€¢ Type 1 vs Type 2
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Functional renal failure in advanced cirrhosis due to splanchnic vasodilation and renal vasoconstriction

HRS-AKI (formerly Type 1):

  • Rapid decline in kidney function (doubling of creatinine to â‰¥2.5 mg/dL in <2 weeks)
  • Often precipitated by infection (SBP), GI bleeding, large volume paracentesis without albumin
  • High mortality without treatment (median survival ~2 weeks)

HRS-NAKI (formerly Type 2):

  • Gradual, steady decline in renal function
  • Associated with refractory ascites
  • Better short-term prognosis than HRS-AKI

Precipitants: SBP (most common), GI bleeding, aggressive diuresis, large volume paracentesis without albumin replacement, nephrotoxins

DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA (ICA-AKI 2015)

Required Criteria:

  • Cirrhosis with ascites
  • Diagnosis of AKI per ICA criteria (sCr increase â‰¥0.3 mg/dL within 48h OR â‰¥50% from baseline)
  • No improvement after 2 days of diuretic withdrawal AND albumin challenge (1 g/kg/day, max 100g/day)
  • Absence of shock
  • No current or recent nephrotoxic drugs
  • No parenchymal kidney disease (proteinuria <500 mg/day, no hematuria, normal renal ultrasound)

Key Point: HRS is a diagnosis of EXCLUSION â€” must rule out other causes first

Urine Studies:

  • Urine sodium typically <10 mEq/L (avid sodium retention)
  • FENa <1% (prerenal pattern)
  • Bland sediment (no casts, minimal protein)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

1. General Measures:

  • Stop diuretics, nephrotoxins
  • Volume expansion with albumin 1 g/kg (max 100g) Ã— 2 days
  • Treat precipitating factors (antibiotics for SBP)

2. Vasoconstrictor Therapy + Albumin:

  • Terlipressin + Albumin: First-line where available
    • Terlipressin 0.5-1 mg IV q4-6h, titrate to max 2 mg q4h
    • FDA-approved 2022 in US
  • Norepinephrine + Albumin: ICU setting, equally effective
    • Start 0.5 mcg/kg/min, titrate to increase MAP by 10 mmHg
  • Midodrine + Octreotide + Albumin: Non-ICU alternative (less effective)
    • Midodrine 7.5-12.5 mg PO TID
    • Octreotide 100-200 mcg SQ TID
    • Albumin 25-50 g/day

3. Treatment Goals:

  • Complete response: sCr <1.5 mg/dL
  • Partial response: sCr decrease â‰¥50%
  • Continue treatment until response or max 14 days

4. TIPS: Consider for HRS-NAKI with refractory ascites; contraindicated in HRS-AKI with high MELD

5. Liver Transplantation: Definitive treatment; evaluate all HRS patients for transplant candidacy

6. Renal Replacement Therapy: Bridge to transplant only; not beneficial without transplant option

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Albumin challenge first: Must give albumin 1 g/kg Ã— 2 days before diagnosing HRS
  • SBP is #1 precipitant: Always rule out infection in cirrhotic with AKI
  • Terlipressin is here: FDA approved 2022 â€” first-line therapy with albumin
  • FENa is low: Despite being "renal failure," kidneys are working â€” just underperfused
  • Transplant is cure: HRS often reverses post-liver transplant
  • Dialysis without transplant: Generally futile â€” doesn't improve survival

319. DRUG-INDUCED LIVER INJURY (DILI)

Hepatotoxicity â€¢ R-Ratio Classification
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Presentation: Asymptomatic LFT elevation to fulminant hepatic failure

Symptoms (when present): Fatigue, nausea, RUQ pain, jaundice, pruritus

Patterns by R-Ratio:

  • R = (ALT/ULN) Ã· (ALP/ULN)
  • Hepatocellular (R â‰¥5): ALT predominant; acetaminophen, isoniazid, statins
  • Cholestatic (R â‰¤2): ALP predominant; amoxicillin-clavulanate, anabolic steroids
  • Mixed (R 2-5): Both elevated; phenytoin, sulfonamides

High-Risk Medications:

  • Antibiotics: Amoxicillin-clavulanate (#1 cause), isoniazid, fluoroquinolones, nitrofurantoin
  • NSAIDs: Diclofenac especially
  • Anticonvulsants: Phenytoin, carbamazepine, valproate
  • Statins: Usually mild, rarely severe
  • Acetaminophen: Dose-dependent, most common cause of ALF
  • Herbal/supplements: Green tea extract, kava, anabolic steroids
  • Immunotherapy: Checkpoint inhibitors (ipilimumab, nivolumab)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Key Principle: DILI is a diagnosis of EXCLUSION

Rule Out Other Causes:

  • Viral hepatitis: HAV IgM, HBsAg, HBV DNA, HCV Ab/RNA, HEV (if appropriate)
  • Autoimmune hepatitis: ANA, ASMA, IgG levels
  • Biliary obstruction: RUQ ultrasound, MRCP if needed
  • Wilson disease: Ceruloplasmin (if <40 years)
  • Ischemic hepatitis: Clinical context, rapid rise/fall pattern

Causality Assessment:

  • RUCAM Score: Roussel Uclaf Causality Assessment Method
  • Considers: Timing, course, risk factors, concomitant drugs, exclusion of other causes, rechallenge
  • Score >8: Highly probable; 6-8: Probable; 3-5: Possible

Hy's Law (Poor Prognosis):

  • Hepatocellular injury (ALT >3Ã— ULN) PLUS
  • Bilirubin >2Ã— ULN WITHOUT
  • Biliary obstruction
  • Indicates ~10% risk of fatal/transplant-requiring outcome
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

1. Stop Offending Agent: Most important intervention

2. Specific Antidotes:

  • Acetaminophen: N-acetylcysteine (NAC)
  • Valproate: L-carnitine
  • Amanita mushroom: Silibinin, NAC, penicillin G

3. NAC for Non-Acetaminophen DILI:

  • Consider IV NAC for early acute liver failure from any DILI
  • May improve transplant-free survival in early ALF

4. Corticosteroids:

  • Consider for immune-mediated DILI (checkpoint inhibitors)
  • DRESS syndrome with liver involvement
  • Autoimmune-like DILI

5. Ursodeoxycholic Acid: May help cholestatic DILI (limited evidence)

6. Liver Transplant Evaluation: If progressing to acute liver failure

Prognosis: Most DILI resolves with drug withdrawal; 10% progress to chronic liver disease

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • R-ratio guides pattern: Calculate (ALT/ULN)Ã·(ALP/ULN) to classify hepatocellular vs cholestatic
  • Amox-clav is #1: Most common cause of idiosyncratic DILI (not acetaminophen, which is dose-dependent)
  • Hy's Law = danger: Hepatocellular + jaundice without obstruction = ~10% fatal/transplant
  • Ask about supplements: Herbal products cause significant DILI â€” patients don't always report them
  • Latency varies: Days (acetaminophen) to months (amox-clav, isoniazid)
  • Never rechallenge: If severe DILI, do not re-expose to the drug

320. AUTOIMMUNE HEPATITIS

Immune-Mediated Liver Inflammation â€¢ Steroid-Responsive
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Spectrum: Asymptomatic LFT elevation â†’ acute hepatitis â†’ fulminant liver failure â†’ chronic cirrhosis

Symptoms: Fatigue, malaise, jaundice, RUQ discomfort, arthralgias

Demographics:

  • Bimodal: Young women (15-25) and perimenopausal (45-60)
  • Female predominance (3-4:1)
  • Associated with other autoimmune diseases (thyroiditis, celiac, UC, RA)

Types:

  • Type 1 (Classic): ANA and/or ASMA positive; most common
  • Type 2: Anti-LKM1 or anti-LC1 positive; more common in children

Overlap Syndromes: AIH-PBC overlap, AIH-PSC overlap

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Simplified Diagnostic Criteria (â‰¥6 points = probable, â‰¥7 = definite):

  • ANA or ASMA â‰¥1:40: 1 point
  • ANA or ASMA â‰¥1:80: 2 points
  • Anti-LKM1 â‰¥1:40: 2 points
  • Anti-SLA positive: 2 points
  • IgG >ULN: 1 point
  • IgG >1.1Ã— ULN: 2 points
  • Liver histology compatible: 1 point
  • Liver histology typical: 2 points
  • Absence of viral hepatitis: 2 points

Laboratory Findings:

  • Elevated ALT/AST (hepatocellular pattern)
  • Elevated IgG (polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia)
  • Positive autoantibodies (ANA, ASMA, anti-LKM1, anti-SLA)

Liver Biopsy:

  • Typical: Interface hepatitis, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, hepatocyte rosettes
  • Helps confirm diagnosis, assess severity, rule out other conditions

Exclude: Viral hepatitis, DILI, Wilson disease, alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Indications for Treatment:

  • AST/ALT â‰¥10Ã— ULN
  • AST/ALT â‰¥5Ã— ULN with IgG â‰¥2Ã— ULN
  • Bridging necrosis or multilobular necrosis on biopsy
  • Symptoms attributable to AIH

Induction Therapy:

  • Prednisone monotherapy: 40-60 mg/day initially, taper over weeks
  • Prednisone + Azathioprine (preferred):
    • Prednisone 30 mg/day + azathioprine 50 mg/day (or 1-2 mg/kg)
    • Allows lower steroid doses
  • Budesonide + azathioprine: Alternative for non-cirrhotic patients (fewer systemic steroid effects)

Maintenance Therapy:

  • Azathioprine 1-2 mg/kg/day as monotherapy after remission
  • Continue minimum 2-3 years after normalization
  • Many patients require lifelong therapy

Treatment Goals:

  • Biochemical remission: Normal ALT, AST, IgG
  • Histologic remission: Resolution of inflammation on biopsy

Refractory Disease: Mycophenolate mofetil, tacrolimus, rituximab

Liver Transplant: For decompensated cirrhosis or fulminant AIH unresponsive to steroids

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
