  • Steroid-responsive: AIH typically responds dramatically to steroids â€” lack of response should prompt reconsideration
  • Check IgG: Elevated IgG is key; often >2Ã— ULN
  • ASMA is smooth muscle: Anti-smooth muscle antibody, not "asthma"
  • Azathioprine is steroid-sparing: Combination allows lower steroid doses and fewer side effects
  • Relapse is common: 50-90% relapse after stopping therapy; many need lifelong treatment
  • Can present as ALF: Acute severe AIH may require urgent transplant evaluation

321. BUDD-CHIARI SYNDROME

Hepatic Vein Outflow Obstruction
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Triad: Abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, ascites

Presentations:

  • Acute: Rapid onset RUQ pain, hepatomegaly, ascites, liver failure
  • Subacute: Gradual onset over weeks; most common presentation
  • Chronic: Complications of cirrhosis (variceal bleeding, encephalopathy)
  • Fulminant: Acute liver failure with encephalopathy (rare)

Etiology (Hypercoagulable States):

  • Myeloproliferative neoplasms: JAK2+ polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia (most common!)
  • Inherited thrombophilias: Factor V Leiden, prothrombin mutation, protein C/S deficiency
  • Antiphospholipid syndrome
  • PNH (paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria)
  • Oral contraceptives, pregnancy
  • Malignancy: HCC, renal cell carcinoma with IVC invasion
  • Infections: Liver abscess, aspergillosis

Key Point: Always look for underlying cause â€” often MPN even without elevated counts

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Doppler Ultrasound (First-Line):

  • Absent or reversed flow in hepatic veins
  • Intrahepatic collaterals ("spider web" pattern)
  • Caudate lobe hypertrophy (drains directly to IVC)
  • Sensitivity ~85%

CT/MRI with Venography:

  • Confirms diagnosis, shows extent of thrombosis
  • "Flip-flop" enhancement pattern on CT
  • IVC involvement

Venography: Gold standard but invasive; used if imaging equivocal or for intervention

Liver Biopsy: Centrilobular congestion, necrosis; may help assess chronicity

Thrombophilia Workup:

  • JAK2 V617F mutation: Test in ALL patients (MPN is leading cause)
  • Factor V Leiden, prothrombin G20210A
  • Antithrombin, protein C/S (after acute phase)
  • Antiphospholipid antibodies
  • PNH flow cytometry
  • Bone marrow biopsy if MPN suspected
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Stepwise Approach:

1. Anticoagulation (All Patients):

  • LMWH â†’ warfarin (INR 2-3) or DOAC
  • Lifelong if underlying thrombophilia persists

2. Treat Underlying Cause:

  • Cytoreduction for MPN (hydroxyurea, ruxolitinib)
  • Eculizumab for PNH

3. Medical Management of Complications:

  • Diuretics for ascites
  • Beta-blockers for varices

4. Angioplasty/Stenting:

  • For short-segment hepatic vein or IVC stenosis/web
  • Consider thrombolysis if acute

5. TIPS:

  • For patients failing medical therapy
  • Decompresses portal system by creating intrahepatic shunt
  • 70-80% long-term success

6. Liver Transplantation:

  • Fulminant liver failure
  • Failed TIPS
  • Decompensated cirrhosis
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Check JAK2 in everyone: MPN is the most common cause â€” even with normal CBC
  • Caudate lobe hypertrophy: Classic finding â€” caudate drains directly to IVC, so it's spared
  • Stepwise treatment: Anticoagulation â†’ intervention â†’ TIPS â†’ transplant
  • Young woman with BCS: Think OCPs + underlying thrombophilia
  • Acute = thrombolysis: May try catheter-directed thrombolysis if caught early
  • Lifelong anticoagulation: Most patients need it indefinitely

322. HEPATOPULMONARY SYNDROME

Intrapulmonary Shunting in Liver Disease â€¢ Platypnea-Orthodeoxia
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Hypoxemia due to intrapulmonary vascular dilations (IPVDs) in the setting of liver disease

Classic Symptoms:

  • Dyspnea: Progressive, often insidious onset
  • Platypnea: Dyspnea worsening when upright (opposite of orthopnea!)
  • Orthodeoxia: Oxygen desaturation when upright (improves supine)

Physical Exam:

  • Spider angiomata, clubbing, cyanosis
  • Signs of chronic liver disease and portal hypertension

Pathophysiology:

  • Intrapulmonary vascular dilations (IPVDs) at capillary and precapillary level
  • Blood flows through dilated vessels without adequate gas exchange
  • Ventilation-perfusion mismatch and true shunting
  • Worse upright because dilations are basal (gravity-dependent)

Severity Classification:

  • Mild: PaOâ‚‚ â‰¥80 mmHg
  • Moderate: PaOâ‚‚ 60-79 mmHg
  • Severe: PaOâ‚‚ 50-59 mmHg
  • Very severe: PaOâ‚‚ <50 mmHg
DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA

Triad Required:

  • Liver disease (usually with portal hypertension)
  • Hypoxemia: Elevated A-a gradient (â‰¥15 mmHg, or â‰¥20 if age >64) OR PaOâ‚‚ <80 mmHg on room air
  • Evidence of intrapulmonary vascular dilations

Contrast-Enhanced Echocardiography (Diagnostic Test of Choice):

  • Agitated saline ("bubble study")
  • Positive: Bubbles appear in left atrium 3-6 cardiac cycles after appearing in right atrium
  • Intracardiac shunt: Bubbles appear in <3 cycles (PFO, ASD)
  • Sensitivity >95%

99mTc-MAA Lung Perfusion Scan:

  • Quantifies shunt fraction
  • Brain uptake >6% indicates significant shunting

Additional Workup:

  • ABG: Hypoxemia, elevated A-a gradient
  • PFTs: Often normal or mildly reduced DLCO
  • CXR/CT: Usually normal; rule out other causes
TREATMENT

No Effective Medical Therapy:

  • No medications proven to improve HPS
  • Pentoxifylline, garlic, mycophenolate â€” studied but not beneficial

Supportive Care:

  • Supplemental oxygen for hypoxemia
  • Avoid hepatotoxins, optimize liver function

Liver Transplantation (Definitive Treatment):

  • Only treatment that reverses HPS
  • HPS is an indication for MELD exception points
  • PaOâ‚‚ <60 mmHg qualifies for exception
  • Resolution of HPS occurs in 85%+ post-transplant (may take 6-12 months)

Contraindication: PaOâ‚‚ <50 mmHg associated with higher post-transplant mortality â€” controversial cutoff

TIPS: Generally NOT effective for HPS (unlike portopulmonary hypertension)

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Platypnea-orthodeoxia: Pathognomonic â€” worse oxygenation when upright (opposite of heart failure!)
  • Bubble echo is diagnostic: Late appearance (3-6 cycles) of bubbles in left heart confirms IPVDs
  • HPS vs portopulmonary: HPS = vasodilation/shunting (low PVR); Portopulmonary = vasoconstriction (high PVR)
  • Transplant cures: HPS is a transplant indication; most resolve post-transplant
  • MELD exception: PaOâ‚‚ <60 qualifies for exception points
  • Spider angiomata = systemic vasodilation: Same process causes both cutaneous and pulmonary dilations

323. CONTRAST-INDUCED NEPHROPATHY (CIN)

Contrast-Associated AKI â€¢ Prevention is Key
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: AKI occurring within 48-72 hours of contrast exposure

  • Increase in serum creatinine â‰¥0.5 mg/dL OR â‰¥25% from baseline
  • Peak creatinine typically at 3-5 days
  • Usually recovers within 7-14 days

Risk Factors:

  • Pre-existing CKD (eGFR <60): Most important risk factor
  • Diabetes mellitus (especially with CKD)
  • Heart failure, hypotension
  • Volume depletion
  • Age >75
  • High contrast volume (>100-150 mL or >3Ã— eGFR mL)
  • Multiple contrast exposures within 72 hours
  • Intra-arterial > IV contrast
  • High-osmolar > low-osmolar > iso-osmolar contrast

Clinical Course:

  • Usually non-oliguric
  • Creatinine peaks day 3-5, returns to baseline by day 7-14
  • Dialysis rarely needed (~1%)
  • May accelerate progression of underlying CKD
RISK ASSESSMENT

Mehran Risk Score (for PCI):

  • Hypotension: 5 points
  • IABP: 5 points
  • CHF: 5 points
  • Age >75: 4 points
  • Anemia: 3 points
  • Diabetes: 3 points
  • Contrast volume (1 point per 100 mL)
  • eGFR 40-60: 2 points; 20-40: 4 points; <20: 6 points

Risk Categories:

  • Low risk (â‰¤5): CIN risk 7.5%
  • Moderate (6-10): CIN risk 14%
  • High (11-15): CIN risk 26%
  • Very high (â‰¥16): CIN risk 57%
PREVENTION PROTOCOL

1. Volume Expansion (Most Important):

  • Isotonic saline: 1-1.5 mL/kg/hr for 6-12 hours before AND after contrast
  • Alternative: Sodium bicarbonate 154 mEq/L at 3 mL/kg/hr Ã— 1 hour before, then 1 mL/kg/hr Ã— 6 hours after
  • IV hydration superior to oral

2. Minimize Contrast Volume:

  • Use lowest effective dose
  • Target: contrast volume (mL) < 3Ã— eGFR
  • Use iso-osmolar or low-osmolar contrast agents

3. Hold Nephrotoxins:

  • NSAIDs, aminoglycosides
  • Hold metformin (risk of lactic acidosis if AKI develops â€” restart after 48h if creatinine stable)

4. Interventions NOT Proven Beneficial:

  • N-acetylcysteine (NAC): No longer recommended (PRESERVE trial negative)
  • Prophylactic dialysis: Not beneficial
  • Fenoldopam, theophylline: Not effective

5. Special Considerations:

  • Emergency procedures: Don't delay for hydration if life-threatening indication
  • CKD + urgent CT: Benefit of diagnosis often outweighs CIN risk
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Hydration is prevention: IV saline before and after contrast is the most effective strategy
  • NAC doesn't work: PRESERVE trial showed no benefit â€” stop ordering it
  • Don't delay necessary imaging: Risk of missed diagnosis often exceeds CIN risk
  • Peaks day 3-5: If creatinine still rising at day 7, consider other causes
  • Metformin is a passenger: Hold it because of lactic acidosis risk IF CIN develops, not because it causes CIN
  • CIN vs atheroemboli: CIN improves by day 7-14; atheroemboli progressively worsens

324. ACUTE INTERSTITIAL NEPHRITIS (AIN)

Drug-Induced Tubulointerstitial Disease â€¢ Eosinophiluria
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Triad (Present in <10%): Fever, rash, eosinophilia

More Common: AKI without classic triad features

Symptoms:

  • Often asymptomatic except for rising creatinine
  • Flank pain, arthralgias, low-grade fever
  • Maculopapular rash (especially with beta-lactams)

Causes:

  • Drugs (70-75%):
    • Antibiotics: Beta-lactams, fluoroquinolones, sulfonamides, rifampin
    • NSAIDs: Can occur after months of use; often without systemic symptoms
    • PPIs: Increasingly recognized; latency can be months
    • Checkpoint inhibitors: Ipilimumab, nivolumab, pembrolizumab
    • Others: Allopurinol, phenytoin, diuretics
  • Infections (15%): Legionella, Leptospira, CMV, EBV, Streptococcus
  • Autoimmune: Sarcoidosis, SjÃ¶gren's, TINU syndrome, SLE
  • Idiopathic

Latency Period:

  • Antibiotics: Days to weeks
  • NSAIDs: Weeks to months
  • PPIs: Weeks to months (median 10-11 weeks)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Urinalysis:

  • WBC casts (hallmark)
  • Sterile pyuria
  • Hematuria (usually microscopic)
  • Mild-moderate proteinuria (<1 g/day, unless NSAID-associated)

Eosinophiluria:

  • Urine eosinophils by Hansel stain (Wright stain less sensitive)
  • Sensitivity only 40-60% â€” ABSENCE does NOT rule out AIN
  • Not specific (also seen in UTI, prostatitis, GN, atheroemboli)

Labs:

  • Peripheral eosinophilia (present in ~35%)
  • Elevated IgE (sometimes)
  • FENa may be elevated (tubular dysfunction)

Kidney Biopsy (Gold Standard):

  • Interstitial edema and inflammatory infiltrate
  • Lymphocytes, plasma cells, eosinophils
  • Tubulitis (inflammatory cells invading tubular epithelium)
  • Consider if diagnosis uncertain or no improvement with drug withdrawal

Gallium-67 Scan: Increased renal uptake; rarely used now

TREATMENT PROTOCOL

1. Remove Offending Agent:

  • Most important intervention
  • Review ALL medications including OTC and supplements

2. Supportive Care:

  • Avoid nephrotoxins
  • Monitor creatinine for improvement

3. Corticosteroids (Controversial):

  • Consider if: No improvement 3-7 days after drug withdrawal, severe AKI, biopsy-proven AIN
  • Regimen: Prednisone 1 mg/kg/day (max 60 mg) Ã— 2-4 weeks, then taper over 4-8 weeks
  • Earlier steroid initiation (<2 weeks) may improve outcomes
  • Benefit less clear with prolonged AKI or chronic changes on biopsy

4. Checkpoint Inhibitor AIN:

  • Higher dose steroids often needed
  • Prednisone 1-2 mg/kg/day
  • May need to discontinue immunotherapy depending on severity

Prognosis:

  • Most recover with drug withdrawal Â± steroids
  • ~40% have incomplete recovery (residual CKD)
  • Poor prognostic factors: Prolonged AKI, interstitial fibrosis on biopsy
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Classic triad is rare: Fever + rash + eosinophilia present in <10% â€” don't rely on it
  • Eosinophiluria is insensitive: Absence does NOT rule out AIN
  • PPIs are underrecognized: Can cause AIN after months of use; increasing reports
  • WBC casts are key: Suggest tubulointerstitial inflammation
  • Early steroids may help: Consider if no improvement within 3-7 days of drug withdrawal
  • NSAID-AIN is different: Often has nephrotic-range proteinuria and lacks systemic symptoms

325. CPPD (Calcium Pyrophosphate Deposition Disease)

Pseudogout â€¢ Chondrocalcinosis
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Clinical Phenotypes:

  • Acute CPP Crystal Arthritis (Pseudogout):
    • Acute monoarticular or oligoarticular arthritis
    • Knee most common (>50%), also wrist, ankle, shoulder
    • Mimics gout or septic arthritis
  • Chronic CPP Crystal Inflammatory Arthritis:
    • Resembles rheumatoid arthritis
    • Symmetric polyarthritis, morning stiffness
  • Osteoarthritis with CPPD:
    • Accelerated OA in atypical joints (wrists, MCPs, shoulders)
  • Asymptomatic Chondrocalcinosis: Incidental radiographic finding

Triggers for Acute Attacks:

  • Surgery, illness, trauma
  • Similar triggers to gout flares

Associated Conditions (Screen if <55 years or polyarticular):

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypophosphatasia
  • Familial/hereditary CPPD
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Synovial Fluid Analysis (Gold Standard):

  • CPP crystals: Rhomboid or rod-shaped
  • Weakly positive birefringence under polarized light (blue when parallel to compensator axis)
  • Inflammatory fluid: WBC 15,000-30,000/Î¼L (can be higher)
  • Always rule out septic arthritis (can coexist!)

Imaging:

  • X-ray â€” Chondrocalcinosis:
    • Linear calcifications in fibrocartilage and hyaline cartilage
    • Best seen: Knee menisci, triangular fibrocartilage of wrist, pubic symphysis
  • Ultrasound: Hyperechoic deposits within cartilage
  • CT: More sensitive for calcifications

Metabolic Workup (if <55 or polyarticular):

  • Calcium, PTH (hyperparathyroidism)
  • Iron studies, ferritin (hemochromatosis)
  • Magnesium
  • Alkaline phosphatase (hypophosphatasia)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Acute Attack:

  • NSAIDs: First-line if no contraindications
  • Colchicine: 1.2 mg then 0.6 mg one hour later (same as gout dosing)
  • Intra-articular corticosteroids: Effective for monoarticular disease
  • Systemic corticosteroids: Prednisone 30-40 mg/day Ã— 5-7 days if NSAIDs/colchicine contraindicated
  • IL-1 inhibitors (anakinra): For refractory cases

Prophylaxis:

  • Low-dose colchicine 0.6 mg daily or BID
  • Low-dose NSAIDs if tolerated

Key Differences from Gout:

  • NO urate-lowering therapy equivalent for CPPD
  • Cannot dissolve existing CPP crystite deposits
  • Focus on treating acute attacks and prophylaxis

Treat Underlying Metabolic Condition:

  • Parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism
  • Phlebotomy for hemochromatosis
  • Magnesium replacement
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Weakly positive birefringence: Blue when parallel (vs gout: strongly negative, yellow when parallel)
  • Knee and wrist: Most common joints (gout favors 1st MTP)
  • No "allopurinol equivalent": Can't dissolve CPP crystals; only treat attacks and prevent recurrence
  • Screen for metabolic causes: Especially if young (<55) or polyarticular â€” check PTH, iron, Mg
  • Chondrocalcinosis â‰  CPPD disease: Many patients with radiographic CC are asymptomatic
  • Can coexist with septic arthritis: Always send fluid for culture; crystals don't rule out infection

326. ANGIOEDEMA

Bradykinin vs Histamine-Mediated â€¢ ACEi-Induced
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Localized, non-pitting edema of deep dermis, subcutaneous tissue, or submucosa

Locations:

  • Face (lips, eyelids, tongue)
  • Oropharynx, larynx (AIRWAY EMERGENCY)
  • Extremities, genitalia
  • GI tract (abdominal pain, nausea â€” can mimic surgical abdomen)

Types:

  • Histamine-Mediated (Mast Cell):
    • Associated with urticaria
    • Pruritic
    • Responds to antihistamines, epinephrine, steroids
    • Causes: Allergic reactions, chronic spontaneous urticaria
  • Bradykinin-Mediated:
    • NO urticaria
    • NOT pruritic (may have burning/tingling)
    • Does NOT respond to antihistamines, epinephrine, steroids
    • Causes: ACEi, hereditary angioedema (HAE)

ACE Inhibitor-Induced Angioedema:

  • 0.1-0.7% of ACEi users
  • Higher risk: African Americans (4-5Ã— higher)
  • Can occur years after starting ACEi
  • Typically affects face, lips, tongue, larynx

Hereditary Angioedema (HAE):

  • C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency or dysfunction
  • Type 1 (85%): Low C1-INH level and function
  • Type 2 (15%): Normal C1-INH level, low function
  • Family history, recurrent attacks since childhood
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical Differentiation:

Feature Histamine-Mediated Bradykinin-Mediated
Urticaria Present Absent
Pruritus Yes No (burning/tingling)
Response to epinephrine Yes No
Response to antihistamines Yes No

Labs for HAE Evaluation:

  • C4: Low during AND between attacks (screening test)
  • C1-INH level: Low in Type 1
  • C1-INH function: Low in Types 1 and 2
  • C1q: Normal in HAE; low in acquired C1-INH deficiency
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Airway Management (Priority):

  • Assess for stridor, voice changes, tongue swelling
  • Early intubation if airway compromise (may be difficult â€” call anesthesia/ENT early)
  • Prepare for surgical airway

Histamine-Mediated Angioedema:

  • Epinephrine 0.3-0.5 mg IM (if severe/anaphylaxis)
  • H1-antihistamines: Diphenhydramine 25-50 mg IV
  • H2-antihistamines: Famotidine 20 mg IV
  • Corticosteroids: Methylprednisolone 125 mg IV

ACEi-Induced Angioedema:

  • Stop ACEi permanently
  • Standard therapy (epinephrine, antihistamines, steroids) â€” often ineffective but still given
  • Icatibant (Firazyr): Bradykinin B2 receptor antagonist, 30 mg SQ
  • C1-INH concentrate: May help (off-label)
  • Fresh frozen plasma: Contains ACE, may help degrade bradykinin (controversial)
  • Do NOT switch to ARB immediately (cross-reactivity ~10%)

Hereditary Angioedema â€” Acute Attack:

  • C1-INH concentrate (Berinert, Cinryze): 20 units/kg IV
  • Icatibant: 30 mg SQ
  • Ecallantide (Kalbitor): Kallikrein inhibitor, 30 mg SQ

HAE â€” Prophylaxis:

  • Lanadelumab (anti-kallikrein antibody)
  • C1-INH concentrate
  • Androgens (danazol) â€” less preferred due to side effects
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • No urticaria = think bradykinin: ACEi or HAE; won't respond to standard allergic treatment
  • ACEi can cause angioedema years later: Don't assume it's not the ACEi because patient has been on it for years
  • Epinephrine won't work for bradykinin: But still give it if uncertain â€” won't harm
  • C4 is the screening test: Low C4 between attacks suggests HAE â€” send C1-INH level and function
  • Icatibant for ACEi angioedema: Bradykinin receptor blocker; works when standard therapy fails
  • Avoid ARBs after ACEi angioedema: ~10% cross-reactivity; find alternative antihypertensive

327. TRALI (Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury)

Non-Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema â€¢ Antibody-Mediated
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Acute lung injury occurring within 6 hours of transfusion, not explained by other ALI risk factors

Symptoms:

  • Acute dyspnea, hypoxemia
  • Fever, chills (common)
  • Hypotension (more common than hypertension)
  • Typically occurs 1-2 hours into or after transfusion

Diagnostic Criteria:

  • Acute onset (within 6 hours of transfusion)
  • Hypoxemia: PaOâ‚‚/FiOâ‚‚ â‰¤300 OR SpOâ‚‚ <90% on room air
  • Bilateral infiltrates on CXR
  • No evidence of left atrial hypertension (PAOP â‰¤18 or no clinical evidence of volume overload)
  • No pre-existing ALI before transfusion

Pathophysiology:

  • Immune TRALI: Donor antibodies (anti-HLA or anti-HNA) react with recipient leukocytes
  • Non-immune TRALI: Bioactive lipids in stored blood products
  • Results in neutrophil activation and pulmonary capillary leak

High-Risk Products:

  • Products with high plasma content: FFP, platelets, whole blood
  • Risk reduced with male-only plasma donors (fewer HLA antibodies)
TREATMENT PROTOCOL

Immediate Actions:

  • Stop transfusion immediately
  • Supportive care with oxygen
  • Mechanical ventilation if needed (lung-protective strategy)

Supportive Care:

  • Oxygen supplementation
  • Intubation/mechanical ventilation for severe hypoxemia
  • Vasopressors for hypotension (not volume â€” avoid fluid overload)

NOT Beneficial:

  • Diuretics (not cardiogenic â€” may worsen hypotension)
  • Steroids (no proven benefit)

Prognosis:

  • Mortality 5-10% (lower than ARDS from other causes)
  • Most improve within 48-96 hours with supportive care
  • Usually no long-term pulmonary sequelae

Reporting:

  • Report to blood bank immediately
  • Donor testing for HLA/HNA antibodies
  • Implicated donor may be deferred from future donations
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Within 6 hours: TRALI occurs during or within 6 hours of transfusion
  • TRALI vs TACO: TRALI = hypotension, non-cardiogenic; TACO = hypertension, volume overload
  • No diuretics: Not cardiogenic edema â€” diuretics may worsen hypotension
  • Usually resolves: Most patients recover within 48-96 hours
  • Report to blood bank: Critical for donor management and future prevention
  • Plasma-rich products: Higher risk with FFP, platelets than PRBCs

328. TACO (Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload)

Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema from Volume Overload
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Acute pulmonary edema due to volume overload from transfusion

Symptoms:

  • Acute dyspnea, orthopnea
  • Hypertension (key differentiator from TRALI)
  • Tachycardia
  • Elevated JVP
  • Typically occurs during or within 6-12 hours of transfusion

Diagnostic Criteria:

  • Acute or worsening respiratory distress within 12 hours of transfusion
  • Evidence of positive fluid balance
  • Elevated BNP/NT-proBNP
  • Evidence of left heart failure (elevated PAOP, response to diuretics)
  • Bilateral infiltrates on CXR

Risk Factors:

  • Pre-existing heart failure
  • Renal insufficiency
  • Age >70
  • Low albumin
  • Rapid transfusion rate
  • Large transfusion volume
  • Positive fluid balance
DIFFERENTIATING TACO vs TRALI
Feature TACO TRALI
Blood pressure Hypertension Hypotension
JVP Elevated Normal/low
BNP Elevated (>1.5Ã— baseline) Normal or mildly elevated
Response to diuretics Yes No
Fever Uncommon Common
Mechanism Volume overload Antibody-mediated
TREATMENT & PREVENTION

Immediate Treatment:

  • Stop or slow transfusion
  • Sit patient upright
  • IV diuretics: Furosemide 20-40 mg IV
  • Supplemental oxygen
  • Non-invasive ventilation if needed

Prevention Strategies:

  • Slower transfusion rate: 1-2 mL/kg/hr in high-risk patients
  • Smaller aliquots: Split units, transfuse over longer time
  • Prophylactic diuretics: Furosemide between units in high-risk patients
  • Restrictive transfusion: Transfuse only when necessary
  • Monitor fluid balance

Prognosis:

  • Usually resolves with diuresis within 12-24 hours
  • Mortality <5% with appropriate treatment
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • TACO is more common than TRALI: Most common cause of transfusion-related death
  • Hypertension = TACO: Key differentiator from TRALI (hypotensive)
  • Diuretics work: Unlike TRALI, TACO responds to diuresis
  • BNP helps differentiate: Elevated in TACO, normal/mildly elevated in TRALI
  • Prevention is key: Slow transfusion, prophylactic diuretics in high-risk patients
  • Can coexist: Some patients have features of both TACO and TRALI

329. ENDEMIC FUNGAL INFECTIONS

Histoplasmosis â€¢ Blastomycosis â€¢ Coccidioidomycosis
GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION

Histoplasmosis (Histoplasma capsulatum):

  • Ohio and Mississippi River valleys
  • Soil contaminated with bird or bat droppings
  • Cave exploration, demolition of old buildings

Blastomycosis (Blastomyces dermatitidis):

  • Great Lakes, Ohio/Mississippi River valleys, Southeast
  • Moist soil, decaying vegetation near waterways

Coccidioidomycosis (Coccidioides immitis/posadasii):

  • Southwestern US (Arizona, California Central Valley), Northern Mexico
  • "Valley fever"
  • Dust storms, construction, earthquakes
CLINICAL PRESENTATIONS

Histoplasmosis:

  • Acute pulmonary: Self-limited flu-like illness; may see hilar lymphadenopathy
  • Chronic cavitary: Upper lobe disease resembling TB; in patients with COPD
  • Progressive disseminated: Immunocompromised (AIDS, TNF inhibitors); hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, adrenal involvement

Blastomycosis:

  • Pulmonary: Pneumonia with mass-like lesions (can mimic malignancy)
  • Skin: Verrucous or ulcerative lesions (papulopustules â†’ crusted nodules)
  • Bone: Osteomyelitis (vertebrae, ribs, long bones)
  • GU: Prostatitis, epididymitis
  • Can occur in immunocompetent hosts

Coccidioidomycosis:

  • Primary pulmonary: "Valley fever" â€” fever, cough, chest pain, arthralgias
  • Pulmonary nodules/cavities: Can be incidental findings
  • Disseminated: Skin, bones, meninges; higher risk in immunocompromised, pregnant women, Filipino/African American descent
  • Meningitis: Most serious complication; chronic basilar meningitis
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Histoplasmosis:

  • Urine/serum Histoplasma antigen: Sensitive for disseminated disease and acute pulmonary
  • Serology: Antibodies (complement fixation, immunodiffusion); less useful in immunocompromised
  • Culture/histopath: Small intracellular yeasts in macrophages

Blastomycosis:

  • Culture: Gold standard but slow (2-4 weeks)
  • Direct visualization: Broad-based budding yeast (8-15 Î¼m)
  • Urine Blastomyces antigen: Cross-reacts with Histoplasma

Coccidioidomycosis:

  • Serology: IgM (early), IgG (complement fixation titers correlate with disease severity)
  • Culture: HAZARDOUS â€” alert lab (biosafety concern)
  • Direct visualization: Spherules with endospores
TREATMENT

Histoplasmosis:

  • Mild-moderate acute: Observation or itraconazole Ã— 6-12 weeks
  • Moderate-severe/disseminated: Amphotericin B (liposomal) Ã— 1-2 weeks â†’ itraconazole Ã— 12 months
  • AIDS patients: Lifelong suppression with itraconazole until immune reconstitution

Blastomycosis:

  • Mild-moderate pulmonary: Itraconazole Ã— 6-12 months
  • Severe/disseminated/CNS: Amphotericin B â†’ itraconazole Ã— 12 months
  • Always treat (higher mortality than other endemic mycoses)

Coccidioidomycosis:

  • Primary pulmonary (mild): Observation in healthy hosts OR fluconazole if symptoms >2 months
  • Severe/disseminated: Fluconazole (high dose) or itraconazole; amphotericin B for severe
  • Meningitis: Fluconazole 400-1200 mg/day LIFELONG (relapse common)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Geography matters: Ask about travel/residence in endemic areas
  • Histoplasma antigen: Best test for disseminated disease; also useful for monitoring treatment
  • Blasto skin lesions: Verrucous/ulcerative â€” can mimic squamous cell carcinoma
  • Cocci meningitis = lifelong azole: Relapse is common; don't stop therapy
  • Broad-based budding: Classic for Blastomycosis (vs narrow-based in other yeasts)
  • Alert lab for Cocci: Highly infectious in culture â€” biosafety hazard

330. PULMONARY HYPERTENSION

WHO Groups 1-5 â€¢ Right Heart Catheterization Required
DEFINITION & CLASSIFICATION

Definition: Mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) >20 mmHg at rest by right heart catheterization

WHO Classification:

  • Group 1 â€” Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH):
    • Idiopathic PAH
    • Heritable (BMPR2 mutations)
    • Drug/toxin-induced (methamphetamines, anorexigens)
    • Associated: CTD (scleroderma), HIV, portal hypertension, CHD
  • Group 2 â€” Left Heart Disease: HFrEF, HFpEF, valvular disease (most common cause!)
  • Group 3 â€” Lung Disease/Hypoxia: COPD, ILD, OSA, high altitude
  • Group 4 â€” Chronic Thromboembolic (CTEPH): Organized thrombi; potentially curable
  • Group 5 â€” Multifactorial: Sarcoidosis, hematologic disorders, metabolic

Hemodynamic Definitions:

  • Pre-capillary PH: mPAP >20, PAWP â‰¤15, PVR â‰¥3 WU (Groups 1, 3, 4, 5)
  • Post-capillary PH: mPAP >20, PAWP >15 (Group 2)
  • Combined: mPAP >20, PAWP >15, PVR â‰¥3 WU
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Symptoms:

  • Dyspnea on exertion (most common, early)
  • Fatigue, weakness
  • Chest pain (RV ischemia)
  • Syncope, near-syncope (ominous â€” suggests severe disease)
  • Peripheral edema, ascites (right heart failure)

Physical Exam:

  • Loud P2, right-sided S4
  • Tricuspid regurgitation murmur
  • JVD, hepatomegaly, peripheral edema
  • Signs of underlying disease (scleroderma, COPD)
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Initial Evaluation:

  • Echocardiogram: Estimates RVSP, RV function, left heart disease
  • PFTs: Assess for lung disease
  • V/Q scan: Rule out CTEPH (more sensitive than CT for chronic PE)
  • CT chest: Parenchymal lung disease, PA enlargement
  • 6-minute walk test: Functional assessment
  • BNP/NT-proBNP: Prognostic

Right Heart Catheterization (Required for Diagnosis):

  • Confirms diagnosis
  • Differentiates pre- vs post-capillary
  • Vasoreactivity testing (Group 1): Response to inhaled NO, epoprostenol, or adenosine
  • Positive vasoreactivity: â†“ mPAP â‰¥10 mmHg to â‰¤40 mmHg with stable/improved CO

Evaluate for Underlying Causes:

  • ANA, Scl-70 (scleroderma)
  • HIV testing
  • LFTs (portal hypertension)
  • Sleep study (OSA)
TREATMENT (GROUP 1 PAH)

General Measures:

  • Diuretics for volume overload
  • Oxygen to maintain SpOâ‚‚ >90%
  • Avoid pregnancy (high mortality)
  • Supervised exercise rehabilitation

Vasoreactivity-Positive Patients:

  • Calcium channel blockers (nifedipine, diltiazem, amlodipine)
  • Only ~10% of PAH patients are responders

PAH-Specific Therapies:

  • Endothelin receptor antagonists: Ambrisentan, bosentan, macitentan
  • PDE-5 inhibitors: Sildenafil, tadalafil
  • Soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator: Riociguat
  • Prostacyclin pathway: Epoprostenol (IV), treprostinil (IV/SQ/inhaled), iloprost (inhaled), selexipag (oral)

Combination Therapy: Most patients started on upfront combination therapy (ERA + PDE-5i)

Group 2 (Left Heart): Treat underlying heart failure; PAH-specific drugs may worsen outcomes

Group 3 (Lung Disease): Optimize underlying disease; supplemental Oâ‚‚

Group 4 (CTEPH): Pulmonary endarterectomy (potentially curative); riociguat or balloon angioplasty if inoperable

ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • RHC is required: Echo suggests PH, but diagnosis requires right heart catheterization
  • Group 2 is most common: Left heart disease â€” don't give PAH drugs!
  • V/Q scan for CTEPH: More sensitive than CT; CTEPH is potentially curable with surgery
  • Syncope is ominous: Indicates severe disease with high mortality
  • Avoid pregnancy: Mortality 30-50% in PAH patients
  • Combination therapy upfront: Most Group 1 patients started on dual therapy

331. OBSTRUCTIVE SLEEP APNEA (OSA)

Sleep-Disordered Breathing â€¢ Hypercapnic Respiratory Failure
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Classic Symptoms:

  • Loud snoring with witnessed apneas
  • Excessive daytime sleepiness
  • Morning headaches
  • Unrefreshing sleep, fatigue
  • Nocturia
  • Cognitive impairment, difficulty concentrating

Screening Tools:

  • STOP-BANG: Snoring, Tired, Observed apnea, Pressure (HTN), BMI >35, Age >50, Neck >40cm, Gender male
  • Score â‰¥5: High probability of moderate-severe OSA
  • Epworth Sleepiness Scale: Quantifies daytime sleepiness

Complications:

  • Resistant hypertension
  • Atrial fibrillation (4Ã— increased risk)
  • Stroke, cardiovascular disease
  • Type 2 diabetes
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS)
  • Motor vehicle accidents

Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome (OHS):

  • BMI â‰¥30 + daytime hypercapnia (PaCOâ‚‚ >45) + sleep-disordered breathing
  • After excluding other causes of hypoventilation
  • Higher morbidity/mortality than OSA alone
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Polysomnography (Gold Standard):

  • In-laboratory overnight sleep study
  • Measures AHI, oxygen desaturation, sleep stages, arousals

Home Sleep Apnea Testing (HSAT):

  • Appropriate for high pretest probability, uncomplicated patients
  • May underestimate severity
  • Not appropriate if: CHF, COPD, neuromuscular disease, suspected central apnea

Apnea-Hypopnea Index (AHI) Severity:

  • Mild: 5-15 events/hour
  • Moderate: 15-30 events/hour
  • Severe: >30 events/hour

Additional Workup:

  • ABG if OHS suspected (daytime hypercapnia)
  • TFTs (hypothyroidism can worsen OSA)
  • Consider echo if pulmonary hypertension suspected
TREATMENT

Positive Airway Pressure (First-Line):

  • CPAP: Continuous positive airway pressure; standard for OSA
  • BiPAP: For OHS, COPD-OSA overlap, CPAP intolerance
  • Auto-titrating CPAP (APAP) often used

Alternatives (If CPAP Intolerant):

  • Oral appliances: Mandibular advancement devices; for mild-moderate OSA
  • Positional therapy: If predominantly supine OSA
  • Hypoglossal nerve stimulation (Inspire): For moderate-severe OSA, CPAP failure, BMI <32

Surgical Options:

  • UPPP (uvulopalatopharyngoplasty): Variable success
  • Maxillomandibular advancement
  • Bariatric surgery: If BMI â‰¥35 with comorbidities

Lifestyle Modifications:

  • Weight loss (10% weight loss can significantly improve AHI)
  • Avoid alcohol and sedatives before bed
  • Sleep position optimization

Inpatient Considerations:

  • Continue CPAP/BiPAP during hospitalization
  • Caution with opioids and sedatives
  • Higher risk of difficult intubation
  • Post-operative monitoring for respiratory complications
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Resistant HTN: Screen all patients with resistant hypertension for OSA
  • AF + OSA: Treating OSA improves AF outcomes and cardioversion success
  • OHS is worse: Daytime hypercapnia indicates more severe disease with higher mortality
  • Weight loss helps: 10% weight loss can reduce AHI by 20-50%
  • Continue CPAP inpatient: Bring patient's home device; reduces complications
  • STOP-BANG â‰¥5: High probability of moderate-severe OSA

332. HYPERPARATHYROIDISM

Primary vs Secondary vs Tertiary â€¢ Hypercalcemia Workup
CLASSIFICATION

Primary Hyperparathyroidism:

  • Autonomous PTH overproduction
  • Causes: Single adenoma (85%), hyperplasia (10-15%), carcinoma (<1%)
  • Labs: â†‘ Calcium, â†‘ PTH (or inappropriately normal)

Secondary Hyperparathyroidism:

  • Appropriate PTH response to hypocalcemia
  • Causes: CKD (most common), vitamin D deficiency, malabsorption
  • Labs: â†“ or normal calcium, â†‘ PTH

Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism:

  • Autonomous PTH after prolonged secondary hyperparathyroidism
  • Typically post-renal transplant
  • Labs: â†‘ Calcium, â†‘ PTH
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

"Stones, Bones, Groans, Thrones, and Psychiatric Overtones":

  • Stones: Nephrolithiasis (calcium oxalate/phosphate), nephrocalcinosis
  • Bones: Osteoporosis, osteitis fibrosa cystica (brown tumors), fractures
  • Groans: Abdominal pain, constipation, pancreatitis, peptic ulcer
  • Thrones: Polyuria, polydipsia (nephrogenic DI from hypercalcemia)
  • Psychiatric: Depression, fatigue, cognitive dysfunction, anxiety

Many Patients Asymptomatic: Discovered incidentally on routine labs

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Initial Labs:

  • Serum calcium (correct for albumin or check ionized)
  • Intact PTH
  • 25-OH vitamin D
  • Phosphorus (low/low-normal in primary)
  • 24-hour urine calcium (distinguish from FHH)
  • Creatinine, eGFR

Key Patterns:

  • Primary HPT: â†‘ Ca, â†‘ PTH (or inappropriately normal), â†“ phos, â†‘ urine Ca
  • FHH: â†‘ Ca, â†‘ PTH, LOW urine calcium (Ca/Cr clearance ratio <0.01)
  • Malignancy: â†‘ Ca, â†“ PTH, â†‘ PTHrP

Localization (If Surgery Planned):

  • Sestamibi scan: Identifies adenoma location
  • Neck ultrasound: Complementary to sestamibi
  • 4D-CT: If sestamibi/US negative or discordant

Assess End-Organ Damage:

  • DEXA scan (osteoporosis assessment)
  • Renal imaging (stones, nephrocalcinosis)
  • 24-hour urine calcium, creatinine
TREATMENT

Indications for Parathyroidectomy:

  • Symptomatic disease
  • Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above normal
  • eGFR <60 mL/min
  • T-score â‰¤-2.5 at any site or vertebral fracture
  • Age <50
  • Kidney stones or nephrocalcinosis
  • 24-hour urine calcium >400 mg/day with stone risk

Surgical Options:

  • Minimally invasive parathyroidectomy (if localized adenoma)
  • Bilateral neck exploration (if localization fails or hyperplasia)
  • Intraoperative PTH monitoring

Medical Management (If Surgery Not Pursued):

  • Adequate hydration, avoid thiazides
  • Vitamin D repletion (if deficient)
  • Cinacalcet: Calcimimetic; lowers Ca but not PTH levels; for hypercalcemia control
  • Bisphosphonates: For osteoporosis
  • Monitor: Calcium, creatinine, DEXA annually
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • PTH should be LOW in hypercalcemia: If PTH elevated/normal with high Ca = primary HPT
  • Rule out FHH: Check urine calcium; FHH has low urine Ca (benign, no surgery needed)
  • Surgery is curative: 95%+ cure rate for adenoma with experienced surgeon
  • Hungry bone syndrome: Post-parathyroidectomy hypocalcemia (bones take up calcium)
  • Normocalcemic variant: Normal Ca but elevated PTH â€” early/mild disease
  • MEN syndromes: Consider in young patients or family history

333. HYPOPARATHYROIDISM

PTH Deficiency â€¢ Post-Surgical Hypocalcemia
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Symptoms of Hypocalcemia:

  • Neuromuscular: Paresthesias (perioral, fingertips), muscle cramps, tetany, seizures
  • Cardiac: QTc prolongation, heart failure (severe/chronic)
  • Neuropsychiatric: Anxiety, depression, cognitive impairment
  • Laryngospasm: Medical emergency

Physical Exam Signs:

  • Chvostek sign: Facial twitch when tapping facial nerve (anterior to ear)
  • Trousseau sign: Carpal spasm with BP cuff inflated above systolic for 3 minutes (more specific)

Etiology:

  • Post-surgical (most common): After thyroidectomy, parathyroidectomy, neck dissection
  • Autoimmune: Isolated or part of APS-1 (autoimmune polyglandular syndrome)
  • Genetic: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11 deletion), AIRE mutations
  • Infiltrative: Hemochromatosis, Wilson disease, metastatic disease
  • Radiation
  • Hypomagnesemia: Impairs PTH secretion and action
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Labs:

  • Low calcium (ionized or albumin-corrected)
  • Low or inappropriately normal PTH
  • Elevated phosphorus (PTH normally promotes phosphate excretion)
  • Low 1,25-OH vitamin D (PTH activates vitamin D)
  • Normal 25-OH vitamin D (unless concurrent deficiency)
  • Check magnesium â€” must be normal for PTH to work

ECG: Prolonged QTc interval

24-hour Urine Calcium: Low (due to lack of PTH effect on renal reabsorption)

TREATMENT

Acute Symptomatic Hypocalcemia (Emergency):

  • IV Calcium gluconate: 1-2 g (10-20 mL of 10% solution) over 10-20 minutes
  • Follow with continuous infusion: 0.5-1.5 mg/kg/hr elemental calcium
  • Calcium chloride: More concentrated but irritating; use central line
  • Monitor for arrhythmias during infusion
  • Correct hypomagnesemia (PTH won't work if Mg low)

Chronic Management:

  • Calcium supplements: Calcium carbonate or citrate 1-3 g/day (elemental Ca) in divided doses
  • Active vitamin D: Calcitriol 0.25-2 mcg/day (most important!)
  • Goal: Low-normal calcium (8-8.5 mg/dL), avoid hypercalciuria

PTH Replacement Therapy:

  • Natpara (PTH 1-84): FDA-approved for refractory hypoparathyroidism
  • Reserved for patients not controlled on standard therapy
  • Black box warning: Osteosarcoma risk in animal studies

Monitoring:

  • Serum calcium: Weekly initially, then every 3-6 months
  • 24-hour urine calcium: Annually (hypercalciuria risk â†’ stones)
  • Renal function, phosphorus
  • Renal ultrasound: Periodic screening for nephrocalcinosis

Avoid:

  • Thiazide diuretics (increase calcium, but can cause hypercalcemia on treatment)
  • Loop diuretics (increase calcium excretion)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Calcitriol is key: Without PTH, can't activate vitamin D â€” must give active form
  • Check magnesium: PTH won't work if Mg is low; must replete first
  • Post-thyroidectomy: Most common cause; monitor calcium closely post-op
  • Target low-normal Ca: Higher targets increase hypercalciuria and kidney stone risk
  • Trousseau > Chvostek: Trousseau is more specific for hypocalcemia
  • High phosphorus: Key differentiator from vitamin D deficiency (which has low phosphorus)

334. TRICUSPID REGURGITATION

Right Heart Failure â€¢ Secondary vs Primary
ETIOLOGY

Secondary/Functional TR (Most Common):

  • RV dilation from pulmonary hypertension
  • Left heart disease (MR, MS, LV dysfunction)
  • RV infarction
  • Atrial fibrillation (annular dilation)

Primary/Organic TR:

  • Infective endocarditis: IV drug use, pacemaker/ICD leads
  • Rheumatic heart disease
  • Carcinoid syndrome: Fibrous plaques on valve
  • Ebstein anomaly: Congenital apical displacement of tricuspid valve
  • Trauma: Blunt chest trauma, RV biopsy
  • Drugs: Ergot derivatives, cabergoline, fenfluramine
  • Pacemaker/ICD lead interference
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Symptoms:

  • Often asymptomatic until severe
  • Fatigue, weakness
  • Peripheral edema, ascites
  • Abdominal discomfort (hepatic congestion)
  • Dyspnea (if associated left heart disease)

Physical Exam:

  • Holosystolic murmur: Left sternal border, increases with inspiration (Carvallo sign)
  • JVD: Prominent V waves ("CV" waves in severe TR)
  • Pulsatile liver: Hepatojugular reflux
  • Peripheral edema, ascites
  • RV heave
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Echocardiography:

  • Assess TR severity: Vena contracta, jet area, hepatic vein flow reversal
  • RV size and function
  • RVSP estimation
  • Evaluate left heart and other valves
  • Look for structural abnormalities (endocarditis, leads)

Severity Grading:

  • Mild, Moderate, Severe, Massive, Torrential
  • Severe: Vena contracta â‰¥7 mm, EROA â‰¥40 mmÂ², systolic hepatic vein reversal

Additional Testing:

  • RHC if pulmonary hypertension suspected
  • CT/MRI for complex anatomy
  • Labs: BNP, liver function tests
TREATMENT

Medical Management:

  • Diuretics: Mainstay for right heart failure symptoms
  • Treat underlying cause (pulmonary hypertension, left heart disease)
  • Sodium restriction

Surgical Indications:

  • Severe TR undergoing left-sided valve surgery
  • Severe primary TR with symptoms or RV dilation/dysfunction
  • Progressive RV dilation despite medical therapy

Surgical Options:

  • Annuloplasty: Ring repair for functional TR
  • Valve repair/replacement: For primary TR
  • Bioprosthetic preferred if replacement needed (lower thrombogenicity)

Transcatheter Options (Emerging):

  • TriClip (edge-to-edge repair)
  • Transcatheter valve replacement
  • For high surgical risk patients
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Secondary TR is most common: Fix the left heart disease or pulmonary hypertension first
  • Carvallo sign: Murmur increases with inspiration (right-sided murmurs increase with venous return)
  • Giant V waves: Classic JVP finding in severe TR
  • IVDU + TR + fever: Think right-sided endocarditis
  • Carcinoid TR: Fibrous plaques cause restricted leaflets with regurgitation AND stenosis
  • Repair at time of left heart surgery: Address significant TR when doing mitral/aortic surgery

335. LONG QT SYNDROME

QTc Prolongation â€¢ Torsades de Pointes Risk
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: QTc >450 ms in men, >460 ms in women (some use >470/480 ms for diagnosis)

Types:

  • Congenital LQTS: Ion channel mutations (17 subtypes identified)
    • LQT1: KCNQ1 â€” triggered by exercise (especially swimming)
    • LQT2: KCNH2 â€” triggered by emotional stress, auditory stimuli
    • LQT3: SCN5A â€” events during rest/sleep
  • Acquired LQTS: Drugs, electrolytes, structural heart disease

Symptoms:

  • Syncope (from torsades)
  • Seizures (often misdiagnosed as epilepsy)
  • Sudden cardiac death
  • Palpitations
  • May be asymptomatic

Acquired Causes:

  • Drugs (CredibleMeds.org):
    • Antiarrhythmics: Sotalol, dofetilide, amiodarone, procainamide
    • Antibiotics: Fluoroquinolones, macrolides, azoles
    • Antipsychotics: Haloperidol, ziprasidone, thioridazine
    • Antidepressants: TCAs, citalopram
    • Antiemetics: Ondansetron, droperidol
    • Others: Methadone, hydroxychloroquine
  • Electrolytes: Hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia
  • Bradycardia
  • Structural: LVH, cardiomyopathy, myocardial ischemia
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

ECG:

  • Measure QTc (Bazett formula: QTc = QT/âˆšRR)
  • T-wave morphology (notched T waves in LQT2)
  • Look for TWA (T-wave alternans)

Schwartz Score (Congenital LQTS):

  • QTc, T-wave morphology, clinical history, family history
  • â‰¥3.5 points: High probability

Additional Testing:

  • Electrolytes (K, Mg, Ca)
  • Medication review
  • Exercise stress testing (paradoxical QT prolongation in LQT1)
  • Genetic testing (if congenital suspected)
  • Family screening with ECG
TREATMENT

Acute Torsades de Pointes:

  • IV Magnesium: 2 g IV over 2-5 minutes (first-line even if Mg normal)
  • Correct hypokalemia: Target K >4.0 mEq/L
  • Overdrive pacing: Temporary pacing to shorten QT (rate 90-110)
  • Isoproterenol: If pacing unavailable (increases HR)
  • Defibrillation: If unstable/pulseless
  • Stop QT-prolonging drugs

Congenital LQTS â€” Long-Term:

  • Beta-blockers: First-line for LQT1 and LQT2 (nadolol or propranolol preferred)
  • Avoid triggers: Strenuous exercise in LQT1, startle/emotional stress in LQT2
  • ICD: Secondary prevention (survived arrest), high-risk patients, breakthrough events on beta-blockers
  • Left cardiac sympathetic denervation: Refractory cases

Acquired LQTS:

  • Remove/avoid offending drugs
  • Correct electrolytes
  • Treat underlying condition
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Magnesium first for torsades: Give 2 g IV even if Mg level is normal
  • LQT1 = swimming: Exercise-triggered, responds well to beta-blockers
  • LQT2 = alarm clocks: Auditory startle trigger
  • LQT3 = sleep: Events at rest; may need pacemaker/ICD, mexiletine
  • Check CredibleMeds.org: Comprehensive list of QT-prolonging drugs
  • Keep K >4.0: Low K + QT drug = torsades waiting to happen

336. BRUGADA SYNDROME

Inherited Arrhythmia Syndrome â€¢ Coved ST Elevation
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Demographics:

  • Male predominance (8:1)
  • Asian descent (especially Southeast Asian)
  • Typical onset: 30s-40s

Symptoms:

  • Syncope (from polymorphic VT/VF)
  • Sudden cardiac death (often during sleep or rest)
  • Palpitations
  • Many patients asymptomatic

Triggers:

  • Fever (can unmask or worsen pattern)
  • Vagal stimulation, large meals
  • Cocaine, alcohol
  • Certain drugs (sodium channel blockers, psychotropics)

Genetics: SCN5A mutations (sodium channel) in ~20-30%; autosomal dominant

ECG PATTERNS

Type 1 (Diagnostic):

  • "Coved" ST elevation â‰¥2 mm in V1-V3
  • Followed by inverted T wave
  • This is the only diagnostic pattern

Type 2 (Suggestive but Not Diagnostic):

  • "Saddleback" ST elevation â‰¥0.5 mm in V1-V3
  • Positive or biphasic T wave

ECG Tips:

  • Place V1-V2 in higher intercostal spaces (2nd-3rd) if standard ECG normal but suspicion high
  • Pattern may be intermittent
  • Fever can provoke Type 1 pattern

Drug Challenge (Provocative Testing):

  • Ajmaline, flecainide, or procainamide
  • Positive if Type 1 pattern appears
  • Perform in monitored setting
DIAGNOSIS & RISK STRATIFICATION

Diagnostic Criteria:

  • Spontaneous or drug-induced Type 1 pattern PLUS
  • One of: Documented VF/polymorphic VT, syncope, family history SCD <45, or Type 1 ECG in family member

High-Risk Features:

  • Survived cardiac arrest
  • Syncope (presumed arrhythmic)
  • Spontaneous Type 1 pattern (vs drug-induced)
  • Inducible VF on EP study (controversial)

Family Screening: ECG for first-degree relatives; genetic testing if mutation identified

TREATMENT

ICD (Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator):

  • Class I: Prior cardiac arrest, documented sustained VT
  • Class IIa: Spontaneous Type 1 pattern with syncope
  • Class IIb: Inducible VF on EP study (controversial)

Medical Therapy:

  • Quinidine: May prevent arrhythmias; used as adjunct or if ICD not feasible
  • Isoproterenol: For electrical storm

Catheter Ablation:

  • Epicardial ablation of arrhythmogenic substrate
  • For recurrent VF despite ICD

Lifestyle & Avoidance:

  • Avoid drugs that worsen Brugada: www.brugadadrugs.org
  • Treat fever aggressively (acetaminophen)
  • Avoid excessive alcohol
  • Avoid large meals (vagal stimulation)
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Coved Type 1 is diagnostic: Saddleback (Type 2) is NOT diagnostic alone
  • Fever uncovers Brugada: Febrile patients may develop Type 1 pattern â€” treat fever aggressively
  • Asian males: Higher prevalence in Southeast Asian populations
  • Events at rest/sleep: Unlike LQT1 (exercise-triggered)
  • High leads may help: Try V1-V2 in 2nd-3rd intercostal space if suspicious but normal ECG
  • BrugadaDrugs.org: List of drugs to avoid in Brugada patients

337. VENTILATOR-ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA (VAP)

ICU-Acquired Pneumonia â€¢ Prevention Bundles
DEFINITION & EPIDEMIOLOGY

Definition: Pneumonia occurring >48 hours after endotracheal intubation

Incidence: 5-15% of mechanically ventilated patients; risk increases with duration of ventilation

Mortality: Attributable mortality 10-15%; increases ICU stay by 7-9 days

Risk Factors:

  • Prolonged mechanical ventilation
  • Supine positioning
  • Heavy sedation, paralysis
  • Reintubation
  • Prior antibiotic exposure
  • Aspiration
  • ARDS, COPD, immunosuppression

Pathogenesis: Microaspiration of oropharyngeal secretions around ETT cuff; biofilm on ETT

MICROBIOLOGY

Early VAP (<5 days):

  • S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, MSSA
  • Enteric gram-negatives

Late VAP (â‰¥5 days):

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • MRSA
  • Acinetobacter
  • ESBL-producing Enterobacteriaceae
  • Stenotrophomonas maltophilia

MDR Risk Factors:

  • Prior IV antibiotics within 90 days
  • â‰¥5 days hospitalization before VAP
  • Septic shock at time of VAP
  • ARDS preceding VAP
  • Acute renal replacement therapy before VAP
DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP

Clinical Suspicion (All Present):

  • New/progressive infiltrate on CXR
  • Fever (>38Â°C) or hypothermia
  • Leukocytosis or leukopenia
  • Purulent secretions
  • Decline in oxygenation

Respiratory Sampling (Before Antibiotics if Possible):

  • Endotracheal aspirate (ETA): Easier to obtain; semi-quantitative
  • Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL): More specific; threshold â‰¥10â´ CFU/mL
  • Protected specimen brush (PSB): Threshold â‰¥10Â³ CFU/mL

Clinical Pulmonary Infection Score (CPIS):

  • Combines temperature, WBC, secretions, oxygenation, CXR, culture
  • Score >6 suggests VAP
  • Limited sensitivity/specificity; not routinely used for diagnosis

Blood Cultures: Obtain before antibiotics; positive in 10-25%

Biomarkers: Procalcitonin may help guide antibiotic duration (not diagnosis)

TREATMENT

Empiric Therapy â€” Low MDR Risk:

  • Piperacillin-tazobactam OR
  • Cefepime OR
  • Levofloxacin OR
  • Meropenem (if local ESBL prevalence high)

Empiric Therapy â€” High MDR Risk:

  • Anti-pseudomonal coverage (choose 2 from different classes):
    • Piperacillin-tazobactam, cefepime, ceftazidime, carbapenem, aztreonam
    • PLUS fluoroquinolone (cipro/levo) OR aminoglycoside
  • Add MRSA coverage: Vancomycin or linezolid

De-escalation:

  • Narrow therapy based on culture results (typically within 48-72h)
  • Stop MRSA coverage if cultures negative

Duration:

  • 7 days for most VAP (non-fermenting GNRs may need longer)
  • Procalcitonin-guided discontinuation reduces antibiotic exposure
PREVENTION (VAP Bundle)
  • Head of bed elevation 30-45Â°
  • Daily sedation interruption ("sedation vacation")
  • Daily assessment of readiness to extubate
  • DVT prophylaxis
  • Stress ulcer prophylaxis (though may increase VAP risk)
  • Oral care with chlorhexidine (0.12% twice daily)
  • Subglottic secretion drainage (specialized ETT)
  • Avoid unnecessary intubation/reintubation
  • Maintain ETT cuff pressure 20-30 cm Hâ‚‚O
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • Duration matters: Late VAP (â‰¥5 days) needs broader MDR coverage
  • 7 days is enough: Shorter courses work for most VAP
  • De-escalate aggressively: Narrow to culture results within 48-72h
  • Bundle compliance: VAP prevention bundles reduce incidence by 50%+
  • Extubation is prevention: Every day on vent increases VAP risk
  • Don't overdiagnose: Many CXR infiltrates in ICU are not VAP (atelectasis, CHF, ARDS)

338. FAT EMBOLISM SYNDROME

Post-Fracture Complication â€¢ Gurd Criteria
CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Definition: Multi-system dysfunction (pulmonary, neurologic, dermatologic) following fat emboli, typically after long bone fractures

Timeline:

  • Typically 24-72 hours after injury/surgery
  • Rarely presents immediately

Classic Triad:

  • Respiratory distress: Hypoxemia, tachypnea, ARDS-like picture
  • Neurologic changes: Confusion, agitation, altered consciousness, seizures
  • Petechial rash: Upper body (chest, axillae, neck, conjunctivae) â€” pathognomonic but present in only 20-50%

Risk Factors:

  • Long bone fractures (femur > tibia)
  • Pelvic fractures
  • Multiple fractures
  • Orthopedic procedures: Intramedullary nailing, arthroplasty
  • Non-traumatic: Pancreatitis, liposuction, bone marrow transplant, sickle cell crisis (rare)

Pathophysiology:

  • Fat globules embolize to pulmonary circulation â†’ inflammatory cascade
  • Mechanical obstruction + toxic free fatty acid effects
  • Systemic inflammation â†’ multiorgan dysfunction
DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA

Gurd Criteria (Need 1 Major + 4 Minor OR 2 Major):

Major Criteria:

  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms + bilateral infiltrates
  • CNS signs (unrelated to trauma or other cause)

Minor Criteria:

  • Tachycardia >110 bpm
  • Fever >38.5Â°C
  • Retinal fat or petechiae on fundoscopy
  • Fat in urine
  • Sudden unexplained drop in Hct or platelets
  • Elevated ESR
  • Fat globules in sputum

Laboratory Findings:

  • Thrombocytopenia (common)
  • Anemia (hemolysis, bone marrow suppression)
  • Hypoxemia (A-a gradient elevated)
  • Elevated lipase (variable)

Imaging:

  • CXR: Bilateral alveolar infiltrates ("snowstorm" appearance)
  • CT chest: Ground-glass opacities, nodular opacities
  • MRI brain: Multiple hyperintense lesions on T2/FLAIR ("starfield" pattern) â€” sensitive but not specific
TREATMENT

Primarily Supportive:

  • Respiratory support: Oxygen, mechanical ventilation (lung-protective strategies)
  • Hemodynamic support: IV fluids, vasopressors if needed
  • Early fracture fixation: Reduces ongoing fat embolism (within 24h if possible)

Controversial/Unproven Therapies:

  • Corticosteroids: Some studies suggest benefit in prophylaxis; no clear benefit once established
  • Heparin: Theoretical benefit (stimulates lipase); not routinely used
  • Albumin: May bind free fatty acids; unproven

Prevention:

  • Early surgical stabilization of long bone fractures (<24h)
  • Gentle surgical technique (minimize intramedullary pressure)
  • Avoid aggressive volume resuscitation with crystalloids alone
  • Prophylactic corticosteroids? (methylprednisolone 7.5 mg/kg q8h Ã— 3 doses) â€” data mixed

Prognosis:

  • Mortality 5-15% with supportive care
  • Most survivors have complete neurologic recovery
  • ARDS may require prolonged ventilation
ðŸ”‘ TEACHING PEARLS
  • 24-72 hour delay: FES doesn't present immediately â€” watch for it in days following fracture
  • Petechiae = pathognomonic: But only present in 20-50%; upper body distribution
  • Think FES: Post-fracture patient with unexplained hypoxia, confusion, and petechiae
  • Early fixation prevents: Stabilize long bone fractures within 24h to reduce risk
  • Thrombocytopenia is common: Unexplained platelet drop post-fracture should raise suspicion
  • Supportive care works: Most patients recover fully with appropriate respiratory support

Internal Medicine Clinical Reference Guide

338 Essential Conditions for Hospital Medicine

BUILD #27

For educational purposes only. Always use clinical judgment and consult current guidelines.
